title: Dollar Hits 132.10 Yen; Japan Acts
description: The dollar opened at a record low today for a second straight day, but its fall was checked by intervention by the Bank of Japan.

description: Richard Fitzpatrick has become a full-time couch potato, courtesy of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

description: American Express Co. plans to introduce a money transfer service in January called Moneygram that will enable customers to send up to $5,000 in cash within minutes.

title: Business and Health; Mental-Health Costs Surge
description: PSYCHIATRISTS have long been aware that bad news comes in clusters for people suffering from mental-health ailments. For employers, too, the dark clouds often multiply as they struggle with the problems of mentally ill workers, the health-care system and cost containment.

description: b-Includes a $4,100,000 charge because of the reduction of expansion plans, primarily in New York City. c-Net income

title: New York, New York: Artists Persist
description: James Fitzsimmons eats candy bars for lunch because they are cheaper than a sandwich, thinks twice about parting with $1 for a subway ride and has rid his vocabulary of the word ''taxi.''

title: Kirkland's Teamster Decision: Pulling a Meany
description: When Lane Kirkland replaced George Meany as head of the A.F.L-C.I.O. nearly a decade ago, more than a few unionists wondered whether the new president would ever personify ''big labor'' in the style of Mr. Meany, with his bulldog scowl, omnipresent cigar and irascible temperament.

title: Hiring Burglars and 'Stealing' Buildings: Tales of Father Ritter
description: In his early efforts to shelter run-away youths, the Rev. Bruce Ritter admits that he forced several addicts out of their apartments by paying burglars to steal their clothes, furniture and plumbing. Then he moved in homeless youngsters.

title: Surnames, Their Past, Present and Future
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Take Steps to Protect Ozone
description: New, legally binding restrictions on the use of chemicals now widely believed to be depleting the earth's ozone layer, which screens out harmful radiation from the sun, will be proposed Tuesday by the Federal Government.

title: Lunar Tug May Cause Magnetism Of the Earth
description: TWO scientists at the University of Georgia have proposed that the Moon may be responsible for the Earth's magnetic field. Lunar gravity, they say, tugs the solid inner core of the Earth away from the planet's center point, much as the Moon pulls the oceans, producing tides.

title: Degas 'Laundry Maids' Sells for $13.7 Million
description: Edgar Degas's ''Laundry Maids,'' an 1870's masterpiece that has been in the same collection since 1895, was sold last night at Christie's in London for $13.7 million, a record at auction for a work by the artist.

title: Turner, Time And NBC Meet
description: Top officials of NBC, the Turner Broadcasting System and Time Inc. met in New York yesterday to discuss NBC's possible investment in Turner Broadcasting, according to executives at the companies.

title: Stake for Japanese In Paine Webber
description: The Yasuda Mutual Life Insurance Company, one of the largest life insurance concerns in Japan, agreed yesterday to pay $300 million for an equity stake of up to 25 percent in Paine Webber Group Inc., the securities firm.

title: Tiny Pacific Palau Has Good Reason to Worry
description: To the Editor:

description: The Economy

title: AMERICAN HOME SHIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $730,000 and $1,670,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes tax credits of $180,000 for the quarter and $539,000 for the 9 months.

title: HEALTH MANAGEMENT ASSOCITES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain related to the termination of two pension plans. The after-tax gain approximated $106,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Included about $146,000, or 3 cents a share, related to elimination of the investment tax credit and $106,000, or 2 cents a share, credit related to other items partially offset by a writedown of certain investments.

title: Court to Review Ruling On Price of Natural Gas
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to consider letting the Reagan Administration stop regulating some natural gas prices, a move Government lawyers say could save consumers as much as $100 million a year.

title: Primerica to Sell A Marketing Unit
description: The Primerica Corporation has agreed to sell its direct marketing subsidiary, Looart Press Inc., to De Luxe Check Printers Inc. of St. Paul. Primerica said its proceeds from the sale would be about $150 million, resulting in an after-tax gain of about $35 million, or 65 cents a share. It said the transaction was scheduled to be completed near year-end. The proceeds will be used by Primerica to reduce debt.

title: Market Place; Analysts Await Move on Trade
description: PESSIMISM hung over the stock market as prices took another plunge yesterday, but most analysts shied away from predicting that investors should brace for a collapse as steep as the 508-point fall last Oct. 19.

title: Sports People; Charges Dropped
description: Murder charges against Derrick Fenner, the former North Carolina football star, were dropped yesterday, but prosecutors in Upper Marlboro, Md., said they would go ahead with a separate drug and weapons case against him. Fenner was arrested in June in connection with the fatal shooting in May of Marcellus Leach, 19, in what the police called a turf war between rival drug-dealing factions. In a written statement released yesterday, Alexander Williams, a state's attorney for Prince George's County, said that investigators had uncovered substantial evidence to indicate that Fenner was not present at the time of the murder.

title: Camera Test Starts Today For Courts
description: After years of hesitation in New York State's legal system, the courts in New York City and four upstate counties will step tentatively into the electronic age today when cameras are allowed for the first time in 50 years during sentencings, trials and testimony.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Is Said to Study Gotti Acquittal
description: A Federal grand jury is looking into whether an attempt was made to improperly influence a jury that eventually acquitted John Gotti, the reputed boss of the Gambino crime family, and six co-defendants of racketeering and conspiracy charges, people familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: Chirac Seeking Warmer Ties to Iran
description: Emboldened by the end of a five-month diplomatic standoff with Iran, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac is seeking to hasten a process of ''normalization'' with Teheran and free three remaining French hostages in Lebanon, Government officials say.

title: Liuqiying Journal; In the Good Earth, Did Envy, Too, Bear Fruit?
description: Yin Yongcheng, a beige snap-brim cap planted firmly on his head, walked among his orange trees, their fruit harvested now, and wondered about the future.

title: Mattingly Close To 3-Year Deal
description: While the Mets steadfastly hold the contract line at one year for Dwight Gooden, the Yankees are on the verge of signing Don Mattingly to a three-year contract worth $6.7 million.

title: Dr. Inge Bogner, Psychiatrist, 77
description: Dr. Inge Bogner, a New York psychiatrist for 40 years, died last Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a brief illness. She was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

When Should Parody Be Punishable?
description: LEAD: Does the press have a constitutional right to embarrass, insult and offend? Does a person who is embarrassed, insulted and offended by the press have any legal remedies?

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Review Cable TV Ruling
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to consider giving local governments the power to regulate the quality of cable television signals.

title: Stop the School 'Extortion'
description: Can New York City's Board of Education do anything right? It has a dismal record on counting dropouts. It stands by while hundreds of homeless children also go school-less. It has allowed the search for a chancellor to drag on for months. The board badly needs a victory, and a prime opportunity now presents itself: contract negotiations with school custodians.

title: NATIONWIDE VOTE IN POLAND REJECTS A PARTY PROPOSAL
description: The Polish Government today acknowledged defeat in Sunday's national referendum to obtain public approval for a severe economic austerity program that also promised some political changes.

description: THE subject is not new; neither is the point of view.

description: Norway withdrew its candidate for the top political job in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization today, ending an embarrassing tussle within the alliance and clearing the way for Defense Minister Manfred Worner to become the first West German secretary general of NATO.

description: Triumphant amid their tears, mourners in a South Side church here offered thanks today for Harold Washington, a black man who made it to the mountaintop.

description: ''MAIN STREET'' seems a shade more serious today than usual.

description: Growing up in Finland, Mikko Makela was consumed by dual passions, happily enveloped like countless young athletes in a love of two sports. But like many sons of legendary fathers, Makela realized that he ultimately would have only one allegiance.

description: EVERYBODY is really somebody else. The waiter who served you last night is really a Shakespearean actor; your dentist is surely a sculptor in her heart, and some airline pilots are obviously talk-show hosts in their souls.

title: Who Can Protect the Haitians?
description: When Sunday's election in Haiti was voided, it shattered hopes for democracy and denied Haitians their first chance in 30 years to elect a President. The culprits are Gen. Henri Namphy's junta, and the murderous Tontons Macoute thugs whose rampages gave the junta the pretext it needed to call off the vote.

The company said the year-ago 9 months includes a $21.6 million writedown of the carrying value of oil and gas assets.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs in use in the United States last week rose by nine, to 1,161, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. A year ago, the count totaled 954. The Houston-based oil tool maker tallies the number of rigs exploring for oil, and not rigs producing oil.

description: As investigators sift through mountains of data in an attempt to understand the cause of the mid-October collapse of the stock market, the influence of so-called portfolio insurance has remained in the spotlight.

description: Scott Turow, the author of the best-selling novel ''Presumed Innocent,'' has been strongly chastised by a Federal appeals court for his actions as an Assistant United States Attorney in Chicago in the early 1980's.

title: Advertising; In the Nile Valley, It's the Pyramids
description: With the exception of the headline and illustration, the ads in the campaign for the new Helmsley Palace hotel will be pretty much alike. And even the headlines will change very little.

title: Prime Minister of Turkey Is Re-elected
description: Prime Minister Turgut Ozal, architect of Turkey's economic surge and avowed custodian of its political stability, has been returned to power with an increased majority in the expanded, 450-seat Parliament.

description: LEAD: Congress and the President recently cobbled together a dubious budget compromise to meet the Gramm-Rudman targets, but hardly anyone is satisfied with the package. If Congress ever intends to get serious about reducing the deficit, the Democrats need to stop reflexively defending every domestic program.

title: No Ground Broken

title: Williams Took Some Giant Missteps
description: In 1983, Perry Williams spent his rookie season on injured reserve. Since 1984, while other members of the Giants' secondary have been burned by opponents' passes, Williams has quietly become a solid right cornerback who made few errors.

title: Two Rikers Island Inmates Caught And a Third Is Sought in Escapes
description: Two men attempting to escape from a maximum security unit on Rikers Island were captured yesterday morning on the grounds of the prison complex when a patrol dog detected their scent, the authorities said.

title: Ruling on Writer Could Choke Flow of Information
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance: 'Sanctus,' From Randy Warshaw
description: THIS has been a good creative year for Randy Warshaw. In the spring, he choreographed the swirling ''Fragile Anchor.'' Now he has given us ''Sanctus,'' the attractive new work the Randy Warshaw Dance Company presented Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater on a program with ''Fragile Anchor.''

title: J. Howard Pyle Dead; Ex-Arizona Governor
description: J. Howard Pyle, Governor of Arizona from 1951 to 1955 and an aide to President Eisenhower, died here Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: Choh Hao Li, Biochemist, Is Dead; Isolated Human Growth Hormone
description: Dr. Choh Hao Li, a biochemist who was a leading researcher in the functions of the pituitary gland, died of cancer of the pharynx Saturday at a hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived in Berkeley.

title: INSIDE
description: James Baldwin Is Dead

title: Lawmakers Meet Cuomo to Avoid Special Session
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders met today for the first time in four months and agreed to try to avoid convening a special session of the Legislature this year. If they are successful, 1987 would be the first year since 1972 in which lawmakers did not have to reconvene in Albany after the end of their regular annual session.

title: Jackson Tramples Seahawks
description: Bo Jackson, rushing for a team-record 221 yards and scoring three touchdowns, led the Los Angeles Raiders to a 37-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks tonight.

title: Father of Youth In Queens Case Defends His Son
description: The father of a white teen-ager charged with murder in the Howard Beach case testified yesterday that his son had told him two days after the incident, ''Daddy, I didn't do anything.''

title: Judge Denies Request To Ban Child Agency
description: A State Supreme Court justice refused to-day to remove the gun-carrying and ar-rest powers of the Society for the Pre-vention of Cruelty to Children, but im-posed limited restraints on the agency.

title: Deaver Role Is Seen in a Meeting On Contract for Presidential Jet
description: Witnesses testified today that Michael K. Deaver persuaded one of his former White House associates to convene a White House committee that the Boeing Company believed would help it clinch a $300 million contract to build two new Presidential airplanes.

title: Christian Pop Is Gaining Fans
description: Angelic the musicians are not, in their skin-tight black-and-yellow Spandex. And no one would mistake their blaring guitars and insistent percussion for choir music, but the ''heavenly metal'' rock group Stryper is part of a growing contingent of Christians preaching salvation in the vernacular of popular music.

title: Atrocity's Aftermath: Haitian Vows, 'Never Again'
description: At the Ecole Argentine de Bellegarde, the school and polling station where at least 15 voters were killed in a massacre Sunday, several abandoned sandals lay stuck in pools of dried blood.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. HAS NEW PLAN FOR WEAPONS CUTS
description: The United States has developed a new negotiating approach on conventional arms that would require Soviet-bloc nations to reduce the number of their tanks and artillery pieces to levels of that of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization - a cut of more than 50 percent.

title: Scholar's 40's Articles Debated
description: In a finding that has stunned scholars, a Yale professor revered as one of the most brilliant intellectuals of his generation wrote for an anti-Semitic, pro-Nazi newspaper in Belgium during World War II, documents have disclosed.

title: Calling All Sources
description: One of the more prestigious and powerful labels one can wear in Washington is that of ''reliable source.'' Establishing oneself as an expert on a particular subject can mean guest spots on television, higher lecture fees and considerable propaganda value - promoting the party line, as it were, for political or ideological purposes.

title: More Workers For Abuse Calls
description: New York State will add 18 workers at its child-abuse hot line to deal with a sharp increase in the number of calls since the death of 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg last month, Governor Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Phoenix Named As Nascar Site
description: Phoenix International Raceway, which has served as host for regional Nascar races in past years, will be the site of a national Nascar race next Nov. 6, after Riverside International Raceway in California is razed, officials said today.

title: Woman in Right-to-Die Case Dies After Removal of Tube
description: The 67-year-old woman whose right-to-die case was the subject of a landmark State Supreme Court ruling last summer, died last week and was buried today, her lawyer said.

title: Twins to Reopen Stadium Lease
description: The Minnesota Twins, claiming net operating losses of $22.79 million over the last three seasons, are exercising their option to terminate the team's lease with the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome, the Twins' president, Jerry Bell, said today. The Twins, the 1987 World Series champions, want to negotiate a new lease for the 1989 season, Bell said.

title: Stage: Texas 'Reunion'
description: CELESTE WALKER'S ''Reunion in Bartersville'' may come to a strange end, but that happens only in the last minute of the play, and who cares? For the previous two hours the plot has taken so many startling turns and the characters have squeezed so many laughs out of every surprise and every line that it hardly matters how it all turns out.

title: Dust May Hide Planets of 3 Stars
description: ASTRONOMERS have found evidence of cleared regions in the dust clouds surrounding three nearby stars, lending further support to the growing belief that planet-sized objects are orbiting stars other than the Sun.

title: Michigan State Senator Guilty in Drug Case
description: Basil Brown, the senior member of the State Senate, pleaded guilty today to two felony drug charges.

title: Post at Time Unit Filled After 3 Years
description: E.Thayer Bigelow Jr., Time Inc.'s chief financial officer, was named yesterday as president of Time's American Television and Communications Corporation, the nation's second-largest operator of cable television systems.

title: Fannie Mae to Set Dual Issue's Rates
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to announce the interest rates today for a two-part debenture offering totaling $1.5 billion.

title: Sports People; White Re-Retires
description: Jo Jo White's comeback at age 41 with the Topeka Sizzlers of the Continental Basketball League, ended yesterday, 26 days after it began. White, a former star with the University of Kansas and the Boston Celtics, said he simply did not have the legs to keep up with younger players and felt it was best to retire. White will leave the team not only as a player, but also as an assistant coach. ''Jo Jo White has never been one to kid himself,'' White said. In five games with the Sizzlers, White averaged 5.6 points a game, despite playing an average of more than 24 minutes a game.

title: Ireland's Abbey Theater To Appear in Manhattan
description: The Abbey Theater will present ''The Great Hunger,'' a drama by Tom MacIntyre set in 19th-century rural Ireland, in March at the Triplex Theater in lower Manhattan. The company has not appeared in New York since 1976, when it presented ''The Plough and the Stars'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Volcker Plea In GATT Talk
description: Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the recent dramatic declines in stock markets worldwide showed the need for large countries to better coordinate their economic policies.

title: AIRGAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a $167,000 credit from the repurchase of a bond at discount.

title: Woman Slain at E. 73d St. House
description: A 48-year-old Manhattan woman was found shot and stabbed to death yesterday in an Upper East Side town house she co-owned. The police said the motive for the slaying was unclear.

title: Advertising; Four Rise at B.J.K.&E.
description: Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt has named four new executive vice presidents on the corporate level. All former senior vice presidents, they are Eugene Bartley, general manager; Joanne Conforti, human resources director; Michael Silverstein, marketing director, and Valentine Zammit, finance and administration.

title: Russians to See Interview
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's interview with NBC News is to be broadcast on Soviet television and published in full the Soviet press this week, a Soviet spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said today.

title: In Quick Reversal, Moynihan Says No to Favorite-Son Bid
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who said Sunday that he would consider running as a favorite-son candidate in the New York Democratic Presidential primary, reversed himself today and said that he had would not pursue it.

title: After Apology, Jersey Authority Votes to Raise Toll
description: The New Jersey Highway Authority apologized to the public today and then voted a second time to increase tolls on the Garden State Parkway to 50 cents from 25 cents.

title: When School Improvements Bypass the Poor
description: THE movement for educational change is bypassing many poor children, a business leader and a top educator assert, and the consequences could threaten both the children's and the nation's future.

title: Dow Drops 76.93 Points, To 1,833.55
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday amid continuing concern over the apparently unbridled fall in the dollar.

title: Advertising; J. Walter Thompson Donates Its Archives
description: The 123-year-old J. Walter Thompson Company has announced that it has donated its archives of more than three million items - advertising for all media as well as taped interviews - to Duke University.

title: Thomson McKinnon Promotes 3 Executives
description: J.Ronald Morgan, the president and chief operating officer of Thomson McKinnon Inc. for nearly three years, was named chairman and chief executive yesterday to replace John J. Maloney, who is retiring. Thomson McKinnon Inc. is the parent of Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., the nation's 17th-largest brokerage.

title: Silent Film Trio
description: A triple-bill of silent films, featuring Laurel and Hardy, Nazimova and Catherine Hessling, is to be shown on Dec. 9 at 7 and 9 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. The films are ''Big Business'' (1929) with Laurel and Hardy; ''Salome'' (1922) with Nazimova, and ''The Little Match Girl'' (1928), directed by Jean Renoir and featuring Catherine Hessling. Piano music, composed and performed by Lee Erwin, is to be featured at the screenings. Tickets are $5. Information: 662-2133.

title: COMNET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Giants Were Felled By a Long String of Interlocking Woes
description: A year ago, the Giants were winning week after week: nine straight victories to finish the regular season, three straight in the playoffs. The final victory came in Super Bowl XXI and crowned the Giants as the champions of professional football.

title: Oil-Import Fee Is a Cure Worse Than the Malady
description: To the Editor:

title: Woolridge Out 4 Weeks
description: The Nets, who have lost their last five games, received some bad news yesterday. Orlando Woolridge, New Jersey's leading scorer last season with an average of 20.7 points a game, has a broken toe.

title: WASHINGTON SEEMS CONTENT OVER FALL STOCK PRICES ALSO DROP
description: The dollar fell to new lows today, amid conjecture by experts that the Reagan Administration was content with the currency's recent slide.

title: TRUE OR FALSE? THE ANATOMY OF A SMILE
description: THE false smile, that ubiquitous social lubricant, has been unmasked by new research that has identified the different specific muscle patterns in smiles that reflect true delight and those that mask displeasure.

title: Pick a Catalogue
description: Any number of America's largest museums, from Washington's Smithsonian to Boston's Fine Arts and New York's Metropolitan, mail out elaborate Christmas catalogues featuring wares for sale from their museum stores.

title: Speeches Offering Insight Into Judge Kennedy
description: Speeches written over the years by Judge Anthony M. Kennedy show that he has expressed cautious skepticism about whether the Constitution protects sexual privacy and other rights not actually spelled out in the text.

title: Ifint-Incom To Be Acquired
description: Imo Delaval Inc. said today that it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Ifint-Incom Inc., the holding company for Incom International Inc., for $166.6 million in cash and the assumption of about $34 million in debt.

title: Strong Earthquake Jolts Alaska Coast; Little Damage Seen
description: A major offshore earthquake jolted south-central Alaska today, prompting thousands of people to flee low-lying coastal areas for the second time in two weeks.

title: Darkening Malaysian Democracy
description: Malaysia has been a singular favorite of diplomats, travelers and investors, a stable and flourishing country with regular elections and lively public debate. But corruption and ethnic tensions, manageable in boom times, are now festering and the Government has responded with drearily familiar steps: detention without trial, a ban on rallies, tightened secrecy.

title: Autolatina Sees Deficit
description: Autolatina, South America's biggest auto maker, which has sued the Brazilian Government seeking eased price controls, said today that it expected widening losses in 1987 of $200 million to $300 million. Last year Autolatina, which produces Ford and Volkswagen vehicles in Brazil and Argentina, lost $78 million. The company dominates Sao Paulo's motor industry and is the biggest industrial multinational concern in Brazil. The company defied the Government at the beginning of the month when it increased its prices by up to 28 percent, instead of the authorized 16.7 percent.

title: Poll Finds Reagan Support Down But Democrats Still Lacking Fire
description: President Reagan's popularity is sliding and so is support for the Republican Party, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: James Baldwin, the Writer, Dies in France at 63
description: James Baldwin, whose passionate, intensely personal essays in the 1950's and 60's on racial discrimination in America helped break down the nation's color barrier, died of cancer last night at his home in southern France. He was 63 years old.

description: The Players Association and the National Football League plan to resume contract talks that broke off Oct. 11 in the midst of a strike that has created an imbalanced season.

title: Joseph S. Stout Jr., Lawyer, 45
description: Joseph S. Stout Jr., a lawyer, died, apparently of a stroke, on Sunday in Canada at Toronto Western Hospital. He was 45 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

description: Roger A. Manvell, a professor of film at the Boston University College of Communications and a biographer and screenwriter, died of a stroke this morning at Beverly Hospital, in Beverly, Mass. He was 78 years old.

description: The Cubans who held control of the Federal detention center here for eight days gained little in the settlement they signed Sunday after releasing 26 hostages, some Cuban sympathizers said today.

description: A GEORGIA physicist has detected signs of superconductivity in a new material at temperatures up to 440 degrees Fahrenheit, far warmer than any substance reported so far.

description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in July 1987. The company said the latest quarter results were impacted by the costs of operating 106 additional stores, a 25 percent increase over a year earlier.

title: Data Called Misleading In Rating Contraceptives
description: THE available data on the comparative effectiveness of different contraceptives is misleading and only marginally useful in helping people choose which method to use, according to a new study and a growing number of health experts.

title: Girl Who Disappeared in 1984 Is Found Dead
description: The remains of a 12-year-old Queens girl who disappeared on July 16, 1984, after going to a Flushing bank to make a deposit for her parents, were found on Thanksgiving in a shallow grave in Yorktown, N.Y., the authorities reported last night.

title: Singer Committed To Sale or Merger
description: The Singer Company said it wants to be bought or merged with another company by the end of the year. Last week Singer said it was talking with a number of potential suitors, domestic and international, in an attempt to find an offer more inviting than the bid of $50 a share, or $1.05 billion, by Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor.

title: Deficit at Corners Worries Walton
description: When you're in a three-way tie for first place, your record is 6-5, and you have Dan Marino facing your depleted secondary, you don't have much time to gloat over a victory.

title: State Dept. Promise of Emergency Funds for U.N. Provokes Dispute
description: A decision by the State Department to promise the United Nations $90 million in emergency financing is arousing political controversy in the Administration and on Capitol Hill.

title: Gorbachev Interview: The Arms Agreement, Nicaragua and Human Rights
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's interview with NBC News, taped in Moscow on Saturday and broadcast yesterday, as provided by the network. His remarks were translated by an official Soviet interpreter. U.S.-Soviet Relations

description: Chiles-Alexander Offshore Inc., Houston, which combines the management and selected rigs of the former Chiles Offshore Inc. and the Griffin-Alexander International Inc. affiliates, appointed C. Ray Bearden senior vice president of operations.

title: West Berlin Strives for Its Old Glory in Science
description: For half a century, ending in the 1930's, this city was the scientific capital of the world. Here Max Planck and Albert Einstein helped lay the foundations of modern physics. Otto Hahn, Lise Meitner and Fritz Strassmann split the atom. Heinrich Hertz began the research that led to communication via radio waves. Here Robert Koch discovered the bacteria that cause anthrax, tuberculosis and cholera, and Paul Ehrlich produced the first treatment for syphilis.

title: Advertising; New Data On Modern Maturity
description: OF the nation's three largest-circulation magazines - TV Guide, Reader's Digest and Modern Maturity - one is particularly saddled with what it considers a misconception of its audience.

title: Luck Is Bouncing The Rangers' Way
description: It was a weekend of mixed emotions and mixed performances for the Rangers, who split their two-game series against the Islanders with a 5-4 loss followed by a 3-1 victory notable for a history-making goal credited to their goaltender, Bob Froese.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How does a squirrel remember where it has buried a nut, particularly when the ground is snow-covered or frozen? A. Squirrels use their ''very acute sense of smell,'' said Skip Garrett, a spokesman for the New York City Parks Department. ''They can tell where the nuts are stored and that's where they go, even if it's not their own cache,'' he said.

title: Sports People; Crum Resigns
description: Dick Crum resigned yesterday as football coach at the University of North Carolina, which finished this season with a 5-6 record. School officials said Crum would be paid an initial $400,000 and $100,000 per year over the four years remaining on his contract. A statement was released jointly by Crum, Chancellor Christopher Fordham and Athletic Director John Swofford. It said that a study was conducted to determine the status of the football program under Crum. ''This study found that the program no longer enjoyed the full support of all elements of the university community,'' they said. Crum had been coach at North Carolina since 1978, and had compiled a record of 72-41-3.

title: CML GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Awaiting Dobrynin
description: The guest list for the official Soviet delegation to the summit is not yet final, but one person the Russians will send is Anatoly F. Dobrynin, according to an official at the State Department.

title: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results reported in new Israeli shekels are adjusted to the rate of exchange between the shekel and the U.S. dollar at Sept. 30, 1987 of U.S $1 equals 1.6093, in accordance with Israeli generally accepted accounting principles, and the rate at Sept. 30, 1986 was U.S. $1.00 equals 1.491. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt and each ADR represents 12 Teva ordinary shares. All earnings per ADR are fully diluted. This is the second quarter of a 9-month fiscal year ending Dec. 31, 1987; the company changed its fiscal year to a calendar year in accordance with new Israeli legislation. The results are corrected from Wednesday, Nov. 25, editions.

title: New York State to Take 2d Look at Proposal to Give Addicts Needles
description: The New York State Health Department is reconsidering a New York City proposal to give drug addicts clean needles as an experiment in the battle against AIDS, state officials said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Securities in Rally
description: Prices of short-term Treasury securities rallied strongly yesterday as a sharp decline in stock prices spurred investors' flight to fixed-income investments.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Off
description: Japan reported today that its trade surplus for the first 20 days of November plunged almost 50 percent, to $2.09 billion, from $3.9 billion a year earlier. Although the yen's increasing strength against the dollar did not inhibit Japanese exports from growing at a rate of 16.4 percent, to $12.16 billion, imports surged 53.7 percent, to $10.07 billion.

title: Patient Point Man in the Prison Crises: Joseph Michael Quinlan
description: There were more than enough crises on J. Michael Quinlan's agenda when he took over this summer as director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons.

title: Jackson Seen as Caring But Lacking Experience
description: Large majorities of both white and black Americans believe that the Rev. Jesse Jackson empathizes with them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. But white Americans are uneasy about Mr. Jackson's ability to deal with international crises and see him as lacking the experience needed to be a good President.

title: Arizona Outshoots Syracuse in Shootout
description: Sean Elliott scored half of his 16 points in the last eight minutes to enable Arizona to thwart a furious second-half comeback and beat Syracuse, 80-69, in tonight's championship game of the Great Alaska Shootout tournament.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Prison Families Wait Apart
description: They wait in separate camps outside the Federal prison here, hostage families under two Army tents, inmate families under a single Salvation Army tent.

title: Prices Paid to Farmers Rise by 3.1%
description: Prices paid to farmers for raw products rose 3.1 percent in November spurred by higher prices for fresh fruits and vegetables, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; As Usual, Nelson Is Impatient
description: Don Nelson was known as the thinking man's basketball player during his 14-year pro career, which included 11 seasons with the Boston Celtics. Five of those Boston teams won National Basketball Association championships.

description: b-Includes a gain of $1,105,000 on the sale of land. The year-ago figures are restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS 87.

title: Win or Lose, Lendl Is a Hit
description: Like an anxious Broadway producer, Ivan Lendl opened a recent morning newspaper to the reviews. He had played poorly in an exhibition match against Tim Mayotte in Detroit the night before, and was expecting to be panned for what he agreed was a forgettable performance.

title: Possible Loss Is Seen by IC
description: IC Industries said today that it might post a loss in its fourth quarter because of a special charge of about $100 million it was taking to cover its restructuring costs.

title: Sports People; Thornton Retires
description: Andre Thornton, a power hitter who had the misfortune of spending many of his most productive years in the middle of a weak Cleveland Indians lineup, retired yesterday. ''I think it was understood that I was no longer in the plans of the ball club,'' Thornton said. Thornton, 38 years old, said that it was possible he might stay with the Indians in a front-office job, although no such arrangement had yet been made. He said that he has no desire to coach or manage. The team president, Hank Peters, said the Indians would honor the final year of Thornton's four-year, $4.4 million contract. Thornton had a career batting average of .254 with 253 home runs. He went to bat only 85 times last season and hit .118.

title: A 4-Year-Old Entrepreneur Helps the Needy
description: Jacob Richard Morvay is a 4-year-old entrepreneur from Manhattan. Last summer, while visiting his grandmother in Scarsdale, he set up a stand to sell apple juice for three cents a cup and cookies for a penny each.

title: Blinder Case Is Dismissed
description: Blinder, Robinson & Company, a penny stock brokerage, said today that a United States magistrate had dismissed a case filed against the firm in 1983 by the Securities and Exchange Commission over compliance with certain regulations. In his decision, Magistrate

description: Clemson was chosen by the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday to be the host for the semifinals and final of the Division I soccer tournament this weekend.

title: Reebok-Ellesse
description: Reebok International Ltd. said it would purchase only Ellesse USA and the Ellesse trademarks for the United States and Canada from Ellesse International S.p.A. for $25 million. Previously, Reebok was to have purchased the entire Ellesse business worldwide for about $60 million. The company did not say why the deal was altered. A company spokesman said Reebok did not encounter any difficulty in raising funds for the original transaction.

title: Arthur H. Dean, Envoy to Korea Talks, Dies at 89
description: Arthur H. Dean, the lawyer-diplomat who tried to arrange a post-Korean War peace conference with the Chinese at the request of President Eisenhower in 1953, and who served as a negotiator on disarmament and other matters for three other Presidents, died of pneumonia yesterday at the Community Hospital at Glen Cove, L. I. He was 89 years old and lived in Oyster Bay, L. I. Mr. Dean succeeded John Foster Dulles as senior partner in the prestigious New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell in 1949, when Mr. Dulles was elected a United States Senator. He had joined the firm in 1923 after graduation from Cornell Law School.

title: Accounting Rule Plan For Banks
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board proposed yesterday that banks and other financial institutions be required to report to shareholders the market value of their assets and liabilities.

title: Francis Gaffney, 58, Accounting Executive
description: Francis M. Gaffney, a partner in Peat, Marwick, Main & Company, an international accounting firm, died Friday after a brief illness at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: CALIFORNIA JOCKEY CLUB & BAY MEADOWS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared by the companies in November 1986 and an additional 972,457 shares from a public offering in December 1986.

title: By Design; The New/Old Fur
description: Be fearless with a fur coat that is no longer in its prime. It probably cost plenty originally, and you clearly intend to amortize the investment by wearing it for many winters. But in this season of above-the-knee chic, it is not frivolous to have the hemline of an old coat chopped fashionably short.

title: London Editor Attacks Ban On 'Spycatcher' as Absurd
description: The editor of The Sunday Times of London said in High Court today that it was absurd for the British Government to ban press coverage of ''Spycatcher,'' the memoirs of a former British intelligence agent that is a best seller in the United States.

title: U.S. Craft Launched To Study Sea Depths
description: The Government has established an undersea research station in the Caribbean Sea that it says will allow scientists to work for a ''virtually unlimited time'' to examine the ocean depths.

title: As Chess Matches Go, This One's Well-Behaved
description: Irascibility, though historically no stranger to chess at the world championship level, has so far failed to destroy decorum when Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov sit down to a match.

title: Sara Lee Offering 5-Year 9.1% Notes
description: The Sara Lee Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.10 percent notes due in 1992 at par through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,285,000 from the termination of pension plan for both the quarter and year, and losses of $2,312,000 for the quarter and $3,770,000 for the year, both from the early repayment of debt. The company said fiscal 1987 earnings were reduced by $1.4 million resulting from the first quarter reversal of certain investment tax credits taken in fiscal 1986; also included is a gain of $1,000,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of real estate. The company also said fiscal 1986 results include gains of about 6 cents a share related to the first quarter sale of a hospital and 6 cents a share during the fourth quarter from the sale of real estate.

title: A Farewell to Frustration
description: Politicians so rarely relinquish power of their own volition that Senator Daniel J. Evans of Washington provoked surprise recently when he announced that he would return to the Pacific Northwest rather than run for another term in 1988.

title: Edward Carter Ives, Real-Estate Agent, 81
description: Edward Carter Ives, a former Connecticut real-estate agent, died Friday at his home in Kennebunkport, Me. He was 81 years old.

title: Sports People; Imlach in Hospital
description: George (Punch) Imlach, a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame who coached the Toronto Maple Leafs to the Stanley Cup championship four times in the 1960's, was in critical condition yesterday at Scarborough General Hospital in Toronto after suffering a heart attack at his home Sunday night. A hospital spokesman said that the 69-year-old Imlach, who experienced heart problems that required a bypass operation in 1981, had no pulse on arrival at the hospital and was revived by emergency-room per-sonnel.

title: Wife of Chinese Diplomat at U.N. Is Injured by a Hit-and-Run Driver
description: The wife of China's deputy envoy to the United Nations was critically injured by a hit-and-run driver as she walked across upper Broadway Sunday night, and the police charged a Manhattan man in the case early yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 1, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Brazilian Inflation Rises
description: Double-digit monthly inflation returned to Brazil in November, and over the last 12 months inflation was a record 338 percent, the Government said today. The consumer price index rose 12.84 percent in November, the most since a partial price freeze cut inflation from 26.06 percent in June to 3.05 percent in July.

title: Advertising; Romann & Tannenholz In Trintex Assignment
description: Romann & Tannenholz has become agency for a new service to be offered by Trintex, the I.B.M.-Sears venture that next year will be offering an information and shopping service to owners of personal computers.

title: Our Towns; Metamorphosis Of a Mayor, And Its Cost
description: Angelo R. Martinelli, the dapper millionaire publisher who has presided over the turmoil of Yonkers politics for 12 years as Mayor, said the reports he had changed were true. It was his transformation, he said with considerable pride, that cost him re-election last month.

title: Korea Suspects Bomb Downed Jet
description: A missing South Korean passenger plane was reported today to have crashed in the jungle along the Thai-Burmese border, and the airline president said a terrorist's bomb was the most likely cause.

title: Job Outlook Is Termed Good for Graduates
description: The job outlook for college graduates is good despite the recent stock market collapse, according to a recruiting survey by Michigan State University.

title: X-Ray Lasers Expand Scientists' Vision
description: ARMED with new techniques for producing and controlling X-rays, scientists are developing a family of research instruments that they expect will allow them to peer with unprecedented clarity into the mechanism of living cells.

title: What's Fair for the Cubans
description: Although Cuban ''Marielitos'' are still holding out in Atlanta, it is not too soon to consider how we should treat the detainees after the rebellions have ended.

title: Stains on Prehistoric Tool Are Human Blood
description: DARK brown stains preserved on a 100,000-year-old stone cutting tool have been identified as the remains of human blood, the oldest human blood ever analyzed. Scientists believe the discovery, though tainted by controversy, points to a new means of exploring early human life.

title: Make New York Legislature Truly Part-Time or Truly Full Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Program Trades Spur Index Futures Volume
description: As stock prices fell sharply, trading was heavy in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index pit today. Some market experts attributed the higher volume to program trading by some institutional investors.

title: Child Abuse Found High in New York Mental Centers
description: Children in New York State mental hygiene facilities are abused and neglected more than twice as often as children in the state generally, a study by a state watchdog commission has found.

title: PLEXUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $42,000. c-Net income and includes a gain from discontinued operations of $42,000.

title: U.S. Rejects A Japan Deal
description: The United States special trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, rejected a compromise with Japan today and called for full adoption of a GATT panel's ruling against that country in a trade dispute.

title: Career Moves: Varying Ways To Dress the Part
description: When Theresa Pye dresses for her job as an administrative assistant at the Merrill Lynch office in Doylestown, Pa., she selects a tailored suit in a solid color and a high-necked blouse.

title: Marietta Contract
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it had received a $608 million Air Force contract for continued production of the Lantirm electro-optical night navigation and targeting system. The equipment is attached to Air Force fighter planes and enables pilots to fly beneath radar at speeds exceeding 500 miles an hour even in conditions of reduced visibility.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing yesterday of estates and trusts whose gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund were received before the beginning of the current campaign misidentified one contributor. It was the estate of Daniel A. Spero.

title: The Image: Moscow Goal; Gorbachev Interview Is the First Volley
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in his interview on American television, said little he has not said before, and this was almost certainly by design. The point was how and to whom he said it.

description: b-Includes a loss of $805,000 for the quarter and a net of $6,090,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1.

title: Price Waterhouse Picks U.S. Operations Leader
description: Price Waterhouse & Company, the nation's fifth-largest accounting firm, said yesterday that it had named Shaun F. O'Malley, head of its Philadelphia office, as chairman and senior partner of its United States operations starting July 1.

title: Faction of Detainees Is Said to Obstruct Accord in Atlanta
description: A Cuban-American aiding in negotiations with Cuban inmates commanding the Federal prison here said today that a small minority of prisoners were blocking agreement in the seven-day-old uprising.

title: AFGHANS SUGGEST SOVIET TIMETABLE FOR WITHDRAWAL
description: The Afghan leader, Najibullah, proposed a 12-month timetable today for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, where they have been fighting Islamic guerrillas for eight years.

title: Rules Proposed to Curb Electrocutions on Job
description: The Government proposed regulations today aimed at reducing by 40 percent the number of on-the-job electrocutions in certain industries.Electricians and farm and construction workers would be excluded from the regulations.

title: JETLINER DIVES TO MISS SMALL PLANE
description: A United Airlines Boeing 767 carrying 116 people went into a dive to avoid a collision with a small plane, passing within 100 feet of the smaller craft, according to a report received by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Spanish Post for Plisetskaya
description: Maya Plisetskaya, the grande dame of the Bolshoi Ballet, flew to Madrid today to take up a new post as artistic director of Spain's National Ballet.

description: SHE needed to buy a computer but didn't know the first thing about them. So she asked her husband.

title: Alzheimer's: Deterioration Of an Artist
description: ALZHEIMER'S disease destroys minds, but there have been few opportunities to study the disorder's impact on artistic creativity, one of the highest expressions of the human mind.

title: NATO Seeks New Strategies
description: Defense ministers of the Atlantic alliance, meeting here this week on the eve of an expected superpower agreement to limit nuclear arms in Europe, are likely to hear some unconventional ideas for strengthening NATO's conventional forces.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Reynolds Metals Company announced the signing of a $1.1 billion loan agreement yesterday to refinance two major term loans and to replace an undrawn revolving credit facility. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company acted as the agent, as well as co-manager with the Bank of Nova Scotia, as part of a consortium of 16 banks.

title: Exiled Duvalier Appeals for Calm
description: Jean-Claude Duvalier, the deposed Haitian President, appealed today for calm in Haiti and for an end to the violence that caused the postponement of the first free presidential elections in 30 years.

title: Careers; Nation's Nursing Shortage
description: ONE profession that needs more people power is nursing. The nation's 1.4 million registered nurses will have to increase 44 percent, to 2 million, by the year 2000, only 13 years away, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says. And the 631,000 licensed practical nurses will have to increase 37 percent, to 869,000.

title: For History With a Sense of Presence
description: Some historians delving into the past go to libraries to research their books; others go to onetime scenes of action. And some, like John Keegan, author of an acclaimed new military history, ''The Mask of Command,'' manage to do both - blend past scholarship with modern reportage.

title: Cheerless, Brokers Go South
description: When the nation's brokers kick off their annual convention in Boca Raton, Fla., today, the partying is expected to be subdued.

title: Americans See Rocket In Soviet
description: FOR the first time, a team of Americans has inspected a Russian rocket before it was launched from the Soviet Union's main spaceport, a complex that has long been shrouded in secrecy.

title: Spanish Bank Bid Faces Counteroffer
description: A leading Spanish bank, Banco de Bilbao, began a hostile takeover bid today for its rival, Banco Espanol de Credito, widely known as Banesto, but immediately faced an unexpected counteroffer for the bank group.

title: Hemmeter Cancels Hawaiian Air Bid
description: The Hemmeter Corporation said that a two-month-old merger agreement to acquire HAL Inc., the parent of Hawaiian Airlines, for $50 a share, or $100 million, had been terminated because of lack of financing.

title: Women Discuss Striving For Status as Composers
description: Clara Schumann surreptitiously used the name of her famous husband, Robert, to get her works performed before 19th-century audiences that thought women lacked the intellect to write music.

title: Music: The Goliard Chorale
description: A PROGRAM devoted to only four works could hardly be more eclectic than that offered by the Goliard Chorale and Chamber Ensemble Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. It opened with a Psalm setting by Telemann, sung with light precision by the 23-voice ensemble and accompanied by violins with harpsichord continuo. Next came the Faure C minor piano quartet, then a jazz-based ''trio sonata'' for piano, violin, soprano saxophone and percussion by James Perla, then the second set of ''Liebeslieder Walzer'' by Brahms.

title: Comrades in Terror; Soldiers and Thugs Are Reportedly Allied In the Campaign in Haiti to Cancel Election
description: The violent disruption of Haiti's elections Sunday seemed to destroy a notion that some mysterious, uncontrollable force had been wreaking violence on the land.

title: TASS REPORTS A FATAL CRASH
description: A number of people were killed when a freight train crashed into a stationary passenger train on the Transcaucasian railway in Soviet Georgia, Tass said today Monday. It gave few details of the accident on Sunday near Gardabani in which the freight train rammed the Tbilisi-Baku express, saying only that there was ''loss of life.'' But it said the railway line was closed for 11 hours and the Communist Party Central Committee had sent condolences to relatives of the victims, suggesting that the death toll could be large.

title: Commodity Prices Fall; Gold Rises Moderately
description: Futures prices of most basic farm and industrial commodities dropped yesterday as a plunging stock market again raised the specter of a recession. And although the dollar fell to new post-World War II lows, gold prices, which normally soar on falling currency and stock values, closed only moderately higher in New York.

title: FANSTEEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The latest 9 months' results include operations for the company's Japanese subsidiary on a consolidated basis. Start-up operations of the new Tantalum production facility in Japan resulted in a 3-cents-a-share loss for the latest quarter. The latest periods' losses also include a significant charge for expenses for the production, development and engineering costs for new government programs in process, as well as a non-recurring charge associated with the close-down of the Waukegan plant and relocating product lines to other Fansteel plants. The latest quarter and 9 months' sales include the effect of discontinued electrical contract manufacturing in late 1986.

title: Sports People; Brown Set to Return
description: Dave Brown's 15-game suspension for slamming Tomas Sandstrom of the Rangers with a cross-check that caused a concussion will be coming to an end this weekend. The Philadelphia Flyers' 6-foot-5-inch, 215-pound right wing will be eligible to return on Sunday at home against the Devils, but he will not be permitted to play in games against the Rangers on Dec. 10 and 22. He must wait until Jan. 17 at Madison Square Garden to face them. In an interview with The Philadelphia Inquirer this week, Brown refused to talk about the Sand-strom incident, but said that he does not plan on changing his style of play.

description: COLLECTED POEMS, 1987. By D. J. Enright. 368 pages. Oxford University Press. Paperback: $12.95.

description: Texas A & M University has established a testing center for deaf dogs, at which dogs undergo neurological examinations and are fitted with hearing aids, when appropriate.

description: The company went public Aug. 26, 1986.

description: The Kemper Insurance Company, faced with $37.1 million in losses this year from its auto insurance policies in Massachusetts, proposed a plan today to take itself out of the state's troubled auto insurance market by creating a replacement company, to which it would contribute $100 million.

title: U.S. Seeks Wedge in Haiti, Tying New Aid to Elections
description: After violence that prompted the cancellation of presidential elections in Haiti on Sunday, the Reagan Administration is struggling to find a way to bring American influence to bear on the military-dominated Government of Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy. The State Department spokesman, Charles E. Redman, said today that the United States would not consider rescinding Sunday's cutoff of military and other nonhumanitarian aid to Haiti until the electoral process was resumed.

title: Judge Kennedy: In His Own Words
description: Following are excerpts from texts prepared by Judge Anthony M. Kennedy for two speeches: straint spring from the Constitution itself, not from a particular judicial theory. The Constitution was written with care and deliberation, not by accident. . . . The constitutional text and its immediate implications, traceable by some historical link to the ideas of the Framers, must govern the judges. . . . If these principles do not provide fixed boundaries for judicial interepretation in constitutional cases, at least two systemic failures become manifest in the operation of checks and balances.

title: Bridge: An Unusual Foursome Wins Reisinger Title at Nationals
description: An unusual foursome scored a convincing victory in the Reisinger board-a-match team championship, which concluded the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals that ended here Sunday night.

description: In a prelude to next week's summit meeting in Washington, Mikhail S. Gorbachev went on American television today in a mixed posture of conciliation and toughness.

description: Gold, silver, ivory and other treasures found in the remains of a shipwreck discovered off the coast of Turkey probably date from the time of King Tutankhamen of Egypt, archeologists have now determined.

description: Former Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who had successful surgery for rectal cancer two weeks ago, was said to be in excellent condition today after surgery to remove his enlarged prostate gland.

description: Once more the United States confronts a basic reality of international life: intervention in the affairs of another country. The ethical and political question about Haiti is not whether to intervene but when and how.

description: Does Ronald Reagan really want George Bush to win the Republican Presidential nomination next year?

description: FOR thousands of people, the educated hand of a friend, relative or professional interpreter is the only communication bridge with the outside world. But an experimental device developed by four mechanical engineering students at Stanford University offers hope of enabling the deaf-blind to receive messages and even read on their own.
