title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Kelly Ryan, the Yale quarterback, was named the Ivy League's top player yesterday, heading the all-star team selected by the league's coaches. Ryan, a senior who led the Ivies in passing and in total offense, was voted the winner of the Asa S. Bushnell Cup. . . . Randy Milligan, the first baseman for the Mets' Class AAA Tidewater farm team, was named the minor-league player of the year yesterday by The Sporting News. Milligan, 26, led the International League with a .326 batting average and 103 runs batted in and ranked third in home runs with 29.

title: Kalapana Journal; An Angry Mountain in Tropical Paradise
description: George Faulkner thought he would spend his final years ''warm and free'' on the Big Island of Hawaii, living in what he called ''the most beautiful place I had ever seen.''

title: Peter F. F. Kissel, Horseman, 61
description: Peter F. F. Kissel of Miami Beach, whose colt Pass Catcher won the Belmont Stakes in 1971, died Saturday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 61 years old.

title: Ford Sales in France
description: The Ford Motor Company led sales of foreign cars in France in the first 10 months of 1987, although its market share declined to 6.86 percent from 7.02 percent, the French Car Importers' Association said today. Ford sold 116,540 cars, followed by Fiat S.p.A. of Italy with 111,135. Fiat's market share rose to 6.54 percent, from 6.17 percent in the first 10 months of last year.

title: Word Hunt Now Easier Than Ever
description: ELECTRONIC thesauruses are popular programs with word processors in these days of greater built-in memory and fast-access, roomy hard disks.

title: BLACK & DECKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: b-Net loss c-After extraordinary charges of $19,000,000 and $21,200,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from early extinguishment of debt.

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $42,246 and $136,357 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After a realized investment loss of $123,546 for the quarter and a realized investment gain of $29,398 for the 9 months.

title: Trial Begins for 2 Held In '81 Brink's Robbery
description: A prosecutor described two defendants yesterday as key members of a gang that carried out the 1981 Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County.

title: ALPHAREL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said because of changes in the company's fiscal year, comparisons throughout the year ended Dec. 31 are made to comparable periods in the company's fiscal year ended Nov. 30, 1986.

title: Commercial Sponsors Will Claim Equal Time in Presidential Debate
description: Each of the 12 Presidential candidates in Tuesday night's televised debate from the Kennedy Center will probably have about the same amount of time as each of the three sponsors' commercials in the two-hour program.

title: Reagan Assails Soviet Policies
description: President Reagan outlined hard-line bargaining positions today on a broad range of issues that he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will discuss during their summit conference next week, as he and other senior officials tried to play down expectations of what the talks might produce.

title: Reagan Takes a Poke at Gorbachev on Nicaragua
description: President Reagan, apparently countering Mikhail S. Gorbachev's remarks in a televised interview about the Soviet role in Afghanistan, declared today: ''The simple people of Afghanistan pose no threat to Soviet territory. They don't now. They never have.''

title: Members of Haiti Election Council Reject General's Order to Disband
description: Several members of the civilian Electoral Council disbanded by the Government after an abortive presidential election refused today to accept the Government action, heightening the conflict over Haiti's future.

title: U.S. REBUKES PARIS ON IRAN DEALINGS OVER 2 HOSTAGES
description: The United States sharply criticized France today for making what one official said was a deal with Iran to obtain the release of French hostages in Lebanon.

title: Leading Indicators Down 0.2%
description: Dragged down by the diving stock market, the Government index designed to predict the economy declined by two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Soviet TV News
description: American publications may not have much of an appetite for such news out of the Soviet Union as ''Volunteers Harvest Uzbekistan Cotton by Hand'' or ''Substandard Auto Services Plague Khabarovsk,'' but Soviet television's version of arms control talks in Geneva or a new flare-up in the Persian Gulf could be a different story - at least the owners of Worldview Inc. hope so.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Picasso Work Brings $7.6 Million, a Record
description: Picasso's ''Souvenir of Havre,'' an oval Cubist work depicting a bottle of rum, a glass, seashells, an anchor, ropes and a piece of fake wood, was auctioned at Sotheby's in London last night for $7.6 million, a record at auction for a painting by the artist.

title: EAST TRADE BLOC SEEKS TIE TO WEST
description: After three decades of hostility and estrangement, the trading bloc of the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies is moving to establish diplomatic and commercial relations with the European Community.

title: Afghan Proposal Inadequate, U.S. Aides Say
description: Reagan Administration officials today described the Afghan Government's proposal to have Soviet troops withdraw over a period of 12 months as inadequate.

title: Artist Donates Two Drawings To Aid Neediest Cases Fund
description: John Hapgood, a pen-and-ink artist, has donated two of his scratchboard drawings to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which opened its 76th annual drive Sunday.

title: Unisys Wins Contract
description: The Government awarded a $450 million multiyear contract to the Unisys Corporation today for the production of advanced weather radar units. The units, part of a system called Nexrad, for Next Generation Weather Radar, are intended to fill the weather forecasting needs of the Commerce, Transportation and Defense Departments. The contract calls on the Detroit-based company to set up as many as 195 of the new radar units throughout the United States, the Caribbean, Western Europe and the Pacific. Completion of the new network is scheduled for 1994-95.

title: A New Twist to Stem Student Loan Defaults
description: The Federal Government spends $3.4 billion a year on guaranteed loans for college students, but $1.6 billion of that, or nearly half, helps no one pay for books and tuition. It goes to cover the cost of defaulted loans.

title: Danger: Gorby Fever
description: The Gallup Poll reveals that twice as many Americans have a ''favorable opinion'' of Mikhail Gorbachev as have an unfavorable view of him. That is a stunning tribute to the skill of Soviet propaganda and dismaying evidence of the power of American wishful thinking.

title: Perle Criticizes Missile Pact Over Verification
description: Richard N. Perle, a former Pentagon official whose hard-line views are expected to be influential in the Senate debate over ratification of the new missile treaty, sharply criticized some of the treaty's verification provisions today.

title: 2 Companies Get Duro-Test Data
description: The Duro-Test Corporation said that it had given confidential financial information to two companies, the American Magnetics Corporation and Ballantrae Partners L.P., that are interested in acquiring the light bulb manufacturer, based in North Bergen, N.J. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Duro-Test said the parties had agreed to purchase no additional Duro-Test shares for a year ''other than pursuant to a tender offer for all shares in which all shareholders are treated equally.''

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES HE WARNED DEAVER
description: Repeated high-level warnings failed to deter Michael K. Deaver from contacting certain former White House associates and venturing broad hints that he could use their help as a private lobbyist, according to testimony today at his perjury trial.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Nov. 28 gave the wrong date for Riverside Church's ''Messiah'' sing. It is Dec. 13.

title: Mattingly Is Secure
description: Don Mattingly, who is expected to sign a three-year contract worth $6.7 million ''anytime soon,'' is feeling about as secure as he ever has in his career with the Yankees these days. But yesterday he was also feeling ''under the weather,'' and that, he explained, was why he did not make a blood donation, as planned, during an appearance to promote the Greater New York Blood Drive at the New York Health & Racquet Club.

title: Williams Benched
description: It's back to the bench for Doug Williams, the Washington Redskins quarterback, and he's a bit miffed about it. Williams was the starter until he missed Sunday's game against the Giants due to a back injury. The job now belongs to Jay Schroeder, who rallied Washington from 16 points behind to a 23-19 victory.

title: A New Administrative Judge Is Named for Five Counties
description: Justice David S. Ritter of State Supreme Court in Orange County was appointed today the administrative judge in the Ninth Judicial District, overseeing state courts in Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam and Dutchess Counties. The appointment, announced by the Chief Administrative Judge, Albert M. Rosenblatt, is effective Jan.1. Justice Ritter will succeed Justice Joseph F. Gagliardi, 75 years old, who has held the post since 1974.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The K Mart Corporation is offering $200 million of 10 1/2 percent debentures, due in 2017, at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Texaco Creditors Back Plan
description: The committee of general creditors of Texaco Inc. yesterday approved an interim settlement proposal in the oil company's three-year battle with the Pennzoil Company, but it declined to disclose its terms until a crucial showdown in bankruptcy court today.

title: Gorbachev, the Movie and the Reality
description: The Soviet leader who will arrive next week in Washington will be less a stranger to Americans than any of his predecessors. Just days before his summit visit, Mikhail Gorbachev was there for all to read in his new book, ''Perestroika,'' and for all to see in an interview on American television. The reviews were quick and varied: canned and candid, belligerent and believable, inspirational and manipulative.

title: TV Reviews; 'Seasonal Differences'
description: ONE of the the quirks of commercial television is that truly provocative and sensitive subjects get shunted to distant corners of the schedule. Take, for example, periodic specials aimed specifically at young audiences. This afternoon's ABC ''Afterschool Special,'' at 4 P.M., tackles the thorny issue of this nation's constitutionally decreed separation of church and state. As usual in these hourlong productions, subtlety and depth are at a premium but the argument outlined in ''Seasonal Differences,'' firmly on the side of keeping church and state apart, is presented clearly and convincingly.

title: Picking College Guide: No Easy Task
description: They line the shelves of bookstores, an array of interchangeable titles: ''College Guide,'' ''Selective Guide to Colleges,'' ''Comparative Guide to American Colleges,'' ''Insider's Guide to the Colleges,'' and so on. That is the first clue that selecting the right college guide can be just as daunting as selecting the right college.

title: Eating Well
description: IT'S not just the nutritionists and doctors telling us to reduce the amount of fat in our diets.

title: Scotch and Silk; A Man of Spirit Shares His Life
description: In good weather there used to be an old man and an ancient woman sharing a stoop on West 11th Street, the man singing and the woman tapping in time. The man, dressed to the nines, would leave his rooming house and put his face to the sun, listening for the familiar sound of his companion's approach - the triple beat of a pair of feet and a cane coming down the walk. Then their afternoons would melt away. The woman, Eleanor Franklin, died some weeks ago at the age of 97. The man, Richard Walker, now mentions her in his prayers every morning and night, and mentions her to strangers, too, who happen to pass by. ''She used to laugh and laugh. I'd say, 'Girl, what you trying to do, being late? You know I'm out here waiting for you!' Oh, she was a sweetheart.''

title: L.I.R.R. Halts 5 Trains as 25 Engineers Walk Out
description: About 25 Long Island Rail Road engineers walked off the job briefly today in a dispute over vacation time, forcing the cancellation of five afternoon trains.

title: Hutton Sale Talks Continue
description: The negotiations to sell E. F. Hutton & Company stretched well into the evening yesterday without a clear winner and with a possibility that the firm would not announce its buyer until Monday.

title: The Opera: 'Grimes' in Philadelphia
description: While it barely qualifies, having had its premiere merely a month after V-E Day, Britten's ''Peter Grimes'' stands as one of the few postwar operas to establish for itself an undisputed place in the standard repertory. This morality play about a violent social outcast remains today a gripping piece of musical theater, particularly when realized in a production of the sort presented this evening by the Opera Company of Philadelphia, here in the Academy of Music. Even with an uneven cast that included several veterans in principal roles, the production handily succeeded at conveying the unusual force of Britten's seaside drama.

title: Punch Imlach, 69, Maple Leafs' Coach For 4 N.H.L. Titles
description: George (Punch) Imlach, who guided the Toronto Maple Leafs during their glory years in the National Hockey League and then built the expansion Buffalo Sabres into a contending team, died today after suffering his third major heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. Seizes 5 Properties Seen as Drug Profits
description: The Federal Government has seized five Florida properties worth $20 million as part of a campaign to confiscate investments made with profits from drug trafficking, estimated to exceed $300 million in Florida.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Nov. 24 about third-quarter bank performance included incorrect figures provided by the First Bank System of Minneapolis and First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles for their common equity ratios. The equity ratio for First Bank System should have been 4.64 percent, placing it third in the rankings behind J. P. Morgan and the Bank of Boston. First Interstate's equity ratio should have been 4.37 percent, placing it fifth behind Bankers Trust, which remains fourth.

title: Black Cubans: Apart in Two Worlds
description: The uprisings at two Federal prisons have focused attention on a dimension of the Cuban refugee exodus generally overlooked among the countless successes achieved by Cubans settling in Miami over the last three decades: the struggle of the black Cuban to share that success.

title: 2 Factors Help Dollar
description: The dollar rallied from Monday's record lows in active interbank trading yesterday, helped by support from Asian and European central banks and by rumors that West Germany is about to cut its key interest rate.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Wins Two $10 Million Billings
description: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton, New York, won two pieces of business yesterday, each of which bills a healthy $10 million. One is Fruit Corners from General Mills. The other is Little Caesars Pizza, the largest pizza take-out chain in America.

title: Market Place; A Post-Plunge Optimist Shifts
description: WHILE other market seers were too stunned to make predictions after stocks collapsed in late October, Barton Biggs shamelessly forecast a rally of at least 400 points for the Dow industrial average. He followed that up with bullish comments in Barron's in November that the imminent rally could take the Dow, which was then around 2,000, as high as 2,500.

title: Hurdle Retires
description: Clint Hurdle, one of the most highly rated rookies in baseball 10 years ago, ended his career as a player yesterday and began a new one as a manager in the Mets' farm system.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No I don't resent his popu-larity or anything else. Good Lord, I co-starred with Errol Flynn once.'' - President Reagan, on Mikhail S. Gorbachev [ A10:2. ]

title: SENATE APPROVES SCHOOL PROGRAMS
description: The Senate voted today overwhelmingly approved elementary and secondary education programs that could cost up to $7.4 billion, including programs for disadvantaged children and grants to states.

title: European Plea To Spur Trade
description: The European Community pleaded strongly today for the United States to cut its budget and trade deficits and for Japan to help lift the world economy by opening its markets to foreign goods.

title: Killer Says He Helped In Chesimard's Escape
description: An admitted killer testified yesterday that he and two defendants had helped carry out the dramatic prison escape of Joanne Chesimard, a Black Liberation Army leader, in 1979.

title: Topics of The Times; The Garlic Experience
description: Some people wouldn't think twice about refusing garlic for the sake of a heavy date. This is the kind of person made for Dr. Saiki's Odorless Garlic, a triumph of Japanese know-how soon to be test-marketed on the East Coast. But marketers of the product may have miscalculated. True garlic lovers don't avoid garlic for the sake of human contact; instead, they limit their human contacts to other garlic lovers.

title: TV Reviews; 'A Conversation With Gorbachev'
description: WHO'S the boss? That's easy; it's Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: KEY RATES
Time and Tide Threaten L.I. Highway and Shore
description: This fall the relentless pounding of the ocean had so badly eroded parts of Gilgo Beach that waves broke within 20 feet of the Ocean Parkway.

title: Emory & Henry Plays Past Its Obscurity
description: When Lou Wacker arrived at Emory & Henry College in 1982 to coach the football team, he said his goal was a national championship for the Division III school. The statement sounded foolhardy, considering that the school's reputation had been made in the classroom, not on the field. Before Wacker arrived at Emory & Henry, the Wasps had had just one winning season in the previous 13.

title: MOMENT OF SILENCE IS ENDED IN JERSEY
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today on procedural grounds to reinstate a 1982 New Jersey law requiring public schools to set aside one minute of silence daily ''for quiet and private contemplation and introspection.''

title: Feuding Delays Selection of Chicago Mayor
description: Chicago's City Council, in an emotional special session in chambers surrounded by chanting protesters, appeared late Tuesday night about to elect Eugene Sawyer, a black Alderman, as Acting Mayor. However, opposition to his selection set off a round of wrangling that continued into the early morning hours today.

title: CAPITALS STOP GRETZKY, 4-2
description: Bengt Gustafsson scored two goals and assisted on another in Washington's four-goal second period tonight as the Capitals defeated Edmonton, 4-2, and became the second team this season to shut out Wayne Gretzky.

title: Jetliner Dives to Avoid Collision With Small Plane
description: A United Airlines Boeing 767 carrying 116 people went into a dive Sunday to avoid a collision with a small plane, passing within 100 feet of the smaller craft, according to a report received by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Paul de Man, a professor of humanities at Yale University, misstated the year of his death and his age. He died on Dec. 21, 1983, at the age of 64. In some copies, a colleague at Johns Hopkins University was misidentified. He is Prof. Neil Hertz.

title: SENATOR APOLOGIZES ON CUOMO RUMORS
description: The chairman of a State Senate committee apologized today to Governor Cuomo, condemning ''false rumors'' that he said had been spread about Mr. Cuomo by a top staff member of the committee.

title: Trintex Service Set
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Sears, Roebuck & Company will introduce their videotex service next year in San Francisco, a spokesman for the venture said. The nation's largest computer company and largest retailer have invested about $250 million in Trintex since 1984. The service is to deliver information to consumers by personal computer.

title: A Soviet Defector's Mission
description: Helped by a fistfight between K.G.B. and C.I.A. agents, Victor A. Vaguine, a Soviet nuclear physicist, defected with his wife and two children to the United States 16 years ago in Switzerland.

title: New Hampshire Paper Endorses du Pont Bid
description: The Union Leader, New Hampshire's influential statewide newspaper, today endorsed Pete du Pont, the former Governor of Delaware, as ''our choice for President.''

title: Nectar of the White Roussillon Peach
description: IN the French language, a pecher is a peach tree and a peche is a sin. To these nearly sound-alike words add mignon, meaning cute, and the result is both a pun and the name of a new liqueur.

title: Betty Ford Returns Home
description: Betty Ford, the wife of former President Gerald R. Ford, returned to her home in good condition after hospitalization for quadruple coronary bypass surgery, a spokeswoman says. Mrs. Ford was expected to be released from the Eisenhower Medical Center for Thanksgiving, but her doctor held her longer to make sure she had recuperated completely, the spokeswoman said. On Nov. 20, Mrs. Ford, 69 years old, underwent quadruple coronary bypass surgery and an operation to clear her right carotid artery.

title: PACT WITH PAN AM REPORTED BY PILOTS
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday struck an 11th-hour deal with its pilots that could undermine a yearlong attempt by some of the airline's unions to find a buyer for the carrier and replace its current management.

title: A Routine Chess Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov played routinely to an uneventful draw in the 18th game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Monday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Shaker Cooking: Simplicity's Renewed Appeal
description: SISTER FRANCES A. CARR is the kitchen deaconess, or head cook, of the little Shaker community of Sabbathday Lake near Poland Spring, Me., about 30 miles northwest of Portland. She is one of the handful of remaining members of the sect, whose adherents once numbered in the thousands. By the mid-19th century, their tidy settlements had spread from Sabbathday Lake in the hills of southern Maine across New Hampshire and upstate New York and into Ohio and Kentucky.

title: EX-U.S. AGENTS GET PRISON IN A DEATH
description: Two former agents of the United States Customs Service were sentenced today to 120 years in prison in the 1982 death of a Dominican currency courier who was robbed of nearly $700,000 in cash and checks.

title: Auto Buyer Incentives May Have Little Effect
description: The latest round of buyer incentives is likely to do even less to stimulate the auto industry than the last round, which ended just two months ago, analysts and industry sources say.

title: Bonn Reappoints Pohl
description: Karl Otto Pohl, 57-year-old president of West Germany's central bank, has been officially reappointed to a second eight-year term by the nation's President, Richard von Weizsaecker.

title: Ex-Viacom Officer Joins Aaron Spelling
description: Jules Haimovitz, one of a group of managers who attempted a leveraged buyout of Viacom International Inc., yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. in Los Angeles.

title: Milk Deliverers Strike As Talks Break Down
description: The milk deliverers' union, angry because management refused to continue contract talks through the night, struck at 12:01 A.M. today, halting all deliveries to New York City, Long Island and most of Westchester County, union officials said.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review of ''About Face'' in Weekend last Friday failed to reflect a cast change, resulting in misidentification of the actor who plays the inspector. The part is played by Victor Arnold.

title: Short-Term Rates Are Steady
description: Short-term interest rates were little changed yesterday while Treasury bond yields rose slightly as traders kept one eye on fluctuations in the stock market and waited for more economic data to give a clearer picture of interest rate trends.

title: All 12 Candidates Debate In First TV Appearance
description: Twelve Presidential candidates brought a foretaste of the 1988 general election campaign into the nation's living rooms tonight with a debate that emphasized party differences on foreign policy far more than distinctions among individual candidates.

title: Holtzman, in Letter, Asserts Judge Degraded Woman in a Sex Case
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney has asserted that a New York City judge ordered the complainant in a sexual misconduct trial to get on the floor on her hands and knees, as the defendant and others watched, to demonstrate her position when she was attacked.

title: Ex-Head of Militia to Testify in Wedtech Trial
description: The former head of New York's state militia will be the star prosecution witness at the first criminal trial in New York resulting from the sprawling investigations into the Wedtech Corporation, a South Bronx military contractor, lawyers in the case said yesterday.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I HATE parent-teacher conferences. I love the teacher. I love the school. I even kind of love the little chairs you have to sit in, that set your knees to knocking against your sternum. I always bring a bribe: a bagel with butter and a cup of coffee. It's unnecessary. My elder child is the kind of kid about whom the teacher says everything you've waited all your life to hear: imaginative, generous, social, the proverbial ''pleasure to have in class.'' This time she added, ''He doesn't have a mean bone in his body.''

title: Stephen Zoll, 55, Dies; Wrote on Architecture
description: Stephen Zoll, an architecture writer and editor, died Nov. 24 of injuries suffered in an automobile accident near Cambridge, England. He was 55 years old.

title: Toni Taylor, 87, Dies; A Writer and a Teacher
description: Toni Taylor, a writer and teacher, died of a stroke Nov. 22 at her home in Rutland, Vt. She was 87 years old.

title: The One Who Got Away
description: Brett Butler and the San Francisco Giants reached agreement on a two-year, $1.8 million contract yesterday, and Chili Davis, whom Butler will replace as the Giants' center fielder, accepted an offer from the California Angels believed to be for one year and an $850,000 salary.

title: Army-Navy Kindness
description: Rivalry between the Army and the Navy will reach fever heat when the middies from Annapolis meet the cadets from West Point for their annual football game in Philadelphia Saturday.

title: Cable System Founders Sell Out at a Hefty Price
description: Paul L. Field and David W. Pardonner, who started a cable television company from scratch just eight years ago, are selling it and four associated partnerships for $225 million.

title: Morriss Injured
description: Guy Morriss, the New England Patriots' center whose 215 games are the most of any active National Football League player, was placed on injured reserve yesterday with a fractured right hand. Morriss, a 15-year veteran, was hurt in the fourth quarter of last Sunday's 34-31 overtime loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Singer to Decide On New Partner
description: The Singer Company, the military contractor that is seeking a merger, said it planned to decide on a new partner by Dec. 21.

title: A Brave New World Emerging?
description: In the days before the Reagan-Gorbachev meeting, a reporter from Washington finds a surprisingly hopeful mood in Western Europe about East-West relations. It's not just anticipation of the first limited agreement to reduce the superpowers' nuclear arsenals. One even hears thoughtful speculation about the beginning of the end of the cold war.

title: Time to Be Serious About the Housing Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN PLAN TO SPUR ECONOMY REPORTED
description: Facing pressure at home and abroad to do something about their sluggish economy, West Germany's Finance and Economics Ministers agreed today on a plan to encourage capital spending, Government officials said.

title: A Little Church Made of Gingerbread, Fantasy and Patience
description: WHEN you close your eyes and think of Christmas, do you see snow-covered cottages decorated with gumdrops, cinnamon candies and candy canes?

title: ATTACKS IN HAITI CONTINUE IN SLUM
description: While many downtown stores opened for the first time today since Sunday's aborted election, and life in much of Port-au-Prince continued to return to normal, residents of one section of the capital fled continued attacks from heavily armed thugs.

title: A Senate Panel Votes to Ban Sale of Missiles to Bahrain
description: The Senate Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations approved a $12.2 billion foreign aid bill today that includes a ban on the Reagan Administration's plans to sell Stinger anti-aircraft missiles to Bahrain.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Citizens' Suits in Pollution Cases Are Limited
description: The Supreme Court today handed industrialists what appeared to be a partial victory over environmental groups in a complex decision limiting the ability of citizens to sue polluters for past violations of the Federal Clean Water Act.

title: CONTRAS RELEASE CEASE-FIRE PLANS
description: Claiming control of more than half of Nicaragua, contra leaders today announced their cease-fire plan, which calls for a 41-day break in hostilities beginning next week and simultaneous talks on political issues.

title: Any Toaster Can Do Toast, But the Little Extras Count
description: THE technology of home toasters has not changed fundamentally in 40 years. Their function is simple and limited. Of course, that hasn't stopped American manufacturers from fiddling with size, shape, color and special features to create diversity, real or imaginary, among brands - just as shoppers are led to believe that there is a difference among the half-dozen brands of canned peas on the market.

title: 60- Minute Gourmet
description: IF I were to catalogue the foods that best lend themselves to hasty cooking or cooking within 60 minutes, scallops - whether sea scallops or bay scallops - would rank high. If they are overcooked, however, they tend to dry out or become chewy. In prolonged cooking, they also tend to lose their moist succulence and even their sweetness.

title: Mother Sentenced in Death
description: A mother convicted of criminal negligence after her 11-month-old son drowned in a mop bucket has been ordered to attend classes on how to rear children as part of her probation. The baby, Justin Hoffman, drowned in a 5-gallon bucket after his mother left him and his 23-month-old brother alone to watch a soap opera. The mother, Penny Hoffman, 23, was convicted on Nov. 18 of criminal negligence.

title: Guidry to Undergo Shoulder Surgery
description: Ron Guidry, who spent an agonizing offseason last winter as a free agent, faces a different problem this winter. He will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left shoulder next week.

title: Davis Accuses Guards of Role In His Slashing
description: Larry Davis, who is being tried for the murder of four suspected drug dealers, told the trial judge yesterday that his throat had been slashed by a fellow inmate at the Bronx House of Detention Monday while three officers from the Department of Correction watched and ''did nothing.''

title: 2 Hunts Seek Chapter 11
description: The personal trusts of Lamar and Nelson Bunker Hunt filed for protection from creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Soviet Tongues Wag Over Raisa Gorbachev
description: A prime-time Soviet broadcast of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's interview on NBC News rolled along untouched for 55 minutes tonight, until the subject of Raisa Gorbachev came up - and with it, by implication, the ticklish question of her role in her husband's grand designs for Soviet society.

title: L.D. Hinshaw Is Dead; Presbyterian Minister
description: Lillias Dulles Hinshaw, a Presbyterian minister and the daughter of the late Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, died after a long illness Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Computer Adds Some Extra Punch
description: When Evander Holyfield beat Dwight Muhammad Qawi for the World Boxing Association junior heavyweight (a k a cruiserweight) title in July 1986, he was a busy man.

title: Anchors of 4 Networks To Interview Reagan
description: A day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's appearance on American television, the White House arranged yesterday for an unusual four-way session between President Reagan and the anchors from ABC, NBC, CBS and the Cable News Network.

title: Hunch on Mary Shelley Pays Off
description: Following a hunch - ''It was really more of an educated guess based on 15 years of research and thinking and teaching about her'' - Betty T. Bennett, professor of literature and dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at American University, arrived last New Year's Day in Australia, of all places, looking for new clues to the life and mind of Mary Shelley.

title: Canada Bank Seeks 75% of Brokerage
description: The Royal Bank of Canada, the largest bank in the country, announced yesterday a complex plan to acquire 75 percent of Dominion Securities Ltd., Canada's largest full-service securities firm. The deal is worth $385 million (Canadian), or $294 million in United States currency.

title: Anti-Apartheid Parley Opens
description: Julius K. Nyerere, the former Tanzanian President, said today that apartheid would leave a social and economic legacy that would last long beyond the transfer of political power to South Africa's black majority.

title: Fed Backs Regulatory Umbrella
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board today supported the creation of an umbrella agency to more closely coordinate policy among the major Government bodies that regulate financial institutions.

title: Swiss Halt Production of Tainted Cheese
description: Production of vacherin Mont d'Or, a soft-ripened cheese prized by connoisseurs, has been halted by the Swiss Government. The cheese has been linked to outbreaks of listeriosis, a sometimes fatal bacterial infection, in the western part of Switzerland.

title: Fresh Techniques Breathe Life Into Latin
description: In Joanell Meringolo's sixth-grade class, students have aliases such as Claudius and Sempronia and a lingering Halloween pumpkin is called Aeneas. When a draft slams the door shut, it is the ghost of Julius Caesar that has just stalked by.

title: 4 COMPANIES WIN NASA'S CONTRACTS FOR SPACE STATION
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration awarded contracts yesterday to four companies to begin building the nation's first permanent outpost in space, an undertaking that would cost at least $14 billion and would be the last manned space program of this century for the United States.

title: Yield About 9.54% On Nordic Notes
description: The Nordic Investment Bank is offering $200 million of 9 1/2 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.80 to yield about 9.54 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Time to Be Serious About the Housing Crisis; The Best Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance: Hawkins At Joyce
description: ''GOD THE REVELLER'' is one of Erick Hawkins's most beautiful dance works, typical in its clarity but unusually threaded throughout with a sly wit. It runs through every image.

title: Reductions At Dayton
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation, which outspent all other retailers with capital allocations of about $2 billion in the last two years, said yesterday that it was cutting back to about $600 million next year for new stores and remodelings. Kenneth A. Macke, Dayton-

title: Microwave Cooking
description: IN the middle of the holidays, one can grow tired of going out, tired of all that heavy food.

title: Josef Vrana Bishop, 82
description: Bishop Josef Vrana, one of only three Roman Catholic prelates in Czechoslovakia, has died at the age of 82, the official press agency reported today.

title: A London Awash In Wine Bars
description: For London's wine crowd the week began Monday with a tasting at the Groucho (''I wouldn't want to belong to any club that would accept me as a member'') Club in Soho. It ended Friday at the opening of Sir Terence Conran's long-awaited oyster and wine bar, Bibendum, in South Kensington. It was a busy five days, but then, this is a vibrant wine city.

title: Dawkins Reflects On Troubled Time
description: For Darryl Dawkins, the last two months have been harrowing. Until tonight, the former Net, who was returning to Byrne Meadowlands Arena as a member of the Detroit Pistons, had not publicly discussed the tragedy of his estranged wife's death by suicide or the turmoil that has led him through four different teams.

title: Father of Steamboat On Banks of the Clyde
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Alleghany Wants More of St. Paul
description: The Alleghany Corporation said it planned to raise its stake in the St. Paul Companies to 20 percent from 8.4 percent. Based on today's closing price of $67.50, up $2.50 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange, purchasing 5.37 million St. Paul shares would cost Alleghany more than $351 million.

title: Heir Guilty in Scheme to Defraud a Texas Charity
description: A Galveston insurance heir was convicted today of defrauding his family's charitable foundation of nearly $1.5 million and faces up to 85 years in prison.

title: People
description: * Robert Jaczko, creative director, has been promoted to senior vice president at Doremus & Co., Boston.

title: Picture of Death Squads Seen In Key Salvadoran Notebook
description: If a former close aide to the rightist Salvadoran political leader Roberto d'Aubuisson ever comes to trial, a key piece of evidence could be a notebook that appears to show the inner workings of rightist death squads, according to American and Salvadoran officials.

title: Senior Democrats Look for Alternative Candidates
description: Senior Democratic leaders, increasingly dismayed and frustrated by the performance of their party's six contenders for President, have started meeting privately to discuss ways of getting other candidates into the race.

title: Stage: 'Real Estate,' By Author of 'Salonika'
description: EVERY young playwright should have it only half so lucky as the English writer Louise Page. The first of Miss Page's plays staged in New York, ''Salonika,'' boasted no less than Jessica Tandy and Elizabeth Wilson in the leading roles at its Public Theater premiere in 1985. For ''Real Estate,'' now at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, Miss Page has attracted two actresses of nearly comparable stature - Sada Thompson and Roberta Maxwell. In spite of the stellar cast and thoughtful script, ''Salonika'' proved an emotionally dead drama about mothers, daughters and lost love. Exactly the same is true of ''Real Estate.'' The fault, I think it's safe to assume, is not in the stars.

title: Howard Bid Rejected
description: Jim Marchiony, a spokesman for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday that the Division I-AA football committee had rejected a proposal from Howard University to expand the playoff field from 16 teams to 20. The university last week filed a $9 million suit against the N.C.A.A. for being excluded from the championship playoffs for reasons that the predominately black school contends were racially motivated. A Federal judge in Washington on Saturday denied a request by Howard to delay the start of the playoffs.

title: Glaxo Hunts a New Winner
description: DR. RICHARD B. SYKES, who heads the research arm of Britain's big pharmaceutical maker, Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., says that trying to develop a major new drug is like betting on race horses, with one notable difference.

title: Charge of Attempted Murder Dropped in AIDS Blood Case
description: A judge today dimissed two counts of attempted murder against a man who twice sold his AIDS-tainted blood, saying the prosecution could not prove the defendant had intended to kill anyone.

title: INSIDE
description: Hostage Freed in Atlanta

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1987
description: International A3-19

title: Rumania Resists Emulating Soviet Changes
description: Little need is felt for far-reaching governmental and economic change in this orthodox Communist country, nor is there much of the striving for the openness that accompanies that process in the Soviet Union.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FYODOR DOSTOYEVSKY. A Writer's Life. By Geir Kjetsaa. Translated from the Norwegian by Siri Hustvedt and David McDuff. 437 pages. Elisabeth Sifton Viking. $24.95.

title: Advertising; Pepperidge Farm Line Of Desserts
description: ON Monday Pepperidge Farm, many a tummy's favorite, will introduce into Northern California eight (count 'em, eight) new frozen, single-serving desserts.

title: In New York's Newspaper War, Tabloids Race to the Final Battle
description: The combatants in New York City's bitter tabloid newspaper war - The Daily News, The New York Post and New York Newsday - appear to be on the threshold of a final melee that could determine the city's newspaper landscape for many years to come.

title: Bail Revoked in Bet Case
description: A Federal judge Monday revoked bail for a son-in-law of former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo who was accused of continuing to take bets four months after his conviction on Federal bookmaking charges. The convict, Joseph Mastronardo Jr., 35 years old, of Huntingdon Valley, was convicted in July of running a multimillion-dollar gambling operation that stretched from New York to Florida. He had been free on $200,000 bail while appealing the verdict, a two-year prison sentence and a $250,000 fine.

title: Robbins Plans Retrospective
description: Jerome Robbins, absent from Broadway since 1964, plans to return next fall with a retrospective of his theater choreography that would include dances from the period between ''On the Town,'' in 1944, and ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' which opened two decades later and was his last work for the commercial stage.

title: A Global Journey Pays Off for Gilbert
description: From Los Angeles to Tel Aviv, Paris to Johannesburg, Brad Gilbert's road to the Nabisco Masters was an eight-week odyssey that ended in Itaparica, Brazil, last week, on a hard court baked by temperatures exceeding 100 degrees.

title: Mary Harmon Nason, Ex-Advertising Official
description: Mary Harmon Nason, a former advertising executive and real-estate developer, died of cardiac arrest Nov. 14 at her home in Longboat Key, Fla. She was 85 years old. Mrs. Nason was active for many years with her husband, James R. P. Nason, in developing properties in Connecticut, Nantucket Island, the Bahamas and Longboat Key. She also was associated with him in advertising from 1945 to 1955 as a vice president and director of Nason Inc., in New York City.

title: Down to a Handshake
description: IVAN LENDL and Pat Cash were playing for the richest single prize in tennis history. It was the final of the initial Stakes Match, seen on ABC-TV Sunday afternoon, and at one point, one of the announcers, Cliff Drysdale or Arthur Ashe, said, ''If Cash gets much further behind, he might be left with nothing but a handshake.''

title: BRITONS DENOUNCE FRANCE-IRAN DEAL
description: France's secret dealings with Iran to obtain the freedom of French hostages have upset the British Government and drawn fierce criticism from the British press.

title: Hypocrisy on Hostages
description: It's a wonder how Charles Redman, the State Department spokesman, kept a straight face when he attacked France yesterday for dealing with Iran to obtain the release of French hostages in Lebanon. Mr. Redman's criticism implied that the virtuous United States would never stoop to rewarding hostage-takers.

title: Chefs Take Laughs With Their Beef
description: THE trouble with hiring a bunch of high-spirited, independent-minded chefs and putting them in the same room is that they may not do exactly what they were hired to do. Since they are unlikely to take a product they are being paid to promote as seriously as the people paying them do, they tend to kid around. And the more the people who hired them rise to the bait, the more they are teased.

title: Food Notes
description: Award-Winning Books

title: Economic Scene; Averting Wild Stock Swings
description: WHAT can be done to prevent the wild swings in the stock market, which jeopardize the stability of the real economy?

title: Senate Begins Work on $9 Billion of Tax Rises
description: Senate tax writers began piecing together a $9 billion package of tax increases today as top White House officials lobbied Republican senators to support the deficit-reduction agreement reached last month between the Administration and leaders of Congress.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1987
description: Companies

title: Nonunion Pensions at Supermarkets General Are Protected
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Dramatic Swiss Team Event Brings Fall Nationals to End
description: There was a dramatic finale to the three-day North American Swiss Team Championship that ended here Sunday night as the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals concluded.

title: Harlem Dance Theater To Tour Soviet Union
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will perform in the Soviet Union in a four-week tour that begins May 13 at the Palace of Congresses in Moscow.

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: In the upper ranks of academe, there are two kinds of creatures, those who hold a Ph.D. and the wretched novitiates who are chasing one.

title: Freshman Sparks Indiana to Victory Manhattan 84, Columbia 80    By The Associated Press - Billy Wheeler scored 22 of his career-high 35 points to power a second-half surge for Manhattan (2-1).   Wheeler, a senior guard who made 13 of 25 field-goal attempts, scored 6 consecutive points during an 11-4 spurt that brought Manhattan from a 66-59 deficit to a tie at 70 with 6:58 to play.   Peter Runge, who had 20 points for Manhattan, put the Jaspers ahead to stay on a free throw with 3:43 left. He gave Manhattan an 80-76 lead on a 3-point play.   Matt Shannon led Columbia (0-3) with a career-high 25 points. He hit all 5 of his 3-point tries in the first half, which ended tied at 38.  Marist 76, Southampton 49    POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. (AP) -Rik Smits scored 19 points and blocked 7 shots to lead Marist. Smits, a 7-4 senior center, became the fourth-leading scorer in Marist history. The first of his five slam dunks capped a 14-2 run for the Red Foxes to open the game.   Marist, which led by 39-18 at halftime, put the game out of reach with a 13-1 flurry midway through the second half.   Rudy Bourgarel added 12 points and a team-high 13 rebounds for Marist. Smits also had 10 rebounds.   Daryl Cambrelen of Southampton (0-5) was the game's leading scorer with 23 points.  Boston College 121 Harvard 80    CAMBRIDGE, Mass. (AP) - Dana Barros led Boston College (2-2) with 26 points. A full-court press throughout the game forced 25 Harvard (1-2) turnovers.   The Eagles received 19 points from Jamie Benton and 17 points from Corey Beasley, a freshman.   Harvard was paced by Ralph James with 16 points and Mike Gielen with 14.
description: Jay Edwards, a 6-foot-4-inch freshman guard, scored 7 consecutive points and had 12 of his team's final 16 as Indiana defeated Notre Dame, 76-59, tonight.

title: A Tough Ox For Afghans: Najibullah
description: He is called the Ox. The nickname for Afghanistan's Soviet-sponsored leader, Najibullah, refers not only to his bulky physique, but also to his stubborn, driving power and his approach to obstacles in his path.

title: Attackers From Egypt Wound Israeli Soldier
description: An Israeli soldier was slightly wounded early today when two unidentified gunmen opened fire on an Israeli Army patrol after having cut a hole in the Egyptian-Israeli border fence, an Israeli Army spokesman said.

title: McHALE'S RETURN SPOILED BY HAWKS
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 22 points and Tree Rollins added 20 tonight to offset a 22-point season debut by Boston's Kevin McHale and lead the Atlanta Hawks to a 120-106 victory over the Celtics.

title: Stage: One-Acts by Lanford Wilson
description: LIKE the apparently mismatched pair in ''Burn This,'' the people in the three one-act plays by Lanford Wilson that opened last night at the Sanford Meisner Theater are on edge. The reconciliations made as the lights go down tend to be soft, but Mr. Wilson's steady humor and his smart dialogue offer pleasures along the way.

title: Moynihan's Favorite-Son Presidential Bid Foiled by Lack of Support
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's brief fling as a possible favorite-son candidate for President, which ended as suddenly as it began, failed to win backing from Governor Cuomo and the Democratic state chairman, Laurence J. Kirwan, .

title: Californians Will Again Vote On Isolating Victims of AIDS
description: Supporters of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., who espouses theories of political conspiracy, have succeeded in placing an anti-AIDS referendum on the state ballot next June, California officials report.

title: Parcells Insists He'll Return
description: Bill Parcells has told his Giants that despite rumors to the contrary, he will return next year as coach. He said the same thing during his weekly radio show for WNEW-AM.

title: Sex Bias Ruling Against A.T.&T. Subsidiary
description: In a decision that could affect 20,000 women, a Federal district judge has ruled that a subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company discriminated against pregnant employees over a 12-year period in the 1960's and 1970's.

title: House Approves Bill on Cherokee Removal
description: The House passed legislation today to commemorate the forced removal of Cherokees from North Carolina to Oklahoma a century ago.

title: U.S. Rejects Claims in Mining of Harbor; Madhouse Music
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Say Officials Withhold Data
description: Two organizations of journalists today accused the Justice Department of refusing to enforce the Freedom of Information Act. Officials of the two groups urged Congress to create an independent agency to resolve disputes over access to Government files.

title: Article 383487 -- No Title
description: About $1 million in rare coins and jewelry was stolen early yesterday when burglars broke into three walk-in safes in the office of a coin dealer in midtown Manhattan, the police said.

title: James Baldwin, Eloquent Writer In Behalf of Civil Rights, Is Dead
description: James Baldwin, whose passionate, intensely personal essays in the 1950's and 60's on racial discrimination in America made him an eloquent voice of the civil-rights movement, died of stomach cancer early yesterday at his home in St. Paul de Vence in southern France. He was 63 years old.

title: Decision Industries Gets Onset Offer
description: The Onset Corporation has begun a friendly $8.75-a-share offer for the Decision Industries Corporation, which it said would cost $92 million, but a second company said that it would pay more for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.

title: Colonial League: New Role Model
description: The Colonial League, the six-team organization that just finished its second season with a flush of success, is delighted to serve as a model for intercollegiate football. But it has no immediate plans for opening its doors to others, according to Peter Likins, the president of Lehigh University and one of the league's founders.

title: Piano: Rudolf Firkusny in Recital
description: NO one has ever accused Rudolf Firkusny of being a frivolous performer, nor were they likely to do so after his extraordinarily demanding program at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. Mr. Firkusny, never one to balk at technical hazards, followed a pair of 20th-century pieces with two of the piano repertory's most daunting works, Schumann's ''Davidsbundlertanze'' and Schubert's posthumously published Sonata in B flat.

title: Southland Proposal To Finance Buyout
description: The Southland Corporation's on-again, off-again attempts to become a private company were on again yesterday as its investment bankers came up with a new plan to finance the $5.1 billion deal.

title: HAIG ON THE AIR
description: Generals don't start wars, politicians do. That is the message of a campaign commercial being broadcast in New Hampshire by Alexander M. Haig Jr., a retired four-star Army general now a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Canada to End Countersubversion Unit
description: To curb overzealousness in its internal security agency, the Canadian Government has ordered it to disband a countersubversion branch that until recently maintained files on 30,000 people, including some in labor and antiwar groups that have broad public backing.

title: Music: Marianne Faithfull Returns
description: MARIANNE FAITHFULL confessed to nervousness Monday at the Bottom Line, in the second of three nights in her first live show since 1983. But a remarkable band, Ms. Faithfull's singular voice and, perhaps, the tension of facing an audience again combined for one of the strongest performances in recent memory - complex, adult emotions conveyed with artful directness.

title: No Headline
description: More than 250 demonstrators gathered last night at the steps of City Hall to demand that New York City make available additional money for AIDS research, treatment and education.

title: Gay Health Group Is Cleared in U.S. Inquiry
description: An investigation by the Department of Health and Human Services has cleared officials of the Gay Men's Health Crisis of accusations that the Manhattan-based group used Federal money to produce sexually explicit educational comic books.

title: Tobacco Lawyer Said to Shift on Cancer
description: A lawyer for the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company conceded in a September meeting with top Government health officials that cigarette smoking is related to cancer, heart disease and chronic lung disease, according to a memorandum written by one of the officials.

title: Russia Between The Coasts
description: One dark night a long time ago in Provincetown, Mass., hearing sounds of desperation in the water that lapped our rental house, I waded in and retrieved a fully clothed female person, age about 18.

title: Paradise Journal; For Amish, Progress Can Be Threat
description: Unworldly the Amish here in Lancaster County may be, but that doesn't mean they are impervious to the new, the modern and the secular.

title: Making Money Out of the Air
description: LEAD: Many things need to be closed in Washington, but the one thing that seems to have captivated Congress and the White House is the Federal budget deficit. Unnerved by a nose dive in the Dow Jones that Mother Jones could only fantasize about, Republicans and Democrats staged a fiscal encounter group session to ''deficit-summit'' the budget shortfall down into the merely colossal range.

title: Nominee to Court Says Judges Should Avoid Making Policy
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's nominee to the Supreme Court, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that judges should avoid becoming active policymakers and opening the way to rulings reflecting their personal biases.

title: Hungary Takes Note of Its Troubled Youth
description: A Hungarian ''tinedzser'' is subject to the same psychological pressures as teen-agers elsewhere.

title: U.S. Rejects Claims in Mining of Harbor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Using Heat in Treatment of Some Cancers
description: MEDICAL historians trace the idea of fighting cancer tumors with heat to Hippocrates, who successfully treated his fellow Greeks in baths of hot sand 24 centuries ago.

title: Gynecologist and Wife Hurt in a Knife Attack
description: A masked man walked into the Upper East Side office of a Manhattan gynecologist yesterday afternoon, stabbed the doctor and his wife, who works as his receptionist, and then fled, the police said.

title: Film: 'Blind,' Wiseman Documentary
description: FREDERICK WISEMAN, the lawyer turned film maker, made his first feature in 1967, the tough, harrowing, litigation-plagued ''Titicut Follies,'' about life in the State Prison for the Criminally Insane at Bridgewater, Mass. It seems he's scarcely taken a day off since. In the last 20 years he's made 18 highly personal documentaries, most of them about institutions (hospitals, the police, the Army, meatpacking, among other subjects) that shape and define American life.

title: The Pop Life
description: Cosby in Charge

title: N.H.L.'s '89-'90 Play May Include Soviet
description: The National Hockey League said yesterday that John Ziegler, the league president, would issue a statement tomorrow on the report that a tentative agreement was reached in Moscow Monday to have four Soviet clubs play against N.H.L. teams in the United States and Canada in two years in games that would count in the regular-season standing.

title: Caledonian Bid By S.A.S. Weighed
description: A bid by the Scandinavian Airlines System for the ailing British Caledonian Airways is being considered by the British Trade and Industry Secretary, Lord Young, a spokeswoman said. S.A.S., half-owned by the Swedish, Danish and Norwegian Governments and half privately owned, is interested in acquiring a 40 percent to 50 percent stake. The bid is competing with one from British Airways, but industry sources say Lord Young's office is supporting the S.A.S. bid.

title: Weed Trimmers Recalled
description: Black & Decker is recalling about 500,000 weed trimmers because of the potential for electric shock, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says. Involved are Model 82209, Type 1 and 2, and Model 82210 Type 1 and 2, 9-and 10-inch bump-feed trimmers, the agency said Monday. The wiring in some of them may be improperly located, allowing the handle tube to cut it, and lead to an electric shock hazard. Four instances of people being shocked have been reported. Owners of the trimmers were advised to stop using them and to take them to a Black & Decker Service Center for repair.

title: Golf to Benefit Special Olympics
description: Proceeds from the 1988 United States Women's Open golf tournament will be donated to the Maryland Special Olympics, Ricki Baker, the tournament's executive director, said today at a news conference at the Baltimore Country Club, which will be the site of the event July 18-24.

title: CUBANS IN ATLANTA RELEASE A HOSTAGE
description: A hostage was released tonight by Cuban inmates controlling the Federal penitentiary here amid uncertainty about why the 36-year-old correction officer was chosen and what obstacles remained to settling the eight-day prison uprising.

title: Koch Plans Veto Of Bill to Limit Business Rents
description: As the New York City Council ended two days of hearings on commercial rent control yesterday, Mayor Koch said he would veto the measure favored by the Council's strongest proponents of regulating the rents paid by commercial tenants.

title: G.M. Investment Seen In Fund for Takeovers
description: The pension funds of the General Motors Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are investing substantially more than $100 million each in a $1.1 billion fund to finance friendly takeovers, officials close to the deal disclosed yesterday.

title: A Labor Shortage May Hamper New England
description: After years of virtually full employment, some economists expect a labor shortage to crimp New England's growth next year and possibly for years to come.

title: Building Outlays Down 0.5%
description: Construction spending fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the first decline since March, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: OBSERVERS, BACK FROM HAITI, ASK O.A.S. TO RESTORE ORDER
description: An international delegation invited to observe the Haitian presidential election returned to Miami today and urged that the Organization of American States act promptly to restore order in Haiti.

title: Jackson Proves He's At Home in the N.F.L.
description: After Bo Jackson's team-record rushing performance and three touchdowns led the Los Angeles Raiders to a 37-14 victory over the Seattle Seahawks Monday night, the running back said that he had not given any thought to giving up his baseball career with the Kansas City Royals.

title: Irish Chief Continues Raids on I.R.A.
description: Concerned that political violence could re-emerge as a threat to the Irish republic, Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey presided uneasily today over two initiatives against the Irish Republican Army.

title: Joel Gordon, 78, Dies; Ex-Business Executive
description: Joel Gordon, a retired business executive and former civil servant, died of a heart attack Sunday in Silver Spring, Md., while on his way to Florida. He was 78 years old and lived in Rosbury, Conn.

title: How the Music Slows as the Last Dance Nears
description: Presidencies, like people, go through a natural aging process. And with 14 months left in office, the two-term Reagan Administration has clearly passed through middle age and is approaching retirement.

title: Real Estate; Rebuilding Pursued in Hempstead
description: IN the 1940's and 1950's Hempstead served as the downtown for many of the new Long Island communities then emerging throughout Nassau County, but it began to slip into decline as the county evolved into a highly prosperous suburban area.

title: Union Pacific Issue
description: The Union Pacific Corporation is offering $150 million of 9.60 percent notes, due in 1994, at a price of 99.90 to yield 9.619 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. Noncallable for five years, the notes are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.&P. and yield about eight-tenths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.

title: Syria, Isolated at U.N., Drops Terrorism Plan
description: The Soviet Union and third-world countries have joined Western nations at the General Assembly to defeat a move by Syria that many countries contended would confer legitimacy on international terrorism.

title: Dow, in a Rebound, Advances 8.79
description: An attempt at a strong rally fizzled on Wall Street yesterday, although stock prices did manage to recoup some of their losses from Monday's big retreat. But winners barely outpaced losers and trading activity was moderate - two signs of Wall Street's still uncertain footing.

title: Primerica's Rating Studied
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it might reduce the Primerica Corporation's senior long-term debt to a speculative BB rating from BBB currently.

title: Why It's Black Tie at White House
description: In tough bargaining for next week's summit meeting, Mikhail S. Gorbachev has already had to make one concession to President Reagan - the state dinner at the White House Tuesday will be black tie, not business dress as the Russians requested.

title: Sports World Is Taking Stock Plunge in Stride
description: Six weeks after the stock market crash wiped out half a trillion dollars of the nation's wealth, those who work in the multibillion-dollar sports industry are in broad agreement that the immediate impact on athletes and athletics was limited, that the short-range fallout has been negligible and that even in the face of a possible recession the long-term outlook remains bright.

title: Manila Journal; Land of 100 Tongues, but Not a Single Language
description: Back in high school, Ponziano Pineda was a dutiful boy who spoke only English. In fact, he was a monitor who fined his fellow students if he caught them speaking their indigenous language.

title: Stock-Index Contracts Delayed by C.F.T.C.
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has delayed approval of new stock-index futures contracts until it can complete its investigation into the Oct. 19 market collapse, commission officials said today.

title: Detroit Symphony Labor Negotiations Break Off
description: The 11-week-old labor dispute between the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and its musicians worsened today as negotiations for a new contract broke down and the symphony canceled its Christmas concerts.

title: Topics of The Times; At the Summit: Well, Well
description: For all the differences between Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan, the Gorbachev interview on NBC Monday night demonstrated a striking similarity.

title: For R.S.V.P., Try D.B.
description: Washingtonians have a way of dealing with invitations to parties they know will be either a crush of warm bodies or a crashing bore.

title: Bhopal Case Charges Filed
description: Investigators for the Government of India filed criminal charges today against the Union Carbide Corporation; Warren M. Anderson, its former chairman, and eight Indians stemming from the 1984 gas leak at a Carbide subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, India.

title: In the Locker Room
description: The Senate has been called the world's most exclusive club. Now comes word that it is much more like the locker room of a sports team.

title: Winter Drink: Pear Liqueur
description: PEACH may be the most popular fruit to flavor wines and spirits these days, but now that winter is approaching it is a pleasure to turn to the seductively rich taste of pear.

title: James Baldwin's Fire
description: Few writers so define a movement or a moment as did James Baldwin, who died yesterday at the age of 63. In the 1950's and 1960's, his searing essays on racial discrimination in the United States gave passionate voice to the emerging civil rights movement.

title: Funds' Assets Drop in Month
description: Assets of the nation's mutual funds plunged $53.2 billion in October, the month of the stock market's spectacular dive, to $774.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: John P. Doswell, Pilot, 64
description: John P. Doswell, a World War II combat pilot and the former director of operations for Flight Safety International, a pilot training school at La Guardia Airport, died of brain cancer Sunday at his home in Old Greenwich, Conn. He was 64 years old.

title: New Terms for Beirut M.P.'s
description: Lebanese lawmakers, who have not faced election for 15 years because of strife, renewed their terms in Parliament today for two more years.

title: Radiation Fears Infect Brazil After Accident
description: Two months after a major radiation accident shocked this Brazilian city, the threat of contamination, like an intangible plague, still reaches deep into the psyche of its inhabitants.

title: The Best Caviar's No Bargain This Year
description: CONSUMERS who look for seasonal caviar bargains are in for a disappointment this year, and those who indulge in this delicacy for the holidays may be shocked at prices posted by retailers across the country.

title: NEW YORK, IN POLICY SHIFT, WITHHOLDS RENT FROM WELFARE HOTEL
description: The Koch administration has for the first time begun withholding rent payments from an uncooperative welfare hotel in an effort to force it to correct dangerous health and safety code violations, city officials said yesterday.

title: Sir Terence Creates His Dream Store
description: Sir Terence Conran, the British entrepreneur who helped make contemporary design affordable, recalls that when he started his retail empire 27 years ago, his little London shop sat alongside a grand, bumptious example of commercial architecture called Michelin House. He admits he often eyed the Michelin building avariciously in those days, wondering what he might do if he ever got hold of it.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $63,555,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $3,780,000 and $13,319,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included an extraordinary loss of $3,000,000 from extinguishment of debt. The company said the income from discontinued operations in the latest 9 months includes an after-tax gain of $87 million, or $3.53 a share, from selling its 75 percent interest in All American Gourmet Co., and an after-tax provision of $15 million for possible losses which could ultimately result from resolution of a June arbitration decision concerning medical insurance coverage claimed by retirees of a business General Host discontinued in 1980. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results include an after-tax gain of $5,681,000, or 22 cents a share, from All American Gourmet's sale of one million additional shares to the public (later reduced to $4,230,000, or 16 cents a share, by additional fourth quarter taxes). The company also said year-ago 9 months include after-tax gains of $14,906,000, or 57 cents a share, from selling Milk Specialties Co. and the Hot Sam Cos. division (later reduced to $11,884,000, or 45 cents a share, principally by additional fourth quarter income taxes).

title: Savings Unit Gets New Chief
description: The American Continental Corporation has named William D. Hinz chairman and chief executive of its main operation, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, based in Irvine, Calif.

title: Officials Back Glass-Steagall Shift
description: Two prominent policy makers told the Securities Industry Association convention here today that they favored repeal of the Glass-Steagall Act under certain circumstances. The brokers seemed to take the idea in stride.

description: THE 200 guests at the recent 100th birthday party of the late modernist architect R. M. Schindler roamed freely through his landmark house on North Kings Road in West Hollywood -through open sliding doors of the historic 1922 structure, across lawns flush with the concrete floors.

description: The Reagan Administration is engaged in a novel effort to restrict the right of Americans to speak freely and receive information on an acute issue of public policy. In that effort it has the support of Senators Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, and others who are usually sensitive to constitutional rights. How can that be?

description: Dr. George D. Ruggieri, director of the New York Aquarium and Osborn Laboratories of Marine Sciences in Coney Island, died of cancer Tuesday at the home of a sister in Moorestown, N.J. He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

description: IT is accepted wisdom among technical analysts that the stock market must test its October low before it gives an indication whether the next meaningful move in prices is up or down.

Cherished Plants That Recall Friends
description: NOT all the plants in my garden come from nurseries or seed firms, although many do. At the beginning of every gardening year, when the catalogues arrive, I pore over them in search of the rare, the unusual and the foolproof. Not all of what I know about gardening comes from books, although my volumes on horticulture fill several shelves. They are some of the most valuable tools I possess.

description: The New York City Transit Police Department suspended the operations of its Decoy Unit yesterday amid accusations that officers in the squad had made dubious arrests on subway trains and platforms earlier this year.

title: Texas Bank To Report Large Loss
description: The First Republicbank Corporation, the largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss between $325 million and $350 million because of the worsening condition of the troubled Texas real estate market.

title: 27 Hurt as 2 Buses Collide
description: Twenty-seven people received minor injuries last night when two private buses collided at 41st Street and 11th Avenue. The police said the accident occurred at 6:20 P.M. when a Trailways bus returning to its garage at 525 11th Avenue collided with a Delaware-bound tour bus. The Trailways bus was traveling west on 41st Street, and the tour bus, owned by Gregg's Bus Service of Yorklyn, Del., was southbound on 11th Avenue en route to the Lincoln Tunnel. All the injured were aboard the tour bus.

title: Officer Aims at Pit Bull But Hits 2d Policeman
description: A New York City police officer was accidentally grazed in the head by a shot fired by a fellow officer who was aiming at a pit bull yesterday in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, the police said.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: HIS eyes narrowed and his skin became flushed until he took on the appearance of a three-foot-high Genghis Khan. Then came the wide-mouthed scream - a cry that combined defiance, frustration and the decibel level of an boom box. He was a little more than 3 years old, and he was throwing a tantrum in the checkout line of the supermarket.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Where Is Arbatov?
description: When the planes began arriving in Washington on Tuesday carrying the Soviet officials who will be spokesmen for Mikhail S. Gorbachev during next week's summit, one familiar face was missing - that of Georgi A. Arbatov, the head of the Soviet Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada, who is a key counselor to the Soviet leader.

title: NUTMEG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pork, China's No. 1 Meat, Will Be Rationed
description: For the first time in several years, pork, the principal meat eaten by most Chinese, will be rationed in Beijing and other cities.

title: U.N. Chief in Talks With Iranian
description: A senior Iranian official gave no significant indication today that Iran is prepared to move to end the seven-year-old Persian Gulf war during a new round of peace talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, according to diplomats and officials.

title: Farthest Space Objects Yet Are Found
description: A team of British and American astronomers has discovered two celestial objects much farther away from Earth than any previously known. The discovery of the two quasars, one 12 billion light years away, reinforces a growing belief that the outer limits of the observable universe have yet to be glimpsed.

title: GOLDTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
Benefit for AIDS Treatment
description: The performance artist Laurie Anderson, the writer William S. Burroughs and the composer Philip Glass are to be among those taking part in an evening of music and poetry on Dec. 16 at 8 P.M. at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. Proceeds from the the show will benefit the AIDS Treatment Project. Sponsored by Giorno Poetry Systems, the evening will also feature the John Giorno Band; Debbie Harry's Tiger Bomb with Chris Stein, and Husker Du. Tickets are $25. Information: 496-7070.

U.S. Looks to Haitian Military to Restore Election
description: Despite evidence that elements of Haiti's armed forces were involved in violence that forced the cancellation of presidential elections, the United States is still looking to the military to get the elections back on track, Administration officials and foreign diplomats say.

title: Reagan on Networks For Interview Tonight
description: President Reagan will appear on the major commercial television networks Thursday night in an interview to be conducted by the network anchors.

title: Piano: Artis Wodehouse In Gershwin
description: ARTIS WODEHOUSE, a pianist who has been something of a pioneer in research on early sound recordings, came to Merkin Concert Hall Monday night with the fruits of her work on George Gershwin. She has transcribed some of the song improvisations recorded by the composer for Columbia in the 1920's. Gershwin himself published 18 such arrangements in 1932 as ''George Gershwin's Song Book''; Miss Wodehouse's work (published by Warner Brothers Inc.) in effect adds eight slightly longer items to that collection.

title: Dollar Drops Late in Day Amid German Uncertainty
description: After closing higher in relation to the West German mark in European trading yesterday, the dollar weakened in later New York trading amid uncertainty about whether the Bundesbank would cut its main lending rate.

title: Chief's Post Is Added By Foxboro President
description: The Foxboro Company, a Massachusetts maker of measuring and control instruments, said yesterday that it had named its president and chief operating officer, Gary K. Willis, to the additional post of chief executive.

title: KUSTOM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
