title: Deaver Trial Hears Tape of Grand Jury Testimony
description: The prosecution in the trial of Michael K. Deaver, having called all its witnesses, today began playing for the jury more than five hours of tape recordings of the grand jury testimony that led to Mr. Deaver's indictment on five counts of perjury.

title: Debate Becomes Centerpiece For Coast-to-Coast Parties
description: They turned off the strobe lights and hushed the music, and, for an evening, the mood at the Dakota nightclub here turned from play to politics.

title: Alleco Dispute
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. disclosed that it might sell its stake in Alleco Inc., formerly the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, because of a disagreement with Alleco over terms of the $18.5 million in senior subordinated debentures controlled by the New York investment firm. Alleco shareholders approved a transaction today in which a management group agreed to acquire Alleco's food service business, the Service America Corporation, for $345 million in cash and the assumption of the debentures. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Salomon said it had asked the trustee of the debentures to file suit against Alleco to halt their transfer. The Alleco debentures are convertible at $21.50 a share. Salomon's holding, if converted, would equal 9.5 percent of the company's shares outstanding.

title: Rebuff to Palestinians Is Upheld
description: A Federal District Court judge today upheld a State Department order closing an information office connected to the Palestine Liberation Organization, rejecting claims that shutting it down was unconstitutional.

title: KEY RATES
INSIDE
description: Battling Dishonest Bills

title: Texaco Deadline Extended
description: A Federal judge, in a key ruling, today granted Texaco Inc. 40 more days to have the exclusive right to file a reorganization plan in its bankruptcy proceedings.

title: Vote Delayed At First City
description: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it would delay until early 1988 a shareholders' vote on the bank's proposed $1.5 billion restructuring plan.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sports People; Sentence in Suns Case
description: A 30-year-old waiter was sentenced yesterday to 30 days in jail on a charge stemming from the Phoenix Suns drug case.

title: Simon Weber, Editor Of Yiddish Newspaper
description: Simon Weber, a writer and editor at The Jewish Daily Forward for nearly 50 years, died Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Justice Dept. Denies Querying Views of Nominee
description: The Justice Department said today that Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's nominee for the Supreme Court, was not questioned in advance about how he would vote on issues likely to come before the Court.

title: Senate Aide Says He Found No Wrongdoing by Cuomo
description: A top staff member of a New York State Senate committee said yesterday that his investigations of contributions to two of Governor Cuomo's political campaigns had uncovered no evidence of wrongdoing by the Governor.

title: The Dozen's Debate: Splits Both Deep and Shallow
description: The first joint appearance of all the 1988 Presidential candidates revealed a Republican Party deeply divided over foreign policy and a Democratic Party with candidates more inclined to argue details of one another's proposals than to debate fundamental principles.

title: Advertising; Saatchi's Pretax Profits Up 77% in Fiscal Year
description: For the year ending Sept. 30, Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's largest advertising concern, reported that it had pretax profits of $193.5 million a gain of 77 percent from the previous year. Much of that increase can be attributed to the acquisition of Ted Bates Worldwide last year.

title: Testimony Ends In Attack Trial Of 4 Teen-Agers
description: Testimony ended yesterday in the three-month-old Howard Beach murder trial, and the judge said he expected jury deliberations to begin next Wednesday, after closing arguments Monday and Tuesday.

title: U.S. SAYS KREMLIN BROKE '72 TREATY ON MISSILE DEFENSE
description: The Reagan Administration charged the Soviet Union today with a new technical violation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. The American move was welcomed by Senate conservatives who have been concerned that the Administration has not been firm enough in dealing with Moscow.

title: NASA WILL LAUNCH UNMANNED CRAFT TO JUPITER IN 1989
description: NASA announced today that its long-delayed mission to Jupiter would be launched in 1989, and would include an audacious rerouting of the spacecraft to use the gravitational force of Venus and Earth to fling the craft like a stone in a slingshot toward Jupiter.

title: Advertising; Trillion Is Set To Return
description: When Hoyt (Pete) Spellman and Richard W. Lynch set up their publishing unit within the British-owned Moorgate Group here last April, they said that one of their priorities was to ac-quire magazines.

title: Dishonest Doctor Bills Provoke New Campaign
description: Insurance companies and Government officials have joined in a new effort to fight dishonest billing practices used by doctors to obtain payments for themselves or their patients.

title: A Warning About Toys That Can Catch Fire
description: When consumer advocates called in reporters for a preholiday toy safety briefing they couldn't demonstrate what they consider a major hazard because the fire marshal objected.

title: Watercolor Attributed To Hitler Brings $8,300
description: A watercolor attributed to Hitler has been sold for about $8,300 at an auction.

title: Milk Deliverers Strike Is Averted By a 10-Day Cooling-Off Period
description: A threatened strike by milk deliverymen and processing plant workers in New York City and surrounding counties was averted yesterday when a state mediator persuaded both sides to accept a cooling-off period of up to 10 days.

title: Environmentalists Push Chesapeake Changes
description: A Federal-state agreement on greater environmental protection of the Chesapeake Bay does not go far enough, 16 environmental organizations said today.

title: Personal Health
description: Jealousy is a feeling we all experience from time to time. In infancy, for instance, we might feel a twinge when we see father give mother a hug, or in childhood when a sibling seems to get more parental attention or a bigger cookie. In adolescence we might experience it when a rival wins the affections of our current heartthrob. And in adulthood it may surface when an ''undeserving'' colleague is promoted over us.

title: Kidnapped Colonel in Chile Reported Released in Brazil
description: Authorities said tonight that a Chilean army officer kidnapped three months ago by guerrillas had been freed in Brazil.

title: COMMUNICATION CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: JUDGE IN SEATTLE FINALLY SWORN IN
description: After a bitter 20-month confirmation process that led to a national furor over ''vote swapping'' and contributed to a Republican Senator's defeat, William L. Dwyer was sworn in Tuesday evening as a Federal district judge here.

title: CUC INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Two-Career Couples: A Delicate Balance
description: SANDRA BERNSTEIN, like millions of others in dual-career marriages, engages in the daily high-wire act of balancing work and family responsibilities. But unlike most of them, she is able to pinpoint the moment when she nearly slipped off the wire.

title: L-o-n-g Day's Journey
description: As packed houses attest, many New Yorkers have been eager to devote nine and a half hours to watching an international cast in ''The Mahabharata'' wrestle with an English translation of a French adaptation of an esoteric Sanskrit epic. Why?

title: Crisis in Haiti Leaves the Neighboring Dominicans Worried
description: Although the violence that shook Haiti over the last week has not spilled over into the neighboring Dominican Republic, the border between the two countries remained closed today and Dominican troops in the area were on alert.

title: Dow Up 6.63; to 1,848.97; Volume Dips
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday as investors remained cautious about the course of the economy, the dollar and the nation's budget and trade deficits.

title: U.S. to Test for AIDS in 30 Cities; Household Sampling Put Off
description: Federal health officials announced today that blood samples would be collected in 30 major cities in an effort to determine how far and fast the AIDS virus was spreading.

title: Some British Bank Ratings Are Lowered by Moody's
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday announced lower ratings for subordinated debt issues of two of Britain's major banks - National Westminster Bank P.L.C. and Barclays Bank P.L.C., or their affiliates.

title: Stock-Selling Scheme Cited
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a foreign investment firm and three British investors with violating Federal securities laws by manipulating the price of Bancroft Convertible Fund Inc. stock in the days before they made a tender offer for Bancroft last year.

title: Wood Gundy Cuts
description: The investment firm Wood Gundy Inc. said it was laying off 150 employees in Canada and overseas because of a slowdown in business since October's stock market collapse. Before the layoffs, the firm had about 2,100 employees worldwide, about 1,100 of whom were in Toronto, a spokesman, John Wegener, said. The layoffs, which took effect Tuesday and today, affect all departments.

title: Gross to Sue for Reinstatement as New York City Medical Examiner
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross notified the Koch administration yesterday that he would file suit to be reinstated as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, a position from which he was dismissed by Mayor Koch on Oct. 29.

title: Guard Fatally Stabbed in a Broadway Store
description: A security guard at a discount store on lower Broadway was stabbed to death yesterday morning by a man who had confronted him with a knife the previous day when the guard asked the man to check his bag at the door, the police said.

title: Nuclear Weapon Test Held
description: A nuclear weapon test that had been delayed because of a strike at the Nevada Test Site was detonated today, the second test announced by the Department of Energy in two days. Today's test, code-named Mission Cyber, was conducted 900 feet beneath the surface of Rainier Mesa, about 90 miles northwest of Las Vegas.The test, which had an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT, was termed successful by a spokesman for the department.

title: Most Treasury Rates Hold Steady
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday for most Treasury issues.

title: The Talk of the Pequot Reservation; Business Sense and Bingo: An Indian Tribe Prospers
description: The tepee jokes elicit only strained smiles from most residents here on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian Reservation. Tribe members hear them often from tourists and out-of-towners. They say it's a common misconception.

title: STREETWISE NEW BLUE BASKETS
description: THERE are roughly 25,000 litter baskets in the Naked City, and the blue polyethylene baskets of Michael Bimonte and Dennis Cleary are approximately 850 of them.

title: Sports People; 7 Drivers Suspended
description: When a long shot named Falcons Mann won the fourth race at Yonkers on Nov. 14, while the 4-5 favorite, Pan Am San, finished fifth, it raised eyebrows in the judges' stand. Yesterday, after reviewing tapes of the race and discovering irregularities in the pattern of betting, the judges suspended seven of the eight drivers in the race and the State Racing and Wagering Board announced that it had begun an investigation into the possible fixing of the race.

title: Bass-Macmillan
description: A group led by the Texas investor Robert M. Bass has raised its stake in Macmillan Inc. to 8.8 percent, from 7.5 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Bass did not amend his previous statement that he was acquiring the shares of the New York-based publishing company for investment purposes only.

title: CATALYST THERMAL ENERGY DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Manila Is Split Over Order To Oust Australian Reporter
description: The Philippine Government ordered the expulsion of an Australian reporter today, revoked the order, then reinstated it in a bureaucratic tug of war.

title: Iran Gamble For Chirac; At Home and Abroad, Issue Poses Problems
description: In reviving the idea of ''normalizing'' relations with Iran, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has taken a major political gamble at home and provoked accusations abroad that France has reverted to a policy of appeasing terrorists.

title: HOTEL MAIDS TOLD: DO FLOORS BY HAND
description: Nearly 60 chambermaids at Boston's luxurious Copley Plaza Hotel have been ordered to put aside their mops and start scrubbing floors by hand, angering union leaders who say washing floors on hands and knees is demeaning.

title: In the Capital, a Battle of the 'Brifinks'
description: In a city where ''spin control'' is an art form, the Soviet Government presented reporters today with four senior officials to field questions about everything from Afghanistan to Mikhail S. Gorbachev's wife, Raisa.

title: New York City Opera Sings in Taiwan
description: The New York City Opera performed 7,700 miles from home last night - in the just completed National Theater and Concert Complex in Taipei, Taiwan. The company's two-week, three-opera, 12-performance visit will keep audiences and singers busy - with five ''La Traviatas,'' three ''La Bohemes'' and four ''Student Princes.''

title: Gilbert Winner Over Connors
description: Sometimes it seems that the day Jimmy Connors retires will also be the day when all those street corner prophecies about the end of the world or California sliding into the Pacific Ocean will be fulfilled. The open era of tennis is 20 years old and Connors has been round for most of them, still playing at a level others aspire to.

title: Japanese 'Family Game' And Updated 'Plaza Suite'
description: SOMETHING familiar, something truly different - if nothing else, tonight's schedule is neatly balanced. For the familiar, there is an updated version of Neil Simon's ''Plaza Suite'' starring Carol Burnett. That's on ABC at 9 o'clock. At the other extreme there is WNET's ''Channel Crossings,'' a showcase for television from other countries. The centerpiece this evening, beginning at 11 on Channel 13, is a Japanese movie entitled ''The Family Game.''

title: Baker Said to Follow Risky Strategy To Bolster Economy in Election Year
description: By allowing the dollar to fall since the middle of October, the Reagan Administration, with the tacit approval of Congress, is betting that it can force major changes in the economic policies of other governments because it is unwilling to change its own policies nearly as much. Analysts said that the

title: ADDINGTON RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 9-month net results are pro forma because it had its initial public offering July 1.

title: Sharp Words in High Court On Hustler Parody of Falwell
description: The Supreme Court took up an important free- speech battle between the Rev. Jerry Falwell and the sex magazine Hustler today in the liveliest argument the Court has heard in recent memory.

title: COMEDY: THE KIDS IN THE HALL
description: THE Kids in the Hall, a promising five-man comedy troupe from Toronto, exude the fresh-scrubbed youthfulness and puppyish charm of a bunch of bright college kids doing skits in a dormitory lounge.

title: Good Fortune Provides Gifts For Neediest
description: Some people like to share good fortune by contributing to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Gannett TV Deal
description: The Gannett Company said it had reached agreement in principle to buy television stations in Greensboro, N.C., and Jacksonville, Fla., from Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. The stations are WFMY-TV, the CBS affiliate in Greensboro, and WTLV-TV, the ABC affiliate in Jacksonville. The purchase price of both stations is $155 million, the company said. The transaction, subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission, would bring to 10 the number of television stations owned by Gannett, which also publishes 90 daily newspapers, including USA Today.

title: Results Plus
description: Horse Racing Migliore Wins Again: Richard Migliore rode his fourth winner in five mounts yesterday when he guided Fine Timing to a front-running 5 1/2-length victory in the $33,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Fine Timing, a 3-year-old daughter of Well Decorated and Rhythmic Lady, covered the six furlongs in 1:11 2/5 as racing shifted to the winterized inner-dirt track. Fine Timing earned $19,800 for her owner, Viola Sommer, scoring her fifth victory in 13 career starts. Fine Timing paid $7.40 for $2 to win. N.B.A. Pistons 115, Bucks 105: Adrian Dantley scored 7 of his 25 points during an 11-2 third-quarter spurt last night to lead the Pistons at home. After a jump shot by Paul Pressey put Milwaukee ahead, 70-69, Dantley led the run that gave the Pistons an 80-72 lead with 4 minutes 46 minutes left in the third quarter. Milwaukee trailed, 88-80, entering the final period before an 11-5 spurt pulled the Bucks within 2 with 9:29 left. But Detroit then outscored Milwaukee by 23-14 the rest of the way. Randy Breuer led Milwaukee with a career-high 33 points. (AP) Cavaliers 104, SuperSonics 102: Mark Price and Phil Hubbard scored 22 points apiece as the Cavaliers withstood a fourth-quarter rally to win at home. Cleveland scored the first 13 points of the third quarter, including 7 by Price, for a 64-49 lead, and the Cavaliers led by 20 before settling for an 84-71 lead entering the fourth quarter. The Cavaliers led, 100-85, when Price made a jump shot with 7:02 remaining. The Sonics then outscored Cleveland, 13-0, in the next 5:35, with Dale Ellis scoring 6 points, to pull to 100-98 with 1:50 left.(AP) Pacers 108, Bullets 102: Wayman Tisdale scored 23 points, including 4 in a critical run in the closing moments last night, to lead the Pacers at home. The Bullets, who trailed by 64-53 at halftime, narrowed the deficit to 79-74 with 1:53 left in the third quarter on 7 straight points, capped by John Williams's 18-foot jumper. The Pacers retaliated with 7 straight points and 12 of the next 14 to lead, 91-76, with 9:28 left. (AP) N.H.L. Bruins 5, Whalers 3: Ken Linseman had two goals and an assist and Ray Bourque added three assists to spark the visiting Bruins. Doug Keans stopped 17 shots as the Bruins snapped a two-game losing streak and stopped Hartford's two-game winning streak. Randy Burridge, Billy O'Dwyer and Keith Crowder also scored for the Bruins. Sylvain Turgeon, Dave Babych and Scot Kleinendorst scored for the Whalers, who are 0-3-1 against their New England rivals this season.(AP) Red Wings 7, Oilers 4: Gerard Gallant scored two of Detroit's five first-period goals to lead the Red Wings over the visiting Oilers. Craig Simpson, who joined Edmonton on Nov. 24 from Pittsburgh in the Paul Coffey deal, scored three goals for the Oilers. It was the fourth loss in the last six games and second in two nights for the defending Stanley Cup champions who concluded a three-game trip. Detroit has won four straight for the first time since last January.(AP) Canucks 3, Canadiens 3: Second-period goals by Stephane Richer and Chris Chelios helped the Canadiens rally to a 3-3 tie at home. Petri Skriko scored two goals for the Canucks who took a 3-1 lead with three goals in the final five minutes of the first period.(AP) Blues 5, Blackhawks 1: Bernie Federko had a goal and three assists and Rob Ramage scored twice as the Blues extended the Blackhawks' streak without a victory on the road to 12 games.

title: Bofors Names Official
description: The Swedish arms maker A. B. Bofors, under police investigation for several bribery and smuggling scandals, said today that it had appointed a new managing director. Egon Linderoth, currently the deputy managing director of the car maker Saab-Scania A.B., will replace Bofors's acting chief, Per Ove Morberg, on March 1. title: S.A.S. Bid Fought
description: Richard Branson, the British entrepreneur whose holdings include Virgin Atlantic Airways, urged the Government today to refer a possible merger between Scandinavian Airlines System and British Caledonian Airways to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Lord Young, the Trade and Industry Secretary, is expected to decide this week whether the Scandinavian carrier can proceed with plans to bid for a significant stake in British Caledonian, which is looking for a buyer and is talking with Britain's largest airline, British Airways. Mr. Branson said in a letter to Lord Young that most other British airlines objected to the S.A.S. bid. ''Why should a foreign carrier be allowed to take control of some of the United Kingdom's best routes when there are plenty of British carriers eager and willing to fly them?'' he wrote. S.A.S. is owned in part by the Swedish, Danish and Norwegian Governments; the rest is held privately.

title: TV Reviews; 12 PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES' DEBATE, ON NBC
description: THERE was a wonderful opening shot; it looked like the bass section of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir. Twelve men in dark suits (save one, Bob Dole, who chose light blue) seemed ready to burst into song. In a way, they did; the television format demanded riffs and recitatives. Tom Brokaw had it right: ''It's not easy running for President of the United States.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THERE were surprisingly few gimmicks among the children's picture books I saw this year - very few pop-up books, or books that collapse into picture puzzles, or books with wheels on them, holes through them, or sound tracks in them, or books with parts the reader can feel, smell, hear or taste. The only noticeable departure from convention was a small outburst of didactic works that reached its nadir in a line of books called ''Disney's Classic Value Stories,'' with the title ''Walt Disney's Dumbo and the Magic Feather: A Tale About Confidence.'' Confidence? I thought ''Dumbo'' was a tale about a baby elephant with big ears who learns to fly by getting drunk. No such thing. In this bowdlerized version of the Disney classic, Dumbo falls asleep sober and has a dream of ''flapping his ears and flying.'' The next morning he wakes up high in a tree. Gone is ''Pink Elephants on Parade.'' I suppose this will help to lower the rate of alcoholism among 6-year-olds. Anyway, the following 10 outstanding titles teach no special values except the ability of their authors and illustrators to combine words and pictures gracefully.

description: Both the median price of a new house and the number of new houses sold fell sharply in October, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, evidence that the collapse of the stock market six weeks ago is beginning to affect other segments of the economy.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Dirt and old polish have accumulated on the surfaces of a teak table and a teak buffet that are about 20 years old. What is the best way to thoroughly clean this grime off and give the finish new life? A. One cleaning method is to scrub with a pad of very fine steel wool dipped in mineral spirits (paint thinner). Scrub a small section, and immediately wipe the surface with clean rags or paper towels. When the rag gets dirty, change to a clean one. You can also clean the finish with one of the ''refinishing liquids'' widely sold in paint and hardware stores.

title: Survey Shows Blacks Lag in Finishing College
description: The Census Bureau says whites are twice as likely as blacks to complete college, although there is a far smaller gap between the races in finishing high school.

title: School Earring Ban Upheld
description: A school district has the right to ban male students from wearing earrings while attending classes, a Federal district judge has ruled. The judge, Paul E. Plunkett, released an opinion Tuesday denying a request for a temporary injunction against the Bremen Community High School District by attorneys for 17-year-old Darryl Olesen of Midlothian, who contended that the ban violated his constitutional rights. School officials have said the ban was made because earrings could indicate youth gang activity.

title: Donn F. Eisele, 57; One of 3 Crewmen On Apollo 7 Mission
description: Donn F. Eisele, one of three astronauts who in 1968 flew the first manned flight of the Apollo spacecraft that eventually took man to the moon, died yesterday of a heart attack while on a business trip in Tokyo. He was 57 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Opera: 'Il Trovatore'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's Azucena problems took a fresh turn at Monday's performance of ''Il Trovatore,'' when the Soviet mezzo-soprano Elena Obraztsova made the first of her three hastily arranged appearances (Mignon Dunn sang the part last Friday; Shirley Verrett will take over for the final two performances later this month).

title: Salvador Rebels Kill Cattle
description: Leftist guerrillas herded about 200 head of prize cattle valued at $1.5 million into a corral and slaughtered them with machine guns at a ranch in eastern El Salvador, according to local press and rebel reports. Newspapers said about 80 guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front attacked the Hacienda Monte Grande just south of San Miguel on Sunday night. The rebel Radio Vencermos confirmed the incident but gave no details.

title: Swearing In of 2 Blacks Ends Era in Illinois City
description: Two black aldermen have been sworn into office here, concluding a 2 1/2-year legal and political conflict over discrimination in City Council representation.

title: Motion on Free Agency
description: The National Football League Players Association has filed a motion in Federal court in Minneapolis that would remove the major restraint to free agency when this season ends.

title: Yugoslav Flights to Israel
description: Adria Airways, a Yugoslav charter company, today began flights to Israel every two weeks. El Al Israel Airlines will begin flights to Yugoslavia early next year. ''We hope this will also bring about the resumption of diplomatic relations between the countries,'' the Israeli Transport Minister, Haim Corfu, said. Yugoslavia broke ties with Israel during the 1967 war in the Middle East.

description: The Transit Authority's wrongful-arrest scandal began unfolding four years ago when an assistant district attorney told a transit police officer that her testimony was needed in a jostling case.

title: Hawaii Bonds
description: Hawaii's $80 million of general obligation bonds were offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.80 percent in 1990 to 6.75 percent in 1997 and 7.70 percent in 2007 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds are rated Aa by Moody's and AA by S.&P.

title: Robertson Discloses His Finances
description: Pat Robertson today became the last Presidential candidate to disclose his personal finances, but his report yielded questions as well as answers.

title: ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31

description: A Department of Correction official asserted yesterday that Larry Davis, a 21-year-old murder suspect, lied when he testified that three correction officers at the Bronx House of Detention stood by and watched Monday evening as he was set upon by a fellow inmate with a razor blade.

description: DUCK and goose hunting has begun on Long Island, and the Nassau County Fish and Game Association has scheduled a waterfowling workshop that would benefit both veteran and beginning gunners.

description: A widely available medicine appears to offer alcoholics some protection from fatal liver disease even when they continue to drink moderately, a study has found.

description: Through more than 14 years of military rule, many of Chile's theater groups have been islands of criticism and opposition.

description: Amy Carter says she does not plan to return to Brown University here to complete her education.

title: Beatrice Deal Final
description: The TLC Group, a New York-based investment concern headed by Reginald F. Lewis, said that its $985 million purchase of the Beatrice International Food Company had been completed. TLC said that more than $340 million in high-yield bonds had been sold to finance the deal, which was arranged by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. It said some of those funds would go toward the operation of the company. The international food unit, based in Chicago, consists of 64 companies in 31 countries. It reported $2.5 billion in sales last year and operating income of $147 million. The company manufactures confectionery goods, snacks, processed meats, beverages and other food products and is engaged in wholesale and retail distribution of food, groceries and household products.

title: Court Order for Blinder
description: A Federal judge has ordered Blinder, Robinson & Company to comply by Monday with a Securities and Exchange Commission subpoena for records sought in an investigation of purported stock manipulation. In an opinion issued Nov. 24 but not released until this week, United States District Judge Harold H. Greene described the S.E.C.'s request as ''reasonably relevant to the inquiry.'' The judge called ''meritless'' the objections raised by Blinder, Robinson, a penny-stock underwriter based in Denver. The S.E.C. is seeking records on 16 companies that issued securities through Blinder, Robinson since August 1983.

description: Pierre Jean Baptiste came to a small Brooklyn storefront Tuesday morning hoping for news about his mother and brother, who were chased from the polls in a Haitian town Sunday morning.

title: New Club, Same Coffey Flair
description: WHEN the question is asked, Paul Coffey looks away momentarily, ruminatively rubbing the jaw his trademark beard once occupied. When he finally turns back, there is softness in his dark eyes. There are no tears. ''My seven years in Edmonton were fantastic,'' Coffey said in response to a query regarding regrets about the defenseman's recent transfer from the Oilers to the Penguins. ''I'll never be able to replay or repeat those. But the memories are good, and I'll never mess with them, either.''

title: Optimism at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company remains optimistic about the 1988 market because the lower stock market has not forced November car sales below levels a year earlier and truck sales have actually risen, the company's chairman, Donald E. Petersen, said. Mr. Petersen told reporters that he expected overall industry vehicle sales of about 15 million in 1988, with trucks making up one-third of the market. This would be about the same as is projected for 1987 and is higher than some industry predictions for 1988. As for Ford, Mr. Petersen said that despite some capacity constraints, the company could increase its market share beyond the 20.2 percent in cars and 29 percent in trucks expected in 1987. Mr. Petersen also said that Ford was considering using the Volkswagen plant in Westmoreland, Pa., that the German auto maker will close next year.

The hand-written paper spelling out the famous formula, E-mc#2, brought $1.2 million. The price was a record at auction for any manuscript sold in the United States and for any unillustrated text manuscript sold anywhere in the world.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; Let There Be Lights
description: The thing to do in New York at Christmas is to walk, anywhere in Manhattan where you can see the lights. This is the truly extraordinary thing about the city now - the way in which the energy of New York becomes, suddenly, frozen in millions of tiny points of perfect light. The light of Christmas in New York is different from the light of any other time, or of any other place; it is more precise, more delicate, at once overpowering in its sweep and gentle in the way it touches the eye. The tree at Rockefeller Center is by tradition the touchstone of the New York Christmas, and it deserves to remain so forever, although if the truth be told, I prefer the march of trees along Park Avenue, with their tiny lights of white, to the multicolored array at Rockefeller Center, for the tree at Rockefeller Center is really a bigger version of the kind that exists everywhere else, while the trees of Park Avenue could be nowhere but in New York.
