title: Art: Legendary Influence Of Black Mountain College
description: IN the history of the postwar avant-garde, the name Black Mountain College crops up repeatedly, framed in the golden glow of legend. The list of artists and writers who as students and teachers entered into the school's short, experimental existence is studded with impressive names. Founded in 1933 in the hills outside Asheville, N.C., by a group of disenchanted faculty members from Rollins College in Florida, Black Mountain placed the arts and, in its first years, especially the visual arts, at the center of its curriculum. One of its leading lights was Josef Albers, who arrived at Black Mountain late in 1933. Albers was fresh from the Bauhaus, just closed for good by the new Nazi Government, and he brought with him ideas and teaching methods that would eventually modernize American art education. Other teachers included the poet Charles Olson, who ran the school in its final years (it closed in 1957); Ben Shahn; Stefan Wolpe; Ilya Bolotowsky; Robert Motherwell; Merce Cunningham; John Cage, and Albers's wife, Anni, a textile designer who set up a weaving workshop based on the Bauhaus model. Clement Greenberg, Franz Kline, Alfred Kazin and Harry Callahan were among those who taught at the school's lively summer sessions. In October 1952, Shoji Hamada, the great Japanese ceramist, and Bernard Leach, his friend and British counterpart, taught a monthlong workshop.

title: The Stage: 'Eldorado,' At Festival
description: TWO years ago, with ''Dreamland Burns,'' Squat Theater seemed to be entering a new and fascinating phase. As written and directed by Stephan Balint, this was an imaginative study of the urban lost, as seen through a mixed media screen of theater and film. In '' 'L' Train to Eldorado,'' a new Squat Theater piece in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, Mr. Balint continues some of his stylistic explorations while creating a work that is both imprecise and dramatically commonplace.

title: Gephardt Urges a Law For Health Insurance
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt has called for legislation forcing businesses to offer health insurance to their employees, ''just as they must now provide a minimum wage.''

title: Cubans End 11-Day Prison Siege In Atlanta, Freeing All Hostages
description: Rebellious Cuban prisoners ended an 11-day uprising at the Federal penitentiary here early this morning and began freeing their 89 hostages.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CHRISTMAS AT THE MET

title: Vehicle Sales in Japan
description: Japan's domestic vehicle sales rose 20.3 percent, to 385,055 units, in November from a year earlier, an official of the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today.

title: TALKS ON GULF WAR FALTERING AT U.N.
description: Efforts to negotiate a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq appeared near collapse today after officials said Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar had made no progress in talks with a senior Iranian official.

title: Hospital Faces Discipline in Warhol's Death
description: State health officials have begun formal disciplinary action against the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in the death Feb. 22 of Andy Warhol.

title: Decision Not to Build as a Cause of Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: A Musical Duel
description: A re-enactment of the 1837 musical duel between Liszt and Thalberg will take place tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Steven Mayer will be the pianist; Alan Walker, a Liszt scholar, will provide commentary. The concert is to benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research. Tickets are $15. Information: 362-1911.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; The Way to the Heart
description: A restaurant writer's urban sextant always points to special dining spots, so when I play tour guide with friends who visit for the holidays, our wanderings seldom stray far from the shores of gastronomy. Sure, I may start the day with a stroll up festive Fifth Avenue, hanging a right at 57th Street, then along the gilded commercial stretch on Madison Avenue in the 60's and 70's, where the only way to avoid insolvency is to have your credit cards stitched to your pocket lining. When the fingers get numb and the stomach turns impatient, my navigation system points us to Alo Alo, the playful Italian cafe on Third Avenue at 61st Street, where you can get a blood-warming aperitif and perhaps an enticing platter of grilled vegetables or maybe a seafood pasta; an alternative, just a block away, is the new cafe at Arizona 206 (206 East 60th Street), where terrific Southwestern finger foods are the specialties.

title: Richard Goode
description: Richard Goode will give another in-stallment in his continuing perform-ances of the complete Beethoven piano sonatas Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y (at Lexington Avenue). Tickets are $12.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Restaurants
description: WHEN I spent a winter seven years ago in the ancient university city of Salamanca, Spain, I passed many evenings in a cluttered and boisterous little taverna called Covechuela. My affection for this place had little to do with the food, which was satisfying but hardly memorable. What attracted me were the warmth and ebullience of the place and the puckish owner, whose nightly performance included picking up coins left as tips, flipping them ceiling high, then catching them in his shirt pocket.

title: House Rejects Long Delay of Clean Air Deadlines
description: The House today overwhelmingly rejected an industry-backed drive to take the tough issues of air pollution and acid rain off Congress's agenda until at least 1989.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; 'Nutcracker' Magic
description: It's that time of the year when, as the song goes, in comes company. You get the fatal phone call from friends, and you curse your reputation for organizing imaginative jaunts. You think of and dismiss all usual and unusual possibilities. Panic sets in and simmers to a boil. And then it hits you. ''The Nutcracker.'' Of course. George Balanchine's classic version, performed by the New York City Ballet, at the New York State Theater through Jan. 3 (ticket information: 870-5570).

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Chango at City College

title: Top Democrat Asks Platform Of Few Words or Promises
description: The chairman of the Democratic National Committee is urging his party to write a short 1988 platform instead of a long one filled with promises to special interest groups.

title: At the Movies
description: The Origins of 'Walker'

title: Is This It? Kin Ask On Day 11
description: Minutes after she arrived home from work today, Zel Benton bundled up her three children and they all climbed into the family van. On the 15-minute drive to the Federal prison where her husband, Charles, was being held hostage for the 11th day, she wondered if this was the day she had been waiting for.

title: Gooden's Taunter Out
description: A Tampa police officer who was disciplined in the Dwight Gooden case last year has been dismissed because of repeated violations, Tampa police officials have said.

title: For Bush, a Strong Pat From the Chief
description: President Reagan, who has not given a formal endorsement to Vice President Bush's campaign for the White House, today gave him a firm political pat on the back.

title: New Lab Tests In Case of Nurse Show No Drug
description: New tests on the urine of a 73-year-old hospital patient revealed no signs of the paralyzing drug that a 25-year-old nurse is accused of injecting into him, the Suffolk County District Attorney's office said today. The nurse, Richard J. Angelo, is suspected of killing at least 10 people.

title: TV Weekend; 'Blunt - the Fourth Man,' on A&E
description: ON Nov. 15, 1979, Margaret Thatcher publicly named Anthony Blunt as the ''fourth man'' in a notorious spy ring that included Guy Burgess, Kim Philby and Donald Maclean, all three of whom had defected to the Soviet Union in 1951. Actually, Blunt had been confronted 15 years earlier by M.I.5, the British security agency, about his longtime role as a Soviet agent. Yet he was allowed to live elegantly in London, performing his duties not only as a distinguished art historian at the Courtauld Institute but also, reaching right into the palace, as Surveyor of the Queen's Pictures.

title: The U.N.Today; Dec. 4, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Chess Game a Draw
description: The 19th game of the world championship chess match ended in a draw yesterday in Seville, Spain, after determined efforts by the 36-year-old challenger, Anatoly Karpov, failed to budge the 24-year-old titleholder, Gary Kasparov.

title: CUOMO IS SEEKING TO COMBAT RUMORS
description: Most politicians would go to great lengths to avoid any mention of unfavorable rumors about them. But Governor Cuomo has done just the opposite in recent weeks, forcing an unusual public airing of rumors about him. The question being asked in political circles is why is he doing it? In interviews with Mr. Cuomo and his closest advisers, a portrait emerges of a Governor acting partly out of anger at rumors about possible ties to organized crime that have plagued him for years and that have flared anew as some people have speculated they might be the reason he announced he was not running for President.

title: Sihanouk Gets Pledge on Vietnam's Troops
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk met again today with Prime Minister Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian Government and said Hanoi pledged to pull its occupation troops from the country next year if the two could reach an agreement to settle their differences.

title: One Killed, 2 Injured In Queens House Fire
description: One person was killed and two others were seriously injured in a fire that swept through a three-story house in Queens late last night, the authorities said.

title: Court Record In Sex Case Is Examined
description: The administrative judge for the New York City criminal courts, beginning an inquiry into allegations that a judge humiliated the complainant in a sexual misconduct trial, examined the record of the trial yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1987
description: International

title: Standard Register Shift
description: Standard Register, the Dayton, Ohio, maker of business forms and systems, has decided to move its advertising to the Martin Agency in Richmond. The business-to-business account is in the $1 million to $2 million range. For the last 25 years, the advertising was handled by Griswold, a Cleveland-based Ross Roy subsidiary.

title:
Market Place;
Futures Board's View of Plunge
description: LEAD: THE Chicago Board of Trade, in a report to the Presidential commission investigating the stock market collapse, has defended its performance and sharply criticized the New York Stock Exchange's specialist system.

title: Dining Out Guide: Game
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARCADIA, 21 East 62d Street (223-2900) - **(Jan. 18. 1985) This cozy East Side restaurant has a little bar up front and a dining room ringed with mauve banquettes. The menu melds the best of American regional cuisine without becoming cute. Appetizer choices include grilled leeks in puff pastry with onion marmalade and chive butter as well as corn cakes with caviars and creme fraiche. During the game season, you might order medallions of venison with cranberry-black pepper sauce and yellow turnip tower; grilled duck steak with wild mushroom and port sauce and wild rice pancakes and kale; or sauteed quail on wild-bean and swiss chard ragout. It makes sense to save room for dessert - the chocolate bread pudding with brandy custard sauce and flourless chocolate terrine, for example. Dinner prix fixe $55. Fridays, noon and 1:45 P.M. seatings and 6 to 10 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 10 P.M.: closed Sundays. BRIVE, 405 East 58th Street (838-9393) - **(Sept. 5, 1986) A romantic town house with a relatively quiet and comfortable atmosphere provides the backdrop for some arresting food. You might begin with noisette of rabbit with artichoke polenta or a torte of duck and ginger. For a main dish, a number of game dishes are available: roast saddle of venison with a chestnut tart; stuffed pigeon, and grilled Muscovy duck breast with three cranberry purees. Prix fixe $50. Fridays and Saturdays, 6 to 10 P.M.; closed Sundays. THE FOUR SEASONS, 99 East 52d Street (754-9494) - ***(Nov. 22, 1985) The lavish Pool Room with its graciously appointed tables, lofty foliage and illuminated marble pools is for romance and extravagance. To start you might order the pheasant consomme, fettuccine with wild truffles or a game-bird pate. During the game season main dish options include fillet of venison sauteed with apples and red cabbage; grilled quails with mustard and sage, and breast of pheasant baked with mustard and filberts. Entrees $34 to $42.50. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 5 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 5 to 11:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL, 12 East 12th Street (620-4020) - ***(Oct. 4, 1985) The multi-tier dining room with its tall columns and high ceilings provides a spacious and comfortable backdrop for some alluring and visually dazzling contemporary cooking. Starter options are squab salad with couscous, croutons and curried vinaigrette; duck confit with lettuces, smoked bacon and lemon-mustard vinaigrette, and guinea hen and foie gras terrine with lettuces, lentils and croutons. For the winter menu, entree choices include Moulard duck breast with figs, turnips and green peppercorns; roast squab over wild mushrooms with Swiss chard, spatzle and mustard butter, and Red deer with sauteed green apple and lingonberries. Dinner entrees $22 to $26. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11:30 P.M.; Sundays, 5 to 10 P.M. NANNI IL VALLETTO, 133 East 61st Street (838-3939) - **(May 16, 1986) One of the more splendiferous Italian restaurants in town is this plush establishment with oversize mirrors and comfortable banquettes. The kitchen is capable of turning out some spectacular pastas - bow-ties tossed with a melange of diced tomatoes, basil, zucchini and eggplant or thin spaghetti with minced shrimp, clams and fresh herbs. And during the season, the menu offers roast quail, venison, pheasant and wild boar prepared with celery, onion, carrots and Barrolo wine. Dinner entrees $27.50 to $30. Fridays, noon to 3 P.M. and 5:30 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays, 5:30 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. RESTAURANT RAPHAEL, 33 West 54th Street (582-8993) - **(Nov. 28, 1986) The atmosphere is refined and rustically elegant at this midtown restaurant; pale yellow walls alternate with pastoral murals in the long rectangular dining room. The chef has a controlled and classically oriented French style, leavened with a sharp eye for presentation. Starters include seafood ravioli with a light tarragon sauce; marinated salmon with ginger, and salad of duck confit. The winter menu features grilled marinated venison with apples, cranberry and apricot as well as breast of pheasant, which can be roasted with wild mushrooms or stuffed with sauteed pears and port wine. Dinner entrees $19.50 to $28. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 to 10 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 10:30 P.M.; closed Sundays. What the stars mean, page C2O.

title: What It's Like To Be In Hell
description: The illusions end on Damon Street, all of them: liberal, Reaganite, black solidarity, beneficent government, the innocence of man. Here are the Henry Horner Homes, 19 10-story buildings, red brick outside and cinder block inside, erected with Federal public housing money and managed by the Chicago Housing Authority. Vacant lots surround them. Most of the broken windows have been replaced with plastic sheeting. The people who live there - well, listen.

title: SNAPSHOTS TAKEN AS CHEMICALS BOND
description: Using pulses of light lasting only one-millionth of one-billionth of a second, scientists at the California Institute of Technology have invented an instrument to detect the subtle sequences of events that occur in some ultra-fast chemical reactions.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Literatary Coincidence
description: Hard on the heels of Russian art comes Russian literature.

title: Carlyle E. Maw, 84, State Dept. Legal Aide
description: Carlyle E. Maw, a former chief legal adviser and Under Secretary of State in the State Department, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 84 years old.

title: Nets Sign Moore For Help at Guard
description: The bruised and battered Nets, losers of 7 consecutive games by a total of 111 points and in need of help at several positions, yesterday signed Johnny Moore, a free-agent guard.

title: Drug Tests for Racers
description: Nascar stock-car drivers will be involved in a drug-testing program in 1988, according to an announcement yesterday by Bill France Jr., the organization's president.

title: On Stage
description: New Amsterdam's New Start

title: States That Require AIDS Education in School Triple in Six Months
description: The number of states mandating education about AIDS in the public schools has tripled in the last six months, with 17 states and the District of Columbia now requiring such instruction, the National Association of State Boards of Education said today.

title: TIGER MOSQUITOES FOUND IN 17 STATES
description: The hardy Asian tiger mosquito, an aggressive biter and a carrier of disease, has spread to 17 states since arriving in Houston aboard used tire casings two years ago, prompting new Federal inspections of used tire imports, health officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Monday about parishioners' efforts at St. Luke's Church in the South Bronx to help homeless people described a church shelter program incorrectly. The Partnership for the Homeless, a private multidenominational coalition, provides food and operating assistance. New York City government provides beds, linen and transportation.

title: Seoul's Growing Exports
description: South Korea's rapidly growing electronics industry has become the country's second business sector to exceed $10 billion in annual exports, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today. Ministry officials said that exports of Korean electronic products since January reached $10.02 billion on Wednesday and were expected to climb to $11 billion by year-end. Last year, electronics exports totaled $6.7 billion. Korean textile exports since January reached $10 billion on Nov. 11.

title: 3 LATE BRUIN GOALS OVERCOME RANGERS
description: Ray Bourque may have surrendered his No. 7 to Phil Esposito tonight and watched it be retired to Boston Garden's rafters without him, but collectively the Bruins were not in so giving a mood. Their seven-minute rally at the game's end brought them a 4-3 victory against Esposito's dejected Rangers.

title: Serving America's Interests
description: A serious battle is building here on arms control agreements with Moscow, but it won't really be about what appears on the surface.

title: Do Justice to Judges, Too
description: A puzzle ran through the recent controversies over President Reagan's first two candidates for the Supreme Court vacancy. Robert Bork, whose fight lasted four months, and Douglas Ginsburg, who withdrew a few days after being chosen, are judges on the prestigious United States Court of Appeals in Washington, only one step below. How could they have got there, by Presidential nomination and Senate confirmation, with so many unanswered questions that they could not be confirmed for the High Court?

title: Thank You, Mr. Gorbachev
description: If you still have any doubts, misconceptions or illusions about what Mikhail Gorbachev wants and plans for the Soviet Union, don't blame him. He has laid it out as clearly as anybody has the right to expect.

title: Watersons, Folk Singers From Britain
description: FORTY years ago, Norma, Lal and Mike Waterson would spend their evenings in their parlor in Yorkshire, England, singing along with their grandmother - reprising ballads, hunting songs, hymns and carols that their grandmother probably sang with her parents. One family member would take up the tune; the rest would join in, and if the melody reached too high or too low, they'd choose a harmony note instead.

title: Wall Street Bonuses Take a Hit
description: Workers on Wall Street are learning that a bonus is exactly what the word implies: a payment or reward in addition to salary that is by no means guaranteed.

title: Rare Respighi Opera at Carnegie
description: Tonight at Carnegie Hall, New York will have one of its infrequent opportunities to assess Ottorino Respighi (1879-1936) as a composer of opera, a sphere in which his relative obscurity is a matter of some irony.

title: Art: Mughal Treasures at the Met
description: SOME of the most touching images now on view in New York are in a small format and a small place (the Kevorkian Gallery in the Islamic section of the Metropolitan Museum of Art). Initiated by a royal personage who was roughly the contemporary of Shakespeare and Caravaggio, they were admired and collected by people as various as Rembrandt, the Empress Maria Theresa of Austria and William Morris, the English poet, painter and all-purpose designer. They have to do with birds and battles, bears and dervishes, lions and great statesmen, exemplary administrators and boy princes already tainted by greed for possessions. Calligraphy often plays a leading role in them, and their painted borders can be as seductive as the images themselves.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: Assets of the nation's 411 money market mutual funds decreased $237.2 million, to $261.85 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds were down $643.2 million, to $73.53 billion. Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $741.9 million, to $79.60 billion. The 93 broker-dealer funds decreased $335.9 million, to $108.71 billion.

title: Decision Not to Build as a Cause of Homelessness; Tale of a Frog
description: To the Editor:

title: Clean Air Needs a Federal Gorilla
description: Seventeen years after passage of the Clean Air Act, 80 million Americans still live with unhealthy amounts of smog and ozone. The plan was to control ozone pollution by the end of this year, but last month the Environmental Protection Agency announced yet another extension and the waiver of penalties for all but a few cities. The House's overwhelming refusal yesterday to roll back the Clean Air Act's deadlines an additional 19 months sends a clear signal through the fog: Breathable air deserves a higher priority.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Old Gold at Sothebys

title: Corrupt or Not, Ex-Mayor Gets Hero's Welcome
description: Everyone loves to make jokes about the stupendous history of corruption in Hudson County. Say what you want, people here know how to welcome home a politician from prison.

title: Noble Buys Tennant
description: Noble & Associates of Springfield, Mo., has acquired the Don Tennant Company in Chicago and has merged it into its Noble & Associates agency there to form Noble Tennant, a shop with $25 million in billings. Robert B. Noble, founder and chairman of the parent company, will be president and chief executive in Chicago.

title: Texas Banks Allowed to Cross Lines
description: The Comptroller of the Currency in Washington today opened the door for nationally chartered banks in Texas to cross county lines to open branches.

title: Record Price for a Work by O'Keeffe
description: Georgia O'Keeffe's ''Black Hollyhock With Blue Larkspur,'' from about 1930, was sold yesterday at Sotheby's for $1.9 million. It was the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist, in a record sale of American art at Sotheby's.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; Sounds of the City
description: A music critic's guests should expect long, late, peripatetic evenings. While the sun's up, they're on their own - although they should savor the sonic smorgasbord that is New York, from the white-noise barrage of the subways to the polyphony of languages and accents everywhere.

title: Bass Is Cleared To Buy Bell Stock
description: An investment group led by the wealthy Texas investor Robert M. Bass has received Federal antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the Bell & Howell Company to 25 percent, from 16.2 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Bass said he received notice of the clearance on Tuesday.

title: Role in '85 Hijacking Is Denied
description: An aide to Justice Minister Nabih Berri today denied a statement by a terrorist suspect in the United States that Mr. Berri ordered a 1985 plane hijacking.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Congress; Name That Legislator
description: Congressional trivia has its aficionados. Here are some questions from a quiz devised by Alan Ehrenhalt, political editor of Congressional Quarterly and editor of a recently published book, ''Politics in America: The 100th Congress'' (Congressional Quarterly).

title: Bork Assails Senators On Confirmation Fight
description: Judge Robert H. Bork said tonight that the Senate appeared to misunderstand its role in the confirmation of Supreme Court nominees, and he blamed politics for his rejection.

title: Kraft Says It Will Sell Its Duracell Division
description: Kraft Inc., said yesterday that it planned to sell its Duracell Inc. battery division in order to focus more heavily on its core food businesses.

title: Steinbrenner Talks With Angels' Witt
description: George Steinbrenner, once the prime pursuer of star free agents, passed up the chance to sign Jack Morris a year ago, but the Yankees' owner may have different thoughts about another free-agent pitcher this year.

title: Goldome Raises Leslie Fay Stake
description: Goldome, the Buffalo-based savings bank, said it had raised its stake in the Leslie Fay Companies to 21.1 percent, from 17.8 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Goldome continued to say that it had acquired the shares of the New York-based apparel concern for investment purposes only.

title: Dance: Alvin Ailey Company Salutes Dunham
description: ''THE MAGIC OF KATHERINE DUNHAM'' is exactly that. One salutes the vision of Alvin Ailey for undertaking and realizing as major a project as this fantastically staged full-evening program of sassy, colorful and vibrant revivals by America's most famous black dance pioneer.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; It's Not Just Books
description: As a tour guide, I rate zero. It is my perception of myself that I know nobody, never go out, have a bad case of agoraphobia, cannot recognize even the most famous buildings and like to believe I am invisible, even when crossing the road. I have no brilliant ideas for people from out of town. Nor has any one of them ever been so foolish as to expect me to have any.

title: Juan Alberto Melgar Castro, General, 52
description: Juan Alberto Melgar Castro, a general who served four years as Honduras's chief of state, died of a heart attack Wednesday. He was 52 years old.

title: Yale Music Spectrum
description: The Yale Music Spectrum will perform works by Mozart and Beethoven tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall (129 West 67th Street). Tickets are $9. Information: 362-8719.

title: U.N. Aid for Drought Area
description: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said today that it would give $23.5 million in emergency aid next year to help feed refugees and drought victims in four African countries, Botswana, Malawi, the Sudan and Somalia.

title: N.C.A.A. Fund for Former Athletes
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will set up a $9 million scholarship fund for athletes who did not graduate but decided later to return to school, according to Dick Schultz, the executive director of the N.C.A.A.

title: Economic Scene; Germans Move, But Cautiously
description: WEST GERMANY's Government and its central bank, the Bundesbank, are at last moving to stimulate the national economy. But the question remains whether the actions proposed are too little, too late and too grudging to restore confidence that international cooperation can restore stability to exchange rates and prevent a deterioration of the world economy.

title: Schubert Chorus
description: The Schubert Music Society Chorus and Orchestra, conducted by Jon Bauer, will perform works by Bellini and Vivaldi Sunday at 3 P.M. at the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters (632 West 156th Street). Tickets are $5 and $10. Information: 927-5066.

title: Gorbachev a Hit With the American Public. . .
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has impressed the American public, winning twice as many favorable opinions as negative ones, and has persuaded a solid majority that he is opening up the Soviet system.

title: 'Words of Zen Masters,' At French Institute
description: An actor and two musicians from the current Brooklyn production of ''The Mahabharata'' will perform ''Interrogations, or Koan, the Words of the Zen Masters'' at the French Institute-Alliance Francaise (22 East 60th Street) tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. and Monday at 6 P.M.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Stage-Managing
description: One member of the White House advance team says he and his colleagues are faced with a quandary over how much of their expertise to impart on behalf of Mr. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa.

title: Alcohol Is No Remedy For Heart Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Newspaper Is Snared; Did Gandhi Spin the Web?
description: Can it be mere coincidence? That is the question here.

title: Text of the Accord in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Friday, Dec. 3 - Following are the eight points of the agreement signed early this morning between the negotiators for the Government and the detainees. It was read to reporters by by Gary Leshaw, an attorney for the Atlanta Legal Aid Society, who was present during the negotiations.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Effort on Gulf Falters

title: EMERSON QUARTET
description: The Emerson String Quartet will perform works by Mendelssohn and Beethoven tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $14. Information: 570-3949.

title: Ben W. Lewis, Economics Professor, 87
description: Ben W. Lewis, Avery professor emeritus of economics at Oberlin College, died Tuesday of a heart attack in Cleveland. Professor Lewis, an economist in the Roosevelt Administration, was 87 years old.

title: Luis Federico Leloir, Chemist, 81
description: Luis Federico Leloir, the Argentine who won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1970, died Wednesday night, a family spokesman said. He was 81 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Pasternak Coincidence
description: Everything is coming up Russian these days in Washington.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Women and the Summit
description: Under the auspices of Women for a Meaningful Summit, a group of political women will converge in the capital this weekend for a host of activities.

title: 2 First Ladies: Will One Be Second Fiddle?
description: The East Wing is in a swivet over Raisa Gorbachev - again.

title: Deregulator Chosen For Commodity Post
description: Wendy Lee Gramm, one of the Reagan Administration's most vigorous deregulators, has been selected to head the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the White House announced yesterday.

title: Film: 'Walker,' Starring Ed Harris
description: TAKING the true story of William Walker, the American adventurer who once ruled as the self-declared president of Nicaragua (1856-57), the director Alex Cox and the writer Rudy Wurlitzer have made ''Walker,'' a hip, cool, political satire that's almost as lunatic as the title character.

title: Relics of Carthage in New Exhibition
description: THIRTEEN centuries have elapsed since the Islamic invasion of North Africa obliterated ancient Carthage. But reminders of the striking blend of artistic genius and institutional cruelty that characterized the Carthaginians have survived, and a new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History brings both the beauty and the horror of Carthage into sharp focus.

title: Aiding Needy Is Tradition for Donors to Fund
description: Giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has become a holiday tradition for many people. The 76th annual appeal opened last Sunday and will continue through February, Elizabeth L. Weiler, who is 82 years old, says proudly that she has contributed to the fund ''ever since the day it started, and I never missed a year.'' Ms. Weiler, a native New Yorker, had heard her mother talk about the Neediest Cases and decided to make her own contribution.

title: Will Shearson-Hutton Be No. 1?
description: For years, executives at Wall Street's big retail brokerages have worked at creating a financial powerhouse that can create imaginative deals with one hand and market them far and wide with the other.

title: Names of Fame
description: Eleven former all-America football players and two coaches will be inducted into the National Football Foundation's College Hall of Fame Tuesday at the organization's annual awards dinner.

title: Triborough Prices Refunding Bonds
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority moved quickly yesterday to price tentatively about $205 million in refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 8 1/4 percent for an issue due in 2012.

title: In Salvador, Harried Right Courts Army
description: In the face of a strong attack from President Jose Napoleon Duarte, who has charged them with complicity in political assassinations, Salvadoran rightists are urgently seeking help from their traditional ally - the army.

title: Productivity Up by 3.6%
description: The nation's non-farm businesses increased their efficiency in producing goods and services by 3.6 percent from July through September, the best improvement since the first quarter of 1986, the Labor Department said today.

title: Teachers' Group Withholds '88 Endorsement
description: The National Education Association, which played a major role in the 1980 and 1984 races for the Democratic nomination, today decided against an early endorsement in the 1988 campaign.

title: Becker Works To Beat Connors
description: He isn't a boy wonder any more, flashing the smile that earned the affection of the fans at Wimbledon in 1985 when he won the biggest tournament of all on the strength of a game called serve and swagger. Tennis has become more like a job than a game for Boris Becker, and like everyone else in the work force, there are some days when he would prefer to stay in bed.

title: Art: Narrative Works Of Vincent Desiderio
description: VINCENT DESIDERIO is a 32-year-old artist, born and trained in Philadelphia, who makes large narrative paintings in a meticulous Old Master style. Using melodramatic stories of adventure and crime, he formulates intellectual messages similar to those of Mark Tansey, who paints esoteric allegories, and John Bowman, who seeds his cryptic paintings with in-references and art jokes.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Post A 9.9% Rise
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks rose 9.9 percent in the last 10 days of November, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Bridge: Sometimes, Even an Expert Thinks Twice on First Trick
description: If someone sat behind a player and recorded the length of time he took to play each card, a graph of the results would provide a good indication of his level of ability.

title: A Dining Strategy For Before and After A Broadway Play
description: ORCHESTRATING a night on the town, such as dinner and a show, is much like directing a play. The script may be solid, the casting superb, the set inspiring - but if your timing is off, the whole effort collapses like a leaky balloon.

title: U.S., Reducing Dues Arrears To U.N., Pays It $90 Million
description: Vernon A. Walters, the United States chief delegate, delivered a check for $90 million to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today in partial payment of American dues to the United Nations, American officials said.

title: Correcitons
description: A list of college guidebooks on the Education page on Wednesday omitted three books in some editions.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about parishioners' efforts at St. Luke's Church in the South Bronx to help homeless people described a church shelter program incorrectly. The Partnership for the Homeless, a private multidenominational coalition, provides food and operating assistance. New York City government provides beds, linen and transportation.

title: Marathon Misconduct
description: Fred Lebow, the race director of the New York Marathon, announced yesterday that six runners in the race this year had been disqualified for cheating. Last year, 25 disqualifications were made, including one in which the men's second-place finisher, Antoni Niemczak of Poland, tested positive for use of steroids. Lebow said all of the first 10 male and female finishers in this year's race had passed a drug test administered by The Athletics Congress.

title: Hutton-Shearson Deal Announced
description: After clearing away last-minute problems on financial terms, Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. and the E. F. Hutton Group Inc. announced yesterday, as expected, that Shearson had agreed to buy Hutton for about $962 million.

title: Fire Sprinkler System Bill
description: A bill was introduced in the House today that would require all hotels and motels to install fire sprinkler systems in rooms and public areas. The bill was inspired by the fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel in Puerto Rico last New Year's Eve in which 96 people died. The hotel did not have a sprinkler system.

title: Pacifying Afghanistan
description: LEAD: The Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting offers a momentous opportunity for a breakthrough in the increasingly promising United Nations negotiations on a Soviet force withdrawal from Afghanistan.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; Modern Music Mecca
description: Music lovers flock to New York for all sorts of reasons, operatic, symphonic or otherwise. But believe it or not, there are some out-of-towners who look toward New York with envy and excitement as a mecca for new music at its most diverse. I know: that's what I did myself, years ago.

title: Youths Seem Undeterred By Get-Tough Crime Law
description: The New York Legislature was in a punitive mood, and responding to public outrage over a few brutal subway crimes committed by teen-agers barely old enough to be in high school, when it passed a law subjecting those as young as 13 years old to prosecution as adults.

title: Soviet Series Not Firm
description: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said yesterday that no specific agreements had been reached to permit Soviet teams to play in the league. Ziegler met with Soviet hockey officials in Moscow this week. According to a report earlier this week in The Toronto Globe and Mail, a tentative agreement had been reached to allow four Soviet teams to play in the N.H.L. at the start of the 1988-89 season, and the games would count in the standings.

title: Dealer in Bronx Indicted in Plot To Resell Guns
description: A 35-year-old Bronx man was indicted yesterday in connection with what prosecutors called a scheme to resell at least 1,000 handguns he had ordered legally by mail as a federally licensed dealer.

title: RESULTS
description: N.B.A. Hawks 102, Bullets 94: Kevin Willis scored 23 points and Cliff Levingston had 21 to lead visiting Atlanta to a victory over Washington last night. Levingston, starting in place of the injured Dominique Wilkins, had 13 points in the first half, during which the Hawks opened a 45-30 lead. Willis added 10 points in the first half, and Atlanta went on to fight off Washington's comeback attempt in the second half.

title:
Advertising;
Hal Riney, In Surprise, Drops Gallo
description: LEAD: HAL RINEY & PARTNERS resigned the E.&J.; Gallo Winery account yesterday after seven years of award-winning work on its behalf.

title: Israelis Face Charges Over Raid
description: Israel is preparing to court-martial some military men in the wake of an attack by a Palestinian guerrilla who killed six soldiers after he flew a motorized hang glider from Lebanon, the army announced.

title: Jacques Travers, French Teacher, 62
description: Jacques Travers, an instructor of French at Brooklyn College and founder of a Roman Catholic house for the homeless, died of cancer of the esophagus Nov. 23 in Elbeuf, France. He was 62 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Construction Shortcuts Caused Fatal Bridge Collapse, Panel Says
description: Construction shortcuts contributed to the bridge collapse on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that killed 10 people last April, New York State's final report on the disaster stated today. The report confirmed earlier findings that erosion around the base of one of the bridge's piers had led to the collapse.

title: U.N. SEEKING EMERGENCY AID TO HELP FAMILIES IN LEBANON Special to The New York Times
description: Secre-tary General Javier Perez de Cuellar appealed today formore than $85 mil-lion in emergency aid to save 250,000 families facing starvation, poverty and disease in Lebanon.

title: New Chief Executive For Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced its expected management transition yesterday. Thomas G. Pownall, who kept the company out of the hands of raiders, relinquished the chief executive's post to Norman R. Augustine, a former Under Secretary of the Army and author of a ''Murphy's Law'' type of book called ''Augustine's Laws.''

title: Get in Step, Verrazano
description: To the Editor:

title: No One Allowed Davis Slashing, Official Testifies
description: A high-ranking New York City corrections officer denied yesterday that he or any of his colleagues at the Bronx House of Detention had ever willfully allowed another inmate to attack Larry Davis, a 21-year-old murder defendant.

title: Court Rejects Appeal of Pakistani Who Cited North in Arms Deals
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday affirmed the conviction of a Pakistani arms dealer who said he had sold arms to Iran under the secret authorization of Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North.

title: Sandinistas and Contras Open Talks on Peace
description: For the first time since the Nicaraguan civil conflict began nearly six years ago, officials of the Sandinista Government held peace talks today with a delegation representing United States-backed guerrillas.

title: 900 Evacuated After a Leak Of Chemical in Derailment
description: Up to 31 railroad cars overturned near here, and a leak of a chemical from a derailed tanker prompted the evacuation of 900 residents, officials said today. No injuries were reported.

title: Ruder Resisting Glass-Steagall Repeal Effort
description: David S. Ruder, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today became the only head of a major financial regulatory agency to withhold support from efforts in Congress to repeal the Glass-Steagall Act.

title: Addendum
description: * Working Woman magazine will increase its circulation rate base by 5.9 percent, to 900,000, and its rates by more than 11 percent, beginning with the March issue.

title: 60 to 75 Soviet Citizens Get Permission to Leave Country
description: In a pre-summit human rights gesture of unusual scope, Soviet officials told Western diplomats today that they were approving the emigration requests of 60 to 75 Soviet citizens, the diplomats said.

title: New Charges Raise Old Question
description: In the dangerous world of the decoy police officer -in which officers, seeking to attract muggers, disguise themselves as helpless old ladies or derelicts sleeping in the subway - there have been heroes and heroines. And there have also been casualties.

title: Haig Says Gorbachev Negotiates Because Soviet System Is Failing
description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. declared yesterday that the Soviet Union was willing to negotiate a reduction in nuclear arms because it was ''in trouble economically, technologically, ideologically and demographically.''

title: Arms to Iran Weren't for Hostages, Reagan Says
description: President Reagan, backing away from his own previous statements on what he called ''the Iran-contra so-called affair,'' said today that it was not a scandal, ''and never at any time did we view this as trading weapons for hostages.''

title: People
description: * Richard Ellington has joined Lotas Minard Patton McIver as executive vice president for account management.

title: Brokerage Said to Quit Coliseum Project
description: Salomon Brothers has withdrawn as a co-owner and principal tenant of a huge commercial and residential development planned for Columbus Circle, throwing the future of the project into doubt, several officials said last night.

title: Decision Not to Build as a Cause of Homelessness; Two Other Reasons
description: To the Editor:

title: About Real Estate; Housing on 89th St. Built in the Old West Side Style
description: In the last few years, residents of the Upper West Side have become accustomed to seeing many of the neighborhood's old town houses restored to their original 19th-century and early 20th-century elegance. That is what seems to have happened to two adjoining buildings at 103 and 105 West 89th Street near the corner of Columbus Avenue.

title: The Cosmopolitan
description: The Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Arthur Fagen, will perform works by Glazunov, Mendelssohn and Brahms tomorrow at 2 P.M. in Town Hall (123 West 43d Street). A $5 contribution is requested. Information: 840-2824.

title: Buckeye Wins Award
description: Chris Spielman, the Ohio State All-America linebacker and a finalist for the Lombardi Award in 1986, won that 40-pound granite trophy last night as the nation's outstanding collegiate lineman of 1987, but the victory was bittersweet.

title: Accounts
description: * New York City Transportation Department to Gleckler & Co., for an advertising campaign to warn young people against drunken driving.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; Touring the Gotham
description: Like every other great city, New York yields up its most picturesque moments slowly. An odd corner; a patch of beauty where you don't expect it; a certain slant of light. . . . But I think people should be left to find out such things for themselves.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Heisman Winners Showing They Can Play Pro Ball, Too
description: The Heisman Trophy used to be a nonstop, first-class ticket to the National Football League for running backs.

title: YEFIM BRONFMAN
description: Yefim Bronfman will give a piano recital of works by Scarlatti, Brahams, Mozart and Prokofiev tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y (at Lexington Avenue). Tickets are $12.50 to $17.50. Information: 996-1100.

title: Suns Lose the Ball; Knicks Just Lose
description: Bad hands won out over bad shooting tonight as the Phoenix Suns gained a 120-114 victory over the Knicks at Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: Factories' Orders Up In October
description: Increased demand in the transportation sector helped lift factory orders 1.1 percent in October despite the shock from the stock market plunge, the Government said today.

title: Film: Soviet Drama
description: THE skill with which ''Repentance'' has been made is sure to be eclipsed in importance by the very fact that it was made at all. The level of political self-criticism to be found in this Soviet film is so high, and the satire so scathing, that ''Repentance'' has been greeted as a phenomenon at home. For American audiences, it will seem almost equally startling. Yet ''Repentance'' also warrants attention for the flamboyant directorial style of Tengiz Abuladze, a man who favors surreal touches, unexpected leaps through time, and the blackest humor. ''Repentance'' would seem mordantly funny if its wit, like that of its central character, weren't also so cruel.

title: Senate Bill Aiding Artists Is Debated
description: A measure that would allow artists to share in the increased prices of their works every time they were resold was endorsed today by artists as an appropriate reward for their contributions.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Sounds of South Africa

title: Records Don't Dim Army-Navy Game
description: That Army versus Navy ranks as an event rather than just another football game is more evident than ever this year. Tomorrow's meeting at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia has been sold out for a month, although the game matches teams that between them have won only 6 times in 20 opportunities.

title: S.M.U. TOPPLES FLORIDA, 82-76
description: Todd Alexander scored 20 of his 24 points in the second half tonight to help Southern Methodist upset Florida, 82-76.

title: Corrections
description: The Food Notes column in The Living Section on Wednesday omitted the publisher of ''Cook Quick.'' It is Oxmoor House.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CHORAL SOCIETY
description: The New York City Choral Society will perform works by Kodaly, Barber and Mozart tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $10 to $22. Information: 247-7800.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think as long as you've got a chance to strive for peace, you strive for peace.'' - President Reagan [ A16:6. ]

title: Slow Sales for Retailers in November
description: Disappointing retail sales in November raised concern yesterday over how retailers will fare this Christmas season.

title: SOVIET ECONOMISTS SEE A NEW ORDER
description: Two leading Soviet economists held out prospects today of a new international economic order inspired by Soviet economic reforms and the impending arms control pacts.

title: Film: 'Hero's Journey,' Documentary
description: ''A Hero's Journey: The World of Joseph Campbell'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. These are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 22. The film opens today at the Eighth Street Playhouse.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: Interest rates on commitments for fixed-rate and adjustable mortgages fell between early October and early November, the first drop since August, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday, The drop in mortgage rates mirrored the drop in interest rates in general after October's stock market collapse.

title: Iraq Offers to Cut Output If Oil Quota Equals Iran's
description: Iraq today affirmed its willingness to reduce its oil production on the condition that its total output equaled that of Iran, its neighbor and enemy in a seven-year-old war.

title: The Stage: 'Serious Money'
description: WHEN the antiquated London stock market finally cast off tradition and plugged into the deregulated frenzy of modern Wall Street in 1986, the phenomenon was heralded as the Big Bang. In ''Serious Money,'' a ferocious new satire about the financial wheeler-dealers born in the ensuing boom, Caryl Churchill takes the term literally.

title: Newark Tried Year-Round School Successfully
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Help for Gorbachev
description: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, apparently concerned about how the summit is going to play in Siberia, wants a little help from his hosts.

title: Vietnam Jails 17 for Attempted Guerrilla Invasion
description: A Vietnamese tribunal sentenced 17 people to prison today on charges of trying to stage a guerrilla invasion with American and Thai backing.

title: Settling Out of Court: Gamble or Skill?
description: Consider a pair of riverboat gamblers. The cards have been dealt, the bets have mounted, the combatants, well-matched in skill, face an all-or-nothing decision. Rightly or wrongly, such an image forms easily in the minds of the public when talk of out-of-court settlement enters the picture in high-stakes lawsuits.

title: Caledonian Set To Sell Stake
description: Britain cleared the way today for the Scandanavian Airlines System to buy a minority stake in British Caledonian Airlines, but announced steps to insure the carrier would remain under British control.

title: Why They're Leaving the Foreign Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Candidate Has the Crowds, but Has He Got the Votes?
description: If huge crowds and supporter fervor were enough, Kim Dae Jung would win South Korea's presidential election hands down.

title: Dow Drops By 72.44, To 1,776.53
description: Yet another wave of pessimism hit Wall Street yesterday as jittery investors ignored presumably positive news about the dollar and interest rates.

title: Arms Dealer Indicted In Copter Sale to Iraq
description: A Miami man described by Federal officials as the largest arms dealer in the United States was indicted Wednesday on charges that he conspired to smuggle 103 combat helicopters armed with wire-guided TOW missiles to Iraq.

title: Devils Not Fussy About Any Victory
description: Apparently, nothing works like home ice for the Devils. They returned to Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight after a long trip and defeated the St. Louis Blues, 4-2.

title: Bonds End Day Slightly Higher
description: Bond prices ended moderately higher yesterday after seven European countries lowered their interest rates.

title: Union Pacific Has 16.4% of Beard
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said it holds 16.4 percent of the Beard Company and may seek control of the Oklahoma City-based oil and gas concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Union Pacific said it might acquire Beard to obtain the company's 28 percent stake in USPCI Inc.

title: Huge Volume In Occidental
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation was the volume leader on the New York Stock Exchange today with more than 44 million shares traded, one of the busiest days ever for a single stock.

title: Film: Teen-Age Farce, 'Student Confidential'
description: IT goes without saying that ''Student Confidential'' is bad, for it arrives by way of Troma Inc., the small company that has turned badness into an art form. Still, there are standards for everything, and this isn't the kind of bad film that's any fun.

title: Showing Off New York City To Visitors From Out of Town; The Cheaper Seats
description: Show your visitors you don't have to be Broadway bound or in bondage to a bank to enjoy a New York musical.

title: LOW-LEVEL FLIGHTS OF B-1 ARE HALTED
description: The Strategic Air Command has suspended low-level flights for the new B-1 bomber, limiting the training of crews for their main mission of low-level bombing, according to officers at the command's headquarters in Omaha.

title: Film: 'Spies'
description: ''THE TROUBLE WITH SPIES'' has the manner of an overage tadpole that knows it will never be a frog. It's dour and gloomy, though it's supposed to be lighthearted. Somewhere along the line, a turn was missed.

title: Former HCM Chief Is a Messner Partner
description: Robert A. Schmetterer, who left the worldwide chief executive's job at the HCM agency determined to start his own place, has settled for partnership status and the presidency at Messner, Vetere, Berger, Carey. Asking for a name on the door as well would have been asking too much.

title: Burnley Is Sworn In; Urges Funds to Hire More Air Controllers
description: The Transportation Department will hire more than 1,000 additional air traffic controllers if Congress approves a request for a $1 billion increase in spending for aviation, the new Transportation Secretary said today.

title: Katherine R. Erskine Wed to Dale Aubrey Jenkins
description: Katherine Ruth Erskine, a freelance writer, and Dale Aubrey Jenkins, an executive vice president of the Urban Group, a New York real-estate development company, were married last evening at the Beekman Tower in New York by Judge Elaine Slobod of the Family Court of Orange County.

title: Woman, at News Conference, Pleads for Release at Bellevue
description: The first person picked up and confined under a New York City program to hospitalize mentally ill street people against their will made an impassioned plea for her freedom last night and pledged not to return to a life on the streets.

title: Federal Prosecutor Takes Over Inquiry Into Transit Arrests
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday that he would take charge of the investigation into suspected false arrests by officers of the New York City Transit Police Department.

title: The Right Treaty, Time and President
description: The American political right has never found an arms control treaty it liked. Now it is marshaling forces for a Senate fight over the treaty eliminating Euromissiles that Mikhail Gorbachev and President Reagan plan to sign Tuesday.

title: From Lake Wobegon to the Hudson
description: Surely, the residents of Lake Wobegon, Minn. (alt. 1,418, pop. 942) still head home each day at the 6 P.M. sounding of the town fire alarm for heaping plates of tuna hotdish with cream of mushroom soup.

title: KEY RATES
Reagan Library Plan Comes to Town
description: The Ronald Reagan Library may soon become a reality, but not everyone can understand why it's being built in this bedroom community where shopping malls, housing developments and ''valley speak'' abound.

title: Kodak's Prospects
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it expected its strong earnings growth to continue next year, attributing the momentum to stringent cost-cutting measures that took effect last year. Kodak's chairman, Colby H. Chandler, told analysts in Chicago that the company had cut 13,000 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, while reducing expenses by 5 percent.

title: Tisch Associate Gets Job
description: Jay Kriegel, a longtime associate of CBS Inc.'s chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, has been named senior vice president in charge of external relations and governmental affairs. He will report directly to Mr. Tisch. Mr. Kriegel had been acting as a consultant to CBS. From 1966 to 1973, Mr. Kriegel served as chief of staff and special counsel to John V. Lindsay, who was then Mayor of New York City. Mr. Kriegel built his relationship with Mr. Tisch when he served as director of special projects at the Loews Corporation from 1975 to 1978. Mr. Kriegel also served as publisher of The American Lawyer from 1978 to 1982. Since 1983, he has run Kriegel Communications, a consulting firm in in government relations, corporate communiations and marketing. CBS has been among his his clients.

title: U.S. MAY BE EASING ARMS TALKS STAND
description: The United States may drop its demand that an overall limit be placed on warheads on Soviet land-based missiles as part of a larger compromise on reducing long-range nuclear arms, senior Administration officials said today.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS CONSERVATIVE FOES OF NEW ARMS PACT
description: President Reagan, strongly defending the arms control treaty he expects to sign with the Soviet Union at the summit meeting next week, said today that conservative critics did not understand what the treaty would accomplish and had accepted the idea ''that war is inevitable.''

title: Showing Off New York To Out-of-Town Guests
description: People pour into New York in December, and some of those who fill the sidewalks to overflowing and drive the cars that clog the streets are going to be friends of yours. When they come to town, they will ask you what to do. Here and on page C6, eight Times critics offer suggestions on what to show visitors in this holiday season, as the city's energy begins to mount to its crescendo.

title: ARMY'S LEARNING PANEL URGES OFFBEAT STUDIES
description: There is little or no evidence that unconventional learning techniques will help the Army produce better soldiers, a National Research Council committee said today. But the panel said some methods deserved further study.

title: Soldier With AIDS Virus to Be Imprisoned for Sexual Contacts
description: A former Army medical instructor was sentenced to five months in the stockade and was given a dishonorable discharge Wednesday for having sexual relations with three female soldiers without telling them he carried the AIDS virus.

title: Amid Criticism of Arrests, Officers Defend Department
description: New York City transit police officers defended their force yesterday amid growing charges that fellow officers had made dubious arrests on subway trains and platforms in recent years.

title: Panama Orders U.S. Aid Agency Shut
description: Panama has ordered the United States to close the operations of the Agency for International Development in Panama and is expelling the agency's American employees and their dependents, the State Department said today.

title: HAITI'S POLITICIANS DOUBT VOTE PLAN
description: Haitian political leaders expressed strong reservations today about efforts by the army-dominated Government to speed through a reorganization of the disbanded electoral council and hold new elections by early February.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. TAX RISE GAINS; Bundesbank First
description: In an unusual, concerted effort to stabilize the dollar and promote economic growth, West Germany's central bank cut its most important lending rate today, and hours later six other European central banks cut their rates.

title: Santa's Quarters Looted
description: The offices and a warehouse of a man who has been Santa Claus for many underpriviledged children were looted of about $500 in merchandise Wednesday. ''I think anybody would have to be pretty bad off to steal from the poor,'' said Dorcas Drake, whose annual toy drive serves 50,000 children. Mr. Drake, a retired justice of the peace, has served as Santa Claus for 30 years.

title: U.S. TAX RISE GAINS; Senate Panel Votes Increase Of $9 Billion
description: The Senate Finance Committee today unanimously approved a $9 billion package of tax increases that would affect mainly businesses and higher-income Americans, but in relatively limited ways.

title: JACKSON TO SHUN SOCIALIST BACKING
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, whose campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination has been built around an appeal to the mainstream of American politics, has asked the nation's leading Socialist organization not to endorse his candidacy at their convention this weekend.

title: For Entrepreneur, Revenge Is Sweet
description: A toy that simulates war sounds and is intended to allow motorists to vent their frustrations is the latest novelty sensation, retailers in New York and California say.

title: More Restrictions for 'Baby Bells'
description: A Federal judge issued an opinion yesterday that increases the restrictions barring the seven regional telephone companies from manufacturing telecommunications equipment.

title: House Approves Spending Bill; Veto Threatened
description: The House of Representatives approved a $587 billion spending bill for 1988 today that requires $7.6 billion in cuts agreed to in the deficit-reducing plan reached last month by Congress and the White House.

title: California Becomes the Land of Quick and Discreet Marriages
description: Want to get married? Quick? Cheap? No hassle?

title: N.L.R.B. Backs Players
description: The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board has authorized a complaint saying that some National Football League players were illegally barred from the first weekend of games after the strike.

title: Uncertainty of Administration Dollar Goals
description: The coordinated cuts in European interest rates today could dissuade the markets from pushing the dollar down for a while. Beyond that, the cuts fulfill a major condition that the Reagan Administration had set for doing more on its own to stabilize the dollar.

title: C.I.A. Aids Harvard Study on Intelligence Policy
description: The John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard Univesity announced today that the Central Intelligence Agency had provided $400,000 for a three-year program of research and training on intelligence assessment and policy.

title: CURRY CAMPAIGN OF VIJAY AMRITRAJ
description: IF this were a screenplay, Vijay Amritraj of Hollywood would not even take a power lunch to consider it.

title: Grand Old Flags in Need of Preservation
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Supreme Court Nominations; After Bork, the Liberals' Silence On Judge Kennedy Is Deafening
description: With the Senate Judiciary Committee's hearing on the nomination of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy barely a week away, most of the liberal groups that were in the forefront of the successful effort to keep Judge Robert H. Bork off the Supreme Court are maintaining a wary silence.

title: For the Soviet Emigres, Gorbachev Stirs Both Optimism and Skepticism
description: Mark Belenky, a recent Soviet emigre, will not meet Mikhail S. Gorbachev next week. But Mr. Belenky would like to take the Soviet leader through a suburban supermarket and then, amid the frozen vegetables, plead the cause of his sister-in-law, who has been refused an exit visa for nine years.

title: MOODY'S WILL REVIEW BOND RATING OF G.M.
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said today that it would review the bond rating of the General Motors Corporation, which has $54 billion in long-term debt. G.M.'s bonds are currently rated Aa-1, Moody's second-highest category.

title: JACKSON SEEKING SOCIALIST BACKING
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, reversing an earlier decision, told the co-chairman of the nation's leading Socialist group yesterday that he would like the group to endorse his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: NICARAGUAN TALKS REACH AN IMPASSE ON PRIMATE'S PLAN
description: Talks between warring Nicaraguan factions broke down today when representatives of the Sandinista Government refused to accept a cease-fire proposal from the mediator, Nicaragua's Roman Catholic Primate.

title:
Patents;
Exhibits and Honors Are Planned for 1988
description: LEAD: Preparations are under way to honor American inventors and promote their inventions next year.

title: TV: A Cronkite Report, Children of Apartheid'
description: ''Children of Apartheid'' is almost a personal essay, its feelings clearly showing. Walter Cronkite wants to communicate his anguish about South Africa. In this Mr. Cronkite is successful - the CBS News program, on Channel 2 at 8 o'clock tonight, leaves us with a feeling of despair.

title: SAVECO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Savin Capital Plan
description: The Savin Corporation has announced a recapitalization plan under which it will offer to exchange all debt securities and a series of its convertible preferred stock for common stock. Savin, a maker of officer copiers, now has 41 million common shares outstanding and will seek shareholder approval to increase that to 400 million shares. The plan also involves an exchange offer with the Canada Development Corporation, a large Savin stock and debt holder. If successful, Canada Development will own between 43.2 percent and 61.8 percent of Savin's stock.

title: What Happened to American Seamen?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pericle Fazzini, 74, a Sculptor for Vatican
description: Pericle Fazzini, the sculptor whose monumental statue ''The Resurrection'' is the backdrop for Pope John Paul II's weekly general audiences, died today. He was 74 years old.

title: DATAPHAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain from discontinued operations of $25,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $57,000 for the quarter and $204,000 for the 9 months.

title: SEOUL STUDENT LEADER SENTENCED
description: A student leader who was charged last summer with slandering the state by making ''undesirable statements'' to a foreign correspondent has been sentenced to four years in prison, the South Korean press reported today.

title: RETAIL SALES STRONGER IN NEW YORK
description: November retail sales in New York City were generally stronger than in the nation as a whole, spurred by big-ticket purchases from affluent shoppers, both domestic and foreign, a spot-check of leading stores found yesterday.

title: With Winterizing Your Car
description: Like most things, automobiles have their seasons.

title: CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

Braves Seeking Horner
description: Bob Horner rejected a three-year, $4.5 million contract offer from the Atlanta Braves last season and chose instead to play for Yakult of the Japananese Central League for about $2 million. But the general manager of the Braves, Bobby Cox, believes that at a meeting next week in Dallas he can persuade Horner to return to the Braves with a one-year contract worth $900,000, including incentives and a provision for daily weight checks. Horner has reportedly been offered a three-year contract worth $10 million by Yakult. ''If he wants to play in the States, I don't think there are too many teams out there prepared to offer what we're going to offer,'' Cox told The Atlanta Constitution on Thursday. ''The impression I get is Horner does not want to go back to Japan.'' Horner's contract with the Braves contained a clause stipulating that he keep his weight at 215 pounds, or lose a portion of his $100,000 bonus.

description: Michael Fay, the New Zealand banker who went to court to force a race next year for the America's Cup, said he might be willing to postpone the event until 1989 if the San Diego Yacht Club backs off its decision to exclude other competitors. ''As it stands now, we're set to sail a match next summer,'' Fay said. ''But we are keen to open it up as an international event.'' Fay's challenge, based on an interpretation of the 100-year-old document governing America's Cup competition, was ruled valid Nov. 25 by the New York Supreme Court. The decision interrupted plans by the San Diego Yacht Club and its cup defense manager, Sail America, to hold an America's Cup regatta off San Diego in 1991 using 12-meter yachts.

He has had a career of distinction, not just as a technician and interpreter of the standard repertory, but also as a champion of new music and an organizer within the musical profession. His playing betrayed the inevitable depredations of age. But at times it was still beautiful on absolute terms, and as with some other honored veterans, it was possible to hear through the imperfections the toughness of mind and passion of spirit that made him what he once was.

Two embryos, frozen in 1981, had remained in storage pending the legal action. Doctors rated their survival chances at 5 percent, but said they would be implanted when a suitable recipient was found.

At your favorite restaurant, did the maitre d'hotel, whom you do not regularly tip, consistently give you extra service? Do you enjoy a special relationship with the people who work for you? Experts agreed that holiday tipping is a highly personal choice dependent on many variables, including where you live. Their suggestions follow: $ Maitre d'hotel $50 to $100 Doorman $20 to $30 Building superintendent $20 to $30 Handyman $10 to $15 Elevator operator $10 to $15 Porter $10 to $15 Maid Week's salary Newspaper deliverer $10 to $20 Hairdresser Half the maximum spent on a single visit Barber Half the maximum spent on a single visit Manicurist Half the maximum spent on a single visit Sources: Council of New York Cooperatives, New York State Restaurant Association, housekeeping agencies, National Cosmetology Association, Newspaper Route Dealer Association of Greater New York

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Skiing Sweep by Swiss: Maria Walliser led the Swiss women's World Cup team to a sweep in the season's opening downhill event yesterday in Val d'Isere, France. Walliser, a two-time World Cup champion, charged down the 2,199-meter course in 1 minute 21.14 seconds, leading her teammates Michela Figini and Zoe Haas. Figini's time was 1:21.19; Haas finished in 1:21.38.(AP) Speed Skating American Misses a Record: Bonnie Blair of the United States barely missed a world record in the 500-meter event last night in the first World Cup race to be held in the Olympic Oval, the site of speed-skating events at the Winter Olympics in February in Calgary, Alberta. Blair, from Champaign, Ill., was timed in 39.44 seconds, .01 behind her own world record of 39.43. Christa Rothenburger of East Germany was second, .04 of a second behind Blair, and Karin Kania of East Germany was third at 39.99. (AP) Horse Show Jacobs Wins Again: Louis Jacobs, an amateur from East Aurora, N.Y., teamed with his horse, Manuel, for their second victory in two nights when they won the $30,000 Jumper Stakes at the Michelob-American Grand Prix Association Show Jumping Championships in Tampa, Fla. Five of the 20 starters qualified for the jumpoff. He had seven clear fences in 32.47 seconds for the victory.

Delegates said that consumers and producers now seemed to have found common ground on a price but that there were still some outstanding problems and the emerging accord could unravel.

title: Savard Dismissed
description: The Quebec Nordiques dismissed Coach Andre Savard yesterday, 24 games into his first National Hockey League season, and replaced him with Ron Lapointe, the coach of their top farm team. Savard, 34 years old, was named June 19 to succeed Michel Bergeron, who left to become coach of the Rangers. Savard, who lasted less than two months, was dismissed a day after the Nordiques lost, 6-3, in Buffalo for their eighth defeat in nine games. ''He gave himself completely to the team, but it did not work out,'' said the general manager, Maurice Filion. ''We had no choice but to make changes.'' The Nordiques were 10-13-1 under Savard, putting them fourth in the Adams Division, a point ahead of the last-place Hartford Whalers. Lapointe, 38 years old, served as an assistant coach with the Washington Capitals for the last two seasons.

description: When Jack Morris was a free agent last year, the Detroit Tigers offered him salary arbitration, he accepted and he won a $1.85 million for 1987. Other players offered arbitration yesterday were Jack Clark, by St. Louis; Charlie Leibrandt, by Kansas City; Dave LaPoint, by the Chicago White Sox, and Paul Molitor and Mark Clear, by Milwaukee.
