Jim Dinerstein, a sculptor, and Suyapa Quinn, a painter, will be among those exhibiting their work. Admission is free. Information: 255-2283.

title: Maids Getting Their Mops Back
description: Maids at the Copley Plaza Hotel will not have to drop to their knees to scrub floors after all, the hotel said Thursday.

title: Fattoria La Loggia
description: To the Editor: We read the letters concerning the accommodations at the Fattoria La Loggia in Tuscany and must take exception to their general negative tenor. As one of the letter writers also did, we (six adults) arrived at the Fattoria La Loggia on July 25 for a one-week stay.

title:
GARDENING;
TIMING IS CRUCIAL FOR CHRISTMAS PLANTS
description: LEAD: BY this time you should be able to tell whether your poinsettia or Christmas cactus will be in flower for Christmas.

title: An Opportunity in Depressed Ad Stocks?
description: WHATEVER the advertising industry's credibility with television viewers, investors have been moving away from Madison Avenue in droves. Shares of such leading companies as the Interpublic Group, the Ogilvy Group and Foote, Cone & Belding, have shown little bounce since the market's October plunge. Portfolio managers worry that any slowdown in the economy in 1988 will translate into slack billings and lean earnings for the ad agencies.

title: London Mourns Fire Victims
description: The Princess of Wales joined about 400 mourners at a memorial service today for the 31 people killed in a London subway fire on Nov. 18. The ecumenical service was held at St. Pancras Church, a landmark 1820's church a few hundred yards from King's Cross subway station, where the disaster occurred.

title: From Belgium, Fierce Artistic Statements
description: WIM VANDEKEYBUS, MICH-ele-Anne de Mey, Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker -all are experimental Belgian choreographers and dancers. All work from both the gut and the brain, and they affect us, accordingly, in the same areas. Their pieces provoke and disturb.

title: Parties That Help Others
description: Broadcast Nostalgia Dec. 7 - They are names from the golden era of radio broadcasting, the 1930's, 40's and 50's: Lon Clark (''Nick Carter, Master Detective''), Fran Carlon (''Big Town'') and others from the Mercury Theater, including Margo Lane. They will be part of the Big Broadcast, an evening of nostalgia, at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, starting at 7. Other scheduled participants are Arnold Stang, Hildegarde, the announcers Ed Herlihy and Red Barber and the singing team of Robin Field and Bill Daugherty. The event benefits the programs of the New York League for the Hard of Hearing. There will be a buffet, an open bar, dancing and entertainment. Tickets $100; 212-741-3143. The hard of hearing should call 212-255-1932. Briefly Noted: Dec. 7 - The Auxiliary of the Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine will hold a benefit cocktail party from 6 to 8 P.M. at the ''21'' Club. Joseph Heller, the author, will be honored. Tickets $125; 212-340-6196. Dec. 7 - The Dance Theater Workshop, now in its 23d year, is holding a benefit performance by Susan Marshall and Company that will include the premiere of ''Companion Pieces.'' Cocktails at 7 P.M. will precede the performance at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street; afterward, there will be a buffet dinner and dancing. Tickets $75; 212-691-6500. Dec. 7 - There will be snacks, a cash bar and entertainment by members of the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players to welcome John Reed, an English actor, to the company at a benefit for the company from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. at the Boulevard Cafe, Broadway at 88th Street. Tickets $25; 212-769-1000. Dec. 8 - Cees Bruynes, chairman of the North American Philips Corporation, will receive the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award at a benefit for the Boys Clubs of America at the Sheraton Centre. Cocktails at 6:30 P.M. will be followed by dinner, entertainment by the Smothers Brothers and dancing. Tickets $350; 212-351-5933. Dec. 9 - Furs and lingerie will be on parade at a 5:30 P.M. ''Christmas Deluxe'' cocktail party at Doubles in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel to benefit the American Cancer Society. Tickets $100; 212-586-8700, extension 390. Dec. 9 - From 7 to 10 P.M., there will be private shopping and a cocktail party at F.A.O. Schwartz in the General Motors Building on Fifth Avenue at 59th Street to benefit pediatric cancer research at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Tickets $35 or $50 a couple, children free; 212-794-7972. Dec. 9 - More than 50 soap-opera actors and actresses will provide cabaret entertainment and then act as bartenders and operate carnival booths at a ''Daytime Cares'' show at the Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street, from 7 to 10 P.M. The event benefits the Stamp Out AIDS organization. Tickets $35 at the door or $25 in advance; 212-869-3530. Dec. 9 - Cocktails at 7:30 P.M. followed by dinner, dancing and an auction of 100 or so Christmas trees decorated by Jim Henson, Bill Blass, Joan Rivers and others will benefit the New York Special Olympics. The benefit will be held at the 1018 Nightclub, 515 West 18th Street. Tickets $150, or $25 for a midnight viewing of the trees alone; 212-645-5156. Dec. 9 - George Plimpton, Calvin Trillin, Maya Angelou, Gordon Parks and Thomas Meehan will present their writings and photographs at a benefit for the East Harlem Tutorial Program in the Stern Auditorium of the Annenberg Building of Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street, at 8 P.M. A reception with the participants follows. Tickets $40; 212-831-0650. Dec. 10 - The New York Philharmonic's annual Holiday Gala will be held at the Metropolitan Club, 1 East 60th Street, starting with 7 P.M. cocktails followed by carols by the American Boychoir, dinner, and dancing. Black tie. Tickets $175; 212-580-8700, extension 381. For a Future Circus Dec. 10 - An evening at the Big Apple Circus at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center will benefit the New York School for Circus Arts, which provides training in circus specialties to students at the Harbor Junior High School for the Performing Arts in East Harlem. There will be refreshments at 7, followed by the performance at 8. From 10 to midnight, there will be dancing in the circus ring. Tickets $100 for ringside, $50 for grandstand; 212-391-0760. Day and Evening Dance Dec. 12 - The Field is a nonprofit support group for dancers that produces works of new choreographers and companies. From noon to 10 P.M., 40 choreographer-dancers will present their works and companies at a loft at 252 West 30th Street. Guests may leave and re-enter during the 10-hour dance marathon. A 10 P.M. cocktail party will honor Bessie Schonberg, an influencial dance teacher for 50 years. Tickets $30, or $15 for performances alone; 212-966-3717. Operatic Tribute Dec. 13 - Roberta Peters will be honored for her 37-year career at the Metropolitan Opera with a dinner and concert party at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. Cocktails at 6 will be followed by performances by winners of a competition sponsored by the Opera Index, which provides young singers with $1,000 grants for career development. Tony Randall will be the master of ceremonies. Tickets $125; 212-691-0552.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 'CHRISTMAS CAROL' TOUR Three touring companies of ''A Christmas Carol,'' a production that originated in Omaha, Neb., in 1976, are going across the country this year. The East Coast contingent will stop at the Jorgensen Auditorium of the University of Connecticut in Storrs for an 8 P.M. performance on Friday. The show, produced by Nebraska Theater Caravan, touring wing of the Omaha Community Playhouse, ''has become a tradition with families who come year after year,'' said the managing director of the company, Caroline Rutherford.

title: 23 Seamen Killed in Fire on Ship Off Spain
description: At least 23 seamen died today after fire broke out aboard a freighter in rough seas off Spain and forced the crew to abandon ship, the Spanish National Radio reported.

title: Correction
description: An article on the art page of the Arts and Leisure section today about David Hockney's designs for a production of Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde'' in Los Angeles, conducted by Zubin Mehta, misstates Mr. Mehta's experience with the opera. He has conducted ''Tristan'' many times, including performances in London at Covent Garden and in Berlin with the Berlin Opera.

title: LYME DISEASE SYMPTOMS CAN RETURN
description: LYME DISEASE is not being treated in the press and by part of the medical profession as the severe affliction it can be.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: Larry Holmes is not too old to fight. He is too old to win, especially against a man of the caliber of Mike Tyson. OWEN P. ROBINSON Madison, N.J.

title: CHAMBER ENSEMBLES FILL CONCERT SCHEDULE
description: HOLIDAY concerts abound this week, but so do solo, ensemble and even opera performances with no seasonal connection at all. On today's schedule, for instance, we find two trios, a string quartet and a quintet providing an especially rich harvest of chamber music.

title: ORGANIZING ARTS PROGRAMS IN SCHOOLS
description: BARBARA LEVINE spends her days immersed in art.

title: The Mood Is Genuinely Hopeful for This Summit
description: AFTER a week of tough talk, conciliatory platitudes and other pre-summit maneuvers, Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev now stand on the verge of what could be one of the most serious and constructive dialogues that Soviet and American leaders have had in many years.

title: NEW CANAAN GALLERY TO OPEN STAMFORD UNIT
description: STAMFORD commuters have the opportunity these days of adding an esthetic dimension to their somewhat hectic existence by viewing contemporary artwork on their way to and from the train. Not only are there mobiles to enjoy in the new Stamford Transportation Center, but also, on Wednesday, the Silvermine Guild Galleries of New Canaan is opening exhibitions of paintings, sculpture, photographs and furnishings at the nearby Metro Center.

title: Vermont Woman in a Lonely Fight To Remove Cross From Public Area
description: LEAD: When Valerie White introduces herself as ''The Grinch That Stole Christmas,'' she is kidding.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf McCumber-Massey Duo Take Lead: Mark McCumber and Debbie Massey shot a seven-under-par 65 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the $650,000 J. C. Penney Mixed Classic in Largo, Fla. McCumber and Massey posted seven birdies on the Bardmoor Country Club course for a three-day total of 199, 17 under. Steve Jones and Jane Crafter scored a 66 for second place at 200, and Wayne Levi and Dale Eggeling shot their second straight 66 to take third at 202. The second-round leaders, Ronnie Black and Dawn Coe, struggled to 72 in the wind yesterday and were among three teams at 204.(AP) Tie in Japan: David Ishii of the United States, winner of the Casio World Open tournament last week, shot the day's best score of 69 and shared the lead with Isao Aoki of Japan in the $220,000 Japan Series in Inagi. Ishii, the leading money winner on the Japan PGA tour with $606,000, had four birdies before carding his only bogey on the 221-yard, par-3 18th hole at the Tokyo Yomiuri Country Club. (AP) Skiing Swiss Wins: Chantal Bournissen of Switzerland scored her first World Cup victory yesterday, taking advantage of changing weather to capture the downhill race in Val d'Isere, France. Bournissen, a 20-year-old in her second year on the team, was the 36th starter but finished the race in 1 minute 22.64 seconds, faster by one-tenth of a second than Marina Kiehl of West Germany. Another West German, Ulrike Stanggassinger, was third in 1:22.94 despite starting 50th of 61 competitiors. Bournissen's previous best was a 23d in a downhill in Austria last year.(AP) Nykanen in Top Form: Matti Nykanen of Finland won the 70-meter competition to open his 1987-88 World Cup jumping season in Thunder Bay, Ontario. Nykanen, a three-time World Cup champion and the 90-meter winner at Thunder Bay last year, jumped 95.5 and 94.5 meters for 250.2 points. Pavel Ploc of Czechoslovakia was second with 227.2 points, ahead of Ernst Vettori of Austria with 220.9. (AP) Horse Racing Anniron Wins by a Neck: Anniron, the co-highweight with 120 pounds and Robbie Davis aboard, wore down La Polonaise in the stretch and won by a neck yesterday in the $70,200 Iroquois Stakes for New York-bred fillies and mares at Aqueduct. La Polonaise held second by six lengths over Chase the Dream. The victory was the 12th in 16 career starts for the 4-year-old daughter of Iron Constitution-Leap Year Miss. It was also her second straight victory in the Iroquois, which she won last year in the same time of 1:44 4/5. Anniron earned $42,120 for her owner, William A. Martusewicz, and returned $4.60 for $2 to win. Goodbye Halo Runs First: Running for the first time in the West, Goodbye Halo captured the $549,100 Hollywood Starlet for 2-year-old fillies by 3 1/2 lengths yesterday in Inglewood, Calif. Ridden by Jorge Velasquez, Goodbye Halo took over the lead heading into the stretch and finished the mile race 3 1/2 lengths ahead in 1:36 1/5. Goodbye Halo, winner of two races in New York including the Demoiselle by 10 lengths Nov. 7, went off at 11-1 and returned $24.80 for $2 to win.(AP) Speed Skating Russian Sets Record: Igor Zhelezovsky of the Soviet Union, racing in the last of 19 pairings, set a world record of 1:52.50 yesterday to win the men's 1,500-meter race at the World Cup speed skating competition on the ultra-fast Olympic Speed Skating Oval track in Calgary, Alberta. Ki-Tae Bae of South Korea took the gold in the second of two men's 500-meter sprints with a time of 37:08. The East German team dominated the two women's races, sweeping the medals in the 3,000 meters and conceding only a silver to Bonnie Blair of the United States in the 1,000-meter race.(AP) N.B.A. Cavaliers 97, Lakers 95: Tyrone Corbin tipped in a missed shot at the buzzer last night, giving Cleveland the victory in Richfield, Ohio. Brad Daugherty of Cleveland missed a 15-foot jump shot before Corbin leaped out of a pack of players to tap in the game-winner. Cleveland led, 95-89, when Phil Hubbard made two foul shots with 2:07 remaining. Los Angeles scored the next 6 points to tie the game on a hook shot by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, a driving layup by Magic Johnson, and Byron Scott's jumper with 55 seconds left. Dell Curry and Johnson missed jump shots before Cleveland called timeout with 15 seconds left to set up the game-winning sequence.(AP) Mavericks 109, Nuggets 96: Mark Aguirre scored 17 of his 35 points during a 20-0 second-quarter outburst and Dallas went on to defeat Denver. Dallas held off a fourth-quarter Denver charge in which the visitors slashed a 25-point deficit to 94-87 with 5:30 to play. But Aguirre's steal and dunk with 56 seconds to play clinched the victory for the Mavericks, who won for the seventh time in their last nine games.(AP)

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: NASA's Plans; A Return to Jupiter
description: IN 1989, more than three centuries after Galileo discovered Jupiter's four largest moons, a spacecraft bearing his name is expected to leave Earth for a six-year voyage to the largest known planet. If all goes according to the plans disclosed last week by NASA, the unmanned craft will swing twice around the Sun, gaining momentum; then, like a rock hurtling from a slingshot, it will head for Jupiter.

title: Bird Not Perfect
description: ANOTHER basketball streak came to an end in Pontiac, Mich., Friday night when Larry Bird of the Boston Celtics missed a free throw in a 128-105 loss to the Detroit Pistons. It was the first time in 60 attempts that Bird had failed from the foul line, and his 59 straight successes, third best in N.B.A. history, left him one behind Rick Barry for second place on the list. The record of 78 straight was set by Calvin Murphy of the Houston Rockets.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: IT sometimes seems that photographers and commercial publishers are incompatible species, destined endlessly to malign each other. Photographers complain that publishers don't understand that pictures have their own merits; publishers counter that picture books don't sell unless they have a ''hook.'' Still, somehow, good books of good photography manage to find their way into print. This is providential, for as the influence of magazine photography continues to decline, books have become an increasingly important outlet for pictures that look better on the page than on gallery walls. The audience for books is far smaller than that of the old Life magazine, but it is better than none.

title: Dreams on the Drawing Board
description: LEAD: WINSOR McCAY His Life and Art. By John Canemaker. Foreword by Maurice Sendak. Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Abbeville Press. $49.95.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SNACK FOOD;
A Slow Decline in Mindless Munchin
description: LEAD: ''THE proportion of mindless munching has really changed,'' said Ms. Doyle of the Consumer Network. ''Now people think about what they're eating.'' As the population ages, she continued, ''they want heavier foods like meat or meat-and-vegetable combinations because snacks double as meals. And they want them to be healthy and taste good.

title: FORMS OF FANTASY
description: NANCY GRAVES is rummaging through her things in the makeshift studio she keeps in a corner of the Tallix Foundry in Beacon, N.Y. The place looks like the treasure trove of a budget-minded King Midas. Scattered on shelves and dumped in boxes are hundreds of everyday objects cast in bronze: bronze milk crates, pleated lampshades, sunflowers, rigatoni, even bronze rippled potato chips. Other objects -a parasol, for example - are frozen in aluminum.

title: Sound: Plus Ca Change. . .
description: PEOPLE CONVINCED that there can't be too much of a good thing prefer their music nonstop, and technology has caught up with them at last. It isn't just that the playing time of records has increased steadily over the years, growing from 4 1/2 minutes a side in the days of 78-rpm disks to about 30 minutes in the LP era and reaching an uninterrupted 70 minutes or thereabouts on CD's. These days, a whole order of magnitude has been added with the appearance of CD changers. They play up to 10 CD's in a row, delivering a musical marathon of more than 11 1/2 hours' duration.

title: In a Risky World, Teen-Agers Get Reckless; Speeding, Not Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Import Tariff an Issue in '88 Race
description: A tariff on oil imports has become a campaign issue in New Hampshire and Iowa as winter sets in, with several Democratic Presidential candidates saying they would consider imposing a tariff and all of the Republicans save Bob Dole firmly against the idea.

title: Executive Plans Retirement At Jewish Home for the Aged
description: The executive vice president of The Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, Mitchell M. Waife, will retire next month after 38 years with the nonprofit geriatric center.

title: AT 91 YEARS, HANGING IN FOR THE LONG PULL
description: HISTORY not only repeats itself, but as I head into my 92d year, I am beginning to suffer from acute deja vu. I have seen Halley's comet twice, lived through two World Wars, and experienced two stock market crashes, one in October 1929, the other October 1987. The two crashes had much in common. The advice given by the experts in 1929 is very much like that being given now. Last time we had Black Thursday, this time Black Monday.

title: Aid to College Students Up, But Costs Rise Faster
description: College students borrowed $10.1 billion last year, received $9.7 billion in grants and earned $662 million on subsidized campus jobs, according to the College Board.

title: FED UP TO HERE
description: AFTER ALL THE HOOPLA, THIS IS A winter of discontent with trendy food. No matter the months past, filled, as they were, with purple potatoes and white eggplants, goat cheese and grazing, a salad called mesclun and a fish called skate, South-western cafes, French bistros, Italian trattorias and restaurants as elaborately designed as M-G-M stage sets. No, the year approaching promises to be one in which the cute and the chic . . . well, are not.

title: Staten Island Agency Provides Counseling
description: For the last 68 years, Staten Island Family Service Inc., the oldest counseling agency in the borough, has been carrying out its mission of strengthening and preserving family life by providing counseling to families, couples and individuals living and working on Staten Island.

title: Stabilizing Families Throughout Brooklyn
description: We ask your help for the thousands of men and women and children struggling to achieve economic and social independence and working to stabilize their families so that their children may be nurtured and helped to reach their full potential.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: O.T.N.M. (Over-Thirty-Never-Married) may soon become the favored code in singles ads, thanks to the exposure given this group by Trip Gabriel in his article ''Why Wed? The Ambivalent American Bachelor'' (Nov. 15).

title: Rapist in California Stumps Police Computers
description: Neither a highly computerized police force nor the efforts of citizens' groups have been able to identify or stop a brazen, ski-masked suspect in the sexual assaults of at least 30 women in the Santa Clara Valley.

title: WEDDED TO BACH OTHER, AND A BUSINESS
description: OF all the challenges in marriage, starting a business together surely ranks as one of the trickiest. All the stresses entrepreneurs face, like the absence of a regular paycheck, are doubled.

title: In a Risky World, Teen-Agers Get Reckless; Wrong Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Going On in the Northeast
description: RARE ARTHUR MILLER

title: BARE KNUCKLES ON MADISON AVENUE
description: I must say I find all this negativism concerning the advertising business these days quite extraordinary. Every time I read an article about the megamergers, etc., I read the lines ''A lot of the fun has gone out of the business.'' The irony is that the quote usually comes from those who have become wealthy (thanks to the advertising business) and have sold out in one way or another.

title: IN MYSTIC, NEW GLORY FOR OLD GLORY
description: LEAD: IT has taken a father and son woodcarving team six weeks to faithfully re-create details needed to restore an historic landmark to its original glory in the meticulous seacoast village of Mystic.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE JAPANESE TOUCH IN TEANECK
description: LEAD: SOMETIMES in the midst of the formalities and rich fare of the holidays, one yearns for the light dishes and casual atmosphere of an Oriental restaurant. Just in time, an outpost of the Manhattan Japanese restaurants called East has opened in Teaneck.

title: St. John's Guards Meet Their Match
description: For the last three weeks, St. John's had played mediocre basketball against mediocre teams but had escaped with victories on the strength of outstanding performances by Boo Harvey and Michael Porter, the two new guards from San Jacinto College.

title: THE DISABLED FIND HOUSING OPTIONS SEVERELY LIMITED
description: LEAD: STEPHEN G. JANICK, who became a quadriplegic as a result of an accident in 1975, is looking for a home closer to work.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Big Thaw Begins
description: AFTER two winters of free agents frozen in baseball's ice age of collusion, the Big Thaw appears to have begun.

title: BLOOD CLINIC FILLS RESEARCH ROLE
description: LEAD: SOON after successful open-heart surgery, a middle-aged woman hemorrhages and doctors are unable to stop it.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON MEDICAL CENTER IN JERSEY CITY
description: LEAD: JERSEY CITY MEDICAL CENTER, the state's last public municipal hospital, will become a private, nonprofit institution Jan. 1 under a long-debated agreement with the city that was signed last Wednesday.

title: U.S. WEIGHS EFFECT OF NEW ARMS PACT
description: The Strategic Air Command is assessing which nuclear weapons could fill the gap in European defenses expected to be opened when intermediate-range missiles are removed under the coming arms agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: STAR WARS IS COMING, BUT WHERE IS IT GOING?
description: IT SEEMS CLEAR THAT STAR Wars has become both impossible and inevitable. The best evidence indicates that, given the current size of the Soviet arsenal of long-range ballistic missiles aimed at the United States, some 10,000 warheads strong, a space-based defense has no chance of working as envisioned by President Reagan. For the foreseeable future, man and his technology, however great, cannot reasonably hope to create a shield that would save the nation's cities and citizens. Even the slightest breach of it during a full-scale nuclear attack would bring an unprecedented rain of destruction and death. Prompted in part by such assessments, Congress recently imposed a new round of cuts in budget requests for Star Wars, dashing Administration hopes that a decision to deploy rudimentary defenses could be made as early as 1992.

title: Rio Rancho's Tangled Legacy
description: IN THE early to mid-70's, residents of New York and other cities were flooded with invitations to free dinners, courtesy of the Amrep Corporation. Those who went were treated to something else as well: a high-pressure sales pitch about the natural beauty and investment potential of land in Rio Rancho Estates, a sprawling new subdivision that Amrep was developing 15 miles northwest of Albuquerque, N.M.

title: 'Time to Re-Tire'
description: To the Editor:

title: RECOGNIZING GADDIS
description: Kudos to Louis Auchincloss for celebrating the brilliant but rarely read William Gaddis in his article ''Recognizing Gaddis'' (Nov. 15). I would like to add further praise by pointing out the enormous influence that Gaddis's 1955 novel ''The Recognitions'' had on the ''black-humor'' and fabulist-oriented writers of the 1960's, specifically Thomas Pynchon. The would-be bohemians of ''The Whole Sick Crew'' who inhabit Pynchon's first novel, ''V,'' (1963) are quite reminiscent of the pretentious forgers and partygoers of ''The Recognitions.'' One also sees in Pynchon the erudition, complexity, ambiguity as well as the detailed knowledge of a stunning diversity of information, from history and art to finance and political economies. ANDREW LIFSON Madison, Wis.

description: To the Editor:

Misha the Magnificent

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Walter Camp Football Foundation yesterday named Dick MacPherson, who guided Syracuse to an 11-0 record, as the coach of the year. . . . The Detroit Tigers traded Dan Petry, who had a 9-7 record last season, to the California Angels for Gary Pettis, an outfielder who hit .208. . . . LaMarr Hoyt, the pitcher seeking to return to the major leagues with the Chicago White Sox, must answer Federal charges alleging he violated probation by testing positive for cocaine use, according to a report in The San Diego Union. Hoyt was sentenced to probation in December 1986 in a misdemeanor case involving possession of sedatives.

title: For Citizens Union, 90 Years of Ideals
description: When the Citizens Union was founded in 1897, its members called for honest and efficient city government, improved rapid transit, better schools and ''lavatories adequate to public needs.''

title: SOME OF THE PITFALLS OF HYBRID OPENINGS
description: THERE is no reason in principle to object to hybrid openings, but the elements really have to go together. One of the best known is the Gruenfeld Defense, which, in essence, is a Queen's Gambit combined with a fianchetto of the black KB.

title: HUNTINGTON MORATORIUM ON RENOVATION EXPIRES
description: LEAD: A WINDOW of opportunity for Huntington property owners seeking to renovate their buildings opened recently when the town's nine-month restraint on land-use applications expired before the new master plan was ready.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: BLACK DAHLIA by James Ellroy. Mysterious Press. 325 pages. $16.95. In January 1947 a beautiful young woman was murdered and dismembered in Los Angeles, and despite the greatest manhunt in California history, the case was never solved.

title: ROLE MODELS
description: AMERICAN MEN ARE AN IMPRES-sionable lot. When they dress, they try on roles in much the same way they slip on loafers. To those who would scoff at that notion, Clifford Grodd, president of Paul Stuart, the Manhattan clothier, replies, ''Men tend to model themselves, sartorially, on public figures they respect.'' The reason, he suggests, is that men often assume, somewhat ingenuously, that ''if a person of note is wearing a thing, it must be correct.'' Or rakish, or hip, or daring, as the case may be. The adjective is a function of the role one chooses, and as l988 approaches, appropriate models for that role may be as worldly/suave as Michael Douglas, playing a powerful corporate raider in the upcoming film ''Wall Street,'' or as reassuringly square as Det. Lieut. Mike Torello, portrayed by Dennis Farina on NBC's ''Crime Story.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Rising to the Occasion In the presence of magnificence - in this case sunlight on a ruin - we sometimes become magnificent too. This is from ''A Glastonbury Romance'' by John Cowper Powys (Overlook).

title: BULK-RATE MAIL CAUSES LATER POSTAL DELIVERIES
description: LEAD: RESIDENTS who find their mail being delivered later than ever may take no comfort in knowing that the fault lies mostly in the abundance of circulars, coupons, brochures and other forms of junk mail being stuffed into mailboxes in greater volume than ever.

title: CHURCH LOOKS BEYOND ASHES TO FUTURE
description: ''THERE is a very lonely feeling, because it's like losing something of your own,'' said Inez Woodbury of the First and Summerfield United Methodist Church, of which she has been a member for 45 years.

title: London
description: To the Editor: We recently returned from a trip to London. We found the article on restaurants near museums (''Sightseers' Sanctuaries,'' Travel, Aug. 16) very helpful. We especially liked Cafe Fish. EVELYN L. STONE Long Beach, Calif.

title: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Fort Salonga $380,000 20 Mountain View Drive 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old ranch; dining room, family room, basement, 1 acre; taxes $6,200. Old Field $376,500 116 Old Field Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; family room, office, 2 fireplaces, pond, 2 acres; taxes $4,000. Poquott $360,000 14 Silver Beech Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; family room, fireplace, whirlpool bath, deck, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $7,000. Ronkonkoma $159,000 7 Hill Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old ranch; finished basement, fireplace, porch, pool, cabana; taxes $3,200. Sayville $166,000 3 Budenos Drive 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; den, finished basement; taxes $3,300. Smithtown $227,000 3 Patricia Court 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old center-hall colonial; finished basement, 1-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $3,800. OTHER AREAS Pound Ridge, N.Y. $400,000 East Woods Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new frame colonial; deck, 3.45 acres; not yet assessed. title: A Life of Skating Leads to Calgary
description: The story goes that when Eleanor Blair was about to give birth to her sixth child, her husband dropped her off at the hospital in Cornwall, N.Y., and proceeded to the skating meet where another of their children was competing.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The walls in my living room are covered with dark wood panels, and I want to paint them a light color. What should I do to paint these walls without damaging the wood?

title: Dance: Erick Hawkins Company in 'Black Lake'
description: ERICK HAWKINS choreographed ''Black Lake'' in 1969 but for some reason this translucent ceremonial suite has not been danced since 1978. On Friday night it was revived again at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, as part of the Erick Hawkins Dance Company season ending tonight.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: A CONTROVERSIAL housing and marina development fronting on Barnegat Bay in Brick Township has spawned a study of the impact of future growth all along that waterway.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: I find it appalling that men who can risk the ups and downs of Wall Street, climbing Mount Everest and racing in the Grand Prix are ''scared'' of taking on the greatest challenge that life has to offer - the ability to commit to caring about another human being.

title: 90 Photographs: Two Faces of Old New York
description: The New York of two very different periods will live again on the walls of the PaineWebber art gallery, at 1285 Avenue of the Americas, beginning Thursday when it opens an exhibit of photographs taken during the first decades of the century by the the architectural firm of McKim, Mead & White and during the Depression by photographers working for the Works Progress Administration. The 90 photographs are on loan from the Museum of the City of New York.

title: GENETICISTS STUDY DAMAGE IN FISH
description: LEAD: BOTTOM fish taken from Long Island Sound and examined by geneticists as part of the Long Island Sound Taskforce study show varying degrees of chromosomal damage, according to a preliminary report.

title: An Untimely Idea for Social Security
description: What a strange time for Otis Bowen, Secretary of Health and Human Services, to float his new Social Security balloon. Just days ago, Congressional and White House negotiators gave up trying to cap automatic cost-of-living increases in Social Security benefits. That's one reason the deficit-reduction package that Congress will struggle with this week is a mouse, or worse. Without some way to hold down payments to middle- and upper-income retirees, the burden of deficit reduction may end up falling too heavily on programs for poor people.

title: From Track to Track in Ireland
description: BY early afternoon, some of the stores on Shop Street, Galway's aptly named main commercial thoroughfare, are starting to close their doors. Bumper to bumper, long lines of cars thread their way along Shop and the other narrow streets that lead out of town. The buskers, strolling street musicians, have put aside their fiddles and tin whistles; they, too, are leaving. And in the window of a shop selling industrial pipe, a sign tells it all: ''Closing at One Today -Gone to the Races.''

title: Political Notes; Amid Doubts, Kemp Rules Out a House Run
description: Although he could keep his options open while he seeks the Republican Presidential nomination, Representative Jack F. Kemp, who represents all or part of four counties in western New York, has ruled out seeking a 10th term in the House, according to his press spokesman, John Buckley.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DOCUMENTARY
description: LEAD: The Coming Of Man Written, produced and narrated by Robert Raymond. Sony Nature Video Library. 1986. 67 minutes. $19.95. Archeology is an affair that requires extraordinary patience, a point that this lethargic video may have taken too much to heart. It presents a history of archeological finds throughout Australia and surveys some current activity.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: A great deal of scientific evidence suggests that the normal central nervous system is significantly less functional at 40 than it is at 20. This dysfunction is perhaps most evident in an area with great implications for a boxer's well being, hand-eye speed and coordination. Holmes, after an amateur career, 50 professional fights, and countless rounds of sparring, does not possess a normal central nervous system. Hence he is not qualified to fight on two counts: 1) his advanced age, and 2) his repeatedly traumatized nervous system. MATTHEW BOWEN Ithaca, N.Y.

title: BARE KNUCKLES ON MADISON AVENUE
description: I noticed that there was no mention made of the nationality or religion of any of the individuals in the Ted Bates article, except for the brothers Saatchi. These men were described as of ''Iraqi-Jewish descent.'' Why is this kind of description relevant? There is no mention of the religion of Mr. Jacoby, Mr. Zuckert, Mr. Mars et al, nor of their places of origin. IRIS BASHKIN Avon, Conn.

title:
ART;
PHOTOGRAPHS THAT RANGE OVER TBME AND CULTURES
description: LEAD: WHAT is probably the best presentation of early photography to be mounted on Long Island is currently on view at the Parrish Art Museum. For this showing, 70 examples from the Paul F. Walter Collection, widely acknowledged for its quality, have been selected by John Szarkowski, director of the department of photography at the Museum of Modern

title: Israel's Arab Army Of Migrant Workers
description: LEAD: ISRAELI writer Dahn Ben-Amotz was standing on his second-floor balcony recently, repairing cracks in his stone wall with plaster. As he worked away, an Israeli couple came walking down the street. The Israeli man looked up at Mr. Ben-Amotz and shouted at him in Hebrew, ''Hey Ahmed, what time is it?

title: HOCKNEY CASTS A NEW LIGHT ON 'TRISTAN'
description: THREE WEEKENDS AGO, IN A large rambling house high up in the Hollywood Hills, a party of three sat before a model theater. Built to a scale of 1 to 12, it mimicked exactly the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles, complete with proscenium, flies and a keyboard for the lights. The house was the home of David Hockney - painter, draftsman, printmaker, photographer and stage designer - and the party of three had driven up from Santa Monica for a run-through in miniature of a new production of Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde,'' which has its premiere this evening at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion.

title:
INVESTING;
A High Return, With Protection
description: LEAD: ''MOST people in the marketplace don't want to take a lower short-term yield,'' said John A. Vogt Jr., whose year-old income fund, Treasury First Inc., offers investors just that. Mr. Vogt says that giving up a small amount of current yield is worthwhile if the result is capital preservation in a volatile bond market.

title: OUTLETS FOR MUSICIANS
description: LEAD: IN Nassau County, where they began four decades ago, such veteran ensembles as the Great Neck and the Rockaway-Five Towns Symphonies continue to thrive, while newcomers like the South Shore Symphony of the Five Towns Music Arts Foundation and the Massapequa Philharmonic Orchestra take hold. The latter, now in its fifth season, has secured its place as the successor of the one-time Merrick Symphony, which is now the all-professional Nassau Symphony

title: ELMSFORD MOTEL LOSES FRANCHISE
description: LEAD: THE company that franchises Howard Johnson Motor Lodges nationwide says it no longer has anything to do with what was the Howard Johnson in Elmsford.

title: Miami Survives By 20-16
description: In an erratic, emotional game, Miami defeated South Carolina tonight to go 11-0 and set the stage for a game that will decide the national championship.

title: ARCHIVES OF BUSINESS: The Toy Industry; Under the Tree, in Christmases Past
description: CHRISTMAS was a lot easier on parents before toys came along. When children played with wooden spoons or pots, their parents not only didn't have to spend any money but, more important, didn't have to make any choices. (They also didn't have to squirm around under couches and beneath dish washers, days later, rooting for mislaid pieces from the Erector set.) By the late 1800's, the toy business was in full swing. Besides dolls and stuffed animals, stores were offering Jack-Straws, the Roaming Turtle, the Jester, the Electric Experiment Box and the Tom Stout Marble Game.

title: Campaign Reform Sabotage
description: Mayor Koch's sound proposal for public financing of New York City election campaigns would reduce the distorting effect of big political contributions, setting a model for Albany and the country. But a small-minded power grab by the City Council now jeopardizes approval.

title: Sports of The Times; A Gain For Civil Rights
description: BARRY McKEEVER was opposed to mandatory drug testing even before the National Collegiate Athletic Association sent around a monitor to watch him urinate.

title: Opera: 'Fledermaus,' In Old World and New
description: AMERICAN culture bears the burdens of tradition lightly if at all. It is both our joy and our calamity and a source of constant confusion. Perhaps it is this kind of rootlessness and free-floating liberty that creates such bewildering events as Friday night's ''Fledermaus'' at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Pennsylvania Tries Again to Limit Abortions
description: Women would be required to notify sexual partners before having abortions under a bill approved by the Pennsylvania Legislature, and girls under the age of 18 would need parental consent or a court order to allow the procedure.

title: LAND PRICES OUTBID LURE OF BOWLING
description: LEAD: WHEN wintry winds blow across playing fields from Mineola to Montauk, Long Island athletes head inside for recreation. But recent economic changes have had a chilling effect on local indoor sports facilities, leaving some players out in the cold.

title: Shoreham's Staff Ratings Rise
description: The staff and management of the troubled Shoreham nuclear power plant have ''improved significantly'' since the last evaluation, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said last week in its annual report on the facility.

title: Cubans Give Up in Return for a Long Shot
description: FOR Federal prison officials, it was an unprecedented situation: Inmates rioting not because of overcrowded cells or poor food, but because they did not want to be deported. Cubans who had come to the United States in the Mariel boatlift of 1980, and who in some cases had been confined ever since, ended their takeovers at two Federal prisons last week after winning one more shot at staying in this country.

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1986. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest, and it does not include the titles chosen by the editors of The Book Review as the Best Books of the Year. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. The quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: There is a joke circulating among singles in New York City: ''How does the single woman get rid of roaches? She asks them for a commitment.''

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
IS THERE LIFE AFTER ERRANDS?
description: LEAD: I KNOW exactly how my epitaph will read. It will say: Here lies Barbara Klaus, who died from an overdose of errands.

title: Correction
description: An essay on Nov. 8 about Joseph Brodsky misidentified Osip Mandelstam's schoolmaster. He was the poet and essayist V. V. Gippius.

title: EDITORS' CHOICES: THE BEST BOOKS OF 1987
description: From more than six dozen books initially considered, the editors of The Book Review have chosen 16 for this, the 20th list of best books of the year. (In the first few years of the list the books were called ''outstanding,'' not ''best,'' but the editors then meant the same thing we mean.) For the first time in some years, poetry is on the list: a selection from the works of the Russian poet Andrei Voznesensky. The six books on the fiction list are all novels - in marked contrast to last year, when there were four collections of short stories. Two of the most traditional in form, those by Saul Bellow and Tom Wolfe, are also the most hilarious. Julian Barnes uses a traditional form, and narrative technique, to create a vision of almost poetic grandeur. Toni Morrison and T. Coraghessan Boyle use history and even ghosts to show us transforming visions of American life. The least traditional in form is Philip Roth's latest novel; it deconstructs itself (intentionally) several times over.

title: TRADITION INSPIRES SELF-TAUGHT ILLUMINATOR
description: THREE years ago, David Dorfman was a road-equipment purchasing agent. Now the 54-year-old Mine Hill resident practices the art of manuscript illumination.

title: Army Outmuscles Navy With Long Drives
description: Tory Crawford ran the option play, the quick-hitting keystone to the wishbone offense, for the last time today. He took two steps to his right, cut inside and sprinted 7 yards into the Navy end zone. Touchdown.

title: In a Risky World, Teen-Agers Get Reckless
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent, Dismissed in Pacifist Stand, Seeks Job Back
description: A former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was dismissed for refusing to investigate groups opposed to United States policy in Central America is fighting to reclaim his job.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: Holmes is too old to fight with his wife, let alone Mike Tyson. This will be a horrible fight. The winner of this fight will be the promoter! ROBERT MAYE The Bronx

title: Not-So-Great Debates
description: 'Those great debates of the middle and early 1800's, the Clay and Calhoun and Webster debates - some of what they did at least put off the Civil War for another decade, some of what they did opened up the opportunity for new states and new territories to be created. . . . I have a suspicion that on some of those big and closely fought issues, the debate itself may well have tipped the balance - but you can't tip the balance today if everybody is so heavily positioned before the debate starts that you can't change or modify your position. '

title: Big Ideas Take A Back Seat To a Good Time
description: ''A BALANCE OF THE HEAD and heart - that's my esthetic,'' the composer Henry Threadgill said a few days ago at his home in Brooklyn. ''I'm an emotional person, a highly emotional person, and I like emotional music.''

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LOUISVILLE, KY.;
Putting an End To Doldrums
description: LEAD: AS in many older medium-sized cities, downtown dwellings here are primarily in aging high-rises with mostly elderly tenants.

title: Vandal Throws Cobblestone Through Window on Liberty
description: A jagged hole and splintered shards of glass greeted park rangers Friday at the building that houses the Liberty Bell, the work of a vandal who threw a cobblestone through an inch-thick pane of glass, officials said.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: Unfortunately, especially among heavyweights, those who fought one fight too many are numerous. Joe Louis, arguably the best ever, being slaughtered in the eighth round by a young Rocky Marciano, most closely parallels Larry Holmes's current sad journey and its probable sad ending. LARRY WOLFSON Port Chester, N.Y.

title: 'POPULATION BOMB': CONCERN FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS
description: THE letter to the Long Island editor on Nov. 15 by John M. Geraghty Jr., referring to the article I wrote, ''The Population Bomb Is Still Ticking'' [ Opinion Page, Oct. 25 ] , calls for this response, as he raises every issue dear to the hearts of those who feel threatened by the mildest suggestion of population control.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: Most of those interviewed seem to be afraid of intimate relationships, with several expressing a fear of being trapped.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL GRIDLOCK IN CAPE MAY
description: CAPE MAY COUNTY currently suffers from a case of environmental gridlock involving sewage sludge, a byproduct of waste-water purification.

title: Baby Killed by Terrier
description: A mixed boxer-pit bull terrier mauled a sleeping 2-week-old baby to death early Friday, officers said. The infant, Brian Lillis, was asleep in a car seat on a sofa when he was pulled to the floor and attacked by the 40-pound dog, the police said. The police killed the dog at the request of a deputy medical examiner.

title: William Pitkin Jr., A Salesman, Wed To Amy H. Fearon
description: Amy Hudson Fearon and William Woodbridge Pitkin Jr., 1986 graduates of Williams College, were married yesterday at the First Church of Christ in Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. Dr. H. Dana Fearon 3d, a Presbyterian minister who is an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article from San Salvador on Nov. 5 about steps by Central American governments to comply with a regional peace agreement discussed the release of political prisoners in Nicaragua. The issue was also described in a chart on Nov. 7 and an article in The Week in Review on Nov. 8.

title: GORBACHEV'S SHREWD SUMMITRY
description: The second summit meeting between President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev ends in icy collapse without any agreement, not even on a date for the next summit. Gorbachev accuses Reagan of scuttling the summit. Reagan coldly tells the Soviet leader, ''I think you didn't want a summit,'' and then rides off cursing in his limousine.

title: MOVIES
description: The Tall Men Starring Clark Gable, Robert Ryan, Jane Russell. Directed by Raoul Walsh. 1955. Playhouse Video. 122 minutes. $59.98. For a tale that pits Clark Gable against Robert Ryan, ''The Tall Men'' makes a mighty mild movie. The weather is heavier than the plot of this Western, which takes place mostly on a big cattle drive from Texas to Montana - 5,000 head herded by a batch of Mexican hombres from ethnic casting plus a tribe of Sioux to be shot down along the way. The scenery is impressive - the mountains of Montana, the plains of Kansas, Jane Russell - but they can't match the gaps in the action, which are wider than Texas.

title: CHOOSING FILES FOR WOOD AND METAL
description: FILES for smoothing and shaping metal and wood are useful and inexpensive additions to any do-it-yourselfer's tool kit. However, files are categorized by an obscure terminology that can make choosing one perplexing.

title: Julie Ann Benton Is Wed in Detroit To M. V. Lynk 3d
description: Julie Ann Benton, a daughter of the late George Ross Benton of Fort Worth and the late Florence Evans Benton Alexander of Detroit, was married in Detroit yesterday to Myles Vanderhurst Lynk 3d, the son of the late Mr. Lynk 2d of Washington and the late Doris Sheafe Lynk of New York. The Rev. Rollin B. Norris performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: LIBRARY ACCESS PROMPTS FEUD
description: LEAD: A FEUD over library access has broken out between residents in the Town Smithtown and the Commack Public Library, which is in the Town of Huntington but has been used by Smithtown residents in the past.

title: Stenographer Supports Judge In Investigation on Sex Trial
description: The stenographer who recorded the proceedings of a sexual misconduct trial has told an investigating judge that she did not see the trial judge humiliate the complainant by ordering her down on her hands and knees to re-enact an assault, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: TAXABLE REAL ESTATE RISES BY 24.9%
description: LEAD: THE total value of New Jersey's taxable real estate increased by a record 24.9 percent, to $357 billion, during the fiscal year that ended July 1, according to state tax officials.

title: GROUP TO ACQUIRE ACRES ALONG RIVER
description: The Nature Conservancy, a nonprofit environmental protection group, plans to acquire and protect about 6,700 acres of marshes, bogs, forests, and other ecologically significant land along the Connecticut River in four states.

title: AQUARIUM BILL APPROVAL DUE
description: LEAD: GOVERNOR KEAN is expected to give this depressed city a Christmas gift in the form of his signature on a bill that would bring it an aquarium.

title: NEW CHINESE ARRIVAL IN WANTAGH
description: IT'S deja vu time; a new Chinese restaurant, Peking Dynasty, has opened on Merrick Road in Wantagh. This restaurant, like other recent Chinese arrivals, is in the mold, with the standard color scheme of pink, rose, plum, burgundy, mauve and gray. In bygone days, Chinese restaurants were red and gold and sported dragons and lanterns. Today's restaurants are visually more restrained but are just as obviously in the Chinese groove.

title: As Rock Becomes History, The Past Crowds the Present
description: IN RICHARD STRAUSS'S OPERA ''Die Frau ohne Schatten,'' a mythical emperor turns slowly to stone because his wife can't bear children, a symbol (in Hugo von Hofmannsthal's brilliant, if now rather sexist, libretto) of her inability to love. Looking at the current state of rock-and-roll, one wonders if something similar isn't happening.

title: Comparing Key Points
description: THE HOUSE DEMOCRATIC BILL Training.

title: TV: 'Northanger Abbey,' Austen Satire
description: PUBLIC television's ''Masterpiece Theater'' ventures into predictable territory tonight - on Channel 13 at 9 P.M. - with Jane Austen's ''Northanger Abbey.'' Here, in a one-part, 90-minute adaptation, is still another excuse for a British period piece, exquisitely costumed and expertly acted. But fans of the series are likely to be perplexed by this particular adaptation. Straightforward naturalism, the bedrock style of ''Masterpiece Theater,'' gives way to rather startling dreamlike, at times nightmarish sequences. At certain moments, it looks like ''Austen Meets Fellini.''

title: IF A STRANGER CALLS, MANY ARE WAITING
description: By the hundreds of thousands, Americans are choosing to spend time on the telephone with groups of strangers.

title: Market Research
description: To the Editor:

title: Gerald Donovan, Lawyer, 96
description: Gerald Donovan, a lawyer in New York for six decades, died Thursday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital Medical Center after a short illness. He was 96 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: Christos Thomas Weds Miss Coufos
description: Donna Ellen Coufos, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George M. Azzariti of Alpine, N.J., was married yesterday to Christos J. Thomas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas of Yonkers. The Rev. Robert Stephanopolis performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral in New York.

title: Andrew A. Sunkin Weds Miss Rubin
description: Leslie Meg Rubin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Stanley Rubin of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Andrew Alan Sunkin, a son of Mrs. Irving Sunkin of New York and the late Mr. Sunkin, were married last night at the Harrison (N.Y.) Jewish Community Center. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and Cantor Lawrence Avery officiated Susan Beth Rubin was maid of honor for her sister. Neil Michael Sunkin was his brother's best man.

title: LANDSCAPES SHOW AT U. OF BRIDGEPORT
description: THE mass filling the picture is one of those Southwestern mesas that look like fossilized architecture. A reproduction of a 1978 black-and-white photograph by Michael Smith, it could be an Abstract Expressionist image, and, in a way, owes its existence to that movement in art. ''Toroweap, Arizona,'' as it's called, is one of the 67 landscapes by 56 photographers that make up ''Views and Visions,'' the present attraction at the Carlson Gallery at the University of Bridgeport.

title: AT THE TOP OF THE MOUNTAIN
description: I read with mixed emotions Patricia Allaire's ''Mountain Hikes, Now'' [ Topics, Opinion Page, Nov. 1 ] . This was an account of how she and her son hiked Crane Mountain near her Adirondack cabin.

title: DELAYS EXPLAINED BY TRAIN OFFICIALS
description: SIXTEEN percent of its trains are running late, according to a recent report by NJ Transit, and its officials say that financial and material factors contributing to the tardiness cannot be eliminated overnight.

title: Leslie Mayers Has Wedding
description: At the Metropolitan Club in Washington Leslie Helen Mayers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel K. Mayers of Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Neil Shroyer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman C. Shroyer of Franklin, Va. Judge Louis F. Oberdorfer of the Federal District Court in Washington performed the ceremony.

title: Gifts the Magi Never Brought: A Literary Quiz; Answers to Quiz
A FAMILY MOVES BUT THE DOG OBJECTS AND DISAPPEARS
description: ALMOST everyone in our old neighborhood knew Gregor. For 11 years he had been a

title: Art
description: This is the last week of an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of which little was known in advance and not a great deal was expected in terms of audience response. Never before had there been in the United States a retrospective exhibition of the great Spanish 17th-century painter Francesco Zurbaran. To organize such a show - above all, to prize important loans out of Spanish museums, not to mention the Louvre and many another important source - was a long and bothersome task. Moreover, the subject matter was often disconcerting to a secular taste. What if nobody went?

title: WHAT CHURCHILL AND JUDY GARLAND HAD IN COMMON
description: LEAD: CARNEGIE HALL The First One Hundred Years. By Richard Schickel and Michael Walsh. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $49.50.

title: Recipient of Artificial Heart Reported in Stable Condition
description: The 60-year-old recipient of an artificial heart opened his eyes today for the first time after the implant operation that lasted for 10 hours Friday. The implant was complicated further because doctors had to replace the first mechanical heart with a smaller model.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
Sailing Through School
description: LEAD: IN 1965, when he was 18 years old, Rob Somerville enlisted in the Navy and requested duty in Vietnam. A year later, he shipped out to the Mekong Delta. For 13 months, he served as gunner's mate second class in River Assault Group 13. He ambushed Vietcong, swept enemy mines and pulled dead Americans from the muddy shallow water of the Mekong

title: Behind the Prison Riots: Precautions Not Taken
description: Federal officials overlooked early signs of trouble and failed to take precautions that might have avoided the riots by rebellious Cuban inmates at Federal prisons in Oakdale, La., and Atlanta.

title: 'SILENCE' RULING SEEN AS CHALLENGE TO LEGISLATURE
description: NEW JERSEY'S law directing schools to conduct a moment of silence at the start of each school day died at the door of the United States Supreme Court last week, and one of the men who brought the case there said that a more important issue was lost at the same time.

title: Susan King, a Student, Weds Matthew Russell
description: At the Presbyterian Church of the Covenant in New York, Susan King, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas King of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew M. Russell, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Russell of Kensington, Conn. The Rev. Karl W. Gillmeister, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Maryland Is Finding Homes For Homeless AIDS Sufferers
description: Seventeen months ago, Glenn Smith was a person with AIDS who needed a home, and Madge Lewis was a person with a home who wanted to help.

title:
GARDENING;
TIMING IS CRUCIAL FOR CHRISTMAS PLANTS
description: LEAD: BY this time you should be able to tell whether your poinsettia or Christmas cactus will be in flower for Christmas.

title: WETLANDS ARE NOT JUST ANOTHER PICTURESQUE PLACE
description: AN ENVIRONMENTALIST is sometimes defined as someone who has a greater concern for the welfare of humankind in the future than in the present.

title: GARDENING
description: THE bad news for those seeking books as gifts for gardeners is that it's not at all hard to find indifferent ones, especially the sleek copycat productions of packagers who overestimate the public's ability to absorb another abundant crop of picture books. (One item this year verges on true atrocity. I won't name it, but it costs $16.95, has only 12 pages including endpapers, and features four gardens made of pop-up paper cutouts. It isn't called ''The Ken and Barbie Garden,'' though it ought to be.) The good news, however, is that 1987 has yielded a satisfying harvest of books on horticulture. Here are the very best.

title: More Schools Offer Drug-Abuse Help
description: MORE and more local school districts in the state have been establishing their own in-school education and treatment programs in response to a continuing rise in alcohol and drug abuse and addiction among students.

title: Campus Debate on C.I.A. Reverses 60's Roles
description: Students at a liberal arts college here are battling for the chance to meet with Central Intelligence Agency recruiters on campus, something college teachers and students across the country are trying to ban.

title: N. CAROLINA UPSET BY VANDERBILT, 78-76
description: Vanderbilt survived a frantic comeback attempt by North Carolina in the final nine seconds tonight and upset the Tar Heels, 78-76.

title: Legislators in Region Brace for Budget Cuts
description: Although New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will feel the sting of Federal budget cuts, most legislators from the region believe cuts are needed for the sake of the general economy.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN SNACK FOOD
description: LEAD: IN the battle for the allegiance of taste buds, snack food makers have been caught in the crossfire between the consumer's desire for something old (read comforting) yet new (meaning fast, different-tasting and preferably nutritious). ''Snack foods are life-style driven,'' said Mona Doyle, president of the Consumer Network, a consumer research company.

title: The Real Economy Is Still Looking Good
description: THE capitalist world last week continued to present a bewildering split-level scene.

title: 'How It Was'
description: To The Editor:

title: The Dance: Alvin Ailey
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater was in top form on Friday night at the City Center Theater when it gave this season's first performances of three works from its repertory.

title: FAREWELL TO WIT, HELLO VULGARITY
description: COMMERCIAL TELEVISION ENTERTAINMENT is tumbling into a Vulgarity Sweepstakes. Today's viewers will find language and situations on their weekly series that would never have got past the ''program practices'' guards just five years ago. One major reason for the change is the expanding presence of cable television, where more permissive rules about content allow operators to carry uncensored theatrical-release films and stand-up comedy acts that revel in aggressive coarseness. According to some current standards, this has something to do with being ''adult.''

title: New York's Odd Antismoking Decision
description: LEAD: The court ruling that New York State's Public Health Council exceeded its authority in setting rules for smoking in public was greeted with an indifference that is hard to comprehend.

title: Laura Jean Forte Engaged to Wed
description: Laura Jean Forte and Martin P. Mair, who both received master's degrees in May from the School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University, plan to be married in February.

title: Baby Talk About Two Cultures
description: IN THE BLITHELY, DANGEROUSLY NONCONFORM-ist household in which Bill Forsyth's superb new ''Housekeeping'' unfolds, maintaining order may be a matter of sweeping the floating debris into closets while the flood waters surge knee-high. Or it might mean letting Darwinism prevail among the houseplants. ''Fungus! D'you suppose she grows them?'' exclaims a very proper lady from the local church, one of several sent to find out whether the woman of the house is a fit guardian for two young girls. What they discover, among other things, are giant mushrooms thriving in what is supposed to be a pot full of flowers.

title: HELPING THE BUYER BE WARY
description: FOR a major towing operator in Tuckahoe, business was thriving.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
ELITE VOLUNTEERS
description: LEAD: American Telephone and Telegraph is seeking to expand its role as a corporation with a social conscience.

title: Old Theater's New Look: Expansion by Excavation
description: If the zoning rules do not permit a taller building, the answer must be to dig deeper for space, and that is what the owners of the old St. Marks Theater building have done at Second Avenue and St. Marks Place in Manhattan.

title: Disillusioned Brazil Awakes From a Dream of Prosperity
description: When Mario Saleiro, a young Brazilian architect, was offered a job in Portugal this year, he jumped at the chance. ''I hope to return here one day,'' he explained while packing, ''but everything has become so difficult.''

title: Re-Examining a Scholar
description: One of Yale University's brightest lights apparently had some rather dark thoughts as a young man. Paul de Man, who was Yale's Sterling Professor of Humanities at the time of his death in 1983, wrote for an anti-Semitic, pro-Nazi newspaper in Belgium during World War II, a Belgian researcher has discovered. Colleagues and associates were stunned to learn that Dr. de Man, later known as a founder of deconstructionism, had written articles addressing such topics as whether Jews ''pollute'' modern fiction. ''I was pained and saddened to learn of these writings,'' said Neil Hertz, a Johns Hopkins University professor. The articles are to be published next year in the Oxford Literary Review. Comments on them will be solicited from scholars.

title: Susan Rachel Webber Wed to James G. Gatto
description: Susan Rachel Webber, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Banice M. Webber of Providence, R.I., was married there last evening to James Gregory Gatto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gatto of Brooklyn. Rabbi Leslie Gutterman officiated at Temple Beth-El.

title: The Editors Grimm
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING LIMITS AS 30 LOOMS
description: SOON I will hit my first crisis birthday. I will turn 30.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Just Plain Millionaires

title: SUFFOLK RESIDENTS FIGHT A NEW CRISIS NURSERY
description: THE ''not in my backyard syndrome'' has been recently felt by a group of Terryville and Port Jefferson Station residents, whose neighborhood is the proposed location for a crisis nursery - for infants and small children at risk of being abused by their parents.

title: A March Wedding For Miss Masket
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ann Masket to Jonathan Sommer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Sommer Jr. of Somers, N.Y., and Boca Raton, Fla., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David C. Masket of the Riverdale section of the Bronx. The couple plan to marry in March.

title: PROFILE OF TYPICAL GAMBLER DEVELOPED
description: THE Council on Compulsive Gambling of New Jersey has reported that 53 percent of callers to its ''hot line'' (800) GAMBLER had problems with casino gambling and that the average gambler was a 34-year-old married male with two children.

title: Age Is Issue in Dakota Senate Race
description: With the election still a year off, North Dakota voters found themselves bombarded this fall by a series of television advertisements for Senator Quentin N. Burdick, the venerable Democrat who next year will seek his fifth full term in the United States Senate at the age of 80.

title: LITERARY FEMINISM COMES OF AGE
description: OUTSIDE THE LEC-ture hall, sunshine falls in dusty beams through the trees. It is a scene suffused with tradition, a mixture that is two parts dry leaves to one part poetry. Students lounge on the steps, books propped before them, just as Princeton students have sat on the same steps, reading the same books, for generations.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN GENEVA
description: Many winter sports enthusiasts passing through Geneva stop over in the city to recover from jet lag or the rigors of schussing and apres-ski.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. The walls in my living room are covered with dark wood panels, and I want to paint them a light color. What should I do to paint these walls without damaging the wood?

title: Baseball Notebook; At Winter Meetings, Nonwinners to Look for Shot in the Arm
description: TEAMS that did not win, some that didn't even contend, watched the Minnesota Twins win the World Series after making one key trade last winter - the acquisition of Jeff Reardon as their No. 1 relief pitcher. The nonwinners saw the San Francisco Giants make some midseason and late-season trades and win a division title after having lost 100 games two years earlier.

title: Single Mothes Seeks Holiday Joy
description: There is a single mother living in Manhattan welfare hotel who will celebrate Christmas again this year in the room she shares with her child, high above the festive lights and evergreen swags that line the city's streets.

title: UTILITY IS ATTACKED ON TRASH RECOVERY
description: THE state's largest utility is under increasing criticism for challenging a law requiring it to subsidize garbage disposal for towns that develop trash-burning electric generators.

title: STATE IS SAID TO CHOOSE OPTION OF ADDING HIGH-OCCUPANCY LANE TO I-287
description: LEAD: THE state's Department of Transportation has apparently decided to rebuild the current six lanes of Route 287, which links the county's eastern and western portions, and add a seventh reversible high-occupancy-vehicle lane. The new lane would be reserved for buses, car and van pools and could be changed according to traffic demands during different travel periods.

title: MODERN CONVENIENCES
description: THE MORE EXPENSIVE THE antique, the faster its sale. Such has been the supply-and-demand rule of home furnishings in recent years. Indeed, the lust for a set of graceful Regency chairs, a beautifully inlaid cabinet or a breakfront crafted by an 18th-century furniture maker became as much a status symbol as a silver Porsche or a gold-faced Rolex watch. This thirst for fine old pieces reflected a rebirth of conservative values nationally. In home design, the point was to make everything look as though it had been inherited, not delivered yesterday to be paid for tomorrow.

title: BARE KNUCKLES ON MADISON AVENUE
description: As a former Ted Bates employee, I was interested to read the truth of the whole mess at the agency (''Bare Knuckles on Madison Avenue,'' by Art Kleiner, Nov. 8). The only people who deserved further mention were those who were not vice presidents or department heads - people who had been with the company 10, 20, even 40 years, and there were many, who had put their lives into Ted Bates Advertising/ New York. The chairman of the board decided to play a game and lost. But he had put himself in a no-lose situation, and many others (those who didn't become instantly wealthy) were thrown out of their jobs or demoted.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SNACK FOOD;
Indulging In a Small-Sized Splurge
description: LEAD: A GREAT many ''new product'' introductions, which have hit record highs for some companies, are really just simple twists on familiar themes. One favorite variation is to change the size of a popular product. For example, Nabisco, maker of the Oreo, which it calls ''the world's most popular cookie,'' recently introduced Oreo Big Stuf, a jumbo-sized, three-inch version of the chocolate sandwich cookie that was first brought to market in 1911.

title: IS THIS FILTER NECESSARY?
description: DO owners of point-and-shoot cameras want to be ''creative'' photographers? That's the tantalizing, seemingly contradictory question raised by Minolta, which recently introduced a compact-camera version of the Cokin Creative Filter System.

title: 'INSTANT IMAGE,' AT ROCKLAND CENTER, A SHOW OF POLAROID PRINTS
description: FAY WRAY was a movie star during the 1930's. Fey Ray, one of the stars in ''The Instant Image,'' is a Weimaraner dog that will probably become more famous as it is the photographer William Wegman's new model. As such, she succeeds the late great Man Ray, not the Dadaist but another Weimaraner (some puns merit capital Punishment).

title: A Proud People Seeks U.S. Respect
description: WHEN visiting Americans tour a Russian factory, farm, school or hospital, they are sure to be politely interrogated about how it stacks up against a comparable facility in the United States. After this questioning, they may be startled to hear their host declare, contradicting the immediate evidence and the apparent rules of glasnost, ''Yes, we have all that, too.''

title:
HOME VIDEO;
SPORTS
description: LEAD: Boom! Bang! Whap! Doink! John Madden on Football. Fox Hills Video. 60 minutes. $29.95. Anyone who has watched a football game covered by John Madden knows where the cartoon expletives in the title of this video come from; they are the kind of refreshingly un-announcerish commentary that, combined with the expertise garnered in a successful coaching career, has made Madden one of the best announcers in sports.

title: 'Why Dad Was in Such a Bad Mood'
description: THE other night, I was at dinner in Washington with five senators, three members of Congress and some Wall Street leaders. There was much talk about the causes and effects of the October crash. One senator said, ''Look, if I asked you to tell me what to do if you were in my shoes, what three steps would you take to solve the problem?'' Other than reiterating impatience with the budget deficit, all the Wall Street leaders were silent.

title: Pricey Services
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE OF FRANCE IN GREENWICH
description: SO many French restaurants, charcuteries and patisseries have opened in Greenwich in recent years that the town seems to be turning into a gustatory department of France.

title: THREE DECORATIONS TO MAKE
description: Holiday time often brings out creative talents. With each year, the traditions become more firmly rooted and the family looks forward to to a display of seasonaltrimmings. The three designs shown here are easy to duplicate and are made from live plant materials. Two of them are based on influences from Victorian England and are enriched by embellishments from this country. The live wreath is long-lasting and can become a favored centerpiece for use again and again. The decorations can be made before the busy schedule of festivities begins and will look fresh and lively through the season. KISSING BELL

title: DEVELOPMENT OF OLD HOUSES PLANNED
description: FROM Suffield to Guilford, from Greenwich to Putnam, new condominiums and commercial developments are cropping up, along Main Streets and tucked away in suburban and rural corners. Now, one of the newest developments is taking on quite a different - and older - look.

description: Giacomo Landi stood in the back of the Federal District Court here this week, balancing his emotions and his lessons.

title: FIG TREE BEARS A CROP OF MEMORIES
description: THE fig tree grew in the backyard of the acre property deeded to us with the purchase of our present home. Embedded in the ground by the gardener, the tree was nurtured by and brought joy to the old man and woman from whom we bought the house. It might have received no more attention from us than any other shrub or tree, except that the old man always asked about it.

title: An Unlikely Locale for a Lovely Bash
description: The lighting is harsh, the stink overpowering and there are no powder rooms, but for one night next week an Air Force hangar here will be transformed, Cinderella-like, into a palace for a ball.

title: Keeping on Top of All Those Details
description: HERE at Mission Control we use a Rolodex file to keep track of sources and telephone numbers. We use a small pocket diary and a larger desk calendar to keep track of appointments and meetings. We keep track of expenses on slips of paper that we stuff into pockets or desk drawers, to be gathered and added up later with a pocket calculator. Phone messages are written on ''while you were goofing off'' slips. We keep our daily ''to do'' lists on pads and the backs of envelopes. We keep track of large projects and deadlines mainly by memory; sometimes we forget. In short, we do things the way they are done in most companies. And we do them this way even though we have personal computers all around us, in every nook and cranny and on almost every desk.

title: Sandra Barrett Weds Chad Copenhaver
description: Sandra Vail Barrett, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Halsey V. Barrett of Bronxville, N.Y., was married at the Reformed Church there yesterday to Charles L. Copenhaver 3d, a son of Mrs. Copenhaver Jr. of Bronxville and the late Rev. Dr. Copenhaver Jr. The Rev. Robert W. Bedingfield performed the ceremony.

description: The Cambridge City Council is to vote Monday on a proposal to censure the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for evicting about 25 homeless people from a vacant lot owned by the university.

description: IF you were wearing a red, blue and white-striped shirt when you found an ancient temple that other archeologists had been seeking for centuries, you might become inordinately fond of that shirt and even consider it a talisman. Iris Love was wearing such a shirt when she discovered the Temple of Aphrodite in southwest Turkey in 1969 and, quite naturally, she considered it lucky.

description: When Evander Holyfield came into the ring tonight, Dwight Muhammad Qawi mocked him with a leering smile.

description: IT will be two more years before some of the restrictions on driving heavy vehicles on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive are lifted, and two years after that before they are all removed.

title: Will Trade Follow the Summit Talks?
description: While Soviet-American trade has never been large in volume - it will total only about $2 billion in 1987 - it has been controversial and highly political. In the early 1970's, during the era of detente, American companies began to move into the Soviet Union in a big way. In 1971, Mack Truck designed and built a large part of the Soviet Union's $1.4 billion Kama River truck manufacturing plant. The following year, President Nixon initiated a major gain sale to the Russians worth $750 million - the first of several such sales.
