description: Al Bianchi, the Knicks' general manager, confirmed today that he has held discussions with Dallas about a trade involving Bill Cartwright and Detlef Schrempf, the Mavericks' 6-foot-10-inch forward.

title: MOVIES
description: Harry and the Hendersons Starring John Lithgow, Melinda Dillon, Don Ameche and Lainie Kazan. Directed by William Dear. MCA Home Video. 111 minutes. $89.95. This film's cassette packaging ought to be emblazoned with a warning: ''View Only in the Presence of a Living Room Full of Noisy Children, Many Crinkly Bags of Oversalted Junk Food, and Large Plastic Bottles of Tooth-Rotting Soda.'' Given these requirements, the movie is likely to provide mindless fun. Absent this ambiance, forget it.

title: Deer Disappears
description: Most deer run away. Jeff Humphreys says his eight-point buck was carried away. Mr. Humphreys, of Ligonier, Pa., told the police that someone stole his freshly killed deer from the back of his pickup truck Tuesday night as the truck was parked at an inn. ''He had shot himself a nice eight-point,'' said Jim Steel, a state trooper, ''and he was at a watering hole for a beer and to talk about his deer, and he came out to find the deer was taken.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: ON THE BLOCK If practice makes perfect, then the students in Hofstra's art appraisal program should be on their way to perfection after today, when they get a chance to put theory to practical use in a Christmas auction. For a handling fee of $3, people who have been cleaning out their attics or bric-a-brac shelves can bring art and artifacts - prints, paintings, glass, furniture, silver and the like - to Monroe Lecture Hall on the Hempstead campus between 10 A.M. and noon to have the neophytes, backed up by their teachers, appraise the items. At noon there'll be a preview for would-be buyers, with the gavel going down at 1 P.M. Whatever is sold will cost the sellers a 10 or 15 percent donation to the program. Robert Myron of the fine arts department suggests that collectors leave their van Goghs at home; this auction specializes in pieces starting at about $50 and going up to $500 or $600. SINGERS CELEBRATE

title: Arnold Lobel, Author-Illustrator
description: Arnold Lobel, an award-winning children's book author and illustrator, died of cardiac arrest Friday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TOP MAINE COURT BACKS RIGHT TO DIE
description: The Maine Supreme Court has ruled that the family of a 25-year-old man who has been in an irreversible coma for two years may have the tube that is feeding him intravenously disconnected so that he can die.

title: Paul Bennion Muenzinger Marries Wendy C. Vickrey
description: Wendy Carolyn Vickrey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Remsen Vickrey of Orleans, Mass., was married yesterday to Paul Bennion Muenzinger, a son of John Weaver Muenzinger of White Plains and Barbara Bennion Friedlich of Belmont, Mass. Walter Lawton, the leader of the Westchester Ethical Humanist Society, officiated at Rutherford House in Manhattan.

title: RUNNING ON EMPTY
description: Andrew A. Rooney's Guest Observer column ''Running on Empty'' (Nov. 8) was amusing and instructive. Thanks. You do not mention my greatx grandfather, President Zachary Taylor, 1849-50. He did not attend the Whig Convention. The announcement of his nomination arrived ''postage due''; he refused it. He didn't want the Presidency. He won! Cuomo? GEORGE E. FARRAR JR. Newtown, Pa.

title: Soviet Emigres and Would-Be Emigres
description: A brief list of a few selected people who have sought to emigrate from the Soviet Union or have actually left the country. This list is by no means intended to be exhaustive. It does not include the names of human rights campaigners and other dissidents who have not sought to emigrate, such as Andrei D. Sakharov, Yelena G. Bonner, Sergei Grigoryants, Mustafa Dzhemilev, Lev M. Timofeyev, Gleb Yakunin, Merab Kostava, Mikhail Chlenov and others. ALLOWED TO EMIGRATE Natan Sharansky, 40 years old, one of the most visible members of the human rights movement of the 1970's; released as part of a ''spy swap'' in February 1986 after spending nine years in prison and labor camps. Now living in Israel. Yuri F. Orlov, 63, founding member of Moscow Helsinki Watch; picked up from internal exile and sent to New York in connection with the release of the journalist Nicholas Daniloff in September 1986. Now living in the United States. Janis Barkans, 27, Latvian nationalist; permitted to leave Nov. 27 after being held under house arrest during the anniversary of Latvian independence day and for a week afterward. Ida Nudel, 56, became internationally famous for activities on behalf of Jews; permitted to go to Israel in October. Vladimir S. Slepak, 60, an original member of the Moscow Helsinki Watch; permitted to leave for Israel in October after waiting 17 years. Anatoly Koryagin, 48, psychiatrist active in opposing use of punitive psychiatric confinement of dissidents; permitted to emigrate last spring after being released from prison in February. Irina Ratushinskaya, 33, poet and Russian Orthodox Church member who spent five years in jail for writings deemed anti-Soviet; permitted to go abroad for medical care in October 1986. Iosip Terelya, 44, organizer in the outlawed Ukrainian Catholic Church; requested permission to leave the Soviet Union while imprisoned, and left last August. Now in Toronto. Serafim Yevsyukov, 54, a former navigator for the Soviet airline Aeroflot; spent more than six years in a psychiatric clinic for demonstrating against his son's imprisonment for refusing the military draft; allowed to leave last summer with his son, Serafim, 28, and daughter, Lyudmila, 26, and now in the Washington area. NOT ALLOWED TO EMIGRATE Eduard M. Nadgorny, 56, and Nina Nadgorny, 53, his wife; once a physicist in one of the Soviet Union's most prestigious scientific institutes, Mr. Nadgorny applied with his wife to emigrate in 1980. They went on a nine-day hunger strike earlier this fall but have not yet received word that refusal of their applications refusal has been altered. Naum S. Meiman, 76, mathematician; has been denied permission to emigrate for 14 years. His wife, Inna, 53, died of cancer in Washington on Feb. 9, three weeks after winning a three-year battle to travel abroad for treatment. Veniamin Charny, 50, applied mathematician; fighting cancer of the skin, the thyroid and the neck since the fall of 1979, six months after he first applied to emigrate. His most recent refusal was upheld by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet last month, when he was told his emigration would be considered a threat to state security until 1995. Sergei L. Petrov, 34, photographer, married to Virginia Johnson of Greensboro, N.C. Last month, shortly after an exhibition of his photographs opened in Paris, he was told by visa authorities that his application to join his wife had once again been denied because he was still considered to be in possession of classified information. Yuri Ziman, 49, and Tatyana Ziman, 48, campaigners on behalf of Jewish emigration; have been trying to emigrate for 12 years. Both recently participated in a seminar on the issue of ''state secrecy,'' although Mr. Ziman's report was read in absentia because he is hospitalized awaiting an operation for an aneurism on the brain. Valery N. Soifer, 51, biologist; continues to write scientific articles and critiques that are occasionally published in the West. He has not been able to practice his profession here since shortly after he applied for emigration a decade ago. Lev Shapiro, 47, and Yelizaveta Shapiro, 38; a computer engineer, Mr. Shapiro applied with his wife for emigration 12 years ago. They are among the most active of the would-be emigres in Leningrad. Aleksandr Y. Lerner, 74, first applied to leave 17 years ago; at Ida Nudel's farewell party he said recent releases had given him reason ''to hope,'' but his situation remains unchanged. Allowed to emigrate but not leaving yet: Iosif Z. Begun, 55, an electronics engineer who turned to Hebrew teaching; spent years in prison and Siberian exile for his advocacy of expanded Jewish rights and was given permission in October to emigrate to Israel. However, his son Boris and daughter-in-law, Jana, have refused to renounce their Soviet citizenship as required for emigration, saying they want to retain Soviet passports to be able to visit her parents. Iosif Begun says he will not leave without his son.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: No, assuming he fights someone his own age. ROB NEISNER Pittsford, N.Y.

description: PEOPLE moving into the Stamford, New Haven and Hartford areas are finding something unexpected in their mailboxes - free one-way bus tickets.

description: Despite Federal and state pressure to reach an accord, the city is locked in a dispute with Atlantic County officials over managing Atlantic City International Airport.

description: ASPEN'S mountain manager, Curt Stewart, looked us over the way a general might regard a squad of Green Berets heading off on a hazardous mission.

ART;
AT BELLPORT GALLERY, GIFTS FOR THE SEASON

An attractive selection is to be found at the Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport, where ''All Things Wise and Wonderful'' will be on view through Dec. 20.

title: When Planning Can Be Too Much of a Good Thing
description: TO A CRITIC OF THE EXCESSES of development that have plagued most American downtowns, San Francisco would appear to be the promised land. Here, the planners and the voters, not the real-estate developers, hold the power. The process of getting approval to put up a high-rise office building in the downtown business district here is so complex it must make the hardiest developer yearn for the simplicities of doing business in New York. In San Francisco, the amount of new office construction permitted each year is limited by a strict quota; there are also limits on the height of those tall buildings that do get approved, and restrictions on their locations. A panel of architectural experts must give its approval to each project, which among other requirements must be designed so as to not put any existing park or plaza in shadow. And there is more: a developer wishing to erect an office tower must make a contribution to the city's transit and housing funds, provide or help finance day-care facilities and then be able to certify the economic viability of his project by showing in advance that tenants are interested in taking space.

description: Stymied in their attempts to find leads in the killing of Prime Minister Olof Palme, the Swedish police turned to a worldwide audience this weekend for help, promising a multimillion-dollar reward and anonymity.

title: The Refinements of France in an Age of Elegance

Today in Paris, two completely unrelated exhibitions, held by coincidence at the same time but in different buildings, give a broad and accurate picture of this particular artistic moment.

title: Marquesas By Freighter
description: IN July 1842 an unhappy 22-year-old jumped ship in the South Pacific. He spent 26 days hiding out in the Taipivai valley on the island of Nuku Hiva in the Marquesas before he joined the crew of another whaler. After many more wanderings, including Tahiti and Hawaii, he enlisted in the United States Navy and sailed home on a man-o'-war. The young man's name was Herman Melville. The book he wrote about his experiences was ''Typee'' (1846) - a sensational best seller in both Britain and America.

title: Sacrificing for Team
description: HE scores so many points with such regularity that it's easy to forget that Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is a team player. That was apparent in Milwaukee Friday night when the 40-year-old Los Angeles center accounted for only 7 points in the Lakers' 85-83 loss to the Bucks. It was the first time in 788 games that Abdul-Jabbar had failed to score in double figures, yet he did not even take a shot in the last 3 minutes 11 seconds.

title: Thai Vasectomy Record

A spokesman for the Population and Community Development Association said 1,214 men were vasectomized free of charge in an annual event held on the King's birthday. The association says the previous record for voluntary vasectomies in a single day was 1,202, set here in 1983.

title: TRAVEL AND ADVENTURE
description: AT 13, I desperately wanted to be what I then thought was called an adventuress. It took years to discover the true landscape of that word, with its night-prowling denizens and emotional quicksand. And further years to understand that I didn't mean adventurer either, but some compound poet-naturalist-explorer whose snares were sentences and whose darts were tipped with the curare of wonder. There was a fine literary tradition to join, though I didn't suspect it at the time, which included such rich fictioneers as Melville and Conrad, who had tramped through what Wallace Stevens would later call ''the wild country of the soul,'' and also rhapsodic nonfiction writers like Loren Eiseley, who always found a green thought for a green shade. Or there were literate explorers like Sir Richard Burton, or sensuous tourists like Walter Pater. But the more film and television electrified armchair travelers with quick sensory jolts, the more travel writing seemed to be looked upon as mild and faintly amateurish. Now, thank heavens, the field has become respectable again, and a caravan of travel, exploration and adventure books has begun filing through the bookstores with panache and variety.

title: The Difficulty of Doing Justice to Each Face in a Crowd

But the murder trial that began Sept. 8, now nearing its end, does more than document the troubled state of race relations in the nation's largest city. It also illustrates the difficulties that allegations of mob violence pose for the criminal justice system, and the additional problems that can result - for both the prosecution and the defense -when much of a prosecutor's case hinges on the account of a confessed participant.

title: THE PRIVATE PAIN OF INFERTILITY
description: THE SMALL OFFICE IS CROWDED: 9 OR 10 women wait for their names to be called. After signing in, I stand by the desk and wait like the rest. The silence is communal - not uneasy. ''What stage of your cycle are you at?'' I ask a woman about 35 - my age. Under other conditions this question would have prompted her to move away from me shaking her head, certain I was one of the many odd characters a large metropolitan city regularly serves up. But she knows what I'm talking about: we speak the same language. The women in this office are bound by one important condition: infertility. The inability to reproduce has driven all of us to this in vitro fertilization (I.V.F.) clinic.

title: TESTING GLASNOST
description: THE FIRST TIME I HEARD THE WORD ''glasnost'' from a Soviet official was last October, on a flight from Reykjavik to New York after the Reagan-Gorbachev summit meeting. Together with other Soviet emigres, I had gone to Iceland to protest human rights violations in Russia. On the flight back, I found myself seated near Yuri Dubinin, the Soviet Ambassador to the United States, a veteran diplomat who had never seen a live dissident so close. His curiosity and my disrespect for authority led to an improvised debate. Neither of us was impressed by the other's rhetoric.

title: Cuomo Moves to Ease Strain On State's Computer Workers
description: New York State employees who use computer video display terminals on the job must be provided with adjustable chairs and work stands to prevent muscle and bone problems under guidelines issued by Governor Cuomo.

title: MAMARONECK CASE CHEERS SUPPORTERS OF WATERFRONT PLANS
description: LEAD: THE village of Mamaroneck's waterfront-preservation program has survived its first legal challenge in a ruling that could have broad implications for other coastal communities seeking to regulate development.

description: The nation's community colleges are locked in a bitter dispute with an agency that accredits business schools over the issue of transferring credits from the two-year colleges.

title: Plugging the Leaks in Your Tax Shelter
description: BEFORE the Tax Reform Act of 1986, many high-bracket investors bought tax shelters. They could use the losses from these deals to offset earned income, or income from such traditional investments as stocks and bonds. But the new law imposed tough restrictions on shelters, and did so retroactively. Now, with less than a month to go before the arrival of the new year and a further phase-in of some of the restrictions, investors should re-examine their portfolios.

title: POLITICAL HONEYMOON AY END IN RANCOR
description: LEAD: THE political honeymoon that normally marks the first days in office for newly elected officials may start instead with an argument in Suffolk County.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Nov. 22 about child-abuse cases in the county included an incorrect description of a conviction, provided by an assistant district attorney. The case in Peekskill concerned a school custodian involved in a summer recreation playground program. He was not an employee of the Peekskill Parks Department.

title: Albany Faulted on Troubled Children
description: The chairman of the State Senate Mental Hygiene Committee said this week that New York was ''guilty of longstanding neglect of its emotionally troubled children.''

Even then, struggling with the issues of sex, food and family in ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' he was keeping a record of his life in his little notebook and dreaming of becoming a writer.

Different Housing Priorities
description: LEAD: SOME advocates of racial integration in housing who assembled here last month urged greater efforts toward achieving economic integration as well. But others said economic integration should remain a secondary goal.

That accolade went in 1983 to the Alice Walker novel that formed the basis for the 1985 movie directed by Steven Spielberg. Nor did ''The Color Purple'' - to be shown on WHT Sunday at 8 P.M. and Friday at 9 and on HBO on Saturday at 8 P.M. -win an Academy Award. That year, the dominant film was ''Out of Africa.''

title: Opera: 'La Fiamma'
description: ''LA FIAMMA,'' the most successful of Ottorino Respighi's operas, came to New York Friday night -apparently for the first time - in a Carnegie Hall concert performance by the Collegiate Chorale under Robert Bass. It is a tale of witchcraft and forbidden love set in Byzantine Ravenna, orchestrated with the lush resourcefulness we expect from the author of ''The Pines of Rome.'' Appearing near the end of Italian opera's creative lifespan, it made the rounds of international introduction in the mid-1930's, but its good reception then did not lead to many postwar revivals.

description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Lordan of Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Maureen Lordan to Hugh Arthur O'Reilly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh P. O'Reilly of Mountain Lakes, N.J. Ms. Lordan and her fiance graduated last year from Dartmouth College. She is a systems analyst with the world banking group at the Bank of Boston. He is a second-year student at the Vanderbilt University School of Law.

title: Poland Scales Back Plan for Sharp Price Increases
description: Poland's Prime Minister announced today that food prices would not rise next year as steeply as planned, and linked the move to a failed referendum that sought popular support for the increases.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: The assertion that singles may face greater difficulty and loneliness in later life is more an expression of a fear common to the middle-aged, regardless of marital status, than a reality of old age. One recent study suggests that singles may, in fact, have an advantage in adjusting to the conditions of aging over those who lose their lifelong mates and are left to develop new personal and social skills on their own. MICHAEL A. OWSOWITZ Buffalo

title: Priority for Giants: Changes on the Line
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants insists he is concerned only with the four games remaining in this losing season, starting with the 1 P.M. game today against the Philadelphia Eagles in Giants Stadium. He says he does not want to think about next year until this year is past.

title: Lelia Gwathmey Plans June Wedding
description: Lelia Dilworth Gwathmey, a sales associate at Tiffany & Company in New York, and Francis X. B. Harrington, the director of admissions at the Portledge School in Locust Valley, L.I., plan to be married in June. The future bride is the daughter of Mrs. Gaines Gwathmey Jr. of Glen Head, L.I., who has announced her engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Harrington Jr. of Winchester, Mass.

title: PLASTIC SURGERY WIDENS ITS APPEAL
description: LEAD: THEY go to plastic surgeons with all kinds of reasons why they want to improve their looks.

title: THE MAGIC TOUCH
description: IT'S PRESS DAY FOR the Los Angeles Lakers, when the players meet -maybe endure is more accurate - the news media for the first time before the season starts. A dozen very tall men are scattered about the gymnasium of Loyola Marymount University, with clusters of reporters bunched around them like shrubbery at the base of trees. For more than two hours the players answer questions, pose for pictures and tape promotional announcements.

title: SONGS AND SIGHTS BRIGHTEN SEASON
description: LEAD: BETTER early than never, this year's holiday programming gets off to an expansive start today, with the Vienna Choir Boys singing in Brookville, Dickens's ''Christmas Carol'' opening in East Rockaway and a special exhibition of antique dolls, complete with a demonstration of present-day doll-making, coming to Riverhead.

title: In Philippines, Mayor Begins Uphill Task
description: Gil Baluyut is a small-town Mayor with big ideas and just 60 days to carry them out.

title: New Church for Gay Minister
description: Rose Mary Denman, who was suspended from her duties as a minister in the United Methodist Church when she acknowledged she was a lesbian, has been accepted as a minister in the Unitarian Universalist Fellowship.

title: Invasion by Bus: Christmas Tourists Arrive
description: As she has done on the first Saturday in December for the last seven years, Mary O'Dea left her home in Taunton, Mass., before sunrise and boarded a chartered bus bound for New York.

title: About Men; Couch Dancing
description: BUSINESS TRAVEL OFTEN takes us to unsought destinations. One recent evening, three men and I, related only by the fact that we had worked together on a business deal, found ourselves at large in Houston after a late dinner. Maybe it was the heat and humidity, maybe it was the myth of Texan rambunctiousness, but we decided it was too early to go back to our hotels.

title: BUDGET COMMITTEE RESTORES BUS ROUTES
description: COUNTY legislative leaders seeking to trim a proposed $850.3 million budget took a step in the opposite direction last week by restoring five bus routes that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke had eliminated to save $250,000.

title: Woman Quits Korean Race And Backs Opposition Figure
description: Hong Sook Ja, the first woman to run for the South Korean presidency, dropped out of the race today and threw her support to an opposition leader, Kim Young Sam.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Developers Finding That Less Sells More
description: LEAD: WHILE sales have slowed in the higher-priced developments on the Island, moderately priced projects where houses sell for less than $200,000 are still doing well.

title: CRIME
description: And still they come, the 87th Precinct procedurals by Ed McBain, as they have been coming these past 30 years or so. The latest, his 39th in the series, is TRICKS (Arbor House, $16.95). ''Tricks,'' because the action takes place on Halloween. And there is plenty of action: a bunch of trick-or-treat kids (or are they kids?) knocking over liquor stores and murdering the owners; a dismembered body; a maniacal sex killer. Needless to say, everything is neatly solved at the end. The men of the 87th Precinct are such pros.

title: Wagner Excels All Ways to Gain Final
description: Wagner achieved the biggest football victory in its history today as it eliminated Emory & Henry, 20-15, in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III semifinal.

title: Landlords Suing the City on Violations
description: THE decades-long battle between municipal officials and landlords over enforcement of health and safety code rules has taken a bizarre turn: The landlords are taking the city to court.

title: Question Of the Week; Is Larry Holmes Too Old To Fight?
description: Holmes, in need of neither money nor adulation, will be allowed to place his future health on the table and roll the dice. Does not the real sickness lie in those who would encourage and permit this obscenity as well as those who would, out of morbid curiosity, observe it? LAWRENCE W. YOUNG State College, Pa.

title: Black Businessmen Donate $22,500 to Jackson
description: Thirty black owners and operators of McDonald's fast-food franchises across the country have contributed $22,500 to the Democratic Presidential campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Tenderfoot in the Wilds of Wyoming
description: THE magnolia was getting ready to bloom back in my Philadelphia garden and I was questioning my sanity. Why was I was trekking into subarctic conditions to spend a week skiing in the highest and most remote private guest ranch in the Wyoming Rockies? I and my intrepid party of seven knew we would be cut off from civilization, deep-frozen, virtually snowbound. Even as a child I had hated being sent outdoors to play. As an adult I'd learned to endure annual family ski vacations, but this would be different - no groomed trails, no chair lifts, none of those cute yodeling ski instructors to numb the inevitable panic attacks, no Muzak on the bunny slope. No bunny slope, even.

title: Submarine's Patrol Sets Silent, Random Course
description: ABOARD U.S.S. HENRY M. JACKSON, in Puget Sound - The sound of the klaxon was grating, but the chief of the watch was crisp: ''Dive, dive.''

title: 'A PARTICULARLY FRUSTRATING SITUATION'
description: LEONARD J. BRUCKMAN is the head of the air quality unit of the State Department of Environmental Protection. His department has been responding in recent weeks to Federal criticism of the ozone level in the state, which exceeds the 0.12 parts per million standard set in the 1970's.

title: Mary E. Horan to Marry
description: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth Horan, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at George Washington University, and Robert Forrest Lutz, the vice president in charge of the Los Angeles institutional equity office for Prudential-Bache Securities, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John William Horan of Fairfield, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Miss Horan graduated magna cum laude from Holy Cross College. Her fiance, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frederick Lutz of Pleasantville, N.Y., graduated from Williams College.

title: Correction

description: ''WHAT is East Hampton like?'' The question is asked by one of the hundred restless students forced into the assembly hall to hear the visiting author.

description: AS the season gets under way, so does the rush to airports and train and bus terminals. For suitcase-toting and package-laden travelers, one of December's most common sights, a folding luggage cart would probably be a welcome and practical gift.

title: Pop Music
description: The voice reigns in South African popular music. Voices join in ringing harmonies, overlap in syncopations, swoop into falsetto or glide through melodies; the clicks that are part of the Zulu language turn into percussion. This week offers two chances to hear South African vocalizing - one from a choir that has won superstardom in South Africa, one from a expatriate female singer.

title: Loss of Engine Forces Plane Back to Philadelphia
description: One engine fell off a twin-engine USAir Boeing 737 five minutes after takeoff today on a flight to Boston, forcing the plane to return to Philadelphia International Airport, officials said.

title: Cries of Censor as Britain Bars Another Broadcast
description: The British Government has stepped up its court actions against news organizations, stirring charges of authoritarian censorship as it blocked a BBC radio series on the inner workings of the intelligence agencies.

title: Kitty Kennedy Becomes Bride
description: The marriage of Katherine Gertrude Kennedy and Gibbons Gray Cornwell 4th took place yesterday in the Thomas Cochran Chapel on the campus of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., from which the couple graduated in 1981. The Rev. Philip Zaeder, the Protestant chaplain at the academy, and the Rev. David B. McIlhiney, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Elderly Couple Living Within Limits of Illness
description: Mary and James Lizzio met at 14 and married at 24, and for a time, they lived a modest life of simple verities: work, family, church and an occasional summer clambake.

title: Q AND A
description: Airport Codes Question: For a research project, I would like to know who regulates the coding system for baggage ticketing at airports. If Kennedy Airport in New York is JFK, why should Key West be EYW? Where can I get information? - I. P. A., Brooklyn Answer: Those three-letter codes used for labeling airline passengers' baggage are determined by the International Air Transport Association, the trade organization of most of the world's airlines. It also decides on two-letter designations for airlines, for use in schedules, like LY for El Al, and three-letter codes for airport cities with more than one airport, like PAR for Paris .

title: The Stage: 'Cabinet of Dr. Caligari'
description: WHY mount a stage adaptation of a screen classic that owed its nightmare quality to startling backdrops, ominous lighting and crafty camera angles? Susan Mosakowski's 50-minute version of ''The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,'' the 1919 spooker about the malevolent hypnotist and the somnambulist he sends forth from his coffin to murder townsfolk, affords no satisfying explanation.

title: AN EARLY START FOR '88 CONTEST
description: WITH 11 months still to go, Connecticut's campaign to elect a United States Senator next November is already well under way.

title: GROUP HOME DEBATED
description: LEAD: HUNDREDS of Shoreham residents are challenging a state decision to convert a single-family home in their neighborhood into a facility for 10 people with developmental disabilities.

title: West Rebuffs East on Pact on Europe Troop Cuts
description: While Washington geared up for the drama of summitry and a major arms pact, negotiators in Vienna wound up another fruitless round of the 14-year-old talks on troop reductions in Central Europe with Western delegations rejecting Eastern efforts to end the talks with a ''symbolic'' agreement.

title: Air Shuttle's Latest Twist: Ferry Ride
description: At 4:40 Wednesday afternoon, two dozen people were pacing about a converted old coffee barge at Pier 11 just below Wall Street, consulting their watches. A boat pulled up and they scuttled aboard.

title: The Larger Nuclear Debate
description: LEAD: It is of great importance that the treaty banning intermediate-range nuclear weapons, and the further possibility of a dramatic cut in strategic nuclear weapons in 1988, be seen as the beginning of a deeper public involvement with arms control issues. The danger is that these hopeful developments will instead further anesthetize a citizenry that, for much too long, has avoided serious thought and creative debate about nuclear weapons.

title: Washington Fought Here: Battle Site Condos
description: In White Plains, on land where George Washington fought and lost, and where children once studied and played, the conversion of an old school has produced a condominium complex.

title: Bateman's
description: To the Editor: My traveling companion and I enjoyed the article on Bateman's, Rudyard Kipling's home (Travel, Aug. 23). Having seen the house and gardens, we must say the article is very accurate. We especially enjoyed the motor car in the adjacent building. Kipling was somewhat of a hot-rodder with his auto, and we could just picture him whizzing down the narrow country lanes we had driven to get to the house. Of course, the less daring can get there by the modern motorway, but we thoroughly enjoyed the picturesque countryside without meeting another vehicle on those wonderful country lanes.

title: Ann B. Kezer Engaged To Stephen S. Lazarus

Mr. Azerrad is the son of Joel Azerrad of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Ruth Mils ner of San Francisco.

title: Thousands of Machetes Found in Atlanta Prison
description: The last 177 Cuban detainees who held control of the Federal penitentiary here for 11 days were returned to cells today after teams of Federal agents swept through the prison and found ''literally thousands'' of homemade machetes, officials said.

title: Why the Summit
description: A summit meeting that is more than cosmetic can take place only when each superpower -and its political leader - has a strong interest in seeking accommodation with the other. That is why Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev are meeting in Washington, and why each can confidently expect to gain something important.

description: CONTRARY TO POPULAR BE-lief, the later 20th century does not have a monopoly on bad music.

title: Thomas E. Powell Dies; Scientist and Executive
description: Thomas E. Powell Jr. of Burlington, N.C., the founder of two biological supply companies, died Thursday at Alamance County Hospital, after a three-month illness. He was 88 years old. Dr. Powell, who was born in Warrenton, N.C., and had a doctorate in biology, founded the Carolina Biological Supply Company in 1927 and headed its operation from 1936 until his death. In 1945, he founded Waubun Laboratories Inc. in Schriever, La., and, in 1970, Rana Laboratories in Brownsville, Tex., an operating division of Waubun Laboratories.

title: FISH, FROM GRAND CENTRAL TO TEXAS COAST
description: ALTHOUGH Texas has a substantial coastline along the Gulf of Mexico, it is not a state that one immediately associates with fish and seafood. But Ann Clark, owner of a cooking school in Austin, provides considerable sound advice and excellent recipes in her new cookbook, ''Ann Clark's Fabulous Fish'' (New American Library, $17.95).

title: On St. Marks Place, Help for Addicts
description: When Anita Fonseca first went to the All-Craft Center in 1985, she was just out of prison and had been arrested dozens of times on drug charges. She has not been arrested since. Ms. Fonesca is just one of an estimated 700 people a day who go through All-Craft, a community center in the East Village area of Manhattan that offers educational, cultural and economic development for recovering drug abusers and others in trouble.

description: MICHAEL BLUM, a 31-year-old New York-born pianist who has studied at the Juilliard School, began his recital on Thursday evening in Merkin Concert Hall with his best work - four of Mendelssohn's ''Songs Without Words'' shaped in limpid, supple phrases and colored by a soft, shimmery tone.

The gift may please, or it may rebound on the giver. It may also expose one or both parties, may express aggression as well as affection.

title: ST. PAUL'S HAS 200TH BIRTHDAY

Music recitals, cooking demonstrations, tours, refreshments and souvenirs will be free to the public as part of the bicentennial celebration.

With computers and crew drills, the battle group pretended to fire at the aircraft carrier Minsk and 26 other warships, at Soviet ports and airfields on the Sea of Japan, the Sea of Okhotsk and the Bering Sea, and at command posts, communication centers and munitions depots well inland.

description: With thousands of Americans pouring into Washington for a demonstration Sunday on behalf of Soviet Jewry, the stage is set for human rights to become a prominent and contentious issue in the summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: ATTRACTIVE FRENCH ISSUES FEATURE LOCAL THEMES
description: THEMES on French postal issues run the gamut from art to wrestling. The latest in the Artists' series offers ''Precambrien,'' a painting by Camille Bryen. This stamp is from a set that includes some of France's most attractive issues. Earlier this year, the work of Bram Van Velde was featured.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: Ingres: Slaves of Fashion Home Vision. 50 Minutes. $39.95. This film's silly title, which presumably refers to Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres's middle-class patrons, gives a clue to its flaws. While it is worthwhile as an introduction to the 19th-century classical realist, it seems to have been put together by people who are determined to dramatize their story.

title: WOULD YOU CHOOSE TO PLAY OR DEFEND?
description: DEFORE exploring the strange history of the diagramed deal, let us consider it as a play-or-defend challenge. If a spade is led against four hearts, would you choose to play or defend? Would your answer be different if one of West's small clubs was traded for one of East's small spades?

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: Commentators on the marriage patterns of baby boomers persistently return to the single, comfortingly familiar assertion (revamped for the 1980's) that women want marriage, men avoid it. In fact, however, the rueful and somewhat bewildered discourse on this subject cuts across gender lines. Single women and men of this generation are saying remarkably similar things about the absence of marriage in their lives. No one seems to have considered the possibility that this generation's ambivalence toward marriage might be something more than just a 1980's version of women hunting husbands. It is time we accepted the idea that something new is happening - it is a generation, not just a gender, that is choosing not to marry. LAURA LEE DOWNS Society of Fellows in the Humanities Columbia University New York, N.Y.

title: TOWN RECALLS DAYS OF BASKET-MAKING
description: LEAD: EDYTH S. HARRIS remembers very clearly her reaction when Whipsnades, a popular women's clothing store across from her Westchester Avenue home in the Scotts Corners section of Pound Ridge, was torn down.

title: Soviet Tries to Revive Support for U.N. Plan
description: The Soviet Union has begun a major diplomatic drive aimed at reversing the setback it suffered at the United Nations last week when many countries withdrew their support from one of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's key foreign policy initiatives, according to Western and third-world diplomats.

title: In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut; Finding Gold in Scarsdale's 'Flag Lots'
description: LAND is so valuable in Scarsdale that some homeowners are selling pieces of their backyards as building lots - and that has become a problem for the village government and some homeowners.

title: CLOTHES MAKE THE SHOW: DRESS FROM THE 19TH CENTURY
description: LEAD: WE often talk about the good old days, yet a close look at a new exhibit of 19th-century costumes leaves a viewer happy to be alive in this era.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: COOKBOOKS tend to cluster. Several along similar themes are published each season, either reflecting current tastes or predicting a trend. This year the cooking of countries bordering the Mediterranean seems to dominate the lists. The current passion for olive oil, vegetables and pasta, not only for flavor but for health, may be a factor. Some of the books are devoted to the entire region; others focus on the cuisine of a single country. And for gift givers, there are a number of elegant, lavishly illustrated editions.

title:
FILM;
Michael Douglas, as Villain, Hits It Big on 'Wall Street'
description: LEAD: WHEN THE TAXI ARRIVES, Michael Douglas is waiting in the driveway of the weekend house he rents in upper Westchester. The visitor descends to be greeted by Mr. Douglas and dogs - a small jolly Scottie, a large, mournful Borzoi. The cab does not move, and the driver is leaning out of the window yelling, ''Hey mistah, mistah.

title: Suspect in Korean Crash Recovers From Poisoning
description: A woman suspected of involvement in the crash of a Korean jetliner last weekend has recovered from a suicide attempt and was moved today from a hospital here to police custody, the Government said.

title: Trump to Quit Resorts Post if Pact Is Denied
description: Donald J. Trump has told the New Jersey Casino Control Commission that he will be ''very much inclined'' to resign as chairman of Resorts International Inc. - an action that could threaten the opening of a planned Atlantic City casino - if the commission does not approve a lucrative contract for him to manage the Resorts casinos.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Airlines Vary 'Lowest Fares, Survey Finds

title: Kasparov Might Play for Tie
description: Gary Kasparov quietly maneuvered to gain the advantage but was stopped by a careful defense from Anatoly Karpov that brought the 20th game of the world championship chess match to a draw on Friday.

title: AT SOUND'S BOTTOM, ABNORMAL SEA LIFE
description: LEAD: BOTTOM fish taken from Long Island Sound and examined by geneticists as part of the Long Island Sound Taskforce study show varying degrees of chromosomal damage, according to a preliminary report.

title: Miss Teitz to Wed James Ackerman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stuart Teitz of Denver have announced the engagement of their daughter Rebecca Eve Teitz to James Curtis Ackerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Ackerman of Oradell, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: I was reading Trip Gabriel's article alone in the kitchen, while my husband (of 29 years) was in the adjacent TV room, watching his sixth hour of football. I wonder why those bachelors who were interviewed believe they must relinquish their cherished adolescence the moment they say ''I do.'' Any of them in need of reassurance is welcome to spend a Sunday at our house from now until the Super Bowl. DIANE M. PATTERSON Mount Lebanon, Pa.

title: ISLANDIA INVENTS A PAST TO BUILD ON
description: LEAD: FRANCES BROWN, the newly hired Islandia village historian, has a problem faced by few Long Island historians. Islandia has virtually no past.

title: Lawyers and Cuomo in Fee Dispute
description: Two lawyers who are battling with Governor Cuomo over $4 million in legal fees have emerged as key figures in a controversy over rumors and inquiries into the financing of the Governor's unsuccessful campaign for mayor of New York City in 1977.

title: A DAY OUTING, ON A NASTY DAY, INDEED, BECOMES A PIPE DREAM
description: THE dog got sick in the living room. My husband and son were rushing to catch an early train. But it was a holiday for me. I would clean up, I told them, not knowing exactly where to begin. ''Have a good day,'' my son said, averting his glance from the mess. ''You must be kidding!'' I cried. ''Well, have a better day,'' he offered.

title: Recital: Martha Anne Verbit
description: MARTHA ANNE VERBIT, a Boston-based pianist with a penchant for the unusual, lived up to her reputation Thursday night with a generally pleasing, always thoughtful recital in Alice Tully Hall.

AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) COVERT ACTION: The Limits of Intervention in the Postwar World, by Gregory F. Treverton. (Basic Books, $19.95.) A historian and former senatorial staff member argues, with sharp narrative illustrations, that the bigger and more secret an operation is, the greater the likelihood of fiasco. STORIES FROM THE WARM ZONE AND SYDNEY STORIES, by Jessica Anderson. (Viking, $15.95.) This two-part collection by an Australian writer gives us, in uncluttered prose, tough, self-aware characters and dry, subtle dissections of family dynamics. SQUANDERING EDEN: Africa at the Edge, by Mort Rosenblum and Doug Williamson. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The authors, a reporter and a naturalist, offer a simple thesis: Africa won't make it. Their proposals for shortening the odds are overwhelmed by their own gloomy statistics and anecdotes. STALIN IN THE BRONX: And Other Stories, by Suzanne Ruta. (Grove, $16.95.) Eleven stories, set in several countries, imbued with a sense of the fatal connectedness of private and political life. BOTTOMS UP! A Pathologist's Essays on Medicine and the Humanities, by William B. Ober. (Southern Illinois University, $19.95.) Brilliant essays on such related topics as infertility in the Bible, the psychosexuality of Rimbaud and the joys of spanking. THE THIRTIETH YEAR, by Ingeborg Bachmann. (Holmes & Meier, $19.95.) Nothing that terrifies or makes life impossible is omitted from these relentless stories, now reissued, by an Austrian writer of genius who died, possibly by suicide, in 1973. CIGARETTES, by Harry Mathews. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $17.95.) Paired in a series of dangerous liaisons, the people in the author's fourth novel are shrewdly invented and powerfully characterized.

description: Four New York Times music critics were asked to pick their favorite recordings of recent months. Following are their selections: Organ Symphonies From the French

title: Arms Pact Has Major Effect on Presidential Race
description: Together, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, have fundamentally altered the way foreign policy issues will be framed in the 1988 Presidential campaign.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-31

title: DOING FEDERAL TIME AND MAKING CABLE
description: SEAGULLS from Candlewood Lake fluttered in the brisk fall air, searching for crumbs on an immaculately landscaped courtyard. It was lunchtime at the Federal prison at Danbury.

title: 'Science and Letters'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Thirsty State Drinks
description: ''WE HOPE TO HAVE WATER TO Tucson by early 1991,'' says Bob Towles, project manager for the Central Arizona Project (CAP), the United States Bureau of Reclamation's $3.5 billion effort on behalf of the nation's thirstiest state. From its source, at Lake Havasu on the California border, the 335-mile system of concrete-lined canals, tunnels, pumping plants and pipelines will provide much of southern and central Arizona with the bounty of the Colorado River. Construction began in 1973; about 290 miles, including the stretch northwest of Phoenix shown in the photo above, are complete.''We're already delivering to four cities, seven irrigation districts and one Indian community,'' Towles says. Indian reservations beyond Tucson are at the end of the line. ''We'll be there by October 1992. We're also constructing one new dam and modifying two others.''

title: X-Rays
description: To the Editor: You recently advised your readers how to save their film from being exposed at airport X-ray machines (Practical Traveler, Sept. 6).

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Why argue about possible future quarrels?'' - Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokeman. [ 1:6. ]

title: RUNNING ON EMPTY
description: Andrew Rooney's proposal for a Presidential candidate who doesn't want the job is a welcome idea, if not exactly a new one. As Plato wrote in Book VII of ''The Republic'': ''The truth is that the State in which the rulers are most reluctant to govern is always the best and most quietly governed, and the State in which they are most eager, the worst.'' DAVID GALEF New York, N.Y.

title: TWISTING THE TALE AT THE END: A SYMPOSIUM
description: At Christmastime every story deserves a happy ending. If only the Three Sisters had moved to Moscow and gone dancing with the Brothers Karamazov. What if Ahab married Hester Prynne and gave up the seafaring life? When The Book Review asked a number of writers what literary endings they would change, heroines were saved from death and despair, underdogs turned into heroes. In such an atmosphere, Godot might show up bearing a sack of presents. ''Sorry I'm late,'' he'd say. ''I was Christmas shopping. Happy holidays!'' Neil Simon Author of ''Broadway Bound.''

title: Large Atom Plant Dedicated
description: The largest commercial nuclear power plant in the United States was dedicated Friday by Energy Secretary John S. Herrington. Construction began in 1976 on the three-unit, 3,810-megawatt plant, and commercial generation began in January 1986. When the third unit comes on line next year, only the Paluel nuclear power plant in France and a plant near Leningrad in the Soviet Union will be capable of generating more power.

title: Miss Knoepffler Married on L.I.
description: At the chapel of St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., Carmen Knoepffler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alberto Knoepffler of Madrid, was married yesterday to Peter Kellogg Ingerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Ingerman of Northport, L.I. The Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony.

title: A CRUISE TO SAY GOODBYE THE WAY HE WOULD HAVE WANTED IT
description: MY ONLY brother had just turned 47 when he died a few months ago. He died one day before my birthday, and so my continuing life and his abrupt death are now inextricably linked.

title: Opera: 'Nixon In China'
description: THE opera ''Nixon in China'' received its world premiere in October by the Houston Grand Opera. At that time it was much written about, and the range of opinion was extreme. Conservatives denounced or dismissed it tooth and claw. Progressives hailed it, sometimes extravagantly. Modernists were confused; most of them dote on Peter Sellars, the director, but dislike Minimalism, the stylistic school from which the composer, John Adams, emerged.

title: City Loses 2, Saves 11 Housing Grants
description: UNLESS Congress approves an extension, New York City has lost two Federal housing grants worth $4.9 million because it failed to meet a 36-month deadline for starting construction.

title: HOMOSEXUALS HELD UNSUITED TO ADOPT
description: The Federal Government should not support efforts to allow homosexuals to adopt children, a Presidential advisory group says.

title: Riverdale
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FAMILY THAT FORGOT CHRISTMAS
description: TIDINGS By William Wharton. 259 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $17.95.

title: Koreans Vie for the 'Undecided' Vote
description: South Korea's presidential candidates fanned out across the country today, drawing vast crowds wherever they went as they tried to win over a substantial number of voters who seem unable to make up their minds.

title: VOLCKER ON THE CRASH
description: Leonard Silk's article ''Volcker on the Crash'' (Nov. 8) did not fully scrutinize the effect the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board had on the stock-market plummet and the economy.

title: Record Price Is Paid For Antique Brooch
description: A fifth-century gold brooch of a standing eagle - an Ostrogothic Dark Ages ornament - was auctioned last night in Monte Carlo, Monaco, by Sotheby's for $2.6 million, a record price at auction for an antiquity.

title: ART
description: ONE of the paradoxical things about art book publishing is that within a book that is almost too heavy to lift, let alone to carry, a slender pamphlet of exceptional distinction may be hiding. Equally well, what looks at first sight like a routine enlargement of an exhibition catalogue that dates back to 1976 may turn out to be full of new facts and new insights and in every way an indispensable addition to knowledge. Both these propositions have been borne out this season.

title: ARCHITECTURE
description: The interest in, bordering on obsession with, the past that has characterized architecture for the last few years continues to have its impact on architectural publishing. This year, it comes not so much in terms of general histories of architecture as in an ongoing quest for new aspects of the old, a continuing search for subjects that have been overlooked. Some of these subjects may be quirky and obscure, while others are well-known, but have never been given book-length treatment until now.

title: Catholic Charities Aids Those in the Shadows
description: For 70 years, the poor, the hungry, the homeless, the troubled, the abandoned and the sick have come to the agencies and offices of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York looking for assistance. We have responded by offering food, shelter, clothing, medical care and services to meet immediate and long-term needs of individuals and families unable to cope on their own with the crisis of survival in the urban setting.

title: SAN DIEGO STATE, CLEMSON IN FINAL
description: Clemson and San Diego State won semifinal games today and will meet Sunday to decide the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer championship.

title: Schools Remain Bedeviled By Old Ills and Old Solutions
description: THE city's public schools are in crisis. The number of dropouts is alarming, but the authorities don't even know what the actual numbers are.

title: Shearson-Hutton: The Deal Is Done
description: Shearson bought Hutton for $962 million in a deal that will, by some measures, create the securities industry's largest firm. For example, the combined sales forces will number 12,300, about 800 more than at Merrill Lynch, the industry leader. The Hutton brokers' jobs were believed to be largely secure but there will undoubtedly be layoffs elsewhere to eliminate duplication. Estimates of the number of jobs to be cut ranged as high as 6,000. It was unclear if the Hutton name would be retained. Hutton had put itself on the block Nov. 23 and several firms made inquiries. But Shearson quickly became the only real contender and worked out a deal with Peter V. Ueberroth, the baseball commissioner who is also a director of Hutton.

title: Common Market Is Divided on Finances
description: The leaders of the 12-nation European Community failed tonight to agree on a major overhaul of the organization's finances to ease its transition to a frontier-free trading bloc by 1992.

title: QUALITY SELLS
description: THE FACT IS, IN SPITE OF ALL THE marketing expertise expended on it, wine drinking is only barely understood as a social phenomenon in this country. If nothing else, the economic reverses experienced by the wine business in recent years have exposed some misconceptions and hammered home some hard truths that should show the direction wine will take in America, at least through the turn of the century.

title: Credit-Card Shuffle
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTORATION PLAN FOR VACANT LANDMARK
description: LEAD: FOR seven years, Westport residents have wondered what would become of a vacant but dignified white-brick building on the Post Road astride the west bank of the Saugatuck River.

title: Critic Charles Spurs Debate By Londoners
description: Britain's best-known architecture critic, Prince Charles, has touched off a spirited public debate about modern buildings and royal privilege with a stinging attack this week on property development.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: Much was made of the willingness, or lack thereof, of men to commit to marriage. But to what would they be committing? Marriage in the 1980's is not the stable, lifelong institution it once was. SIMON SPIVACK, M.D. Worcester, Mass.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SNACK FOOD;
Enduring Loyalties, Endless Novelties
description: LEAD: AMERICANS hold a special place in their hearts for favorite snacks. Last week Twinkies addicts sighed with relief when the strike against Continental Baking Company ended and the product reappeared. More than 40 billion Twinkies have been sold since their inception 57 years ago.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT WAS a bridge toll-taker on duty at the Delaware Water Gap who was credited with having seen the first flakes touch down in New Jersey.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: A PLAY WITH PUPPETS James Merrill, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1977 for ''Divine Comedies,'' a collection of poetry, will bring his one-act play with puppets, ''The Image Maker,'' to Seton Hall University in South Orange tomorrow evening.

title: Pennsylvania Towns Try to Ride the Video Wave
description: Fierce competition to lure industry has prompted an increasing number of Pennsylvania towns to make expensive promotional videotapes to give themselves big-time appeal.

title: Alissa B. Ehrenkranz Wed To Peter Morris, a Lawyer
description: Alissa Bick Ehrenkranz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joel S. Ehrenkranz of New York and North Salem, N.Y., was married last evening to Peter Douglas Morris, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sherwin M. Morris of Rochester. Rabbi Joel Goor officiated at the Regency.

title: COURTS PREPARE FOR INFLUX OF DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: WHILE many Long Islanders are beginning to plan for holiday parties, officials on Long Island are preparing to deal with the problems these parties often bring.

title: Lauri Livesey Engaged To James M. Sanduski
description: Lauri Ann Livesey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William James Livesey of Chappaqua, N.Y., and James Michael Sanduski, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Albert Sanduski of Omaha, plan to be married in June.

title: Dance: 'Nutcracker' Opens Its Annual Run
description: AT least one thing's right with this wicked old world. ''The Nutcracker'' has returned to the New York State Theater. On Thursday night the New York City Ballet danced this season's first performance of Tchaikovsky's eternally popular holiday ballet. Once again, George Balanchine's choreography conjured up a realm of enchantment.

title: Distillers and Breweries Face Suits on Birth Defects
description: Four parents have sued three liquor distillers, three beer breweries and a wine cooler company, saying their children's birth defects stem from the mothers' drinking while pregnant.

title: 'WHAT HAPPENED TO MY BABY?'
description: ''THIS baby just wasn't meant to be,'' a friend told me, by way of comfort, when the pregnancy dragged to its horrible four-and-a-half-month conclusion.

title: Linda Ronstadt Explores Her Heritage
description: LINDA RONSTADT ONCE LAMENTED half-jokingly that she sang like a German and thought like a Mexican and wished it were the other way around. Listening to her beautiful, long-awaited album of Mexican mariachi music, ''Canciones de Mi Padre'' (Asylum 9 60765-1; all three formats), however, one hears no conflict between music and concept. Immersed in the rancheras, huapangos and other Mexican songs that span nearly a century, Ms. Ronstadt sounds as at home as she did singing the country-folk songs that made her a star in the late 60's and early 70's. ''Canciones de Mi Padre'' (''Songs of My Father'') may in fact be the most deeply felt album the singer has ever made.

title: A SHORT GUIDE TO SHOPPING FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: A SURVEY of holiday offerings in craft shops indicates concentrations here and there on single items such as chairs, teapots or kaleidoscopes, but otherwise broad selections of work in all media.

title: Austerity And Unrest On Rise in Eastern Bloc
description: IN one country, plans are afoot to close unprofitable steel mills and eliminate thousands of jobs. In another, a Government-decreed belt-tightening drove thousands of workers into the streets, where they ransacked a city hall. In a third, voters rejected an economic austerity program.

title: Jazz
description: Concerts in memory of two widely admired jazz musicians who died during the past year - Woody Herman and Dick Wellstood - will be presented this week.

title: Jane Blinder Marries Robert Barocas on L.I.
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Jane Elizabeth Blinder, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seton Laurence Blinder of Woodmere, L.I., was married last evening to Robert I. Barocas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Barocas of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbis Joel Y. Zion and Gerald Davidson officiated.

title: First President Named In New Fijian Republic
description: Ratu Sir Penaia Ganilau has been appointed the first President of the new republic of Fiji, the army commander announced today.

title: Keeping Wright's Furniture at Home
description: THE RAPID ESCALATION of prices paid at auction in the 1980's for Frank Lloyd Wright's furniture and architectural fittings has spurred increased activity in the marketplace for his designs and has intensified debate over the fate of furnishings removed from his houses.

title: 'STAR WARS' CURBS NOT SUMMIT ISSUE, SOVIET AIDES HINT
description: The Soviet Union will put aside its differences with the United States over the meaning of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty in order to speed progress at the summit meeting next week toward a reduction in long-range nuclear arms, according to senior Soviet officials.

title: Bank Robber's Loot Blowing in the Wind
description: The money was blowing in the wind as part of a bank robber's booty sailed off into a stiff breeze, only to be grabbed by eager bystanders and even more eager police officers.

title: DATA BANK: December 6, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Cambridge Guide to the Museums of Britain and Ireland By Kenneth Hudson and Ann Nichols 435 pages; 368 illustrations. Cambridge University Press, New York. Hardcover. $24.95.

description: To the Editor: After reading the letters about Fattoria La Loggia, I wish to relate our experience. We were more fortunate than those who visited in June. We arrived on Sept. 26 and were housed in a fairly comfortable apartment on the grounds of La Loggia, but we could see that the place in no way resembled Mary Davis Suro's description. We decided to put up with the missing ''idyllic retreat,'' but our biggest disappointment was the treatment we received.

title: THE AMBIVALENT AMERICAN BACHELOR
description: If life expectancy is said to be 70-80 years, why give up your freedom by marrying at age 25? Yes, I'll admit I am one of the ''self-indulgent'' generation; I cannot see myself getting married until I find someone I ''cannot live without.'' Until then, I know I will be content not having to report to someone daily or having to ask what that $100 check was spent on. I will be in control, living the life of the ''ambivalent'' American bachelor. GREG K. INGRAM Marietta, Ga.

title: Pleasure And Profit Of Revivals
description: REVIVALS THAT DRASTICALLY ALTER THINK-ing about a composer and his work are not common, but they do happen. The most famous such event in musical history took place in 1829, when a 20-year-old named Felix Mendelssohn brought the ''St. Matthew Passion'' out of obscurity by conducting the first performance since Bach's death 79 years earlier. In our day, such efforts at exhumation have become such an integral part of musical life that it is hard to imagine a time when digging into the past was not only difficult but unnecessary. Looking back, we might pinpoint Mendelssohn's rediscovery of Bach as a pivotal moment, a foreshadowing of the modern curatorial period in which important new works are so scarce that musicians are forced to forage in the past in search of mislaid masterpieces.

title: WILL SEXY SELL?
description: SPRING 1988 MAY WELL BE ONE of the sexiest seasons in recent times. Now that the collections for next season have been presented in Milan, Paris and New York, it is clear that most of the design community has become obsessed with promoting overt seductiveness. In general, skirts are not only short, they are skintight. Necklines are low, often dangerously so. Shoulders are less padded, more rounded, occasionally even bare for day. The silhouettes of the new clothes emphatically emphasize breasts, hips and legs. Accessories accentuate the ''female,'' especially with charming but nonessential hats perched on top of many outfits. One of the favorite themes for fabrics is flower patterns, the kind that usually show up on decorators' chintzes. Of course, miles of more mainstream merchandise have also been shown, and will be out there to buy, but the fashion emphasis is definitely on the provocative.

Thousands of boisterous demonstrators surrounded City Hall as members of the Board of Aldermen wrangled into the night over two contenders to succeed Mr. Washington, who died of a heart attack Nov. 25 at the start of his second term.

It leaves you with a 9 percent loss - a hefty penalty for failing to take profits before they evaporate.

The exhibitions, Stella's at the Museum of Modern Art, Schnabel's at the Whitney, are both by the enfants terribles of their respective artistic generations, and come toward the end of a tumultuous decade in art. Both artists have produced controversial, even iconoclastic works of art that are unusually emblematic of widely differing viewpoints - and different turning points - in recent art.

title: A Jazz Label, Complete
description: AMONG THE MOST FAMOUS series of jazz recordings ever made is certainly that overseen by Milt Gabler in the late 1930's and the 40's and 50's, a series that has not lacked for reissues over the years. Most recently, Book-of-the-Month Records issued a four-LP set (two cassettes or three CD's) and a few years ago CBS issued a clutch of some of the most famous cuts in a series of LP's. Now, Mosaic Records, a mail-order producer of jazz reissues (often in massive ''complete'' form) has announced plans to release all the Commodores - all. As Charlie Lourie, one of Mosaic's proprietors, put it in the announcement: ''When I say complete, I mean everything, from first note to last. It'll all be arranged chronologically on something like 60 or 70 LP's. We plan to issue it in three major volumes.''

Interests of state, by contrast, appear remote and arbitrary, and capable of being bent to the demands of compassion.

title: TREKKING ACROSS BERINGER
description: THE GREAT JOURNEY The Peopling of Ancient America. By Brian M. Fagan. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Thames & Hudson. $19.95. BRIAN FAGAN sees the origin of the native Americans as an archeological detective story seeking answers to a series of questions: who were the first Americans, where did they come from and by which route did they migrate, and why did they move and above all when? There are many detectives, some overenthusiastic and a few eccentric, but most of them are dedicated, painstaking and impartial scholars. They have had to struggle with fragmentary and inadequate clues. None has yet found the ''smoking gun'' - an archeological site in the right place on the migration route, with plenty of datable material of sufficient antiquity and in sufficiently undisputed context to prove the validity of one given theory.

Austria's Traditional Dirndl
description: LEAD: THE Austrian dirndl has a long history and a peculiar charm. Everyone agrees that on little girls it looks enchanting; opinions differ, particularly among Americans, as to its attractiveness on adult women. It is thought to be the only European national costume, except for the Scottish kilt, that has been worn, essentially unchanged, by maid and mistress alike for well over 200 years.

title: Sephardim Ask for More From Israel
description: SEPHARDI Jews from around the world gathered in Jerusalem last week to destroy a myth and to declare a war. The myth they hoped to lay to rest is that Sephardim in Israel are always hawkish on Arab-Israeli issues. The declaration of war was against Israel's Ashkenazi-dominated religious establishment, which many Sephardim see as swallowing their unique heritage and customs.

title: HER DRAMAS PONDER THE PRICE OF LIBERATION
description: IN THE ROLE-REVERSAL WORLD OF Louise Page's ''Real Estate,'' men become enthusiastic house-husbands, fathers willfully assert their own sense of paternal responsibility. At the same time, women, advancing their individualism and seeking fulfillment, isolate themselves from the needs of others. With compassionate equanimity, Ms. Page scrutinizes a closely allied, disparate quartet - mother, stepfather, daughter, daughter's lover, dancing around one another, unable to provide love or sustenance. The men achieve a natural community of feeling while the women remain as divisive as only a mother and daughter can be. In this and in other plays by the young British playwright, Ms. Page looks beyond questions of feminism and wonders what life is like for women - and men - who have been liberated from traditional roles.

The 15-minute ride from the muddy Mount Shark Heliport above Bryant Creek and over Assiniboine Pass was exhilarating. Suddenly there was a new world below with white snow interspersed with dark patches of larch, spruce and fir.

title: Lessons for Skiers, Old and New
description: THE advice from seasoned skiers is that lessons are the most important investment skiers can make in their career on the slopes. Beginners, obviously, need good teaching from trained instructors, but wherever there are ski classes you'll find intermediates and experts trying to smooth out trouble spots, everything from progressing from stem to parallel turns and planting poles correctly to racing. Some of the most competent skiers on a week's ski vacation never miss taking at least a half day of lessons.

title: A NEW LOOK INTO THE ABYSS OF CALIGARI'S CABINET
description: THE 1919 GERMAN FILM CLASSIC ''The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari'' has been a favorite of Film 101 courses for a variety of reasons. Although its validity as a harbinger of the moral climate that permitted Hitler's rise to power has been debated, its significance for the cinema as a bold stylistic departure into a realm of fantasy and expression has remained indisputable. As originally conceived by Hans Janowitz and Carl Mayer, and directed for the silent screen by Robert Weine, the macabre story focused on an asylum director named Caligari who hypnotically controls Cesare, a side-show somnambulist, to commit murders. In presenting their idea for the film, the creators were determined that it should be photographed in an innovative way, employing avant-garde techniques of expressionism then in vogue on the German stage. Susan Mosakowski's new stage version of ''The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari,'' which opened last Wednesday at the La Mama Annex, is -esthetically speaking - closing a circle begun seven decades ago.
