title: Army Set to Screen Personnel for AIDS Once Every 2 Years
description: All Army personnel on active duty will be tested for exposure to the AIDS virus at least once every two years. The Army thus becomes the first military service to establish a formal policy for periodic retesting of servicemen for the deadly virus.

title: TV Reviews; 'Eye on the Sparrow,' On NBC
description: IN June 1969, Ethel and James Lee were officially allowed, after a six-year struggle, to adopt a child they had been bringing up. The case was significant because the Lees are blind. Tonight at 9 on Channel 4, the Lees are brought to prime-time television by way of a ''based on fact'' movie called ''Eye on the Sparrow.'' Lovely performances by Mare Winningham and Keith Carradine as the Lees lift the film well out of the ordinary.

title: Baseball; Guarantee Stalling Mets and Mazzilli
description: The Mets admitted today that they had a Ray Knight-type problem in their negotiations with Lee Mazzilli, but Mazzilli's agent blamed the Player Relations Committee for the snag that could end the player's second term with the club.

title: Rukeyser Is Shifting From Time to Whittle
description: William S. Rukeyser, a former editor of Fortune and Money magazines, is joining Whittle Communications, a magazine publisher based in Knoxville, Tenn., as editor in chief.

title: MARCH BY 200,000 IN CAPITAL PRESSES SOVIET ON RIGHTS
description: On the eve of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's arrival in the United States, about 200,000 marchers streamed down Constitution Avenue to Capitol Hill today to send the message that Jewish emigration and human rights should figure prominently in the Soviet leader's meeting this week with President Reagan.

title: Salvadoran Illusions Keep Outpacing Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadly Intent Underlies the AIDS Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Montana's Record Helps 49ers Win
description: Joe Montana completed his first 17 passes, giving him a league-record 22 straight over two games, and he also passed for two touchdowns and ran for another today as the San Francisco 49ers defeated the Green Bay Packers, 23-12.

title: Two Navajo Police Officers Found Slain on Tribal Land
description: Two Navajo tribal police officers have been found dead in a burned-out vehicle on a reservation near the Utah-Arizona border, prompting a murder investigation by Federal and local agencies , authorities said.

title: Elway Revives Broncos
description: John Elway, rebounding from a poor first half, threw two second-half touchdown passes today, and Mark Haynes scored a fourth-quarter touchdown on an interception return as the Denver Broncos overcame a 17-3 deficit to defeat the New England Patriots, 31-20.

title: Hoyt Arrested On Drug Charges
description: LaMarr Hoyt, the former San Diego Padres pitcher, was arrested Saturday at his apartment here and charged with possession with intent to distribute cocaine and marijuana, authorities said.

title: Lendl and Wilander in Final
description: Stop if you have heard these before: Mats Wilander of Sweden played his countryman, Stefan Edberg, in a matinee performance of the Nabisco Masters with only a handful of fans in attendance; Ivan Lendl gave Brad Gilbert a painful lesson in power tennis as practiced from the baseline; Lendl will play Wilander in the final of a major tournament, and one of the players had some unkind words for the Masters format before departing.

title: INSIDE
description: Offer by Texaco Reported

title: Political Spotlight Surprises a Small Texas Town
description: People here seemed surprised when not just one but two candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination showed up Saturday night for a campaign forum sponsored by the Johnson County Democratic Party.

title: Fitness; Payoff Still High In Aerobics That Stick to Ground
description: FIRST came aerobic dancing, with rooms full of people energetically bouncing up and down, kicking and cavorting like gazelles. The music was loud and disco-fast, and the true believers were every bit as committed, even as fanatic, as the daily runner.

title: Market Place Haven Hunters Look at Utilities
description: AFTER the October rout in stock prices, many investors turned to electric utilities in search of a safe haven. ''Most utility issues offer high yields and superior price stability, which appeal to investors in a bear market,'' the Value Line Investment Survey noted.

title: Peter Lorenz, Politician, 64
description: Peter Lorenz, a conservative politician who was kidnapped by leftist extremists in 1975, died today of a heart attack at his home here, a Government spokesman reported. He was 64.

title: PRIEST'S KILLER ARRESTED AS ROBBER
description: Andre Nichols, a Brooklyn man who fatally shot a Roman Catholic priest last year but was acquitted of murder in the shooting, was arrested at a Fort Greene housing project Saturday night after he attempted to rob a woman at gunpoint, the housing police said last night.

title: Suzanne Leonard Weds a Physician
description: At St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York, Suzanne Kathleen Leonard, a daughter of Dr. Barbara M. Marlowe of Brooklyn and the Rev. Richard D. Leonard of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Karl-Walter Sykora, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Sykora of Bonn. The Rev. John Clermont performed the ceremony.

title: Putter Loses Its Grip
description: There is more to a well-worn putter than the personal attachment to a golf club with years of winning matches under its heel. It is often a club with a hardened grip, fashioned that way with the same hands applying a similar intensity, game after game. A golfer is more sensitive to the feel of the putter than to any other club.

title: Sports World Specials; An Unsteady Start
description: Losing baseball games and being away from home were two experiences that were foreign to Willie Banks in high school. But the 18-year-old right-hander received an education in both while struggling through a summer of discontent with the Elizabethton (Tenn.) Twins in the Class A Appalachian League.

title: Deidre M. Stein Weds Dr. Amnon Eric Sadeh
description: Deidre Meryl Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Stein of Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Amnon Eric Sadeh, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dov Sadeh of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Aryeh Gotlieb and Cantor Pinhas Ben-Ari officiated at the Tammy Brook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J.

title: FRAUD IN WELFARE PUT AT $1 BILLION
description: Fraud in the Federal Government's major welfare program for mothers and children could be costing $1 billion a year, according to a report by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Baseball; Yanks Lose Out on Hassey
description: The Yankees today lost Ron Hassey, the left-handed-hitting catcher they thought they had secured, but they intensified their effort to obtain a left-handed-hitting outfielder. General Manager Lou Piniella acknowledged that he had talked to the Cincinnati Reds about Dave Parker and said he would meet with them again Monday.

title: Jokes, Debates and Therapy at Brokers' Meeting
description: Wall Streeters may not have much to laugh about these days, but they did have some light moments at the four-day annual convention of brokers that ended here today.

title: Avon Stock Trades in Japan
description: Trading begins today in Japan's over-the-counter market for newly issued shares of the Avon Products Company, an offshoot of the American cosmetics concern.

title: Israel and Syria Urged to Show Restraint
description: The United States has urged both Israel and Syria to exercise restraint in the wake of an attack Nov. 25 by a Palestinian guerrilla on an Israeli army base, a State Department official said today.

title: Outdoors: The Cutting Edge
description: BEING fond of kitchens and what goes on in them, I have learned over many years of easing myself into some useful culinary role when visiting friends that there is no one in most households who can put a decent edge on a knife.

title: Jonathon Chase, Law School Dean, 48
description: Jonathon ChaseLaw School Dean, 48 NORWICH, Vt., Dec. 6 (AP) - Jonathon Chase, who was dean of the Vermont Law School in South Royalton from 1982 to July 1987, died of cancer Saturday at his home here. He was 48 years old.

title: Joint Rule: Gorbachev and the System
description: Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev, the Soviet leader who makes his first visit to the United States Monday, is a product - even, it sometimes seems, a prisoner - of the system he is trying to change.

title: Boxing; Holyfield Stops Tough Talker
description: At Saturday morning's weigh-in, Dwight Muhammad Qawi was snarling.

title: The 100 Cases Club
description: Only two lawyers in this century have argued 100 cases before the Supreme Court. Tomorrow they will be joined by a third when Lawrence G. Wallace, a deputy solicitor general, defends a Federal tax law.

title: Free the Disabled With Para-Transit
description: Thousands of disabled people - some young, others frail and elderly - cannot navigate subways and buses. Many feel imprisoned in their own homes. They find it difficult, sometimes even impossible, to get to medical appointments and senior citizen centers, or to visit friends or relatives. Meanwhile, disabled people with jobs pay private ambulette companies up to $200 a week to get to and from work. And it is costly for disabled students to travel to classes where they can be trained for jobs and receive vocational rehabilitation.

title: Ah, Yes, Isn't It Romantic? Rainbow Room to Reopen
description: If Joseph Baum's fantasy is fulfilled, lovely ladies in long gowns will step onto the maitre d'hotel's terrace, pause for a modest moment, place a hand on the burnished brass handrail with its lead-crystal balusters, and then, on the arm of an escort, flow down the stairs.

title: Iranian Speedboats Attack 2 Tankers
description: Iranian gunboats raided two tankers today, setting one ablaze and killing at least one crewman on the other.

title: Leslie Beth Galton Wed To Scott David Goldberg
description: Leslie Beth Galton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Barry Galton of Wayne, N.J., was married yesterday to Scott David Goldberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Goldberg, also of Wayne. Rabbi Joseph Brodie officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Fatal Ship Fire Puzzles Spanish
description: Officials said today that they were puzzled by an explosion that set fire to a freighter and killed 23 of its crew on Saturday in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article from Atlanta in some copies on Wednesday about the release of a hostage by Cuban inmates at the Federal penitentiary misstated the date of an agreement between Cuba and the United States on the deportation of some 2,500 Cubans from this country. It was Nov. 20.

title: OTHER FACES, OTHER PACTS: THREE DECADES OF DIPLOMACY - VISITS BY SOVIET LEADERS TO THE UNITED STATES
description: September 1959: In the first visit to the U.S. by a Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev and President Eisenhower have Khrushchev and President Eisenhower have a summit meeting at Camp David, Md. No ends with an understanding that the world must disarm and that cultural and scientific exchanges would be good. September 1960: Khrushchev arrives in New York to address the Unted Nations General Assembly and call for the resignation of Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold. He interrupts a delegate's speech by banging his shoe on his desk. As a result of tensions over the downing of an American spy plane in May, he was not invited to meet with Eisenhower. June 1967: President Johnson and Aleksei N. Kosygin, who is visiting the United States for a United Nations session on the Arab-Israeli war, meet in Glassboro, N.J., to discuss nuclear arms, the Middle East and the Vietnam War. In two days of discussions they lay the groundwork for future talks, but there are no concrete agreements. June 1973: President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev meet in Washington, at Camp David and in San Clemente, Calif. They agree to try to finish a new arms treaty by 1974, and agree on several other practical issues.

title: Olympic Notebook; Top Skier Is Out With Injured Knee
description: The United States' chances to win medals at the Calgary Olympics in Alpine skiing were slim enough before Tamara McKinney broke an ankle while training last month, three weeks before the start of the World Cup season in Sestriere, Italy.

title: Debate Raised Over Doomed Fetus's Organs
description: A couple want their fatally impaired child kept alive after birth just long enough so that the organs can be removed for transplants, but no hospital has agreed to go along with the plan.

title: NICARAGUAN FOES URGED BY CARDINAL TO RENEW TALKS
description: The mediator in Nicaragua's civil conflict, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, called today for further peace talks between the two sides, and urged both to make concessions.

title: NEW CAMPAIGN SET ON DRIVING DRUNK
description: With the number of fatalities from drunken driving rising in 1986 after years of decline, the Harvard School of Public Health today announced an attempt to refocus attention on the problem.

title: Jets Take Series Seriously
description: Can a salami sandwich help the Dolphins when the defense doesn't?

title: Director of the Ford Library Is Sworn In as U.S. Archivist
description: Don W. Wilson, standing in front of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution in the rotunda of the National Archives, was sworn in Friday as Archivist of the United States.

title: Insurance Broker Gets First Non-Corroon Chief
description: The Corroon & Black Corporation, a big insurance brokerage, has named Richard M. Miller chief executive. Robert F. Corroon, 65, and the son of a founder, has relinquished the position.

title: Knicks Humbled By Blazers, 117-99
description: Winning breeds an uncanny confidence, even amid inexplicable adversity.

title: Chip Maker's Chief to Retire
description: Mark Shepherd Jr., chairman of Texas Instruments Inc. and a leading figure in the electronics industry, said last week that he would retire in April after 40 years with the company. Mr. Shepherd, who will keep his seat on the board, will be 65 years old in January.

title: Press Notes; Texas Papers' Foes Gain Ouster of Executive
description: After the removal of the controversial general manager of Amarillo's newspapers by the owner during a boycott effort, the papers have apparently struck an uneasy peace with T. Boone Pickens and other critics from the local Texas business community.

title: Man Found Stabbed to Death At His Home on Long Island
description: A 32-year-old Long Beach, L.I., man was stabbed to death in his house early today, the police said.

title: Joan Bodenheimer Marries
description: Joan Sandra Bodenheimer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bodenheimer of River Edge, N.J., was married yesterday to Ted William Borowsky, a son of Irvin John Borowsky and Beverly Borowsky, both of Philadelphia. Rabbi Robert L. Lehman performed the ceremony at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J. The bride is a marketing manager at Germantown Insurance Marketing Inc. in Philadelphia. The bridegroom is the president of the Foster Manufacturing Company, a graphic arts equipment and supplies concern in Philadelphia.

title: Nominee for Mine Agency
description: President Reagan intends to nominate T. S. Ary to be director of the Bureau of Mines, the White House has announced. Mr. Ary, president of the Kerr-McGee Corporation's Minerals Exploration Division, will succeed Robert Carlton Horton if confirmed by the Senate to the Interior Department post.

title: Rockville Journal; Visit to the Real Uncle Tom's Cabin
description: It is not one of the capital's famous monuments. There are no tour buses passing by or marble statues to mark the spot.

title: Piano: Yefim Bronfman at Y
description: YEFIM BRONFMAN is an unusually talented young pianist who seems to have trapped himself in a confining world. The heavy Romantic virtuoso repertory that dominated his evening at the 92d Street Y on Saturday certainly confirmed many of his virtues, but one also had the feeling it concealed others.

title: College Basketball; Major's Long Shots Spark Seton Hall
description: Last summer, James Major returned to the playgrounds of Brooklyn to refine his basketball skills. The countless hours of work on the blacktop paid handsome dividends for Major tonight.

title: Haitians Pushed To Choose Sides By Call to Strike
description: A week after Haiti's disastrous attempt at holding its first presidential election in 30 years, lines are being drawn for a new phase of political battle.

title: Haiti General Has Backing In Hometown
description: Before Francois Duvalier nominated his son to succeed him as President, legend has it that he passed on his secret for controlling this disparate country.

title: Profile of a General
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Trade Surplus Down
description: The broadest measure of Japan's trade surplus fell 21 percent in October from its level of a year earlier, shrunken by the effect of the strong yen, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

title: How to Make Mammography Affordable
description: Nancy Reagan's breast cancer surgery in October prompted a national surge of interest in mammography, the procedure for detecting such cancers long before they can be felt. But when such cases fade from the news, demand for the procedure recedes. Only 11 percent of American women undergo mammography on a regular basis. That's not enough. All women over 40 ought to have a mammogram every other year.

title: Drowsy Broadway About to Be Stirred
description: There are no Broadway openings scheduled until the Jan. 26 premiere of ''The Phantom of the Opera'' at the Majestic Theater. But producers and theater owners have been competing feverishly during the past few weeks for the rights to a number of musicals, plays and comedies that promise one of the busiest spring seasons in years.

title: Robertson, a Foe of System, Qualifies for Campaign Funds
description: Pat Robertson can receive Federal matching funds for his race for the Republican Presidential nomination, the Federal Election Commission has announced.

title: 5 Receive Kennedy Center Honors for Artistic Contributions
description: The presence of the actress Bette Davis at the White House this evening gave President Reagan another opportunity to repeat one of his favorite lines.

title: Newbury Journal; Pact or No Pact, Greenham Women Stand Guard
description: At this time of year, the east wind lopes across Greenham Common Air Base and bites like a wolf. The women in the Peace Camps stick close to their fires, brewing tea in blackened kettles, warming their anger at predictions that their movement will wither away once President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev sign a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles.

title: Scott Paper to Pay Fine For Safety Violations
description: The Scott Paper Company has agreed to pay the Federal Government fines totaling $475,000 to settle charges that it deliberately violated Federal health and safety regulations at its paper mill in Winslow, Me.

title: China Has Pessimistic View Of Summit Impact on Arms
description: The Government said today that it did not expect much to come of this week's summit meeting between President Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Music Noted in Brief; British Folk Singing From the Watersons
description: The Watersons, an English a cappella folk group that helped spearhead the 60's British folk revival, perform in a style that is about as bare-boned as ensemble folk singing could be. The Yorkshire-based family group, made up of Norma, Lal and Mike Waterson, along with Martin Carthy (a Waterson by marriage), made a rare New York appearance at the Triplex Theater on Friday night. They were joined by Mike's daughter, Rachel.

title: Advertising; Gargano Is Seeking No Mergers
description: AMIL GARGANO, chairman of Ally & Gargano, has decided not to talk to corporate suitors any more. It just leads to a lot of problems, he says.

title: Turbulence of the Economy Inspires Gifts to the Neediest
description: Despite the shrinking dollar and economic uncertainties, there has been an outpouring of generosity in response to the 76th annual appeal for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; A Man With 2,478 Solutions To the Deficit Awaits a Call
description: While Congressional committees were picking away at the Federal budget last week, looking for $30-odd billion to cut in the inconclusive war on the Federal budget deficit, J. Peter Grace was flying around the world calling them clowns.

title: Linda Stein Weds Kenneth Kaufman
description: The marriage of Linda Sue Stein, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Stein of Pompano Beach, Fla., to Kenneth Michael Kaufman, a son of Dr. Sherwin A. Kaufman of New York and the late Miriam Daniels Kaufman, took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Irving J. Block, assisted by Cantor Herman Diamond, performed the ceremony.

title: Music Noted in Brief; The New-Age Music Of George Winston
description: All the trappings of George Winston's solo piano concert Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall suggested humility. Proceeds from lobby sales of Mr. Winston's recordings were donated to the Food for Survival Food Bank in the Bronx; program notes gave discographical data on albums by Mr. Winston's influences. On stage, he cited composers and styles he was about to draw on, explaining such terms as stride piano and klezmer.

title: Sports World Specials; Wilander Settles In
description: The Nabisco Masters brought the international tennis tour to the New York area last week, but Mats Wilander had already begun to plant roots close by and to partake in the customs near his new Greenwich, Conn., home.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Chamber Music Society Performs Caplet Work
description: Melodrama now refers to overheated theatricality, but the word's original meaning is more specific and quite different, describing the combination of music and dramatic reading. In its version of Andre Caplet's ''Masque de la Mort Rouge,'' the Chamber Music Society has satisfied both definitions. Saturday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, Irene Worth narrated Poe's tale from one side of the stage. On the other, one harp and four strings told the story in Caplet's way.

title: Dashiell L. Madeira, Retired Admiral, 90
description: Dashiell L. Madeira, a retired Navy rear admiral, died Nov. 29 at his home in Virginia Beach, Va. He was 90 years old.

title: David R. Scofield Wed To Elizabeth J. Padwee
description: The South Presbyterian Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Jane Padwee, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Howard Padwee of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., to David Rawley Scofield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Scofield of Indianapolis. The Rev. Joseph H. Gilmore performed the ceremony.

title: Marchers See Need to Fight Injustice
description: It was still dark this morning when 39 sleepy New Yorkers boarded a bus bound for the capital, bringing blankets and newspapers and bags of lunch. They crossed the Hudson River and drove onto the New Jersey Turnpike as the sky turned light and the road filled with scores of other buses, all going south for the rally today on behalf of Soviet Jews.

title: Jackson, Once Overlooked, Earns Knicks' Confidence
description: A VERITABLE fortune is spent on scouting these days. Each season, coaches and scouts from National Basketball Association teams travel the country, evaluating college players and viewing hours of videotaped college games.

title: CANADIAN RIFT GROWS OVER FREE TRADE...
description: AS TALKS ON AN ACCORD BOG DOWN

title: Biasucci's 3 Kicks Are All Colts Need
description: Dean Biasucci kicked three second-quarter field goals and the Indianapolis defense forced a fourth-quarter fumble deep in its own territory today as the Colts defeated the Cleveland Browns by 9-7.

title: College Basketball; Redmen May Lose a Guard
description: Marcus Broadnax, the guard who was supposed to provide St. John's with outside shooting this season, may leave the university, possibly as soon as the end of the month.

title: Advertising; People
description: Morton Baran has joined the Martin Agency, Richmond, as senior vice president and director of broadcast production.

title: Books of The Times
description: TRUMP: The Art of the Deal. By Donald J. Trump with Tony Schwartz. Illustrated. 246 pages. Random House. $19.95. WHAT ''Trump: The Art of the Deal'' is about is how its author, the builder Donald J. Trump, is simply smarter than the rest of us. He's smarter than Barron Hilton of Hilton Hotels and Stephen A. Wynn of the Golden Nugget Hotel in Atlantic City and the people who run Holiday Inns and all the others he's beaten in the various deals he's made.

title: Flexibility and Mobility
description: As Mikhail Gorbachev descends on Washington, both sides seem optimistic about moving beyond elimination of medium- and short-range missiles to ''deep cuts'' in strategic weapons. Even the long deadlock in which the U.S. has sought reductions in Soviet land-based missiles, while Moscow demanded limits on U.S. submarine-launched missiles, might be overcome.

title: Charges Against a T.V.A. Official Become an Issue on Capitol Hill
description: A Justice Department investigation into charges that the Tennessee Valley Authority's nuclear power manager lied about safety procedures at a reactor has become a political issue on Capitol Hill.

title: A Legacy of Ruin
description: When I was a boy, I sometimes visited a house in upstate New York that was just across a fence from an old, overgrown, hillside cemetery. This graveyard was a beautiful place, shady on hot days, and I used to love playing there. Cemeteries are often intriguing to children, I think. They are sometimes our first brush with the mystery of death, and also with the power of memory. In the dates on tombstones is contained the message that we all must die and the reassurance that a mark will be left, our names will be preserved. Some day other children may play on top of our bones and know whose they were.

title: Spain and U.S. in 50's
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTEBOOK: CALMING CLIENTS AT ATTACK TRIAL
description: For three months, in the public spotlight, prosecution and defense lawyers in the Howard Beach murder trial have been clashing in a Queens courtroom over the guilt or innocence of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter in the death of a black man.

title: Israeli Court Decides Peres Must Testify at Spying Trial
description: Judges ruled today that Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Abba Eban, a member of Parliament, must testify at the trial of Mordechai Vanunu, a former nuclear technician accused of espionage, the defense said. Mr. Peres was Prime Minister when Mr. Vanunu told The Sunday Times of London in the fall of 1986 that Israel manufactured nuclear weapons at a secret installation. Mr. Eban is chairman of Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee. Israel has not responded directly to the allegations about its nuclear weapons industry,

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many catchers have been voted into the Hall of Fame and how many finished their major-league careers with batting averages of .300 or better? What's the highest average for a catcher not in the Hall?

title: Divorce May Be the Price of Living Together First
description: Couples who lived together before marrying have nearly an 80 percent higher divorce rate than those who did not and they seem to have less regard for the institution, according to a study of Swedish women by the National Bureau of Economic Research here.

title: Polish Youths Find Identity In Boy Scouts
description: In Communist countries, the party likes to set the pace - a woman sending her child to Sunday school is seen as a dissident, a man wearing a funny lapel button is considered a subversive.

title: Japan's Different Stock Market
description: From the visitors' gallery of the Tokyo Stock Exchange, this nation's leading stock market seems to work like any other. Young men dash around the big bright room, frantically signaling their trades and nervously scanning the rows of computer screens flashing prices.

title: Charlotte Thorndike North, Writer and Artist, 74
description: Charlotte Thorndike North, a writer and artist, died of cancer Friday at her home in Montclair, N.J. She was 74 years old.

title: Police Scatter Moscow Protesters Denied Permission to Leave Soviet
description: A swarm of plainclothesmen scattered a small demonstration today by people denied permission to leave the Soviet Union, tearing their placards and roughing up Western television journalists trying to film the event.

title: Spanish Bank Ends a Fight To Force Its Rival to Merge
description: A leading Spanish bank, Banco de Bilbao, has dropped its hostile takeover bid for the rival Banco Espanol de Credito, known as Banesto. The merger would have created the largest banking group in Spain.

title: Dolphins' Demise Has Shula Fishing For Some Answers
description: IN this, his silver anniversary season as a head coach, Don Shula shakes his head trying to figure out why this year is different from all the others.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1987
description: Companies

title: Strategic Arms Cuts and Afghan Pullout Seen as Offering the Best Prospects
description: In a final stream of commentary before the arrival Monday of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Soviet and American officials indicated today that reductions of strategic nuclear weapons and a Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan had emerged as the two areas holding the greatest opportunities for progress at the summit talks.

title: Sports of The Times; For L. T., Sunday Is Sunday
description: NO matter what Lawrence Taylor has done when he hasn't had his Giants helmet on, it's time that even the perfectionists who question his life style realize that as a football player, maybe no one has ever displayed a purer spirit in the pursuit of an opposing quarterback.

title: Cowboy Crowd Stadium's Smallest
description: The Dallas Cowboys drew their smallest crowd ever for a game at Texas Stadium yesterday as small turnouts marked some games in the National Football League's 12th weekend of play.

title: End the Afghan War
description: If Mikhail Gorbachev wants to change minds and make friends in his summit talks this week, a sure place to start is Afghanistan.

title: COMPUTER PROGRAMS AS UNIVERSITY TEACHERS
description: Students of French history at Stanford University are getting a taste of life in the time of Louis XIV. Using a sophisticated computer game in which they play the role of a landowner in 17th century France, they try to increase their wealth and status by making the proper investments, seeking favor with court officials and courting the proper women.

title: REAGAN'S MISSILE-CUT OFFER THROWS OPEN 'WINDOW OF VULNERABILITY' DEBATE
description: As the United States and the Soviet Union prepare for summit talks on a new treaty to reduce long-range arms, a debate is intensifying over whether the American proposal would increase or decrease the vulnerability of the U.S. nuclear forces.

title: Soviet Explorer Yevgeny Tolstikov, 74, Dies
description: Yevgeny I. Tolstikov, a Soviet explorer who led several pioneering expeditions to the Antarctic, died Friday, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today. He was 74 years old.

title: College Soccer; Clemson Captures Title With Shutout
description: Clemson's $1.2 million investment in a small stadium built exclusively for soccer paid its first dividend in a big way over the weekend.

title: Metro Matters; As Towers Rise, A Slow Fade-Out Of Sun and Sky
description: It was raining when Peter Bosselmann walked a visitor through Central Park and the Upper West Side the other day to measure Manhattan's disappearing sunlight.

title: The Stage: 'Flora, the Red Menace'
description: ''FLORA, the Red Menace,'' the 1965 John Kander-Fred Ebb musical, whose brief stay on Broadway is remembered mainly for the presence of Liza Minnelli, opened last week at the Vineyard Theater, with a few new Kander-Ebb songs and a new book by David Thompson. In its present incarnation, the show catches enough of the 1930's (''Mister, just give me a job'' is the refrain) to make one wish it had mined that rich vein more deeply and allowed its appealing central characters more of a chance to break out of musical comedy convention.

title: To Screen Amnesty
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Summit: Nuclear Age Drama'
description: HOW does a summit look from the inside? What happens when the two sides actually sit at a table? In ''Breakthrough at Reykjavik,'' a dramatization of last year's meeting between Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, an addled President faces a cool, purposeful Soviet leader. The dramatization, which makes up the first half of the two-hour ''The Summit: A Nuclear Age Drama,'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: Solidarity Calls Its Followers to Action in Poland
description: Leaders of the outlawed Solidarity labor union, contending that Poland's Communist leaders ''failed to gain a public mandate to govern'' in the national referendum last Sunday, appealed to union members today to step up activities both openly and underground.

title: The U.N. Today: Dec. 7, 1987
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Local Boards Try to Refine Their Role
description: Roughly a decade ago, the results of New York City's last revision of its charter went into effect, decentralizing many services and giving 59 community boards the responsibility of overseeing the city's performance on behalf of local residents.

title: Article 861387 -- No Title
description: Texaco Inc. has said it is willing to make a $1 billion payment to the Pennzoil Company in exchange for a cap of $3.5 billion on its total liability, professionals on Texaco's side of the negotiations say. The offer was reportedly made early yesterday to the creditors' committee in Texaco's bankruptcy proceeding.

title: Trip to the Bahamas By Mayor of Capital Falls Under Scrutiny
description: Mayor Marion Barry spent the Thanksgiving holiday weekend in the Bahamas with a woman who used to work in his office and is now associated with a company that gives the city financial advice, according to a report published today.

title: A Couple Reunited
description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti Chief's Politics a Mystery to U.S.

title: Critic's Notebook; Memories of Flagstad's Decades of Opera Magic
description: KIRSTEN FLAGSTAD died 25 years ago today, and the anniversary raises memories. All of us have done dumb things in our lives, and one of the dumbest I ever did was to miss the Metropolitan Opera debut of Kirsten Flagstad. It was a Saturday matinee performance on Feb. 2, 1935. In those Depression days I was the complete Wagnerite and missed no performance of importance. There was no money around and yet, somehow, it was always possible to raise the 75 cents for standing room in the family circle, or $1.50 for the parquet. (It was also possible to sneak in, but that is another story.) The debut of a new, unknown Norwegian soprano did not mean much to me. When the great Frida Leider made her debut in 1932 all of us were there. We knew about her. But Kirsten Flagstad? I had more important things to do that Saturday (though what they were I cannot remember). I did not even listen to the broadcast. That was the broadcast in which Geraldine Farrar, one of the intermission commentators, threw away her script and said something to the effect that the most thrilling thing in music had just taken place: a star had been born.

title: The Gorbachev Blueprint: Remodeling the System
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has announced several major domestic policy initiatives. Here are some of the programs and the progress so far in putting them into effect. Financing industry: Beginning Jan. 1, about 60 percent of Soviet factories will be required to pay their own way, the biggest step so far in decentralization of economic controls. Unprofitable companies will be cushioned by a bailout fund, so few bankruptcies are expected, but failure to produce will mean pay cuts for workers. Experiments so far have been confined to profitable enterprises. War on alcoholism: Prices of vodka have been nearly doubled and supplies and liquor store hours cut back. Some regions have eased up in response to complaints, but Soviet officials say the law has reduced alcohol consumption sharply and increased life expectancy. Soviet officials said recently that arrests for home distilling of spirits had increased fivefold since the crackdown began in 1985. Price Controls: Since Communist Party leaders agreed in July to roll back central price controls, the prospect of higher prices has led to hoarding and angry letters. Officials say that they plan to relax controls on wholesale prices between now and 1990, but that ending the subsidies on food and other consumer goods will come later, after extensive public discussion. Cooperatives: A series of new laws taking effect in the last year have permitted small groups to set up cooperative restaurants and cafes, taxis, recycling centers and other enterprises. The press still reports bureaucratic resistance. Competitive elections: Responding to a proposal by Mr. Gorbachev in January, voters in some of the elections for local government office last summer chose from among competing candidates for the first time. The system is to be expanded for the next local elections, in 1990. Beginning in January, workers in most factories and farms will vote for their bosses. Mr. Gorbachev proposed competition in party elections as well and the press reported many experiments, but lately there has been little mention of multicandidate elections in the party. Stalin's victims: On Nov. 2, Mr. Gorbachev announced a commission to resume the rehabilitation of those wrongly accused and punished during Stalin's repressions. The process started under Nikita S. Khrushchev, but stopped when he was ousted in 1964. Individual businesses: A law that took effect May 1 allows individuals to moonlight as repairmen, tailors, taxi drivers and the like. Many moonlighters prefer to keep operating without a license. Family farming: Many state and collective farms now have greater freedom to decide what to plant, and to sell more of their produce for market prices. Mr. Gorbachev is pushing to spread family farming, with each family plot tied to a large state farm for its seed, tractors, and fertilizer. Farm production has improved, but much production rots because of poor storage and transport. Legal rights: A variety of new legal safeguards are under discussion, including changes in laws punishing dissent, a new law assuring reporters access to public documents and protecting against reprisals, and measures to increase rights of criminal defendants and reduce the use of the death penalty. None of these laws have been published. A law enacted in July gives citizens broader rights to appeal violations of their rights by public officials. History: Government commissions are rewriting school textbooks, the official Communist Party history, the history of World War II and other books, reportedly to fill in ''white spots'' and restore some official nonpersons to their place in history. Quality control: A state system of quality control has been introduced at 1,500 enterprises and is to be expanded in the fight against shoddy products. The plan has caused some resentment because rejected goods do not count toward worker bonuses, and has also produced drops in production at major factories. Joint ventures: Under a law published in January, foreign companies may own up to 49 percent of joint business ventures with Soviet enterprises. Fifteen companies from capitalist countries have signed contracts, including one American company, Combustion Engineering, which will produce equipment for petroleum processing. Scores of joint ventures have been set up with other Communist countries.

description: Long considered an important nationalist symbol, Petrobras, Brazil's huge state oil monopoly, has decided to expand and diversify its operations abroad to help distance itself from Brazilian economic troubles.

description: It has taken longer to build than Grand Central Terminal - five years versus three - but the new Stamford train station is now open. It is not completely finished even now, but after innumerable delays, cost overruns and construction problems so serious that they required the complete rebuilding of certain sections, no one is likely to worry too much that there is still no escalator on one side of the tracks or a tunnel beneath them.

title: Business and the Law; Fewer Applicants To Law Schools
description: FEWER of the best and brightest students have been applying to law schools, forcing many schools to be less selective, a recent study has concluded.

description: Lower interest rates in Europe were of no help in the Treasury bond market last week, as yields fluctuated around 9 1/8 percent in light trading amid widespread confusion about the direction of the economy.

The authority said Friday it could not support the current proposal, under which S.A.S. would have a limited vote of 29.5 percent. British Airways has also bid for its smaller rival.

description: With the Dow Jones industrial average near its low of Oct. 19, the mood among professional investors shifted last week from nervousness to outright pessimism. The hopelessness is now pervasive and most investors can find few reasons to buy stocks, Wall Street traders and money managers said.

description: A 38-year-old firefighter died early yesterday after suffering a heart attack while working on the roof of a burning building in Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Woosnam Wins Record Golf Prize: Ian Woosnam of Wales won the biggest prize in golf history yesterday, clinching the winner-take-all Million Dollar Challenge at Sun City, Bophuthatswana. He shot an eagle 2 on the 17th hole en route to a four-under-par 68. Woosnam scored a four-stroke victory over his fellow Briton, Nick Faldo, finishing at 274, 14 under par, tying the tournament record. Woosnam sank a shot on the 17 hole from 165 yards to clinch the victory. ''Everyone dreams about being a millionaire,'' Woosnam said. ''If the taxman is not too harsh on me, I might have done it.''(AP) Crafter and Jones Take Team Golf: Jane Crafter chipped in two 40-foot-plus birdies and sank two 30-foot birdie putts yesterday to lead her team to victory in the $650,000 J. C. Penney Mixed Team Golf Classic at Bardmoor Country Club in Largo, Fla. Crafter, a 31-year-old Australian, teamed with Steve Jones, a 28-year-old PGA Tour player from Phoenix, to post a final 68 and a 72-hole total of 20-under-par 268.(AP) Ishii and Aoki Share Victory: David Ishii of the United States and Isao Aoki of Japan, tied for the lead at seven-under-par 138 after two rounds, shared the victory in the Japan Series of Golf yesterday as snow forced cancellation of the final round at Inagi, a suburb of Tokyo.(AP) Speed Skating East Germans Dominate: Christa Rothenburger of East Germany set a world record and beat the former record-holder to win the 500-meter sprint final in World Cup speed skating yesterday at Calgary, Alberta. Rothenburger's time of 39.39 seconds shaved 4-hundredths of a second off Bonnie Blair's previous record. Blair, an American skater, had to settle for a silver medal with 39.56. Karin Kania of East Germany, picked up a bronze when she crossed the finish line in 40.11. In the 5,000-meter event, Andrea Ehrig, East Germany, took the gold in 7:21.31. Her teammate, Gabi Zange, placed second.(AP) Horse Racing Landing Plot Is First: Landing Plot saved ground all the way and caught Sir Smokem in the final yards for a three-quarter-length victory yesterday in the $75,000 Joe Palmer stakes for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. The 4-year-old, ridden by Ruben Hernandez clocked 1:11 3/5 for six furlongs on the fast track. Landing Plot paid $21.80 for $2 to win. Girl Powder captured the $63,500 Bold Princess Stakes for fillies and mares 3-years-old and up. The 4-year-old went six furlongs in 1:11 2/5 under Randy Romero and returned $10 for $2 to win. Ski Jumping 90-Meter Event to Nykanen: Matti Nykanen of Finland capped a spectacular ski-jumping double yesterday at Thunder Bay, Ontario, winning the 90-meter title in addition to the 70-meter crown he won Saturday in the opener of the World Cup circuit. Nykanen, 24, the reigning Olympic 90-meter champion, soared 121.5 meters on his first jump and followed that with a jump of 126.5.(AP) College Hockey Harvard Suffers First Loss: Colgate handed Harvard its first loss of the season yesterday as the Red Raiders beat the Crimson, 4-1, in Hamilton, N.Y. Wayne Cowley had 37 saves for Harvard and Marc Dupere scored what became the winning goal in the second period.

description: Two of the major executive recruiting companies, Russell Reynolds Associates and Spencer Stuart, have announced shifts in top management. description: Jonathon Chase, who was dean of the Vermont Law School in South Royalton from 1982 to July 1987, died of cancer Saturday at his home here. He was 48 years old.

title: Expatriate Looks Homeward
description: When 30 young South Africans arrived in New York earlier this fall to introduce ''Sarafina,'' Mbongeni Ngema's fiercely passionate South African musical, their wide-eyed wonder reflected their first visit outside their own troubled country.

title: The Summit: Ready to Raise the Curtain; In Stopover to See Thatcher, Celebration Rules the Air
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, stopping here briefly today on his journey to Washington, said the treaty that he and President Reagan are to sign on Tuesday is an expression of a yearning everywhere for a ''nonnuclear world.''

title: Music: Hank Ballard
description: HANK BALLARD, who was at the Lone Star Cafe on Friday with the new edition of his group the Midnighters, made some of the toughest, most powerful rhythm-and-blues records of the 1950's. From his controversial early hit ''Work With Me Annie'' through rock-and-roll gems like ''Finger Poppin' Time'' to his original recording of ''The Twist'' in 1960, Mr. Ballard sang in a liquid, soaring tenor about dancing and other strenuous physical activities, dropping suggestive asides that teen-agers relished. A rich blend of gospel-trained voices and a strong, churning rhythm section backed him all the way.

title: LENDL DEFEATS WILANDER WITH RAPID-FIRE SHOTS
description: He is no longer the interim champion, a caretaker of the men's top ranking until one of the young heirs such as Boris Becker or Stefan Edberg is ready to hold the title. This will be remembered as the Ivan Lendl era in tennis, three years and counting.

title: GORBACHEV BEGINS SUMMIT TRIP IN U.S. WITH PLEA ON ARMS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Washington today and immediately challenged President Reagan to offer ''some new words'' that would lead to a treaty dramatically reducing Soviet and American strategic nuclear arsenals.

title: Sony-Ford Tape Deal
description: The Sony Corporation will supply the Ford Motor Company with digital audio tape players for sale under Ford's name, a Sony spokesman said today. The playback-only units will be available as an option in 1988 Lincoln Continental cars, he said.

title: Opera: 'Tristan Und Isolde'
description: The new production of ''Tristan und Isolde'' that the Los Angeles Music Center Opera put forward this evening was something of an oddity for our times, but a welcome one. It had about it a tone of antic freshness, of fairy-tale legend filtered through adult (and adulterous) fantasy, while nonetheless managing to resemble the naturalistic stagings familiar to previous generations of Wagnerians. At times, a clash of styles between the designer, David Hockney, and the director, Jonathan Miller, suggested that the two had worked out their plans independently and then reconciled them in rehearsals. However, what developed out of the apparent creative conflict, in which Zubin Mehta's conducting acted as both mediator and catalyst, was a theatrically persuasive, capably sung and played ''Tristan'' that any opera company could be proud of.

title: Jersey Commuters Vie for the Elusive: A Parking Space
description: It is 10 A.M., and there is not a parking space to be found.

title: Stage: 'Forest of Women'
description: THE most striking visual images in ''Forest of Women,'' a multimedia dream play involving mime, puppetry and ''homemade'' music, are its masks, puppets, and sculptures inspired by the work of Alberto Giacometti. Adaptations of Giacometti's tall, emaciated sculptures of the female figure loom mysteriously above a stage on which masked figures enact a post-Freudian ritual that the play's director, David Marquis, describes in a program note as ''the story of a man's inability to understand his relationship to women.''

description: Farmland values are rebounding after six years of decline, a modest turnaround that Agriculture Department economists say is nonetheless significant.

title: About Education; The Uses of Technology
description: UNLESS the schools are radically transformed and become part of the age of technology, the United States will spend decades catching up with more enterprising countries, according to an educational consultant. At the present pace of change, a small number of privileged children in a few pioneering public school systems will benefit from high-technology learning tools. But students in the vast majority of public schools, many of them from poor families, will remain technologically backward.

title: FANCY LINGERIE: THE FRILL OF IT ALL
description: Women are wearing frilly lingerie again. Underneath the board-room suit and professional uniforms are feminine camisoles, ruffled teddies, lacy bras, stretch-lace bodysuits or silk panties. Instead of the ubiquitous T-shirt, secretaries and stockbrokers alike are sleeping in satin shorts and embroidered tops or short nightgowns, which they wear with short robes instead of blue jeans when lounging around the house.

title: Amendment Payload For Missile Pact Grows
description: The Senate, that remarkable legislative vehicle built for 100 drivers with no back seat, is revving up to drive toward approval of the arms control treaty that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev are to sign on Tuesday.

title: New York Said to Give NBC A Tax-Break Package to Stay
description: The Koch administration and NBC are prepared to announce today that they have reached agreement on a plan to keep the network in Rockefeller Center, its headquarters for more than 50 years.

title: Decision Industries
description: A Massachusetts-based investment partnership, CBC Associates, said it plans to make a bid for Decision Industries Inc. that would be ''substantially higher'' than the friendly $8.75-a-share tender offer begun by the Onset Corporation. The disclosure of the possible new bid, made in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, increases the number of suitors for Decision Industries to three. Econocom International N.V., a Netherlands-based concern, has also said that it might make a bid for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa. CBC is headed by Gautam Gupta, the chief executive officer of IDEA Associates, a private computer concern in Billerica, Mass.

description: In a tribute to Diana Vreeland, who helped forge the link between art and fashion, women donned their most spectacular dresses and, with their escorts in black tie, arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art early yesterday evening. Seven hundred-sixty people paid $850 for the festive night of dining, dancing and, most important, checking out the clothes women chose in this most flamboyant fashion season. Shoulders were bared, fabrics glistened with bead and sequin embroidery and skirts trailed the floor as most guests felt that the grand rooms of the museum demanded sweeping dresses, not short ones.

Books: Setting Stages Books: Setting Stages
description: THE THEATER ART OF BORIS ARONSON. By Frank Rich with Lisa Aronson. 322 pages. Knopf. $75. BORIS ARONSON (1900-1980) was an artist who, having chosen set design as his metier, enjoyed the boon of early recognition both in his native Kiev and in New York City. Luckily for him (though he is unlikely to have thought so at the time), this recognition fell short of that premature elevation to fame and fortune that has tainted the lives of so many other young artists in our era. Fame and fortune came to Aronson comparatively late, after many years of hard work; by then, they were past posing any threat to his art.

title: Fargo Journal; For Displaced Farmers, More Than Sympathy
description: Until three years ago, when the bankers foreclosed on his land, the only thing Mike Friederichs had ever been was a farmer. Out of work, and out of hope, the best he could do was drive a truck part time.

title: Peripherals; The Promise, The Reality And the Hope
description: IT was 1976, say, or 1977. If you had a personal computer, you were a rarity. It might have been an Altair or an IMSAI, and you had built it yourself from a kit. It couldn't do much of anything, but it was a computer, and its possibilities seemed unlimited.

title: BANGLADESH CHIEF PROMISES ELECTION
description: President H. M. Ershad said today that new parliamentary elections would be held within three months.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Maple Leafs 5, Red Wings 4: Russ Courtnall's goal at 2 minutes 21 seconds of overtime last night capped Toronto's comeback from a 3-0 deficit and gave the Maple Leafs a victory at home. The victory ended the Maple Leafs' five-game losing streak and snapped Detroit's five-game winning streak. With Detroit's Doug Houda sitting out a holding penalty, Courtnall cruised into the slot, took Todd Gill's passout from the corner and slapped a fluttering shot past the Detroit goalie, Glen Hanlon, for his 14th goal of the season.

title: Music: The Cosmopolitan
description: THE Cosmopolitan Symphony Orchestra is one of New York's many pickup ensembles, pulling its members from the city's deep pool of young, talented players. The roughly 50-member orchestra gave the first concert of its season in Town Hall on Saturday afternoon. Presenting a program of palatable Romantic fare, it displayed not only the vigor one expects from a youthful ensemble, but also a relatively high degree of style and coordination.

title: Emanuel George Venetucci, Model Builder, 62
description: Emanuel George Venetucci, who built a model of the Milan Cathedral out of more than a million matchsticks, died Sunday. He was 62 years old.

title: Irwin Schiff Case Turns To Contractor Payments
description: Before Irwin Schiff was shot to death last August in a Manhattan restaurant, he received at least $10 million in questionable payments from an electrical contractor, according to law-enforcement authorities. They say they believed Mr. Schiff was a middleman who transferred payoffs from construction companies to organized-crime figures in the city.

title: Haitian Capital Slowed by Strike Over Aborted Vote
description: Most stores and offices in the Haitian capital were shut today and most factory workers stayed away from their jobs to protest the violent disruption of national elections eight days ago.

title: Dance: Balancing 'Divertimento' Duetj in Queens
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Divertimento,'' set to music by Alexei Haieff and first performed in 1947, is famous as a ''lost'' - but much loved -ballet. On Saturday night the ballet's pas de deux was presented in a ravishing program of dances performed at the Colden Center of Queens College, under the aegis of the Queens Symphony Orchestra, by Bart Cook and Bayside's own Maria Calegari, principal dancers with the New York City Ballet. Working with Tanaquil LeClercq, a member of the original cast, Mr. Cook and Ms. Calegari reconstructed the excerpt from a tape of two couples dancing the pas de deux, also used in a 1985 revival by the State Ballet of Missouri. The result was a dance - and performance - of unforgettable eloquence and perfume.

title: Market Place; Second Thoughts On Tri-Star Deal
description: IN September, when the Coca-Cola Company announced that it would sell Columbia Pictures Industries to Tri-Star Pictures, Wall Street greeted the move favorably. Tri-Star's stock rose by $2.50 a share, to $13.50 on Sept. 1.

description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar joined angry Arab representatives today in protesting a Congressional move to close the Palestine Liberation Organization's observer mission here.

title: Correction Chief Opposes Transfer of Larry Davis to Federal Prison
description: A New York State Supreme Court judge cleared the way yesterday for Larry Davis to be transferred from a city detention center in the Bronx to a Federal prison in Manhattan, but the city's top correction official said he would ''vigorously'' oppose such a move.

title: Robertson and History
description: In an attack on Mr. Reagan's policy toward the Soviet Union, Pat Robertson is comparing the President to Neville Chamberlain, the British leader who was the architect of the policy of appeasement toward Nazi Germany. The Republican Presidential contender made the comparison in a statement to the American Political Campaign Hotline. The nation is being subjected to a ''peace offensive'' by the Russians, he said, and ''what worries me is that we appear to be taken in by this in the highest levels of government.''

title: Stingless Bee Of Dinosaur Age Lies in Amber
description: EIGHTY million years ago, when dinosaurs were about and tropical breezes warmed the land that is now New Jersey, a stingless honey bee there got itself caught in the sticky resin of a conifer. The resin hardened into a piece of amber, preserving the bee in lifelike fossilization.

title: Dance: Theatrical Mode Of Guimond Associates
description: THE members of Guimond Dance Associates appeared to be trying to create a dance-theater of the absurd on Saturday night at Theater 61, 211 West 61st Street. Rick Guimond juxtaposed curious sights and sounds in his choreography. Nevertheless, his works often seemed vague.

title: By Design; 'Informal' Evenings
description: It's always easy for men. If the invitation to a swell dinner party reads ''black tie,'' they get out the dinner jacket. If it says ''informal,'' they wear a dark business suit and a white shirt. But for women, informal can be a quagmire.

title: When Will the Shackling Stop?
description: On Nov. 11 the New York City Department of Correction declared it would put an end to the barbaric practice of shackling ailing prisoners to beds in city hospitals. Shackling of women prisoners was to end immediately, which it did. Male prisoners were to be freed of their shackles a week later. As of yesterday about two dozen men, including some suffering from AIDS, remained in chains, manacled to bed rails and posts at Bellevue Hospital.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Do Eskimos get scurvy? A.Scurvy, a condition marked by weakness, anemia and bleeding from the gums and elsewhere, is caused by a lack of Vitamin C in the diet. But according to Dr. Douglas A. Shedden, a medical officer in Canada's Indian and Northern Health Services, the traditional diet of the native Inuit people contains surprising amounts of Vitamin C. ''The traditional foods of the Arctic people include seal meat, and the fat right under the skin of the seal contains quite a lot of Vitamin C,'' he said. ''There's also a lot of Vitamin C in the liver of deer,'' he said, and smaller amounts in bear meat; Arctic char, a kind of fish, and ptarmigan, a bird.

description: A man who had killed a sheriff's deputy during a gunfight was shot in the head by officers as he lay wounded and handcuffed, a witness says.

title: BASEBALL CHANGES THE STRIKE ZONE
description: Baseball's rules committee officially shrunk the strike zone today but said it actually enlarged it. Nevertheless, the new upper limit of the zone still doesn't conform to the reality of the strike zone that umpires use in games.

title: Kabul Journal; The Dogs (and the Camels) Are Fighters, Naturally
description: The champ shook out his massive shoulder muscles as the handlers stepped back. He glared at his opponent, bounding toward him from the far side of the ring, his breathing already heavy. Barking, he went for the throat. There was a hush as more than a thousand men, Afghans with hard, lined faces, leaned forward intently to watch the two battling dogs. Handlers carrying the wreath of flowers that had been draped over the champion scrambled to get out of the way. The referee, an old man dressed all in black, circled the twisting, snarling animals, waving a long pole with feathers on the top.

title: Art: Hockney's Design for 'Tristan und Isolde' in Los Angeles
description: ''Tristan and Isolde,'' as designed by David Hockney, had to be set up and engineered in a fast five days on unfamiliar ground and engineered with elaborate new technologies that had never been used in such a context. Necessarily the result was not quite the polychromatic utopia, responsive to Wagner's every nuance, that had been dreamed of.

title: Man and 4 Grandchildren Die In House Fire in Cleveland
description: An 83-year-old man and four of his grandchildren were killed early today in fire that gutted a two-story frame house, the authorities said.

title: Enzo Magnozzi, Soccer Promoter, 67
description: Enzo Magnozzi, a promoter of international soccer games in the United States for the last three decades, died of a brain tumor Sunday at St. John's Hospital in Elmhurst, Queens. He was 67 years old. Funeral services are scheduled for Thursday morning at St. Leo's Church in Corona, Queens.

title: Vote in the Seychelles Elects 3d Assembly Since '77 Coup
description: Voters in the Indian Ocean nation of the Seychelles elected a new four-year Parliament on Sunday. It was the third general election since France Albert Rene seized power in a coup in 1977 and established one-party rule.

title: Bitter Trade Battle Tests Japan's New Leader
description: Increasingly bitter trade disputes about agriculture and construction may pose some of the toughest challenges for Japan's new Prime Minister, Noboru Takeshita, and are likely to come up when he visits Washington next month to meet with President Reagan.

title: Reagan and History
description: President Reagan, always the optimist, is concerned but not fearful about his role in history. In an appearance at the National Archives last Friday, he cited three critical moments in American history. His first two dates were 1787, when the Constitution was drafted, and 1861, when Abraham Lincoln came to Washington to face civil war. Both times, Mr. Reagan said, the question was ''Could the Republic survive?''

title: Signet Bank Offer
description: Signet Bank of Virginia, a subsidiary of the Signet Banking Corporation, a holding company, is offering $100 million of 9 1/4 percent deposit notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.93 to yield 9.27 percent through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding. Rated Aa-3 by Moody's and A by S.&P, the noncallable issue yields about 95-hundredths of a percentage point more than four-year Treasury bills.

description: The Florida Legislature is expected to repeal the state's controversial new tax on advertising and other services at a special session to begin Tuesday.

title: Youth Faces Charges In Crash Fatal to 4
description: A 16-year-old Bethany youth was charged yesterday with four counts of misconduct with a motor vehicle in connection with the deaths of four of his friends in a car crash in October, the police said.

title: Pretoria Complains to CBS On Making of Documentary

description: The company converted to stock ownership last month.

One of them was a familiar face with a familiar voice, Viktor M. Sukhodrev, who was a rising star among official translators when he came to the United States in 1959 as a backup man for the Eisenhower-Khrushchev summit talks.

description: More than 30 years after he was a prisoner of war in North Korea, Al Storm is still jolted awake some nights by visions of enemy soldiers standing over his bed.

title: Emanuel Saxe, 88, Former College Dean

title: Marietta Contract
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation has been awarded a $1.56 billion military contract for work on 13 big Titan 4 space rockets, the Air Force said. The effort is another step by the Pentagon to increase its ability to launch heavy spy and other satellites into space in the wake of setbacks in America's space program in the last two years. Under the continuing Titan 4 program, part of the money awarded in the latest contract will also be used by Martin Marietta to help activate a Titan 4 launching site at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, the Air Force said.

title: Anna T. Schweinler, Founder of Monastery, 88
description: Anna T. Schweinler, founder of the Roman Catholic Carmelite Monastery in Morristown, N.J., died last Tuesday at the Inglemoor Nursing Home in Livingston, N.J. She was 88 years old and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: Books of The Times
description: JOHN CALVIN. A Sixteenth Century Portrait. By William J. Bouwsma. 310 pages. Illustrated. Oxford University Press. $22.95. We probably picture him, when we think of him at all, as a kind of gray abstraction - stiff, severe, the living embodiment of a grim theological system.

title: A Bird With Backing
description: While a seagull inside the Kingdome has eluded animal-welfare workers for a week, letters have arrived urging officials of Seattle's domed stadium to handle the trapped bird with care. Bill Sears, director of promotions and media relations for the Kingdome, said he has received 30 calls and letters from people with suggestions on how to remove the seagull. ''The bird is becoming something of a cult hero,'' Sears said yesterday.'' Sears said the suggestions have ranged from sending radio-controlled model airplanes aloft to frighten the bird, to overfeeding it with herring so that it would have to waddle rather than fly back to its perch on top of loudspeakers high over the Kingdome floor. The bird was released by an Oregon man during a game between the Seattle Seahawks and the Los Angeles Raiders on Nov. 30. One of the blue-and-green streamers that had been attached to the bird came loose last week. It bore the name of an Oregon tavern, which led Kingdome officials to a man who admitted setting the bird free after a friend had carried it into the stadium in her purse.

description: The Giants said today that Jim Burt, their Pro Bowl nose tackle, would undergo surgery, probably on Thursday, to remove a herniated disk from his back. He will miss the three remaining games of the season, and the Giants placed him on injured reserve today.

title: Monk Is Out
description: The Washington Redskins will probably be without one of their wide receivers, Art Monk, until the playoffs. The Redskins clinched the National Football Conference East title Sunday with a 34-17 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. But their second-half comeback was marred by the loss of Monk, who suffered a partial tear of a ligament in his right knee. Coach Joe Gibbs said a decision on Monk would be made today after team officials talked to the physicians. Regardless of the diagnosis, Gibbs said, Monk would miss two to three weeks. Monk has 38 catches this season for 483 yards and 6 touchdowns. His 504 receptions put him second on the team's career list behind Charley Taylor.

title: Keep Fit the Way the Old-Timers Do
description: To the Editor:

title: The Summit: Missiles and Other Matters; A Few of the Actors in the Summit Spotlight
description: George P. Shultz: Secretary of State, 66; was in Geneva last month to resolve the final details on the intermediate-range missile treaty; a former Secretary of Labor, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Secretary of the Treasury. Michael H. Armacost: Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, 50; a career diplomat, now a key figure on regional issues; travels to Moscow periodically for talks on Afghanistan, Nicaragua and other countries. Frank C. Carlucci 3d: Secretary of Defense, 50; a career Foreign Service officer who has served in Africa, Latin America and Europe; held posts in Department of Health, Education and Welfare and C.I.A. Adm. William J. Crowe Jr.: Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, 62; President Reagan's chief military adviser at the summit meeting, offering advice on technical capabilities of weapons. Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell: National security adviser, 50; Army officer; will coordinate among the senior policy and technical advisers during the summit meeting; was a corps commander in West Germany before becoming deputy national security adviser and then national security adviser this year. Rozanne L. Ridgway: Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, 52; career diplomat and former ambassador. Marlin Fitzwater: White House spokesman, 45; former writer, editor and public relations official for government agencies; became a White House press assistant in 1983, left in 1985 to become a spokesman for Vice President Bush, and took current post this year. Richard Schifter: Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, 64;previously U.S. representative to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. Paul H. Nitze: Special adviser on arms control, 80; gotiating teams at the summit meeting; took part in negotiations for the first strategic arms pact in 1972; fought ratification of the 1979 arms treaty. Jack F. Matlock Jr.: Ambassador to the Soviet Union, 58; President Reagan's chief adviser on Soviet affairs; was in a major position at the Geneva and Reykjavik summit meetings. Eduard A. Shevardnadze: Foreign Minister, 59 years old; full Politburo member and Foreign Minister since July 1985; accompanied Mr. Gorbachev to two previous summit meetings. Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh: A Deputy Foreign Minister, 54; worked in United Nations Secretariat from 1960 to 1966, when he became first secretary to Andrei A. Gromyko, the longtime Foreign Minister; held posts at Soviet Embassy in Washington. Sergei F. Akhromeyev: First Deputy Defense Minister and Chief of General Staff, 64; became Defense Ministry official in 1974 and a marshal in 1983; promoted to his current posts in 1984; went to one previous summit meeting. Yuri V. Dubinin: Soviet Ambassador to the United States, 57; in diplomatic service since 1955; Ambassador to Spain and then chief delegate at the United Nations; Named Ambassador to United States in May 1986. Aleksandr N. Yakovlev: Central Committee Secretary and Politburo member, 64; was an exchange student at Columbia University in 1959; Central Committee secretary for propaganda and the press since March 1986; accompanied Mr. Gorbachev to two previous summit meetings. Vladimir M. Kamentsev: Deputy Prime Minister and Chairman of State Foreign Economic Commission, 59; named Chairman of the State Foreign Economic Commission last January. Gennadi I. Gerasimov: Chief Foreign Ministry spokesman, 57; a former journalist, he was named to current post at Information Department in 1986. Georgi M. Korniyenko: First Deputy Chief of Central Committee's International Department, 62; counselor at Soviet Embassy in Washington from 1960 to 1965. Returned to Foreign Ministry and rose to First Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, a post he held from 1977 to 1986. Anatoly F. Dobrynin: Central Committee Secretary responsible for foreign affairs, 68; Ambassador to Washington from 1962 to 1986; has probably had a role in every Soviet-American summit meeting since the war. Col. Gen. Nikolai F. Chervov: Chief of Treaty and Legal Directorate at Soviet Defense Ministry; an army officer who has long dealt with military participation in arms negotiations; has held current post since 1982.

title: Stage: 'Moonchildren,' In a Season of Weller
description: EVER since it appeared on Broadway in 1972 - to enthusiastic reviews and scant audiences - Michael Weller's ''Moonchildren'' has enjoyed a reputation as the definitive play about college students of the 1960's. That's a tough burden for any work to bear. The kids of the 60's seemed homogeneous only to those adults who failed to understand them. Not every student was an antiwar activist or hippie out of the caricaturing pages of Life magazine. And even those who were had trouble agreeing on a political program or on the correct musical or pharmacological route to a spiritual high. A ''definitive'' play about the 1960's generation would have to be a lie - a poster-bright smorgasbord of slogans, fashions and knee-jerk attitudes.
