description: The Soviet Government plans to disband its officially sanctioned Anti-Zionist Committee, which has been an irritant in relations between the Kremlin and Jews in Israel and the United States since it was created more than four years ago, an American official said today.

title: New Space Challenge: Monitoring Weapons
description: DEFENSE planners looking beyond the most immediate issues of the Soviet-American talks this week, beyond the treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles, have begun to focus on what they see as one of the major technology issues of the 1990's: the ability to monitor space.

title: OLSTEN DEBENTURES
description: The Olsten Corporation, a Westbury, L.I., supplier of temporary personnel, said yesterday that it was withdrawing a proposed public offering of $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures because of recent stock market conditions. It filed for the offering on Oct. The company, through its trade names of Olsten Services and Olsten Health Care Services, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Oct. 2.

title: Red Flags in D.C.
description: Pained warnings from the right, cautious urging from the left, protest marches and posters, a tingling sense of extraordinary occasion . . . Red flags, complete with hammer and sickle, are flying in front of Ronald Reagan's White House. Demonstrators with sharp Slavic cheekbones and clusters of black balloons stand quietly in Lafayette Park, watched by mounted police who do not interfere or harass them as the police did in Moscow a few days ago.

title: Polar Explorers Announce New Expeditions
description: WILL Steger, an Arctic explorer who last year led the first dogsled expedition to the North Pole since 1909, now plans to make the first non-mechanized journey to the first non-mechanized journey to the South Pole and across the entire continent of Antarctica.

title: Make the School Summit a Platform
description: Governor Cuomo has called a school summit meeting for the end of this week to discuss an agenda for change in New York City's troubled system. It could be warmly welcome if directed toward two paramount goals: to consolidate all the pulling and hauling by different interests for different reforms in different directions, and to create and mobilize consensus behind the chancellor soon to be chosen to replace Nathan Quinones.

title: Memorex Offers to Pay $911 Million for Telex
description: The Telex Corporation, which has been fighting a takeover bid from the New York financier Asher B. Edelman, said yesterday that it had received a proposal from Memorex International N.V. to acquire the company for cash and securities valued at $62 a share, or about $911 million.

title: Tax Watch; A 'Cats and Dogs' Senate Package
description: THE distinguishing feature of the $9 billion package of tax increases that the Senate is scheduled to consider today is that few people are likely to remember what was in it. In fact, few people are likely to understand most of what is in it. And that is exactly what tax writers on the Senate Finance Committee had in mind when they drafted it last week.

title: Northeast U.S. Mussels Are Banned by Ontario
description: The Province of Ontario today banned the sale of mussels from Canada's Atlantic provinces and the northeastern United States after 37 cases of food poisoning in Canada were attributed to shellfish.

title: Stage: Comedy Group, 'Artificial Intelligence'
description: LAST winter, the satirical comedy troupe that calls itself Artificial Intelligence took over the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, to stage an imaginary television variety show called ''Vicki's Valentine Thing.'' Set in 1967, it featured the actress Nancy Cassaro playing a mythical star, loosely modeled after Judy Garland, surrounded by her family and guest stars celebrating ''love'' in a style that might be called Las Vegas hippie.

title: 17 Arrested by U.S. in Heroin Ring in Puerto Rico
description: Federal officials said today that 17 people, including one person in New York, had been arrested in connection with the operation of a family-run heroin ring here. The officials said they believed it to be one of the biggest drug rings in Puerto Rico.

title: The Summit: Missiles and Other Matters; A Scorecard on Weapons
description: Arsenals Eliminated in This Pact Ground-Launched Cruise Missile

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax non-recurring gain of $946,000 for the latest period, compared with a similar gain of $10,157,000 for the year-ago period; the year-ago 9 months also included losses of $6,130,000 from discontinued retail operations. Share earnings are adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend distributed July 1 and are fully diluted.

title: Australian Oil Outlook
description: The Exxon Corporation's Esso Australia Ltd. said today that it had lowered its estimate of Australian oil reserves yet to be discovered by 25 percent, to between one billion and five billion barrels.

title: SILKWORM MISSILE IS FIRED AT KUWAIT
description: Iranian forces fired a Silkworm missile at Kuwait today, but it exploded harmlessly in waters off the main oil loading terminal, the Defense Ministry said.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday from Cambridge, Mass., reported that a study of Swedish women concluded that couples who live together before marriage have a divorce rate nearly 80 percent higher than those who do not. The headline in some editions said, ''Divorce May Be the Price of Living Together First.'' That went beyond the conclusions of the authors of the report. One author, Neil Bennett of Yale University, was quoted in the article as commenting about marriage, ''What we are saying is that people who cohabit premaritally are less committed to the institution and are more inclined to divorce than people who don't live together.''

title: Peers Seeking Allis-Chalmers
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection last June, said it had received a proposal from Peers & Company to purchase substantially all of its operating assets and properties for $385 million in cash.

title: Ex-Clergyman Leaves Dallas
description: Walker Railey, the former Methodist minister whose wife was the victim of a near-fatal attack last April, says he has left Dallas to build a new life.

title: The Summit: Ready to Raise the Curtain; PROTESTERS BLOOM NEAR WHITE HOUSE
description: There were Ukrainian-Americans gripping black balloons as they denounced Mikhail S. Gorbachev. There were conservative women's groups supporting the Strategic Defense Initiative. There were demonstrators seeking less money for missiles and more for AIDS research. There were immigrants from Vietnam, Ethiopia and Afghanistan.

title: PULLMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes net from discontinued operations of $2,711,000 and $3,224,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Includes net from discontinued operations of $924,000 and $4,942,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for the year-ago periods are restated to reflect fiscal 1987 sale of a temperature monitoring business and the anticipated disposition of an electrical components business. Effective July 1, the company acquired all of the common and preferred stock of Clevite Industries for cash consideration of about $160 million; the acquisition has been accounted for as a purchase.

title: Cabaret: Julie Wilson Sings
description: AFTER a month of singing the songs of Kurt Weill and Stephen Sondheim as a theatrical presentation in the tiny Kaufman Theater, Julie Wilson is back in the more familiar surroundings of the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel, where she will concentrate on the songs of Mr. Sondheim through Jan. 2.

title: German Praise For U.S. Moves
description: A top West German economic official spoke charitably of American efforts to reduce the Federal budget deficit and appeared to go along with the Reagan Administration's new reluctance to commit itself to continue stabilizing the dollar as it did much of this year.

title: Many Anonymous Donations Are Given to Neediest Cases
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask not to be identified, a request that is always honored.

title: Broad Limit on Growth Passes in San Francisco
description: Amid growing public concern that San Francisco's neighborhoods are losing their distinctive character to ugly apartment buildings, the Board of Supervisors today imposed a 120-day freeze on demolition of houses throughout the city and on major additions to existing homes.

title: IEC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Recital: O'Riley, Pianist
description: WHAT Christopher O'Riley does well he does very well, but it was not quite enough to sustain interest through the course of his recital in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening. The pianist began with Bach's B flat Partita, which immediately brought out his strong suit - a gentle, small-scale, unpretentious approach to the music that included judicious use of the pedal and a scrupulous concern for detail.

title: Pitino's Patience Is Wearing Thin
description: So much for patience. Rick Pitino had finally had enough. The 35-year-old first-year coach of the Knicks, who has strived to maintain a positive spirit amid trying times, made that clear Sunday evening.

title: Ex-Teammates Meet
description: A narcotics officer who played high school baseball with LaMarr Hoyt, a 1983 Cy Young Award winner, crossed paths with Hoyt again - during a drug arrest. Hoyt, 32 years old, was arrested Saturday at his Columbia, S.C., apartment. Narcotics investigators from the Richland County Sheriff's Department reported finding about two grams of cocaine and several plastic bags containing marijuana. Hoyt was charged with possession with intent to distribute cocaine and marijuana. At Keenan High School, Andy Jones and Hoyt switched back and forth playing shortstop and pitcher on the baseball team, Jones recalled Sunday. The two men had seen each other only in passing since high school, Jones said. On Saturday, he helped arrest Hoyt. ''Anytime you arrest somebody, you feel bad for them,'' Jones said. ''It's a shame it had to happen to someone like LaMarr, with the talent he had, and he had the whole community behind him.''

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Welcome to the United States of America.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. ''On behalf of the people and the Government of the Soviet Union, I wish to assure all Americans that we sincerely want better relations between our countries and peoples.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A14:4. ]

title: James Royal Case, 92, Retired Army Officer
description: James Royal Case, a Masonic historian and retired United States Army colonel who served in both World Wars, died Nov. 26 while on a Thanksgiving visit to his daughter in North Granville, N.Y. He was 92 years old and lived in Wallingford, Conn.

title: Drexler Rolls On
description: The Portland Trail Blazers' Clyde Drexler, who averaged 31 points in leading his club to four victories last week, was named the National Basketball Association's player of the week for the second straight time. . . . . The Blazers have removed Ronnie Murphy, their first-round draft pick, from the suspended list, and the former Jacksonville University guard is accompanying the team on its four-game road trip this week. Portland suspended Murphy without pay on Nov. 13 for failing to comply with a diet and physical-rehabilitation program.

title: CARLTON COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $12,198,000. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipts (ADR); each ADR consists of two oridnary shares. Results are in U.S. dollars. All monetary results are based on a rate of $1.626 a pound sterling, the rate in effect Sept. 30.

title: Phillips Auction House Slashes New York Staff
description: Phillips, the London-based auction house, announced yesterday that it had cut its New York City staff of 34 in half, effective Dec. 31, adding that beyond next week's sales, no auctions are scheduled for the immediate future.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Centocor Inc., Malvern, Pa., a maker of therapeutic and diagnostic health-care products, said James E. Wavle Jr. had joined as president, chief operating officer and a director.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Deaver's Maintains 'Special' Ties to Mrs. Reagan
description: When Michael K. Deaver relinquished his official White House perquisites 19 months ago, he quietly held on to at least one unofficial privilege: the access to 1600 Pennyslvania Avenue provided by his close relationship with Nancy Reagan.

title: CMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $437,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss and after a reversal of a tax credit of $315,000 for the quarter.

title: MOLLY O'DAY, SINGER OF COUNTRY MUSIC IN ROUGHHEWN STYLE
description: Molly O'Day, who never became a major national star but who was prized by aficionados as one of the finest country-and-western singers ever, died of cancer of the colon Saturday at Cabell Huntington Hospital in Huntington, W.Va. She was 64 years old.

title: C. George Willard, 58, Broadway Press Agent
description: C. George Willard, a Broadway press representative and former theatrical company manager, died Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chiles of Florida Is Retiring, Saying Zeal for Senate Lags
description: Senator Lawton Chiles, citing a loss of enthusiasm for the Senate, today surprised his colleagues here and his supporters in Florida by pulling out of his race for re-election next year.

title: Stock Rebound Spurs Rate Rises
description: Short- and long-term interest rates soared yesterday as rebounding stock prices lured many investors from a fixed-income securities market that has seen thin trading of late.

title: 2 Top Correction Officials Demoted After 3 Inmates Escape
description: Calling several recent escapes from city jails ''an embarrassment,'' Richard J. Koehler, the New York City Correction Commissioner, yesterday demoted two top penal officials.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $47,000.

title: Victims and Suspects
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City to Pay Jersey Town $1 Million Over Shore Pollution
description: A Federal judge today approved an agreement intended to halt the pollution of New York Harbor and the Jersey Shore by garbage from the city's Fresh Kills Landfill on Staten Island.

title: Governing Party Is Set Back In Bolivian Municipal Voting
description: Bolivia's governing party was set back in municipal elections as leftist and conservative opposition parties were leading in eight provincial capitals, including La Paz, according to initial results reported today.

title: CUBAN PRISONERS SEEK MIDDLE PATH
description: Between the two extremes of deportation and indefinite detention, some Cubans who have served time in American prisons have been paroled into rehabilitation programs in preparation for integration into society.

title: It Takes Two to Make a Cold War; Behind Abuse Case Is the Baby Market
description: To the Editor:

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Friendship Nurtures Jewish-Catholic Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Burdick in Hospital
description: Senator Quentin N. Burdick, the 79-year-old Democrat who is seeking re-election, was hospitalized for observation today after he fell on ice at the airport and hurt his head, said the Senator's Washington press secretary, Jean Brodshaug.

title: Chess Game a Draw
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov agreed to a draw today after 28 moves in the 21st game of the world chess championship. The score is now 10 1/2 points each.

title: Gallo Responds To Riney Move
description: The E. & J. Gallo Winery responded yesterday to last Thursday's resignation by its ad agency, Hal Riney & Partners.

title: Tornadoes Strike in Texas
description: Tornadoes destroyed homes and uprooted trees and power lines in at least two East Texas counties Sunday, but no injuries were reported, the authorities said. The Anderson County Sheriff's Department here, 110 miles southeast of Dallas, said the damage was farther south in the county and in Polk County, 75 miles to the southeast.

title: It Takes Two to Make a Cold War
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split which occurred on March 31, which has been retroactively reflected for all periods.

title: Landlord Arrested On Housing Charges
description: A 50-year-old Brooklyn landlord was arrested yesterday on charges that he repeatedly ignored hundreds of orders from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development to fix violations ranging from leaky pipes to mice and roaches at his Crown Heights apartment building, the Brooklyn District Attorney's office said.

title: Exxon-Celeron Deal Completed
description: The Exxon Corporation has completed its purchase of the Celeron Oil and Gas Company from the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company for slightly less than $650 million. Goodyear had made arrangements in August to sell Exxon the subsidiary to help pay off a huge debt incurred last year when Goodyear fought off a hostile takeover bid by the British-French financier Sir James Goldsmith.

title: At Least 15 Are Dead in Peru After Mudslide Hits Villages
description: At least 15 people were killed and about 100 missing after mudslides swept through four villages in the foothills of the Peruvian Andes, the police said today.

title: 2 Bombings Worry Manila; Army Threat Seems to Wane
description: A car-bombing this evening at Manila International Airport added to the worries of Philippine officials as they prepare for a regional summit meeting next week.

title: Montreal Edges Islanders
description: For the Islanders, tonight's game with the Montreal Canadiens was designed to serve as something of a measuring stick, a tool with which to determine whether they could genuinely be counted among the National Hockey League's elite.

title: Washington Talk: Intelligence Security; Whither Moscow Embassy Scandal?
description: Six months ago, American intelligence officials were convinced their worst nightmare had come true: Marine guards had let Soviet agents into the Moscow Embassy and presumably given them access to some of the most closely guarded secrets of the United States Government.

title: Pro-Olympic Gesture
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors agreed yesterday to bend its waiver rules to make some players available to the American and Canadian Olympic teams for the Winter Games in February in Calgary, Alberta. John Ziegler, the league's president, said the Canadian-based teams have been asked to submit a list of five or six players who would be available to Team Canada. Ziegler said the players chosen by the Olympic team must be ranked in the bottom half of each N.H.L. team's roster and that each N.H.L. team and player must give their consent. The United States Olympic team has the option to borrow up to two United States players from American-based N.H.L. teams in the event of injuries to regular Olympic team members.

title: Surgery for Guidry; Is Tolleson Next?
description: Ron Guidry underwent surgery on his pitching shoulder in Birmingham, Ala., today, and Wayne Tolleson will undergo a second examination there on his throwing shoulder Wednesday, to determine if he needs surgery.

title: Friends Gather To Celebrate Baldwin's Gifts
description: James Baldwin, a son of Harlem whose words and perceptions influenced the lives of millions around the world, was eulogized yesterday as a literary giant and as a loving spirit whose unflinching honesty was informed by a delicate and yet durable tenderness.

title: Plight of Homeless Prompts Donations to Neediest Cases
description: Concern for the plight of New York City's hungry and homeless has motivated people from all over the country to send donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: President Leaves Post At Rockefeller Fund
description: Dr. Richard W. Lyman, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, is leaving the philanthropy and returning to Stanford University to head a new Institute of International Studies.

title: Books of The Times
description: MANY MASKS. A Life of Frank Lloyd Wright. By Brendan Gill. 544 pages.

title: Dance: Sally Silvers
description: ''LIKELY SUITE'' was the fitting name of a piece Sally Silvers presented on Sunday at the Middle Collegiate Church. Her dances, fully set but developed from improvised material, exist in that challenging mid-ground between the possible and the probable.

title: Fruit Wines' New Popularity
description: A CONCORDE flashed across the Atlantic carrying the first case of Beaujolais nouveau last year, and a chauffeur-driven limousine sped it into Manhattan from Kennedy International Airport. A few days earlier a slow 1941 two-seat biplane had bumped to a halt on a tiny grass airfield in Blue Hill, Me. A case of light, fruity wine was unloaded into a 1917 Model T Ford, which chugged downtown to Jonathan's Restaurant. The wine maker, Robert W. Bartlett, ceremoniously uncorked a bottle. The nouveau blueberry had arrived.

title: About New York; A Cabby Takes The Joke Pulse Of the City
description: Jim Pietsch (pronounced peach) pitched up in the city with a smile and a knack for hustle. He was a musician, a drummer by training, an aspiring lyricist, and an artist-cartoonist-illustrator. It was only natural, then, that, like thousands of others with similar credentials, he got a job driving a taxi.

title: The Emerging Candidate: Who Is Senator Simon?
description: Senator Paul Simon of Illinois promises an administration of good deeds. He spins the vision of a nurturing Government.

title: Beard Sets Defense
description: The board of the Beard Company, an oil and gas exploration company based in Oklahoma City, has taken steps to block a takeover by the Union Pacific Corporation. Union Pacific, in its bid to gain control of USPCI Inc., announced last week that it had increased its holdings of Beard outstanding shares to 16.6 percent. Beard and a subsidiary own about 28.1 percent of USPCI's outstanding shares. Union Pacific, a rail and energy company based in New York, has twice tried to acquire USPCI, an Oklahoma City hazardous waste management company. Last month Beard's president, Herb Mee, said that, under the new plan, shareholders would receive one right for each share of Beard common stock held on Dec. 18. The rights could be exercised in the case of a takeover offer so as to make the attempt very expensive.

title: Pop Musicians Plan World Tour for Rights
description: Sting, Peter Gabriel and other internationally known musicians are planning a six-week world tour beginning next August to support Amnesty International, the human-rights organization, and its campaign to renew support for the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The dates and itinerary have not been set, but the prospective tour, called Human Rights Now, is to include Eastern European and third-world countries. The organizers hope to include countries that have been accused of violating human rights.

title: U.S. Envoy Is Urging Black Pretoria Rule, Minority Protection
description: The United States Ambassador here has called for the creation of a black majority government in South Africa with specific protection for the Afrikaner minority.

title: Brodsky Advocates Reading As Criterion for Leadership
description: Joseph Brodsky, the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature, said today that there would be less grief in the world if leaders were chosen on the basis of what they read rather than their political programs.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Theater: 'The Gingerbread Lady'
description: NEIL SIMON'S strange 1970 play, ''The Gingerbread Lady,'' seems to strain mightily to fly into pieces, and part of the fascination of seeing it lies in watching director and cast struggle to hold it together. The challenge of keeping it coherent, in fact, must be one reason it continues to appeal to producers. This play, which runs through Dec. 20, is an efficient testing machine.

title: Broadnax Moving On
description: Marcus Broadnax, a sophomore reserve guard at St. John's, said yesterday that he would leave the university after this semester, which ends Dec. 23. ''I'm through practicing,'' he said. ''Next semester I'll be in another school. I spoke with Coach Carnesecca and he said that he understood.'' Broadnax, who averaged 38.9 points a game in his senior year at Fort Walton Beach (Fla.) High School, said he had been misled during the recruiting process by Coach Lou Carnesecca and his assistants, Ron Rutledge and Brian Mahoney. ''They said that I was going to play, that they wouldn't recruit over me, and that myself and Elander Lewis were the future of St. John's basketball,'' Broadnax said. Carnesecca has confirmed the promises to Broadnax, but said that when Michael Porter said he wanted to come to St. John's along with Greg (Boo) Harvey, the coach had no choice but to take him. Porter and Harvey were regarded as the nation's best junior-college backcourt while at San Jacinto. With Harvey and Porter starting for the Redmen, and Lewis and Steve Shurina playing behind them, Broadnax had played in only two of the team's four games. . . . Rod Strickland, a DePaul point guard, was ruled academically eligible yesterday to rejoin the Blue Demons. Strickland was DePaul's No. 2 scorer, with a 16.3 average last season.

title: Rare Easy Game for Knicks
description: Either Rick Pitino is a supreme motivator or the Washington Bullets have serious problems.

title: MILITARY SUPPLIER SUED FOR EQUIPMENT DEFECTS
description: The Government is accusing an Ollio military contractor of fraudulently supplying the Army with defective drive shaft assemblies for M-48 and M-60 tanks, the Justice Department announced Monday.

title: 'Serious Money' Is Set To Move to Broadway
description: An American production of Caryl Churchill's ''Serious Money,'' a comedy set in the financial markets of London and New York, is to open Jan. 18 at the Royale Theater on Broadway. The production will mark Miss Churchill's Broadway debut.

title: Webster Names Ex-Agent to Top C.I.A. Post
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, today named a former Central Intelligence Agency official to head the agency's operations directorate, the section that has drawn the greatest Congressional and public scrutiny.

title: France Expels Iranians to Gabon
description: France expelled 14 Iranians and 3 Turks today, saying they are members of an Iranian opposition group. The Government denied accusations that the expulsions were tied to an agreement with Iran on freeing French hostages in Labanon.

title: Dr. David Mann, Psychotherapist, 61
description: Dr. David Mann, a psychotherapist and former professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 61 years old.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Schedule? What Schedule?
description: This year, the Russians are working on openness. Next year they may get around to organization.

title: Letters; Those Holiday Meals
description: To The Living Section:

title: Pan Am Board Sets Deadline for Officer
description: The board of the Pan Am Corporation has given the company's vice chairman until today to negotiate further concessions from the pilots' and flight engineers' unions before resuming deliberations on a takeover offer this afternoon, union officials and other people close to the board said yesterday.

title: Bass Group Sees Bell & Howell Pact
description: An group that includes the Texas investor Robert M. Bass and senior managers of the Bell & Howell Company said that it was near an agreement with the company about its proposed takeover offer of $64 a share, or $678 million. In a letter to Bell & Howell, included in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group said it had reviewed a draft merger agreement from the publishing company, based in Skokie, Ill. ''We expect these matters can be promptly negotiated and an agreement signed,'' the Bass group said in the letter.

title: Remarks by Reagan and Gorbachev at White House Welcome
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday at welcoming ceremonies at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by an official Soviet interpreter. Reagan Remarks

title: Basketball League On a Small Scale
description: A small new basketball league, or a new basketball small league, or both, or neither, held its first draft, big or small, yesterday morning at the Sheraton Centre.

title: Article 456287 -- No Title
description: Henry R. Kravis, a New York City financial investor who specializes in corporate management buyouts, has pledged $10 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art to help complete a $51 million, five-story wing that is the last major component of the museum's master expansion plan, museum officials announced yesterday.

title: A State Dinner for the Gorbachevs: Front-Row Seat on World History
description: President and Mrs. Reagan invited a cross-section of America - 126 stars of business, science, sports, politics and the arts - to the White House state dinner this evening in honor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa.

title: The Big Farmers' Tax Harvest
description: To most Americans, the difference between ''cash'' and ''accrual'' tax accounting remains a matter of accounting esoterica. But a handful of giant, family-controlled farming businesses know how to make the most of it. They use cash accounting, meant to make life easier for individuals and small farmers, to defer hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes. Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey leads the fight to close this expensive loophole.

title: Limited Success Seen In War Against Drugs
description: The Reagan Administration's top experts on drug law enforcement and the prevention of drug abuse told a Congressional panel today they had made limited progress in the war against drugs.

title: The Treaty at a Glance
description: Missiles Eliminated (Articles III, IV and V)

title: TransCanada Lifts Offer for Encor
description: TransCanada Pipelines Ltd., one of Canada's largest gas-pipeline companies, increased its takeover offer for the Encor Energy Company, to about $1.1 billion (Canadian), or $825 million (American). Encor, a smaller Canadian oil and gas producer, had rejected an earlier bid of $8.75 a share as inadequate. Encor had no immediate comment on the new offer, which is about $9.375 a share.

title: YOUNGSTERS WHO LICK THE BOWL CAN ALSO MAKE THE COOKIES
description: BAKING may be the most alluring kitchen activity for children. This is especially true at holiday time, when batches of cookies and other festive specialties perfume the house with their tempting fragrances. As soon as youngsters are old enough to lick the batter bowl, they are likely to become willing participants.

title: Reds' Parker Goes to Athletics
description: The first two big trades of the winter baseball meetings took place today when the Cincinnati Reds sent Dave Parker to the Oakland Athletics, and the Boston Red Sox obtained Lee Smith, one of baseball's best relief pitchers, from the Chicago Cubs.

title: 'Utopia Versus Reality' In Brazil's Art Biennal
description: Every two years, Sao Paulo, like its two European counterparts, Venice and Kassel, West Germany, organizes a momentous forum to review current modern art.

title: Morrill Cody, 86, Dies; Ex-Official of U.S.I.A.
description: Morrill Cody, a former deputy director of the United States Information Agency, died Nov. 23 at the Manor Care nursing home in Wheaton, Md., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Ex-Police Chief Is Sentenced
description: The former police chief of Glendale, a suburb of St. Louis, has been fined $24,000 and placed on five years' probation for his part in what the authorities describe as a $1 million sports bookmaking operation. The 53-year-old former chief, Cecil H. Livesay, who pleaded guilty Oct. 26 to participating in a gambling operation and tax evasion, was sentenced Monday by Federal District Judge George F. Gunn Jr.

title: Prominent Americans Hear Gorbachev's World Vision
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev summoned some of the nation's leading cultural, intellectual and political leaders to the Soviet Embassy this afternoon, turned on the television lights, and delivered a two-hour sales pitch for his vision of a new world order.

title: The Treaty After the Treaty
description: An agreement emerging at the summit would cut Soviet and American long-range nuclear weapons by half. But is that - as opposed to the treaty signed yesterday banning Euromissiles - good? Will it actually reduce the risks of war? Many experts argue that the strategic arms agreement actually would make U.S. intercontinental forces more vulnerable and thus weaken deterrence. These concerns cannot be dismissed.

title: A HAWK PRAISES THE TREATY
description: Those hawks now mobilizing to block Senate ratification of the treaty eliminating intermediate-range nuclear missiles threaten to snatch defeat from the jaws of victory, both for their own side in the defense-policy debate and for America's position against its adversary.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Nov. 14 about a dispute between New York City firefighters and police officers gave an incorrect address for the New York City Fire Museum. It is at 278 Spring Street in Manhattan.

title: A Leading Washington Hotel Becomes Kremlin West
description: Georgi A. Arbatov, a member of the Communist Party's ruling Central Committee, sat in his shirtsleeves Monday evening sipping a Johnnie Walker Scotch and water in his room at the Madison Hotel.

title: HOW TO DESTROY THE 2,611 MISSILES
description: The text of the treaty signed today by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev spells out how hundreds of American and Soviet inspectors will insure that 2,611 American and Soviet missiles are smashed, exploded, crushed, burned or launched to be destroyed.

title: For New York, Coliseum Setback and a Costly Victory; Concern Over a Possible Conflict of Interest
description: The judge who on Monday invalidated the sale of the New York Coliseum site on Columbus Circle ruled that the city had illegally made the full purchase price contingent on a zoning variance.

title: Number of 'Boarder Babies' Cut
description: The Koch administration said yesterday that it had sharply reduced the number of abandoned babies living in hospitals in New York City.

title: THE FAMILY ALBUM: DIVINING THE RIGHT GIFT
description: YOU can, without a doubt, have too many ties. You can even have too many books, records, scarves, gloves and all the other perennials of the gift-giving season. Food, though, is another matter. You might be given the wrong food: chocolate when you can't bear the sight of it; mustard when you have two dozen jars; Julia Child's opus when you haven't mastered tuna fish sandwiches. But for everyone there is some kind of food that is just right, because everyone has to eat.

title: James Stewart McDonald, Executive, 59
description: James Stewart McDonald, president of J. S. McDonald Consultants of Darien, Conn., died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 59 years old. Mr. McDonald was previously a district manager for I.B.M. and a vice president of the Computer Usage Corporation.

title: Vienna Journal; The Angst Over Waldheim Just Won't Go Away
description: Although Kurt Waldheim has defiantly dismissed any notion of resigning, the humiliation his presidency has brought down on Austria is rapidly swelling sentiment here that he must go.

title: Folk Museum to Occupy Mall Under Zoning Pact
description: The Museum of American Folk Art, currently without a home, would move into what is now a gloomy, lifeless mall across from the Lincoln Center, under a negotiated cease-fire in a 15-year zoning battle.

title: New York Loses Plea For New Census Count
description: A Federal judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit that said the population of New York City and State had been disproportionately undercounted in the 1980 census.

title: The Pop Life
description: Musical Odyssey

title: Leave the P.L.O. Offices Open
description: LEAD: Some self-styled representatives of American Jews claim that closing the Palestine Liberation Organization offices in Washington and at the United Nations would constitute a victory for American Jews. It would be a defeat - for peace in the Middle East and the right of free speech. That should worry all citizens regardless of faith or ethnic background.

title: An Underdog Savors Victory in Coliseum Battle
description: There was a mood of quiet satisfaction yesterday at the Municipal Art Society, with no unseemly gloating about a court victory over the New York City government.

title: Was It a 'Cheap Shot,' or Was It Clean?
description: HE is only as good as his legs. Sturdy or swift, if his legs are damaged, he's not the same player. Without that thrust or without that speed, his career is threatened. Throughout the National Football League, the hardest words one player can say about another is, ''He took a cheap shot at my knees.'' Cheap shot or clean, with all those knees moving around out there, it's a wonder that more players aren't carted off the field.

title: Experts Seek to Determine If Shots Played Role in Crash
description: How would the firing of high-caliber bullets have sent the Pacific Southwest Airlines four-engine jet into a fatal dive to the ground?

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''For everyone, and above all for our two great powers, the treaty whose text is on this table offers a big chance, at last, to get onto the road leading away from the threat of catastrophe.''

title: Lois Yellin Abramson, Art Collector, 54
description: Lois Yellin Abramson, who helped obtain many items in the permanent collection of the art gallery at Queensborough Community College, died of brain cancer last Wednesday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 54 years old and lived in Queens.

title: Lessons
description: She was sitting at her desk in the oak office on James Street when he went to meet her for the first time. She was to be his adviser, the registrar said, his guide back to the scholar's life of lectures and books.

title: Landry Criticized
description: Coach Tom Landry of the Dallas Cowboys was surprised to receive heavy criticism from Bum Bright, the team's principal owner, after a 21-10 loss to the Atlanta Falcons Sunday. Aware that the Cowboys (5-7) were perilously near elimination from playoff contention, Landry said yesterday that he intended to coach the Cowboys until 1989. ''I knew it would take three years to bring the team back into contention again when I signed my contract,'' said Landry. ''There is no magic to it. I've been down a little bit, but that's part of football. To receive criticism from an owner was a deviation from the past a little bit.'' When asked if Bright were suggesting plays for the team to run, Landry replied, ''If he wants to try one, I'll welcome him.''

title: Advertising; People
description: Eric Weber has been promoted to vice chairman, creative operations, and a member of the management group at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

title: Specialist Inquiry Seen
description: The New York Stock Exchange is investigating the performance of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg and M. J. Meehan & Company, specialists that make the markets in the stock of J. P. Morgan & Company and Gould Inc. respectively, people in the industry said yesterday.

title: Tasting 43 Varieties, Apricot to Peach
description: THREE specialists gathered last week at The New York Times to taste wines made from fruit other than grapes. They liked about half of the 43 they sampled.

title: Washington Talk: The Press; Western Scramble, Meet Eastern Scramble
description: While Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan met in the Oval Office today, reporters at the summit press center in the basement of the J. W. Marriott Hotel across town dogged a bewildered young woman whose status as the only black reporter in the Soviet press corps was making her an instant celebrity.

title: Scientists Challenge Finding Of Oxygen in Ancient Amber
description: The recent discovery of oxygen-rich bubbles that had apparently been preserved in amber since the time of the dinosaurs has drawn its first major challenge. Two researchers in California say that their amber samples show no oxygen at all.

title: SOVIET SEEKS BAR ON RIGHTS MEETING
description: The Soviet authorities moved today to disrupt an unofficial seminar on human rights planned for later this week, according to the seminar's organizer.

title: Captive Liked Life 'Close to the Edge'
description: Down at Jubelt's Cafe, off the town square, James Jordan Denby liked to show his friends photos taken at his farm a stone's throw from Nicaragua. In them, he could be seen beside contras in full battle gear.

title: Letters; Live and Learn
description: To The Living Section:

description: Following are excerpts from a protocol to the arms treaty signed today, governing the elimination of missile systems: Items of Missile Systems Subject to Elimination

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES SPENDING FOR '88
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved a wide-ranging $606 billion appropriation bill for the 1988 fiscal year, including $7.6 billion of the spending cuts required by the budget compromise between Congress and the White House.

title: EDUCATION: Information; College Enrollment: Full Time, Part Time
description: Total number of students enrolled in colleges and universities. Figures for 1987 through 1990 are estimates. Full time Part time '85 7,075,000 5,172,000 '86 7,148,000 5,249,000 '87 7,000,000 5,300,000 '88 6,970,000 5,340,000 '89 6,980,000 5,380,000 '90 6,900,000 5,400,000 (Source: Department of Education)

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; A Book of Udall Jokes
description: President Reagan may be a collector of jokes, but he is no match for Representative Morris K. Udall, the Arizona Democrat and erstwhile Presidential candidate who is widely regarded as Capitol Hill's resident wit and storyteller.

title: For New York, Coliseum Setback and a Costly Victory; Mixed Messages From City Hall on Finances
description: The fiscal news from New York's City Hall lately has come with typical speed and classic urgency, with the kind of drama Mayor Koch invests in most matters that swirl about him. It has also come with seeming contradictions - mixed messages that tend to confuse an already murky economic picture.

title: Article 539487 -- No Title
description: New York State's top law-enforcement officials yesterday asked Governor Cuomo and the Legislature for a special fund of $10 million to uncover corruption by public officials and private businesses.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1987
description: International A3-26

title: THE SUMMIT: A Tempered Optimism; At the End of an Unlikely Journey, Reagan And Gorbachev Are Mindful of Differences
description: Even for this city, which long ago mislaid its sense of wonder, this was a thrilling day, bathed in a glow of satisfaction at what has been achieved and of optimism about what may lie just ahead.

title: Merola Aide Seen as Choice For Prosecutor
description: Governor Cuomo will name Paul T. Gentile, a career prosecutor, to be the Bronx District Attorney for a one-year term, Bronx politicians said yesterday.

title: Jail Commissioner Criticizes Davis and Orders Isolation
description: The New York City Correction Commissioner, Richard J. Koehler, yesterday ordered Larry Davis, accused of murdering four men, to be isolated and guarded in his cell in the Bronx House of Detention by a special unit from Rikers Island.

title: Giant Group Inquiry Cited
description: Burt Sugarman, the television and film producer who is the chairman of Giant Group Ltd., disclosed today that he had been questioned in September by the Securities and Exchange Commission's staff in connection with Giant's purchase of the TRE Corporation's common stock and an offering of Giant debt securities last year.

title: 13 Medical Colleges Say Staffs Must Treat AIDS
description: New York State's 13 medical colleges said yesterday that any faculty member, hospital resident or medical student who refuses to treat an AIDS patient would be dismissed.

title: Oxford Theologian Tied to Criticism of Prelate Is Found Dead
description: A coroner opened an inquest today into the death, apparently by suicide, of an Oxford University theologian suspected of having written an attack on the Archbishop of Canterbury that created an uproar in the Church of England.

title: Estimate of Risk Of Dioxin Is Cut In Cancer Study
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, in a new draft study with the potential for far-reaching policy implications, has sharply reduced its estimate of the cancer-causing potential of dioxin, a widespread chemical pollutant.

title: Bridge: For 9 Top Administrators, A Cruise and Celebration
description: If you put nine of the world's leading bridge administrators on a luxury yacht with something to celebrate, the result may be a somewhat bibulous bridge game. It happened in October on the Southern Breeze, which was anchored off Ocho Rios, Jamaica, during the world team championships.

title: For Black Parents, The Doll Debate
description: ON Christmas morning, 9-year-old Hodari Wells of Crown Heights in Brooklyn, and her 7-year-old sister, Liana, will probably rise just after dawn to rip packages open that their parents spent hours wrapping the night before. Each girl is hoping one of the boxes holds that special doll on her list.

title: TOP RATING GIVEN TO JUDGE KENNEDY
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, President Reagan's latest nominee for the Supreme Court, received the American Bar Association's highest rating today by a unanimous vote.

title: BOOK-ENTRY ISSUE BY CONNECTICUT
description: Connecticut, which has not bor-rowed since before the new tas law, entered the debt market yesterday with a $200 million offering of general obligation bonds through underwrit-ter's led by the Citicorp Investment Bank.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Washington yesterday about the makeup of missile crews included an incorrect figure from the Strategic Air Command for the number of women serving in nuclear missile control centers. The number is 42, not 120.

title: For the Cellular User, Ecstasy and Agony . . . As the Industry Hunts for Cures
description: DEAD spots - situations in which portable telephones do not work - can enrage customers, and cellular companies and equipment manufacturers are trying to remedy the problems.

title: Koreans Find New Freedom For Vote Talk
description: One flight up from the dusty side street, the clacking of plastic discs could barely be heard over the chatter of politics in Chun Woo Wang's baduk parlor.

title: Hanukkah in Israel: Not by Latkes Alone
description: AMERICAN Jews have generally celebrated Hanukkah, or the Feast of Lights, as a minor holiday, particularly in culinary terms. Little thought is given to ceremonial foods other than the ubiquitous potato pancake, or latke, and a few sweet pastrylike desserts, all fried in oil.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Summer in a Jar

title: Jeep Dealers Will Sell New Chrysler Eagle Car
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which has packaged the remnants of the American Motors Corporation as a new Jeep/Eagle division, will begin selling new auto models this month.

title: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY: Advances; Cost-Saving Device Helps Pay TV
description: FOR years, pay-per-view television has been merely a dream for the cable industry. The technology required to offer the service was costly and few cable operators were willing to pay the price.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I REMEMBER the first time I smoked marijuana. It was a summer night and I was 19 years old. I was a passenger in a Volkswagen (I believe that most first drug experiences during the 1970's took place in Volkswagens) and we were driving down a back road redolent of honeysuckle and manure. The effects of the drug were that I lost all feeling in my tongue and developed a maniacal craving for French toast.

title: Merrill Lynch Official To Join World Bank
description: Donald Roth, the chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company's merchant banking subsidiary, yesterday was named vice president and treasurer of the World Bank, one of the most important positions at the giant lending institution.

title: Advertising; Amnesty International Volunteers
description: ''A STUDENT in South Africa. A journalist in Chile. A dissident in the Soviet Union,'' the TV commercial's voice-over will intone, and the camera will open on a single eye, an eye filled with fear and panic. Then it will slowly pull back to reveal the other eye and the nose of a frightened man.

title: Krol Will Retire As Archbishop Of Philadelphia
description: John Cardinal Krol, a onetime meatcutter who became one of the most influential prelates of the Roman Catholic Church, announced today that he would retire Feb. 11 as Archbishop of Philadelphia .

title: In Moscow, a Different Sort of Meeting
description: Amidst the summit hoopla, some less exalted Muscovites now prepare another gathering, humbler but earth-shaking in its own way: an unofficial human rights conference to begin tomorrow. That a group of former political prisoners could contemplate such a seminar in Moscow says much about how times have changed. The Kremlin's response will say more.

title: WALTON HINTS SHAKE-UP IS IN STORE IN '88
description: The Jets - a maddening team of continual promise and scant fulfillment -may face a shake-up when the season is over.

title: TV Reviews; Coverage of Gorbachev and the Summit Talks
description: TELEVISION was cheery yesterday. Ronald Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev both spoke from the East Room of the White House. Their wives sat side by side. Then Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev spoke again, this time in front of a pretty fireplace in the State Dining Room. ''There's the great Gorbachev smile,'' Dan Rather said accurately; the mood was almost festive. Then CBS went live to Mark Phillips in Moscow.

title: Film: Spielberg's 'Empire of Sun'
description: GOD playing tennis: that's what Jim Graham (Christian Bale), a privileged British schoolboy living in high colonial style in the pre-Pearl Harbor Shanghai of 1941, sees in one of his dreams. God taking a photograph: Jim thinks he sees that four years and seemingly several lifetimes later, as a starving, exhausted prisoner witnessing the brilliant light of the atomic bomb.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Mixed in Quiet Day; Dealers Await Trade Data
description: The dollar turned in a mixed performance on very thin trading yesterday, as dealers grew increasingly pessimistic about trade figures due from the Commerce Department tomorrow.

title: B.P. Acquires 14.9% of Britoil And Will Seek 29.9% Stake
description: The British Petroleum Company announced today that it had bought 14.9 percent of one of the world's largest independent oil exploration and production companies, Britoil, for $409 million. The company also said it would make a tender offer to raise its Britoil stake to 29.9 percent - a deal that would cost British Petroleum more than $810 million over all.

title: Chicago Leads Way In City School Woe
description: In this city that divides bitterly over almost every topic, from baseball to politics, one subject engenders rare unity: the awful state of public education.

Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by an official Soviet interpreter. Reagan Address

title: Canada-Japan Venture
description: The government of British Columbia has announced a $1 billion (Canadian) pulp and paper project with a Japanese forest products company. The Economic Development Minister, Grace McCarthy, said that Oji Paper Ltd. of Japan would join with the Howe Sound Pulp division of the Canfor Corporation to build a $350 million newsprint mill at Port Mellon, near Vancouver, which would probably employ at least 450 workers. An additional $650 million would be invested over three years to expand existing mills in the area.

title: Fed Chief Cites Inflation Peril
description: Despite widespread fears of recession after the Oct. 19 Wall Street collapse, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, stressed the dangers of inflation yesterday. In a speech at the Waldorf-

title: Chess Rivals in Hard-Fought Draw
description: Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov fought to a thorny draw Monday in the 21st game of their world chess championship match in Seville, Spain. The score now stands at 10 1/2 points each.

description: Yo the Editor:

title: Southland Holders Approve Buyout
description: Shareholders of the Southland Corporation approved a $4.9 billion leveraged buyout, putting the nation's largest convenience store chain in private hands. The buyout by the company's founders, the Thompson family, is expected to be closed next Tuesday, said Markeeta McNatt, a Southland spokeswoman.

title: Cannon Merger With Melia Set
description: The Cannon Group Inc. said today that it would merge with Melia International N.V., a hotel and tourist company in Amsterdam that is partly owned by the film maker's European investor.

title: Reagan and Gorbachev Sign Missile Treaty and Vow to Work for Greater Reductions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  With fervent calls for a new era of peaceful understanding, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev today signed the first treaty reducing the size of their nations' nuclear arsenals.

title: For the Cellular User, Ecstasy and Agony . . .
description: IT is 6 P.M. on the tarmac of National Airport in Washington, and a passenger on the Eastern Airlines shuttle realizes that he has neglected to make an urgent phone call.

title: Chefs' Creations, but Not for the Eating
description: A BREAKFAST auction last week at the Four Seasons called ''Great Cooks Salute Thirteen'' gave new meaning to the term culinary artist. Included in the Channel 13 benefit were paintings, drawings, decoupages, photographs, pottery, a multidimensional sculptured collage, sculpture in terra cotta, bronze and clay, and even a diorama of lobsters. It seems that when chefs aren't cooking, they are doing other creative things with their hands.

title: Gasoline Station of 30's: Is It Eyesore or Artifact?
description: This is a village of 700 buildings. One of them, depending on the observer, is either an eyesore, a dilapidated commercial artifact of the 1930's, or an architectural gem, a compact well-preserved example of the modern style.

title: Dr. Sarah Kestenbaum, Professor, 57
description: Dr. Sarah Kestenbaum, a professor of social work at Hebrew University in Jerusalem and a legislative assistant to Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat, died of cancer Saturday at the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem. She was 57 years old and lived in Jerusalem and Washington.

title: Lawyer Argues Blacks Incited Attack in Queens
description: A defense lawyer in the Howard Beach murder trial told the jury yesterday that the encounter between three black men and a group of white teen-agers began when one of the men ''scared'' some of the teen-agers and then the young whites - driven by ''the old macho garbage'' - returned in larger numbers to confront the men.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Japanese for Lunch
description: American cattle producers who have been battling to persuade the Japanese to import more American beef will descend on Capitol Hill next week with 300 pounds of prime beef to be served at a luncheon for Japanese officials.

title: Florida Tax Repeal Studied
description: The State Legislature began action today on the repeal of Florida's 5 percent sales tax on advertising and other services.

title: Bishara Sirhan, Assassin's Father
description: Bishara Sirhan, whose son killed Robert F. Kennedy in 1968, died last week at his home village of Taibe in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.He was in his 80's.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; New York and Drugs
description: Ann Wrobleski, the State Department's narcotics maven, has so nettled members of the New York Congressional delegation by suggesting that the Empire state was lax in dealing with its drug problems that one member of Congress has asked the Administration to publicly repudiate her.

title: HAITIANS CONTINUE STRIKE FOR 2D DAY
description: A protest strike went into a second day today with most of the stores and offices here closed, but with considerably more factory workers at their jobs than Monday.

title: Treasury Issues Show Few Changes
description: Dealers hurriedly marked down prices of Treasury securities late yesterday after a late surge in the stock market, then they marked them back up after underwriters of the four-part, $1.5 billion Southland Corporation offering reported the deal as ''done.''

title: 4 Chevron Officials Died in Air Crash
description: Four executives of the Chevron Corporation were among the 44 people killed Monday in the crash of Pacific Southwest Airlines Flight 1771, the company said today.

title: Raisa Gorbachev's Whirl: Now You See Her, Now You Don't
description: When they heard that Raisa Gorbachev was coming today, the Soviet and American officials abruptly interrupted their technical talks at the National Academy of Sciences to await the Soviet First Lady's arrival.

title: Chief of U.S. Panel On Labor Relations To Quit Next Week
description: Donald L. Dotson , chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, is resigning, and Administration sources say President Reagan is expected to name one of two current members of the board to succeed him.

title: Dow Soars 56.20 More, To 1,868.37
description: Blue-chip stocks staged another sharp rally yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 56.20 points, or 3.1 percent, to close at 1,868.37.

title: Blasius Outlines Plan for Atlas
description: An investment group led by Blasius Industries, a rubber and metal company based in Erie, Pa., has proposed an extensive restructuring of the Atlas Corporation, a gold exploration and development concern based in Princeton, N.J..

title: TV Reviews; 'Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award Show'
description: TELEVISION has given us spinoffs of sitcoms (''All in the Family'' begat ''Maude'' and ''The Jeffersons''), and spinoffs of action-adventures (''Police Story'' begat ''Police Woman''). Now television gives us a spinoff of an awards show. Since 1963, the annual Grammy Awards have included a special category honoring individuals for their outstanding contributions to ''the field of recording.'' That means, among other things, that they sold a lot of records. This year, the recipients are getting their own prime-time special. Taped on Nov. 5, the first ever ''Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award Show'' can be seen on CBS from 9 to 11 this evening.
