description: An Associated Press obituary of E. E. Fogelson last Thursday misstated his role in World War II. An independent oilman and lawyer, Mr. Fogelson was chief of the petroleum planning division on the staff of Gen.

title: Economic Scene; Incompatibility Of Soviet Plans
description: A SOVIET joke of the kind President Reagan likes to collect tells of the May Day parade in Red Square, with the usual array of troops, tanks and missiles. Then along comes a flat-bed truck carrying three men in business suits. ''Who are they?'' an American visitor asks his Soviet guide. The guide explains: ''They are our most powerful weapon. They are the economists. They can destroy an entire nation.''

title: Masters: A Change Of Venue, Anyone?
description: For Ivan Lendl, it was a week in which he solidified his hold on the No. 1 ranking and earned the right to be mentioned with Jimmy Connors, Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe as the best tennis players of the open era. For the Nabisco Masters, itself, however, it was another week of confusion and controversy, raising the question whether the tournament and New York City would benefit from a trial separation.

title: Court Blow To a Plan For Texaco
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge said today that a committee of Texaco Inc. shareholders must approve any settlement proposed by the company's creditors and the Pennzoil Company.

title: Strike-Zone Outlook: Not Entirely Clear
description: In baseball, when is a strike a strike?

title: New York City Prestige Outweighs Lower Costs in Jersey, NBC Chief Says
description: The chief executive of NBC said yesterday that, despite nearly $100 million in tax breaks from the city and state, the television network would have saved tens of millions of dollars a year if it had moved to New Jersey.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''THIS is a Dish Towel Club,'' the copied letter begins. ''Send a dish towel to the person listed as No. 1 below, copy this letter and send it to six of your friends.'' Then the good news: ''You should receive 36 dish towels.''

title: Computer Makers See Strong '88 Sales Rise
description: Despite the stock market plunge and fears of a recession, the nation's personal computer makers are predicting extremely strong sales growth next year, buoyed by demand for a significantly more powerful generation of machines.

title: 'The Risks of Distrust'
description: A recent harangue in this space denouncing three lies put forward by Mikhail Gorbachev in his NBC interview has drawn a revealing response from Georgi Arbatov, the Kremlin's Americanologist.

title: ECONOMY REPORTED HOLDING UP WELL SINCE STOCK SLIDE
description: Defying widespread predictions, the economy has held up well since the stock market collapsed in mid-October and an imminent recession appears quite unlikely, private and Government analysts maintain.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Rockets 106, Kings 97: Akeem Olajuwon scored 26 points and Purvis Short had 25 last night to lead the Rockets at home. Reggie Theus scored 25 points for the Kings, but he was scoreless in the fourth quarter. (AP) Pistons 127, Trail Blazers 117: Isiah Thomas scored 7 points and Rick Mahorn 6 in a key third-quarter run to lead the Pistons at home. The victory ended the Trail Blazers' nine-game winning streak. Detroit's Adrian Dantley, who was scoreless in the third quarter, hit a layup with 11 seconds remaining in the game, making him the 13th N.B.A. player to score 20,000 points. Dantley, in his 12th season, finished with 17 points. (AP) Pacers 103, Bucks 101: Steve Stipanovich scored 24 points, including the decisive free throws with 12 seconds left to lead the Pacers at home. (AP) 76ers 109, Bulls 96: Gerald Henderson, reserve guard, led a fourth-quarter Philadelphia surge with 13 of his 16 points and Charles Barkley added 32 points for the 76ers. Henderson paced Philadelphia to a 90-82 edge with 6:24 remaining on two baskets. Cliff Robinson, who along with Maurice Cheeks had 19 points, added two baskets in the next three minutes as Philadelphia took a 97-90 advantage.(AP) Spurs 105, Jazz 100: Frank Brickowski scored a career-high 27 points, for the Spurs. With Utah leading, 99-98, with 2:02 left, Brickowski hit two free throws to give the Spurs a 100-99 lead. After an offensive foul on Utah's Karl Malone, Alvin Robertson hit a 10-foot jumper, giving the Spurs a 102-99 lead. The victory was San Antonio's sixth consecutive at home, while the Jazz - leading the league in both defense and field goal percentage defense, fell to 1-6 on the road.(AP) N.H.L. Flames 5, Capitals 4: Mike Bullard snapped a 3-3 tie with his second goal of the game as the visiting Flames extended their unbeaten streak to nine games. Carey Wilson added an empty-net goal with 55 seconds left to make it 5-3, offsetting Dave Christian's third goal of the game with 13 seconds to go.(AP) Whalers 5, Nordiques 4: John Anderson's power-play goal with 5:30 to play gave the visiting Whalers the victory. The defeat was the first for Quebec's new coach, Ron Lapointe, who had won his first game after replacing Andre Savard last Friday. (AP)

title: Hoosiers Are Saved by Smart
description: Keith Smart, removed from the starting lineup and relegated to the bench most of the game, scored two key baskets in the final minutes tonight to give Indiana a 63-61 victory over Vanderbilt.

title: KEY RATES
CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Nov. 27 about the adoption system in New York City carried an erroneous description, provided by Surrogate Marie M. Lambert of Manhattan, for the results of a home study of prospective parents, conducted by a legally blind worker. The worker recommended against adoption by prospective parents who were later found to have abused the child they were seeking to adopt.

title: Houston Journal; Breakup of a Team and a Way of Life
description: Juan Chanax nods proudly toward the shiny soccer trophies on display throughout his family's modest apartment: symbols of his life as an immigrant, and now of the passing of a way of life.

title: Opera: Rossini's 'Bianca'
description: Rossini's ''Bianca e Falliero,'' largely forgotten soon after its premiere in 1819, is a score of appreciable beauty and interest. It is one of the many operas to emerge from the laboratory of the annual Rossini Festival in Pesaro, Italy, where it was revived last year, and it reached America for the first time under the auspices of the Greater Miami Opera Monday evening.

title: Air Crash Inquiry Is Said to Focus On Disgruntled Ex-Worker on Jet
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that criminal activity was strongly suspected in the crash of a jetliner that smashed into a cattle ranch here Monday after the pilot reported gunfire in the passenger cabin.

title: To Keep Larry Davis Alive
description: When 27 police officers tried to arrest Larry Davis a year ago in connection with the murder of four drug dealers, the resulting shootout attracted national attention. Subsequently he surrendered and was charged with trying to kill nine police officers. Now that his trial has finally begun, the case risks attracting national attention once more: Mr. Davis complains that he has been continually attacked while in custody.

title: In Moscow, a Rosy New Glow Is Cast Over the Official Portrait of America
description: If the official Soviet caricature of America used to be Rambo, this week it is Mister Rogers.

title: Letters; Judging One Another
description: To The Living Section:

title: Soft Approach to Hard Lessons
description: RAY and Mike, both 15 years old, sat in an imaginary living room, watching a football game and talking about sex. Their girlfriends, Maria and Michelle, were in the kitchen, baking cookies and also talking about sex.

title: U.N. SEEKS INQUIRY INTO MISSING FILES
description: The United Nations ordered an investigation yesterday into a report that some of the war crimes files it has been guarding for nearly 40 years were missing.

title: Nets Are Remedy For Laker Slump
description: Gary Vitti, the Los Angeles Laker trainer, worked on James Worthy's painful left knee for almost 45 minutes in an attempt to get him ready for tonight's game at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Upjohn Swine Vaccine
description: A new bioengineered vaccine against pseudo-rabies, a swine disease, won approval for marketing today from the Agriculture Department, the Upjohn Company said. The Tolvid vaccine, developed by Upjohn, is produced by Diamond Scientific. Pseudo-rabies is a contagious virus that affects about 6.4 million, or 8 percent, of the nation's 80 million hogs.

title: Kuwait Buys More B.P.
description: Kuwait has increased its stake in the British Petroleum Company to 11.5 percent from 10.6 percent, it disclosed today in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Wine Talk
description: Someone broke into a glass case in the Museum of Contemporary History here last week and made off with a menu. Of course this wasn't just any menu, but one that listed the food and wines served at a lunch tendered by the military governor of Paris to Gen. John J. Pershing on June 23, 1917, shortly after he arrived in France to command the American Expeditionary Forces.

title: Advertising; Stolichnaya Vodka Ads On Soviet-U.S. Pact
description: A somewhat older Soviet-American accord is saluting the latest one in full-page ads today in four newspapers.

title: Donors Support Bruce
description: Fifty-seven donors who had pledged a total of $408,030 to an Ohio State University fund-raising drive canceled their promises after the school dismissed Earle Bruce as football coach last month, according to Thomas L. Tobin, the university's vice president for communcations and development. By far, the largest gift was to have come from John McConnell of Worthington Industries in Columbus, who made a corporate pledge of $400,000 to a fund supporting the university's indoor athletic complex. ''It was not the firing of Coach Bruce, it was the way it was done,'' said McConnell in reference to the announcement of the dismissal less than a week before the season's finale against archrival Michigan. McConnell, though, said his company might reconsider the donation ''down the line.''

title: Motorola Has High Post For Founder's Grandson
description: Christopher B. Galvin, the son of Motorola Inc.'s chairman, Robert W. Galvin, was promoted to a high corporate position yesterday. The move puts him a position to eventually run the company founded by his grandfather, Paul V. Galvin, in 1928.

title: INSIDE
description: Sandinistas Down American

title: REAGAN AND GORBACHEV SIGN MISSILE TREATY AND VOW TO WORK FOR GREATER REDUCTIONS
description: With fervent calls for a new era of peaceful understanding, President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev today signed the first treaty reducing the size of their nations' nuclear arsenals.

title: Market Place; Loews Is Moving Off the Sidelines
description: AFTER missing the stock market's move in 1986 and 1987, the Loews Corporation has been moving hundreds of millions of dollars into stocks in recent days. ''Stocks have become interesting, where they were not interesting six months ago or three months ago,'' said Laurence A. Tisch, chairman of the divesified company and one of the most closely followed investors on Wall Street.

title: Hutton Sets Fees
description: E. F. Hutton Group Inc. disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it would pay its financial advisers - Salomon Brothers Inc. and the Blackstone Group -$3.35 million each if the brokerage's $960 million merger with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. was completed.

title: Glaring Inequalities Are El Salvador's Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Studios Shrug Off Stock Fall
description: Unlike the many industries that watched the stock market's plunge with horror, the movie industry is curiously unperturbed by declining stock prices, a falling dollar and the threat of a recession.

title: Ex-Social Worker Is Elected Mayor Of San Francisco
description: Assemblyman Art Agnos, a former social worker, was elected Mayor today, defeating City Supervisor John Molinari.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The St. Louis Cardinals have signed Al Del Greco, a place-kicker, and plan to carry two kickers for the remainder of the season. Del Greco, who was cut two weeks ago by the Green Bay Packers, will share the assignment with Jim Gallery, who has made only 9 of 19 attempts this season. . . . Stefan Edberg, who with his Swedish partner, Anders Jarryd, will begin defending the Masters Doubles title today in London, was threatening to concentrate on singles play next year because of tournament scheduling that he said had doublesw play hampering him.

title: AUSTRALIA GUNMAN KILLS 8 IN RAMPAGE
description: A gunman killed eight people today and wounded several others in a downtown credit cooperative before crashing through an 11th-floor window and falling to his death, the police said.

title: Hextall Shoots, Scores
description: Ron Hextall became the first National Hockey League goaltender to shoot and score a goal as the Philadelphia Flyers downed the Boston Bruins, 5-2, tonight.

title: Real Estate; Office Space Pushes West Across Jersey
description: FOR more than 10 years, developers in New Jersey have pushed steadily westward from New York to offer cheaper alternatives to Manhattan's high-cost office space and to accommodate the growth of Jersey-based companies. So far, however, few have ventured beyond Morris and Somerset Counties.

title: Eating Well
description: IT'S enough to make a person crazy, sorting through all the health information about fats and oils. Do you really have to bid farewell to butter? Is corn oil that much better for your heart than soybean oil? If canola oil has even less saturated fat in it than corn oil, should you toss out the corn oil and go for the canola?

title: Edward Staley Is Dead; Led the W.T. Grant Co.
description: Edward Staley, former chairman of the W. T. Grant Company, died of cardiac arrest Friday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Antismoking Bill Approved By New York Council Panel
description: A New York City Council committee yesterday unanimously approved an antismoking bill that its sponsors say would be the toughest of its kind in the nation.

title: The Treaty: Text of the Agreement to Eliminate Some Missiles
description: Following is the text of the treaty between the United States and the Soviet Union on the elimination of their medium- and shorter-range missiles, which was signed by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the White House today:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE- 10 A.M.

title: German in Red Square Flight Is Denied a Pardon
description: Mathias Rust, the 19-year-old West German serving a four-year sentence here as a result of his border-hopping solo flight to the Kremlin wall, has been denied a pardon, a Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Higher Education, Low Drama
description: It finally dawned on Meg Phillips as she entered the dormitory room and found Jason Mathews, the womanizer who had betrayed her, arguing with Steve Carter, the friend who had spurned her advances. What she had thought a love triangle of Jason, herself and her roommate Page Ryan was - gasp - more. For Steve loved Jason, who had turned into a two-timer of both Meg and Page as a way to allay his fears of his own homosexuality.

title: Advertising; Saatchi & Saatchi
description: The American depository receipts for Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., which had been sold over the counter in the United States, are now going to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol SAA. Each A.D.R. represents three ordinary shares traded on the London Stock Exchange.

title: Surprise: College Demand Is Heavy
description: The admissions office at Rice University in Houston is almost out of applications because demand has been so heavy. Normally, the forms do not run out until January.

title: A Shop That Makes Bread The Old-Fashioned Way
description: LEAD: A CASE can be made that nothing in the New York neighborhood of Little Italy has changed less than the way superb bread is made at the D & G Bakery.

title: Nicaragua Captures American; C.I.A. Link Charged
description: An American pilot was shot down over Nicaragua on Sunday while ''clearly engaged in enemy activity against our country,'' the Nicaraguan Defense Minister said today.

title: The Signing: 'Universal Significance for Mankind'
description: Following is a transcript of remarks by President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the White House yesterday before the signing of the treaty on medium- and shorter-range missiles, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by an official Soviet interpreter. REAGAN. Thank you. Thank you all very much. Welcome to the White House. This ceremony and the treaty we're signing today are both excellent examples of the rewards of patience.

title: A Change of Subject
description: This is not about the summit. It was going to be until The Editor came by.

title: The Credit for Calling McKinley an Eclair
description: To the Editor:

title: Making April 15 Less Painful: Some Tax Steps to Take Now
description: Americans still have three weeks left to take advantage of a variety of tax-saving strategies that will make next April 15 less costly.

title: Topics of The Times; Stifled Speech in Korea
description: Next week, the South Korean Government of Chun Doo Hwan faces the great test of its democratic bona fides: the first direct presidential election in more than 15 years. Last week the results of another test came to light, disappointing those who value free speech.

title: I.B.M. Renaming Unit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is renaming the Rolm Corporation, the maker of telephone switching systems it acquired in 1984. At year-end it will become the Rolm Systems division.

title: The Summit; Reporter's Notebook: Moscow on Madison Ave.
description: As East meets West this week, it is often difficult to discern who is winning the game of political exploitation.

title: Deluxe Decorating: The Beat Goes On
description: BLACK MONDAY and its aftershocks put a sudden stop to some decorating projects, but in spite of the stock-market decline, most clients remain bullish about investing in their homes - bullish but sobered into thinking more carefully about quality and style.

title: BANK OF MONTREAL (CALIFORNIA) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After special provisions for losses on Trans-Border claims of $12 million for the quarter and $765 million for the year. c-Net income The results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange.

title: The Hotel Poll
description: The Hotel Washington, only a block from the White House, is naturally concerned about who will be the new occupant in 1989. So it began exploring the Presidential preferences of its guests last February, distributing a ballot listing 11 possible Republican candidates, 19 Democrats and a space for write-ins.

title: PENNVIEW SAVINGS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $400,000 and $300,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Per share earnings for the prior year are unavailable because the company converted to stock ownership in September.

title: Movie Magazine Joins Campaign by Showtime
description: Premiere - The Movie Magazine, a monthly owned by Rupert Murdoch that made its debut in October, is going to benefit from a promotion being started by Showtime/The Movie Channel.

title: Talking Deals; Texaco-Pennzoil Gamesmanship
description: THE uncertainty over what the Supreme Court will do in the Texaco-Pennzoil battle has generated a level of high-stakes gamesmanship rarely seen in the corporate world. It emerged this week as Texaco tried to satisfy the differing views of its creditors and its shareholders to keep them from siding with Pennzoil.

title: THE TOP GUN WEARS SHOULDER PADS
description: THE finest untrumpeted college football player in the nation did not seem to know how to react to this situation. In the tradition of the United States Air Force, Chad Hennings understands that a considerable amount of time and energy must be spent before a senior at the Air Force Academy can achieve the status of Top Gun. Hennings understands and accepts that the football system at his school, and the military existence he has chosen, both define an individual as less significant than the greater good.

title: Stage: Wilson's 'Piano Lesson'
description: August Wilson has vowed to write one play about each decade of black American life in this century. But this writer, whose fecund career is creating its own patch of history in the American theater of the 1980's, knows history is not a serial, to be ladled out event by event according to the artificial dictates of a textbook time line. History is a dynamic heritage haunting a people to the bone, and it can all pour out, with its full range of pain and triumph and mystery, at any time, anywhere, in any humble voice.

title: Prosecutor in Park Killing to Link Suspect to Possible Marijuana Use
description: The prosecutor in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. intends to argue that Mr. Chambers may have been under the influence of marijuana at the time of Jennifer Levin's death in Central Park, according to court documents obtained yesterday.

title: Baseball Expansion Won't Come Soon
description: The expansion of the big leagues was turned over to a joint committee of the American and National Leagues today. Commissioner Peter Ueberroth made it clear, however, that nothing concrete could be done until baseball had cleared two ''hurdles'' in the next two years: negotiations for new contracts with the players' union and the television networks.

title: AN AIR OF OPTIMISM
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev confronted two of the knottiest problems of their three-day summit conference today - the war in Afghanistan and cutbacks in strategic nuclear weapons -without achieving an immediate breakthrough on either one.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Oh, I think when you look closely you will see I am not exceptional. I think it is an exaggeration. I am just like other people. I am a normal person.'' - Mikhail S. Gorbachev. [ A1:5. ]

title: PIONEER SAVINGS BANK (NORTH CAROLINA)(O) reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Currents; Ever More Antiques at the Armory
description: THE drafty main room of the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue has become one of the hottest spots for antiques shows. ''It's considered the prime place in town because of its location,'' said Sanford Smith, who organizes two of the eight shows held there each year.

title: Currents; Bohemian, Belgravian: Brand New Nightclub
description: RALPH LAUREN would be proud. A look he made popular when he opened his store on Madison Avenue - one that captures the atmosphere of an English country house or a men's club - appears to be a trend that has gone well beyond merchandising.

title: Stray Squirrel Shuts Down Nasdaq System
description: An adventurous squirrel touched off a power failure in Trumbull, Conn., that shut down the National Association of Securities Dealers' automatic quotation service for 82 minutes yesterday.

title: Cordell D. Meeks Sr., Kansas Judge, 73
description: Cordell D. Meeks Sr., the first black district judge in Kansas and the first black in state history to be elected to a countywide office, died Monday. He was 73 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Use of Real Names in Novels Upheld
description: In a ruling that upholds the historical practice of authors using the names of living people in works of fiction, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has denied an attempt by Archbishop Paul Marcinkus, a former head of the Vatican bank, to suppress a novel by A. J. Quinnell in which the Roman Catholic Archbishop figures as a character.

title: Moscow Grain Estimate
description: A Soviet official said today that his country stood by its earlier estimate that 210 million metric tons of grain was produced in 1987. Valeriy Biryukov, head of the raw materials department of the Soviet trade delegation in London, said, ''Though we had bad weather, it was the same size as last year's crop.'' Next year's goal is 235 million tons, he said.

title: New Luster for a Once-Ignored Architect
description: EILEEN GRAY, the first woman to achieve recognition as an architect, was born surrounded by Victorian splendor in County Wexford, Ireland, but made her fame as a modern designer and architect in Paris.

title: GENERAL PARAMETRICS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dr. King's Widow Sues Boston U. for Return of His Documents
description: The widow of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has filed a lawsuit here demanding that Boston University be required to return a collection of the civil rights leader's letters, manuscripts and other papers that has been the crown jewel of the university's vast collection of personal archives.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HITCHCOCK AND SELZNICK. The Rich and Strange Collaboration of Alfred Hitchcock and David O. Selznick in Hollywood. By Leonard J. Leff. Illustrated. 383 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicholson. $22.50

title: Illinois Acts to Preserve Site of Indian Village
description: The state has placed the site of an ancient Indian village and burial ground on its register of historic places, temporarily blocking plans to build a luxury resort there.

title: Opera: Berg's 'Lulu' By the Lyric in Chicago
description: In composing ''Lulu,'' Alban Berg made a fascinating attempt to reconcile chaos and order under one operatic roof, setting a harrowing tale of moral anarchy to a 12-tone score that is rigorously organized down to the smallest staging detail. Most productions of the work, some of them highly acclaimed, have ignored or played down Berg's intricately interlocking scheme of music and stage action. That also is the line pursued with a vengeance and often brilliantly by Yuri Lyubimov's staging for Lyric Opera of Chicago, a production that the emigre Soviet director first mounted in Italy four years ago.

title: AC&R to Withdraw From Public Relations
description: Stephen Rose, chief executive of AC&R/DHB & Bess, a Saatchi & Saatchi company, has eliminated the agency's 15-year-old public relations operation because it has not been growing fast enough.

title: CHRISTMAS SHOPPING IS PICKING UP, STORES SAY
description: After a sluggish start, sales for the Christmas shopping season's first 10 days picked up in many stores, according to telephone interviews with nationwide and local retailers that cater to consumers with a broad spectrum of incomes.

title: Columbia College Trying for Student Diversity
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dance: Maria Benitez Spanish Company
description: THE Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company presented a compelling program on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue. But there was one moment that stood out. It came with a farruca performed by Eduardo Montero. Choreographed by Jose Luis Ayuste to traditional music, the solo gave Mr. Montero, a guest artist with the company, a chance to let loose with steely, lacy fusillades of foot beats of such exquisitely precise timing and dynamic range that one watched breathlessly. And near the end of the solo, Mr. Montero extended his arms to the audience, his face crumpling, just a little like a singer drawing in his listeners triumphantly as he hits a final, exhilaratingly exhausting high note.

title: Frost in the White House for 2 First Ladies
description: Raisa Gorbachev paused for a moment on her tour of the White House today when a reporter asked whether she would like to live in such a place.

title: A Dual Financing By Texas Eastern
description: The Texas Eastern Corporation is offering $200 million of senior unsecured notes with maturities of 5 years and 10 years through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Wohl Dismissed as Coach of Nets
description: The Nets, struggling with injuries, a 2-13 record and a streak in which they have lost nine straight games by an average of 18.7 points, dismissed Dave Wohl as their coach today. Bob MacKinnon, the assistant general manager, was named interim coach.

title: West German Unions Help Close U.S. Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: Audio and Video Gifts for the Holidays
description: DEVICES to create diversions and spectacles through sight and sound have always been among the most cherished gifts of the season. Once it was the music box and the magic lantern. Today it's audio and video equipment. Here are suggestions for holiday giving, ranging from a complete desk-top video system to a simple Walkman for children. They all represent good quality and unusual value in their classes. They are available at electronics shops, special audio and video dealers and some department stores. List prices are given, but discounts may be available.

title: FROM EAST EUROPE, APPLAUSE IS HEAVY
description: East European governments erupted in a chorus of applause today for the Soviet-American arms treaty. They praised it as a victory for Moscow's advocacy of change and willingness to compromise and expressed some hesitant admission of President Reagan's role.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $600,000 for the quarter and $1.5 million for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a pre-tax non-recurring gain of $946,000 from termination of pension plans. c-After a loss of $6,130,000 from discontinued operations and disposal of discontinued operations, and also included a pre-tax non-recurring gain of $10,157,000 from life insurance proceeds and termination of pension plans. Share earnings were adjusted for a 4 percent stock dividend distributed on July 1, 1987, to shareholders of record on June 10, 1987. The results have been corrected from Tuesday, Dec. 8, editions.

title: New Data Reduce Russian Missile Force
description: The Soviet Union has fewer operational medium-range missiles than previous American Government estimates have stated, according to a confidential annex to the new missile treaty.

title: U.S. TO USE ROBOTS TO FIND GULF MINES
description: ABOARD U.S.S. FEARLESS, in the Persian Gulf, Dec. 9 - United States Navy vessels searching for mines in the Persian Gulf will soon be equipped with underwater robots that will vastly enhance their ability to find mines, officials on one of the wooden-hulled minesweepers said today.

title: Maxwell Gives Up Bell & Howell Bid
description: The acquisitive British publisher Robert Maxwell said he was giving up his bid for the Bell & Howell Company, seemingly clearing the way for a rival group to take over the United States information-services concern. The news sent Bell & Howell's share price down $1.75 today on the Big Board, leaving it at $63.75, or just below the $64-a-share bid by the BHW Acquisition Corporation, composed of Robert M. Bass Group Inc. and some top Bell & Howell managers.

title: ROTECH MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cairo Embarrassed by Report on Nasser's Son
description: Reports that Nasser's son has been involved in a clandestine leftist terrorist cell have embarrassed the Egyptian authorities.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary net gains of $1,170,000 for the quarter and $1,424,000 for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary net gains of $513,000 for the quarter and $1,783,000 for the 6 months.

title: Mary E. T. Zabriskie, Retired School Board Head, 90
description: Mary E. T. Zabriskie, a retired president of the board of St. Agnes School in Alexandria, Va., died Sunday at her home in Washington. She was 90 years old.

title: Night of Hatred by Whites Is Depicted at Racial Trial
description: The chief prosecutor in the Howard Beach murder case declared last night that a gang of white teen-agers, yelling racial epithets in a ''night of fists, fear, terror and hatred,'' chased a black man into a ''chasm of death'' during an attack on him and two other black men in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: HAITI SETS A DATE FOR NEW ELECTION
description: Eleven days after the violent disruption of Haiti's first effort at a presidential election in 30 years, the army-dominated provisional Government announced tonight that it was planning another attempt at elections on Jan. 17.

title: Swarms of Tiny Comets May Travel Solar System
description: A host of miniature comets so small that they have eluded detection are probably swarming through the inner solar system and their bombardment over several billion years could account for many of the craters on the Moon, Earth, Mercury and Mars, space scientists reported yesterday.

title: Thompson Is Chosen
description: J. Walter Thompson's Los Angeles office has been tapped by the Standard Brands Paint Company, a West Coast chain of home decorating stores with 150 outlets concentrated in 16 cities. According to trade sources, the billings will be more than $5 million. The previous agency was Admarketing Inc., Los Angeles.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Topics of The Times; Recouping an Education Loss
description: Mayor Koch erred badly in losing control of ethnic politics to the extent that he had to dismiss Richard Beattie from New York City's Board of Education. Mr. Koch had promised to appoint a Hispanic and could not conveniently remove anyone else. Now he has made up some of the loss with the appointment of a superb replacement, Amalia Betanzos.

title: The Summit; From Chinese, Tempered Praise
description: China reacted with tempered praise today to the signing of a Soviet-American treaty to eliminate intermediate-range nuclear missiles.

title: President Is Said to Threaten a Veto of Deficit Bill
description: Senate Republicans said today that President Reagan would veto deficit-reducing legislation unless the Democrats removed provisions unrelated to cutting the deficit.

title: Tax Repeal Is Passed In Florida
description: The Florida Legislature, working in a marathon special session, repealed the state's controversial tax on services early today.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a provision of $692.9 million for Trans-Border losses. c-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Missing U.N. Nazi Files Are Reported Located
description: United Nations officials have located virtually all the war-crimes files reported missing this week, diplomats said yesterday.

title: NORTH CAROLINA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
We Need a Way to Talk to North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Courtesy and Survival
description: To The Home Section:

title: Phnom Penh Journal; Meditation Among the Ashes of a Wondrous Past
description: Every afternoon at Wat Sambuor Meas, a once glorious temple a few miles south of here, a silent drama begins. Nuns deep in prayer and meditation pace ruined porches, passing twisted fences and the rubble of Khmer Buddhist art strewn over grass and garden.

title: Motive Is Discounted at Krishna Arson Trial

title: Q&A
description: Q. The rainwater from the gutters around my house drains into a dry well, but I don't know exactly where this dry well is. For the last couple of years, in every heavy rain, water penetrates the cement-block wall of my playroom, which is five feet below ground. I believe the dry well is clogged and not draining properly. Can it be cleaned out without digging down and opening it? A.It is also possible that the underground pipe connecting the dry well to the downspout is clogged or damaged. The only way to determine this is to uncover the drainpipe. That way you will also find out where the dry well is. To clean out a dry well, you have to dig down and uncover the top of it. In many cases this is impractical, so it is often easier just to dig a new dry well. Q.I am replacing some of the windows in my old house. I want to insulate the hollow spaces around the old frames where the chains and weights now fit, and I am thinking of using expanding foam, since the exterior trim cannot be removed and the interior trim would be difficult to remove. Since the foam comes in small cans, this would make it costly to use for these large spaces. Do you have any other suggestions? A.Even if the inside trim is ornate, I see no reason why it could not be removed. It is usually held on with nails and is fairly easy to pry off, but work carefully to avoid splitting the wood. You might have to do some minor plaster patching after the trim is replaced. With the trim removed it would be simple to fill cavities with fiberglass. But if you choose not to do this, you can use one of the expanding foams, as you suggest. Many marine-supply outlets and large building-supply dealers carry it in larger containers that would be less expensive than the smaller sizes stocked by most hardware stores. Q.We own a split-level house, and under the lower level there is a three-foot-high crawl space with a concrete floor. We would like to know if it is possible, or feasible, to excavate this crawl space to create a full-height basement. A.In most cases it is possible but quite expensive, especially where there is a concrete floor, which would have to be broken up first. You must call in an experienced architect or engineer to determine what must be done and then hire a contractor handle the excavation and to pour a new footing, foundation and floor. Questions about home repair should be addressed to Bernard Gladstone, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Questions of general interest will be answered in this column; unpublished letters cannot be answered individually.

All eyes are on them, and, one article said, hopes are soaring. But a different sort of hope soared at the bottom of the page Tuesday, in a tiny advertisement: ''JRS: The 30 days are over! I love you! Marry me! JDR.'' When Mikhail Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan sit down together, the world can believe that perhaps even relentless tensions can be managed, and the possibility creates its own atmosphere. The event takes on such dimensions that it seems to overshadow all else.

Mecir and Smid, who also trailed, 4-0, in the fourth set, won by 2-6, 7-6, 1-6 7-6, 7-5. Because of the round-robin format, however, the defending champions are not eliminated. In other matches, Americans Ken Flach and Robert Seguso beat Sergio Casal and Emilio Sanchez of Spain, 6-3, 6-3, 6-2; Paul Annacone of the United States and Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa battled for 4 hours 8 minutes before they defeated Australians Laurie Warder and Peter Doohan, 7-6, 7-6, 2-6, 4-6 7-6; and Peter Fleming and Gary Donnelly beat fellow Americans David Pate and Scott Davis, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4. Clever Secret, who made all the pace, was second. The Watcher carried 110 pounds and was ridden by Julio Garcia over a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:43 4/5 to record his sixth victory in sixteen career starts. The Watcher, a 5-year-old son of Buckfinder and Marking Time, earned $33,000 for Evergreen Farms and returned $66.80 for $2 to win. N.H.L. The visiting Flames had not lost since dropping a 6-5 decision to Boston on Nov. 17.(AP) Whalers 5, Capitals 4: Kevin Dineen and Sylvain Turgeon each scored twice to spark the Whalers at home. Dineen's 12th goal of the season snapped a 4-4 tie at 9:07 of the third period as the Whalers posted their third straight victory and their first this season without scoring a power-play goal. Kevin Hatcher had two unassisted goals for the Capitals, who fell to 4-9 in one-goal games.(AP) Blues 4, Red Wings 4: Mark Hunter scored an unassisted goal with 8:43 remaining in regulation to lead the visiting Blues.(AP)

title: Why Nixon Shouldn't Pass Up 'Nixon in China'
description: SITTING the other night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's production of ''Nixon in China,'' I found myself hoping that Richard M. Nixon would overcome whatever reservations he may have and go to see it. Before one had seen the opera, one could understand his doubts. He had every reason to fear that he would be made to look foolish, or that his attendance might become a silly celebrity event, full of reporters and flashbulbs and television cameras.

title: Olympic Coach Backed
description: Joe Vigil, the men's distance-running coach for the United States Olympic team, received a vote of confidence yesterday. He was recently involved in a controversy over racist statements attributed to him in a magazine article. The International Competition Committee of The Athletics Congress, the national governing body for track and field, unanimously approved a motion ''reaffirming his status as Olympic coach.'' In the November issue of City Sports magazine, Vigil was quoted as saying that members of minority groups lack the determination for distance running. Vigil, coach at Adams State for nearly 23 years, has denied making such a statement and presented his case to the competition committee yesterday after a request for an investigation by Anita DeFrantz, a member of the United States Olympic Committee and the International Olympic Committee. After the competition committee agreed to accept Vigil's explanation and give him its support, Vigil agreed to meet with the athletes during this week's Athletics Congress convention to present his views.

title: New Role for Fleming
description: Peter Fleming, the longtime doubles partner of John McEnroe, will soon be taking on a new assignment. Early next year, he will become McEnroe's manager in an attempt to help the volatile left-hander regain the No. 1 position in international men's singles rankings. Speaking in London yesterday at the Masters Doubles championships, Fleming said his aim was to remove ''negative aspects'' of McEnroe's game, which should enable him to challenge Ivan Lendl for the top ranking. ''My major goal is to get him back physically as good as he was three years ago when he was No. 1,'' said Fleming. ''If I can do that, then I think everything else will fall into place.'' Fleming said that although he would concentrate on helping McEnroe regain his fitness, Tony Palafox will continue to serve as McEnroe's coach.

title: Cleveland St. Penalized

The violations included an attempt to recruit Manute Bol, the 7-foot-6-inch center from the Sudan, who now plays for the Washington Bullets. The university is preparing an appeal, according to Robert F. Busbey, the athletic director. Although Bol was not named in the list of sanctions, a university source confirmed that he was among the three principal athletes involved in the investigation. The N.C.A.A. report said that Cleveland State improperly provided financial assistance, transportation and housing to an athlete while he was attending English language proficiency classes at a nearby school. In addition to the two-year ban on postseason play, the N.C.A.A. said Cleveland State could not appear on live television next year and imposed restrictions on recruiting. Cleveland State gained acclaim during the 1986 season, when its unheralded team advanced to the round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: A Reverse on Winter Woes
description: Researchers studying people who become depressed in winter and manic in summer have discovered that the syndrome has a mirror image: some people become depressed every summer and excitable in winter. Those with the newly identified seasonal syndrome report that their depression typically starts in the March-June period and ends in August or September, when the manic phase takes over.

title: Tax Law and Bond Market Head for Collision; Let the Cuts Go On
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Brunt to Handle Caramba Restaurants
description: Caramba, a seven-year-old New York restaurant chain hoping to go national, has retained its first ad agency, Van Brunt & Company.

title: Dick Williams, Theatrical Agent and Editor, 72
description: Dick Williams, a former theatrical press agent and editor, died Sunday in a boating accident in Gulf Breeze, Fla. He was 72 years old. Mr. Williams, who was born in Farmingdale, L.I., served in the Army during World War II and became the editor of Theater Arts magazine in the late 1940's. He spent more than 20 years with Bill Doll Associates, a Broadway public-relations concern, before opening a merchandising firm in Stamford, Conn., in the 1970's.

title: Maryland's Yields Range Up to 6.90%
description: Maryland is offering $80 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. It won the issue in competitive bidding.

title: 4TH GRADERS WATCH AND LEARN AT TRIAL
description: Thirty-seven fourth graders made the 90-minute trip via two subway lines from Public School 304 in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to State Supreme Court in Kew Gardens, Queens, for the Howard Beach trial.

title: US HEALTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LIBRARY BUREAU reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Accountant Is Chosen As President of Pennzoil
description: Randal B. McDonald, a top executive of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of the Pennzoil Company, the first executive post he has held in an energy company.

title: GENETIC LABRATORIES INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Atelier International Has New Owner
description: Atelier International, a 20-year-old company in Long Island City, Queens, known for its modern furniture and lighting designs, has been sold to Steelcase, an office-furniture company in Grand Rapids, Mich., it was announced Tuesday.

title: F.A.A. Absolves a Controller In Jet Crash at Indianapolis
description: No action is expected against the air traffic controller who did not respond when the pilot of a powerless Air Force jet warned that he might have to crash and asked if he was near a populated area, a Federal official said today.

title: Seabrook Utility Told To Pay by Jersey Bank
description: A New Jersey bank demanded yesterday that the Public Service Company of New Hampshire immediately repay a $425 million debenture issue that is due in 2004, because the utility had defaulted on a $37 million interest payment that was due Oct. 15. The effect on the company, which is already on the brink of bankruptcy, is not clear.

title: HADCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,470,000. c-Net loss and is after a loss of $7,512,000 from discontinued operations. The latest year includes a gain of $554,000 from the recovery of an account receivable previously written off.

title: ECOLOGY & ENVIRONMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LAROUCHE TAKEN IN BY AIDE, TRIAL TOLD
description: A neo-Nazi hired for security by Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr., the political extremist who frequently runs for President, bilked and ridiculed Mr. LaRouche and his associates, according to testimony and statements in the man's trial for conspiracy to obstruct justice.

title: Dr. Wilfred Bloomberg, Neuropsychiatrist, Dies
description: Dr. Wilfred Bloomberg, a neuropsychiatrist who was Commissioner of Mental Health in Connecticut from 1958 to 1969, died Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Ratings of Salomon's Debt Reduced a Notch by S.&P.
description: The short-term and long-term debt ratings of Salomon Brothers Inc. were reduced a notch yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Yields Show Increases
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts rose modestly in the week that ended yesterday.

title: Wider G.M. Rebate
description: The General Motors Corporation added several lines of Chevrolet pickups to its rebate program. Buyers of 1987 and 1988 models of the S-10 and of the 1988 full-size C/K and S-10 Blazer will receive $500, which may be applied to the down payment.

title: Worry Grows That Korean Army Might Intervene in the Elections
description: Serious concern has been raised here that South Korea's military might step in to cancel next week's presidential election or to nullify its results if the opposition wins.

title: 26th St. Brewer Cites High Costs And Shuts Plant
description: The Old New York Brewing Company, which had sought to revive the lost tradition of local beermaking, has ceased operating the Manhattan brewery that produced its New Amsterdam beer. The company said the cost of doing business in the city had become prohibitive.

title: MOUNTAINEER BANKSHARES OF WEST VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $643,000 and $964,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the acquisition of several banking concerns accounted for as pooling of interest.

title: Nuclear Plant Closes 6th Time in 6 Months
description: The Hope Creek nuclear power plant was shut down automatically Tuesday, its sixth closing in the last six months, a spokesman for the plant said.

title: Semiconductor Index Is Up
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator remained positive for the 12th month in a row in November, as both orders and shipments again increased for chip manufacturers in the United States, Europe and Japan, a trade group reported today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Chrysler Recalls 14,000 Cars
description: The Chrysler Corporation said Tuesday that it was recalling 14,000 1988 Chrysler Fifth Avenue, Plymouth Gran Fury and Dodge Diplomat models because of a wiring defect that could cause an engine fire. A fire occurred in a car at the assembly plant, but no fires have been reported by motorists, the company said.

title: Nuggets End Celtics' Streak
description: Michael Adams scored a career-high 31 points as the Denver Nuggets scored a stunning 124-119 victory last night to end the Celtics' string of 34 consecutive regular-season victories at Boston Garden.

title: Live! From New York . . .
description: It was a startling prospect: Could the National Broadcasting Company really move to New Jersey? ''Live! From Secaucus . . .'' went the incredulous parody of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live'' introduction. Or was it all a bluff, to squeeze tax breaks out of New York City?

title: Redmen Top Rams In 2 Overtimes, 76-71
description: Fordham, at a great height and weight disadvantage, nearly beat St. John's last night for the first time in 17 years. But the Rams fell short in double overtime, 76-71, at their Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
L.I. Employers Join to Build New Housing
description: More than two dozen Long Island employers today announced a partnership to build middle-income housing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, saying the Island's economic growth was threatened by a lack of affordable housing.

title: Tax Law and Bond Market Head for Collision
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A physician confessed that at first he hated his colicky newborn daughter, whose ''continuous high-pitched shriek'' made him want to shake her until she stopped. ''God, I thought, how can such a small helpless infant, my own beloved flesh, evoke such nearly uncontrollable hostility in me, her daddy, a physician?'' he asked in a recent column in The New York Times Magazine.

title: Maxwell Gives Up Bell & Howell Bid
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell said he was giving up his bid for the Bell & Howell Company, seemingly clearing the way for a rival group to take over the United States information-services concern. The news sent Bell & Howell's share price down $1.75 today on the Big Board, leaving it at $63.75, or just below the $64-a-share bid by the BHW Acquisition Corporation, composed of Robert M. Bass Group Inc. and some top Bell & Howell managers.

title: EMERGENCY REPAIR UNIT FAULTED
description: The chairman of the New York State Senate Investigations Committee charged yesterday that the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development had ineptly handled the thousands of emergency repair calls placed to its complaint number each year.

title: D.M.B.&B. Picks Up Bahamas Tourism Job
description: ''With a long cold winter just around the corner, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has just picked up the perfect new client: the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism. The assignment is for worldwide advertising and the budget is around $13 million.

title: Home Improvement
description: DRIPPING or leaking faucets are among the most exasperating household annoyances. Not only is the dripping sound a nuisance, but the amount of water that flows uselessly (and expensively) down the drain can be appalling. In porcelain sinks, basins and bathtubs, constant contact with water also causes stains.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1987
description: International

title: Brooks Fashion In Chapter 11
description: Brooks Fashion Stores Inc., one of the nation's largest apparel-shop chains, and four of its affiliates have filed for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, seeking to reorganize to pay debts.

title: Meldrum & Fewsmith Chosen by Mr. Coffee
description: Mr. Coffee came under new management in July as a result of a leveraged buyout and then decided to get an ad agency to replace its in-house facility.

title: Winfield-Gibson: Trade Talks End
description: The Yankees, seeking a productive left-handed-hitting outfielder, talked to the Detroit Tigers about a Dave Winfield-for-Kirk Gibson trade, but the Tigers terminated the talks today.

title: The Summit; In Moscow, Heartfelt Joy for Treaty
description: The artificial unanimity that often makes public debate here an exercise in aggressive agreement turned into the real thing today, as dissidents and generals, skeptics and Communist believers greeted the first nuclear arms reduction treaty with muted but palpable joy.

title: CENTRAL JERSEY SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split approved in July 1987.

title: Stock Rally Extended To 3d Day
description: Stock prices surged higher for the third straight day, but many on Wall Street still fear the rally will be short-lived.

title: Hers
description: IN these latter days the shop talk of university professors tends to anecdotes about our laughable undergraduates. My contribution includes the story of a student from an Eastern liberal arts college whom, for cause, I advised against taking my course in creative writing. The student complained that there was nothing else that satisfied her time slot and humanities requirement except a course in 17th-century poetry, and how, she asked, did she know she was going to like it?

title: Michigan Prisoners Allowed 10 Postage Stamps a Month
description: Each prisoner in the Michigan correctional system is entitled to 10 first-class postage stamps a month, the State Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: The Summit; Questions Rise in Soviet On Dissent and the Press
description: While Mikhail S. Gorbachev pitches glasnost to America, the battle over how to practice his policy of ''openness'' has flared up anew at home.

title: Political Lot of Reagan And Gorbachev Linked
description: Two days of summit talks have demonstrated how closely President Reagan has tied his political fortunes to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the leader of the nation that Mr. Reagan has spent his entire career denouncing, according to political experts inside and outside the White House.

title: 2 in Navy Killed as U.S. Research Plane Crashes in Antarctica
description: A United States polar exploration airplane crashed and burned in Antarctica yesterday, killing two Navy crew members and injuring nine others.

title: 11 Finalists Are Named For Playwrights Prize
description: Eleven finalists have been named for the 10th Susan Smith Blackburn Prize, an award given annually to an English-speaking playwright who is a woman.

title: Kemp Aide Seeks to Clarify Candidate Stand on Pardons
description: A spokesman for Representative Jack F. Kemp has tried to clarify the Republican Presidential candidate's stance on pardoning Lieut. Col. Oliver North and Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter should they be indicted for their roles in the Iran-Contra affair.

title: CENTRAL CO-OP BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $167,000 from the sale of a bank office. c-Includes a gain of $164,000 from the sale of fixed-rate mortgages to the secondary market. Year-ago per share earnings are not shown because the bank converted to stock ownership in October 1986.

title: HIGHLAND SUPERSTORES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a gain of $5,685,000 from an accounting change.

title: Article 036887 -- No Title
description: A brokerage executive who killed his family and then committed suicide has left more than half of his estate to his mother, the Academy Award-winning actress Mercedes McCambridge.

title: Accounts
description: * US magazine to Altschiller Reitzfeld.

title: Emotional Preparation Aids Surgical Recovery
description: The trauma of surgery, part biological and part psychological, can be greatly eased by psychologically preparing patients for surgery, studies are finding. The techniques are proving to aid physical recovery and lessen the pain and anxiety that surgery brings.

title: Nixon Saves Widow From Being Evicted
description: A 93-year-old blind widow who knew Richard M. Nixon when he was a boy learned today that she would not have to move out of her home to make way for a Nixon library after all, thanks to the former President.

title: BOSTON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes after-tax gains from securities sales of $135,000 and $3,427,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; year-ago quarter and year includes after-tax gains of $1,585,000 and $3,073,000, respectively. c-Includes a gain of $1,675,000 for both the quarter and year from the deposit insurance fund of Massachusetts. Per share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 31.

title: HOLTZMAN LOSES PURSE TO A THIEF IN TIMES SQUARE
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn was the victim of a purse snatcher yesterday evening when she paused to make a telephone call at a Times Square phone booth, authorities said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: LEAD: Stephen M. Wolf, credited by analysts with turning around Tiger International Inc., yesterday was named chairman, president and chief executive of the Allegis Corporation and its United Airlines subsidiary.

title: Paramount Names New Head of Production
description: Paramount Pictures yesterday named Gary Lucchesi as head of its motion picture production division.

title: Is Vermont Third World?
description: LEAD: If Vermont were a small third world country, news that its leaders were willing to sacrifice a valuable natural resource to reap the benefits of capital investment by a large Japanese bank would cause hardly a ripple of protest.

title: Pan Am And Braniff Set Deal
description: The Pan Am Corporation announced last night that it had reached a tentative deal with Braniff Inc. that could result in the merger of Pan American World Airways and Braniff if certain conditions are met.

title: The Wall Street Scream
description: When Wall Street raises its voice, the Treasury Department listens.

title: DEERE & COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the latest fourth quarter income was favorably affected by $39.9 million of income tax benefits resulting mainly from tax loss carryforwards. The fourth quarter last year was affected by a strike. Sales represent worldwide sales.

title: CARENA BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: INTERNATIONAL ROBOMATION/ INTELLIGENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Mixed Reviews for Upper East Side Rezoning
description: A proposal to rezone long stretches of upper Fifth and Park Avenues was praised yesterday as a way of creating low-income housing and condemned as the opening step in the gentrification of East Harlem.

title: VARITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that because of losses at 45 percent-owned Massey Combines Corp., it wrote down its investment in the Brantford, Ont., facility by $17 million during the 9 months, leaving a balance of $15 million. Figures are in U.S. funds.

title: Congress Told of Telephone Frauds
description: Several people who lost hundreds of dollars each in telemarketing scams have told Congress that the public needs more protection against disreputable companies.

title: German Film Series
description: Ten films will be shown during the annual Recent Films From West Germany series, beginning today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street. Four films will be shown today, beginning at 12:30 P.M.: ''The Journey'' by Markus Imhoof, ''Silence of the Poet'' by Peter Lilienthal, ''The Chinese Are Coming'' by Manfred Stelzer and ''Joe Polowsky - An American Dreamer'' by Wolfgang Pfeiffer. The series runs through Dec. 17. Screenings are included in museum admission, which is $5 ($3.50 for students and $2 for the elderly). Information: 708-9400.

title: Hers; Carved Parrots And Other Necessities
description: RONALDO MAIA, the floral designer, is exploring new territory in Manhattan. In addition to his flower shop at 27 East 67th Street, he recently opened Casa Maia at 1143 Park Avenue (91st Street), where he sells objects for the home.

title: 2 Bettors Won $105,000 In Suspicious Race
description: New York State racing investigators say that two bettors made more than $105,000 through nearly 50 wagers on a suspicious harness race on Nov. 14 at Yonkers Raceway.

title: 'Court' Buys Case for Chicken Soup
description: A mock court gave a shot in the arm to Jewish mothers everywhere today by ruling that chicken soup deserves its reputation as ''Jewish penicillin.''

title: Advertising; Transition For Levine And Schmidt
description: HAROLD LEVINE and Robert H. Schmidt, the disparate pair that have been running Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver since it began with $1.5 million in billings in 1972, have now completed a sort-of second-generation management transition.

title: Experts Err On Carracci
description: A painting valued by auctioneers at Sotheby's at just $720 has sold for more than 2,000 times that amount at the rival Phillips auction house here.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
N.H.L. Notebook; Flyer Goalie's Goal: 'A Matter of When'
description: That Ron Hextall became the first goaltender in the National Hockey League to score a goal by shooting the puck in to the opponent's net came as no surprise to the flamboyant and outspoken Flyer.

title: Nobel Laureate Urges U.S. to End Contra Aid
description: On the eve of accepting the Nobel Peace Prize, President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica today urged the American Congress to resist President Reagan and deny all further funds, even non-military aid, to the contra rebels of Nicaragua.

title: Official Reverses Stand on Davis
description: The New York City Correction Commissioner, reversing himself, yesterday withdrew his opposition to the transfer of Larry Davis from a city detention center to a Federal prison.

title: Stage: ''Mlle. Colombe,'' Musical of Anouilh Play
description: HAROLD CLURMAN, who directed Jean Anouilh's ''Mlle. Colombe'' in its original 1954 Broadway production, regarded the play as ''a tragic harlequinade,'' in which the world of the theater is filled with dreams and possibilities and real life is stultifying. The first is represented by the title character, a repressed young woman who blossoms as an actress on stage, the second by her rigid husband, Julien. They are intertwined in a Columbine-Pierrot romance.

title: 12-Meter Supporters
description: A group of 12-Meter owners has urged both sides racing for the America's Cup next summer to reinstate the 12-Meter as the official class in a multinational cup series in 1991. At a meeting of the International 12-Meter Association yesterday at the New York Hilton, 28 of the 29 members approved the idea. A representative of Michael Fay of New Zealand abstained. The San Diego Yacht Club, as guardian of the America's Cup, had planned on a 12-Meter series that year. But a court order last month forced the club to accept a challenge from Fay's Mercury Bay Boating Club next summer in boats much larger than the 12-Meters, which are about 65 feet long.

title: Warrant Against Rock Singer
description: An arrest warrant was issued today for the rock singer Sly Stone after he failed to appear in court to answer charges he had not paid $2,500 in child support to his former wife and 14-year-old son. The 43-year-old singer was free on $10,000 bail after being arrested on the charges last month at a theater, where he was to have given a concert.

title: Brooklyn Rapist Gets Long Term
description: A 22-year-old Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to prison terms totaling 201 to 603 years for robbing, raping and sodomizing women he stalked from a BMT station in the Flatbush area of Brooklyn.

title: Now, Reassure Our Allies on the Treaty
description: LEAD: The treaty reducing nuclear arsenals, which President Reagan and General Secretary Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed, will have only a modest impact on superpower relations. But it will profoundly affect the Western alliance. Whether eliminating intermediate-range nuclear forces helps or hurts the alliance will depend on what the United

title: SOVIET VISITOR MIXES CHARM WITH VENOM
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is borrowing one of President Reagan's own political tricks and taking his case directly to the American people. In the effort, Mr. Gorbachev sometimes assumes a conciliatory stance, but at other times he is combative.

title: Calendar: Jewelry, Wreaths And Tours
description: Holiday Bazaar

title: GROUNDWATER TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Nobel Laureate's Work Is Published in Soviet
description: Six poems by Joseph Brodsky, the 1987 recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature, who was once sent to a Soviet labor camp because of his writing, appeared in the December issue of the Soviet monthly Novy Mir.

title: A New View of Frames
description: ''WHEN I first started, people were throwing them out. No one throws them out now.'' Eli Wilner was talking about the antique frames that he sells from his shop, Eli Wilner & Company, on the second floor of a small 19th-century building at 1525 York Avenue, near 80th Street.

title: BATTERED JETS TAKE BRIEF REST
description: With the Jets and the Patriots both reeling from costly losses, the rival coaches took opposite tacks today in preparing their battered squads for a showdown Sunday in New England that could prove to be the last stand of the season for either team.

title: Hospital Suit Expected Over Warhol Death
description: The estate of Andy Warhol is expected to sue New York Hospital soon over the death of the 58-year-old Pop artist at the hospital last February.

title: Mets and Dodgers Go Back and Forth
description: The Mets' prize project in the trading market collapsed today when the Los Angeles Dodgers refused to send Bob Welch to New York for Mookie Wilson, Jesse Orosco and Rafael Santana.

title: Air Force Tests New Missile
description: The Air Force announced today that it successfully tested a new missile launched from an aircraft against a target drone plane two weeks ago. The Air Force issued a statement saying the test was conducted on Nov. 22.

title: Air-India to Add Planes
description: Air-India will spend 15 billion rupees, or about $1.15 billion, in the next three years to buy new planes and expand its routes, the state-run carrier's managing director, Rajan Jetley, said today. At a news conference, he said two Boeing 747's and two Airbus 310's would be added by early 1988.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday incorrectly characterized remarks made by Robert Galvin, chairman of Motorola Inc.

title: The Summit; West Germans Greet Arms Treaty With Relief and Anxiety for the Future
description: After all the grief over first bringing American medium-range missiles into Europe - and then over removing them - Germans greeted the disarmament treaty today with a mix of relief and anxiety over what comes next.

title: The Dole Snare
description: Aides to Senator Bob Dole have written a letter to Vice President Bush, his leading rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, saying, in effect, ''Gotcha!''

title: JUDGE PUTS LIMIT ON DEAVER DEFENSE
description: Michael K. Deaver's defense lawyers were told today that they could not argue before the jury that the former Presidential aide's memory was impaired by alcoholism when he was questioned about his lobbying business.

title: A Timeout In Chess
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, took his final timeout today, postponing the 22d game of his title match with Anatoly Karpov until Friday.

title: PRECISION TARGET reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income and includes an extraordinary gain of $91,000 and $93,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Tougher Rules Sought On Disposal of PCB's
description: House members asserted today that the Reagan Administration had failed to keep a three-year-old pledge to tighten control over the handling and disposing of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's.

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Results of operations in 1986 included a fourth quarter charge of $14.5 million relating to the curtailment of the company's Ion Implantation division.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $114.1 million for the quarter and $94.7 million for the year, and includes an extraordinary tax credit of $7.2 million for the both periods. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $33.5 million for the quarter and $41.8 million for the year. The year-ago periods' figures are restated to reclassify all of the metals segment from continuing operations to discontinued operations, except for the lead operations previously included in the metals segment, which remain in continuing operations as a separate segment.

title: Washington State Dismantles Mural
description: A giant abstract mural that has been praised by art critics but panned by legislators has been removed from the State Senate chambers.

title: DIGITAL TRANSMISSION reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bond Prices Post Slight Advance
description: Bond prices rose modestly in light trading yesterday, as investors and traders continued to wait on the sidelines until there are enough economic data to clarify the welter of year-end economic forecasts now being published.

title: Darkness as Drama
description: To The Home Section:

title: Devils Edge Kings
description: Although they are last in the National Hockey League point standings, the Los Angeles Kings have a high-powered offense. But the Devils thwarted that offense tonight for a 2-1 victory at Byrne Meadowlands Arena that spoiled Robbie Ftorek's coaching debut.

title: Music: Temirkanov and Philadelphians
description: YURI TEMIRKANOV is a noted conductor in the Soviet Union, and the first to appear with the New York Philharmonic after the melting of the long cultural freeze between his country and the United States. So it was symbolically fitting for him to reappear here during a summit meeting, as he did Tuesday night with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.

title: Parental Cooperation
description: To The Home Section:

Gorbachev. Page A1 Mr. Gorbachev is taking his case directly to the American people, sometimes assuming a conciliatory stance, while at other times the Soviet leader is combative. title: From Astor to Minnelli, Greetings to the Rainbow Room
description: Near the top of the RCA Building, the celebrities of business, politics, academia, communications and entertainment, along with a good chunk of the upper crust of society, gathered last night for a party marking the restoration and reopening of the Rainbow Room.

title: 42 Believed Dead in Peru Crash; Star Soccer Team Among Victims
description: A navy plane carrying Peru's top soccer team crashed into the ocean off a Lima beach Tuesday night, and only one of the 43 people aboard was known to have survived, the navy said today.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $10 million for the quarter and $22 million for the year; the year also includes a gain of $20 million from discontinued operations and a restructuring charge equal to 26 cents a share, the effect of which was offset by the recognition of extraordinary tax credits related to the restructuring provision made a year ago that could not be fully tax affected. c-Net loss d-After gains of $4 million for the quarter and $16 million for the year, both from discontinued operations; the year also includes a gain of $66 million from a change in pension reversion accounting and a restructuring charge equal to $1.65 a share. The company said after-tax foreign currency gains for the latest periods were $11 million for the quarter and $23 million for the year, compared with year-ago periods of a break-even position for the quarter and losses of $4 million for the year.

title: Speaking for, and Speaking to, the Russians
description: WHO speaks for the Soviet Union? On television, Mikhail S. Gorbachev gets help. The other night, John Chancellor wondered about the Soviet leader's ''blow dried, horn rimmed and well dressed'' surrogates. The NBC commentator was not alarmed, but he did seem skeptical. The surrogates have been on television all week. If you do not recognize, say, Gennadi I. Gerasimov by now, most likely you have not been watching.

description: Eurotunnel shares sank 29 percent today, the first day they were traded, underscoring the risky nature of investing in the Anglo-French consortium that is building a rail tunnel under the English Channel.

title: Denial by Hoyt
description: LaMarr Hoyt, the American League Cy Young Award winner in 1983 when he pitched for the Chicago White Sox, yesterday denied an allegation in United States District Court in San Diego that he had violated terms of Federal probation by testing positive for cocaine use. Judge Roger Curtis McKee scheduled a Jan. 15 hearing on the charge.

description: The Soviet Union apologized today for the intrusion of a Soviet TU-16 Badger bomber into Japanese airspace over the island of Okinawa, saying the incident was unpremeditated and was caused by poor weather.

title: Mikhail and Ronald Twinned
description: Galina and Vyacheslav Sakharov have named their newborn twin sons Mikhail and Ronald, in honor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan. The Communist youth daily Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today that the Sakharovs had decided on the names after the boys were born on Tuesday. The family, which lives in Moscow, is no relation to Andrei D. Sakharov, the Nobel Peace Prize winner and human rights campaigner.

title: FILM: 'THROW MOMMA'
description: THE film with the best title around (well, it certainly gets your attention) and the year's funniest trailer (a single, extended breakfast-table scene, culminating in Danny DeVito's swatting Billy Crystal with a frying pan) may also be the comedy of the season, at least thus far. It's ''Throw Momma From the Train,'' Danny DeVito's highly unorthodox variation on Hitchcock's ''Strangers on a Train,'' which Mr. DeVito has had the good grace to credit directly. Not every remake-meister bothers to do this, after all. And there are other signs of an underlying decency that helps make the film enormously likable without compromising its mean-spirited fun.

title: Lead Found in Water From Many Electric Coolers
description: Many electric fountains for drinking water in schools and other buildings are exposing people to unhealthy levels of lead, a House panel was told today.

title: Miss Seasonwein Wed To Richard E. Gutman
description: Rosann Seasonwein, the daughter of Helen Seasonwein of Brooklyn and the late Simon Siegel Seasonwein, was married yesterday to Richard Edward Gutman, the son of Samuel Gutman Jr. of Hamden, Conn., and the late Marjorie Gutman. title: French Whines

All were accused of harming French interests by plotting against the Khomeini regime. Oh no, says Paris, this isn't appeasement and has nothing to do with other efforts to placate Iran and gain the release of two French hostages held in Lebanon. Who could possibly think otherwise?

title: Art: 'Master Drawings Of Otto Wagner'
description: OTTO WAGNER (1841-1918) was one of the most remarkable and peculiar men of his time in Vienna. Others -Gustav Klimt, Oskar Kokoschka, Egon Schiele, Josef Hoffmann, Adolf Loos and Karl Kraus, not to mention Gustav Mahler - have lately been more in the news. But it emerges from the loan show of drawings by Otto Wagner at the Drawing Center that with pencil, ink or watercolor he was a very seductive performer.
