title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The U.S. trade deficit jumped to a record $17.6 billion in October as Christmas goods and other imports rose more than five times as much as exports. The result was far worse than analysts had expected and caused turmoil in the financial markets. The dollar fell to record lows against the yen and the mark, bond prices rose steeply and stocks fell. Imports of cars and oil contributed to the growing deficit. Many economists said they were more concerned about the slow rise of U.S. exports than by the increase in imports. The trade figures prompted fresh appeals by Democrats and organized labor for passage early in the new year of the trade bill pending in a Senate-House conference committee. The Reagan Administration acknowledged a setback but insisted that the figures were not as grim as they appeared. [ Page A1. ] Florida's Legislature repealed the tax on advertising and professional services, and Governor Martinez said he would sign the bill today. Many corporations and advertising agencies that had led the fight against the tax said the repeal would discourage other states from following Florida's attempt to tax services. The Legislature also raised the general sales tax to 6 percent, from 5 percent, to maintain revenues at current levels. [ A1. ] The Senate gave final approval to a deficit reduction package that includes $9 billion in tax increases. The package would put into effect a major portion of the budget compromise reached by Congressional and Administration negotiators last month. [ A27. ] Three men were convicted of tax fraud in what Federal officials said was the largest tax fraud case ever filed. They included Charles A. Atkins, sometimes known as ''the boy wonder of tax shelters.'' A Federal District Court jury in Manhattan found Mr. Atkins guilty of 28 counts of conspiracy and fraud. [ D1. ] A Federal land bank declared itself insolvent, the first ever to do so. The $2.4 billion Federal Land Bank of Jackson, Miss., said it had frozen deposits of borrowing farmers. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL The Federal Reserve and 11 foreign central banks reached a preliminary accord to increase the required capital base of banks. The accord is part of a two-year effort by the Fed and other American regulators to force higher capital cushions on banks that are taking greater risks in lending. It also reflects the global trend of closer coordination of regulatory policies. [ A1. ] OPEC suspended deliberations to allow mediation of the sharply divergent views of Iran and Iraq on production policies. But prospects of reconciliation appeared dim. [ D1. ] Mikhail S. Gorbachev asked American business for help in improving the economic relationship between the U.S. and the Soviet Union, now that political tensions have eased. [ A22. ] MARKETS The dollar plummeted to its lowest levels since the 1940's amid heavy trading as dealers sold the currency in the wake of the unexpectedly bad report on the nation's trade deficit. Gold rose to its highest level in nearly five years, reaching $492.30 an ounce, up $7.80, on the New York Commodity Exchange. [ D1. ] Stock prices closed sharply lower after a seesaw session that reflected the bad news on the trade front. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 47.08 points, or 2.47 percent, to 1,855.44. In the three previous sessions, it had climbed 135.78 points. [ D1. ] Bond prices were battered, with the losses most pronounced among the longer-term Treasury maturities. [ D13. ] COMPANIES British Airways raised its bid for British Caledonian to more than $360 million in its fierce battle with S.A.S., which has offered $200 million for 26 percent of British Caledonian. [ D4. ] Revlon's chairman wants more of TW Services, the successor to Trans World, and is seeking U.S. clearance. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS There are various ways to shrink the nation's trade deficit, and all involve pain for the American consumer. But there may be some choice in concocting a recipe for the necessary ''bitter medicine,'' a leading economist says. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] There is little cheer among stockholders of toy companies as Christmas approaches - and for good reason. Share prices have plunged far below levels of a year ago. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Jacobs May Seek Outboard Marine
description: The price of shares of the Outboard Marine Corporation, the world's leading maker of outboard motors, rose sharply today on the possibility of a takeover bid by the stock speculator Irwin L. Jacobs, who already controls the boat builder Genmar Industries. The stock closed up $2.875, at $23.125. Minstar Inc., a company controlled by Mr. Jacobs, notified Outboard Marine on Wednesday that it had sought regulatory approval to buy up to 49.9 percent of the company. A merger of Genmar, which builds a wide range of recreational boats, and Outboard Marine could create a formidable rival for the Brunswick Corporation, the boating industry leader, analysts said. ''It would close the gap between the companies,'' said Harold Vogel, an analyst at Merrill Lynch.

title: Trade Surplus Of Japan Falls
description: Japan's trade surplus shrank in November for the seventh month in a row, falling 36 percent from a year earlier as the stronger yen continued to affect the country's imports and exports, the Government said today. The surplus, not adjusted for seasonal factors, totaled $4.74 billion, down from $7.4 billion in November 1986.

title: Reviews on Cuban Aliens Shifted to Justice Dept.
description: The decisions on whether to send Cuban detainees back to Cuba will be taken away from the immigration authorities and entrusted to a special panel of the Justice Department, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: 8 Nobel Laureates Receive Prizes
description: King Carl XVI Gustaf handed the Nobel Prize in Literature today to the poet Joseph Brodsky and gave seven other laureates their awards for economics, physics, medicine and chemistry.

title: Mayor Reportedly Set to Appoint New Investigation Commissioner
description: Mayor Koch has chosen the city's Criminal Justice Coordinator, Kevin Frawley, to be Commissioner of Investigation, the chief mayoral watchdog over corruption and other abuses by city employees, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Drop in New Housing
description: The Commerce Department said today that completions of new homes fell 2.4 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1,536,000 from 1,574,000 in September.

title: Wooing the South
description: Determined to re-establish their Southern credentials for 1988, the Democrats have already chosen Atlanta as the site of their national convention next July and are now seeking a prominent Southerner as the keynote speaker. Paul G. Kirk Jr., the Democratic national chairman, is said to have approached Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas.

title: College Basketball; Freshman Leads Temple by St. Joseph's
description: Mark Macon scored 22 points and helped spark a 12-0 first-half surge as Temple defeated St. Joseph's, 83-62, tonight in an Atlantic 10 Conference game. Howard Evans added 18 points for the Owls.

title: At the Bar
description: It was one of the indelible moments of the 1950's, witnessed by millions watching the Army-McCarthy hearings. On June 9, 1954, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy revealed that a protege of Joseph N. Welch, the Army counsel -a young lawyer, Fred Fisher - once belonged to what the Senator called ''the legal bulwark of the Communist Party.''

title: TURNING MIGHTY ARMS INTO MUSTY ARTIFACTS
description: The Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces provides for eliminating missiles by smashing, exploding, crushing, burning, launching and static display.

title: Pop: Oliver DeCoque of West Africa
description: OLIVER DeCOQUE is a star in West Africa, where he has made several dozen popular albums in a modernized version of the Nigerian high-life style. But while King Sunny Ade, Fela Anikulapo Kuti and a few other Nigerian pop musicians have attracted followings in America, Mr. DeCoque remains little known here. His present American tour, which included a stop last night at S.O.B.'s, could help rectify this situation.

title: SENATE APPROVES PACKAGE ON DEFICIT
description: The Senate early this morning approved a $26 billion deficit-reducing package, including $9 billion in tax increases, that is needed to carry out a major part of the budget compromise reached between Congress and the White House last month.

title: I.B.M. Out of Intel
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had sold its remaining 3.1 million shares of the Intel Corporation, which it had bought as part of an investment in the chip maker five years ago. I.B.M. did not disclose the price it received, although it was thought to have been about $75 million. In the privately arranged transaction, Salomon Brothers Inc. bought the stock from I.B.M. and resold it to institutions. Intel stock closed today at $24, down $1.50, in over-the-counter trading. I.B.M. has gradually disposed of its holdings in Intel, which peaked at 22 million shares.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in The Living Section on Wednesday about a New York bakery in Little Italy misidentified it.

title: KEY RATES
Many Contribute to Neediest As an Old Holiday Tradition
description: Giving to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has become a tradition closely linked to the holiday season, according to many donors.

title: ULSTER JURY URGED BY NEW YORK BAR
description: A study of Northern Ireland justice by the City Bar Association of New York has concluded there is a ''compelling need'' for the British authorities to curtail the use of trials without juries in cases involving terrorism charges.

title: Film: Stone's 'Wall Street'
description: OLIVER STONE'S ''Wall Street'' is a gentrified ''Everyman,'' an upscale morality tale to entertain achievers who don't want to lose touch with their moral centers, but still have it all.

title: Primate Is Acting to Ease Greek-Turkish Hostility
description: The Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America is leading an effort to ease hostility between Greece and Turkey.

title: Louis T. Hindenlang, Executive, 72
description: Louis T. Hindenlang, a retired executive vice president of the American Bank Note Company, died of cancer Sunday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: 2 Suicides Protest South Korea Opposition Disunity
description: Park Eung Soo, distraught over the potentially ruinous split in South Korea's political opposition, killed himself last weekend to express his unhappiness.

title: Economic Scene; Facing the Reality Of Big Trade Gap
description: THE White House tried to put the best face possible on yesterday's newly released trade data for October, suggesting that one should not pay too much attention to numbers that would probably be revised later. This sounded like the small boy's plea to Shoeless Joe Jackson, implicated in the Black Sox baseball bribery scandal: ''Say it ain't so, Joe.''

title: AUCTIONS
description: Illuminated Manuscript

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Crown American Corp., Allentown, Pa., elected as a director Kenn Hinkle, a senior vice president at Hess's Department Stores Inc. in Allentown.

title: Questions for Judge
description: Liberals have long accused the Reagan Administration of seeking to pack the Federal courts with anti-abortion conservatives and of privately grilling prospective nominees on their views about disputed issues to make sure they subscribe to the Reagan social agenda. Administration denials have met with some skepticism by Democrats.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Bruins 4, Kings 3: A freak goal by Lyndon Byers in the second period broke a 2-2 tie last night as Boston collected its fourth victory in its last five games. Bobby Carpenter and Paul Fenton gave visiting Los Angeles a 2-1 lead in the first period, but the Kings couldn't hold it and were defeated for the sixth time in the past six games. Byers's goal came after Steve Kasper's pass was intercepted by Jimmy Carson. The Kings' center put the puck on Byers's stick in front of the Los Angeles net. (AP) Blues 5, North Stars 4: A power-play goal by Mark Hunter late in the second period gave visiting St. Louis the lead for good. Hunter, the Blues' leading scorer, put in his 13th goal of the season when he deflected a shot by Robert Nordmark past the Minnesota goalie, Kari Takko, with 1:06 left in the period. (AP) TENNIS Edberg and Jarryd Win: Stefan Edberg and Anders Jarryd, the defending champions, recovered from an opening-day upset to beat Paul Annacone of the United States and Christo Van Rensburg of South Africa, 7-6, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday at the $200,000 Masters Doubles championship in London.

title: Art: 'Fictions,' Views of the Future and the Past
description: ''FICTIONS,'' the work of a critic, Douglas Blau, is one of the better curatorial performances of the season. A double-gallery exhibition of more than 40 paintings, drawings and photographs, at both the Curt Marcus Gallery and Kent Fine Art, ''Fictions'' reaches across the past three centuries to compare and contrast a variety of equally romantic realisms and world views. At Marcus, for example, it is possible to look at Thomas Anshutz's ''Dissecting Room'' from 1879 in the company of John Bowman's ''Heart of Stone'' (an operating-room scene from 1987) and a signed colotype of Thomas Eakins's masterpiece ''The Gross Clinic'' of 1876. At Kent, one encounters Elihu Vedder's ''Laboring in the Fields Before the Colossi of Memnon'' of 1891 (a startling yet seemingly straightforward painting of Egyptians harvesting wheat within distant view of the ruined colossi), and Mark Innerst's ''Memnon'' of 1984, which isolates the statues in the near dark of night.

title: Nets Lose No. 10, MacKinnon's First
description: The start of Bob MacKinnon's second term in six years as the Nets' interim coach was marked by a first half in which fewer plays were called from the bench, the substitution pattern had longer playing time, and the emphasis was on better ball movement and passing.

title: NEW YORK IS LOSING JUST THE SHOPS THAT MAKE A NEIGHBORHOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: Festive Tour Celebrates New Rainbow Room
description: The newly restored Rainbow Room is the subject of a series of tours and events on Sunday sponsored by the Municipal Arts Society. Tours begin at 11:30 A.M. and run through 2 P.M. with a buffet lunch throughout.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Blue Note Double Bill

title: Yo-Yo Ma to Speak
description: The cellist Yo-Yo Ma will discuss such issues as the Asianization of American music and the appeal of Western music in Asia tonight at 7 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. He is to speak along with the society's president, Robert B. Oxnam. Tickets are $10. Information: 517-8508.

title: New York Is Losing Just the Shops That Make a Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: American Brands To Sell Pinkerton's
description: American Brands Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Pinkerton's Inc. security services unit to CPP Security Service Inc. of Van Nuys, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. Pinkerton's is the nation's oldest provider of security services. American Brands, based in Old Greenwich, Conn., had announced in October that it planned to divest the company as part of its strategy of concentrating on its core businesses: tobacco, distilled spirits, financial services and office products.

title: Robeson, Gilpin, O'Neill And 'Emperor Jones'
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCORD IN HOUSE ON INQUIRY PANEL
description: The House agreed today to extend the life of its Iran-contra investigating committee into next year to provide for an orderly disposition of classified documents and continued access to the papers for those involved in follow-up inquiries.

title: Threatening Note Is Found at Site of Fatal Jet Crash
description: A former airline passenger agent angry at his dismissal wrote his former supervisor a threatening note on an air-sickness bag shortly before the airliner carrying them crashed in central California on Monday, Federal agents said yesterday.

title: Strong Dayton Offense
description: The two major victories this season for Dayton, Wagner's opponent for the Division III national championship, were over Ithaca College and Augustana of Illinois.

title: A Rookie Proves Fit for N.F.L. Survival
description: Seven weeks ago, in the Giants' first game after the National Football League players' strike, Stephen Baker made a play he could not forget. He wishes he could forget it.

title: Cantata and Recital
description: The Chants Elysee Opera and Concert Ensemble will present a staged performance of Debussy's cantata ''L'Enfant Prodigue'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. Francisco Aybar, a pianist, is to give a recital of works by Schumann, Liszt and Albeniz on Sunday at 3:30 P.M. in the cathedral. Both performances are free. Information: 662-2133.

title: Italy Presses Case Against Vatican Bank Officials
description: The Italian magistrates investigating the Vatican bank scandal remain determined to prosecute an American Archbishop despite a court ruling in July that declared him beyond their juridiction, judicial officials say.

title: Thruway Unit Suspends Plans For Interchange
description: In a surprise announcement, the New York State Thruway Authority said yesterday that it was halting preparations to build a Thruway interchange at the edge of Sterling Forest, a 30-square-mile tract of private timberland less than an hour's drive northwest of Manhattan.

title: Rossi Retires
description: Paolo Rossi, the hero of Italy's 1982 World Cup victory with six goals, said yesterday he was retiring from soccer. The 31-year-old striker said he was leaving because of a knee injury that has sidelined him for several months. Rossi said he was joining a publicity agency in Rome, as well as continuing his real estate work in Vicenza.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Roy Buchanan

title: Royals Get Bannister
description: The Kansas City Royals, and not the Yankees, got Floyd Bannister tonight when the Chicago White Sox sent Bannister to the Royals for four young pitchers. The trade ended a months-long scramble for the left-handed pitcher.

title: Dining Out Guide: American Cuisine
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AN AMERICAN PLACE, 969 Lexington Avenue, near 71st Street (517-7660) -

title: Foes Criticize Tower Project In Times Sq.
description: Plans to lease a 13-acre Times Square plot for the construction of four large office towers should be blocked until allegations of improprieties by the project's principal developer are fully investigated, speakers told a public hearing yesterday.

title: House Passes a Bill Including New Curbs Over Latin Policies
description: The House approved Thursday an $11.5 billion foreign aid bill despite warnings from Republicans that President Reagan would veto the measure because it contains new restrictions on his Central American policy.

title: Court's Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPT FROM STATEMENT
description: Following is an excerpt from the joint American-Soviet statement issued tonight at the end of the summit meeting here:

title: Arias Talk On Getting The Nobel
description: Following is the text of the address today by President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica upon receiving the Nobel Peace Prize. Mr. Arias spoke in English, and the text was issued by the Nobel Foundation.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL KANSAS CITY (AL) - Acquired Floyd Bannister, pitcher, and Dave Cochrane, infielder, from the Chicago White Sox for John Davis, Melido Perez, Chuck Mount and Greg Hibbard, pitchers. BASKETBALL INDIANA (NBA) - Waived Clint Richardson, guard. MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Waived Dudley Bradley, forward. PHOENIX (NBA) - Activated Eddie Johnson, forward, from the injured list. COLLEGE MISSISSIPPI - Named Jim (Red) Parker, former Delta State head football coach, as the new offensive coordinator. WEDNESDAY BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Kevin Hickey and Mark Bowden, pitchers, and assigned them to Rochester of the International League. BOSTON (AL) - Acquired Randy Kutcher, infielder-outfielder, from the San Francisco Giants to complete an earlier trade. BRADENTON (Gulf Coast League) -Named David Jauss, manager, and Elias Sosa, pitching coach. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Dave Collins, outfielder, to a one-year contract. Assigned Dave Vetsch, outfielder, to Nashville of the American Association. MINNESOTA (AL) - Traded Dave Vetsch, outfielder, to the Cincinnati Reds for Bill Cutshall, pitcher. Assigned Cutshall to Orlando of the Southern League. MONTREAL (NL) - Named Orrin Freeman scout.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS AIDE SLAIN IN SALVADOR
description: In what Government officials are treating as a political assassination, unidentified gunmen killed a leading member of El Salvador's official Human Rights Office last night, officials said.

title: The Treaty: Another Sellout
description: LEAD: The United States has never been in more danger than now, during the final 13 months of the Reagan Administration.

title: A Host of Tree Farms Throughout the Region
description: Despite the heavy snows of early October that damaged hundreds of thousands of trees in the Hudson Valley, cultivated Christmas trees weathered the storm in good shape and are now ready for harvest.

title: Dollar at 40-Year Low; Gold and Silver Surge
description: The dollar plummeted yesterday to its lowest levels since the 1940's amid heavy trading, as dealers sold the currency in the wake of the unexpectedly bad report on the nation's trade deficit in October.

title: Yanks Close to Signing Davis
description: The Yankees, who have tried and failed all week to get a left-handed-hitting outfielder in a trade, appeared to be close today to securing one on the free-agent market. The agent for Mike Davis said there was a strong chance Davis would soon reach agreement with the Yankees.

title: James Dobson, Actor, 67
description: James Dobson, who appeared with President Reagan in ''Hellcats of the Navy,'' died of a heart attack on Sunday. He was 67 years old.

title: A Kennedy Declines
description: Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, who was defeated for Congress in 1986 in her first political outing, has decided not to run again next year. Mrs. Townsend, a 36-year-old daughter of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, said this week that she would devote her efforts instead to a youth program for community service being organized by the Maryland Department of Education.

title: IT PAYS TO DEFER INCOME UNTIL JAN. 1
description: With income tax rates dropping on Jan. 1, taxpayers can benefit by finding ways to defer income until next year.

title: Pennzoil Talks Said to Gain
description: A director of the Pennzoil Company said yesterday that the company ''had been making progress'' in talks with representatives of Texaco Inc.'s creditors and shareholders about a possible plan of reorganization for Texaco. Any such plan would include a settlement proposal between Pennzoil and Texaco in their legal dispute, which will be four years old next month.

title: DEAVER JURY HEARS OF A PERJURY PLAN
description: The prosecutor told the jury at the perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver today that Mr. Deaver's exploitation of his 20-year friendship with Ronald and Nancy Reagan to enhance his lobbying business may have ''broken their hearts.''

title: Time for New York to Turn Up the Candlepower
description: Ever illuminated, New York becomes even more incandescently lustrous in the weeks before Christmas as holiday lights flicker on, building tops are bathed in red-and-green spotlights and even familiar street lamps acquire a cool, wintry glow. From the malls of Park Avenue to the poinsettia-encircled ''trees from different lands'' at the New York Botanical Garden, evergreens of every description are already festooned with millions of lights.

title: AIDE TO LAROUCHE GUILTY IN A PLOT
description: A former aide to Lyndon H. LaRouche was convicted today of plotting to obstruct a Federal investigation into reports of fraud by the 1984 Presidential campaign of the political extremist.

title: Righetti 'Confused' After Japan's Offer
description: Dave Righetti can defect to Japanese baseball for at least $8 million over two years, but the mammoth offer has left him ''confused'' and has prompted George Steinbrenner to say that the development could seriously damage United States-Japanese baseballl relations.

title: From Little, Wagner Builds Success
description: Wagner College on Staten Island resembles one of those small Midwestern liberal-arts colleges, a Hiram, a Hope or a Hanover, with grass and trees and an old building in the middle called Main.

title: Abuse by Women
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: MAYA'S COMIC 'RANTS'
description: THE world according to Frank Maya is a treacherous place.

title: GORBACHEV EXTOLS TALKS ON LEAVING
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, speaking as much to his own people as to his American audience, tonight depicted his talks with President Reagan as precisely the kind of success he had promised his first visit to the United States would produce.

title: Knicks Romp Past Nuggets
description: During three years as a marketing representative for I.B.M., Stu Jackson learned much about product presentation and consumer relations. Those lessons served him well last night in another, very different, capacity.

title: Florida Legislators Vote to Repeal Tax on Advertising and Services
description: The Legislature voted early today to repeal the state's tax on advertising and professional services, and Gov. Bob Martinez indicated he would sign the bill Friday.

title: Diner's Journal
description: A FESTIVE spot in midtown for a self-indulgent snack is Petrossian, the caviar and champagne palace on Seventh Avenue at 58th Street. The menu has been greatly expanded to offer a wide range of refined finger foods that can be tasted in the plush Art Deco dining room or at the marble-topped bar. Options include tasty little roulades of smoked sturgeon with wild mushrooms, truffled foie gras en croute, smoked salmon wrapped around avocado and Russian salmon roe, and fillets of smoked eel encasing shiitake mushrooms (all $12 each). Two ''teaser'' plates, combining morsels of each, are $13 and $19 respectively.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''For our fellow countrymen who have followed the course of our discussions, I am pleased to report that upon the completion of our business, that this summit has been a clear success.'' - President Reagan. [ A22:2. ]

title: 30% Rise in Thruway Tolls Is Called Likely by Authority
description: The New York State Thruway Authority, which has been plagued recently by a bridge collapse that took 10 lives and by scandals that claimed its two top executives, is now facing serious cash problems that make a toll increase of up to 30 percent likely this spring, according to its chairman, William C. Hennessy.

title: Tense Lawyers Search For 'Dominant' Jurors
description: After three months of trying to woo, cajole, persuade and perhaps even provoke the jury in the Howard Beach murder trial, each lawyer is now pinning his hopes on certain key jurors as he tensely awaits the verdict.

title: Radiotelescopes Discover 'Maternity Ward' of Stars
description: New observations by radio telescopes strongly support the theory that stars form from collapsing gas clouds and indicate for the first time that the process is spawning dozens of stars at once, scientists reported yesterday.

title: SOUTH AFRICA BLACK POLICE REVOLT
description: Scores of black constables revolted against their white commander today, tried to run him down and fought a gun battle with a riot squad that chased them, the authorities said.

title: Fire Damages Interior of the Biltmore Theater
description: The interior of the Biltmore Theater in Manhattan, which recently received landmark designation, was damaged by fire early yesterday in a blaze that officials say was deliberately set.

title: Politics Tipped Food Law, Panel Says
description: A Congressional subcommittee charged today that politically motivated officials at the Office of Management and Budget improperly pressured health experts into adopting a regulation easing food labeling requirements and ''undercut the credibility'' of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Stage: 'Only You,' By Timothy Mason
description: WHIMSY rides high at the Circle Repertory Company with the opening last night of Timothy Mason's ''Only You,'' a short evening of small talk. Ostensibly this comedy concerns the compartmentalization of prospective young lovers, each of whom never seems to know when he has found a rightful romantic partner. The characters are irredeemably ingenuous and the gimcrack set, designed by John Lee Beatty, is as cute as a pop-up storybook - pasteboard scenery with peephole doors and rollaway furniture.

title: Frederic V. Grunfeld Dies at 58; Author Wrote a Rodin Biography
description: Frederic V. Grunfeld, an author and journalist whose biography of the French sculptor Auguste Rodin was published last month, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Barcelona, Spain. He was 58 years old and lived near Deya, Majorca.

title: On Poetry
description: A discussion of the poetry of William Blake and Samuel Taylor will be led by the writers Stanley Kunitz and Mark Strand tonight at 8 at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. The discussion is part of the Y's series ''The Writer's Voice.'' Admission is $6. Information: 787-6557,

title: Postal Chief Sees Major Problems in New York but Expects Progress
description: Postmaster General Preston R. Tisch acknowledged yesterday that there are major problems with mail delivery in New York City. But service will begin to improve, he said, after new equipment is installed next year.

title: Timid Rangers Fall to Flyers
description: One team has evidently undergone a formal regrouping. The other, also adrift at the bottom of the National Hockey League pack, continues to speak of a need for consistency, for positive breaks and attitudes, and for the players to get acquainted so that familiarity can breed something useful, like a winning streak.

title: A Bomb in Greece Wounds 5 At Commerce Chamber Vote
description: Five people were wounded today, one of them seriously, when a bomb exploded at the Athens Chamber of Commerce and Industry as the chamber was crowded with members taking part in board elections, the police said.

title: glasnost (glas'nust) n. 1. publicity 2. openness
description: Glasnost has entered the international vocabulary as a catchword for a general liberalization of Soviet society. But in the Soviet Union itself, glasnost is a term whose meaning and practice are matters of intense debate.

title: Drug Recalled in AIDS Scare
description: Armour Pharmaceutical is recalling 208 lots of a blood clotting agent distributed for hemophilia patients because of the possibility it could contain the AIDS virus, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: On Stage
description: After 'Fences,' 'Joe Turner'

title: Restaurants
description: MANY restaurants in New York these days carry voluminous wine lists, some on computer printouts, others enshrined in thick leather-bound covers that resemble diplomas. This is fine for grape-stained wine aficionados who revel in vinous research at the dinner table, but for the average diner who merely wants a pleasant wine to complement the meal, such lists might as well be in Sanskrit.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly - Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 ADMINISTRATIVE AND BUDGETARY COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. LEGAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M.

title: Trade Gap Sets Monthly Record At $17.6 Billion
description: The nation's deficit in foreign trade leaped to a record $17.6 billion in October as Christmas goods and other imports rose more than five times as much as exports, the Government said today.

title: Kin of Suspect Defiant and Contrite
description: Altamont and Allan Burke alternately expressed defiance and contrition today over the evidence that their brother David had fired shots aboard an airliner that led to its crash and the deaths of all aboard.

title: 3 Guilty in Tax-Fraud Case Where Rich Got Deductions
description: In what officials described as the largest tax fraud case ever filed, Charles A. Atkins, sometimes known as the ''boy wonder of tax shelters,'' and two associates were found guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan of operating an illegal scheme that produced hundreds of millions of dollars in fraudulent tax deductions for wealthy investors.

title: 'Leave Us in Peace,' Costa Rican Pleads
description: President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica accepted the Nobel Peace Prize today with a plea of ''utmost urgency'' that the superpowers cease intruding in Central America and ''send our people plowshares instead of swords.''

title: Market Place; A Sad Christmas For Toy Stocks
description: AS Christmas approaches, there is little cheer among stockholders of toy companies - and for good reason. Share prices have plunged far below levels of a year ago.

title: Bridge: Herman Horowitz of Queens Was a Champion in His 80's
description: The New York bridge scene lost one of its great veterans when Herman Horowitz of Rego Park, Queens, died in August just short of his 90th birthday. Only two weeks earlier he was the big winner in a six-hour rubber bridge session that would have tested many a younger man.

title: CONCERT: 'L'ENFANCE DU CHRIST'
description: ''L'ENFANCE DU CHRIST,''

title: There's No Room In Neighborhood For Mentally Ill
description: Please don't get members of the Highland Road Civic Association wrong. The folks who live in these $300,000 to $500,000 homes love mentally ill people! At a meeting here about a proposed group home on Highland Road for recovering psychiatric patients, it sometimes sounded like there were 100 Mother Teresas in the room.

title: Advertising; Big Doings For Subway Ad Concern
description: IT has been an eventful couple of weeks for Marvin Schwartz and William M. Apfelbaum, president and chairman, respectively, of New York Subways Advertising.

title: The 'Angels' Stress Patrol On Streets
description: Except for the red berets and metal-studded belts of the Guardian Angels, the people fighting could have been involved in just another street-corner brawl in Chelsea. Such fights have become common there since the crack epidemic began, residents say.

title: Koch Names Dinkins Deputy Chief of Financial Services
description: Mayor Koch named Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Borough President of Manhattan, to be Commissioner of Financial Services yesterday.

title: OPERA: CHICAGO'S LYRIC IN 'MARRIAGE OF FIGARO'
description: Metropolitan Opera audiences who know Peter Hall only as the director of two famously lackluster productions, ''Macbeth'' and ''Carmen,'' must have a seriously distorted view of his talents. As often happens, the right man was hired for the wrong jobs. The prolific Englishman's work is more justly represented by his stagings of Mozart operas, particularly for the Glyndebourne Festival, of which he has been artistic director since 1984. In any event, the ''Marriage of Figaro'' that Mr. Hall has produced for his debut season with Lyric Opera of Chicago demonstrates that he is a Mozart man to the bone, one who knows the difference between an ensemble and a collection of singers. It helps his cause, too, that the four-act opera is played, as it always should be, with only one intermission.

title: U.S. BISHOPS BACK CONDOM EDUCATION AS A MOVE ON AIDS
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops, long-time opponents of artificial birth control, yesterday offered qualified support for teaching about condoms in educational programs aimed at fighting the spread of AIDS.

title: Feltsman in L.I. Recital
description: The pianist Vladimir Feltsman will give a recital of works by Schubert, Messiaen and Schumann tonight at 8:30 at the Tilles Center for the Performing Arts in Greenvale, L.I. Mr. Feltsman is replacing Rudolf Serkin, who canceled his recital because of illness. Tickets are $22.50 and $25. Information: (516) 922-0061.

title: REAGAN FINDS U.S.-SOVIET TIES NOW FAR MORE CANDID
description: President Reagan said tonight that his three-day summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had placed Soviet-American relations ''on a far more candid, and far more realistic footing.''

title: Empire Brass
description: The Empire Brass, conducted by Joseph Giunta, will perform works by Handel, Gabrieli, Rossini, Purcell, Prokofiev, Gershwin and others tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Tickets are $14 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

title: Rural Phones
description: As the Federal Communications Commission voted yesterday to improve telephone service in remote areas by allocating radio channels to that use, a commissioner, James H. Quello, said the action would show the agency's ''sensitivities'' to ''the people out in the rural boonies.'' A colleague, Patricia Diaz Dennis, was quick to disassociate from the usage of Mr. Quello, who has lived in the Detroit suburb of Grosse Pointe Woods. ''I would never describe my home state of New Mexico as the boonies,'' she said. ''Boonies'' is helpfully defined in the Dictionary of American Regional English as ''the sticks.''

title: The Best Linebacker
description: After disproving scouting reports that said he was too small and too slow to become a competent college football player, Paul McGowan of Florida State University capped his collegiate career yesterday by winning the 1987 Butkus Award as the nation's best collegiate linebacker. McGowan, who totaled four first-place votes and 25 points from a panel of 11 sportswriters and broadcasters, won by a point over Chris Spielman of Ohio State, who had five first-place votes.

title: Lawyer Talk? You Can Look It Up
description: What H. W. Fowler did for everybody, Bryan A. Garner, a 29-year-old associate at a Dallas law firm, set out to do for lawyers. The result, published this month by the Oxford University Press, is ''A Dictionary of Modern Legal Usage.''

title: WHERE TO HEAR (AND SING) THE SONGS OF CHRISTMAS
description: NOTHING - not the decorated shops nor the bright and bustling streets nor the restaurants and museums and theaters packed with holiday visitors -nothing so embodies the spirit of Christmastime in New York as the sound of music.

title: OPEC Talks Halt for Try At Mediation
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries suspended deliberations today to allow mediation of the sharply divergent views of Iran and Iraq on production policies.

title: Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation closed the polls on a thrice-delayed shareholder vote on a vital part of the telecommunications concern's restructuring plan. A shareholder meeting for balloting also was adjourned for the corporation's chief subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company. A spokesman said the shareholder meeting would be reconvened on Monday to announce the results of the balloting. Voters were deciding on a merger of the two entities under a reorganization that company officials said might be necessary to avoid seeking protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws. The company has been seeking to exchange most of its obligations to creditors for new issues of preferred stock.

title: Regional Premiers Talk With Haitian Leader
description: Five Caribbean Prime Ministers held talks today with the head of Haiti's army-dominated provisional Government, Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, over the cancellation of the Nov. 29 election and his plans to hold a new vote.

title:
Real Estate;
Big Complex Is Converted In Queens
description: LEAD: WHEN it was built in 1956, Dara Gardens, a 534-unit complex in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, was considered one of the borough's more ambitious developments.

title: A New Warning on the Trade Deficit
description: Bad news on the October trade deficit came right in the middle of the Washington summit conference. Even as President Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev explored arms control, there it was -stark confirmation that the Soviet Union is not the only superpower with economic problems. America's economy is also out of kilter, and the experts aren't sure how to fix it.

title: Corrections
description: An article from San Francisco on Nov. 19, about a California Poll citing the preferences of state Democrats for the party's Presidential nomination, included individual percentages that totaled more than 100. The article omitted a sentence stating that respondents to the poll were allowed to choose more than one candidate.

title: 'Jakob Lenz' at Juilliard
description: The Juilliard School's American Opera Center will present the New York premiere of Wolfgang Rihm's ''Jakob Lenz'' tonight at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street. Tickets are $10. Information: 874-7515.

title: Olympic Green Light
description: The International Olympic Committee's executive board in Lausanne, Switzerland, gave final approval yesterday for competition in the next year's Olympic Games to 18 athletes, including Ingemar Stenmark and Marc Girardelli, skiing stars, and Naim Suleymangolu, a weight lifter.

title: Howard Beach Jury Gets Case And Asks to Visit Attack Scene
description: Nearly a year after the death of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, sparked one of the most bitter racial controversies in New York City in years, a jury began yesterday to deliberate the fate of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter in his death.

title: At the Movies
description: Waiting for 'Freedom'

title: Smart Team
description: One day after he received the Outland Trophy as the nation's best interior lineman, Chad Hennings of the Air Force Academy was named to the GTE Academic All-America football team. The 260-pound defensive tackle heads a team that also includes the Holy Cross quarterback Jeff Wiley and the defensive back Chuck Cecil of Arizona.

title: U.S. Settles A.T.&T. Rift
description: The General Services Administration and the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reached an agreement late today on the company's protest of the award of contracts for telephone switching equipment.

title: 'Asinamali!' and 'Foxfire' Explore Pain of Survival
description: TWO plays newly adapted for television explore, in very different ways and contexts, the subject of survival. The South African ''Asinamali,'' on Channel 13's ''Great Performances'' tonight at 9, describes the brutality of living under the oppressive policy of apartheid. ''Foxfire,'' a Hallmark Hall of Fame presentation on CBS Sunday at 9 P.M., deals with the unavoidable pressures of simply growing old. The setting happens to be the Blue Ridge Mountains of southern Appalachia.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1987
description: International A3-26

title: Refund Order For Comsat
description: The Federal Communications Commission today ordered the Communications Satellite Corporation to refund $38.8 million for overcharging telephone company customers, principally the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The commission found that

title: GORBACHEV MEETS BUSINESS LEADERS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev asked American business leaders today to help improve the economic relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union now that political relations are on what he called a ''more predictable footing.''

title: 12 Countries Want Banks to Increase Capital
description: The Federal Reserve and 11 foreign central banks announced a preliminary agreement today to increase the required capital base of banks, seeking to create a bigger cash cushion in the world banking system.

title: Perelman Acts On TW Stake
description: Ronald O. Perelman, the chairman of Revlon Inc., said today that he was seeking clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to raise his stake in TW Services Inc., the successor to the Trans World Corporation, to 25 percent, from 14.8 percent. Mr. Perelman, who waged a takeover battle for Trans World last fall, left open the possibility that he might renew his attempt to gain control of the New York-based food and health-care services concern.

title: U.N. CHIEF FAULTS TEHERAN'S STANCE
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the Security Council today that its authority was being undermined by Iran's refusal to accept its cease-fire call and indicated he felt it was time to impose an arms embargo.

title: MUTE QUARREL OVER 'STAR WARS'; REAGAN TRIP IS DUE
description: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev concluded their three-day summit conference today with what they described as significant progress toward a treaty limiting strategic weapons. But they failed to conclude major new agreements on Afghanistan or the other key issues that still divide them.

title: Other Christmas Offerings Around Town
description: TODAY RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL. ''Magnificent Christmas Spectacular,'' with the Rockettes. Today through Sunday, sold out. Through Jan. 6. Tickets, $24 and $27. Information: 757-3100. title: Village Orchestra
description: The Greenwich Village Orchestra will perform works by Rimsky-Korsakov and Tchaikovsky on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Washington Irving High School, Irving Place at 16th Street. Tickets are $5, $2 for students and the elderly.

title: New Chief Will Stress GTE Core Businesses
description: The GTE Corporation announced yesterday that James L. Johnson had been elected to succeed Theodore F. Brophy as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Brophy retires at age 65 in April after 30 years at the telecommunications company.

title: Bassdrumbone
description: Bassdrumbone - the trio of Mark Helias, bassist, Gerry Hemingway, percussionist, and Ray Anderson, trombonist, - is to perform Sunday at 9 and 11 P.M. at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Admission is $6.

title: As 'Gorby' Works the Crowd, Backward Reels the K.G.B.
description: Have you ever seen a Soviet motorcade go backward?

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about CBS News film of a Soviet missile carrier misidentified its cargo. CBS later reported that it was not an SS-20 missile, only a canister used for one.

title: More Yachtsmen Issue Challenges
description: Michael Fay, the New Zealand banker who has challenged the San Diego Yacht Club for the America's Cup next summer, may not be the only challenger.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Political Image-Making; In the Land of George, Abe, Ike and Jack: Mikhail
description: He is masterly in his use of television, good at the small gesture, quick in repartee. He appeals directly to the people over the heads of the political establishment. He seems to enjoy a close relationship with an attractive wife, always a political asset, and he appears open to new ideas and to change. He is succeeding in blurring his party affiliation - no small achievement.

title: British Air Raises Bid In Fight for Caledonian
description: British Airways raised its bid for all of British Caledonian Airways to more than $360 million today in a fierce battle with the Scandinavian Airlines System, which Wednesday night offered $200 million for 26 percent of British Caledonian.

title: Democratic Hopefuls Raise Issue of Tax Climb
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates raised the possibility of higher taxes to reduce the nation's budget deficit last night in their first joint appearance before a New York audience.

title: Good Big Buildings Need Friends
description: The Shadow Trend is apparent coast to coast, from San Francisco to New York: a newly energized movement that opposes big buildings in cities because they cast shadows, threaten views, crowd facilities and offend somebody's taste. But the virtuous opponents rarely explain how, without big new buildings, cities can end housing shortages, expand job opportunities and collect tax revenues.

title: Allis Rejects Bid
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation, the struggling equipment maker on the block since November, said it had rejected a $385 million offer by a New York investment firm for most of its assets and property. Allis-Chalmers, which filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors more than a year ago, rejected the offer by Peers & Company as too low and because of its plans to sell two major units. It said it had begun to try to sell its remaining principal businesses either together or separately.

title: Threadgill Premiere
description: Henry Threadgill's ''Run Silent, Run Deep, Run Loud, Run High'' - a work for 28 musicians and singers -is to receive its world premiere tonight and tomorrow at 8 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, in the Fort Greene section (718) 636-4100). Tickets are $15 to $20.

title: Suicide Victim in Jet Inquiry Termed North Korea Envoy
description: The man who swallowed poison and died before he could be questioned about the disappearance of a South Korean airliner was probably a former North Korean diplomat, Japanese officials said today.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A President Is Chosen At the Battelle Institute
description: LEAD: The trustees of the Battelle Memorial Institute, a worldwide research and development organization based in Columbus, Ohio, today named Douglas E. Olesen as president and chief executive. He replaces Ronald S. Paul, 65, who will remain on the board of trustees.

title: Political Memo: Presidential Race Puzzles the Pundits
description: After every Presidential debate there is a scramble to declare the winners and losers. Did Gov. Michael S. Dukakis look Presidential on NBC last week, or merely subdued and tired? Did Alexander M. Haig Jr. inflict serious damage to Vice President Bush, or merely nip him around the ankles?

title: A Federal Land Bank Is Insolvent
description: After years of losses throughout the Farm Credit System from depressed land values, a Federal land bank declared itself insolvent today, the first ever to do so.

title: 90 MEET IN MOSCOW AT RIGHTS SEMINAR
description: An independent international human rights seminar, stripped of its meeting hall, some leaders and many participants, nonetheless brought 90 people together today to discuss the persecution, hardship and faith that animates the Soviet human rights movement.

title: 9 Sites Listed for Public Housing in Yonkers
description: A housing expert working under a Federal judge's orders has identified nine privately owned sites here that he says could be used to build the public housing required under a desegregation order.

title: 5,000 Layoffs Seen by Hutton
description: About 5,000 New York employees are expected to lose their jobs when E. F. Hutton & Company merges with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. next month, executives of the two companies said here today.

title: British Prelate Says Dispute Damages Church
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury said today that a dispute stemming from an attack on him in an official church publication had damaged the Church of England.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in The Home Section yesterday about home improvement in Greenwich Village apartment misidentified two people. The man seated in the center was William F. Miller, a general contractor; the other man was Tom Brashares, a Manhattan architect.

title: Donald Jackson, 68; A Writer and Editor Of American History
description: Donald Jackson, editor of the six-volume ''Papers of George Washington'' and other historical documents, died of cancer of the prostate Wednesday in Colorado Springs, Colo. He was 68 years old.

title: Park City Journal; Silver Mine in the Sky Awaits Nature's Whim
description: There are still riches to be found here in the great, round-topped mountains brooding over the eastern rim of the Salt Lake Valley, although sometimes the finding is as chancy as it once was for prospectors in this old mining town.

title: Chile's Leader Takes to Task Foreign Foes
description: Within Chile's increasingly heated electoral climate, the role of foreign governments, politicians and organizations has become a point of contention between President Augusto Pinochet and his opponents.

title: Hugh R. Williams, 65, Maryland Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Hugh Roberts Williams, director of the Talbot County Mental Health Clinic in Easton, Md., from 1977 to 1985 and the in-patient psychiatrist at Franklin Square Hospital in Baltimore from 1985 until early this year, died Wednesday of prostatic cancer at his home in Royal Oak, Md. He was 65 years old.

title: Elizabeth H. L. Gurlitz, Editor, 96
description: Elizabeth Harper Landon Gurlitz, a magazine editor for four decades, died last Friday at the Mediplex Home in Westport, Conn., where she had lived several years. She was 96 years old.

title: Pan Am Board Differs on Bid
description: The board of directors of the Pan Am Corporation has major reservations about some of the terms proposed by Jay A. Pritzker for the takeover of Pan American World Airways that will have to be resolved before he can gain control, a source close to the board said yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Gorbachev News Conference: 'A New Phase in Relations'
description: Following are excerpts from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by an official Soviet interpreter. OPENING STATEMENT

title: Trade Data Send Dow Down 47.08
description: Ending Wall Street's three-day rally, stock prices fell sharply late yesterday after a seesaw session that reflected unexpectedly bad news on the trade front.

title: Warsaw Dissidents Protest
description: Six Polish opposition figures chained themselves to scaffolding in the center of Warsaw today to demand the release of prisoners they say are being held for political reasons, Western reporters said. It took more than an hour for the police to cut the chains and lead away the demonstrators.

title: Jets Trying to Outwit Grogan
description: Their coach looked at the Jets' pass defenders and labeled the unit a shambles.

title: Dr. Louis Gray, Physician, 98
description: Dr. Louis Gray, a retired physician from New York City, died Wednesday at the National Orthopaedic Hospital in Arlington, Va. He was 98 years old and lived in Rockville, Md.

title: NEW YORK IS LOSING JUST THE SHOPS THAT MAKE A NEIGHBORHOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: New Music at Galleria
description: Jay Elf, David First and Virgil Moorefield will present new compositions Sunday at 4 P.M. at La Mama Galleria, 6 East First Street (505-2476). Admission is by donation.

title: Suspect in Sex Ring Is Cleared
description: An insurance executive was acquitted today of charges that he let two Brown University students become prostitutes by offering them money and hope of modeling careers.

title: 11 Killed on Shanghai Ferry
description: Thousands of passengers stampeded onto a fog-delayed ferry in Shanghai today, and 11 people were killed and 76 injured in the crush, the official New China News Agency said. The stampede occurred as thousands of people pushed forward when the vessel docked after a delay of several hours.

title: Catch-1984
description: It was there on the table in the Soviet press room all through the summit talks, a neat pile of copies of a document prepared in Moscow for American journalists covering the great event. Nobody paid attention to it, what with all the important meetings and statements and interviews.

title: Principal in Paterson Is Directed To Reinstate 50 Expelled Students
description: Joseph Clark, a high school principal here who has won national acclaim as a disciplinarian, has been ordered to reinstate 50 students he had ejected because they were disciplinary problems and were not doing their school work.

title: Cuomo Meeting Fails to Agree on Restructuring School Board
description: Political and education leaders, summoned by Governor Cuomo yesterday to discuss the New York City schools, failed to agree on the Governor's main goal: restructuring the Board of Education.

title: THE SUMMIT: Avoiding the Obstacles; U.S. and Soviet Put Aside Thorniest Issues And End Summit Talks on a Positive Note
description: The United States and the Soviet Union were able to end the summit meeting on a positive note not only because they had made some real progress but also because they sidestepped their central disagreement on the issue of testing space-based defensive weapons.

title: O'Neill Ends Hospital Stay
description: Former House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was released today from Brigham & Women's Hospital here after a nearly monthlong stay in which he underwent surgery for rectal cancer and had an enlarged prostate removed. A hospital spokeswoman said Mr. O'Neill, who marked his 75th birthday Wednesday, left the hospital accompanied by his wife, Mildred, for their home in Harwichport on Cape Cod. His physicians have said the cancer surgery was so successful that Mr. O'Neill would not require chemotherapy or radiation therapy.

title: A Calendar of Music Events for the Holiday Season
description: This is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Christmas season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. At 3 P.M. Tickets, $2 (50 cents for the elderly). Information: (718) 622-4433. CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE (Episcopal), Cathedral School, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. All-Bach program with the Cantata 142 (''Uns Ist ein Kind Geboren''), the motet (''Lobet den Herrn Alle Heiden'') and Missa Brevis in A; Central City Chorus; Debra Vanderlinde, soprano; Diana Skinner, mezzo-soprano; Darrell Lauer, tenor; Richard Christopher, baritone; Charles Pilling, director. At 7 P.M. Donation, $7. Information: 838-0808. CHURCH OF ST. MARY THE VIRGIN (Episcopal), 145 West 46th Street. Brahms's ''Meese'' and Bach's ''Nun Komm der Heiden Heiland'' and ''Wachet Auf! Ruft Uns die Stimme''; Quentin Lane, director. At 11 A.M. Information: 869-5830. CORPUS CHRISTI CHURCH (Roman Catholic), 529 West 121st Street. Pachelbel's Magnificat; Josiah Flagg's ''Hallelujah''; Holyoke's ''Lo! He Comes in Clouds Descending''; Wright's Missa Brevis; Louise Basbas, director. At 11:15 P.M. Information: 666-0675. title: A VARIETY SHOW, AVANT-GARDE STYLE
description: SOME performance artists, like Eric Bogosian and Ann Magnuson, delight in caricaturing an entire spectrum of American types. Others, like Michael Smith, concentrate their energies on the refinement of a single symbolic character.

title: In High School, Armed to the Teeth
description: The education summit meeting called yesterday by Governor Cuomo marks an important first step toward reform of New York City's troubled school system. But as education and political leaders seek consensus on issues of school system governance, students at Manhattan's Park West High School face a more basic problem: personal safety. This week they staged a sit-in to protest violence in and around the school, where students routinely carry guns, knives and other weapons.

title: About Historians Who Can't Write
description: In 17th century France, there lived an unusual woman, Ninon de Lenclos. She was the most famous of courtesans, lover, friend, adviser and companion of the great and near-great: monarchs, statesmen, authors, philosophers, generals. Her lawyer, Francois Arouet, was a former peasant who served her with diligence, and she was quite taken with the lawyer's precocious 10-year-old son.

title: Walter Anderson, 69, Investigator in Queens
description: Walter Anderson, an investigator in the office of the Queens District Attorney for 25 years, died Wednesday at the Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Lloyd Harbor, L.I.

title: N.F.L. Told to Pay Players It Barred
description: The National Labor Relations Board ordered the National Football League today to pay between $21 million and $25 million in wages and bonus incentives to players who were barred from games on Oct. 18 and 19.

title: The 'Key Log' in America's Economic Logjam
description: LEAD: A logjam that snarls the down-river flow of logs is a recurring problem in logging. The logger's task is to discover the key log, whose extraction unlocks the jam. Similarly, a tangle of short- and long-term problems incapacitates our economy.

title: Record Mexico Inflation
description: Consumer prices rose 7.9 percent in November, bringing inflation for the first 11 months of 1987 to a record 125.8 percent, the central bank has announced. November's rate was down from October's 8.3 percent rise, according to figures released by the Bank of Mexico. Private analysts have predicted that inflation for the year could go as high as 140 percent, well above the previous annual record of 105.7 percent, reached in 1986.

title: Cutting This Year's Taxes: Retirement Plans a Big Help YOUR TAXES: TIPS FOR YEAR-END; Third of five articles.
description: Depositing money in a personal retirement account or in a company-sponsored plan is one of the most lucrative ways still left for individuals to trim their 1987 income tax bill.

title: Senate Approves McLaughlin As Secretary of Labor, 94 to 0
description: The Senate today unanimously approved President Reagan's nomination of Ann Dore McLaughlin, a former Under Secretary of the Interior, to be Secretary of Labor.

title: Koch Picks Investigation Aide To Be Criminal Justice Chief
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would appoint the first deputy investigation commissioner, Peter J. Benitez, the Criminal Justice Coordinator.

title: Official of Ford Foundation Will Head Haverford College
description: Tom G. Kessinger, a scholar on South Asia who heads the Ford Foundation's office in New Delhi, has been named president of Haverford College.

description: b-Included tax loss carryforwards of $276,000 for the quarter and $405,000 for the 6 months. c-Included tax loss carryforwards of $237,000 for the quarter and $1,162,000 for the 6 months.

title: Panels to Decide Fate of Cuban Inmates
description: The Reagan Administration established a new process today to decide whether Cubans held in American prisons should be sent back to Cuba, but lawyers for the inmates said the procedures were inadequate.

title: Uspci Takes Steps To Block Takeover
description: Uspci Inc., trying to ward off a $25-a-share takeover proposal from the Union Pacific Corporation, disclosed that it had entered negotiations to acquire ''a business which complements the company's operations.'' Uspci, the hazardous waste management concern based in Oklahoma City, has previously said that an acquisition might be used as a defense against Union Pacific's proposal.

title: Yanks, Mets Will Play
description: The general managers of the Mets and the Yankees disclosed today that the teams would resume playing exhibition games against each other in 1989.

title: Olympic Summit
description: As he promised Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, President Reagan raised the issue of support of the Olympic Games by the United States and the Soviet Union at the summit meeting this week in Washington, an aide to the Republican Senator said. But even though Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, acknowledged general support for the Olympic movement, the aide said, he would not promise that a team from his country would attend the Summer Games next September in Seoul, South Korea. ''The Senator,'' said the aide, Jane Robbins, ''was very disappointed.'' Anchorage is making a bid to be host to the 1994 Winter Games.

title: 11 KILLED BY BOMB IN NORTHERN SPAIN
description: Eleven people, including four children, were killed today when a car bomb wrecked a barracks for Civil Guard families in this northern Spanish town.

title: Guidepost
description: Holiday Mailing Tips

title: Big Board Fills Security Post
description: David Doherty, who has worked with the Central Intelligence Agency and the Securities and Exchange Commission, is joining the New York Stock Exchange as senior vice president for enforcement.

title: DOW RISES 11.60 POINTS
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, helped by signs that inflation remained in check.

description: Questions appear on page 18.

title: Delayed Payment
description: He had to wait more than 20 months, but Charlie Sifford has finally collected $100,000 for making a hole-in-one during the 1986 Johnny Mathis Senior Golf Classic. Sifford, who joined the Tour in 1962 at the age of 37, was awarded the prize money yesterday by a Federal jury in Los Angeles. The five men and one woman took three and a half hours before rendering a unanimous verdict in favor of Sifford, who had filed suit last May against B.P.J. Enterprises, the promoter of the tournament, and Freemont Indemnity Co., one of its sponsors. Jerry Roisman, Sifford's lawyer, said that the tournament sponsors had advertised that the first player to make a hole-in-one on the par-3 168-yard 15th hole at the tournament would win $100,000 and a new automobile. Sifford made the ace on March 28, but received neither the money nor the automobile at the time. Roisman said the sponsors refused to pay Sifford because they claimed the signs advertising the prizes for the hole-in-one had been torn down before Sifford played the hole. After Sifford filed suit last May, the sponsors gave the golfer the automobile, and on Thursday he received the remainder of his payments. ''It means a lot to me,'' Sifford said. ''It means peace of mind and a lot of anger gone. I've been angry ever since I made the hole-in-one.''

title: INSIDE
description: Yanks and Mets in Deal

title: 2 Broadcast Measures Die in Senate
description: In its deliberations over the bill to reduce the Federal deficit, the Senate dropped two measures concerning television and radio broadcasting.

title: Harvard Endowment
description: Harvard University's multibillion-dollar endowment dropped 7.2 percent in value when the stock market plunged in October, the university said today. The endowment's decline of $290 million was far smaller on a percentage basis than the overall market, which by various measures was down more than 20 percent in October. Harvard said its endowment that month dropped from $4.14 billion to $3.85 billion. Robert H. Scott, Harvard's vice president for finance, praised a decision late in the summer by the university's investment managers to shift from stocks to cash and bonds.

title: Saving More Than Turtles
description: Several mischievous amendments are waiting as the House gets ready to vote next week on reauthorization of the Endangered Species Act, one of the most effective environmental laws ever enacted. The most troubling, offered by Solomon Ortiz of Texas, would delay new regulations requiring shrimp fishermen to use excluder devices that permit sea turtles to escape their nets.

title: Disneyland-Style Park To Be Built in Italy
description: A fantasy-theme park similar to Disneyland is to be built outside this city on Italy's northeast Adriatic coast.

title: Educators Say Thrust of Cuomo Proposals Doesn't Address the Needs of Schoolhouse
description: As the argument over who should control the Board of Education - the Mayor or the current melange of officials - remained unresolved after a ''summit meeting'' on the school system called by Governor Cuomo, some wondered whether the right question was being asked.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report yesterday about the marriage of Richard Edward Gutman to Rosann Seasonwein misstated the bridegroom's former marital status.

title: New York Cultural Commissioner Names Deputy
description: Mary Schmidt Campbell, New York's new Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, appointed Charmaine Jefferson as her deputy yesterday. Ms. Jefferson is the 33-year-old general manager of the Dance Theater of Harlem and a former government official.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
The Even Sadder New York Police Saga
description: The recent revelation that Transit Police officers made scores of illegal arrests for alleged sex abuse and other crimes in 1983 and 1984 is only the beginning of what promises to be a long and sorry story. It is fast becoming clear that the ill-advised practice of measuring police productivity by arrest quotas is responsible for a far more extensive pattern of false arrests and for undermining the credibility of an entire police agency.

title: Most of Adult Illiterates Are White, Study Finds
description: The majority of American adults who need help learning to read are white, not members of minority groups, according to a survey released today by a state education group.

title: TAKEOVER TAX CRITICISM
description: Joseph A. Grundest, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has sharply criticized provisions of a House deficit-reduction bill that are aimed at slowing corporate takeover activity.

title: New York Asks Jersey to Alter New Token
description: Officials of the New York City Transit Authority implored the New Jersey Highway Authority yesterday to change a new token for the Garden State Parkway, for fear they could be used to take the city for a ride.

title: CORRECTION
description: The crossword puzzle clues yesterday omitted an entry for 33 down. It should have been Wag.

title: Consumer Spending Found Cautious
description: Evidence mounted today that consumers have slowed their spending in recent months, but the cutback does not appear severe enough to shove the economy into early recession.

title: Toy Guns on '10 Worst' List
description: Realistic toy guns that shoot a variety of projectiles and other gun-like toys place children at risk of serious injury or death, a Boston lawyer who is an advocate of child safety said Thursday.

title: Your Money; Lessons in Risk In Mutual Funds
description: LIKE other stock market investors, the 40 million mutual fund shareholders learned several important lessons from the record plunge on Oct. 19. Indeed, they were awakened to some of the realities of the investment world.

title: Gorbachev Stops in Berlin; Gets a Triumphal Welcome
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev stopped here today on his way home from the Washington summit meeting and was given a triumphal welcome by other Warsaw Pact leaders and thousands of East Berliners who cheered him along the motorcade route.

title: A Gulf Patrol: Tense Moods Despite a Lull
description: As a convoy of oil tankers under United States Navy protection approached from the south, helicopter minesweepers from this American warship spent the last five days trolling their gear through the shipping channels of the northern Persian Gulf.

UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for 12mo Nov 30
description: The latest 12 months' figures reflect a decrease in earnings of $43,741,076, net of taxes, or 78 cents a share, resulting from December 1986 provision for the coal mining operations refund.

title: Workers to Get Pension Data
description: All American workers will soon be able to obtain estimates of their Social Security benefits and how much their families would receive if they die or become disable, the head of the $200 billion pension and disability program said Thursday.

title: JAZZ: AMERICAN ORCHESTRA
description: Since its debut a year and a half ago, the American Jazz Orchestra has been gradually working its way through the repertories of the classic big jazz bands from Fletcher Henderson to Dizzy Gillespie. The orchestra added one more band to its list on Thursday evening at the Cooper Union when it played a memorial concert of arrangements that originated in the explosive bands led by Woody Herman in the 1940's.

description: b-Net income

title: Dr. Sidney Yudin, Psychologist
description: Dr. Sidney Yudin, a New York City psychologist, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 66 years old.

title: GETTY PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Wife of Spy Hospitalized
description: The jailed wife of convicted spy Jonathan Jay Pollard today was transferred from a prison hospital in Kentucky to one affiliated with the Mayo Clinic for treatment of a digestive disorder, Government officials and family members said. A Justice Department official said Anne Henderson Pollard, who was given a five-year term in March after pleading guilty to charges related to her husband's sale of state secrets to Israel, was checked into Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn.

title: McKinnon-Carolina Accord
description: Thomson McKinnon Securities announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the Carolina Securities Corporation, a Raleigh, N.C., brokerage house. No purchase price was disclosed.

title: U.S. Official Says Trade Schools Recruit Jobless
description: A Federal education official, defending a crackdown on people who default on student loans, said today that some profit-making business schools recruited barely literate students from unemployment lines.

title: John Heller, Writer, 91
description: John Heller, a retired candy manufacturer and writer, died of pnuemonia Monday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 91 years old and lived in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: On the Court, Fads Are Fast-Breaking
description: LEAD: Several years ago, Michael Jordan, the high-flying forward of the Chicago Bulls, decided that he needed more room in the seat of his pants. For the sake of comfort, not style, he had two inches added to the rise in his basketball shorts and four inches added to their length. Whether he intended to or not, he started a trend, one of several - in fashions, hair styles and uniform numbers - that are sweeping the world of basketball.

title: Nicu Haas, Anthropologist, Dies
description: Dr. Nicu Haas, an Israeli scientist who helped in the discovery of the only known remains of a man crucified in the time of Jesus, died last week after 13 years in a coma, colleagues said today. He was 60 years old.

description: County Natwest Ltd. announced today that it would acquire Wood Mackenzie & Company, an Edinburgh-based brokerage house, in the most significant consolidation move in the British securities industry since the worldwide stock market plunge in October.

title: Santa Fe Ends Talks With Henley Group
description: The Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had broken off takeover talks with the Henley Group, which holds 14.7 percent of Santa Fe's stock and which had been seeking close to $8 billion in financing to take over the diversified railroad company.

title: Article 607987 -- No Title
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company announced today that it plans to build a $2 billion development of offices, stores and apartments on the Hudson River site where it has manufactured soap and detergents since 1847.

title: German Coal Output Cut
description: West Germany's troubled coal industry will cut annual production by 16 to 18 percent, costing 30,000 jobs, under a pact reached today by Government, industry and union officials. Economics Minister Martin Bangemann, who led the Government delegation in the latest round of talks on restructuring the industry, said coal output would be cut back by between 13 million metric tons and 15 million tons. The coal industry currently employs about 160,000 people.

description: Good news is not confined to the atomic front this week. An influential food journal reports that midget vegetables are passe and will soon disappear from fancy restaurants.

description: The judge in the Howard Beach trial yesterday refused the request of a jury deliberating the fate of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter to visit the scene of an attack on three black men a year ago.

description: At least 57 schoolchildren on a holiday outing to a library were killed and 58 were injured today when their bus collided with a train at an unmarked crossing, hospital and security personnel said. [ Reuters, quoting police sources, reported that the toll could reach 65. ] Most of the victims were thought to be about 10 years old.

description: On Tuesday morning, after the elaborate pageantry of the arrival ceremony for Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the South Lawn of the White House, President Reagan escorted his guest to the Oval Office and promptly committed a minor and intentional breach of etiquette.

description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had lowered its rating on $35 billion of long-term debt of the General Motors Corporation. The rating company said it had taken the action because of G.M.'s declining earnings and the auto maker's reduced share of the passenger vehicle market.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, already weakened in the frontcourt by injuries to Tim McCormick, a 7-foot center, and Roy Hinson, a 6-9 forward, suffered another setback yesterday. Chris Welp, a rookie 7-foot center from the University of Washington, was told after undergoing arthroscopic surgery that he would be sidelined for a year because of ligament and cartilage damage in his knee. Welp, the 76ers' first-round draft choice, had been used sparingly until Hinson and McCormick were sidelined. . . . Walter Davis of the Phoenix Suns, a six-time All-Star who has been hospitalized for more than a week with a disk problem in his lower back, was placed on the injured list on Thursday and will miss a minimum of five games. . . . Joe Wolf, a Los Angeles Clippers rookie forward from North Carolina, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair torn cartilage in his right knee and is expected to miss about three weeks of play. . . . description: David Frishberg, the Los Angeles-based songwriter and performer, is a consummate craftsman of pop-jazz songs whose lyrics have the cutting precision of the best light verse. In the refinement of his language, he is equaled only by Stephen Sondheim among contemporary American songwriters. But instead of theater songs, he writes jazz tunes filtered through the climate of Hollywood movie music. And instead of reflecting on love and death, his lyrics present dour, up-to-the-minute sociological observation.
