title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Gretzky Passes Esposito: Wayne Gretzky reached another scoring plateau, and Grant Fuhr stood out in goal in leading the Oilers to a 2-1 triumph last night over the Vancouver Canucks at Edmonton. Gretzky moved into sole possession of third place on the league's career scoring list with 1,591 points. Gretzky drew an assist on Jari Kurri's second-period goal to move him a point ahead of Phil Esposito. Gretzky is now 259 points behind Gordie Howe's record 1,850. The Rangers' Marcel Dionne is second. The assist was Grezky's 1,023d, leaving him only 26 behind Howe's career record of 1,049. Fuhr, meanwhile, came within 14 minutes of recording his second straight shutout. Before Greg Adams slapped in a rebound on a power play, Fuhr set a team record by running his shutout string to 124 minutes 26 seconds.(AP) Red Wings 3, Flyers 3: Bob Probert scored with 6:10 remaining in the third period to give the Red Wings the tie. The Flyers extended their unbeaten streak to 5-0-2. With Philadelphia leading, 3-2, Steve Yzerman intercepted a clearing pass by a defenseman, Kjell Samuelsson, in the faceoff circle and slid the puck to Probert, cutting in front of Mark LaForest. The goaltender got a piece of Probert's shot, but the puck dribbled through his pads for Probert's 12th goal of the season. (AP) N.B.A. Pistons 114, Bullets 108: Joe Dumars scored 8 of his 22 points in the final 4 minutes 25 seconds last night as Detroit held off Washington at home. It was the Pistons' fifth consecutive victory, improving their record to 12-5. Detroit led, 82-67, with 3:40 remaining in the third quarter, but the Bullets, getting 10 points from John Williams and 9 from Terry Catledge, outscored the Pistons by 30-16 to cut their lead to 98-97 with 6:36 remaining. It was still a 1-point margin, with Detroit leading by 101-100, when Dumars went to work, hitting four free throws and two jumpers.(AP) Mavericks 108, Suns 104: Sam Perkins scored 6 points in overtime, including two free throws with two seconds left, to carry Dallas past Phoenix. Coach John MacLeod gained the home victory over the Suns in his first meeting against the club that dropped him last February, after 14 years with the franchise. Perkins had two field goals and two free throws in the overtime. (AP) Bucks 125, Trail Blazers 112: Jack Sikma scored 25 of his 35 points in the second half, and Terry Cummings added 28 points for Milwaukee at home. The Bucks used a 16-7 run in the fourth quarter to extend a 94-93 lead. Paul Pressey scored 7 points and Cummings 5 in the spurt. Portland has lost three straight after winning nine in a row. (AP) Golf Hulbert and Tway Lead: Mike Hulbert and Bob Tway shot a 13-under-par 59 yesterday to take a five-stroke lead at the halfway point of the $600,000 Chrysler PGA team championship in West Palm Beach, Fla. Hulbert and Tway, runners-up a year ago, had 11 birdies and an eagle at the Palm Beach Polo and Country Club for a two-round 120 that was 24 under. The teams of Jeff Sluman-Robert Wrenn and Fred Couples-Mike Donald were tied for second place at 125. Jim Nelford-Richard Zokol were a stroke farther back in the best-ball tournament. Last year, Hulbert and Tway led for three rounds but lost the tournament by a stroke. The 72-team field will be reduced to at least 28 after the third round today.(AP) College Basketball 705th Assist at Delaware: Paurence Chisholm of Delaware became only the 12th player in college basketball history to surpass 700 career assists in a 63-53 victory last night at Columbia. Chisholm had 7 assists to raise his career total to 705. Delaware (5-1) held a 26-25 halftime lead, helped by Chisholm's 700th assist on a 3-point basket by Tony Tucker. Columbia (1-4) tied the score at 28-28 on a free throw by Trevor Holland with 17:34 remaining. But a basket by Chisholm and two by Elsworth Bowers put Delaware ahead to stay.(AP) Darts Bristow Wins: Eric Bristow of London, beat John Lowe in less than 20 minutes and won the Lucky Lights International Challenge of Champions tournament in the Penta Hotel yesterday. Bristow earned $10,000, and Lower, who is also British, received $5,000. Lowe won the tournament for the last three years. In his first appearance in the 32-player tournemant, Bristow beat Lowe, 4-0, in the four-of-seven-game match. Terri Marcello of Morrisville, Pa., won the women's bracket, 4-0, over Connie Sroka of Fort Collins, Colo., and earned $5,000. Marcello returned to competition last August after five years' retirement. Sroka won the North American ladies' title earlier this year.

title: Mullin Suspended
description: Chris Mullin was suspended for last night's game by the Golden State Warriors, a day after he missed a practice for the second time this season. Mullin failed to show up for practice on Thursday and was barred from practice and the game against the Atlanta Hawks. Coach George Karl, who met with team officials Thursday night to discuss the situation, said the starting guard would be fined. Mullin's scoring average has improved to 17.7 points a game this season from 15.1 last season. The Warriors were 3-13 going into last night's game. Mullin, a former St. John's all-American, in his third pro season, missed a practice last month. On Thursday, he told Karl by telephone that he would be late for practice, then called a second time to say he wouldn't make it ''for personal reasons.''

Each winner, chosen as the best inventor of his or her grade level in the state, will receive a $200 savings bond, and the teachers and schools will receive larger grants.

title: PRESIDENT UPBEAT ON RELATIONSHIP WITH GORBACHEV
description: President Reagan, obviously upbeat and enthusiastic about the summit meeting that ended Thursday, said today that he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev had established ''an entirely different relationship'' from what existed previously.

title: Southern Broadcast Group Cancels Candidate Forums
description: The Southern Educational Communications Association, citing a lack of money, on Thursday canceled two sets of debates among Presidential candidates scheduled for Jan. 23-24 and Feb. 20-21. The forums, to have been broadcast live on public radio and television, were to have focused on issues of interest to the South, which holds a dozen primaries and caucuses on March 8.

title: White Georgia Clay Turns Into Cash
description: Kaolin, a white clay that is in growing demand, is found in such high concentrations in central Georgia that it has become the kaolin capital of the world and produced a $500-million-a-year industry.

title: Jury Starts Deliberations in Deaver Case
description: The perjury trial of Michael K. Deaver went to the jury today, and the jurors deliberated for six hours before recessing for the weekend after a Federal district judge instructed them to disregard defense contentions that alcoholism had impaired Mr. Deaver's memory.

title: Devils Resemble Mortals at Home
description: The Calgary Flames completely outclassed the Devils tonight, on ice that has offered little resistance to New Jersey's skating so far this season.

title: chess Game a Quick Draw
description: The 22d game of the world chess championship between the titleholder, Gary Kasparov, and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was agreed drawn today after just 19 moves. The score is tied, 11 to 11, with just two games remaining.

title: U.S. Officials Assail a Bill on Covert Actions
description: The Reagan Administration expressed strong opposition today to legislation that would require Presidents to tell Congress about all covert operations within 48 hours, saying it could ''seriously impair'' the conduct of foreign affairs.

description: Iranian oil officials said today that France and Iran had agreed in principle to end a French ban on the purchase of Iranian oil that had been imposed in the summer.

description: In this modern age, the whole world is supposed to know instantly when anything of interest occurs. If an exciting new composer or performer crops up in Iceland, he or she is theoretically a household name in Argentina by morning.

title: Church's Chicken Stake Purchased

In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had purchased the shares as an investment. Earlier this year, Church's, the nation's second-largest fast-food chicken operation, rejected a $469 million offer from a group of former company executives.

title: Bridge; From China to Netherlands, A Tough Test Upon Arrival
description: To go halfway round the world to play in an international tournament and then face difficult problems on the very first deal would be a challenge for anyone. Wang Jung-ren of China passed this test on the diagramed deal recently.

title: FEARS OF VIOLENCE DOMINATE KOREA CAMPAIGN'S LAST DAYS
description: South Korea's presidential campaign entered a climactic phase today in a swirl of warnings about violence and charges that brutality and fraud were being used to win votes.

title: NATO Foreign Ministers Praise Treaty and Urge Senate Approval
description: NATO foreign ministers today hailed the Soviet-American accord on intermediate-range nuclear missiles as a ''treaty without precedent in the history of arms control,'' and called for its speedy approval by the United States Senate.

title: Jardine Maps Defense
description: Jardine Strategic Holdings Ltd. said it would defend in court its right to terminate an offer for a 20 percent stake in Bear Stearns Companies Inc. On Thursday, the New York-based investment banker said it was suing Jardine in Federal court, contending that the Hong Kong company wrongfully terminated its agreement to buy a stake in the company for about $390 million. ''The lawsuits are without merit and will be vigorously defended,'' said a Jardine statement quoting the managing director, Brian Powers. ''We were entirely within our legal rights in terminating the offer and acted in the best interests of our shareholders in doing so.''

She said the Brooklyn District Attorney's office had coerced her into making the false accusation, according to her lawyer.

title: TV: 'Mystery!' Opens Agatha Christie Series
description: Public television's ''Mystery!'', packaged by WGBH of Boston and underwritten by Mobil, is on a nifty winning streak these days. Having just finished a splendid trio of Dorothy L. Sayers adaptations, with Edward Petherbridge as Lord Peter Wimsey, the series is now returning to Agatha Christie's Miss Marple stories, once again starring Joan Hickson as the venerable but dogged sleuth. For starters, the two-part ''Nemesis,'' written by T. R. Bowen and directed by David Tucker, gets under way on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock this evening. It's a gem. ''Nemesis,'' published in 1971, was the last of the Miss Marple novels. The story begins as, in Miss Marple's words, a crossword puzzle without any clues. Her old friend Jason Rafiel, a cockney millionaire, has died and left instructions in his will for Miss Marple to ''investigate something.'' The only requirement is for her to become part of a bus tour of ''historic homes and gardens.''

Chaining such prisoners to their hospital beds is not just cruel; it's superfluous. But the guards insist that this is a matter of collective bargaining, not humanity. They will have a hard time making that case; meanwhile, why do the courts insist on putting back the chains?

Two more engineers were seriously wounded and airlifted to Lima, 350 miles north, for medical treatment.

They said the King, accompanied by Prime Minister Zaid al-Rifai, was also expected to visit Bahrain, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar and Oman during his three-day trip.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC SOCIETY: 100 Years of Adventure and Discovery. By C. D. B. Bryan. (Abrams, $45.) If any American institution merits a five-and-a-half-pound $45-birthday card celebrating its centennial, it is the National Geographic Society. The society's superbly produced flagship magazine has guided generations of Americans from the benthos to the cosmos and is, I warrant, the only periodical regarded as impossible (if not downright illegal) to throw away; tons of issues are passed down like family heirlooms. The society wisely chose an outsider to document its history: C. D. B. Bryan (the author of ''Friendly Fire'' and other books), who, with felicitous anecdote and meticulous detail, has written an engaging account of the Geographic's growth from a charter membership of 165 with practically no assets to an international juggernaut with 11 million members in 170 countries and annual revenues of more than $350 million. He confronts forthrightly the most common criticism of the magazine: that, until relatively recently, it sedulously avoided controversy, ignored such unpleasantness as poverty and reported only the sunny side of war. Optimism, he points out, was the magazine's mandate. One of the guiding principles set down by Gilbert H. Grosvenor, the society's director in the first years of this century, was that ''only what is of a kindly nature is printed about any country or people, everything unpleasant or unduly critical being avoided.'' As good as the writing is, however, readers may delight most in the profuse illustrations, for, as befits a biography of a magazine whose photography has no peer, the anniversary tome is replete with pictures both fascinating and breathtaking. In all, the birthday book is, like the ''new'' Geographic itself, exhaustively researched, gracefully and precisely written and splendidly illustrated.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: LEAD: RADIOS: The Golden Age. By Philip Collins. (Chronicle Books, Paper, $14.95.) This, as Casey Stengel might say, is a ''splendid book'' - especially for someone who lived through the early days of radio and has a touch of nostalgia. ''Radios'' is also a shocking reminder of how our rapidly moving society devours not only material things but also our remembrance of events.

title: Letters and the Law
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr.'s primary legacy -his contribution to the reshaping of a society - is in the public domain. But Dr. King also left something more tangible - certain letters and other documents - whose ownership is now in dispute. Last week, Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, filed suit against Boston University, demanding that the school relinquish 83,000 documents that Dr. King deposited at the university four years before he was murdered in 1968. Officials at the school, where the civil rights leader earned a doctorate in theology, maintain that the papers were a permanent gift. Mrs. King's lawyers said it was her husband's oft-expressed wish that some other final repository be established. Mrs. King proposed to house them, with other King papers, at the King Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta.

description: I BRING this up now because Arthur is dead. I heard about his passing thirdhand, which is not surprising if you consider how many years we were out of touch.

description: Sara Emily Weiner, the daughter of Jane Brown of New York, and Dr. Jay Weiner of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to John Verneuille, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Verneuille of Lindenhurst, L.I. Judge Edward J. Kiley of the Suffolk County District Court officiated at the West Babylon, L.I., home of the bridegroom's brother, Robert Verneuille Jr. Mrs. Verneuille is a field service engineer with the Digital Equipment Corporation in Melville, L.I. She and her husband graduated from the Suburban Technical School in Hauppauge, L.I. The bride's mother, whose professional name is Jane Raskin, is a senior editor in the equity research department at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York. Her father is an internist in Danbury. The bride is a granddaughter of A. H. Raskin, who was the national labor correspondent, assistant editorial page editor and labor columnist for The New York Times; he is now retired.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Nuggets 131, 76ers 121: Jay Vincent scored a season-high 33 points as the Denver Nuggets built a 19-point lead and then held off the 76ers yesterday in Philadelphia. After trailing by 87-68 early in the third quarter, the 76ers closed the deficit to 120-116 with 2 minutes 9 seconds to play when Gerald Henderson tapped in a missed free throw. But Alex English of the Nuggets, who finished with 30 points, connected on a jump shot from the side and Vincent hit a layup and a free throw to put Denver ahead by 125-116 with 52 seconds remaining. (AP) Bulls 112, Rockets 103: Michael Jordan scored 31 of his 44 points in the second half, including 18 in the final quarter. Jordan, who scored the Bulls' last 10 points, added nine assists, five steals and five blocked shots as the Bulls ran their record to 14-6. (AP) Trail Blazers 108, Pacers 101: Clyde Drexler scored 28 points and the Portland Trail Blazers held off a late Indiana rally. Portland led, 103-94, when Scott Skiles's 3-pointer cut the margin to 6 with 47 seconds remaining.(AP) Hockey Capitals 2, Blackhawks 1: In Landover, Md., Mike Gartner scored one goal and assisted on another, and Pete Peeters made 26 saves as Washington extended Chicago's losing streak to eight games. The Blackhawks are without a victory in their last 15 road games. (AP) Sabres 3, Bruins 3: Randy Burridge scored on a pass from Steve Kasper in the opening minute of the third period as Boston rallied from a two-goal deficit on home ice. Adam Creighton of Buffalo and Geoff Courtnall of Boston had two goals apiece before Burridge tied the score by taking Kasper's pass from the corner and beating the goalie, Tom Barrasso, from close in.(AP) Soviet Selects 6, Team U.S.A. 4: In Cincinnati, Vyacheslav Lavrov and Sergei Tepliakov scored 18 seconds apart in the third period last night to lead the Russians to the exhibition-game victory. The quick scores enabled them to even their record at 1-1 in the eight-game series against the Americans, which continues tonight at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I. The Soviet Selects are an all-star squad secondary to the Soviet national team. Craig Janney's deflected shot put the United States Olympic team ahead, 1-0, in a ragged first period, in which both teams wasted opportunities with sloppy passes.(AP) Skiing Boyd Returns to Victory Site: Rob Boyd of Canada edged Pirmin Zurbriggen and Brian Stemmle, in Santa Cristina, Italy, to win the second men's downhill race of the season. Boyd, of Whistler Mountain, British Columbia, triumphed exactly one year after his first victory here brought him to the attention of the Alpine ski world. His winning time was 2 minutes 2.29 seconds down the icy, 3,445-meter-long Saslong run with a vertical drop of 839 meters. (AP) Figini Dominates Race: Michela Figini, the Olympic downhill gold medalist, displaying impressive dominance in a Super-G race, scored yesterday the fourth straight World Cup victory for the Swiss women's team as a streak of American bad luck continued with a spill by Tori Pillinger of Park City, Utah. Although bruised in a fall after capturing the downhill Friday, Figini mastered the tricky, bumpy Torrent course with a time of 1 minute 30.21 seconds to beat Silvia Eder of Austria by 1.05 seconds. The victory sent the 21-year-old Figini to the top of the overall World Cup standing with 77 points in seven events. Pillinger, starting as No. 19, lost her balance after the last gate and crashed against the right finishing post after overturning twice. X-rays showed a fracture of her right femur, or thighbone. Pillinger's fall meant that four of the top five American women in last year's World Cup competition are now out.(AP) Golf Tway and Hulbert Lead: Bob Tway and Mike Hulbert fired four birdies each for an 8-under-par 64 to maintain their five-stroke lead after three rounds of the Chrysler PGA team championship in Boca Raton, Fla. Tied for second place were the teams of Fred Couples and Mike Donald and defending champions Gary Hallberg and Scott Hoch. Johnny Miller and Peter Jacobsen were another stroke back. Tway and Hulbert built their lead with scores of 61 and 59 in the first two rounds. (AP) Squash Racquets Labossier and Doyle Post Upset: Hugh Labossier of Seattle and Bill Doyle of Greenwich, Conn., upset Peter Briggs of Ithaca, N.Y., and Mark Talbott of Barrington, R.I., 15-10, 11-15, 15-9, 15-12, yesterday to move into today's semifinals of the Xerox North American Open doubles championship at the Greenwich Country Club. The winners, who had to play a qualifying round to make the draw, will face top-seeded Ned Edwards of New York City and David Johnson of Southport, Conn., who defeated Victor Harding of Toronto and Ralph Howe of Clearwater, Fla., in a three-hour match, 14-15, 15-11, 13-15, 15-10, 15-4. Horse Racing Soar to the Stars Soars: Soar to the Stars took the lead after entering the stretch and went on to a three-length victory in the $120,600 Gallant Fox Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $650,000 17 Lawrence Lane 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 50-year-old waterfront brick colonial; library, family room, 3 fireplaces, 1 acre; taxes $6,700. title: The Costs of Cutting an Education Short
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, the Board of Education in New York reported that 55 percent of those who entered city high schools in 1982 did not graduate in 1986. Such numbers have been heard before, in New York and elsewhere, but educators, politicians, business leaders and others are showing new concern about the problem of high school dropouts. One reason is a growing belief that the American economy can no longer afford to lose the talents of so many young people. Another is fear that the country cannot afford a polarized population of educational haves and have-nots.

title: CALCULATING THE COST OF THE GRACEFUL DEER
description: Deer [ ''Deer Issue Is to Be Explored,'' Nov. 15 ] are to northern Westchester what alligators are to southern Florida: predators. Alligators wound and eat and sometimes kill people. Dear eat shrubbery painstakingly and lovingly planted and replaced by optimistic homeowners.

title: OPEC Unable To Set Accord On Oil Output
description: After four days of futile talks, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries failed today to reach an agreement to end the rampant discounts and runaway oil production that are undercutting the cartel.

title: Howard Beach Jury Requests Testimony
description: The jury in the Howard Beach murder trial, in its third day of deliberations, listened again yesterday to the testimony of a woman who told of hearing a black man plead with a group of white youths who were beating him.

title: 'Star Wars' Isn't Tied To Pact, Reagan Says
description: President Reagan said today that he would never give up plans to develop the ''Star Wars'' space-based missile defense system to achieve a strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Racial Split Feared in Bid to Remove Black Mayor in Virginia
description: Three years ago, when he was sworn in as the first black Mayor of this old Navy town, James W. Holley 3d said it was ''a city on the verge of greatness.'' Today he is not so sure. True, the dramatic renovation of Portsmouth's once-crumbling downtown proceeds apace, giving the city a spruced-up colonial look and expanding its tax base. True, the shipyards resound with the fevered activity required to keep the 600-ship Navy fit, welders' sparks flying off the huge gray warships along the waterfront. True, nobody jokes much anymore about Portsmouth being the ugly stepsister of neighboring Norfolk, which was never noted for its beauty.

title: COMMUNITIES SEEK OPTIONS TO STATE HEALTH PLAN
description: LEAD: LOCAL governments and some school districts in the county, facing unexpected rises of as much as 70 percent in the health-insurance premiums they pay on behalf of their employees, are exploring the feasibility of withdrawing from the state health plan and becoming self-insured.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN PLANTS COME BY MAIL
description: LEAD: I have often thought, as I sent in my plant orders, that being a mail order nurseryman must be a terribly difficult job. It's hard enough to grow a number of different kinds of plants with all their varying needs, but to undertake sending them to customers all over this large country with its different kinds of climates seems to me a daunting assignment.

title: Attack Victim Is Healing
description: SOME police investigators called it the most savage crime they had ever seen: On Aug. 23, 22-year-old Cheryl Ickson was kidnapped, beaten and left for dead in a construction ditch near Alpine, N.J.

title: U.N. Belt Tightening Affects Recruitment
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: IF IT were not for progress and all it demolishes, many a collection of nostalgia would not be on the bookshelves today.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ANDRE WATTS AT LEHMAN Andre Watts, the 38-year-old-pianist whose debut at the age of 16 -when he substituted for the ailing Glenn Gould in a New York Philharmonic concert - brought him instant success, will perform at 7 o'clock this evening in the Performing Arts Center of Lehman College.

title: Cold Winter on Wall Street
description: MAYOR Keith L. Gillins wants to know if there is an investment banker in the house. Fillmore, Utah, the city he runs, needs a new pool where children can learn to swim; the old one, he said, is ''pretty dilapidated.''

title: Music: Henry Threadgill, Performance of 'Run Silent'
description: LIFE and death, form and void, symphonic scale and improvisation -Henry Threadgill tackled the big ones in ''Run Silent, Run Deep, Run Loud, Run High.'' Commissioned by the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival and the New York State Council on the Arts, the hour-long piece for strings, percussion, voices and Mr. Threadgill's alto saxophone had its premiere Friday night. It was Mr. Threadgill's magnum opus to date, and - as rarely happens with this composer - the results fell short of his ambitions. In trying to be somber and expansive, the piece ended up stilted and dutiful.

title: THE BOSS WAS A HUSTLER OR, HOW I GOT MY BIBLE
description: IN the fall of 1937, I got my first job in New York - a rather odd one, and not at all what I had expected when I started looking. Life magazine, which had begun publication under the auspices of Time Inc. the year before, was expanding its staff, and I had heard that the chances of editorial employment for a young man with my background were pretty good. On the September morning when I headed for Manhattan for an interview, however, I overtook Edwin Robert Rumball-Petre on the way to the subway in Brooklyn Heights. He was a good friend of my father -an impressive Englishman, tall, heavyset, ruddy, with an intimidating two-tone beard. What I liked most about him was that although he claimed to be an ordained minister - between churches, as he put it - he was fond of advancing outrageous opinions on everything including religion.

title: BAN ON SALES OF BILLFISH IS DUE BY END OF MONTH
description: LEAD: THE Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council, an advisory organization that oversees fishing practices in waters that include Long Island's, is expected to recommend to the Secretary of Commerce this month that the sale of billfish be banned next year. This would affect American and international fishermen and would be the first time that the United

title: Ravitch Urges a Stronger Board of Ethics for New York City
description: The chairman of the New York City Charter Revision Commission urged last week that the city's Board of Ethics, which monitors the conduct of municipal employees, be strengthened by establishing a more detailed list of prohibited activities for workers.

title:
DINING OUT;
PAUL MA COMES TO CROSS RIVER
description: LEAD: DINERS familiar with Paul Ma's China Kitchen in Yorktown Heights will be pleased to know that Mr. Ma has opened a second, spiffier restaurant in Cross River, one marked by a luxury of space, dramatically high ceilings and comfortable chairs. Situated in the angle of Cross River Plaza, this new dining spot brings to another part of the county pleasing aspects of the old: a personal rendition of Shandong cooking, thought to be the richest, most varied and oldest of Chinese regional cuisines (Mr.

title: City Hall Notes; Koch Meets His Match in a Talkative Nobel Poet
description: Rare is it for anyone to get the rhetorical best of Mayor Koch, but that is precisely what happened not long ago, right in the Mayor's office.

title:
ART;
SURPRISES LURK IN WITTY COLLAGES
description: LEAD: IN the art world, there are no sacred territories, no precincts that, once invaded and captured by artists, however revered, are not fair game for others of their number. In fact, the very works of the masters often become the object of intense scrutiny by artists who cannot be considered copyists or followers, but who find in art history the raw material of their own invention.

title: Wagner Is Winner Of Division III Title
description: Wagner College established superiority early today and went on to win the Division III football championship by defeating Dayton, 19-3, in the Amos Alonzo Stagg Bowl.

title: COUNTRY COMFORTS FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: STONY BROOK'S Country House is much like a big Christmas tree now, awash with light and beckoning to all who see it. The large white Colonial is arresting at any time of year, but during the holiday season it's especially dazzling.

title: Bush, Fresh From the Summit, Tackles Iowa
description: Vice President Bush campaigned across Iowa today as the candidate of peace, hoping his presence at the summit meeting would help him here.

title: FOREIGN MONEY, U.S. FEARS
description: LEAD: THE CAPITOL CORRI-dors were crowded this fall with hundreds of lobbyists who had descended upon House and Senate negotiators working on the final stages of the omnibus trade bill. Few were as resolute as those lobbying against a House-passed amendment that would require major foreign investors in America to disclose their identities and holdings.

title: Eastern Michigan Tops San Jose St.
description: Though he spent most of today blocking, Craig Ostrander, an Eastern Michigan flanker, knew he could get open when he needed to. All he had to do was convince Coach Jim Harkema.

title: SHULTZ ASKS NATO TO RAISE SPENDING ON NON-ATOM ARMS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz issued a plea to NATO nations today to increase spending for conventional weapons.

title: 'PLEASE BABY. PLEASE BABY. PLEASE ...'
description: SPIKE LEE'S GOTTA HAVE IT Inside Guerrilla Filmmaking. By Spike Lee. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Fireside/Simon & Schuster. Paper, $9.95.

title: Judith Lynn Ambrose Weds Philip Duncan Ewald
description: Judith Lynn Ambrose, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Bond Ambrose of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Philip Duncan Ewald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Philip Ewald of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. John Calvin Knox Jackson performed the ceremony at the Basking Ridge Presbyterian Church.

title: A Player Who Let His Skill Do the Talking
description: FIVE YEARS AGO, ALLEN MEYER watched a television vignette about a blue-eyed baseball player who was born during the Civil War in Houcktown, Ohio. In 14 major-league seasons, he had a .288 batting average, with 2,054 hits and 597 stolen bases.

title: Hector Babenco Harvests 'Ironweed'
description: HOOKING HIS RIGHT HAND across his left arm in a marksman's pose, Hector Babenco aimed an imaginary weapon downhill, across the canyon and past Beverly Hills toward Hollywood, then mimed the snap of a trigger. ''I am not part of this Hollywood vortex,'' the director said, grinning. ''I feel now like a. . .a. . .how you say? A sniper.''

title: Laurel Smith to Marry William K. Doggett 3d
description: Hedrick Smith of Chevy Chase, Md., and Ann B. Smith of Arlington, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laurel Ann Smith to William Kirk Doggett 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Doggett Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: TRUE COLORS
description: BEHIND EVERY WOMAN, there is a closetful of unused makeup - a lipstick that is almost the right shade of red, a pile of slightly garish eye shadows, a foundation that tints the skin an eerie shade of green. You'd think that all of these bungled purchases would help to keep cosmetics companies in business. The truth is, a number of companies hope to ring up more sales by reducing these errors.

title: Frank G. Boyce, Educator, Dies; Leader of Foreign Study Program
description: Frank G. Boyce, who served for nearly a quarter-century as president of the Experiment in International Living, an exchange program for students, died Wednesday at Brattleboro Memorial Hospital in Vermont after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in West Brattleboro, Vt.

title: Sri Lanka: A Nation Disintegrates
description: IN AN ISLAND in a pristine lake near Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka, gunmen guard the sleek new Parliament building, which a terrorist bomb ripped through last August, wounding the Prime Minister and barely missing the President. Downtown, the scattered vacant lots and burned-out buildings are remnants of the riots of July 1983, when hundreds of Tamils were pulled from their homes and burned alive, or hacked to death with axes in the streets.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
CARDS WITH PURPOSE
description: LEAD: Holiday greeting cards are being offered for the fourth consecutive year by the Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in North Tarrytown. Proceeds from the sale of the cards will benefit the Phelps Hospice Inc., which offers care to the terminally ill.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: NOT too long ago Miriam Paar, the wife of the television personality Jack Paar, was walking in Manhattan, looking hither and yon, when her eye fell on untied shoe laces flopping from a pair of Reeboks. She didn't give them a second thought until she observed that this was a peculiarity common to a number of teen-agers, all of whom were sporting untied shoe laces that frequently dragged along the pavement.

title: Boston's Statue Problem: John Kennedy's Coat Style
description: The committee assigned to choose a statue of John F. Kennedy to stand outside the Statehouse here has run into a problem: no one seems certain if the top button of the 35th President of the United States's suit coat should be buttoned.

title: What Hath Liszt Wrought? Jean Sibelius, Henri Dutilleux and John Cage.
description: THE 20th CENTURY HAS RECEIVED the gift of Liszt's piano music with puzzlement. How is one to spend so considerable a bequest, if at all? Are its assets, in other words, to be saved and reinvested or else repudiated as tainted and regressive?

title: Three Sisters and a Death in the 80's
description: Cassandra Life was a familiar customer at Jay's Restaurant. She came alone to drink coffee, work crossword puzzles and chat shyly with the waitresses. They were protective of the petite 81-year-old, whom they called Sandy.

title:
SOUP KITCHENS AND WINTRY EVENINGS: RECALLING STRUGGLES OF THE NEEDIEST;
Widening the Effort To Aid the Vulnerable
description: LEAD: The most chilling aspect of recent media attention to incidents of child abuse is that tragedies such as these occur much more often than we want to believe. Over the last 12 months, agencies of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York have been confronted with case after case.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO PRESERVE A CHRISTMAS TREE
description: LEAD: EVERGREENS have long played an important role in winter holiday decor. In fact, primitive northern societies used evergreens to celebrate midwinter festivals long before the establishment of Christmas.

title: Cynthia E. Pierce, Executive, Is Wed
description: Cynthia Ellen Pierce, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Pierce of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Edmund R. Belak Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Belak of Syracuse. The Rev. Avery C. Manchester performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Zoning Dispute Extends Olympia's Run
description: AFTER struggling 21 months to obtain a special zoning district, the developers of an apartment building planned on the site of the Olympia Theater on Broadway at West 107th Street say it may still be years before construction begins because a Toronto movie-theater chain has a long-term lease on the theater.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE GREAT DIMPOLE OAK By Janet Taylor Lisle. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. 135 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $11.95. (Ages 9 to 11)

title: The Spending Spree That Won't Go Away
description: JOINING ranks in a show of conspicuous confidence, America's big spenders so far are making some concessions - but not many - to the blows of Black Monday.

title: UTILITY IS PRUNING NOW FOR POWER LATER
description: NORTHEAST UTILITIES has a tree-trimming program that has something to do with bright lights but nothing at all to do with Christmas. The utility is engaged in a five-year program of cutting tree limbs that might threaten power lines in a storm, in hopes of cutting the number of power failures.

title: Miss Ferrone To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerard G. Ferrone of Centre Island, L.I., and Ashland, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Francesca Olivia Ferrone to William Carter Gould, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Perkins Gould of Marblehead, Mass. The couple plan to marry in April.

title: SEOUL RIVALS VOW ECONOMIC CHANGE
description: For years South Korea's economy has been the country's success story. A team of economic specialists guided development, virtually free from public scrutiny or political pressure.

title: INSIDE
description: Troubles in Cambodia In a country short of food, money and expertise, a longer than usual dry season may seriously cut back crops when the chief aid donor, the Soviet Union, is complaining that its assistance is being wasted. Page 26. Surrogate Mothers at Issue State legislatures are preparing to consider a variety of bills to regulate surrogate motherhood. Page 42.

title: Monitoring Drugs for the aged
description: MADAME F., AN elderly Frenchwoman, had been unaccountably depressed for a few months, so her husband of 50 years tried to cheer her up with a brief trip. But the vacation had to be cut short when she fainted a couple of times, again for no apparent reason, and the couple returned to their home in a village in Normandy.

title:
INVESTING;
Premium Price, Negative Return
description: LEAD: THE Z-Seven Fund stands out among closed-end investment funds less for its performance - net asset value has sagged 18 percent since January - than for investors' persistent willingness to pay a premium over net worth to own the fund's shares. Last week, Z-Seven was trading at about $14.50 on the Pacific Stock

title: In the Cities: Replacing the Downtown Mall With Traffic
description: IN the early 1970's, officials in this Chicago suburb closed their two main shopping streets to traffic, planted trees and grass and flowers where there had been concrete, and turned the whole area into a landscaped pedestrian mall. The hope was to revitalize a fading downtown, and lure back shoppers and retailers from those other malls, the large regional shopping centers that had stolen them away.

title: Networks' Approach To the '88 Campaign Takes On Lean Look
description: The three major television networks have drastically altered their approach to covering Presidential politics for 1988, no longer assigning correspondents and crews to travel with every candidate, as in past campaigns.

title: City's Mood Dips From the Celebratory to the Cautionary
description: JUST last spring, New York City was, as its political leaders were delighted to report, wealthy. It was rolling in money that was going to buy all sorts of things that politicians like to give to the people who elect them: More police officers, more teachers, better schools, cleaner streets.

title: Troy State Reclaims Division II Crown
description: Mike Turk ran for two touchdowns, including a 51-yarder with 1 minute 43 seconds remaining, as Troy State defeated Portland State, 31-17, today to win its second National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II championship in the last four years.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 29 about buying secondhand records in London referred incorrectly to the saxophonist and flutist Bud Shank. Mr. Shank is alive, in Port Townsend, Wash.

title: Siamese Twins Recovering
description: MORE than three months after they were separated in a dramatic, 22-hour-long operation, two Siamese twins from Ulm, West Germany, remain in stable condition in their private room at the Children's Center of the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions in Baltimore.

title: Gooden Knows The True Score
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Joel Bruce Rosen And Miss Swartz To Marry in June
description: Addi-lyn Swartz and Joel Bruce Rosen, the son of Mrs. Lester Rosen of Boston and the late Mr. Rosen, plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Harry M. Swartz of Rumson, N.J., have announced.

title: Article 792187 -- No Title
description: It was a festive occasion with red and black balloons, T-shirts bearing a double-headed eagle, traditional dancing and patriotic speeches marking the 75th anniversary of Albanian independence.

title: New Australian Dining Treat: Fresh Salmon From Tasmania
description: UNTIL the last decade or so, a hefty slab of meat - at lunch, sometimes at breakfast and almost always at dinner - was the staple of the Australian diet. A meat pie, oozing with tomato sauce, was the closest thing to a national dish. Even cafes selling fish and chips still boast signs saying, ''Fish and grills,'' as if to say that fish is too light for the hearty Aussie appetite.

title: Elissa Von Heill To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. William H. Von Heill of Syosset, L.I., and Dunewood, Fire Island, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elissa Ann Von Heill, to George Hartwell Hylton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Hylton of Danville, Va.

title: WIDE MIAMI INQUIRY INTO POLICE IS SEEN
description: With the second corruption trial of police officers in two years in progress here, indications are rising that a Federal investigation of the Miami Police Department might eventually affect 100 to 200 officers.

title: Music: St. Cecilia Chorus, in 'King David'
description: HAVING heard the St. Cecilia Chorus and Orchestra's performance of Honegger's ''King David'' on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, it is not difficult to understand why the work was greeted so favorably at its premiere in 1921. The oratorio tells the grandiose, impassioned story of the Old Testament figure's passage from shepherd to king in music that is both ingratiating and light.

title: The Mutual Admiration Of Fashion And Surrealism Over the Years
description: IF YOU ARE PLANNING to eat your hat, the place to go to put yourself in the right mood is the Fashion Institute of Technology at Seventh Avenue and 21st Street. There, in the exhibition gallery, you will find a hat that looks like a serving of French fries and a hat that looks like a strawberry tart; indeed, a whole array of culinary millinery, spread out like a banquet -headgear got up to resemble a salad, a Christmas pudding, a bowl of onion soup.

title: Notes From Underground
description: NOW THAT A FRACTION of Lester Bangs's writing has been collected between hard covers as ''Psychotic Reactions and Carburetor Dung'' (Knopf), the literary world has noticed what rockers already knew: Bangs was one of the best writers ever to appear on newsprint. When he died in 1982, 33 years old, of complications from flu, American culture lost one of its most astute, most ornery, funniest and most soulful observers - although he would probably have cringed at one or two of those adjectives.

title: Illinois Gets A Bargain At Auction
description: Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois got a bargain of sorts yesterday by spending a mere $330,000 - less than half of what he'd planned - to buy Frank Lloyd Wright furniture and architectural drawings at auction.

title: PHILOSOPHER OF THE FAR-OUT
description: ST. EOM IN THE LAND OF PASAQUAN The Life and Times and Art of Eddie Owens Martin. As told to Tom Patterson. Photographs by Jonathan Williams, Roger Manley and Guy Mendes. Foreword by John Russell. 261 pp. East Haven, Conn.: The Jargon Society/Inland Book Company. $30.

title: In the Suburbs: Bringing Back Front Porches, Town Squares
description: The small clapboard house, with its gabled roof and broad front porch, seemed an unlikely place for a discussion about futuristic city planning. But a group of about 20 architects, developers and planners recently met in Seaside, Fla., in a traditional American-style house on a tree-lined street, at a neighborly intersection, a short walk from a town square, to discuss a vision of future cities modeled after America's small towns.

title: FUNNY ON RADIO, TROUPE TRIES PUBLIC TV SPECIAL
description: DON'T tell them they are just like ''Saturday Night Live.'' They will say they already know that and hope the comparison is being made with the original cast of the late-night NBC-TV show.

title: States Assess Surrogate Motherhood
description: Spurred by growing concern over the social and moral implications of contracts for women to bear children for other women, state legislatures are preparing to confront a spate of bills seeking to regulate the practice.

title: A CHRISTMAS PACKAGE OF SEASONAL MUSIC
description: CHURCHGOERS throughout the county may again look forward to an abundance of Christmas music over the next few weeks, ranging from merry carols to soaring masses to the lyric purity of medieval chants. One of the more ambitious presentations will be staged at 8 P.M. Jan. 15 in the Rye Presbyterian Church, when a two-act Christmas opera called ''Welcome, Jesus!'' will have its premiere performance.

title: NEW HAVEN'S TOP KILLER OF YOUNG MEN IS AIDS
description: LEAD: AIDS is now the leading cause of death among men in New Haven 20 to 45 years old, according to the city's Medical Director, Dr. Fred Gager.

title: Of Real Butter and Big Bucks
description: ''WE ARE DETERMINED to give back to our patrons the rush, excitement, anticipation and curiosity that should be theirs when they leave the techno-regimented world of their daily lives for the fantasy world of escape that is the movies.''

title: Women's Leukemia Rate Higher in 4 Jersey Towns
description: Four small industrial communities in northern New Jersey with histories of chemically contaminated ground water had elevated levels of leukemia among women and girls from 1979 to 1984, according to a study by the New Jersey Department of Health.

title: VILLAGE IN MAINE FIGHTS DEVELOPER
description: Until last spring, Hartford, a town of 500 residents in Maine's western mountains, had so little real estate activity that it did not have a planning board.

title: Dance
description: This will be a particularly rich week with the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center. For one thing, there is Tuesday's company premiere of ''Vespers,'' a ballet by Ulysses Dove. A former lead dancer with Mr. Ailey, Mr. Dove has choreographed three intense works now in the Ailey repertory, as well as the ''Rome'' section of the Robert Wilson-Philip Glass ''Civil WarS.'' Originally choreographed for the Dayton Contemporary Dance Theater, ''Vespers'' is a dance for six women to music by Mikel Rouse. And some of the most beloved dances in the Ailey repertory will be performed on Wednesday in a program called ''In the Black Tradition,'' and on Friday in an all-Ailey program.

title: Lynn Becker Is the Bride Of Robert Cobban Dewar
description: Lynn Becker, an associate counsel at Simon & Schuster in New York, and Robert Cobban Dewar, a deputy commissioner for administration in the New York City Department of Juvenile Justice, were married last evening at the Otto Kahn Castle in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim officiated.

title: SAG HARBOR INITIATIVE SCHEDULES FOLLOW-UP DATE
description: WHAT to some was a stale airing of overworked political ideas was to others an outburst of deep thought at the recent first meeting of the Sag Harbor Initiative, a group of liberal intellectuals and concerned citizens who want Americans across the country to hold town meetings to discuss urgent social issues.

title: Is It History, Or Is It Drama?
description: LEAD: WHEN I WALKED INTO the movie theater to see ''The Wannsee Conference,'' I did so with some trepidation. Vincent Canby's review in The New York Times had prepared me for an unusual experience. The film was going to replicate a meeting of ranking S.S. and ministerial officials held on Jan. 20, 1942, in the Wannsee section of Berlin.

title: POLITICS: Campaign Finance; Both Parties Go All Out in Pursuit of PAC Funds
description: Eleven months before the 1988 Congressional elections, more than 100 officials of political action committees gathered recently at Democratic Party headquarters to hear suggestions on how to spend their money.

title: INCINERATOR FOES FORM ALLIANCES
description: AN attempt to form a broader base and to create a stronger impact in the fight against mass-burn incineration has led the Coalition to Save Hempstead Harbor to mobilize residents of several Long Island communities.

title: JAILED IN PRAGUE
description: MY COMPANIONS IN THE BLEAK HOUSE By Eva Kanturkova. Preface by Vaclav Havel. 314 pp. Woodstock, N.Y.: The Overlook Press. $19.95.

title: A House of the Future, Now Part of Our Past
description: THERE ARE HOUSES THAT ARE of interest primarily as esthetic objects, and there are houses that are of interest primarily as relics of a way of life, but it is rare that a house manages to be both, and sums up all the aspirations, architectural and social alike, of a particular moment in time. But that is precisely what is achieved by the house that the architect Rudolf M. Schindler built for himself in 1921-22 on Kings Road in West Hollywood. It is is one of the great modern buildings of Los Angeles, and its greatness comes equally from its physical form and from its utopian ideals.

title: Wilmington, Del.: New Condos In Old Homes
description: WHEN a resurgence in office construction began here in 1982, Bonnie M. Sherr decided there was also a need for high-end residential development.

title: DOGS TRAINED TO HELP THE DISABLED
description: LEAD: MELISSA MALE, 9 1/2 years old, has muscular dystrophy and is confined to a wheelchair. But when she needs to get dressed or get a washcloth in the morning or take a late night snack from the refrigerator, she has no need for the assistance of another human being. Instead, she calls Cashew, a golden retriever, and he performs all the necessary tasks.

title: MOVIES
description: Beyond Therapy Starring Julie Hagerty, Jeff Goldblum, Glenda Jackson, Tom Conti, Christopher Guest. Directed by Robert Altman. 1986. New World Video. 93 minutes. $69.95. This surreal romance is strictly for Robert Altman addicts. Christopher Durang's play has been Altmanized, which is to say that characters have been transported to the director's alternative universe, making ''Beyond Therapy'' a disorienting experience indeed. Cutting through Mr. Altman's customary melange of aleatory dialogue, strange epiphanies and subtle plot mysteries, one can state with fair certainty that a spirited but exceedingly odd young woman, Prudence (Julie Hagerty), has answered a personals ad; she meets the ad's originator, Bruce (Jeff Goldblum), who reveals that he is a bisexual living with his male lover Bob (Christopher Guest).

title: Of Candidates, Conversations and Chimes
description: IS ANYBODY WATCHING, AND IF SO, who cares? David Brinkley wondered about it last Sunday on ABC. It's possible, he said, ''there are too many debates - maybe they're becoming a bore.'' Mr. Brinkley didn't specify, but he perhaps had in mind the two-hour, 12-candidate extravaganza on NBC a few nights before. That was billed as a debate, although it had all the elements of a game show. There is a sense in which all politics on television has elements of a game show, but the NBC program, ''America's Future: A Presidential Debate,'' set a house record. Candidates were restricted to one-minute bursts, while sitting in what looked like a jury box. A minute was marked by the mellifluous sound of a chime; then we heard from the next candidate-contestant. As a way to pick Presidents, this was better than a coup d'etat, but as a way to discuss issues it didn't amount to much.

title: A CONFERENCE CENTER TURNS AROUND
description: LAST December, two executives, Wesley A. LaBay and Jeffrey V. Farina, left good jobs to buy a conference center in Ossining. Their acquisition, the Hudson River Inn and Conference Center, was a property that had consistently lost money for 20 years, under a succession of experienced owners. Starting life as the Eagle Bay Inn, a Sheraton Hotel, the complex was later operated by Dunfey Hotels, before it was sold to the SCM Corporation, which ran it as a conference center until last December.

The undertaking - which would reveal the precise biochemical makeup of the entire genetic material, or genome, of a human being - would, he heard, revolutionize medicine. It would answer the Japanese challenge in biotechnology. It would grant insight into human biology previously held only by God.

title: France's Candidates Scramble Dutifully for the High Road
description: ONE would almost think that America's moralizing politics had beached up on France's worldly shores. The fall season had been taken up with a scrappy tennis match in which the right served up a financial or personal scandal at the left only to have the left slam one back; the right won in, let's say, three sets. But as the Christmas season approaches - and, more to the point, as the presidential candidates try to brush up their statesmen images - French politicians are talking solemnly, though unpersuasively, about adopting a law to regulate campaign financing in time for the spring election.

title: East Berlin
description: To the Editor: I thought that the article on the Weissensee cemetery gave an excellent description of the cemetery and the history surrounding it. I have been fortunate enough to visit Berlin twice and stay with close friends who live there. I have also toured extensively in East Germany. On my most recent visit to East Berlin, I was taken to the Weissensee cemetery one Sunday afternoon. As a Jew, I was deeply touched by my visit. I received a powerful understanding of the large German Jewish community, especially in Berlin. I was able to see with my own eyes by reading the gravestones how strong the Jewish community was in Germany up until the coming to power of the Nazis. I have also traveled to Prague and seen the old Jewish cemetery there. There is no comparison as to the magnitude of the Weissensee cemetery. While Berlin was destroyed, it is amazing that the cemetery was untouched. The article failed to mention that there is a very small Jewish community in East Germany today and that most of the 600 Jews (according to official statistics) live in East Berlin. A small number of Jews also live in Leipzig. There is even a kosher butcher in East Berlin. The eight Jewish congregations in East Germany, small though they may be, receive considerable support from the state. HOWARD B. MARCUS Hoboken, N.J.

title: A TRADITIONAL ENGLISH CHRISTMAS FEAST
description: FOR me, Christmas dinner has to be traditional. That means a serious roast - goose, turkey or suckling pig - and plum pudding brought flaming to the table. Being British, I am used to dishes that might seem unusual to an American, but they are very much part of our repertoire and date back to long before the Revolution. At this time of year, like many immigrants, I get nostalgic for ''the old country'' and a traditional feast reminds me of home.

title: Aretha Franklin Reaches For Gospel's Higher Ground
description: WITH HER SOARING VOICE and sometimes fiery abandon, Aretha Franklin has had a long, variable but frequently incandescent career. She's been a queen of soul, she's sung jazz and the blues, but the basis of her style has been gospel music. Her ''Amazing Grace'' double album of 1972 (now on a double CD set, Atlantic 2-906-2) counts among her finest achievements. Now, for the first time since that album, Miss Franklin has returned to gospel. Her ''One Lord, One Faith, One Baptism'' (Arista 8497, two LP's, one cassette and, with slight cuts, one CD) is one of the most eagerly awaited albums of the year. Which makes its failure all the more disappointing.
