New Rochelle, N.Y. $215,000 57 Monroe Street 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 81-year-old colonial; eat-in kitchen, enclosed porch, walk to station; taxes $1,694.

title: AN AGENDA FOR THE 203D LEGISLATURE
description: NEW JERSEY'S rising prominence is due in part to the strength of its state government working in response to citizen needs.

title: A BROOKLYN YOUTH, SHOT, DIES
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn high school student died yesterday from a gunshot wound he received when he was the victim of a street robbery in the borough's Fort Greene section near his school two days earlier, the authorities reported yesterday.

title: GRADES WEIGHTED IN QUEST FOR GRANTS
description: LEAD: AT least three Long Island school districts are weighting students' grades to compete with districts in other parts of the state that have been adding up to 10 points to grades in honor and advanced courses as part of a policy to encourage more scholarships for women.

title: Q AND A
description: Sled-Dog Race Question: I have always wanted to see the winner of the Iditarod Trail Sled-Dog Race in Alaska. Once in Nome, will it be easy to learn when the winner will arrive and get a front-row look? - E. S., New York, N.Y. Answer: It is not easy, one of the race officials explains, to estimate accurately when the winner and his or her dogs will cross the finish line until the leaders are about 200 miles from Nome. That is usually a couple of days or so before the winner's arrival. The dog-sled event begins next March 5 from Anchorage. Many enthusiasts in Alaska follow the progress of the race on the radio and in newspapers and head for Nome as quickly as they can when the day of the finish appears to be obvious. A resident of the Lower 48 might consider checking with Alaska by phone during the race - with the Iditarod Trail Committee, for example - to obtain a good estimate of when the first dog team is expected and when to fly to Nome.

title: AFTER 6-YEAR HIATUS, THE SMOKE RETURNS
description: WHAT I was about to do seemed very strange. I listened for quiet and looked around to be sure that I was alone. I even stuck my head into my son's bedroom. Then a quick peek into the den where the television set is located.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DEVIL & MOTHER CRUMP By Valerie Scho Carey. Illustrated by Arnold Lobel. 39 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $11.95. (Ages 7 to 11) THE DEVILS WHO LEARNED TO BE GOOD Written and illustrated by Michael McCurdy. Unpaged. Boston: Joy Street Books/ Little, Brown & Company. $13.95. (Ages 7 to 11)

title: MUSIC IN CELEBRATION OF CHRISTMAS
description: CONNECTICUT'S abiding love of music is never more evident than during the Christmas holiday, when the largest of concert halls and the smallest of churches put forth their best efforts.

title: Chromium Clean-Up Plan
description: A consultant has recommended a $60 million project to dismantle and clean up the chromium-contaminated former Allied chemical plant in Baltimore. The report, by NUS Corporation of Gaithersburg, has been sent by Allied-Signal Inc., of Morristown, N.J., which will pay for the work, to the Maryland Department of Environment. Allied said the project was intended to ''insure that the site can be redeveloped for residential and commercial uses.''

title: The Trade Deficit Comes in a Shocker
description: The trade deficit jumped to a record $17.6 billion in October, with imports rising by 12.3 percent while exports edged up only 3 percent. The gap was much worse than had been predicted by the experts, most of whom were expecting it to be no worse than $15 billion. October is a big month for importing Christmas goods, but there were signs that the report could not be dismissed as a seasonal quirk. For example, automobile imports from Japan rose by 33 percent over the September figure and cars from other nations had a 41 percent jump. The deficit with Japan climbed to $5.9 billion, from $4.6 billion in September, and with Western Europe it soared to $3 billion, from $1.7 billion.

title: Value Investing
description: To the Editor:

title: Chapultepec Park: Mexico in Microcosm
description: IT is one of the world's great urban parks, rivalling the Bois de Boulogne in Paris, the Imperial Gardens in Tokyo and Central Park in New York. But for the 20 million residents of Mexico City, the Bosque de Chapultepec is more than just a vast verdant expanse in the heart of the city. It is also a repository of national history and identity, a major cultural center and their favorite place for a Sunday picnic, soccer game or flirtation.

title: The Dance: An Evening at Ailey Works at City Center
description: GLITTER, love and pain were the main ingredients in the ''All Ailey Evening'' presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday at City Center. Mr. Ailey is an eclectic. That the evening proved. But there is a unifying humanity in all his work. And it was danced here in the penetratingly expressive way that is so distinctive a feature of the Ailey dancers and their repertory.

title: SELFISHNESS BEGINS AT HOME
description: THE WIDOW'S MITE And Other Stories. By Ferrol Sams. 218 pp. Atlanta: Peachtree Publishers. $14.95.

title: Birds Clog 2 Jets in Chicago And Seattle, Aborting Flights
description: A Delta Airlines jet had to turn around shortly after takeoff here because a bird was sucked into an engine, a company spokesman said today.

title: Russians? Welcome, Says Utah
description: The signing of the new Soviet-American arms treaty has brought a special sense of expectancy to the residents of this mining and manufacturing community near the Great Salt Lake.

title: Hilary Coons Wed To Bruce Murray
description: Hilary Watts Coons, a staff psychologist and an assistant professor of psychiatry at Dartmouth College, and Bruce Lawrence Murray, a potter and sculptor in Bradford, Vt., were married yesterday at the First Parish Unitarian Church in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Charles Ludeking performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: OF JAMS AND A FAMILY
description: Andrew Malcolm's article brought back fond memories of my boyhood in Ohio, almost 70 years ago.

title: EDITOR'S NOTE
description: A picture on the cover of The Times Magazine on Sept. 29, 1985, with an article about the character of Australia, showed a cowboy on horseback against a rugged landscape. The caption said, ''A cowboy rides past Ayers Rock in Australia's vast Outback.''

title: A June Wedding For Gail E. Loflin
description: Gail English Loflin, a daughter of John J. Loflin of Rye, N.Y., and the late Bonnie Loflin, and Steven Alexander Wolff, the son of Joan M. Wolff of Port Chester, N.Y., and Joel C. Wolff of New York, plan to marry in June.

title: U.S. Navy Rescues Tanker Crew in Gulf
description: An American warship today helped rescue the crew of an oil tanker flying the Cypriot flag in the southern Persian Gulf, according to officials aboard the command ship of the United States Navy's gulf fleet.

title: Temples and Tortillas On a Mexican Tour
description: ONE thing that you will find out, as we did, when you travel in the Yucatan, is that climbing down those Mayan pyramids is completely terrifying. Unfortunately, you are not going to find this out (and even if you are warned, you won't really believe it) until you are standing on top of one. So there we were at Chichen Itza, and Larry was up on top of the biggest pyramid, and Perri was down at the bottom reading to Benjamin from a favorite book, ''The Cow Who Fell in the Canal,'' and after she had read it through for the seventh time she realized that Larry was not down yet. Meanwhile, Larry had arrived at a new appreciation of Mayan culture. Not only did the Mayans conceive of the mathematical zero and the mathematical infinite, not only did they work out a calendar of marvelous accuracy, not only did they know everything there is to know about the fascinating topic of maize cultivation, but they also built these most magnificent pyramids, which are somehow a breeze to climb, at a brisk pace, no hands, but which scare the life out of you once you start thinking about going down.

title: A. P. H. Wyrough And Miss Brown To Marry in June
description: Kathryn Mary Brown and Alexander Penn Hill Wyrough, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Wyrough of Upper Marlboro, Md., plan to marry in June, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John S. Brown of Princeton, N.J., have announced.

title: TAX EQUITY -- THE STATE'S NO. 1 ISSUE
description: SOME 15 years ago, a highly respected Republican Assemblyman, now deceased, rose on the floor to move a bill that would have created a 1 percent-7 percent graduated income tax in New Jersey.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Arms Maker Predicts a Burden Under Treaty
description: The chief executive of the nation's leading arms maker says that the treaty banning land-based intermediate nuclear forces will burden his company with an ''overly heavy Russian presence'' at a key plant, but that he nonetheless supports it.

title: Leaving Home for Christmas
description: I STILL remember the artful phrase that first enticed us to leave home for Christmas, a habit we have kept up for 25 years. Earlier that year, my father had died suddenly. Bereft of this central figure, how were we - my mother especially -to endure our usual rituals? In the want ad section of the Saturday Review, a wellspring of intriguing possibilities in those days, I found our refuge: ''Tiki, Your Tropic Island Home.''

title: East Bloc Couple Fighting for Asylum
description: Fleeing a Government they feared would arrest them, Tamas Koppany and his family arrived last year at Kennedy International Airport from Hungary with three small suitcases, a pocket English dictionary and the belief they had found refuge.

title: 5 PALESTINIANS WOUNDED BY ISRAELIS IN GAZA STRIP
description: Israeli soldiers shot and wounded at least five residents of the occupied Gaza Strip today, as shopkeepers throughout the West Bank shuttered their stores to protest the violence that has left six Palestinians dead in four days.

title: CRUDE, UNPOLISHED AND UNSURPASSED
description: CHAUCER His Life, His Works, His World. By Donald R. Howard. Illustrated. 636 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $29.95.

title: Man Carrying a Knife Slain by Transit Officer
description: A transit police officer shot and killed a man who attacked him with a knife yesterday in a subway station in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Capturing Experiences of Past Generations
description: Mina Huang, 12 years old, tells how her grandfather survived the Hiroshima bombing in 1945.

title: Islanders Regroup And Win
description: The Islanders, who had just lost two consecutive games for the first time this season, had added incentive to snap out of their losing ways: They wanted to keep the Devils out of first place in the Patrick Division.

title: Susan Annabel Myers To Wed George Treyz
description: Second Lieut. Susan Annabel Myers, U.S.A.F., a satellite-operations officer at the Consolidated Space Operations Center at Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado Springs, and George Victor Treyz, a doctoral candidate in solid-state science and engineering at Columbia University, plan to be married in March.

title: Schmidt, in Best-Seller Memoirs, Says Carter Showed Naivete
description: In 1977, President Jimmy Carter sat down with Helmut Schmidt and asked the West German Chancellor how they could work together to bring down the Berlin Wall.

title: Time Off for Dawkins
description: IT'S hard to keep your mind on basketball when your personal problems keep mounting, and for Darryl Dawkins, things finally got to the point that he had no choice. On Friday morning, he called the Detroit Pistons' coach, Chuck Daly, and told him he was tired and needed time to sort out some problems. According to Jack McCloskey, the Pistons' general manager, Dawkins, who was acquired in a Thanksgiving Day trade with the Utah Jazz, asked to be placed on indefinite suspension and the request was granted.

title: THE PLUNGE: A STUNNING BLOW TO A GILDED, IMPUDENT AGE
description: When the closing bell rang on Oct. 19, at the end of the worst day in the history of the New York Stock Exchange, a characteristically American era came to an end.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;
FRESH-CUT TREES
description: LEAD: LOOKING for a Christmas tree that's a cut above the rest? Maybe this year you should take matters into your own hands.

title: STUDENT GROUP TAKES ACTIVIST ROLE
description: LEAD: FIVE months ago, high school and college students in Nassau and Suffolk Counties organized the Long Island Student Coalition for Peace and Justice. Its purpose is to promote awareness and responsibility on worldwide issues among local youths. To that end, members of the student coalition have set out to educate themselves.

title: SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
description: Yes, the Mets should keep Mookie Wilson. We fans are asked to be loyal to teams even though management charges a lot for a game, sells expensive concessions, builds ever bigger impersonal stadiums and bombards us with clacky music and commercials. Then, on top of that, the owners blithely trade players we enjoy - Hubie Brooks, Kevin Mitchell, Jeff Reardon, Ray Knight, Jesse Orosco, Rafael Santana. CAROL WELLMAN Wilton, Conn.

title: ABOUT ALARM SYSTEMS AND THE REAL WORLD
description: I could not read ''Closed Windows, Good Neighbors'' [ Nov. 22 ] without being grateful that I am not one of Sara Jasper Cook's next-door neighbors. Does she think that the people who have alarm systems are any happier about them than she is? We, too, have to listen to them when they go off, have to worry that someone may be breaking into our homes, and feel like we live in a cage. But I'd rather have an alarm than an unfeeling neighbor. Maybe if she listened and reacted to an alarm, she could have been a real neighbor and saved someone the heartache of a burglary. Instead, she'd rather close her windows to the real world around her. ALBERTA LEONE Croton-on-Hudson

title: Divestment Efforts Fade In the Face Of Success
description: TWO years ago, students at campuses across the country erected shanties and staged hunger strikes in an attempt to persuade their schools to stop investing in companies that do business in South Africa. Now the movement seems to be fading, a victim, in part, of its own success.

title: OF JAMS AND A FAMILY
description: With a name like Smucker's, it helps to be male, or so it would seem from Andrew H. Malcolm's article ''Of Jams and a Family'' (Nov. 15). ''Smucker boys absorb the jam business from childhood,'' according to your report. Apparently, Smucker's perpetuates the myth in American business that men are better suited than women for leadership positions. Here is an example of one of the most successful family businesses in the country, and there appear to be no women in the family in the management structure.

title: Sneaking Out of School For Delaware's Big Day
description: Gov. Michael N. Castle and former Chief Justice Warren E. Burger stepped from a ceremonial carriage in front of the State Capitol to be greeted by students carrying signs that read, ''We skipped school to be here.''

title: 'It Shouldn't Be This Way,' But Trade Deficit Expands
description: THE roller coaster that the financial markets boarded in the middle of October just won't stop. Stocks went up 100 points last week, their best performance since August, but the dollar was battered. It now will buy less than half as many German marks and Japanese yen as it did at its peak in early 1985.

title: HOSPITALS SEEKING RATE RISE
description: LEAD: AFTER seven years of state controls that have kept their rates well below those in neighboring states, hospitals in New Jersey are crying ''uncle.''

title: Robertson Forces Defeat Bush Camp in Michigan Rules Fight
description: A conservative coalition led by supporters of Pat Robertson narrowly won a party rules showdown today with forces of Vice President Bush, but the Bush forces denounced the rules changes as illegal.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: LEAD: GEORGIA O'KEEFFE: One Hundred Flowers. Edited by Nicholas Callaway. (Callaway Editions/Knopf, $100.) This collection of flower paintings, beautifully presented and exquisitely reproduced, is a revelation: first, because they have never been exhibited in their full array and, secondly, because the book allows the viewer to discover Georgia O'Keeffe's view of herself and her own sexuality and - more importantly - of nature.

title: James Blue, a Consultant, Is Wed to Marcia Patricof
description: The marriage of Marcia S. Patricof, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Patricof of New York, to James Blue, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ira Blue of Westport, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. Justice Benjamin Glass of State Supreme Court in Queens performed the ceremony.

title: In War-Crimes Trial, Horror and Humdrum
description: The war-crimes trial of John Demjanjuk, which began as a dramatic retelling of the Holocaust, has evolved in recent weeks into a detailed study of signatures, ink, paper and even paper clips.

title: SECRET TIPS HELP SOLVE CRIMES
description: IN recent months an anonymous phone call helped the Willimantic Police Department find and arrest a suspect in an armed robbery of a convenience store. Another call helped the department make arrests in a drug case.

title: Civil Liberties Group in Jersey Aids Bands, and Their Critics
description: Last week, the American Civil Liberties Union rallied behind the British. Now it is taking up the cause of the Irish.

title: WHEN SMOKERS GO THEIR OWN WAY
description: I have just read Albert F. Cafiero's article regarding improving rail service rather than widening our congested highways. [ ''Why Widening Congested Highways Is the Wrong Route to Follow,'' Nov. 15 ] .

title: Farm of 'Christina's World' Is Back on the Market Again
description: The farm depicted by Andrew Wyeth in the painting ''Christina's World'' is on the market for at least the second time in little over a year, a real estate agency said Wednesday.

title:
GARDENING;
HOW TO PRESERVE A CHRISTMAS TREE
description: LEAD: EVERGREENS have long played an important role in winter holiday decor. In fact, primitive northern societies used evergreens to celebrate midwinter festivals long before the establishment of Christmas.

title: OFFICIALS DEBATE IMPACT ON HOUSING
description: THE impact on affordable housing of the proposed transfer of development rights program to preserve farmland is being debated by Riverhead Town officials.

title: Sharon Scherl to Marry
description: Sharon Scherl and Eric H. Morgenstern, fourth-year students at the New York Medical College, are planning a May wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Dr. and Mrs. Newton D. Scherl of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., have announced. Miss Scherl is a graduate of the Columbia University School of Nursing. Her fiance, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Morgenstern of Kew Gardens, Queens, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: The Gorbachev Effect: Charming, Very Tough
description: To the Americans who met him, Mikhail S. Gorbachev emerged variously as a charming, steely and unpredictable Soviet leader - a man who, alternately, ''blew up'' at tough questions, who startled guests with his awareness of American culture, who seemed ''very controlled'' and curiously mysterious.

title: A Solitary Voyage
description: WELL into the second day of a severe storm in mid-Atlantic the young navigator of the Polish freighter Stefan Starzynski contemplated a course change. The storm had forced the ship south of the great circle route to its destination, Le Havre, France. A tight schedule necessitated a change that would put the ship into the troughs of 30-foot waves. The navigator decided to execute the maneuver at 2 P.M. when the galley would be quiet. He didn't want the cook storming the bridge with a meat cleaver.

title: Delighting in Katherine Dunham's Sense of Gaity
description: ONE OF THE SEASON'S HIGH-lights is the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's program in tribute to Katherine Dunham. What better way to honor this American modern-dance pioneer who introduced so much of the black heritage to the field of concert dance than to restage her choreography?

title: Korean Throngs Bring Campaign To Home Stretch
description: By the many hundreds of thousands, South Koreans poured into the streets and broad plazas of their major cities today to protest past repression and affirm their hope for a more democratic future.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: RINGERS AND BELLINGERS

title: Portland, Me.: Bay Condos In an Old Fort
description: A CONTROVERSIAL housing development is being created on Great Diamond Island in Casco Bay, less than one mile by ferry from downtown Portland.

title: Railroad Sues Union in Maine
description: The Springfield Terminal Railway Company is seeking more than $15 million in damages from its employees' striking union.

title: Recaptured, She Cites 17 Good Years in Plea
description: For 17 years, Rebecca Billips worked quietly in New York City, winning praise for her skills and dedication as a secretary. She also avoided the police, shunned any social life and used an assumed name.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Customizing a House in a Development
description: LEAD: THE option of having a house custom-built by a developer in a subdivision, instead of settling for a model that the builder is offering, is usually available only in high-priced developments - generally where houses sell for $1 million or more.

title: Kelly Sheridan to Wed
description: The engagement of Kelly Kathleen Sheridan to Gregg Jones Nowell has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Hayes of Rumson, N.J., the stepfather and mother of the future bride. Miss Sheridan is also a daughter of the late John M. Sheridan. Mr. Jones is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Nowell of Fair Haven, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: MELVILLE RESIDENTS FAULT NEW HOUSING
description: FEW disagree that there is a need for more affordable housing on Long Island. Of the 60,000 families in Huntington, 3,500 are in desperate need of housing, according to Francis Neary, lawyer for the Huntington Housing Authority.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: THE 'TROCKS' AT THE 'Y'

title: About Men; The Road to Self-Reliance
description: )ONCE AGAIN I AM LONELY, A man turned 40 standing in a remembered room looking out between the mullions at the cold gray river of his youth.

title: Mary-Catherine McCarthy Wed to Leo Spellman
description: At St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., Mary-Catherine McCarthy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. X. McCarthy of Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday to Leo Spellman, a son of Anne D. Spellman of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and the late Leo F. Spellman. The Rev. John E. McCarthy, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Wife of Spy Hospitalized
description: Anne Henderson Pollard, serving a five-year term for pleading guilty to charges related to the sale of state secrets to Israel by her husband, Jonathan Jay Pollard, was transferred Friday from a prison hospital in Kentucky to one affiliated with the Mayo Clinic for treatment of a digestive disorder, Government officials and family members said. Mrs. Pollard was checked into Methodist Hospital in Rochester, Minn., a Justice Department spokesman said.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago. I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off. Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left. I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago. I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off. Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left. title: PROSPECTS
description: Marketers on the Move

title: Trying to Build a Bigger Blimpie
description: TONY CONZA had dropped out of college and was working as an order clerk for E.F. Hutton when he went to a party in Jersey City. It was 1964. Among the guests were two high school friends - Peter DeCarlo and Angelo Bandassare - whom he hadn't seen in a while. After a few drinks, they began to bat around the idea of starting a business.

title: Alcoholism: The Judgment Of Science Is Pending
description: DESPITE decades of research costing hundreds of millions of dollars, scientists admit to a profound ignorance about the nature of alcoholism and the effect of drinking on the body.

title: TWO PRESCRIPTIONS FOR SOCIALISM
description: A WAY OF HOPE By Lech Walesa. Illustrated. 325 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $19.95.

title: 'Knowledge Is a Good Thing'
description: Self-confident and charming. Defensive and truculent. The Mikhail Gorbachev we saw was both those men.

title: Temp Time
description: To the Editor The ''Time for Temps'' has been a developing, real phenomenon in the marketplace for the last three to four years, not just a recent development caused by the October market collapse (Prospects, Nov. 23).

title: CHAMBER FESTIVAL IN HOLIDAY CONCERT
description: THERE was a great Preston Sturges movie in 1940 called ''Christmas in July'' - but now it's July in the Christmas season, as the Westchester Chamber Music Festival departs from its summer-only schedule to present two preholiday concerts. What's more, the spirit of cultural brotherhood hovers over the venture, as Saturday's 8:30 P.M. program at the Ossining High School is being given with the cooperation of Friends of Music, and next Sunday's 4 P.M. repeat in Peekskill reflects the participation of the Paramount Center for the Arts.

title: A CAREER COLORED IN SUCCESS
description: FABER BIRREN is a colorist, but not in the sense that Matisse is - or Bonnard or even Josef Albers. If anything, his lifelong devotion to the subject comes out of his rejection of art - or perhaps it was his rejection by art.

title: NASA to Test Backup Flight Control Center
description: The space agency plans to test a backup Mission Control center to communicate with an orbiting space shuttle in an emergency. The plan will involve the use of portable computers hastily set up at an alternative site.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN HONOLULU
description: The power breakfast craze is old hat in Honolulu, where pashas of business and fund raising, or political mikados and workhorses, have been putting their heads together at 7 A.M. over ''two scoops rice'' since the days of the missionaries. Whether the dawn burst of activity is due to climate or just plain vitality, no one has bothered to analyze; it's the Hawaiian way.

title: INSURANCE COMPANY PURSUES AN EXCLUSIVE INTEREST IN ART
description: SOME of the best examples of Connecticut-made art and antiques are to be found not in a museum or gallery but at the headquarters of the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company in Hartford.

title: A ROUTE IS CHOSEN FOR THE KATONAH BYPASS
description: SOME houses on a tree-lined street in Katonah have had a hard life. First, in about 1895, they were lifted from their foundations and hauled a mile south on horse-drawn rollers. Then, after sitting there for a peaceful half century they were rattled and shaken for years by truck traffic.

title: WHEN THE DOCTOR IS IN AND THE PATIENT FUMES
description: THERE are now two Great Mysteries in life. One is, how can you look it up if you don't know how to spell it?

title: KING'S 32 HELP DEFEAT NETS
description: Bernard King twisted and turned down the lane tonight the way he used to, leading the Washington Bullets to a 122-107 victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: 1,500 Drink a Toast to the Constitution
description: As the last of 1,500 formally dressed guests piled into a military hangar here Monday for the grandest black-tie ball in memory, one guest mused about a plan for another kind of party.

title: THREE-GENERATION PERSPECTIVE OF HUNTING AND KILLING
description: BIG HERB, my father, never lost the thrill of killing. For him, there was no greater excitement than to be among a covey of quail, on an autumn morning, and to bring down one of their thundering forms with each barrel of his double-barreled Winchester. Or to stand in a blind at sunset, as the mallards lanced in from the exposed waters of the lake, and send one of their speeding bodies plunging into the marsh. Or to hook into a grandfather of largemouth bass and fight off its desperate lunges until it slid, exhausted, into the meshes of his landing net.

title: Miss Merola, an Engineer, Engaged to Alfredo Forte
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Mario Merola of the Bronx of the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Merola to Alfredo Forte, the son of Mrs. Paolo Forte of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Forte.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MAMA, by Terry McMillan. (Washington Square Press/ Pocket Books, $5.95.) Mildred Peacock, the protagonist of this novel about a poor black family in a decaying suburb of Detroit, finds many ways to transcend poverty -alcohol, prostitution and plain, hard work. ''In its inexorable movement toward economic doom, 'Mama' [ proves ] that dignity can't be carried in a wallet,'' Will Blythe said here earlier this year. ''Mildred Peacock slaps the forces of economic determinism clean upside their hoary heads.'' ADAM'S TASK: Calling Animals by Name, by Vicki Hearne. (Vintage, $8.95.) Vicki Hearne, a poet who trains horses for a living, believes that animals are sentient, moral beings that should neither be condescended to nor treated as though they were machines. While our reviewer, Yi-Fu Tuan, said last year that he found the author's anthropomorphizing a bit extreme, he thought much of the book was ''illuminating and educational.'' ''She believes profoundly in the intelligence of the animals she trains, in their vocation to fulfill themselves as beings of courage, responsibility and wisdom.'' NEVER COME MORNING, by Nelson Algren. (Four Walls Eight Windows/Consortium Booksales and Distribution, $7.95.) When Nelson Algren's novel about a young Polish boxer on Chicago's rough West Side was published in 1942, Fred T. Marsh said here that it was ''a brilliant book.'' This new edition includes an introduction by Kurt Vonnegut and a 1962-63 interview with Algren, who complains about how badly he was treated by Hollywood. THE PHYSICISTS: The History of a Scientific Community in Modern America, by Daniel J. Kevles. (Harvard University, $12.95.) In the name of their god, pure science, America's physicists have long expected society to love them and support their multimillion-dollar experiments, Daniel J. Kevles shows in his study of a scientific elite. In 1978, John Leonard said in The Times that ''with a sharp eye for the telling anecdote, Mr. Kevles paints a picture of aristocrats who [ believed ] everything that is any good will 'trickle down' from those who know better to those who know nothing.'' TO SKIN A CAT, by Thomas McGuane. (Vintage, $5.95.) Boxed in by a modern world in which there are no more frontiers, some of the characters in Thomas McGuane's short stories become ridden with angst, others erupt into violence. Sometimes ''this nasty behavior seems gratuitous and unearned,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. But ''the finest stories in this volume . . . have the sad-funny, sad-surreal texture of daily life.'' PRESENT AT THE CREATION: My Years in the State Department, by Dean Acheson. (Norton, $12.95.) For those who would understand the web of alliances and threats - both real and imagined - that constitutes our present world, Dean Acheson's memoirs have long been considered indispensable. As he describes his role in helping to create United States foreign policy during the cold war, Acheson ''makes us privy to one of the best-trained and resourceful minds that has ever been put at the service of the nation,'' Wallace Carroll said in The Book Review in 1969. GOLDEN DAYS, by Carolyn See. (Fawcett, $3.95.) Carolyn See's perversely titled novel is about Southern Californians during the aftermath of a nuclear holocaust. The story is ''defiantly rude and hilariously sad,'' Carol Sternhell said in The Book Review last year. ''In its weird way, this may be the most life-affirming novel I've ever read.'' THE HARVEST OF SORROW: Soviet Collectivization and the Terror-Famine, by Robert Conquest. (Oxford University, $9.95.) From 1929 to 1933, millions of peasants died during the Soviet Union's forced collectivization of agriculture and the famine that followed. Robert Conquest ''has chronicled [ one ] of the great Russian tragedies of the 20th century,'' Craig R. Whitney said here last year. ''This is a powerful story.'' HAVING EVERYTHING RIGHT: Essays of Place, by Kim R. Stafford. (Hepworth/Penguin, $6.95.) This celebration of the Northwestern United States is ''written in a vivid, succinct prose that sparkles with imagery,'' our reviewer, John Tallmadge, said last year. The author ''is particularly attracted, as were Thoreau, Whitman and the Beat poets, to eccentrics and outcasts, the people he calls 'local saints.' '' FLOATER, by Joseph Koenig. (Mysterious Press, $3.50.) When a con man who seduces and kills rich women meets up with his female counterpart, they go into business together. This is a ''fast-paced book, well plotted, with a devastating ending,'' Newgate Callendar said here earlier this year. Joseph Koenig ''has written a splendid procedural expressed in sharp, economical, yet sensitive prose.'' THE CREATION OF PATRIARCHY, by Gerda Lerner. (Oxford University, $8.95.) Men's subordination of women is rooted in history, not biology, and thus it is something that can be changed, the feminist scholar Gerda Lerner argues. Last year one reviewer said that her book ''gives us a grand historical framework that was impossible even to imagine before the enlightenment . . . provided by her earlier work and that of other feminist scholars.'' LILIAN'S STORY, by Kate Grenville. (King Penguin, $6.95.) This first novel about an obese Australian girl's escape from her sick, incestuous father and other horrors of life ''is a work of considerable beauty and power,'' James Purdy said in The Book Review in 1986. ''Indeed, her fat itself comes to be a kind of strength of being, a true aura, the authentic envelope of her soul.''

title: Private Hospital to Treat AIDS Closes After Loss of $8 Million
description: An empty white building beside a busy freeway is all that remains of the nation's first private hospital for AIDS patients, which closed Friday after losing $8 million in the 14 months it was in operation.

title: 'Maquiladoras' Cost American Jobs
description: OVER the past decade, the term maquiladora has entered the business lexicon. Maquiladoras are American-owned plants along the United States-Mexican border operating under special United States tax treatment and Mexican foreign investment regulations. American-made components are shipped to Mexico and used to assemble products that are sent back to the United States. Under Item 807 of our Tariff Code, import duties on goods are paid only on the value of Mexican labor.

title: Banker to Be Wed To Ginna Schrum
description: Virginia Durald Schrum and William Frederick Laporte 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Laporte of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., plan to marry in April, the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. John L. Schrum of Charlotte, N.C., have announced.

title: Cambodia Is Short of Everything but Vietnamese
description: Even the weather conspires against the battered nation of Cambodia, which is already short of money, expertise, labor, reliable statistics and communications with the outside world.

title: In Louisiana, a Search for 'the Best and Brightest'
description: Hundreds of resumes have poured into the offices of Gov.-elect Buddy Roemer in response to advertisements seeking applicants for jobs in his cabinet.

title: East Berlin
description: To the Editor: I found the article on the Weissensee Cemetery in East Berlin (Travel, Nov. 8) of great interest. My grandparents are buried in this cemetery and I have visited there four times in the last 15 years.

title: Business Schools Warned on Decline in Minorities
description: After several years of dramatic gains, the proportion of minority students entering graduate business schools has fallen so low that educators are warning that business schools risk a serious overall decline in enrollment.

description: LEAD: THE advertisement reads something like this: ''Litchfield County land for sale.

title: Art
description: Outside the mainstream, contemporary art sometimes seems to be turning into a menagerie. So many animals have been invented, depicted and unleashed in painting that they almost seem to be taking over. This need for nature is something of a reaction against the amount of theory in art now. Animals also make it possible for artists to express an affection for living creatures in a way that the human figure, as problematical as it has been in 20th-century art, does not. Now, as before, animals play a role in allegory.

title: KENTUCKY BEATS LOUISVILLE AT BUZZER
description: Cedric Jenkins tipped in the winning basket as time expired to lift Kentucky to a 76-75 victory over Louisville today.

title: Sunday Observer; Dangerous To the Last Drop
description: THE HOUSE IN which we live sits under a coffee-bean tree. Had we known about coffee-bean trees before buying the house, we probably would have told the real-estate agent to show us the next place. Because we lived previously in the city, however, we knew almost nothing about the personalities of trees, so we said we would take the house.

title: They Can Make History
description: Expectations about the summit meeting soared so unreasonably that to some, its genuine successes seem pallid. Already the moaning can be heard about failure to reach accord on space-based defenses, on long-range nuclear arms, on Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan and on breakthroughs for human rights.

title: WHERE TO FIND THE ICE FOR SKATING
description: WHEN atmospheric moisture and temperature are just right, a hoarfrost rises like a ghost over the Ebersole Ice Rink in White Plains. Somehow during this darkest time of the year, this is a warming sight for those who thrive on Arctic cold and boreal sports.

description: Investigators have ended their examination of a hillside littered with the wreckage of a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner that crashed this week, killing all 43 people aboard, officials said today.

description: LEAD: CHRISTINE PAPES, Scott Grenz and Phyllis Popkin are three Long Islanders who bought shiny new cars this year. At first the vehicles were a source of pride, but shortly they became the subject of horror stories that the owners tell with disbelief.

description: LEAD: AGNES SMEDLEY The Life and Times of an American Radical. By Janice R. MacKinnon and Stephen R. MacKinnon. Illustrated. 425 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $25.

description: IN baseball's version of shuttle diplomacy, Sandy Alderson, the Oakland Athletics' vice president for baseball operations, led his entourage to the 19th floor of the Tower at the Loews Anatole Hotel in Dallas at 11 o'clock Thursday night. Armed with a tentative agreement on a trade with the Los Angeles Dodgers, they had a meeting with their counterparts with the Mets.

title: Sarah J. DeCrane Engaged to Wed Daniel J. Norton
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. DeCrane Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Sarah Juliana DeCrane to Daniel John Norton, a son of Anne Strannahan Norton of Binghamton, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: EMERGENCY BROADCAST PLAN DECIDED
description: LEAD: SIX small radio stations have agreed with the Long Island Lighting Company to broadcast emergency messages in the event of an accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Opera: 'The Mikado' By Village Group
description: WHEN Gilbert and Sullivan wrote ''The Mikado,'' the English-speaking world's superficial understanding of Japan came largely from exhibitions like the quaint and pretty one underway at Knightsbridge in 1885. Our superficial understandings today are likelier to center on businesslike, technological Tokyo -where Peter Sellars set his ''Mikado'' production a few years ago - or perhaps on the look and sound of Kabuki theater, which were imported into the operetta by the Village Light Opera Group in its current production at the Fashion Institute Theater.

description: A special State Supreme Court panel has issued the mildest sanction possible against a justice of that court who dismissed a state-paid secretary for refusing to baby-sit his son.

title: STAMFORD STAGING NEW YEAR'S PARTY
description: AS hundreds of Christmas shoppers spill into downtown Stamford during this pre-holiday gift-buying season, a handful of people only yards away are already concentrating their efforts on New Year's Eve.

title: Black Lawyer Pleased By Special Prosecutor
description: C. Vernon Mason, the lawyer, has long argued that the criminal-justice system has a double standard - one for whites and a lesser one for blacks.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago. I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off. Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left. I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

title: HOLLY FOREST FEELS PRESSURE OF POACHERS
description: ''DECK the halls with boughs of holly,'' Park Ranger Bruce Lane sang as he patrolled the 284-acre virgin forest of holly trees at Gateway National Recreation Area here.

title: Phyllis Krulik Is Wed to David B. Saxe

Saxe of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue in New York. Rabbi Marvin Tokayer, assisted by Rabbi David Lincoln and Rabbi Stephen Franklin, performed the ceremony.

title: Group Cites Police Torture and Killings in Brazil
description: A United States human rights organization said today that, while political repression has diminished since civilian rule returned to Brazil in 1985, the police in major cities still routinely use torture and executions in dealing with suspected criminals.

title: Questions to Jurors Trace Outline of a Murder Trial
description: NEARLY every day for the last eight weeks, the participants in the murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. have sat in a tiny 13th-floor room in the Manhattan Criminal Courts building, elbow-to-elbow around a rectangular wooden table, while nearly 350 prospective jurors have filed through for questioning one by one.

title: Leaderless Conservatives Approach '88 in Splinters
description: A WEEK in which the hammer and sickle was flying in front of the White House is not a bad time to contemplate the dismay and disarray that grips much of the American conservative movement. Leaving aside the arms-control agreement with the Soviet Union - and for many conservatives that's bad enough - the movement is in a decidedly bad humor.

title: Foundation Stone, Stepping Stone
description: The signing ceremony for the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces was a moment filled with potential for the future. Such moments are to be savored, and then we return to the realities of the tough work still to be done.

title: New in the Magazine: Body and Mind
description: A weekly column on health and behavior. This week: The urgent need to monitor medication as the body ages.

title: RULES ARE MADE ...
description: ACCORDING to an instructional book entitled ''Basketball Hints,'' those graceful giants in Boston Garden violated common wisdom nearly every time they ran up and down the parquet floor.

title: PRISON CHRISTMAS TOY DRIVE LAGGING
description: LEAD: DONATIONS to Project Ayuda, the toy drive operated by inmates at Eastern Jersey State Prison, formerly Rahway State Prison, have slipped this year, according to its founder and director, Richard Rowe, just when requests for toys for poor and handicapped children have increased.

title: Correction
description: An article from Cambridge, Mass., last Sunday about a dispute between M.I.T. and the City Council incorrectly described the eviction of squatters from a lot owned by the university. Two police dogs that were coincidentally driven past the scene of the disturbance belonged to the city police and were not involved in the eviction. The campus police, who carried out the eviction, have no dogs.

title: SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
description: Should the Mets keep Mookie Wilson? Should the Beatles have kept Ringo Starr, even though there were better drummers around? Do thousands at Shea call ''Moo-kie, Moo-kie'' instead of ''Lenny'' or some other name? Would this Englishman have taken so happily to baseball if Mookie hadn't been there?

title: Bargains in Closed-End Funds
description: THIS year has brought another deluge of stock offerings in new closed-end investment funds; a total of 34 issues raised about $9 billion, according to one estimate. But even before the plunge in stock prices in October, investors in many of the equity-oriented funds shared a common experience: They were a bit poorer for having bought at the initial offerings.

title: KEAN TO OPEN SWEDISH OBSERVANCE
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the King and Queen of Sweden will not be in New Jersey to formally open the celebration of the 350th anniversary of the landing of Swedes in the New World, Governor Kean will start the observance Wednesday.

title: From the Particular to the Sublime
description: THERE IS SOMETHING REALLY rather peculiar about the virtual unanimity with which Anselm Kiefer, now 42, has been accepted in the United States as the most important artist to have emerged from Europe in the last quarter of this century. Kiefer's work is like nobody else's. Often daunting in size and undeniably bizarre in its physical structure, it is predicated upon myths and magics, both private and public, that are quite unfamiliar in this country.

title: FARMERS OPPOSE A PLAN TO SAVE THEIR LAND
description: RIVERHEAD town planners want developers to bear more of the public load that their residential developments create, and under a proposal, developers would be compelled to provide for not only the physical structures, like roads, but also the preservation of vast amounts of farmland, the town's most valuable natural resource.

title: SHOREHAM'S FUTURE: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
description: LEAD: BECAUSE of its complexities and frequent twists and turns, understanding the status of the Long Island Lighting Company application to operate the Shoreham nuclear power plant in the face of broad local opposition has never been easy.

title: A BACHELOR NEIGHBORHOOD
description: In his article ''A Neighborhood'' (About Men, Nov. 8), George Pollock proudly relates that he is ''chief cook, cleaner and handyman - as well as interior decorator, gardener, washerwoman, shopper (complete with coupons) and bill-payer.'' Evidently, these are roles that his former wife played when she wasn't managing his social life and providing the ''womanly restraints'' that prevented him from ''reverting to the wild state.''

title: A BACHELOR NEIGHBORHOOD
description: It is no wonder that George Pollock is divorced.

title: A Clear Picture of Affordable VCR's
description: WITH VCR'S RANKING high on countless Christmas lists, an appraising look at some recent models may be in order. Let's, for a change, not start at the top. Sure, it's nice to have the best picture and the latest features. But the latest advances in these respects add greatly to the cost. Viewers who simply want a reliable, basic VCR can save a good deal of money without sacrificing any really esssential functions by staying away from the leading edge of video technology.

title: Corrections
description: A cruise listing on Nov. 1 carried an incorrect description from the Royal Viking Line for the amenities in a Dec. 21 cruise aboard the Royal Viking Sea. The fare does not include a two-night hotel stay.

title: Mafia Prefers Nicknames, New York Trial Tape Shows
description: Sometimes, a distinctive nickname can be helpful in becoming a member of the Mafia.

title: Special Hanukkah Celebrated in Japan
description: WE eagerly anticipated the holiday season even though we'd be dispersed at divergent global points. Our son would commemorate his 25th birthday with his first trip abroad - destination London. Our daughter would be in Florida with her newly acquired college friends, and we'd be on our inaugural trip to the Orient. I had packed off each of my children with gifts to be opened only on Hanukkah and, for my further assuasion, left the menorah filled with candles. We would arrive home on the last day of the celebration, and at least on that one day they could be lighted.

title: A Soldier's Plot
description: Corazon C. Aquino, who has had a trying tenure as president of the Philippines, found something to be ''really overjoyed'' about last week. In a raid on a Manila townhouse, the police captured Col. Gregorio Honasan, the army officer who in August led an attempt to topple the Aquino Government. The authorities said Colonel Honasan would face ''due process of law'' for his part in an attempted coup that left 53 people dead and hundreds wounded, including Mrs. Aquino's son, Benigno. In the months between the attempted coup and the colonel's capture, some suspected that he was being protected by opposition political figures. Indeed, one such figure, Senator Juan Ponce Enrile, promptly announced that his law firm would defend Colonel Honasan, who was captured at the home of one of Mr. Enrile's former aides.

title: GOING UNDERCOVER FOR ART'S SAKE
description: RESTING ON AN easel, the 15th-century ''Madonna of the Graces'' was lost amid the impatient cameramen and bureaucrats.

title: How to Retool the Weapons Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: 'COMMUNIST NO. 1' IS HAILED AT HOME
description: Vladimir Dunayev, the Washington correspondent for Soviet television, was so taken by the strong impression that Mikhail S. Gorbachev made on many Americans in Washington this week that tonight he violated the unspoken etiquette of reporting on Soviet leaders. He gushed.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN BUSINESS CELEBRATIONS
description: IN the wake of the stock market's plunge, some budgets have been trimmed, but most businesses are still planning to follow their holiday traditions of years past, whether it's playing host to an employee party, wining and dining valued customers or giving gifts. Indeed, some companies that canceled parties right after the Oct. 19 stock market meltdown ''are regretting and trying to rebook,'' said Nicholas Baxter, a Manhattan corporate caterer.

title: New Peak Is Reported In New York Employees
description: Local government employed 447,000 people, a record number, in New York City during the first nine months of this year, according to Federal labor officials.

title: Earthquake Off Japan
description: A strong earthquake with a preliminary reading of 5.6 on the Richter scale occurred in the Pacific Ocean off central Japan today, the Hong Kong observatory reported. The observatory said the quake hit at 12:56 P.M. and its epicenter was about 340 miles south of Tokyo in an area where several small islands are located. The observatory had no additional information on the quake. There were no reports of damage or casualties.

title: The Bosporus
description: To the Editor: Alan Cowell's account of his trip to the Bosporus via zig-zag ferry (Travel, Nov. 8) stirs pleasant memories. From an earlier New York Times piece, my wife and I learned of this commuter run a few years ago. That article directed us to Pier 1 near the Galata Bridge in Istanbul as the launch site.

title: Marbled Paper From Florence
description: IN Turkey where it flourished in the 15th century, marbled paper making was known as ebru, or the art of the clouds.

title: Man and Wives
description: For a five-year period in the early 1980's, four marriages and two divorces added up to one wife too many for Vito J. Castellano. Mr. Castellano, the former commanding officer of New York State's militia, who is a prosecution witness in the Wedtech Corporation bribery trial, admitted in court last week that bigamy was among the crimes he committed around the same time he was taking bribes from Wedtech. The 61-year-old Mr. Castellano, who has pleaded guilty to tax evasion and falsifying documents, said he took $58,000 in bribes to support the two wives and two households he maintained until one of his wives died last spring. He had married each of the women twice, but did not divorce his first wife a second time before remarrying his second wife a second time.

title: The Fawning After
description: Here is the central fact of the recent summit meeting: Mikhail Gorbachev spent only 330 minutes in so-called working sessions with Mr. Reagan (including lunch) but spent 420 minutes in hard-selling the new Soviet line to awe-struck celebrities, ga-ga politicians and businessmen, tongue-tied media executives and a frustrated press corps.

title: PANELS AND LEADERS IN CAPITAL FOCUS ON FISCAL ISSUES
description: AS the artificial Christmas tree was going up section by section last week in an atrium of the State Capitol, legislators and other officials were making lists as visions of Feb. 3 - never mind Dec. 25 - danced in their heads.

description: To the Editor:

If You're Thinking of Living in:;
CALDWELL
description: LEAD: A GENTLE but cold rain was falling in Caldwell on a recent Saturday morning as many early-rising residents huddled in the warmth of the Colony Diner on Bloomfield Avenue.

title: Chile Opposition Struggles to Gain TV Time
description: During a recent swing through Chile's desert north, President Augusto Pinochet strongly criticized a prominent Socialist politician and equated him with the President of Nicaragua.

title: Prosecutors Seeking to Link 3 Held in a Bomb Smuggling
description: Federal prosecutors have asked three Canadians accused of smuggling a bomb into the United States to submit to a series of tests in an effort to link them to each other.

title: St. John's Defeats U.C.L.A.
description: Michael Porter's act may be news to many college basketball fans, but for Jerome (Pooh) Richardson, U.C.L.A.'s backcourt flash, Porter's high-flying acrobatics are old hat.

title: WHAT HAPPENED TO THE MARKET?
description: It is curious that when the market experiences a decline, members of the securities industry and the Administration refer to the phenomenon as a ''correction'' (On Language: ''What Happened to the Market?'' by William Safire, Nov. 8). However, when the market goes up, the term ''correction'' is never applied. This linguistic disparity illogically implies that it is incorrect or unnatural for the market to be high, and correct for it to be low.

title: The Subway's Police Force: Battling a Poor Reputation
description: THE New York City transit police have often been branded a second-class force, and the criticism has continued through much of the 1980's - from the death of Michael Stewart after his violent arrest in 1983 to the latest reports of false arrests by officers trying to improve their performance records.

title: THE COVERAGE OF COLLEGES PRESENTS A DISTORTED PICTURE
description: WHEN I was faculty representative for athletics at Duke University, I thought I had learned something about college sports and the news media. When I moved to Dallas last summer and became president of Southern Methodist University with a mandate to put behind us the athletic problems of the previous year, I knew that I was about to learn a great deal more. The experience has not been disappointing in that regard, and let me add that while news-media coverage of S.M.U.'s recent problems has been extraordinary, it has also been generally fair and judicious. On the wider sports media scene, however, I believe there is reason for concern and room for improvement.

title: Battling the Doldrums in Condo Sales
description: CONDOMINIUM developers are turning to clearance sales, low down payments and other marketing techniques to help sell an overload of new condominium apartments in Manhattan. But sales activity has grown sluggish as the financial trauma on Wall Street intensifies a traditional winter downturn.

title: TWO RELIGIONS FOR ONE GRANDCHILD
description: MY grandson has a Jewish mother and a Catholic father. This is not unusual. There is hardly a family today in which someone hasn't married outside the faith. What is unusual is that my grandson, now 5 years old, is making me aware of my religion.

title: POSTINGS: In Jersey City; Seriously, Folks
description: First, vaudeville stopped being funny. Then a fire burned off the top floor. Finally, Jersey City, itself, began to slip. All in all, Florida Flats had hit hard times.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: LEAD: BARBIE: Her Life & Times. By BillyBoy. (Crown, $25.) Looking at a teal blue and shocking-pink cover, an author with the trademark name of ''BillyBoy*,'' and a title that promises the life history of Barbie Doll, you might assume that this coffeetable book is a put on. No such luck. ''Barbie: Her Life & Times'' is a dead serious, naively written, reverential and lavishly illustrated account of everything that has happened to Barbie, her friends, her family and, most of all, her clothes, since she was born as a full-blown teen-ager in 1959.

description: Crate Crackdown In Pennsylvania

title: Impatience Seen in Bus Theft
description: A man heading for California on a Greyhound bus apparently grew impatient while waiting for it to leave a terminal and stole an empty bus, driving it half a mile before he was arrested, the police said. They said that what made the incident even odder was that the man,. Norman Harrington, 36 years old, of South Wales, N.Y., was on crutches. The bus was taken Thursday from Greyhound's Erie terminal in suburban Millcreek Township on Thursday, the police said.

title: LANGUAGE NO HANDICAP TO MUSICAL'S STAR
description: LEAD: MARY SOREANU, currently starring in the Off Broadway English-Yiddish musical revue ''On Second Avenue,'' did not even understand Yiddish until after she arrived in Israel as a teen-ager in 1967.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: RODIN A Biography. By Frederic V. Grunfeld. Illustrated. 738 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $35.

title: Leslie Glick to Wed
description: A March wedding is planned by Leslie Janice Glick and Dr. Michael Goldberg. Announcement of their engagement has been made by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Glick of Liberty, N.Y. Dr. Goldberg is the son of Rosalie Goldberg of East Brunswick, N.J., and the late Max Goldberg. The future bride is a product manager at Lederle International in Wayne, N.J., a division of the American Cyanamid Company. Dr. Goldberg is a dentist in New York.

title: Daily News Reaches an Accord With the Last of Its 10 Unions
description: The Daily News reached a tentative agreement with the last of its 10 newspaper unions yesterday after nearly a year of intense labor negotiations that the paper has consistently described as critical to its survival.

title: In and Out of Storyville: Jazz and Fiction
description: ONE morning in New Orleans I went to a jazz funeral. The deceased was Thomas Jefferson, a trumpet player, gone now at 65. His own band was going to play. It was cool and cloudy when my wife and I, with the baby in his stroller, joined a crowd gathered on the sidewalk and street outside the funeral home. We were there for second-lining. The first line at a jazz funeral is family and friends, there to mourn; the second-liners come to follow the slow music down the street until the band stops, the body is passed by it, then the line of march reverses, the music gets fast and the dancing starts.

title:
WINE;
SAMPLING SPARKLBNG WINES FOR HOLIDAYS
description: LEAD: RESULTS of two recent samplings of sparkling wine provide insights for area consumers planning to accompany the holiday season with a glass or more of bubbly.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY HANUKKAH Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, lasts for eight days. This year, the first candle will be lighted at sundown Tuesday, the last on Dec. 22. But actually the celebrating starts a bit earlier. For example, today at the Elmont Jewish Center, 500 Elmont Road, in a pre-Hanukkah Adult Education Breakfast at 10:45 A.M., the folk singer Oscar Brand performs his ''Welcome to America'' program. Call 488-1616 for ticket information.Staying in the neighborhood, the American Chamber Ensemble offers its Hanukkah Concert, with works on a Jewish theme by Prokofiev, Bloch, Engel and Kougell, at 3 P.M. at the Lawrence Country Day School on Meadowview Avenue in Hewlett Bay Park. Courtesy of the Hewlett-Woodmere Public Library, the performance is free. Another chamber ensemble, the Roslyn Artists String Quartet, contributes its ''Musicale Judaica: A Jewish Pops Concert'' of classical and folk compositions, at 3:30 P.M. at the South Shore Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., 25 Castleton Court in Oceanside. For ticket information call 766-4341.

title: Next Week; Can Bo Jackson Succeed in 2 Sports?
description: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: LEAD: CHRONICLE OF THE 20TH CENTURY. Clifton Daniel, editor in chief. (Chronicle Publications, Suite 311, 105 South Bedford Road, Mount Kisco, N.Y. 10549, $49.95.) title: Bangladesh Leader Is Defied As Protesters Begin a Strike
description: Opponents of the Government and most shopkeepers in Dhaka defied a Government ban and began a dawn-to-dusk general strike today in an effort to overthrow President H. M. Ershad.

title: Miss Stuart Weds Michael Shnayerson
description: At the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Cynthia Stuart, the daughter of Mary Stuart Neumann of New York and Weston, Conn., and Richard Krolik of Washington, was married yesterday to Michael Shnayerson, the son of Robert Shnayerson of New York and Hillsdale, N.Y., and the late Lydia Todd Shnayerson. The Rev. David H. C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: COOL STORIES, INFLAMED POETS
description: A TRULY capitalist country is one that can afford not one but several annual collections of ''best'' short stories. While short story collections used to be notoriously poor sellers, they are proliferating - which means either that the market for them has improved, or that American literature has, in some improbable way, transcended the question of sales.

title: Pennsylvania Drunken Driving Cases Doubted
description: Thousands of convictions for drunken driving in Pennsylvania are now in question because of faulty breath analyzers that led to arrest for the innocent and release for the guilty, a state official says.

title: Fresh Voices Hope to Be Far From Wobegon
description: THIS SATURDAY EVENING, when listeners gather around their radio sets and tune to their local public-radio station - in New York City, WNYC-FM from 6 to 8 - they will preview a continuing anomaly: a live radio show performed before a live studio audience, featuring music, storytelling and comedy sketches. And while the format may sound strikingly familiar, gone is the host often described as lanky and woebegone. Instead, the new host is rather short and considered.

title: TRANQUIL TIMELESSNESS OF THE PARK
description: THE park has been our refuge for the last three seasons. From the earliest days of tolerable spring through the warm autumn, my son and I have visited our sanctuary religiously.

description: A court today imposed a death sentence in absentia on the deposed President, Ali Nasser Mohammed al-Hassani, on charges of treason.

description: WHILE President Reagan and the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev were writing a new chapter in United States-Soviet relations last week, Shelley Zeiger, a Trenton importer, was hard at work on a small footnote.

HOW TO PRESERVE A CHRISTMAS TREE
description: LEAD: EVERGREENS have long played an important role in winter holiday decor. In fact, primitive northern societies used evergreens to celebrate midwinter festivals long before the establishment of Christmas.

title: SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
description: No. Mookie and Len Dykstra are both aggressive base runners, good fielders and switch-hitters to boot. But the leadoff hitter should make contact or walk. Dykstra will lead the Mets in plate appearances and runs scored. RICHARD H. MARX Stamford, Conn.

title: Commercial Property: Labeling Buildings; A Name Can Build an Image - or Scare Off Tenants
description: IN 1925 the Postum Cereal Company moved into an office building on Park Avenue bearing its name. A year later Farmer's Loan and Trust followed suit on Fifth Avenue. Today one name has become a piece of nostalgia to market aggressively; the other, a burden to shake off.

title: CHAMPAGNE: A COOL GRIP
description: A LESSON in the art of drinking Champagne is neatly provided in a single picture by the French Ambassador to the United States, Emmanuel de Margerie; his wife, Helene, and Mayor Koch.

title: But Tougher Issues Await a New Round
description: IN all of the long and turbulent history of Soviet-American relations, through 17 summit conferences and countless agreements, through blow-ups in Paris and Reykjavik and calmer days in Yalta and Glassboro, there has never been a week quite like the one when Mikhail S. Gorbachev came calling on Ronald Reagan in Washington. It was momentous, it was revealing and it was fun.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Old Quarries Emerge as Housing Sites
description: LEAD: OLD quarries scattered across New Jersey that are no longer used for mining stone or sand are increasingly being adapted as housing sites. Four such projects in Essex and Sussex Counties will together produce more than 1,000 dwelling units.

description: LEGISLATORS in Essex and Bergen Counties will square off soon over whether Van Saun Park Zoo in Paramus or the Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange should be designated the official state zoo.

description: ''THERE'S another war,'' my mother said.

description: The brother of Mayor George Voinovich of Cleveland and the Geauga County Republican leader were indicted Wednesday.

title: TWO NEW BANKS OPEN OFFICES IN WHITE PLAINS
description: JUDGING from the proliferation of banks on every corner, downtown White Plains has become a major banking center. And two newcomers, the American Savings Bank and the Apple Bank for Savings, are joining the competition. Even though more than two dozen banks in White Plains are already vying for business, the chief executives of the most recent arrivals, John T. Morgan, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Savings Bank and Jerome R. McDougal, chairman of Apple Bank for Savings, say that the potential business in the county warrants their presence in White Plains.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor: I recently returned from my first and most certainly my only trip to Mexico. While several guidebooks that I purchased before the trip implored me to make sure my car was safeguarded regularly and that bribery of officials is a virtual way of life, I felt that my trip would be restful and enjoyable and that those statements could not apply to a resort town like Puerto Vallarta. I was most assuredly wrong. A short time into the trip, at about 9 P.M. on Nov. 11, a friend and I were stopped by Mexican police near the Gloria del Mar Hotel. We were both asked to present drivers' licenses, even though I was not driving, and were told that we had been driving the wrong way down a one-way street and turned incorrectly onto the present street.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GOLD CUP RACERS Baby Bootlegger, a fully restored 30-foot powerboat that won the Gold Cup Races in 1924 and 1925 will be on display at Mystic Seaport until April 10 in an exhibition titled ''A Gentlemanly Pursuit: Gold Cup Racing in the 1920's.''

title: LOOKING FOR MR. WRIGHT
description: LEAD: MANY MASKS A Life of Frank Lloyd Wright. By Brendan Gill. Illustrated. 544 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $24.95.

title: A Man in Jersey Surrenders To the Police After Standoff
description: A man described as emotionally troubled is said to have admitted that he killed a neighbor whose body was found in their apartment building, then barricaded himself in his apartment for six hours before surrendering tonight, the authorities said.

title: Court Rules Out Town's Cross
description: A lighted cross atop a Christmas tree in the town of Hyde Park should be removed because it is ''a symbol of the Christian beliefs of the community,'' a Federal magistrate has ruled.

title: Sports of The Times; Glasnost For Mets, Yankees
description: THE trade was hardly the magnitude of Star Wars, such as Darryl Strawberry for Don Mattingly. It was nowhere near the importance of long-range nuclear arms, such as Dwight Gooden for Dave Righetti. The trade involved only intermediate-range and short-range missiles: Rafael Santana and four minor leaguers. But it was the first time in the 25-year chill of coexistence between the Mets and the Yankees that the two New York teams had swapped a major-league player. Glasnost on the Triborough Bridge, at least for the moment.

title: Rori Glover Wed
description: Rori Lisa Glover, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Glover of North Caldwell, N.J., was married last evening to Richard Edward Berse, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gurson Berse of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Charles Kroloff performed the ceremony at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N.J. The bride, an account executive at Country Home magazine in New York, graduated from Boston University. Mr. Berse, who graduated from Lehigh University, is a certified public accountant in New York.

title: Two Artists, One Goal
description: MODERN DANCE HAS been called an art of rugged individualism, and modern-dance choreographers usually go their own creative ways. In contrast, Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis are two choreographers who for 38 years have worked in harmony together, even though each directs a company with its own esthetic personality: Mr. Nikolais is famous for multimedia experiments; Mr. Louis has developed a dance style capable of being lyrical one moment and perkily comic the next. However, unlike most modern-dance troupes, the Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company have occasionally shared New York engagements since the early 1970's.

title: A TRADITIONAL ENGLISH CRISTMAS FEAST
description: FOR me, Christmas dinner has to be traditional. That means a serious roast - goose, turkey or suckling pig - and plum pudding brought flaming to the table. Being British, I am used to dishes that might seem unusual to an American, but they are very much part of our repertoire and date back to long before the Revolution. At this time of year, like many immigrants, I get nostalgic for ''the old country'' and a traditional feast reminds me of home.

title: Manila Security Is a Worry for Asian Parley
description: The myriad security concerns of this struggling nation have come to the fore this weekend on the eve of a six-nation regional summit meeting.

title: Social Events
description: Day and Night for All Ages Rainbow Restoration Dec. 13 - After two years of refurbishing, the two-story complex atop the RCA Building at Rockefeller Center will reopen to the public Dec. 29. But first, three preliminary events will introduce guests to the restored glitter of one of the premier nightspots in the city. From 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. there will be a cocktail buffet, at which the team responsible for the restoration will guide guests through the Rainbow Room and such other restored rooms as the Rainbow Pavilion and the Rockefeller Center Club. From 3 to 6 P.M. there will be a tea dance, cocktails and a buffet, and a lecture by the urban historian Barry Lewis. At 7 P.M. cocktails will precede a black-tie dinner-dance, at which Jacqueline Onassis and Brendan Gill will honor William Shawn and The New Yorker magazine. The three events will benefit the Municipal Art Society and its efforts to create a more pleasing city. Tickets for the 11:30 A.M. preview, $50 for society members, $85 for nonmembers; for the tea dance, $75 for members, $110 for nonmembers, and $1,000 for the dinner-dance. Tickets for day events can be purchased at the door and for the dinner-dance from 212-874-4098. 'Paris in Japan' Dec. 14 - While the effect of Japanese art on French painters in the 19th and early 20th centuries is well known, the impact of the French on Japanese art has been more obscure. A private showing of 77 oil paintings from 33 public and private collections in Japan will explore this phenomenon at a benefit exhibition and reception for La Maison Francaise of Columbia University and the Japan House Gallery, 333 East 47th Street. The ''Paris in Japan'' show will be held at the gallery from 6 to 8 P.M. Tickets, $25, or $20 for members of La Maison Francaise, at the door. Information: 212-280-4482. Briefly Noted: Dec. 14 - Barbara Cook, Cy Coleman, Tom Jones and a score of other singers and songwriters are to perform at an 8 P.M. AIDS benefit at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. A Champagne reception follows. Tickets, $100 and $200 from 212-534-5366, or for performance alone, $25 and $50 at the door. Dec. 15 - The North Star Fund, part of a national network of philanthropies, will benefit from a cocktail party from 6 to 8 P.M., with Brazilian hors d'oeuvres and music followed by a performance by Herbie Mann at Sounds of Brazil, Varick and Houston Streets. Tickets, $30, at the door. Information: 212-460-5511. Dec. 15 - Henry A. Kissinger will be the main speaker at a black-tie dinner celebration at the New York Hilton for the 10th anniversary of Tel Aviv University's Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies. Cocktails, 7 P.M. Tickets, $500, from 212-687-5651. Dec. 16 - Matthew Nash Music and Dance will have a benefit ballet preview and reception at 890 Broadway, at 19th Street. Performances at 6:30 and 8 P.M., with a reception after the 8 P.M. performance. Tickets, $10 for performances and $20 for the party, at the door. Information: 212-674-1917. Dec. 17 - St. Michael's Home for the Aged in Yonkers, founded 28 years ago by the Women's Guild of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America in New York, is holding a benefit black-tie dinner-dance at the Pierre, with cocktails at 7:30 P.M. Tickets, $150, from Mary Lou Steel at 212-983-7500. Mansion Party Dec. 17 - The mansion at 7 East 95th Street, with the interior of a northern Italian palazzo and furnishings from the 14th, 15th and 16th centuries and a ceiling painting attributed to Raphael, was completed in 1914 by a granddaughter of Commodore Vanderbilt. It remains an ideal setting for a formal dinner-dance. The evening, with cocktails at 7 P.M., will benefit the performance season of the New York Art Theater Institute, which presents plays of literary and fine arts interest in museums and theaters. An unusual touch for the evening is the individually designed crinoline ball dresses in the style of 1850, in black, lilac and cream, that women can order for $99.95. Tickets, $175, or $75 for those under 30, from 212-996-3512. Hanukkah Celebration Dec. 19 - The Jewish National Fund New Leadership of Greater New York is sponsoring ''A New York Chanuka'' at the Crystal Pavilion, 805 Third Avenue near 49th Street. There will be a buffet, dancing and an open bar starting at 8:30 P.M. Tickets, $50 from 212-737-7441, or $60 at the door. La Fiesta Dec. 19 - ''La Fiesta Navidena Puertorriquena'' will feature Puerto Rican music, food and dance in a Christmas celebration designed for people who don't speak Spanish as well as for Hispanic people. Sponsored by the Ethnic Folk Arts Center in association with the Albizu Campos Community Center and the Association of Hispanic Arts, the benefit will be held from 7 P.M. to midnight at the Campos Plaza Community Center, 611 East 13th Street, between Avenues B and C. Admission, $3 at the door; free to those under 3 and over 60. Information: 212-691-9510. Students' Party Dec. 20 - The 31st annual Gold and Silver Ball for the Youth Counseling League's vocational and psychiatric services in New York City and Westchester will be held at the Palladium from 8:30 P.M. to 1 A.M. The nonalcoholic black-tie evening for high school students and college freshmen will have a waltz orchestra as well as disco music, and a buffet dinner. Tickets, $145, from 212-473-4300.

title: A VOTE FOR VOLCKER
description: As Leonard Silk's article ''Volcker on the Crash'' (Nov. 8) demonstrated, Paul Volcker is one of the most respected men in this country and throughout the world. I applaud and agree with his statement: ''We can control events if we do the right things.'' And there is, as he believes, time to deal with the underlying problems threatening the American and world economies. But to deal with these economic and political problems in time, we need a leader who knows what to do. Let's start a movement: Volcker for President. EDNA FUERTH LEMLE New York, N.Y.
