title: John Huston's Last Legacy
description: ''IT HAD BEGUN TO SNOW again. He watched sleepily the flakes, silver and dark, falling obliquely against the lamplight. The time had come for him to set out on his journey westward. Yes, the newspapers were right: snow was general all over Ireland. It was falling on every part of the dark central plain, on the treeless hills, falling softly upon the Bog of Allen and, farther westward, softly falling into the dark mutinous Shannon waves. It was falling, too, upon every part of the lonely churchyard on the hill where Michael Furey lay buried. It lay thickly drifted on the crooked crosses and headstones, on the spears of the little gate, on the barren thorns. His soul swooned slowly as he heard the snow falling faintly through the universe and faintly falling, like the descent of their last end, upon all the living and the dead.''

title: SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
description: The Mets should keep Mookie Wilson. Not only is he a fine fine ballplayer but Len Dykstra has become unreliable, homer-happy, and is not the fielder Wilson is. He should also be kept in an attempt to show that the Mets do not have a racial quota system. THOMAS E. HILTON Brooklyn

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: THE VIEW FROM THE KINGDOM: A New England Album. By Richard Brown and Reeve Lindbergh. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $24.95 until Jan. 1; $29.95 thereafter.) The nostalgia of city dwellers for life in the country will be well-fed by this delectable coffeetable book, a collaborative effort by the husband and wife team of Reeve Lindbergh and the photographer Richard Brown. Noel Perrin's introduction defines the area under scrutiny - the Northeast Kingdom, that upper-right-hand corner of Vermont where it abuts New Hampshire and Canada and cows heavily outnumber people. Mr. Brown is my favorite upcountry artist with a camera. His photographs have such crisp luminosity I think I would recognize them anywhere. Uniquely, he captures the quality of northern light, whether it's the beatification of a curly Dorset sheep or the stunning blow of sunlight hammering the east face of a snowed-in farmhouse. These pictures may occasionally idealize, but they do not cloy. Mr. Brown's authentic pigs, goats, hens and horses lift the spirit. Those who face the winter down with wood stoves, salute spring with maple taps and new lambs or foals, will appreciate the few glimpses and black humor Reeve Lindbergh's text allows. One of her best essays, ''Wood and Blood,'' contains just the right combination of love and bile.

'TWIN' BAS MITZVAHS

title: Hip Graphics
description: THE COMPUTER-GENERATED images above represent a human hip. Reading left to right, two rows at a time (the white images illustrate bone structure; the surrounding musculature is in red), the hip appears to be rotating on a vertical axis. It's stop-action photography. Imagine the rotation performed before your eyes on a screen, the illusion of three dimensions, and you envision the accomplishment of innovative hardware and software now being readied for market by Pixar, a computer firm based in San Rafael, Calif. ''It's as if the physician has the hip in his hand,'' says Elliot K. Fishman.

description: Gary Kasparov made only the most careful and delicate attempt to gain advantage against Anatoly Karpov in the 22d game of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Friday, and unsurprisingly, he was held to a draw. The score is tied 11.

title: A SELLER'S MARKET FOR STORE HELP
description: WHAT is worrying retailers this Christmas season is not so much the number of buyers. It is the number of sellers. And they are going to great lengths in their pursuit of peace of mind.

title: MOVIES
description: Anchors Aweigh Starring Gene Kelly, Frank Sinatra, Dean Stockwell. 1945. MGM/UA Home Video. 146 minutes. $29.95. In ''Anchors Aweigh,'' Gene Kelly and Frank Sinatra play two sailors on the loose in Los Angeles. The breezy duo, who are searching, of course, for a good-looking dame, find instead a precocious lad who wants to join the Navy. The small boy (Dean Stockwell) has a beautiful Aunt Susie, and astute viewers can easily surmise the rest.

title: NURSERIES ARE CLONING PLANTS
description: THE fastest growing sector of Connecticut's agricultural industry is turning to high technology to meet increased demand for its products.

title: 'WE CERTAINLY NEED NOURISHING FOOD'
description: HUNGER is an urgent problem in the cities and rural areas of the state, according to the Rev. Robert Betts, the director of the Connecticut Food Bank in New Haven. Mr. Betts, an ordained Episcopal priest and a social worker, struggles daily with the problem of hunger.

title: 'SOMEONE HAD TO LOSE'
description: LAST month, for the first time in my life, I ran for public office.

title: In Search Of the Perfect Margarita
description: LEAD: A WIT once declared that you will never be lonely when traveling, be it in the Sahara or the high Himalayas, if you take along the makings for a salad. As soon as you bring out the oil and vinegar someone is bound to pop up and show you the only way to make the perfect dressing.

title: NICARAGUA PLANS MILITARY BUILDUP
description: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua plans to more than double its military forces over the next seven years and increase the number of warplanes and other weapons over fear of a United States invasion.

title: SEDUCED BY THE GLOW OF MEMORY
description: SOME YEARS AGO, AFTER HAVING WRITTEN what must have been an especially effusive review of an Arthur Rubinstein recital, I received a long, remarkably detailed letter of disapproval from a young pianist. In particular, he wanted to chide me for being so bedazzled by the Rubinstein reputation that I could not recognize what was clearly an ''abominably imprecise, slovenly'' performance of the final movement of Chopin's ''Funeral March'' Sonata. To substantiate the charge, the young Chopinist included a privately recorded tape of his own version, which he challenged me to compare, note for note, measure for measure, with that of the more famous artist. The tape documented an obviously spliced performance of this gusty, rather spooky movement that was indeed remarkably precise. However, I had to confess that it evoked nothing much more than the image of a champion typist rattling away in a speed contest.

title: A MODERN SCROOGE: 'EBENEZER!'
description: MAYBE the revivals that the fledgling theater company in nearby Fairfield, Conn., has announced for next year will validate its claim to the name Music Theater of Connecticut; its inaugural attraction, ''Ebenezer!,'' emphatically does not.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TIFFANY: 150 YEARS OF 'FANCY ARTICLES'
description: LEAD: ALL THAT glitters at Tiffany & Company is not gold, silver or precious gems, but such luxuries have maintained the image of this retailing establishment as a favorite of presidents, potentates and generations of carriage-trade customers.

title: A Skating Party for Brooklyn Children
description: Stephen Smith, brother-in-law of former Senator Robert F. Kennedy, and Courtney Kennedy Ruhe, a daughter of the Senator, at a skating party for disadvantaged children from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. The annual event is held in honor of the Senator, who was assassinated in 1968. (The New York Times/Dith Pran)

title: Wendy A. Miller To Wed in Spring
description: Dr. and Mrs. Maurice H. Miller of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Ann Miller, to Paul Scott Lurrie, a son of Eileen Lurrie of Glen Oaks, Queens, and the late Lawrence Lurrie. A spring wedding is planned.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TEAROOM IN APPEARANCE ONLY
description: LEAD: JERDENS, in the Bergen County community of Westwood, is a little difficult to find, but it's worth the effort because the 14-month-old restaurant serves a variety of innovative and, at times, delicious dishes.

title: Dr. George H. Brown; Led Research at RCA
description: Dr. George H. Brown, former executive vice president for research and engineering at the RCA Corporation who led the company's development of color television, died Friday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: THE EMBATTLED MRS. AQUINO
description: When Mrs. Aquino left a meeting on land reform, an issue vital to the Philippines, to go to court to file a libel suit because her ego was hurt, she proved that, even after 19 months in office, she cannot do the job.

title: Sylvia Plath
description: To the Editor:

title: January Wedding For Mary Tinsley
description: Mary Tinsley, an associate deputy secretary of Labor in Washington, and Alan Charles Raul, an associate counsel to the President, plan to marry Jan. 30.

title: Young Shoppers
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance: Pennison's 'Nightlight'
description: MARLEEN PENNISON'S dance pieces often use spoken or recorded texts that are integrated with movement. In the past, her works have been strong on character study, suggesting they might spring from a literary sensibility.

title: Hiram Lewis Bell 3d Wed To Donna Grant, an Editor
description: At the Riverside Church in Manhattan, Donna Marie Grant, the daughter of Gloria H. Frye of Laurelton, Queens, and the late Charles H. Goins, was married to Hiram Lewis Bell 3d, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Bell Jr. of Brooklyn. The Rev. Fanny Erickson performed the ceremony.

title: RECENT ISSUES HONOR FAMOUS PERSONAGES
description: MANY nations have restrictions on depicting living people on stamps. For example, the United States will not issue such a stamp until a person has been deceased for at least 10 years. Exceptions are recently-deceased American Presidents.

title: TESTING FOR RADON TO BEGIN IN 14 AREAS
description: A STEPPED-UP effort to determine areas with radon problems is under way at the State Department of Health Services. Last week, the department distributed testing devices for 1,400 homes.

title: Elisa A. Mitchell To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Elisa Anne Mitchell to Dr. Thomas Joseph McDonough Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. McDonough of Madison, N.J., and Southold, L.I., has been made known by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul L. Mitchell of Huntington, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: THE DON: GOING STRONG AT 200
description: THE GREATEST OPERA - SO a surprising number of people who dare to nominate one have called it - is 200 years old this season. Whatever its absolute standing among the great, ''Don Giovanni,'' first heard on Oct. 29, 1787, in Prague, can claim one primacy without question. It did something no other opera before it had ever done - it survived its epoch.

title: Madaline Baker Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen H. Baker of Weston, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Madaline Parke Baker to Joseph Albert Kennedy, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Albert F. Kennedy of Winchester, Mass. The future bride, who graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University, is a candidate for a master's degree in communications and international relations at Boston University. The future bridegroom, who also graduated from Tufts, is a partner in R. T. Britt Associates, real-estate developers in Boston.

title:
ART;
FOUR YOUNG PRIZE-WINNERS TAKE A VARIETY OF PATHS
description: LEAD: IF a major aim of the open competitive exhibition is the discovery of emerging young artists, then last fall's competition sponsored by the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island certainly reached that ideal.

title: New Council for Haiti Vote Sworn In
description: Clement Maurice Barthelemy was eating dinner with his family Friday night when he heard his name crackle across the radio: the Government had appointed him to the civilian council that is to organize the next presidential election.

title: IN SOMERS, A CASE OF TAKE AND GIVE
description: LEAD: WILLIAM C. HARDING says he will never forget his 35th birthday and the ''present'' he received that night from the Somers Town Board when he attended its meeting - a $7,800 salary cut.

title: JAMES BROOKS LAUNCHES A STAR
description: IN JAMES L. BROOKS'S NEW FILM, ''Broadcast News,'' a handsome new anchorman is called into television action during a crisis in the Middle East. As played by William Hurt, the anchorman is, intellectually, way over his head and completely unprepared for the demanding assignment. Jane Craig, the producer of the newscast and the heroine of the movie - a brainy, feisty and extraordinarily self-possessed young woman - speaks to the anchorman through a hidden Telex earpiece, and, while he is on camera, force-feeds him questions, information and direction. She is ''in'' his head and, with split-second timing, she leads him into giving a brilliant performance. Question: Jane Craig is played by: A. Sigourney Weaver. B. Meryl Streep. C. Kathleen Turner. D. None of the Above. The answer is D.

title: Music
description: Only part of Handel's ''Messiah'' is really suited to Advent, but that is when we do it in this country, and at least five varieties are available this week. My recommendation is a choice between two Baroque-oriented groups. The elegant ''Music Before 1800'' series at Corpus Christi Church on 121st Street is presenting the Amor Artis Chamber Choir and Baroque Ensemble Sunday at 4 P.M. with the unfailingly interesting and stylish Julianne Baird in the soprano solos (Johannes Somary conducts). Tuesday and Thursday at 7:30 P.M., the Concert Royal Ensemble, which has revived so many Baroque operas in New York, will give the work with the other leading ''early music'' soprano around town, Ann Monoyios (I remember her heartfelt singing as a ray of light in an otherwise gloomy, big-and-tired orchestra ''Messiah'' some years back; here she should be in her element).

title: India Is Agog At a Wedding In Full Regalia
description: The slim young prince arrived in a silver carriage, wearing a scarlet and gold tunic draped with pearls, diamonds and rubies. The princess emerged from an immense fairy tale palace that shimmered with strands of white lights.

title: A FAMILY MAKES MILK THE OLD WAY
description: ''THE amount of milk we would deliver to some houses depended on the number of clothespins a housewife left out on the step,'' Edith Shepherd said as she recalled the milk routes in the early 1900's. Mrs. Shepherd, who is 83 years old, represents the second generation of a four-generation dairy farm in Woodbridge.

title: ENDOWMENT DROPS 7.2% AT HARVARD
description: Harvard University says its endowment dropped 7.2 percent, to $3.85 billion, in October as a result of the stock market collapse, far less than the 21.6 percent drop in the market over all.

title: Putting the Brakes on a Runaway
description: THE wonderful new computer system was supposed to be up and running in June. It's now December, and the only thing exceeding expectations is the cost. Expenses are already twice what the consultant estimated they would be, with no end in sight. Morale is low, projects are delayed, and opportunities are being missed.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: LEAD: THE Borough of Metuchen has issued a request for proposals, due Feb. 1, seeking a developer to transform its 77-year-old Franklin School into apartments and build new apartments and a center for the elderly.

title: The Dollar's Drop
description: To the Editor:

title: East Germany in Games
description: East Germany has decided to participate in the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, and is expected to make an official announcement soon, the West German newsmagazine Der Spiegel reported today.

title: Jersey Casino Group Protests Ban on Politicking
description: The 10-member Atlantic City Casino Association has voted unanimously to support a casino official's challenge to New Jersey restrictions on casino participation in the political process.

title: Debuts; Felicity Lott Sings at the Frick
description: Felicity Lott

title: Holding Conferences Closer to Home
description: THE meetings industry records revenues of about $40 billion yearly, the principal beneficiaries being hotels and airlines, according to Mr. Hosansky of Successful Meetings magazine.

title: SENATE APPROVES BILL ON SPENDING WITH CONTRA AID
description: The Senate approved a $606 billion catch-all appropriation bill this morning that includes $7.6 billion in spending cuts required by the budget compromise between Congress and the White House. It also includes $16 million in nonmilitary aid for the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Travel Advisory
description: Seoul Hotels Fully Booked

title: New York State Reimburses Lawyer's Victims
description: In an unusual meeting, victims of a dishonest lawyer in Rockland County got an apology from the legal profession and a pledge of full restitution from a state agency this week.

title: Holiday Gifts With a Financial Twist
description: IF YOU are still scratching your head about what to give your executive spouse or Wall Street friend for the holidays, and want to buy something with a financial theme, here are some suggestions. There is even an idea or two for the budding 5-year-old investment banker in the family.

title: HUNTERS EXCEEDING LIMIT ON KILLING DEER
description: THE abundance of deer this year has more hunters beating the Connecticut brush, and many hunters are killing more deer than allowed.

title: MARSHALL FAULTS THE JUSTICE DEPT.
description: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court says the Justice Department has been so politicized that it is trying ''to undermine the Supreme Court itself.''

title: LEARNING BY EXPERIENCE - THE HARD WAY
description: EXPERIENCE may be the best teacher, as the old saying goes, but it surely is the most costly.

title: In Belgium, Will Familiarity Breed Coalition?
description: The campaign buses and mobile billboards rolled out of their garages in the gray dawn this morning for the last day of activity before yet another Belgian national election.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: LEAD: THIS month marks the third anniversary of the court-ordered closing of Hamm's Landfill in Lafayette Township, Sussex County, an action that left garbage piling up on the streets of Morris County and ushered in the state's solid-waste crisis.

title: SPEEDWELL CELEBRATES TELEGRAPH
description: LEAD: NEXT year marks the 150th anniversary of the first public demonstration of the telegraph, and special events are planned at several sites, including Speedwell, the restored historic village in Morristown.

title: ALL-STAR HOLIDAY ALBUM PRODUCERS SUED
description: The producers of ''A Very Special Christmas,'' the nonprofit all-star album whose proceeds are to benefit Special Olympics International, are being sued for $10 million in damages by Orpheum Records, which claims to have originated the idea for the project.

title: Why Choke Japanese Auto Imports?
description: Curbs on imports of Japanese cars were supposed to be temporary. Now almost seven years old, their cost to consumers has been staggering and the benefit to American car makers only marginal. Even so, Detroit has come up with a laughable new argument to make the ceiling lower still.

title: Is South Korea Ripe for Democracy - or More Repression?
description: POLITICAL parties in South Korea last about as long as the fashionable width of men's lapels. By custom, they exist only to serve the immediate needs of national politicians, and no party has outlasted the ambitions of its founder.

title: Comings and Goings
description: JOE PATERNO was honored last night at the Waldorf-Astoria as the 80th recipient of the Pennsylvania Society's Gold Medal for Distinguished Achievement. The society donated $25,000 in the Penn State coach's name to the university's Joe Paterno Library Endowment Fund. Paterno donated $150,000 to launch the fund in May 1986. . . . Bill Goodstein, the agent for Dave Righetti, said the Yankees had made a new proposal to the free-agent pitcher yesterday during a three-hour meeting, but ''we still have a long way to go.'' He said the offer contained ''some new wrinkles'' for his client, who has received a multimillion-dollar offer from a Japanese team.

title: A HOLLOW RING TO ROTHSTEIN'S DEFENSE
description: Polly Rothstein's defense of the tactics that she and the Westchester Coalition for Legal Abortion used against me in the recent election for County Legislature have a hollow ring to them. [ Letters, Nov. 29. ] The newsletter that W.C.L.A. sent out in the waning days of the campaign not only misrepresented my prochoice position on abortion, but resorted to outright character assassination. In it, Ms. Rothstein accused me of harboring ''vehement hostility toward women'' and a ''lack of compassion.''

title: SEATING CHANGED FOR ROCK CONCERTS
description: Officials at the New Haven Veterans Memorial Coliseum, after a stabbing death in a melee at a rap concert last month, have stopped selling open floor tickets for rock concerts.

title: Sampson Traded In 4-Player Deal
description: The Golden State Warriors acquired Ralph Sampson and Steve Harris from the Houston Rockets tonight in exchange for Joe Barry Carroll and Eric (Sleepy) Floyd.

title: Voter Registration Drive Takes Aim at Minorities
description: Saying that perhaps half of the eligible black and Hispanic residents of New York City are not registered to vote, a coalition of politicians, community groups and clergymen yesterday began a drive to sign up at least 250,000 minority-group voters in the next seven weeks.

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. I am having a problem removing nonskid bathtub decals I put down five years ago. I had taken up the old ones and put new ones in their place without ever getting all the old adhesive off. Now I would like to remove these decals and the sticky residue left. I have tried benzine, nail-polish remover and Spray 'N' Wash (which was recommended by the manufacturer of these decals), but I have only been able to remove the top layer, not the adhesive.

title: BIG MAN IN THE KITCHEN
description: EVEN IN HIS APRON, Charles Palmer looks like a fullback. The 28-year-old chef is 6 feet 3 inches, 236 pounds, and is clearly more than a match for the sea bass on the cutting board in front of him. Palmer runs a meaty left forefinger along the scales, then, with a few strokes of the knife in his right hand, bones the fish and splits it into two fillets.

title: RESTAURANT STAFF SERVES UP 'TOP GIRLS'
description: Six months ago Betsy Howie, a bartender at Phebe's Place on the Lower East Side, wrote to Caryl Churchill, the author of ''Serious Money.'' Could Ms. Howie and six other waitresses and bartenders at the restaurant produce ''Top Girls,'' another play by Ms. Churchill?

title: IRISH GROUP PLANS PROTEST AT BRITISH BAND CONCERT
description: LEAD: THE North New Jersey chapter of the Irish American Unity Conference plans to send some 350 demonstrators to the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford tomorrow night to protest a performance by the Grenadier Guards and the Gordon Highlanders, both British military bands.

title: NEW TUNIS CHIEF BEGINS DEMOCRATIC CHANGES
description: Soon after the new Government was installed a month ago, the theology school at the University of Tunisia reclaimed its old Islamic name, Zitouna.

title: CALIFORNIANS PUSH RIGHT-TO-DIE ISSUE
description: A voter-initiated referendum that would give terminally ill patients the right to choose a time to die is being proposed for the California ballot next year.

title: RESIDENTIAL RESALES
description: Closings in the week ended Nov. 28 MANHATTAN Murray Hill $220,000 155 East 34th Street (Warren House) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 822-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, new kitchen appliances; common charge $314, taxes $2,616 (Broker: Gala Realty) Sutton Place $515,000 60 Sutton Place South 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 972-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; part-time doorman, dining area, roof garden; maintenance $746, 50% tax-deductible (Broker:

title: STUDENTS ARE BRIEFED ON AIDS
description: ONE hundred and one teen-age journalists representing 35 high schools in northern New Jersey convened here recently for a course in AIDS education so they could teach their peers through their school newspapers.

title: Lake Titicaca
description: To the Editor: In 1974 we took the hydrofoil, just as Edwin McDowell did in ''The Lake Atop Bolivia'' (Travel, Nov. 29), from the Crillon Company's dock on Lake Titicaca. It was an April day, gray and drizzly. We were going to Copacabana with a stop along the way, to see the Aymaras' reed boats. There had been an unusual amount of rain that year. When we reached their island we found that the dock, a concrete pier, was under water. However, the Indians met our hydrofoil about 100 yards off shore. We climbed into their wooden sailboat, 20 or so of us, and about 10 Indians. The water reached within three inches of the rail.

title: U.S. FUGITIVE FREED AND THEN RETAKEN
description: Charles McVey 2d, an American fugitive wanted in the United States in connection with a multimillion dollar plot to sell advanced technology to the Soviet Union, was rearrested in a courthouse here Friday seconds after the judge freed him on an extradition warrant.

title: JERSEY CITY: EARLY COLLECTOR'S COLLECTION
description: THERE are no art lovers so ardent as those who buy the objects of their affection. It is also true that some of the United States's most patriotic citizens were born elsewhere.

title: Landmarks Panel Declines to Endorse Bryant Park Restaurant Plan
description: Although it has the backing of the Koch administration, a plan to build restaurants in Bryant Park has failed to win endorsement from the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, adding ambivalence to a four-year chronicle of contention.

title: New York City Maps Deadly Pattern of AIDS
description: In the South Bronx, the AIDS virus infects as many as one in five sexually active men, Dr. Ernest Drucker calculates. He warns women that such rampant infection makes intercourse with neighborhood men ''sexual Russian roulette.''

title: HISTORIC DISTRICT AT ISSUE IN OMAHA
description: In a city desperate for development, the pricetag on a plan for the new headquarters for a major local corporation is the destruction of a warehouse district that preservationists say is essential to understanding Omaha's role in the growth of the American west.

title: Mullin in Rehabilitation
description: Chris Mullin has entered an alcohol rehabilitation program and will be out of action indefinitely, the Golden State Warriors announced tonight.

title: DANCING TO DADDY'S FAVORITE JAM
description: BE-BOP, RE-BOP By Xam Wilson Cartier. 147 pp. New York: Available Press/Ballantine Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: CHRISTMAS MUSIC: NEW, OLD AND RARE
description: LEAD: TRADITIONALLY, Christmas has been a time of musical abundance, and this season will be no exception, with motets, anthems, oratorios, cantatas, hymns and carols at every turn.

title: GEARING UP FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: I enjoy turning first to the last page of The New York Times Magazine to see what you have decided to feature in Works in Progress. The photographs are invariably interesting, and sometimes evocative (''Gearing Up for the Holidays,'' Nov. 15).

title: Streetscapes: The Elks Club; An Endangered Species on 43d
description: IT seems like a typical, seedy West Side hotel, no different than a score of other aging buildings in the West 40's. But if you look up you can still make out the letters ''BPOE'' on the 1911 ''Mother Lodge'' of the Elks, at 108 West 43d Street. Now the Hotel Diplomat, the building sits on one of the largest assemblages in midtown, and a recent court ruling has removed the last legal obstacle to its demolition.

title: Congress Plans Inquiry on the Military Press
description: Enactment of a bill dealing with Defense Department programs in the 1988 fiscal year has set the stage for an investigation of allegations of censorship at Stars and Stripes, the newspapers published for members of the armed forces stationed overseas.

title: Afghanistan Reports Attack
description: Guerrillas fighting the Afghan Government fired rockets and mortar shells at the northern Afghan town of Maimana, killing 10 people and wounding 34, the official Kabul radio reported today.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WESTFARMS MALL;
FOR THE HOLIDAYS, SHOPPER MADNESS
description: LEAD: BY noon, not a parking space could be found, and lines of cars snaked through the vast lot. A shopper, laden with bundles, was spotted as she returned to her automobile. Drivers, like birds of prey, maneuvered into position.

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: LEAD: JAPAN: The Beauty of Food. Photographs by Reinhart Wolf. Text by Angela Terzani. (Rizzoli, $50.) The oral personality is acquisitive. We only want everything. I know that I shall probably die one day when a pile of cookbooks topples over on me (if my liver doesn't give out first). Still, I cannot resist the annual Christmas seduction.

title: Kimberly Wood Weds Biochemist
description: At the United Church of Christ in North Hampton, N.H., Kimberly Merin Wood, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin P. Wood of North Hampton, was married yesterday to Dr. Bryan Bruce Fuller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Wayne E. Fuller of El Paso. The Rev. William McConnell officiated.

title: SHOULD THE METS KEEP MOOKIE WILSON?
description: Should India keep the Taj Mahal? Should Egypt keep the pyramids? Of course the Mets should keep Mookie Wilson! At least, until somebody perfects a time machine that would render Willie Mays young again. BOB MURRAY Mt. Kisco, N.Y.

title: 4 REFUGEES ACCEPT SANCTUARY
description: ALTHOUGH they received a personal invitation to attend, representatives of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service did not arrive and arrest any of the undocumented aliens at a recent conference on sanctuary at the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America in Ossining, known informally as Maryknoll.

title: YOUNG MOTHER OF 6 REBUILDS HER LIFE WITH AGENCY'S HELP

title: ILLUSTRATED BOOKS FOR CHRISTMAS: GIVE THE BIG PICTURE
description: DANCE AND PHOTOGRAPHY. By William A. Ewing. (Holt, $50.) William Ewing's primary interest in photographs of dance lies neither in performance preservation nor in star adulation but in something more profound: the craft, sensuality and intelligence framed within each individual image. The author presents more than 200 full-page exquisitely reproduced images by such artists as Brassai, Genthe, Steichen, Man Ray, Degas, Nadar and Walker Evans, all of them connected by the subject of dance - primitive, avant-garde, spontaneous, classical. Mr. Ewing's thoughtful essay traces the history of dance through its great innovators - Marie Taglioni, Isadora Duncan, Nijinsky, Martha Graham, Balanchine - alongside the development of the photograph from the first attempts by Daguerre in the early 19th century to the highly refined but sometimes less imaginative techniques used by photographers today. The wonderful paradox of dance photography - the recording of movement by freezing it - is outlined with vivid force. But the reproductions, some familiar, many not, speak for themselves: the wit of George Platt Lynes's portrait of the young Balanchine as a deity of carpentry; the perverse horror of Duncan peacefully poised in a car, wearing the scarf that strangled her; the intensity of Rudolf Nureyev's hips and legs, photographed by Irving Penn, tells the whole powerful story of this dancer and of the classical dance discipline. The boldness of Ruth St. Denis and Ted Shawn implanting themselves in the landscapes of Yosemite's natural wonders is awesome, amusing and American. And there are the quieter moments: Anna Pavlova's neck inextricably entwined in a swan's, and the soft sexiness of Ginger Rogers's naked back draped in chiffon, photographed by Horst. The cumulative effect of this book is one of confirmation; nothing is more beautiful - or eccentric or entertaining - than the human body when it is shaped by its dancing spirit.

And nothing bonded Mets fans, total strangers only moments before, more than yelling ''Mooooooooooo-kie!'' whenever he made a big play or came to bat.

title: HOW-TO
description: Design With Plants Morris Video. 57 minutes. $14.95. Ed Hume likes toothpicks. This knowledgeable host, who is an author and radio-TV commentator, uses toothpicks to test whether the soil in a pot is dry and needs water. He also likes to lift a pot to determine its weight; if it is too light, he says the soil is probably dry. Mr. Hume offers three points to consider when choosing interior plants for decoration: their foliage color, their leaf texture and their flower color. He tells exactly where to place particular plants in a home so they grow best. If plants need humidity, such as ferns do, place several on a tray of gravel and tuck a glass of water out of sight to be sure there is enough moisture in the air. He also reminds hobbyists of many growing techniques, such as pinching plants back - a sort of finger pruning to keep plants shapely. Or if leaves are yellowing or waning, he shows how to use a magnifying glass and turn them upside down to see if any insects are present.

He and Abstract Expressionism, for which he is a symbol, remain so vivid that he seems to be still alive, still dancing over his canvas, still trying to lead art to places it has never been. There is a sense that no one, not even post-modernists who reject everything he stands for, knows how to cut him down to size. More than 30 years after his death in 1956, at the age of 44, he remains the great presence in American art, and no one else is close.

description: To accommodate as many as 5,000 more patients in drug treatment programs run by New York State, Mayor Koch has offered 10 city-owned buildings and space in municipal hospitals and clinics.

description: The apparent failure of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to agree on halting overproduction and ending price discounts may cause a drop in the world oil market, putting pressure on the cartel to accept Iranian proposals for a price increase, oil industry analysts said yesterday.

But another Russian, Boris A. Bakhmetev, ambassador of the Soviet provisional government of 1917 after the overthrow of the Czar, once spoke to the Senate and the House separately.

The team likes to stockpile a lead, and is suspect if forced to work its way out of trouble. Tonight at Nassau Coliseum, a disjointed group of Soviet skaters played right into the Americans' favorite scheme.

description: MIHAI TETEL, a Rumanian cellist trained in Canada and now resident in New York, gave a debut recital of Haydn, Beethoven, Schumann, Debussy and Sarasate Saturday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. Mr. Tetel is capable of making good musical sense, and he avoids many of the exaggerations of vibrato and phrasing that often cling to this repertory. His tone can be a little lacking in smoothness, but he has a songful way with lyric lines, and when his pianist (Aki Ando) took over the melodic material in the Beethoven Sonata in A (Op. 69), Mr. Tetel pointed the bass lines with coherence and energy.

title: Stage: 'Dummy Hoy'
description: LARRY BAZZELL scores in ''The Signal Season of Dummy Hoy,'' but the play never makes it to first base. This is purportedly the story of how hand signals came to professional baseball in 1886. They were devised, according to the script by Allen Meyer and Michael Nowak, to meet the needs of William Ellsworth (Dummy) Hoy, a good center fielder who could not hear or speak. If virtue were enough to make a satisfying piece of theater, ''Dummy Hoy,'' which shouts its good intentions as though the audience were hard of hearing, would send everybody home cheering. But not even Mr. Bazzell, eloquently silent as Hoy, can carry this team.

title: After the Storm Over the Court
description: Anthony Kennedy, President Reagan's third choice for the Supreme Court vacancy, can expect a friendlier reception than his defeated forerunners when he meets today with the Senate Judiciary Committee. That's not because he's a closet liberal, as some senators on the right seem to suspect. Judge Kennedy may prove just as ''conservative'' as Robert Bork or Douglas Ginsburg. Yet his confirmation hearings promise none of the provocations of the Bork fight, and he triggers little of the unease stirred by the stillborn Ginsburg nomination. It's a remarkably welcome change.

title: Vandals at Mecham's Home
description: Someone pushed over two decorative brick pillers in front of Gov. Evan Mecham's home Tuesday evening, the police said. Mr. Mecham, who faces a drive to remove him from office, and his wife, Florence, were in Washington at the time. Last Dec. 21 when Mr. Mecham was Governor-elect, prowlers entered through a hole they cut in the roof and walked about while the Mechams were asleep, the police said.

title: Robinson Pays the Price for Dugout Seat
description: ''I DON'T know if you have to do this, to pay the sacrifice,''

title: Packers Sidetrack Viking Playoff Run
description: Kenneth Davis ran 7 yards for a touchdown with 1 minute 9 seconds to play today to cap a 72-yard drive that gave the Green Bay Packers a 16-10 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Two Tough Questions
description: It detracts not at all from the many useful accomplishments of the Washington summit meeting to point out that it left unresolved two difficult questions crucial to the success of arms control.

title: Columbus Circle Developer Wins Assistance From Koch
description: The developer of a controversial office-tower project near Columbus Circle insisted earlier this month, in negotiations with Mayor Koch, on receiving a $5 million reduction in the site's purchase price as well as the equivalent of a short-term loan from New York City in that amount.

title: 'New Beginning' Is Seen For Smith International
description: A renegade engineer whose company helped push Smith International Inc. into the oil service industry big leagues was drafted last week to guide the company from out of its doldrums.

title: More Cuts At Coleco
description: Coleco Industries gave layoff notice to 25 workers at its headquarters Friday and the company said there could be further staff cuts throughout the corporation by the end of the month.

title: A Boot for Smooth Going
description: SKI boots are probably the oddest footwear worn by modern man. In some ways they're the man-made equivalent to webbed feet: they're not pretty nor particularly comfortable to walk around in, but they're not supposed to be. They've been designed for function. Ski boots have outer shells made of very stiff - almost rigid - plastic that come with buckles, knobs, dials and levers to make them fit tightly. Inside the outer shell they have soft liners made of foam padding to cushion the feet.

title: States Study Laws to Fight Hiring Bias in Ulster
description: Eleven more state legislatures are considering laws that would encourage American business to fight employment discrimination against Catholics in Northern Ireland.

title: Corrections
description: An article headed ''Phnom Penh Journal'' last Thursday about life in Cambodia misstated the cost of one couple's Buddhist wedding in dollar terms. The sum, 10,000 riel, is about $80.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Hockey and Missiles
description: Trade officials say the Canadian-American free trade agreement is somewhat similar to the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear weapons that was signed last Tuesday by Mr. Reagan and Mr. Gorbachev.

title: FED SEEN HOLDING TO COURSE
description: Faced with conflicting advice and confusing economic projections, Federal Reserve officials are likely to stand pat and leave monetary policy unchanged at this week's meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, analysts said.

title: China Assails Doubters Of Japanese Atrocity
description: The People's Daily published an article today denouncing Japanese who dispute that their country's army put to death 300,000 Chinese in Nanjing 50 years ago, and added that Tokyo would never again become militaristic.

title: Music: Kahane and 2 Guests
description: IN a gesture rare among recitalists today, Jeffrey Kahane invited two colleagues, Arleen Auger, the soprano, and Gary Hoffman, a cellist, to join him during his performance at the 92d Street Y on Saturday evening. As it happened, the pianist found himself being upstaged at one moment by Ms. Auger, who contributed the evening's only inspired passage - her still and gentle version of the opening lines from Brahms's ''Unbewegte, laue Luft'' (''Mild, unagitated air'').

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Inventory-Sales Ratio... Nov. Tuesday Industrial Production... Nov. Wednesday Capacity Utilization... Nov. Housing Starts... Nov. Thursday Gross National Product.... 3d qtr.(revised) Corporate Profits... 3d qtr. Friday Consumer Price Index... Nov. Personal Income... Nov.

title: Business-Campus Ventures Grow
description: Only four years ago, corporate efforts to enlist university researchers in the drive to make American industry more competitive seemed to face major difficulties. But the problems - which mainly involved fears that these alliances would compromise basic academic freedoms - have proved relatively easy to resolve, and many research projects are not only flourishing but producing tangible results.

title: Rangers' Rookie Is His Own Man
description: For almost as far back as Steve Nemeth can remember, he has been on his own. Decisions were his, backed by the family, but shaped exclusively by his instincts, less than developed though they may have been.

title: 7 Theaters Become Landmarks; Owners Plan Appeal
description: With the designation of seven additional theaters, more than half of Broadway's playhouses are now official New York City landmarks.

title: Clifton Chenier, 'King of Zydeco,' Popularized Spirited Cajun Sound
description: Clifton Chenier, the Louisiana accordionist and singer whose fans called him ''the king of zydeco,'' died Saturday evening at Lafayette General Hospital in Lafayette, La. He was 62 years old.

title: Christie's to Auction Art in AIDS Fight
description: Since last June, at more than 75 galleries ranging from the scruffiest East Village storefronts to the toniest Upper East Side salons, artists and dealers have offered paintings to sell for the benefit of AIDS research.

title: Beth Landau Marries
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., Beth Jill Landau, a daughter of Muriel Landau of Oceanside, L.I., and the late Sidney Landau, was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel Dancis Benjamin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Benjamin of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Abner Bergman officiated. The bride graduated from Hofstra University and is a candidate for a master's degree in speech pathology and audiology there. The bridegroom, a specialist in nuclear medicine in New Hyde Park, L.I., and Great Neck, graduated magna cum laude from Lafayette College and received a medical degree from the New York University School of Medicine.

title: Nets' Williams Sidelined by Injury
description: The Nets, with an 11-game losing streak and a 2-15 record, will be without Buck Williams, the heart of the team, for the next 10 days to two weeks, according to Dr. John Sanzoni, the team doctor.

title: Howard Beach Jury Meets for Five Hours
description: The jury in the Howard Beach trial deliberated for five hours yesterday without reaching a verdict in the case of four white teen-agers charged with taking part in what has been described as a racial attack on three black men in Queens last December.

title: Redskins Beat Cowboys, 24-20
description: The Washington Redskins, who struggled all year to win the Eastern Division of the National Football Conference, fulfilled the admonition of their coach, Joe Gibbs, to peak toward the end of the season and played one of their best games of the season today, defeating the Dallas Cowboys, 24-20.

title: Intel Officer Will Join U.S. Venture Partners
description: Jack C. Carsten, one of the Intel Corporation's highest-ranking executives and the leader of the company's move into an important new market, is leaving the semiconductor company to become a venture capitalist.

title: Julie A. Lawrence Becomes a Bride
description: Julie Ann Lawrence, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Lawrence of Fairfield, Conn., and Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married yesterday to Horace McDonald Barker Jr., the son of Mrs. Lloyd Watson of Grand Terrace, Calif., and Mr. Barker of Dana Point, Calif. The Rev. Peter Floyd, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn.

title: Ortega Warns the Opposition
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that his Sandinista Government would leave office if it lost an election, but would remain the power in the land.

title: Purnick, Times Bureau Chief, Is Selected for Kihss Award
description: Joyce Purnick, City Hall bureau chief of The New York Times, has been named by the Fund for the City of New York as the recipient of its fourth annual Peter Kihss award ''for outstanding reporting on New York City government.''

title: Deaver's Jurors Take Up Vocabulary
description: Two hours after it began deliberating at noon on Friday, the Federal District Court jury that is expected to decide Michael K. Deaver's guilt or innocence early this week sent a message to Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. The 12 middle-class Washingtonians wanted a dictionary, and the judge sent it to them.

title: New Attention Focused On Infant Organ Donors
description: A novel use of an old technique is forcing new attention on one of the most wrenching issues in medicine: the use of babies born without brains as organ donors.

title: GUNMAN KILLS FIVE AND THEN HIMSELF
description: A man shot and killed his former wife, two of their children and two other adults and wounded another of his children before killing himself early today, the police said.

title: Politics; Candidates Try to Adjust to Post-Summit Politics
description: For months, the 1988 Presidential campaign has moved forward almost independent of the actions of government. Although the candidates would often mention the budget deficit or the Iran controversy, they were largely free to define themselves and their images as if decisions made by the President and Congress had nothing to do with them.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What quarterback holds the N.C.A.A. record for passing yardage in a game and whose record did he break?

title: Dance: 'Assimil,' on Communicating
description: PROBLEMS of communication were examined in ''Assimil,'' the fascinating dance-theater event presented by the Danspace Project Saturday night at St. Mark's Church. Unlike pessimists who maintain that it is ultimately impossible for human beings to communicate, Anne Bogart and Georg-Maria Pauen, who conceived and directed ''Assimil,'' may believe that human beings constantly communicate. But they do so on so many different levels simultaneously that their messages are ambiguous.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; About the 'D-word'
description: With memories still fresh of the President and the Soviet general secretary calling each other ''Ron'' and ''Mikhail,'' denizens of the capital are pondering the duration of the new thaw in U.S.-Soviet relations.

title: Rice Has 49ers In Good Hands
description: YOU can't help but notice the hands.

title: Opera: 'Traviata' at the Met
description: ANNA TOMOWA-SINTOW'S is definitely the kind of soprano voice the Metropolitan Opera needs more often: big enough to sail out into the huge house without forced tone or loss of beauty. Several passages of sustained lyrical singing in her ''Traviata'' performance Saturday evening gave pleasure, especially the lamenting lines beginning ''Cosi alla misera'' in Act II.

title: A Couch Potato's Summit
description: LEAD: As a long-time Washington person recently transplanted to the West Coast, I wondered if I could bear observing the summit meeting from outside the Beltway. How could I get the real feel without access to the rumors swirling through the Brookings Institution and the Carnegie Endowment? Would I starve without tidbits from the journalists at Germaine's and the morsels from the power brokers at the Palm?

title: The Name Game
description: Pity the poor play-by-play announcer who comes to a National Basketball Association game unprepared. Imagine the contortions of his tongue as Uwe Blab of the Dallas Mavericks blocks a shot by Larry Krystkowiak of the Milwaukee Bucks. Envision his consternation at a Boston-Seattle game when Jerry Sichting of the Celtics fouls Russ Schoene of the SuperSonics, or at a Sacramento-Utah game when Joe Arlaukas of the Kings dribbles between Mark Iavaroni and Bart Kofoed of the Jazz.

title: Christie's Changes Sale After Egypt Complains
description: A decorated gold sheet depicting King Tutankhamun, believed to have come from his tomb, has been withdrawn from a London sale at Christie's after a complaint by the Egyptian embassy, the auction house said.

title: Politics; Cities Press Their Case on Candidates
description: Nearly seven years ago, when a group of mayors met in Washington with officials of the brand-new Reagan Administration, they got a shock whose waves still have not died away in city streets and city halls.

title: What to Ask Judge Kennedy
description: What do we really know about Judge Anthony M. Kennedy, the United States Supreme Court nominee?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 30 from East Greenville, Pa., about an automobile fatality involving four teenagers on Halloween night, misstated the distance from East Greenville to the nearest McDonald's. It is much less than 20 minutes by car. A map with the article mislocated two communities. The designations for East Greenville and Reading were reversed; East Greenville is east of Reading.

title: A Glimpse of Kremlin Economics
description: The Soviet Union could pay, in part, for increased imports from the United States by selling Americans inexpensive cars, a top Soviet economist has suggested. Those cars would be intended to compete with low-cost Yugoslav and South Korean models.

title: Shawnee Journal; In Saving Schools, Official Pays Price
description: The good news about education here is that test scores are up, expenditures and discipline problems are down, and Shawnee has averted what was a blossoming financial crisis in its public schools.

title: Bernard Barnett, 71; Headed Jewish Appeal
description: Bernard H. Barnett, past national president of the charity organization United Jewish Appeal, died Thursday at University Hospital here. He was 71 years old.

title: Hess Needs to Assess Jets
description: IN his annoyance with the Jets' 37-28 loss in Miami last Monday night, Joe Walton warned of a ''very strong evaluation'' of the roster after the season.

title: East Germany Says It Freed 25,000 Prisoners in Amnesty
description: East Germany has freed more than 25,000 prisoners since July in the most comprehensive amnesty in its 38-year history, the official press service A.D.N. reported today.

title: Officer, Making an Arrest, Is Shot
description: A New York City police officer was shot in the leg yesterday while trying to apprehend a suspect in a double homicide in Brooklyn, and a passing motorist was slightly injured in the shooting, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Babies as Organ Donors Medical developments are raising ethical questions about keeping alive babies born without brains as organ donors. Page A18. Cities Back in the '88 Ring Cities' officials, after years of feeling ignored by the Government, are pressing an urban agenda on the Presidential candidates. Page B10. Israelis Battle Unrest As the Israeli Cabinet heard a report on disturbances in the occupied territories, at least 11 people were wounded in further unrest. Page A3. For Haiti, Old Fears Anew Haitians fear a new dictatorship is rising as they are drawn back into the dark world of violence and suspicion the Duvaliers created. Page A3. Irish Capital at 1,000 Joyce's ''dear dirty Dublin'' is preparing a yearlong celebration as it enters its second millenium. Page A4.

title: Merc May Extend Daily Limits
description: Despite vocal opposition from some institutional investors, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange is likely to set permanent daily price limits on its popular Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts in coming weeks, officials said.

title: Elizabeth Haas Weds Steven G. Edersheim
description: Elizabeth Ann Haas, a partner in McKinsey & Company, management consultants, , was married yesterday in New York to Steven Gallen Edersheim, a corporate vice president of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Rabbis Marshall T. Meyer and Irving Block officiated at the Brotherhood Synagogue.

title: MUSIC: CATHERINE COMET AND AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: JOHN ADAMS is very much the American composer of the moment. Across the river in Brooklyn, his opera ''Nixon in China'' plays to large and approving audiences; his ''Harmonielehre'' is being taken up by many orchestras, and on a smaller scale, there is his ''Tromba Lontana'' - a five-minute fanfare written for the Houston Symphony in 1986. ''Tromba Lontana'' came to Carnegie Hall and New York for the first time on Sunday afternoon. It was part of a program by the American Symphony conducted by Catherine Comet.

title: General Picked For Key Position In Arms Control
description: After months of searching for a new director for the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, President Reagan has decided to nominate an Army major general who helped negotiate the new treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles.

title: GATX Chief's Retirement Set
description: The GATX Corporation said Friday that its president and chief operating officer, J. Warren Samborn, would take early retirement, effective March 1. Mr. Samborn, 56 years old, joined GATX in 1969 in its capital leasing subsidiary, where he held several mangement positions before being named president of the division. He became president and chief operating officer of GATX in 1984. The company said that

title: National Tests Make U.S. Children Nonreaders
description: To the Editor:

title: Nation Found Lacking on Infant AIDS Threat
description: The nation's health care and foster care systems are overburdened and ill-equipped to deal with an expected increase in pediatric AIDS cases by the year 1991, according to a Congressional report to be released Monday.

title: Amfac Is Planning to Sell Its Non-Hawaii Businesses
description: Amfac Inc., a diversified services company with major real estate holdings in Hawaii, said yesterday that, as part of a restructuring, it planned to sell all of its businesses in the continental United States and concentrate on its Hawaiian operations.

title: Saints' Streak at 7 As Hebert Stars
description: Bobby Hebert threw two touchdown passes to Eric Martin and one to Lonzell Hill today to lead the New Orleans Saints to a 24-10 victory over the Houston Oilers. The victory extended the league's longest current winning streak to seven games.

title: TV Review; Spalding Gray On HBO
description: SPALDING GRAY is an occasional actor who makes a decent living telling stories. He has been marketing his autobiographical monologues for about 10 years in theaters and, more recently, in a film called ''Swimming to Cambodia,'' a recounting of his small role in the film ''The Killing Fields.'' Now, courtesy of the pay service Home Box Office, Mr. Gray can be seen on cable television. The next showing of ''On Location: Terrors of Pleasure'' on HBO is tonight at 9:30.

title: Politics; New York's Democrats Prepare to Choose Sides
description: Released from neutrality by Governor Cuomo last week, many Democratic public and party officials in New York are preparing to take sides in the Presidential contest, with the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts and Senator Paul Simon of Illinois picking up most of the support.

title: Market Place; 'January Effect' On Stock Prices
description: WHAT is popularly known on Wall Street as the ''January effect'' has nothing to do with wintry weather. It is a seasonal phenomenon in which stocks that have been hard hit by selling for tax purposes in December often stage a partial recovery the following month.

title: In Haiti, Fears of a New Dictatorship
description: The gray-haired man sat on a stool in an airless alcove off one of the main avenues of the Haitian capital, waiting for a tailor using a treadle sewing machine to finish a piece of work.

title: Caroline Jones Agency Gets Bahamas Business
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles didn't get all of the business of the Bahamas Ministry of Tourism. When D.M.B.&B. landed the $13 million account last week, there was still some left over for Caroline Jones Advertising.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Although people asked for democracy, I didn't know that democracy was going to be this chaotic and bring about so much worry. We cannot vote for the ruling party if we want democracy, but we cannot vote for the opposition because we fear chaos.'' - Chun Hae Sun, a Seoul restaurateur, about Korea's election. [ A14:3. ]

title: Insurer Sees Lloyd's Link
description: The St. Paul Companies of Minnesota, which has made a bid for the British insurance broker Minet Holdings P.L.C., is aiming to become the first insurance company to win a place at the Lloyd's of London insurance market. Lloyd's had previously argued that there would be a conflict of interest if insurance companies owned its insurance-broker members, whose task is to shop around among insurers for the best policy for their clients. But last month, Lloyd's proposed dropping the rule that bars insurance companies from owning more than 26 percent of a broker.

title: G.M. to Alter Its Pay Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to require its 114,000 salaried employees in the United States to pay for part of their health-care benefits. The company also plans to offer a bonus system for white-collar workers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 5,000 Are Removed From a Texas Town As Tank Cars Derail
description: Three railroad tank cars burst sporadically into flame today after a derailment Saturday that forced the evacuation of some 5,000 people because of a threat of toxic fumes.

title: Man in the News; First German In NATO Job: Manfred Worner
description: It may be only a coincidence that the man chosen Friday in Brussels as Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization wrote his doctoral dissertation on ''The Stationing of Foreign Forces in Friendly Countries.''

title: Dance: Ailey Troupe in 'Divining' and 'Memoria'
description: THE accent was on strong and resonant performing when the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater presented a program of four dances on Saturday night at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Washington Talk: The Federal Pay Scale; . . . Anomalies in the Upper Ranks
description: What is a President worth? Should the Vice President earn the same salary as the Chief Justice of the United States and the Speaker of the House of Representatives? Is a scientist on leave from an academic post more valuable than a Cabinet officer?

title: Korean Middle Class Agonizes Over Vote
description: Last June, Lee Yul Hee took part in her first demonstration, a peaceful protest against the tear gas that choked the streets of Seoul. Today, Mrs. Lee and her friends sat in church and talked of their hopes for democracy - and their fears that the freedoms they helped to win may yet elude them.

title: Scandinavia Fund Shifts
description: Bjorn Carlson, president of Scandinavia Fund Inc., and five members of its board resigned last week, the investment company has announced. No reason was given. Those resigning were Kari Kairamo, Jan Erik Langangen, Curt Nicolin, Arthur Ernst Frederick Schmiegelow and the chairman, Curt G. Olsson. At a recent board meeting, Alexander M. Vik, previously head of an investor group that held 48 percent of the fund's shares, was elected chairman. Gustav M. Vik and Jan Frydman were elected secretary and treasurer, respectively. The new chairman said that a news release from those resigning that referred to the possible liquidation of the company was false.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Gary Pranzo has been appointed executive vice president at Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 14, 1987: MONDAY McDonald & Co Inv RTE Corp TUESDAY Ames Dept Stores First Boston Inc Brunswick Corp House of Fabrics CPC Intl Hydraulic Co Essex Chemical MONY Real Estate Invstrs Firestone Tire & Rubber Super Valu Stores WEDNESDAY Amer Tel & Tel National Convenience Strs DCNY Corp National Intergroup Engelhard Corp Stanley Works Fairchild Indus United Jersey Banks Hunt Mfg Valspar Corp Keystone Intl Vestaur Securities THURSDAY Ampco-Pittsburgh Primark Corp Arkansas Best Corp Russ Togs Bell Atlantic Southern Cal Edison Central Maine Power Stevens (JP) & Co Commonwealth Engy Sys Tribune Co Flight Safety Intl FRIDAY Central Hudson G & E Perry Drug Stores General Cinema Raymond James Fin'l Iowa Resources Rexham Corp Knight-Ridder Inc Southeast Banking Pacific Telesis Group Southwestern Bell SUNDAY Montana Power

title: Iran Minister to Take OPEC Plan to Teheran
description: The oil minister of Iran, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, said tonight that he was leaving a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to consult with his Government about a potential agreement that would allow its enemy, Iraq, the freedom to produce as much oil as it wishes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Dec. 3 about Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Carl H. Pforzheimer & Com-pany described their business ar-rangement incorrectly. The firms have formed a joint venture.

title: Veterans Stampede Congress
description: Elevating the Veterans Administration to cabinet status is an idea that doesn't improve with age. So the case made for it last Wednesday in the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee was no more persuasive than that made last month in the House. But the legislators don't need any persuasion, it seems. They are stampeding to enact the bill, and unless someone heads it off, the Senate will shortly be overrun as effectively as the House was.

title: PANAMA'S LEADER WOOS FOES OF U.S.
description: With his support among American officials eroded, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military strongman, has begun more openly courting the Soviet Union, the Salvadoran guerrillas and others hostile to the United States, according to Administration officials and a Nicaraguan defector.

title: Washington Talk: National Institutes of Health; Scientists Do Not Live by Patriotism Alone . . .
description: When Dr. Robert C. Gallo, the Government's top expert on the AIDS virus, began hinting in recent months that he might resign to help found a private research institute, a collective shudder passed through the top officials of the National Institutes of Health, where Dr. Gallo has his laboratory.

title: Bias Cases Fuel Anger Of Blacks
description: Tawana Brawley, a popular 15-year-old high school student, was found Nov. 28 curled in a fetal position inside a plastic bag behind an apartment house in Wappingers Falls, six miles south of here.

title: DIFFERENT WAY TO PROTECT YOUR BOAT FROM WINTER
description: THERE is an annual ritual among sailboat owners who face winter's onslaught of cold and snow. They haul the boat out of the water, throw a canvas cloth across its deck, and store it somewhere until the next boating season. But it doesn't have to be that way.

title: Southeast Asia Talks Face Major Shift
description: The leaders of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, arriving here today for their first summit meeting in more than a decade, face a region and a world that has changed profoundly for them since their organization was founded 20 years ago.

title: Harold Washington Deserved Better
description: To the Editor:

title: John Guarino Wed To Miss Hawkins
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Bronxville, N.Y., Cynthia Cleveland Hawkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic H. Hawkins of Bronxville, was married yesterday to John Mitchell Guarino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Guarino of Fairless Hills, Pa. The Rev. Christopher L. Webber performed the ceremony.

title: Buildup Would Imperil Region, U.S. Aide Says
description: Lieut. Gen. Colin L. Powell, President Reagan's national security adviser, said today that the United States would view the introduction of advanced Soviet weapons into Nicaragua as ''a very serious matter.''

title: Judith Ann Kramer Weds Stephen A. Kovach on L.I.
description: Judith Ann Kramer, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Albert S. Kramer of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, L.I. to Stephen A. Kovach, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen M. Kovach of Fairview Park, Ohio. Rabbi Neil Kurshan officiated. The bride is a product manager for the Progressive Corporation, an insurance holding company in Mayfield Village, Ohio. She graduated from Brandeis University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago, as did the bridegroom. Her father is an internist.

title: Settlement Could Double Value of Pennzoil
description: The Pennzoil Company will more than double in value if Texaco Inc. pays it $3 billion in cash to settle their legal dispute, according to analysts.

title: Cardinal Won't Allow Instruction on Condoms in Programs on AIDS
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he would not allow instruction about condoms in AIDS education programs in the schools, hospitals and youth programs of the Archdiocese of New York despite the qualified approval of such an approach by his fellow bishops.

title: Study Indicates Strong Enforcing Of Seat Belt Laws Cuts Fatalities
description: Laws requiring the use of seat belts have saved an estimated 1,300 lives in recent years, a new study shows, and the researchers say there is a direct relationship between strong enforcing of the laws and reducing highway fatalities and serious injuries.

title: Eastern Utilities-Neco
description: Eastern Utilities Associates said Friday that it had agreed to buy 52 percent of Neco Enterprises Inc. and will seek to buy the remainder of the company, which is the parent of the Newport Electric Company. Eastern said it would buy the stake for $21 a share from David F. Larouche, Neco's largest investor who recently failed to win shareholder approval for a plan to liquidate the company. Neco has about 973,000 shares outstanding. The purchase must be approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: RESULTS
description: Skiing Italian Wins Giant Slalom: Alberto Tomba of Italy won the men's giant slalom yesterday at La Villa, Italy, for his third World Cup victory in three races. Tomba, who will be 21 years old Saturday, edged Rudolf Nierlich of Austria, and Joel Gaspoz and Hans Pieren, both of Switzerland. Fastest in the first heat, Tomba had the second best time in the second run for a winning aggregate of 2 minutes 32.34 seconds. (AP) Austrian Gets First Triumph: Ida Ladstaetter recorded her first World Cup triumph yesterday, capping a brilliant showing by the Austrian team in the slalom at Leukerbad, Switzerland, after a string of four Swiss cup victories. Ladstaetter, 22, a veteran of six World Cup seasons, beat Camilla Nilssonby of Sweden by 4-hundredths of a second to post a two-heat total time of 1 minute 34.63 seconds.(AP) Czechoslovak Triumphs: Pavel Ploc of Czechoslovakia made two 92-meter jumps to win the Subaru World Cup ski jumping championship 70-meter event at Lake Placid, N.Y., yesterday. Ploc scored 246.2 points to beat his countryman, Jiri Parma, who scored 236.4.(AP) Tennis Upset in Doubles: Miloslav Mecir and Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia upset the Wimbledon doubles champions, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso of the United States, 6-4, 7-5, 6-7, 6-3, to win the $200,000 Masters Doubles tennis title yesterday at Albert Hall in London.(AP) Golf Hulbert and Tway Winners: Mike Hulbert and Bob Tway won the $600,00 Chrysler PGA team championship at West Palm Beach, Fla., by a stroke yesterday. Starting the day five strokes ahead, they had trouble putting and almost got caught by Fred Couples and Mike Donald. Hulbert and Tway collected the $100,000 first prize with their 72-hole 250, 38 under par.(AP) Marathon Racing Hussein Wins in Hawaii: Ibrahim Hussein of Kenya, who won the New York City Marathon on Nov. 1, captured the Honolulu Marathon yesterday. Hussein was timed in 2 hours 18 minutes 26 seconds. Carla Beurskens of the Netherlands captured the women's division in 2:35:11.(AP) Squash Racquets Advancing to Final: Hugh Labossier of Seattle and Bill Doyle of Greenwich, Conn., toppled top-seeded Ned Edwards of New York City and David Johnson of Southport, Conn., in straight sets yesterday, 15-12, 15-5, 17-15, in the semifinals of the $15,000 Xerox North American Open doubles championship at the Greenwich Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. In the other semifinal yesterday, Todd Binns of Toronto and Tom Page of New York City overpowered Alan Grant and Jamie Bentley, both of Toronto. Horse Racing Vinnie the Viper Triumphs: Julie Krone, riding her fourth winner in five mounts yesterday, guided Vinnie the Viper to a nose victory in the Gravesend Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. King's Swan was second and Best by Test finished third. Vinnie the Viper, a 4-year-old colt, carried 116 pounds over six furlongs in 1:09 3/5 and returned $7.60 for $2 to win.

title: A Collector's Noblesse Oblige
description: Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo of Varese, Italy, is a man with a cultural mission. And that is to place his vast, in-depth collection of recent American art in the right hands, even at bargain prices.

title: Sports World Specials; Survival Tactics
description: Maurice Lucas is one of the few survivors of an era when teams often traveled by bus and players were surprised when their paychecks cleared the bank. Such was life in the American Basketball Association, a league whose existence seems as ancient to today's youngest players as the Hippie movement of the 1960's.

title: Fairness Issue in Korean Election Stirs Fears and Threats of Disorder
description: The question whether South Korea's presidential vote this week will be seen as fair or rigged emerged clearly today as the issue with the greatest potential to touch off post-election disorder.

title: Mullin Getting Treatment

The Oakland company wants to test the bacteria, which it calls Frostban, on an acre of strawberry plants near here to determine whether Frostban can prevent frost damage to fruit and nut crops.

title: Sports People; Hextall Objects
description: Ron Hextall, the feisty goalie of the Philadelphia Flyers who has left his mark on more than a couple of National Hockey League players, believes he is getting more attention than he deserves from the league's referees. Hextall was assessed two penalties 21 seconds apart during the Flyers' 4-3 victory over the Winnipeg Jets on Sunday. He was first detected tripping the Jets' Andrew McBain, and then Referee Dan Marouelli called a penalty on Hextall for delaying the game after his attempted clearing pass went over the glass. While he agreed with the latter penalty, Hextall claimed self-defense in flattening McBain. ''McBain gave me a whack and he whacked me all night so I gave him one back,'' said Hextall, who is as mild-mannered off the ice as he is tenacious while playing. Hextall's reputation as an aggressive competitor started last year in his rookie season when he logged 104 minutes in penalties, a N.H.L. record for goalies. He also sat out the first eight games of this season after being suspended for a vicious two-handed slash on the Edmonton Oilers' Kent Nilsson in the Stanley Cup final.

He spent years tracking the man who ordered her death, to kill him. But when he confronted the murderer he did not take out his gun. description: MARIA IRENE FORNES'S aberrant version of ''Uncle Vanya'' (at the CSC Repertory) plummets to the depth of un-Chekhovian absurdity late at night in the professor's dining room. The characters, dressed in nightshirts, lounge around the stage in the dimmest of candlelight. Michael O'Keefe, who has played Dr. Astroff to a standstill, suddenly picks up Uncle Vanya (Austin Pendleton) and cradles him in his arms as if he is a baby in bunting. As might be said in parallel circumstances about King Lear and Cordelia, it is fortunate for Mr. O'Keefe that Mr. Pendleton is a light Vanya.

title: Opera: First 'Turandot' Of Metropolitan Season
description: THE title role in ''Turandot'' requires at minimum a soprano voice able to give out the imperious cries of the cruel Chinese Princess with trumpet-like power. If the two-dimensional character of Turandot can somehow, in addition, be projected with more than a bulldozer's nuances, all the better. But penetrating power is the first requisite, the one upon which renowned Turandots of the past have built. Ghena Dimitrova, who made her Metropolitan Opera debut last evening in this vocally punishing part, had something convincingly like a trumpet at her disposal in her highest register, which frequently aroused the audience to excited applause. The voice, mostly built of head tones and glottal stops, could weaken lower down, lose quality and stray out of focus.

description: Dick Williams of the Seattle Mariners said yesterday that he'll probably retire after next season, his 21st as a major league manager. ''I have one more year to go on my contract,'' the 58-year-old Williams said at a news conference called by the Mariners. ''I'm planning on it to be the last year.'' Williams, who took over the Mariners on May 9, 1986, after Chuck Cottier was dismissed, announced near the end of last season that he planned to retire at the end of the 1988 season. Last week at baseball's winter meetings in Dallas, however, Williams said he would leave the door open about managing beyond the 1988 season.

title: Results Plus
description: College Basketball Wyoming 100, Georgia State, 89; Fen-nis Dembo scored 29 points, 23 in the second half, as unbeaten Wyoming won for the fifth time last night. Wyoming, struggling at home early, closed out the first half with an 8-2 run to take a 43-38 lead. The Cowboys then took control, opening their biggest lead when Willie Jones hit two free throws for a 74-53 margin. Georgia State was led by Harlen Graham, who scored 24 points.(AP) Southern Methodist 87, South Florida 66: Eric Longino led a high-scoring backcourt with 21 points as S.M.U. won in Tampa, Fla. Kato Armstrong and Todd Alexander added 16 and 13 points for the Mustangs (6-1). Darrell Coleman scored 21 points and had a career-high 18 rebounds for South Florida (0-5). Hakim Shahid scored 20 points.(AP) Manhattan 80, Lehman 50: Peter Runge scored 17 points, all in the first half, and grabbed 14 rebounds for Manhattan. Billy Wheeler led the Jaspers (5-3) with 18 points. Runge scored 9 points as Manhattan jumped out to a 16-5 advantage in the first 9 minutes 16 seconds. The Jaspers built a 41-23 halftime margin against the Division III Lancers (5-4). Lehman committed 15 turnovers in the first half. Kevin Lyons topped Lehman with 11 points.(AP) C. W. Post 102, East Stroudsburg 64: Jimmy Feagins scored 27 points and Darrick Heath added 19 points leading the Pioneers (3-4) in Brookville, L. I. Feagins, a junior guard, connected on 11 of 14 shots from the floor, including three of five 3-point attempts. Heath hit on seven of nine shots from the floor as Post shot 54.9 percent. Darrell Gray led the losing Warriors (4-5) with 10 points. Brooklyn College 82, Maryland-Eastern Shore 81: Stious Kirkpatrick scored 32 points, including two free throws with 10 seconds left, and David Grady had 21 points as Brooklyn College (5-3) won in Princess Anne, Md. Kirkpatrick's layup with 3:05 left gave Brooklyn a 75-65 lead, but Eastern Shore battled back to close the gap to 80-78 with 18 seconds to play. Kirkpatrick then hit both ends of a one-and-one to build the lead back to 82-78 before Eastern Shore's Terrance Barge made a 3-pointer with three seconds to close the scoring. Eastern Shore is 2-4. (AP) City College 74, York 45: The Beavers took the lead and never let up. The two leading scorers for City were Steve Mack and Mark Wilson, with 17 points each. Ed Adolphus led all York players with 15 points. N.B.A. Jazz 116, SuperSonics 95: Utah's Thurl Bailey scored 29 points, and the Jazz, behind a 21-5 run in the first period, defeated Seattle last night in Salt Lake City. John Stockton added a career-high 26 points, including 11 of Utah's first 14 points, and Karl Malone had 22. Stockton hit 9 of 10 field goals and 8 of 8 free throws. He also made five steals. Dale Ellis led the Sonics with 29 points. The Jazz used the first-quarter surge to take a 28-13 lead. Utah extended its margin to 56-36 at the half.(AP) Horse Racing Seriously Wins at Aqueduct: Seriously took the lead after entering the stretch and went on to carry Randy Romero to a one-length victory yesterday in the $40,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. Split Sentence, the outsider in the field of six, was second. For Seriously, a 4-year-old daughter of Believe It-Girlfriend, the victory was the fifth in 16 career starts. She covered a mile and a sixteenth carring 117 pounds on the fast track in 1:46:2 to earn $24,000 for Mill House. Seriously returned 3.60 for $2 to win as the favorite. For the second straight day, no bettor selected all winners in the Pick Six. A $117,471.94 carryover to tomorrow resulted. Squash Racquets Binns and Page Win: Todd Binns of Toronto and Tom Page of New York City captured the $3,000 first prize in the Xerox North American Open Doubles Championship last night with a 15-14, 15-12, 15-9 victory over Hugh Labossier of Seattle and Bill Doyle of Greenwich, Conn. The $15,000 tournament was played at the Greenwich County Club. The match was marked by numerous cross-court rallies between the left-handed Binns on the left court and Doyle on the right. Binns and Page, the defending champions played virtually error-free squash. The defeat put an end to a string of upsets by Labossier and Doyle, including a straight set 15-12, 15-5, 17-15 victory in the semifinals over the top-seeded players, Ned Edwards of New York City and David Johnson of Southport, Conn. Binns and Page advanced to the finals with a 15-12, 15-10, 15-7 victory over Alan Grant and Jamie Bentley, both of Toronto.
