description: Kicking off one's shoes is the first thing almost everyone does after shutting the front door. Comfort is the prime consideration, and no complaints, please, from any nearests and dearests about what replaces the shoes.

title: Arab Is Killed in Gaza and Another Dies of Wounds
description: Two more Palestinians died today as a result of clashes with security forces in the occupied territories.

title: DATAVISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said its latest quarter and year results reflect certain non- recurring expenses associated with the company's recent restructuring and normal year-end adjustments. The company also said the latest year loss includes an unspecified reserve for bad debt in the third quarter.

title: Righetti's Situation Becomes Confusing
description: Confusion erupted yesterday over the Japanese offer to Dave Righetti that his agent says is worth $10 million for two years. The United States representative of the Tokyo Giants, the team that reportedly made the offer, denied that the Giants have made an offer. But Bill Goodstein, the pitcher's agent, who has refused to identify the team, said that Righetti is ''seriously considering going to Japan'' and will make a decision in the next few days.

title: MEXICO CUTS PESO BY 22% IN EFFORT TO HELP ECONOMY
description: Seeking to relieve pressure on its beleaguered peso, Mexico's central bank today devalued the official exchange rate by 22 percent against the dollar.

title: INSIDE
description: Deadlock on Abortion Law

title: Coalition in Belgium Barely Wins
description: With counting complete in the Belgian general election held Sunday, the center-right coalition of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens held onto 110 seats in the 212-seat Chamber of Deputies but faced a challenge from a resurgent Socialist bloc.

title: South Korea's Chance to Grow Up
description: Put aside for the moment the fiery oratory of the rivals in tomorrow's free election in South Korea, the first in 16 years. Ignore, too, competing threats: military intervention if left-of-center Kim Dae Jung wins, versus riots by radical students if the ruling party nominee, Roh Tae Woo, is declared the victor. Instead, ponder the abiding enigma of South Korea - a dazzling economic success with an authoritarian political history that embarrasses the managers and workers who have wrought the Korean miracle.

title: Martha Graham's Art Is Worth Preserving
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch Warns of Impact of Columbus Circle Defeat
description: Mayor Koch, stepping up his lobbying on behalf of a modified development proposal for Columbus Circle, said yesterday that if the Board of Estimate did not approve the plan, ''then we will without question have huge reductions in our work force.''

title: One Good Piece of the Trade Bill
description: Another year of battling over the Federal budget has pushed the foreign trade bill off until 1988. Over all, that's fine; the protectionist legislation that might have passed is temporarily shelved. But the delay also has a negative side effect, freezing the United States out of a global deal to harmonize trade regulation. There's still time to break out this valuable piece from the whole bill, but Chairman Lloyd Bentsen of the Senate Finance Committee stands in the way.

title: EAGLE ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company was founded in November 1986; year-ago comparisons are not applicable.

title: Preventing Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwait Lifts B.P. Stake
description: The Kuwaiti Government said today that it had raised its stake in the British Petroleum Company above 13 percent. The Kuwait Investment Office, which invests the Persian Gulf state's petrodollars worldwide, began buying B.P. stock last month. B.P. said the Kuwaiti agency now holds 13.07 percent.

title: How Some Bacteria Outwit Body's Defenses
description: UNDER a microscope, the three bacteria look exactly alike. Yet one causes food poisoning, another causes typhoid fever, and the third causes a blood infection.

title: Military Child-Care Center In San Francisco Is Reopened
description: An Army day-care center here, which has been the focus of allegations of sexual abuse of children, reopened today after being closed Nov. 25 for health and safety problems.

title: A Photographer's 50 Years in Fashion: No Still Life
description: It was, one guest said, a ''social top-gun shoot-out,'' when the National Academy of Design held a fund-raising dinner in New York late last month. Presiding over tables were Brooke Astor, Lee Radziwill, Gayfryd Steinberg, Ronald O. Perelman and Anne Bass.

title: Reubin Askew to Seek Seat In Senate, Former Aide Says
description: Former Gov. Reubin Askew, a Democratic Presidential candidate in 1984, will run for the Senate seat being vacated next year by Senator Lawton Chiles, a spokesman said today.

title: Minority Shift In Work Force Is Reported
description: Black, Hispanic and Asian workers are on the verge of becoming a majority in the resident labor force in New York City for the first time, but they are still largely concentrated in lower level jobs, the United States Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Bell Accepts Bass Group Bid
description: The Bell & Howell Company said today that it had agreed to accept a $674.6 million takeover offer from a group that includes some company executives and the Texas financier Robert M. Bass.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: ARCO Withdraws
description: ARCO, citing unfavorable market conditions, said it had withdrawn from a proposed pipeline project to transport natural gas from Alaska's North Slope. The Los Angeles-based energy company said its decision would result in a $50 million charge against its fourth-quarter earnings. The project began in 1977 and would bring natural gas to the continental United States through 4,800 miles of pipeline, including a 745-mile section to be built in Alaska.

title: TV Host Accused of Assault
description: An assault charge has been filed against Sean Morton Downey Jr., a television talk-show host, by a guest who said Mr. Downey struck him during a taping of the program Wednesday night.

title: GISH BIOMEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $80,000 and $14,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: OPEC Maintains Price and Quotas
description: After six days of shaky and difficult negotiations, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today extended its current $18-a-barrel price and its production quotas through the first six months of next year.

title: Ex-F.B.I. Agent Is Nominated As M.T.A. Inspector General
description: A former F. B. I. agent who began his career as a New York City police officer was nominated today by Governor Cuomo to be the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Advertising; Norstar Consolidates At Duke & Brennan
description: Two of Norstar Bancorp's agencies have merged and have been rewarded with all the company's consolidated New York State advertising business. Billings could be in the area of $5 million to $8 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ANGOLA GUERRILLA DESCRIBES U.S. AID
description: A captured Angolan rebel has said that 10 armed and uniformed Americans worked in a rebel-controlled section of Angola earlier this year coordinating United States arms deliveries from Zaire.

title: Space Probe Turns 20
description: ONE of NASA's longest-lived space probes celebrated its 20th year of operation Sunday. The craft, Pioneer 8, has traveled about 11 billion miles and has helped push back the frontiers of astrophysics by providing scientists with a stream of data on solar flares and how they interact with the Earth and its magnetic fields.

title: Brazil to Pay Interest Again
description: Brazil, whose $113 billion debt is the largest in the developing world, will resume interest payments on its suspended foreign debt this month, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today. Francisco Baker said by telephone from Brasilia that an agreement would be signed Tuesday in New York.

title: Shultz Backs Oslo on Exports
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz praised Norway today for imposing new export controls after disclosures that its state-owned arms company illegally sold equipment to the Soviet Union that helped make its submarines quieter. At the same time, he criticized Congress for trying to punish the Norwegians.

title: Electrons From Space
description: Scientists have shown that powerful low-frequency radio beams used throughout the world to help airplanes navigate can bring showers of electrons from outer space down into Earth's atmosphere.

title: CIRCUIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S., in Afghan Talks, Decides to Hold Firm on Timing of a Pullout
description: Administration officials, assessing the results of talks on Afghanistan during the summit meeting, have concluded that a tough stand by the United States can probably force further compromises from the Soviet Union on the timing and manner of its proposed troop withdrawal.

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ogrodnick Goal Beats Red Wings
description: John Ogrodnick played his 600th National Hockey League game last night, no small moment in personal history. To the Rangers' delight, there was more to talk about afterward than his 600th game.

title: Family Court: Stage for Suffering and Crises
description: From her bench in Manhattan Family Court, Judge Judith B. Sheindlin looks down on a pageant of suffering that crowds her days and troubles her nights.

description: To the Editor:

SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,605,000 from a segment of the company's defined benefit pension plan. c-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $554,000 and $1,688,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. d-Includes extraordinary tax credits of $317,000 and $557,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the quarter also included a $608,000 gain recognized by the company resulting from renegotiation of certain financing lease agreements. In the third quarter of 1987, the company sold its wholly owned subsidiary Sun Electric France, S.A. Included in other expense on the consolidated statement of operations for the year ended Oct. 31, 1987 is an $839 charge resulting from the recognition of the deferred currency translation loss. The fourth-quarter earnings for both periods are revised.

title: Oil Contracts Fall Sharply In Reaction to OPEC Pact
description: Futures prices of petroleum products fell sharply yesterday, as traders remained concerned about OPEC's production and pricing levels.

title: Icahn Studies USX Stake
description: The USX Corporation said yesterday that Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, had received permission from the Federal Trade Commission to increase his stake in the giant energy and steel company to 25 percent or more of the company's common stock. Mr. Icahn currently holds an 11.4 percent stake in the company.

title: Inventories Rise by 0.8% As Sales Drop Slightly
description: Business inventories climbed a sharp eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest advance in five months, while total business sales dropped slightly during the month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: The Questions Begin: 'Who Is Anthony Kennedy?'
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee began hearings yesterday on the nomination of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court. Following are excerpts: SENATOR JOSEPH R. BIDEN Jr., Democrat of Delaware, committee chairman: . . . Our role of advice and consent demands from every Senator a thorough and careful review, even with nominees of sterling character and qualifications, as you obviously have, Judge Kennedy.

title: Duro-Test Board Supports TCA Bid
description: The Duro-Test Corporation will recommend that its shareholders accept a $71 million takeover offer from the TCA Acquisition Corporation, ending a battle for the North Bergen, N.J., manufacturer of light bulbs that began four months ago. TCA is led by William P. Lyons, a professor of business at Yale University.

title: MAX & ERMA'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: b-After tax credits of $19,000 for the quarter and $34,000 for the year; the year also includes a net gain of $181,000 on the sale of assets. c-After a tax credit of $18,000. d-Net loss

title: FISHER BUSINESS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Italy's Chief Hardens Gulf Stand
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria, who is due to visit Washington this week, will tell President Reagan that Italy believes the time is approaching for the United Nations to adopt an arms embargo to end the Iran-Iraq war, a senior aide to the Prime Minister said today.

title: TRANSNATIONAL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Gorbachev Irritated by U.S. Assertions on 'Star Wars'
description: Clearly irritated by Administration assertions that his talks with President Reagan last week left Washington free to develop and deploy space-based weapons, Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the issue was far from settled.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Funderburk Is Back
description: Back from the forgotten-but-not-gone category comes David B. Funderburk, who served the Reagan Administration as Ambassador to Rumania from 1981 to 1985, then left in a huff complaining of ''shocking collaboration'' between his superiors at the State Department and the Bucharest regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu. In 1986 Mr. Funderburk, a former college professor, ran unsuccessfully as a conservative Republican for the Senate from North Carolina, losing in a primary race against Representative James T. Broyhill. The seat was eventually won by Terry Sanford, a Democrat.

title: U.S. Output Rose by 0.4% In November
description: Industrial output climbed a healthy four-tenths of 1 percent last month as American industry continued to show strong gains despite the October collapse of the stock market, the Government reported today.

title: TV Review; 'Season's Greetings,' British Holiday Satire
description: SLIPPING into cable's Arts & Entertainment network this evening at 9, ''Season's Greetings'' is not still another sweet confection for the holidays. It is a play by Alan Ayckbourn, the British playwright whose work doesn't travel easily. Though long hailed in England, he has had difficulty connecting with audiences in this country. His biggest Broadway hit, running for nearly 600 performances, was ''Absurd Person Singular,'' and that was in 1974.

title: Garson Meyer Is Dead; Advocate for Elderly
description: Garson Meyer, a chemist who was a founder of the National Council on Aging and an advocate of programs for the elderly, died Sunday at the Jewish Home in Rochester, N.Y.. He was 91 years old and lived in Rochester.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Philip Morris Enlists Pravda in Its Campaign
description: Pravda does not carry cigarette advertising. But last month it became a vehicle for America's largest tobacco company, Philip Morris U.S.A.

title: In Saigon '87, Ho, Ho, Ho, Ho Chi Minh
description: At the Dong Khanh Bakery in Cholon the other day, the pastry chefs got to work on the first of the season's traditional French Christmas logs.

title: Wickes Plans Sale Of Its Lumber Unit
description: The Wickes Companies said it planned to sell its lumber division to a group of former managers. It was the first sale announced of the three businesses that the company put on the block in October. Terms were not disclosed, but an analyst estimated the price for Wickes Lumber at around $200 million.

title: Memorex Chief Calls Telex Deal a Good Fit
description: When Giorgio Ronchi was a high school student in Milan, Italy, he spent his senior year in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, as a foreign exchange student. That began a close association with things American.

title: U.S. Weighs Turning Agency Into Private Health Institute
description: Federal budget officials have drafted a proposal to convert the world-famous laboratories of the National Institutes of Health into a private research center financed with money from the Government, industry and foundations, according to confidential budget documents.

title: SENATORS PREDICT FAST CONFIRMATION OF JUDGE KENNEDY
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy completed his testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee today to the congratulations of both Democrats and Republicans who predicted that he would easily be confirmed to the Supreme Court.

title: Wagner Society Plans 'Rheingold' Seminar
description: Richard Wagner's opera ''Das Rheingold'' is to be the subject of a four-hour afternoon seminar on Jan. 10 at the Lillie Blake Auditorium, 45 East 81st Street. The four-part session will deal with the political, mythological and symbolic aspects of the work, and will include a round-table discussion by singers who have appeared in ''Rheingold'' at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: RESULTS
description: N.H.L. Flyers 5, Penguins 2: Kerry Huffman and Mark Howe scored second-period goals as the visiting Flyers extended their unbeaten streak to nine games (7-0-2) last night. The Flyers passed the Pittsburgh Penguins in the standings and are in third place in the Patrick Division. Huffman broke a 2-2 tie at 8 minutes 48 seconds of the second period when he tapped in Pelle Eklund's pass for his second goal of the season. Howe scored on a power play at 18:19 when he backhanded Peter Zezel's rebound past Gilles Meloche, the goaltender, from close range. It was Howe's 100th goal, making him the first Philadelphia defenseman to reach that level. Murray Craven had three assists for the Flyers and scored his 10th goal of the season into the empty net with :02 left. (AP) Canucks 2, Whalers 2: Dave Babych converted a pass from Mike Millar with 8:54 to play during a power play for the tie. Babych's goal, his seventh, capped a Hartford rally from a two-goal deficit. Mike Liut, the Whaler goaltender, who made a point-blank save on Dave Saunders in overtime, stopped 22 shots. Dean Evason also scored for the Whalers, who are unbeaten in five games. (AP) Maple Leafs 5, Capitals 3: Russ Courtnall scored two first-period goals and Allan Bester stopped 24 shots to lead Toronto at home. Peter Ihnacak, Miroslav Frycer and Ed Olczyk also scored for Toronto, which won for the third time in four games.(AP) Hockey U.S.A. 9, Selects 1 Corey Millen scored two goals and added an assist to lead the United Sates Olympic team over the Soviet Select team in St. Louis. Lane MacDonald added a goal and an assist. The Americans have a 3-1 lead in the eight-game series. Game 5 will be in Bloomington, Minn., tomorrow. (AP) Cross-Country Skiing Mogren Wins Again: Torgny Mogren of Sweden won a spectacular three-way sprint in a 30-kilometer men's race yesterday at Castelrotto, Italy. It was his second consecutive World Cup victory. However, the 24-year-old Mogren was unhappy about the new cup formula that had all skiers start the race simultaneously; it was the first time a World Cup race was started this way. The new formula is aimed at making cross-country races more spectacular and more interesting. Nordic events have usually been raced against the clock, individually. Mogren finished ahead of his teammate, Gunde Svan, a former Olympic and world champion. Mogren finished in 1 hour 16 minutes 11.7 seconds and Svan in 1:16:12.2. Pierre Harvey, Canada's best hope for a medal in this event at the Olympic Games in Calgary, Alberta, in February placed third in 1:16:14.8.(AP) College Basketball Indiana 103, E. Kentucky 75: Dean Garrett, who was removed from the starting lineup after having scored only 2 points last Saturday against Washington State, matched his career high with 25 points and grabbed 18 rebounds to lead Indiana at home. Garrett made 9 of 11 from the floor and 7 of 8 free throws. Rick Calloway finished with 16 for Indiana (6-1). Randolph Taylor scored 18 for Eastern Kentucky (3-2).(AP) Old Dominion 83, Long Island 68: Steve Trax led a balanced attack with 19 points for Old Dominion at home. The Monarchs improved to 4-0, and the Blackbirds slipped to 4-3. Trax's 3-point goal with 17:06 remaining gave Old Dominion the lead for good at 46-43. Garrick Davis scored 16 points for Old Dominion, Freddie Burton paced the Blackbirds with 15 points.(AP) Trenton St. 69, Glassboro State 48: Jimmy Glover scored 23 points and had 16 rebounds to lead Trenton State. Glassboro (5-1 over all and in the New Jersey Athletic Conference), kept Trenton State scoreless for the first five minutes of the game. Franklen Burnside scored 13 points and was the only player in double figures for Glassboro State (3-3).(AP)

title: ESSAY New Man in the Arena
description: 'S o when are you going to dive back in?'' I asked Gary Hart on Nov. 2, seven weeks ago.

title: Joan Streit Is Married To Edgerton North Jr.
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Joan Springler Streit of New York and Edgerton Grant North Jr. of New York and Scarborough, N.Y., were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson.

title: Light-Truck Sales Lead 7.1% Rise at Car Makers
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks totaled 299,262 units in early December, up 7.1 percent from the corresponding period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: A Correction
description: A transmission error altered the meaning of a sentence in I. F. Stone's article, ''For a 'Yeast' Bloc,'' yesterday. It should have read, ''Many Bolsheviks were shocked when, after taking power, Lenin wiped out freedom of the press, even for faithful fellow travelers like the writer Maxim Gorky.''

title: Iranian Naval Vessels Wreck a Supertanker
description: Iranian war vessels raked the 102,088-ton Greek tanker Ariadne with grenades and machine-gun fire today, forcing most of the crew to abandon ship, and in a second attack tore it nearly in half with a missile.

title: Economic Scene; Markets Grope For Confidence
description: TWO months after the stock market's deep dive, the economy is holding up remarkably well. The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that American industry was operating at 81.7 percent of capacity in November, two-tenths of 1 percent higher than in October. Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities was up four-tenths in November, after a nine-tenths gain in October. But we're not exactly out of the woods.

title: Dispute Ends in Murder-Suicide
description: A woman pleading for the return of her 2-year-old daughter was fatally stabbed and shot in a struggle with an unidentified man who then shot and killed himself inside a Harlem stationery store yesterday afternoon, the police and witnesses said.

title: U.S. JURORS CLEAR LEADER OF A SECT
description: A Federal jury found the leader of the nation's largest Hare Krishna community not guilty of arson and fraud charges today but convicted a follower of burning an apartment building to collect $40,000 in insurance.

title: Federal Sanctions Are Needed for Clean Air; Smoke-Filled Rooms
description: To the Editor:
