description: Easy Riddle: What is longer than the opening statement at a Mikhail Gorbachev news conference?

title: INVESTORS RETREATING FROM FOREIGN MARKETS
description: The worldwide bull market made global securities dealing a hot investment concept in the 1980's. But with the October collapse of markets worldwide, professional and individual investors are pulling back from what they now fear has become a ''globalization of insecurities.''

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column last Wednesday and an article in Business Day on Monday about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top economics adviser misidentified him. He is Abel G. Aganbegyan.

title: 49ers Lose 2 Players
description: The San Francisco 49ers' euphoria over a 41-0 victory Monday night against the Chicago Bears, gave way to mild depression yesterday when it was announced Joe Montana may miss the remaining two regular-season games and the top linebacker, Keena Turner, was undergoing knee surgery. Montana has a torn hamstring that definitely will keep him out of Sunday's game against the Atlanta Falcons, and there's ''a good chance'' he'll miss the final game against the Los Angeles Rams, Coach Bill Walsh said. The 49ers may be in deeper trouble with the loss of Turner, who Walsh said ''conceivably is out for the season,'' after arthroscopic surgery for ligament damage. ''There is a chance he will need major surgery,'' Walsh added. ''If not, he could conceivably be back in four weeks.''

title: South Korean Vote Reaches to Games
description: When the citizens of South Korea vote to elect a new president today, they will also be starting a process that will determine whether the 1988 Seoul Olympics will be staged successfully or at all.

title: Federal Sanctions Are Needed for Clean Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Protesters Want Four Tried As Adults in Killing of Indian
description: About 150 members of this city's Indian community demonstrated on the steps of the Hudson County Courthouse today, demanding that four youths charged with fatally beating an Indian man be tried as adults.

title: West Virginia Delays Pay for State Workers
description: West Virginia officials said today that they hoped to have enough money by Wednesday to cover paychecks this week for 40,000 state workers.

title: Film: 'Overboard,' Comedy, With Goldie Hawn
description: ''OVERBOARD'' is an apt title for a comedy that tries to show how the hard, brittle, thoroughly horrible exterior of an heiress named Joanna Stayton (Goldie Hawn) actually conceals a sweet, spunky, hard-working little homemaker and mom. All Joanna needs is a bout of amnesia to bring the better person within her to the fore.

title: A Christmas Goose at the Ready
description: FOR the traditional Christmas goose to be on the family table, orders should be placed with butchers now. A new source is the branch of the Ottomanelli Brothers butcher shops at Macy's Herald Square. Fresh geese, ranging from 8 to 12 pounds, are $3.49 a pound. Macy's will also cook the bird for $15; call 212-967-4930 to order. The geese are the same price at the Ottomanelli Brothers shop at 1549 York Avenue (82d Street); 212-772-7900. At the Makinajian Poultry Farm, 276 Cuba Hill Road, Huntington, L.I., geese are $2.49 a pound and must be ordered no later than Saturday; 516-368-9320. Dreesen's Butchers, at 33 Newtown Lane in East Hampton, L.I., will accept orders for geese at $2.89 a pound through Sunday and will cook them for $10; 516-324-0465.

title: Drug Task Force In Westchester Rounds Up 16
description: A new suburban task force of police officers and Federal agents today arrested 16 suspected ''mid- and upper-level'' cocaine and heroin dealers based in Westchester County, Federal authorities said.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A PAL ABOUT TOWN writes (in swift on-the-go script):

title: Corrrections
description: An article yesterday about Mexico's devaluation of the peso on the official market inaccurately described the action. The move pushed the peso's value against the dollar down by 18 percent.

title: ASIANS END TALKS IN MOOD OF RELIEF
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia put into words today the relief felt at the uneventful end of a two-day meeting of six Southeast Asian leaders, a gathering held reluctantly and with unusually tight security in this volatile capital.

title: Deaver's Jury Obtains Clarification on Proof
description: The jury considering charges of perjury against Michael K. Deaver, a former White House deputy chief of staff, was interrupted for an hour today by a delay in obtaining an answer to a procedural question. It then recessed for the third time without a decision.

title: New Architect To Redesign Coliseum Plan
description: Boston Properties, the development company at the center of a plan to erect a double-towered skyscraper at Columbus Circle, will hire a new architect to redesign the project, according to officials of the developer.

title: Quincy Journal; Can Prosperity Rise From the Ashes of . . . Cigars?
description: O.K., let's get this straight.

title: Moyers Looks at Baptists In 'God and Politics' on 13
description: WHOM or what do conservative Baptists serve -God or right-wing causes, or both? ''Moyers: God and Politics'' distinguishes itself by suggesting there is a choice; Baptists often are portrayed as without option. Bill Moyers allows them to breathe. The program, the second in Mr. Moyers's three-part series, will be seen on Channel 13 at 9:30 tonight.

title: KOREAN STUDENTS READY TO PROTEST
description: This nation's students, aflame with idealism and self-righteousness, are preparing to move back to center stage.

title: No Money, No Headquarters, No Staff but 'I'm Back in the Race'
description: Following is a transcript of a statement in Concord, N.H., yesterday by former Senator Gary Hart, announcing his re-entry into race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: House Leaders to Seek Stopgap Spending Bill
description: House leaders said today that they would push for a two-day stopgap appropriation bill to keep the Government running through Friday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Giants' problems incorrectly named the team's next opponent. The Giants play the Green Bay Packers on Saturday.

title: William E. Park, 78; Simmons College Head
description: William Edgar Park, retired president of Simmons College, died Dec. 7 at Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth, Mass. He was 78 years old. Mr. Park, who lived in Cotuit, Mass., was president of the Simmons from 1955 to 1970. As president he oversaw a self-study curriculum that expanded the number of departments from 9 to 18 and changed the college into a predominantly residential campus by adding three dormitories.

title: Celebrity Bake Sale
description: Joanne Woodward will donate a cake, as will Liza Minnelli, Kathleen Turner, Woody Allen, Jerome Robbins and other celebrities who are to take part in a benefit bake sale tomorrow from 4 to 7 P.M. at the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance, 316 East 63d Street. Almost 100 cakes have been donated by individuals and restaurants for the sale, whose proceeds will benefit the Martha Graham Dance Company. Information: 832-9166.

title: EDUCATION: LESSONS
description: Somewhere in the annals of unrecorded time is the story of the first test, a no doubt Neanderthalic affair administered to a clan of nervous candidates. Since then, it is fair to say that no American is able to get from cradle to grave without some inquisitor pestering for an answer.

title: Cookbooks To Cherish
description: FEW things are more boring to read than compilations of recipes, whether they have been brought together as favorites of the compiler - always a person of note, though not always in food - or as illustrations of the thousand different ways to (1) prepare hamburger, (2) use a blender, or (3) entertain for two.

title: Judge to Rule on Bhopal Aid
description: Judge M. W. Deo said today that he would announce on Thursday whether the Union Carbide Corporation should pay interim relief to victims of the Dec. 3, 1984, gas disaster at Bhopal, the world's worst industrial accident.

title: Panel Says New York Athletic Club Discriminates Against Women
description: The New York City Human Rights Commission said yesterday that it has found that the New York Athletic Club discriminates against women in violation of a city law, and must develop a plan to end the discrimination or face a judge's order to do so.

title: U.S. Industry Operating at 3-Year High
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 81.7 percent of capacity in November, the highest level in more than three years, the Government said today.

title: Life in the 30's
description: I AM going to a business lunch, and I look good.

title: Sihanouk Plans to Talk With Cambodian Chief
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former leader of Cambodia, announced another about-face today and said he would meet with the Prime Minister of Cambodia's Vietnam-backed Government after all.

title:
At the Nation's Table;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: ''I T is like first encounters of the third kind when you're approaching,'' Patrick Kuleto, an architect, said of his newest building. He hardly exaggerated. It is a roadside diner, the Buckhead, which opened here Thanksgiving week at 3073 Piedmont Road NE in the Buckhead section. With its facade of stainless steel wreathed in neon, it cost $1.5 million.

title: Air Force Would Arm B-52 With Nonnuclear Missiles
description: The Strategic Air Command is planning to equip a fleet of B-52 bombers with small, nonnuclear cruise missiles that have been secretly developed by the United States and with highly accurate short-range missiles made in Israel, Air Force officers said today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Marc Sullivan, a catcher for the Boston Red Sox the last three years, with more skill behind the plate than at it, has been traded to Houston. One of the co-owners of the Red Sox is the former major-league catcher Haywood Sullivan, Marc's father. . . . Lonnie Smith, the veteran outfielder who returned to the team last season after failing to attract interest on the free-agent market, was released by the Kansas City Royals. In 48 games, he hit .251 with three home runs and eight runs batted in. . . . The San Francisco Giants have granted Rick Reuschel's request for a contract extension and signed the veteran pitcher through the 1989 season. Reuschel was 13-9 last season with a 3.09 earned run average. With the Giants, he was 5-3 with a 4.32 e.r.a.

title: Robert S. Taft Is Dead; New York Tax Lawyer
description: Robert S. Taft, a New York tax lawyer, died Thursday in Hollywood, Fla., after being struck by an automobile. He was 53 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Nets Hold Off Spurs to End Streak
description: With Buck Williams missing from the lineup for the first time in seven years and with Mike Gminski missing his beard for the first time in two years, the Nets ended their losing streak at 11 games tonight with a 104-98 victory over the San Antonio Spurs at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Dr. Arthur J. Antenucci Internist, 81
description: Dr. Arthur J. Antenucci, an internist, died of Hodgkin's disease Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Concert: I Cantori, Choir
description: AMONG this city's many small choirs, the 19-member ensemble called I Cantori di New York is distinctly one of the best. Its concert Monday at Merkin Concert Hall, under the direction of Bart Folse, was a display not just of well-chosen and well-blended voices (I especially liked hearing a tenor section with some juice in the tone) but of thoughtful preparation and carefully structured phrasing. One could hear right away that the rehearsals of this group cannot be the note-learning, time-marking affairs some choirs know.

title: Italian Leader, in U.S., Hints at a 'Star Wars' Deal
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria of Italy suggested today that at some future point it might be wise to put President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' program on the bargaining table in arms negotiations to reassure the Russians that the West continues to favor a strategic equilibrium.

title: Letters; Toys for Black Children
description: To The Living Section:

title: Award Helps Rebuild Emptied Food Co-op
description: The Crown Heights Cooperative Market opened 10 months ago when 25 people in the Brooklyn neighborhood who had organized a food-buying club decided they wanted to expand.

title: Mullin's Recovery: Obstacles Ahead
description: Chris Mullin is in a California hospital trying to learn how to handle a drinking problem. In the months to follow, however, he will have to return to a world full of danger.

title: Mildred S. Simon, Retailer, 88
description: Mildred S. Simon, a founder of a chain of self-service discount stores, died of lung cancer Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: HAITIAN GENERAL DISAVOWS KILLINGS
description: Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, the head of the provisional Government, has disavowed all responsibility for the massacre that disrupted Haiti's presidential elections two weeks ago and disparaged the Roman Catholic Church, Haitian political leaders and the civilians who organized the election.

title: Don't Let Banks Sell Securities
description: To the Editor:

title: Mura Dehn, Dancer, As Subject and Chronicler
description: FOR many dancegoers, Mura Dehn is known, a little vaguely, as a woman who had something to do with film and black dancers. But the Film Forum is doing something about that, with a double feature consisting of ''In a Jazz Way,'' a short film on Miss Dehn by Louise Ghertler and Pamela Katz, and a two-hour excerpt from ''The Spirit Moves: A History of Black Social Dance on Film,'' a documentary by Miss Dehn. The program opens today for a two-week run at Film Forum 1.

title: Israeli Force Raids Guerrilla Bases in South Lebanon
description: Israeli troops backed by tanks and helicopter gunships attacked guerrilla bases in southeast Lebanon today.

title: Committee And Icahn In Dispute
description: The financier Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that he would oppose any reorganization plan that gives a committee of Texaco shareholders the authority to appoint members to the company's board.

title: Topics of The Times; Gift Gimmick, Hard to Bear
description: 'Tis the season of gift-giving, a joyous thing - except when public-relations gimmicks come disguised as gifts. The 1987 booby prize in this category goes to the YMCA of Greater New York.

title: Students Aid The Neediest For Holidays
description: To celebrate the holiday season and the 100th birthday of the Browning School, the boys in the fourth grade got together and sent $317.15 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: DEMOCRATS SEE NEED TO RAISE U.S. AID ON MEXICAN BORDER
description: Six of the seven candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination debated tonight in one of the poorest areas of the country and agreed that a range of new Federal programs was needed to help the economy on both sides of the Mexican border.

title: Head of Quotron Unit Is Named by Citicorp
description: J. David Hann, a communications and computer executive, yesterday was named president and chief executive of Quotron Systems Inc., the stock quotation service acquired by Citicorp in 1986 for $680 million.

title: A User-Friendly Keyboard
description: Hunt-and-peck typists who feel inadequate because they are not proficient at touch typing may now have something to be smug about. After studying touch typists, who use all fingers instead of just one or two, a Tucson, Ariz., group has concluded that they must cock their left wrists slightly to type and could be damaging tendons and nerves. It contends that the typewriter keyboard is the culprit.

title: Maria-Theresa Duncan, a Dancer And Last of the 'Isadorables,' Dies
description: Maria-Theresa Duncan, a dancer who was the last of Isadora Duncan's adopted daughters, died at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan Monday. She was 92 years old.

title: Rights Seminar Is Split on Coexisting With Soviet
description: An unusual independent human rights seminar ended today with some of its leaders, united by experience in Soviet prisons and labor camps, parting ways over how to coexist with the Government that imprisoned and freed them.

title: Education Chief Finds A School to His Liking
description: William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, is a severe critic of many American schools, but he has finally found one that he really likes. It is James Madison High School and it exists entirely in his mind.

title: Washington Talk: State Department; Finders and Fliers of Foreign Flags
description: In a warehouse of the District of Columbia Public Works Department on a small side street in the Northeast section of the capital, amid spare street lights, signs, posts and paint, is a giant steel cage containing thousands of flags from nations throughout the world.

title: A Seven-Course Feast of Fish
description: IT is a Christmas Eve ritual handed down from mother to son. Every year, Ed Giobbi, the artist and cookbook author, serves a holiday feast of seven fish dishes (seven for the seven sacraments). Each dish is cooked in a different manner -broiled, fried, baked and so on - or uses a different main ingredient. There is generally a fish or seafood salad and, inevitably, pasta served with a seafood sauce.

title: The Beef and Gary Hart
description: What did people do yesterday when they heard that Gary Hart had re-entered the Democratic Presidential race? Again and again, they laughed. Sometimes the laughter was nervous, incredulous: Is this some kind of practical joke? Or it was cynical: He must be after Federal matching funds to reduce his campaign debt. Or it was ribald, recalling the philandering that drove him out of the race last spring. Or, among Democrats, it was rueful, in recognition of the turmoil his decision would create for their party.

title: Mexico's Tough Economic Crisis
description: The Mexican Government is struggling to regain control of an economic crisis that has unleashed a new round of record inflation, caused Mexicans to shun the peso and send their savings abroad, and stirred up labor discontent.

title: At the Nation's Table; Washington
description: IN official Washington, where and with whom you eat is usually more important than what you eat. But there are exceptions.

title: Opera: Dimitrova Makes Met Debut in 'Turandot'
description: THE title role in ''Turandot'' requires at minimum a soprano voice able to give out the imperious cries of the cruel Chinese Princess with trumpet-like power. If the two-dimensional character of Turandot can somehow, in addition, be projected with more than a bulldozer's nuances, all the better. But penetrating power is the first requisite, the one upon which renowned Turandots of the past have built. Ghena Dimitrova, who made her Metropolitan Opera debut Monday evening in this vocally punishing part, had something convincingly like a trumpet at her disposal in her highest register, which frequently aroused the audience to excited applause. The voice, mostly built of head tones and glottal stops, could weaken lower down, lose quality and stray out of focus.

title: Mehta, With Buts, Talks of Leaving the Philharmonic in 1991
description: Zubin Mehta said yesterday that he would retire as music director of the New York Philharmonic at the end of the 1990-91 season. Then he said he couldn't entirely preclude the possibility that he might change his mind. Then, after a nervous telephone call from Philharmonic officials, he said he really hadn't come to any decision at all.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1987
description: International A3-17

title: Repairing the Big Board
description: If one benefit has emerged from the stock market crash, it is that the inadequacy of the specialist system, long known to market insiders, is now out in the open.

title: Knick-Piston Fight Brings Fines for 9
description: The Knicks went through two dry spells last night. The first one, in the third period, cost them a 15-point advantage and the second one, in the final 4 minutes 15 seconds of the fourth period, cost them the game. They were beaten, 103-98, by the Milwaukee Bucks, who played without the injured Terry Cummings, their leading scorer.

title: At Bill Signing, Camden Sees Hope in Aquarium
description: Governor Kean brought this depressed city a big Christmas present today, signing legislation for a $42 million aquarium to be built on the bank of the Delaware River.

title: Amoco '88 Budget
description: The Amoco Corporation's board approved a $3.8 billion capital and exploration budget for 1988, a 17 percent increase over the company's $3.25 billion budget in 1987. Richard M. Morrow, Amoco's chairman, said in a prepared statement that the company's ability to carry out 1988 spending plans depend on price levels for crude oil, natural gas and refined petroleum products.

title: WINE TALK
description: The great chefs of France share various faults, but excess modesty has never been one of them. Eagerly do they lend their names to cookbooks, videotapes, canned foie gras, nonstick pans, Beaujolais and, in one extreme case, tennis togs. And who is to say them nay? After long years in the kitchen it's hard to resist a little easy money and fame, even if it does tend to look commercial.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WESTERN LANDS. By William S. Burroughs. 258 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: 3 Feared Dead in Explosion At Factory in Pennsylvania
description: A blast destroyed a building at an explosives plant today, the authorities said. Three workers were missing and presumed dead.

title: RICE LOSES HER JOB
description: Just as Gary Hart announced yesterday that he would return to his old job as a Presidential candidate, Donna Rice, who was partly responsible for his losing the job, lost hers.

title: 26 Months In a Prison, Wrongly
description: After being imprisoned 26 months as a convicted rapist, Marion Coakley heard himself declared an innocent man yesterday by a judge and prosecutors in a brief hearing in a Bronx courtroom.

title: William L. Greene, 71; Figure in Court Rulings
description: William Lewis Greene, an aeronautical and civil engineer whose security clearance was denied in the early 1950's, resulting in two important Supreme Court decisions, died of a heart attack Dec. 9 at his home in Bath, Me. He was 71 years old. Mr. Greene was an executive with a Navy contractor until 1951 when, as a result of the denial of his security clearance by the Defense Department, he was forced to leave. He worked as an architect's draughtsman for several years until he shifted to civil engineering and became president of Texfab, a concrete panel manufacturer.

title: Pastry Chef's Christmas Delights
description: AT the age of 23, Markus Farbinger, the pastry chef at Le Cirque in New York, is acclaimed as among the most daring and gifted patissiers to arrive on the American restaurant scene in years.

title: It Was Rather a Poor Show, Not Cricket at All
description: The English are renowned for their wit and dry humor, but they are grimly serious about their national sport, cricket.

title: U.S. Preparing to Inspect 2 Old Radars in Soviet
description: American officials have developed tentative plans to carry out inspections in the Soviet Union next week of several old radars that the Reagan Administration charges are a technical violation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty.

title: POLAND WILL RAISE PRICES 27 PERCENT
description: Poland's Prime Minister announced today that average consumer prices, excluding alcohol and cigarettes, would rise 27 percent next year.

title: A Brighter Future for American Orange Juice
description: Three new varieties of oranges have been developed in a 25-year research project. They should deliver brighter juice to American consumers and help domestic growers compete against imports, the Agriculture Department recently announced.

title: Kaisertech Chief In Debt to Jefferies
description: Jefferies & Company said Alan C. Clore, a longtime customer, and companies he controls had failed to pay for $17 million of Kaisertech Ltd. stock that it had placed orders for in October. Mr. Clore is chairman of Kaisertech, an Oakland, Calif., holding company for the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

title: Ford-Soviet Link
description: The Ford Motor Company is considering a joint automotive venture with the Soviet Union, but the proposals are at a very early stage, Ford's vice chairman, Harold A. Poling, said. Soviet officials approached the second-largest United States auto maker four weeks ago and outlined a ''large range of possibilities,'' from components to full assembly of vehicles, Mr. Poling said. The Soviet Union is interested in small cars, he said.

title: Coke Can Adds a Color
description: A touch of blue will ornament traditional red-and-white Coca-Cola cans as the cola maker tries to entice Americans to drink more ''new'' Coke.

title: Film: 'Moonstruck,' With Italians in Love
description: THE moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie in ''Moonstruck,'' and a lot of other things do too. ''Moonstruck'' is so heavily ethnic that it begins with Dean Martin's rendition of ''That's Amore,'' and there's plenty more where that came from. With its accordion music, its bits of dialect and its love of opera (a key segment of the story unfolds at a Metropolitan Opera performance of ''La Boheme''), ''Moonstruck'' clearly means to celebrate all things Italian. However, it creates the false but persistent impression that most of the people who made it have never been closer to Italy than, perhaps, Iowa.

title: Dr. Martin R. Katz, Cardiologist, 54
description: Dr. Martin R. Katz, a New York cardiologist, died of leiomyo sarcoma of the lung last Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 54 years old.

title: Judge, Winding Up Senate Testimony, Outlines His Constitutional Views
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee conducted its second day of hearings yesterday on the nomination of Judge Anthony M. Kennedy to the Supreme Court. Following are excerpts, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: U.S. Was Defrauded in Health Plan, Panel Is Told
description: Federal investigators told Congress today that one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations had defrauded the Government of Medicare reimbursement payments while leaving many elderly patients liable for bills they thought had been paid.

title: Dr. Robert J. Adrian Professor, 66
description: Dr. Robert J. Adrian, associate professor of educational and community programs in the department of education at Queens College, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Syosset, L.I. He was 66 years old.

title: Israeli Prices Up 1.6%
description: Israel said today that the cost of living rose 1.6 percent in November, and experts forecast that the 1987 annual figure would drop to about 16 percent, from 19.7 percent in all of 1986. Annual inflation has steadily declined since Israel initiated an emergency economic program in mid-1985 to halt runaway inflation, which topped 400 percent in all of 1984.

title: At the Nation's Table; San Francisco
description: MOST travelers postpone serious eating until they are well beyond the airport. But San Francisco International may change that. The airport concessionaire, Host International, proposes to sublet 30 percent of food and beverage space to entrepreneurs who might offer regional and national favorites to reflect the ''diversity and ethnicity of San Francisco,'' according to Louis Turpen, the airport director.

title: Apartments to Replace Wing of Walden School
description: With the agreement of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, the former Progress Club at Central Park West and 88th Street, now a five-story wing of the Walden School, is to be torn down to make way for a 23-story apartment building.

title: TV Reviews; For Holidays, Puppets, Songs and Capote Story
description: HOW do you grapple with the traditional in a world that puts a premium on novelty? Television takes a scattershot approach when it comes to Christmas specials, mixing a few new shows with repeats of others that have been around for years. Many of the so-called classics are not only popular, they're also cheap to rerun. Occasionally, the mix works.

title: Howard Beach Jury To Continue Today
description: The jury at the Howard Beach trial deliberated for a sixth day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the case of four white teen-agers charged with murder or manslaughter stemming from the death of a black man in the Queens neighborhood a year ago.

title: Role of the Police Studied In Death of Bronx Woman
description: Bronx prosecutors and at least three city agencies are investigating the death of a 28-year-old Bronx woman who, according to her companion and lawyers for her family, was severely beaten earlier this month in a confrontation with the police. The police deny those allegations.

title: Italy Opens Trial in Airport Raid
description: The only gunman who survived the attack on the Rome airport two years ago in which 16 people were killed went on trial today at the Rebibbia maximum-security prison.

title: Market Place; Banks' Reserves And Latin Loans
description: AFTER the Bank of Boston's decision to write off 20 percent of its Latin American loans and to establish reserves equal to more than half its remaining Latin loans, many investors are wondering whether the other money-center banks will follow.

title: Teaching 4-Year-Olds: A Program Grows
description: Nursery school teachers are masters of deceit.

title: Chesapeake Cleanup Pact Is Signed
description: The Governors of Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia, along with the Mayor of Washington and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, signed an agreement today on to a regional effort to clean up and protect the Chesapeake Bay, one of the largest and most polluted ecosystems in the country.

title: Music: Oratorio Society In Handel's 'Messiah'
description: EVER since its founding in 1873, the Oratorio Society of New York has performed Handel's ''Messiah'' each holiday season, all but the first 18 of those years in Carnegie Hall. The group sang the oratorio there on Monday evening, with Lyndon Woodside, its music director, conducting a version full of vigor and buoyed by the presence of several able soloists. Despite its roots in the last century and its tradition of large-scale resources for the presentation of such Baroque works as this one, the Oratorio Society's clean-textured, slimmed-down ''Messiah'' performance had something of the feel, if not exactly the instrumentation, of a period-instrument rendition.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Meeting Akhromeyev
description: When Marshal Sergei F. Akhromeyev of the Soviet Union marched into the Pentagon last week to meet with Adm. William J. Crowe Jr. and other members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, almost everything he said and did was shrouded in secrecy.

title: E.P.A. to Allow Use of Herbicide, Citing 'Reasonable' Health Risk
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would allow continued use of the herbicide alachlor with some restrictions. After four years of study, the agency has decided that the chemical does not pose an ''unreasonable'' risk of cancer in humans.

title: Topics of The Times; How Republicans Keep House
description: What do New York Republicans have to hide? That's the question raised by the state G.O.P.'s court fight to keep secret how it spends the tens of thousands of dollars the party raises each year for ''housekeeping'' expenses.

title: Ray Malavasi Is Dead; Former Coach of Rams
description: Ray Malavasi, who coached the Los Angeles Rams to their only Super Bowl appearance, died today of a heart attack, a spokesman for Western Medical Center said. Mr. Malavasi was 57 years old.

title: Legalized Extortion Charge Against School Custodians Is False
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampson In, Washburn Out
description: Golden State officially ushered in the Ralph Sampson era this afternoon. The 7-foot-4-inch center joined the team for the first time since being traded by Houston, along with Steve Harris, for Joe Barry Carroll and Eric (Sleepy) Floyd.

title: Six Library Scholars Given N.Y.U. Degrees
description: Six scholars from major libraries in the United States and Europe received honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degrees from New York University at the Elmer Bobst Library on Washington Square yesterday.

title: New Missile Planned By France and Britain
description: French and British military officials have made ''good progress'' with discussions on the possible joint development of a new air-launched nuclear missile that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says is permissible under the new Soviet-American arms treaty.

title: ROCK: RICHARD BARONE
description: RICHARD BARONE'S performance at the Bottom Line on Monday was an impressive reminder that in pop music, as in other arts, talent has a way of surviving changes in fashion.

title: Mellon Expects to Lose $220 Million in Quarter
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss of $220 million, which would bring its net loss to $830 million for the year.

title: In London, If the Shoe Is Bumpy, It's Chic
description: THE House of Beauty and Culture is outre not just in terms of the styles it sells. It is also near the fringe in terms of London geography, situated as it is at 34-36 Stamford Road in the neighborhood known as Hackney.

title: The Homeless, at Suppertime
description: LEAD: The food van pulls up to the back entrance of Port Authority Bus Terminal most mights at about 8:15. A hundred or so homeless people, most of them black and male, are waiting in a ragged line that becomes unsettled when they see the van.

title: 'Kill Us or Get Out!' Arabs Taunt As Rocks and Bullets Fly in Gaza
description: ''Kill us all!'' taunted the young Palestinians throwing rocks at the Israeli soldiers. ''Come and kill us all or get out!''

title: Staff Cutbacks For Boeing Jet
description: The Boeing Company said today that it was continuing to cut back the manpower being assigned to develop its futuristic 7J7 aircraft and said it was no longer predicting when the aircraft would be available.

title: Record Trade Imbalance Is Reported
description: The broadest measure of the nation's foreign trade showed a record $43.4 billion quarterly deficit last summer, as the United States ran a deficit with the rest of the world in investment earnings for the first time in 29 years.

title: How to Stop a Bagful of Dirty Tricks
description: They have names like ''playing the piano'' and ''relay voting,'' but they are simply colorful descriptions for the possible ways to cheat in the presidential election Wednesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The whole lesson of our Constitutional experience has been that a people can rise above its own injustice, that a people can arise above the inequities that prevail at a particular time.

title: Islanders Fashion Ugly Tie
description: UNIONDALE, L.I. Dec. 15 -

title: Citicorp's Auction Rates
description: Interest rates rose for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction yesterday of new commercial paper.

title: BASEBALL EXPANSION
description: Baseball Commissioner Peter Ueberroth made no commitments on expansion at a meeting in Washington yesterday with a group of Senators interested in securing major league teams. Following a meeting with 10 Senators representing Colorado, Arizona, Ohio, Indiana and Florida, as well as the delegate from the District of Columbia, Ueberroth said that baseball wanted to expand, but that it had no timetable and had made no commitments to any city. ''We talked about all kinds of scenarios,'' Ueberroth said. ''The numbers that get interesting are 30 or 32 teams down the line. There is no commitment from baseball.''

title: Why It's Oval
description: To the Editor:

title: I. William Fishkind, Securities Executive, 53
description: I. William Fishkind, an executive with the National Association of Securities Dealers in Washington, the regulatory organization for the securities industry, died of cancer Friday at his home in Burke, Va. He was 53 years old.

title: Nicaragua to Keep Big Military Force, Its Leader Declares
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that Nicaragua would continue to maintain a large standing army and a force of 600,000 or more men in reserve, even if it ''normalizes'' relations with the United States and its neighbors.

title: Peter Birch, Dancer and Choreographer, 65
description: Peter Birch, a dancer, choreographer and television director, died of a heart attack Sunday at White Plains Hospital, White Plains, N.Y. He was 65 years old.

title: U.S. Cutting Sugar Imports In Blow to Trading Partners
description: The United States will cut its 1988 sugar imports by 25 percent, to the lowest level in more than 100 years, the Reagan Administration announced today. The action is expected to increase prices for consumers and hurt the debt-burdened economies of some of America's trading partners among developing nations.

title: SHIFT ON CONTRAS SEEN IN CONGRESS
description: Congressional leaders said today that a Nicaraguan defector's assertion that Managua intends to enlarge its military appeared to be turning Congress in favor of renewing non-arms aid for the contras.

title: KEY RATES
Free Holiday Concert
description: The Armonia Chamber Ensemble will give a free concert Dec. 30 at 4 P.M. in the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at West 65th Street. The program will feature excerpts from Handel's ''Messiah'' and works by Telemann, Vivaldi, Faure, Beethoven and Mozart. Tickets will be available at the library one hour before the performance. Information: 870-1630.

title: Food Notes
description: Dinner With Louis

title: Film: 'Broadcast News,' Comedy
description: THERE once was a time when big news events had the power to stun and, sometimes, to cause a certain amount of anxiety. Wars, earthquakes, airplane crashes, stock market busts, mass-murder sprees, kidnappings, duplicity in positions of public trust, political assassinations. These things could upset daily routine. They were reminders of the precariousness of the existence we tend to take for granted.

title: For Ben & Jerry, A Frustrating Bid To Aid Subways
description: Last spring Ben Cohen went to catch a train at 59th Street and Columbus Circle, heading for the Brooklyn Botanical Garden, and he was dumbstruck by ''the filth, the disrepair, the degrading effect on your sensibilities.''

title: Officer Found Guilty In Off-Duty Shooting
description: A New York City transit police officer was convicted of misdemeanor charges yesterday in the off-duty shooting of a Brooklyn man last year, which prosecutors characterized as a racial incident. However, the officer was acquitted of more serious felony assault charges.

title: Dow Up by 8.62 in Seesaw Trading
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in a seesaw session. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 8.62 points higher at 1,941.48, bringing its advance in the last two days to nearly 75 points.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Trouble in Maine
description: Caspar W. Weinberger, who as Secretary of Defense faced big frustrations in the public furor over the Air Force's $7,400 beverage unit, the Navy's $435 claw hammer and a $640 military toilet cover, is in trouble again with contractors. This time it is not those overcharging military contractors but contractors who promised to finish an extension on his retirement home in Maine by mid-November. Mr. Weinberger, who left office last month, said the latest target date was mid-January, but he isn't sure about that either. He and his wife, Jane, will stay on at their Watergate apartment until work is finished on the house, which is on Somes Sound near Acadia National Park. The question of cost overruns hasn't yet arisen, he said.

title: New Substitutes for Injured Nerves
description: AT the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Cleveland, several people whose legs are paralyzed have been able to walk and even to climb and descend stairs. Throughout the world, about 2,000 profoundly deaf people have had some of their hearing restored, in some cases well enough to allow them to talk on the telephone.

title: A New Use For Sludge: To Make Oil
description: OVER the years, cities have tried all manner of methods to dispose of sludge, the end product of the typical sewage treatment plant. They have burned it, buried it, dumped it in the ocean, spread it on farms and even made bricks of it.

title: Shultz Favors Europe's A-Arms
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that a strong nuclear arsenal was crucial for Western security after intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe are destroyed.

title: At the Nation's Table; Houston
description: MEXICAN food is a serious subject in this part of the world: witness the debate over whether the true Mexican salsa is red or green.

title: Dance: From Nikolais, 'Eruptions,' a Premiere
description: A JOINT program by Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis, who are certainly two major American modern-dance choreographers, may sound like a capital idea. But the same notion can make for a long evening as demonstrated by last night's opening of the Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company at the Joyce Theater.

title: Happiness Is a Warm Dessert
description: MOST of us are suckers for warm desserts. Whether it's homemade apple pie, a sophisticated souffle or that seldom-seen classic crepes, we are almost powerless to resist a still-warm-from-the-oven or stove-top sweet at the end of a meal.

title: Topics of The Times; Truth in Juice
description: It tastes sweet and looks like juice, but a popular apple drink sold in supermarkets contains only 10 percent real fruit juice. The rest is sugar and water. Consumers have a right to accurate information about the content of diluted fruit ''punches,'' ''ades'' and ''cocktails'' that compete on store shelves with real juice. Yet instead of promoting that right, the Federal Food and Drug Administration stands in the way.

title: Real Estate; A New Look For the Old White Castle
description: Since 1932, a White Castle restaurant has been on the northwest corner of Northern and Bell Boulevards in the Bayside section of Queens. Today, two of the restaurant chain's unmistakable white porcelain and notched-roof buildings are squeezed onto that site.

title: 'Tilted Arc' Gains Adherents
description: After a visit in a cold, driving rain to inspect ''Tilted Arc,'' the Richard Serra sculpture that sweeps across 26 Federal Plaza in downtown Manhattan, a committee of art experts and public officials from around the United States decided yesterday that the work could not be removed or relocated without destroying its artistic value.

title: Sinai Reported To Weigh Shift
description: Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Shearson Lehman Brothers, whose views have commanded a wide following, is considering a new position at Shearson that, some sources at the firm say, may resemble an independent consulting arrangement.

title: Bird Helps Celtics End Losing Streak
description: Larry Bird scored 27 points and had 7 assists tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 122-102 victory over the Washington Bullets.

title: Firestone Reorganizing Into Three Divisions
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that its board had approved a reorganization that will establish a parent company and divide its operations into three independent subsidiaries.

title: Scabrous Epochs and the Character Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Pinky Tomlin, Songwriter, 80
description: Pinky Tomlin, who wrote the 1930's hit ''The Object of My Affection'' and dozens of other tunes, died of a heart attack at a medical center in North Hollywood Saturday. He was 80 years old.

title: Japan Offers Southeast Asia Aid
description: In his first trip abroad since becoming Prime Minister of Japan, Noboru Takeshita told the heads of six Southeast Asian nations today that his Government would reject remilitarization and assist the region in greater economic development.

title: Doctors' Quandary: Picking Who Gets a Heart
description: Every Friday morning at 7 o'clock, heart transplant surgeons at Presbyterian Hospital gather with other staff members in a small 14th-floor conference room to decide over coffee and doughnuts the fate of dozens of patients waiting for a transplanted heart.

title: 2 Defendants Are Found With Weapons
description: LEAD: A scissor blade and two razor blades were found yesterday in the possession of two defendants whose murder conviction last month touched off a battle in a Brooklyn courtroom in which 11 court officers were injured.

title: Hart Unsettles Democrats, Which Pleases Republicans
description: Hart's decision to re-enter the Democratic Presidential race today threw the contest into confusion, stunned his party's leaders and left Republicans gleeful over the Democratic disarray.

title: College Hockey Notebook; Little Man Is Big Again on Ice
description: Although the typical college athlete in the last generation has grown about 3 inches and added 20 pounds, there is still a place for the smaller performer in hockey.

title: Bruce Rejects Kansas
description: One of Schembechler's foremost Big Ten rivals, former Ohio State coach Earle Bruce has turned down the head-coaching position at Kansas, university officials said yesterday. The Kansas athletic director, Bob Frederick, said Bruce decided against accepting the offer to succeed Bob Valesente at the Big Eight Conference school because ''we could not resolve certain contractual issues surrounding Bruce's previous contract settlement and aren't able, therefore, to pursue the matter further.'' Bruce, who was dismissed by Ohio State last month, said, ''I guess we'll just have to wait and see what happens after the first of the year at the other jobs.''

title: Coach Is Recuperating
description: Doctors at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., said last night that Bo Schembechler's prognosis for recovery was good after the Michigan football coach had undergone his second quadruple heart bypass operation. Schembechler, 58, was listed in satisfactory condition in the intensive-care unit, where he underwent the seven-hour procedure. Barring complications, Schembechler was expected to be released from the hospital shorly after a 7-to-10-day recovery period, officials said. The veteran coach, who suffered a heart attack in 1969, entered the hospital Monday for a checkup following stress tests a week earlier, the hospital spokesman, Bill Brauker, said. Schembechler was about to be released yesterday when he complained of chest pains, Brauker said. Schembechler's first quadruple bypass operation was in 1976. According to Bruce Madej, Michigan's sports information director, it would be ''almost impossible'' for Schembechler to coach Michigan in the Hall of Fame Bowl against Alabama on Jan. 2 in Tampa, Fla. Athletic Director Don Canham said Gary Moeller, the offensive coordinator, had been appointed acting head coach.

title: Insider-Case Delays Seen
description: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that it would probably be months before the agency would bring any new insider trading cases.

title: Bridge: Nassau-Suffolk Event Ends In Time for the 1988 Version
description: The final of the Nassau-Suffolk Double Knockout Team Championship was completed a week ago at the Grand Club in Franklin Square, L.I., with victory going to Alan Tucker of Great Neck, L.I., Harry Stappenbeck of Uniondale, L.I., and Jim Becker, Howard Chandross and Josh Parker, all of Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: Oil Prices Drop Further

title: Dodgers Get Davis as Yanks Lose Out
description: The Yankees, who were one phone call and $35,000 away from solving a pressing need for a left-handed hitter, apparently procrastinated too long Monday afternoon. Mike Davis, the free-agent outfielder they had been pursuing since last week, agreed yesterday to a two-year contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers, leaving the Yankees empty-handed again.

title: Eating Well
description: ''WHAT is this stuff,'' said a shopper to no one in particular - a fairly common occurence in the supermarket.

title: Sears to Acquire Pinstripes Petites
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to acquire Pinstripes Petites, a women's specialty-store chain based in Minneapolis, for an undisclosed sum. It is Sears's second specialty-store acquisition in recent months - the first was Eye-Care Centers of America Inc., a 41-store chain based in San Antonio.

title: The Pop Life
description: That Sylvian Sound

title: SPECIAL COUNSEL IS SIGNED INTO LAW
description: President Reagan today signed a five-year extension of the independent counsel law, despite what he said were ''my very strong doubts about its constitutionality.''

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 3:30 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Kemp's Complaint
description: A member of the Jack Kemp for President staff was flattered but suspicious when a caller, identifying herself as a student, asked for statements from the Republican contender on the Strategic Defense Initiative. The address she gave, 733 15th Street, sounded familiar; it turned out to be the George Bush for President Campaign headquarters.

title: Saudi Pretoria Boycott
description: To the Editor:

title: Diana Sheean, 72; Her Books Showed Britain in Wartime
description: Diana Sheean, an author and the widow of Vincent Sheean, died of a stroke complicated by pneumonia at St. Stephen's Hospital in London last Wednesday. She was 72 years old.

title: Transit Scandal: Do Arrest Incentives Motivate the Police or Invite Abuse?
description: The four New York City transit police officers accused of making scores of false or improper arrests worked for a commander who gave the best jobs to his most ''active'' officers, those who made the most arrests and issued the most summonses.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: ALMOST unnoticed, garlic has become a significant part of the food scene, both in this country and abroad. It is a delightful development.

title: Van Ellis Huff, Inventor, 93
description: Van Ellis Huff, inventor of the jalousie window, died at home here last Thursday. He was 93 years old.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The Indian 'War' Is Bitter; Can the Few Survive?
description: Amid charges of conspiracy, forgery and espionage, a fierce battle has erupted between Brazil's Roman Catholic Church and powerful conservative groups that want commercial mining to be permitted on lands traditionally occupied by Indians.

title: Boxing Notebook; Sparring Begins for Holmes
description: Larry Holmes, the former heavyweight champion, was at ringside when Mike Tyson knocked out Tyrell Biggs in October. After seeing the bout, he now says that Tyson is a dirty fighter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1987
description: International

title: SENATE REJECTS HOUSE TAX PROPOSAL
description: Senate negotiators working on a compromise tax increase package tonight rejected a bid by House conferees to water down - but not abandon - a proposal to limit interest deductions in corporate takeovers.

title: Mayor, Accused of Hate Mail, Is Removed
description: The city's first black mayor was removed from office today in a recall election prompted by charges he sent racist hate mail to community leaders.

title: Alabama to Forfeit $250,000 to N.C.A.A.
description: Alabama must forfeit more than $250,000 in basketball receipts for using two ineligible players in the 1987 N.C.A.A. Tournament, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced today.

title: Deciding to Celebrate Christmas, or Not
description: IN the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn, a Christmas tree may help light Santa's way to the house of Kaid and Fatima Almontaser. The Almontasers are Moslems.

title: Answers for Le Monde Contest
description: LAST week Le Monde published the answers to its wine quiz, which has had the French madly competing for prizes. With the publication of some of the questions in this column, American readers may also have been taxing themselves and their knowledge of arcane wine information. Here are the answers:

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: KEAN AND JERSEY CITY MAYOR CLASH ON SCHOOLS
description: Governor Kean's plans for the state to take over failing school districts have been blocked in the Legislature again, but he has vowed to move against those districts in court, and this city is at the top of his list.

title: HART, IN SURPRISE, RESUMES CAMPAIGN FOR WHITE HOUSE
description: Gary Hart resumed his Presidential campaign today, shocking Democratic leaders and the six others seeking the party's nomination. He vowed to ''let the people decide'' on his candidacy.

title: Moet Blends Old Art and Latest Science
description: ''WE are heirs to a tradition,'' said Bruno Duteurtre, who heads Moet & Chandon's enological research laboratory in Epernay, France. ''And we must seek to progress while upholding that tradition.''

title: Fay Accepts Match Race
description: Michael Fay, a banker from New Zealand, gave up his demand for a multinational America's Cup regatta and agreed today to the San Diego Yacht Club's condition that it race only against Fay's boat for the cup next year.

title: Youth Slain in Hiccup Cure
description: A high school senior shot his friend to death in an attempt to cure his hiccups by scaring him, the police said Monday. The 19-year-old senior, David E. Duquette, of Glocester, told the police the gun he was holding on Nicholas Lovell, 16, went off accidentally. Mr. Duquette was charged with murder.

title: Ulfert Wilke Painter, 80
description: Ulfert Wilke, a painter and calligrapher who was founding director of the University of Iowa Art Museum, died of complications from a stroke at his home in Anahola, Kauai, Hawaii, on Dec. 7. He was 80 years old.

title: SLIDING OIL PRICES KEEP BONDS UP
description: Treasury bond prices rose for the second consecutive day, following the lead set by declining oil prices.

title: Corrections
description: A photograph accompanying the New Yorkers & Co. column in Business Day on Monday was incorrectly captioned. It showed E. Theodore Stolberg, a junior partner at the firm Weiss, Peck & Greer, not Philip Greer, a senior partner at the firm.

title: OPEC Pact Sends Oil Price Down
description: Oil prices fell again on world markets yesterday after OPEC decided to extend its current production and pricing levels through the middle of next year.

title: ICE, GUM AND HAMSTRINGS
description: HIS head down, his blood pressure up, Mike Ditka was striding toward the Chicago Bears' locker room at halftime with turnovers on his mind. His quarterback, Mike Tomczak, had thrown four passes that were intercepted and the San Francisco 49ers had recovered two fumbles for a 20-0 jump in what would be a 41-0 rout. As Ditka, the Bears' coach, approached the door below the Candlestick Park stands, he was suddenly struck by what he later described as ''ice'' tossed by a patron no doubt trying to cool him off.

title: With South Korea's Stability in Balance, Millions Vote for a New President
description: With their country's political stability hanging in the balance, millions of South Koreans voted today, their first chance in 16 years to elect a president on their own.

title: Of Courses Such as Spots 'n' Dots
description: The course at Brown University had a reputation as being undemanding, a ''gut,'' in campus argot. But it nearly became a college student's nightmare.

title: Sins of the Summit
description: Among the best ways to sabotage the frail process of Soviet-American summitry is for participants to say one thing in private and another in public. Another is to pass over tough subjects in private and then explode them publicly. With Mikhail Gorbachev's jetstream barely dissipated, President Reagan has done both.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association was quick to take advantage of yesterday's rise in bond prices by offering $200 million of 10-year debentures through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: 9 Fined in Knick Fight
description: Seven Pistons and two Knicks were fined a total of $8,500 yesterday for their parts in a fight Saturday night at the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich.

title: Western Union Note Offering
description: The Western Union Telegraph Corporation has arranged a $500 million offering of five-year speculative grade notes through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., a Drexel official said late yesterday.

title: Washington Talk: The News Media; Watching Cable News Network Grow
description: In some offices at the Pentagon, the State Department and the White House, a television set is tuned to Cable News Network most of the time. A British reporter used CNN to help cover President Reagan's summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. And Nancy Reagan sent CNN's chief Washington anchor a complimentary note about the summit coverage last week.

title: CUBANS ON PATROL IN SOUTH ANGOLA
description: Cuban troops started to patrol southern Angola this week with orders to engage South African troops in combat, Angolan authorities here say.

title: BOY IN 'EMPIRE' CALLS ACTING 'REALLY GOOD FUN'
description: When Christian Bale auditioned for Steven Spielberg's ''Empire of the Sun'' a year and a half ago, he had never been in a feature film and was but one of 4,000 teen-age boys vying for the role of Jim Graham, a pampered, cocky schoolboy in pre-World War II Shanghai who is transformed by four terrifying years of war into a gaunt yet courageous young man. In fact, the 13-year-old English boy had never really considered acting professionally until three years ago, when his sister Louise was cast in a musical in London's West End. ''I thought it was really good fun, and it looked easy,'' said Mr. Bale, whose critically acclaimed performance in Mr. Spielberg's new $30 million movie has made him an odds-on favorite to join the very select group of child actors ever to be nominated for an Academy Award.

title: STUDY SEEKS TO AID DISABLED DRIVERS
description: Disabled motorists are being unfairly ticketed when they park out of state because of wide discrepancies in the states' regulation of access to parking for the handicapped, a study by the Federal Highway Administration says.

title: KEAN AND THE SENATE AGREE ON FINANCING ON SCHOOL TAKEOVER
description: The Kean administration and Senate Democrats reached a compromise today in a money dispute that had threatened to kill the Governor's proposal that would give the state power to take over failing school districts.

title: State Officials Assail Brokers Over Collapse
description: The brokerage community came under intense criticism today from state securities regulators, who contended that nearly half the losses to investors during the October stock market plunge resulted from of shoddy brokerage practices and irresponsible investment advice, not falling stock prices.

title: Political Concerns of OPEC Members Make Oil a Secondary Consideration
description: Some analysts on Wall Street may feel confident that a resourceful OPEC can stop the slide in oil prices that began Monday, when the group failed to reach an agreement to curb runaway production and discounting. But many in OPEC, as well as industry experts who observed the recent meeting, are less confident and say that political divisions and economic hardships have cut too deeply into the group's cohesion.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Celtics 121, Jazz 111: Larry Bird scored 38 points and teamed with Robert Parish in a third-quarter surge last night as the Celtics kept intact their 14-season Boston Garden unbeaten streak against the Jazz. The Celtics, who had lost their previous two games at the Garden, are 18-0 at home against the Jazz. Boston hasn't lost three straight home games since the 1978-79 season. With the score tied, 73-73, with 7 minutes 32 seconds left in the third quarter, Parish's jumper began a 21-12 run that gave the Celtics a 94-85 lead entering the final period.(AP) 76ers 114, Spurs 102: Charles Barkley scored 32 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead Philadelphia at home. David Wingate added a career-high 28 points for Philadelphia. Barkley had 22 points and 9 rebounds in the first half, and the Spurs committed 17 turnovers.(AP) N.H.L. Red Wings 6, Capitals 1: Petr Klima scored two goals and John Chabot added one goal and four assists last night to lead Detroit at home. Mike O'Connell, a Detroit defenseman who returned to action after serving an eight-game suspension following a match penalty Nov. 27, opened the scoring at 11 minutes 8 seconds of the first period.(AP) Canadiens 5, Nordiques 4: Ryan Walter scored two goals last night to lead the Canadiens at home. In the closing seconds, Rick Green, a Montreal defenseman, preserved the victory when he made a sliding stop on a shot by Michel Goulet of Quebec.(AP) Ski Racing Tomba Wins Fourth Straight Race: Alberto Tomba of Italy won his fourth straight World Cup race yesterday when he captured a men's slalom in Madonna di Campiglio, Italy. Tomba, who will turn 21 Saturday, clocked the fastest time in both heats down the steep and icy Miramonti course for a winning time of 1 minute 43.97 seconds. Rudolf Nierlich of Austria finished second in 1:45.31, improving four places from the first heat. Bojan Krizaj of Yugoslavia finished third in 1:45.54.

title: Market Street Journal; Dingy Palace Braces for Renaissance
description: The sign over the door leading to Palace Billiards says, ''We never close.'' But now the habitues of one of the country's last big downtown pool halls fear that closing is exactly what the Palace is being forced to do.

title: Stage: 'Love Suicides'
description: SINCE no credit is taken in the Playbill for translating ''The Love Suicides at Amijima,'' perhaps no offense will be taken at the suggestion that everything has been lost in translation. The work, by Monzaemon Chikamatsu, the renowned Japanese dramatist of the 17th and 18th centuries, is a tale of star-crossed lovers, a married businessman named Jihei and a prostitute, ''the good-hearted, good-natured, good-in-bed Koharu.'' Jihei's wife and in-laws are upset at the relationship, and it all ends in soul talk, sex and suicide. ''I have fled the burning house of the three worlds of delusion,'' announces Jihei.

title: ELECTION PROVES DELICATE FOR U.S. AMID OPPOSITION CHARGE OF FRAUD
description: The United States Government was confronted with a delicate situation tonight as the candidate of the Government party, Roh Tae Woo, captured the South Korean presidential election and opposition parties charged that there had been electoral fraud.

title: G.E. Capital Sets $500 Million Issue
description: The General Electric Capital Corporation is offering $500 million of notes due in 2007 with an initial interest rate of 8 3/4 percent for three years for 100 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Contra Aid Plan Encounters Opposition in House
description: House Democrats expressed strong opposition today to a compromise plan, backed by their leadership, to provide aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Crude Oil, in Hectic Trading, Drops Below $16 a Barrel
description: Crude oil prices broke below $16 a barrel yesterday, hitting their lowest level in more than a year.

title: Dance: Ailey in 'Vespers'
description: ULYSSES DOVE possesses the ability to choreograph dances that, though they may be totally lacking in conventional plot, nevertheless possess a strongly dramatic atmosphere. One cannot always be sure just what is going on in them or why things happen the way they do. Yet one keeps watching with interest. ''Vespers,'' his newest work of this type, received its New York premiere at the Tuesday night performance of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: Children Forgo Stockings to Aid the Neediest
description: In a joint effort, four Manhattan children have sent their ''stocking money'' to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Store Chains Praised for Not Selling Toy Guns
description: An organization that opposes handguns has honored three store chains and a suburban village for their efforts to keep realistic toy guns out of the hands of children - or anyone else.

title: Soviet Ready to Face Off
description: The Soviet Union is prepared to send the Soviet League champion to play the Stanley Cup champion in a world series of hockey as early as September, according to Vyacheslav Koloskov, the Soviet Union's hockey director. But, he said in an interview in Thursday's Toronto Globe and Mail, his nation's best players would never be allowed to join National Hockey League teams.

title: FLORIDA DRUG RING REPORTED BROKEN
description: A drug-smuggling ring that killed an informer and cut up his body while trafficking in a half-million pounds of marijuana has been broken, the Federal authorities said today.

title: JUDICIARY PANEL FOCUSES ON BORK
description: The air of bipartisan calm surrounding the confirmation hearings for Judge Anthony M. Kennedy evaporated on the final day today as members of the Senate Judiciary Committee engaged in sharp debate over the Reagan Administration's first choice for the Supreme Court vacancy, Judge Robert H. Bork.

title: Critical Stage Seen For Texaco
description: Executives of Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company have reached a critical point in their discussions over a plan for Texaco to emerge from its eight months in bankruptcy, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Gastineau Gets Starting Spot
description: Mark Gastineau, once the premier defensive lineman in pro football, received a promotion and a pat on the back today from his coach, Joe Walton.

title: EXPLODING STARS SHOWN TO YIELD LIFE ELEMENTS
description: Instruments aboard an astronomical satellite and two scientific balloons have provided the first direct evidence that exploding stars create the heavy chemical elements that make up most things on Earth, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration reported yesterday.

title: PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in November.

title: Jerry H. Johnson, AIDS Health Worker, 53
description: Jerry H. Johnson, an AIDS coordinator for the Gay Men's Health Crisis, died Dec. 14 of lung cancer at his home in Manhattan. He was 53 years old.

title: SOUTH KOREA VOTE BACKS CANDIDATE OF RULING PARTY
description: Roh Tae Woo, the candidate of the Government party, registered a surprisingly sturdy victory today over a divided opposition in South Korea's first genuine presidential election in 16 years.

title: Strong Quake Kills 2 in Tokyo
description: A strong earthquake rocked the Tokyo region this morning, killing 2 people, injuring 10 and causing buildings to sway violently for several minutes, authorities said.

title: Critic's Notebook; Young Pianists Stuck in Mainstream
description: TO judge by a few dozen recitals in recent months, the trend toward a historical reassessment of the repertory has not extended all that far into the pianistic community. While other musicians are busily resurrecting forgotten works, young pianists remain on the whole unusually faithful to the mainstream.

title: Joseph I. Lichten, 81, B'nai B'rith Rome Aide
description: Joseph I. Lichten, who served as head of the Vatican liaison office of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith for 15 years, died Monday at his home in Rome. He was 81.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $200,000. c-Net loss

title: Bail Set for Nurse in L.I. Lethal Injection Case
description: A Suffolk County judge set bail today at $50,000 in cash or a $100,000 bond for a nurse suspected of injecting many of his patients with fatal amounts of muscle-paralyzing drugs.

title: Coney I. Train Yard Fire Seen as Suspicious
description: A fire last week at the Coney Island maintenance yard of the Transit Authority may be the latest in a series of suspicious incidents, officials said yesterday.

title: Currents; Packaging Inspired by Origami
description: TO Katsu Kimura, a 53-year-old package designer from Tokyo, a box is not merely a container. It can just as easily look like a banana, a hot dog or an egg.

title: SPELLING (AARON) PRODUCIONS (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included non-recurring income of $3.5 million received from American Broadcasting Co. as part of the modification and extension of the company's agreement with ABC. c-Included a non-recurring charge of $750,000 for expenses related to the company's reorganization in August 1986.

title: In Reborn Quest, Hart Hears Praise and Scorn
description: ''Hey, Gary, how's Donna Rice?'' the truck driver called out to the candidate. ''How's Donna?'' Sometimes it was whispered and sometimes it turned up in obscene signs and jokes, but the name of the Miami model whom Gary Hart entertained in his Washington town house that fateful weekend seven months ago kept coming up today.

title: Charles Shaw, Journalist, 76
description: Charles Shaw, a former newspaper and broadcast journalist, died of complications from emphysema and heart disease at Doylestown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Doylestown.

title: Farm Credit System Plan
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a compromise version of a $4 billion bailout for the Farm Credit System, and lawmakers said final approval would come before the holiday recess.

title: Explaining the Pentagon, for a Fee
description: Burdeshaw Associates Ltd., a small concern, differs from the 100 other consultants' offices that dot the Beltway, the highway circling Washington.

title: Raymond E. Majerus Dies at 63; Secretary-Treasurer of U.A.W.
description: DETROIT, Dec. 16 -

title: Sandinistas Warn Opposition Not to Push Too Far
description: In some of their harshest statements in recent months, Sandinista leaders have warned opposition political parties that they are in danger of overstepping the limit on dissent that is tolerated by the ruling party here.

title: KETCHUM & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mexico's Rulers Reassessing Future
description: A sudden and unexpected turn for the worse in Mexico's economic crisis, now in its sixth year, has seriously weakened the prestige of President Miguel de la Madrid and forced the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party to reassess its political strategy for the coming election year.

title: Dow Surges 32.99 to Close at 1,974.47
description: Stock prices rallied in late trading yesterday after remaining narrowly mixed throughout most of the session. The Dow Jones industrial average surged more than 20 points in the last hour to close 32.99 points ahead, at 1,974.47.

title: College Basketball; Princeton Upsets Seton Hall
description: Dave Orlandini scored 21 points and Princeton hit 11 of 20 3-point shots tonight to overcome Mark Bryant's 26-point performance and upset Seton Hall, 61-59.

title: For Haiti TV, New Regime Is Like the Old
description: When roving bands of thugs and soldiers massacred at least 34 voters and forced the cancellation of the first presidential election in 30 years last month, the national television network here all but skipped the story.

title: Army Sergeant Pleads Guilty Of Infecting a G.I. With AIDS
description: A sergeant has pleaded guilty to charges that he had sex with a soldier who is a woman despite knowing that he had been infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Hers
description: LEAD: WHEN my friend the Australian sculptor Clement Meadmore comes to dinner, I see how he tries to suffer my room in silence. His malaise expresses itself in the way he sits sideways on my couch and how he frowns downward. There comes a moment when he cannot bear it another moment. He has got up. He is moving the couch inches to the left.

title: 23d Chess Game Adjourned
description: The 23d game of the World Chess Championship between Gary Kasparov and his challenger, Anatoly Karpov, was adjourned today. Karpov, playing white, sealed his 41st move.

title: Yonkers Bears Costs Amid Wealthier Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOPOLITAN CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a $728,000 provision for possible losses, after provision for recovery of income taxes, resulting from the termination of a New York City agency contract to collect parking meter revenue, the discontinuance of the operations of five operating centers, and other items. c-Net income d-Includes a pre-tax gain on sale of stock in a partially-owned subsidiary of $1,248,000. Corrected from Tuesday, Dec. 15, editions.

title: Pretoria Journal; Great Trek Updated: Whither Now, White Tribe?
description: As recorded bells rang through the marble chamber of the Voortrekker Monument, a broad-shouldered man put his arm around his small daughter and peered with her over the parapet to the floor below. After a moment, he pulled a handkerchief from his pocket and dabbed his eyes.

title: NOMINEE'S ANSWERS CONTRAST WITH BORK'S
description: Judge Anthony M. Kennedy came across in Senate testimony this week as a man with a subtle mind who had no preconceived answers to the hardest questions he would face on the Supreme Court.

title: AT BUSH'S PARTY
description: Vice President Bush has made loyalty to President Reagan the foundation of his Presidential bid, and he displayed that quality again Tuesday night at his Christmas Party.

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED AS SAN JOSE RAPIST
description: A man suspected of being responsible for attacking at least 30 women over three years was arrested today, the police said.

title: Sports People; Ditka Cuts Interviews
description: In a terse statement issued yesterday by the Chicago Bears, Coach Mike Ditka said he would reduce his availability to reporters. ''Mike Ditka has decided to decrease his activities with the media in disgust over the media's treatment over the trivial incidents that have occurred over the past several weeks,'' the statement said. ''He will be available only for postgame interviews on Sunday and on Monday following the game.'' The Bears suffered a 41-0 loss to the 49ers Monday night in San Francisco, and Ditka, after being pelted by debris from fans as he walked to the locker room at halftime, responded by throwing a wad of gum into the stands. The incident received news coverage after a woman said she had been hit by the gum.

title: Cold City, They Say
description: LEAD: My husband died on Thanksgiving evening after a long illness, but the death was unexpected. My son and daughter-in-law had been unable to come to New York, so, for the first time in 29 years, we had Thanksgiving dinner alone.

title: BEAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $27,421 and $95,018 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $42 for the quarter and $5,618 for the 9 months.

title: Coast Guard Cutter Reaches Two Freighters That Collided
description: A Coast Guard cutter fighting bad weather today reached two freighters damaged in a collision and began evaluating whether the more seriously damaged vessel was safe to tow, officials said.

title: WESTERN MICROWAVE LABORITORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Koch Supports Air Rights Sale To a Developer
description: A New York development company, which Mayor Koch said Monday should have been disqualified from a major city project because of its ties to the Marcos family, is seeking - this time with the Mayor's support - to buy development rights from the city to build another midtown skyscraper.

title: Joseph Grossfield, Professor, 47
description: Joseph Grossfield, a professor of genetics at City College, died of lung cancer Saturday at the Cabrini Hospice in Manhattan. He was 47 years old.

title: Alan Mitosky Is Dead; Head of Video Concern
description: Alan Mitosky, president and chief operating officer of CEL Video Services of New York, died of lung cancer Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 53 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Once an Embattled Show 'Newshour' Gains Friends
description: For the first time since it became television's only national hourlong nightly newscast, public television's ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' is reasonably assured of its survival, at least for the immediate future.

title: Tokyo Stock Exchange Lets In 16 Foreign Firms
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange today granted 16 of 22 new memberships to foreign securities firms, fulfilling a promise made earlier this year to increase the number of foreign-owned seats before the end of 1987.

title: Ratings Take a Funny Bounce
description: FOR those in the television business, the end of college football's regular season has settled some questions and left others hanging. Naturally, not everybody is happy with the answers produced by the 1987 season.

title: Coffee Table Books for Giving, Admiring and Even Reading
description: AT this point in the Christmas gift marathon, forget the glass vase, the heated towel rack and the silver salver. With one-stop shopping, you can bestow on every one of your favorite households a book: an inherently ornamental object that might just possibly offer good reading, too.

title: Bowing to Foes, Thatcher Backs Health Fund
description: In a rare concession to political criticism, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher authorized a $180 million emergency appropriation today for the National Health Service.

title: INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26

title: Leaders of Cities to Press '88 Candidates on Needs

But can they do it? Joanne Grueskin, Bob Scott and David Paulsrud, three of the five members of the City Council of Sioux City, Iowa, intend to put the idea to the test.
