title: A WEDTECH FIGURE IS CLEARED BY JURY
description: The first defendant to be tried in New York in the investigations into the Wedtech Corporation was acquitted of bribery charges yesterday after jurors discounted the testimony of the prosecution's main witness, a former commander of the state militia who admitted taking payoffs.

title: Superbabies Aren't Happy Babies: One Crusade
description: THEY are buying baby exercise gyms hawked by a growing crowd of merchandisers. They are drilling their infants in math and reading skills, using flashcards, books and videotapes. They are enrolling their 3-year-olds in tennis lessons and entering their 4-year-olds in beauty contests and athletic competitions. Now they are even trying to educate their children in the womb with phonelike learning devices.

title: West Virginia Meets Payroll But Has Only $3 Million Left
description: West Virginia met its payroll today but was left with just $3.87 million in the bank afterward, state finance officials said.

title: Righetti Fielding Offers
description: The Yankees, burned this week in their attempt to sign a free agent outfielder, turned their attention yesterday to Dave Righetti. But the team's hope of reaching an agreement with the pitcher is still uncertain, despite a pronouncement by Lou Piniella, the general manager, that a deal was very close.

title: Film: 'The Dead,' by Huston
description: ''ONE by one we're all becoming shades,'' says Gabriel Conroy, looking out into Dublin's bleak winter dawn. Gretta, the wife he loves and suddenly realizes he has never known, lies asleep on the bed nearby. His own life now seems paltry: ''Better pass boldly into that other world, in the full glory of some passion, than fade and wither dismally with age.''

title: MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY: FINETUNING PACEMAKERS TO MATCH BODY'S NEEDS
description: When the first artificial pacemakers for the human heart were developed about 30 years ago, the sole objective was to save the patient from unpredictable sudden death. Today's devices, smaller, longer-lasting and, in some cases, able to alter the rate of heartbeat to match the body's needs, help restore the quality of life as well.

description: PALERMO, Sicily, Dec. 16 -

title: WHY THE COLUMBUS CIRCLE PLAN IS SHAKY
description: The Columbus Circle project, the ambitious development Mayor Koch announced with such great panoply more than two years ago, has been so complicated by controversy, missteps, an unpredictably troubled economy and mishandling that its immediate future, and perhaps its ultimate success, is shaky.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about plans to tear down part of the Walden School in Manhattan and replace it with apartments misstated the amount that the developer, Sutton East Associates, will pay for the property. It will give the Walden School a total of $10 million, not $16 million, in cash and other benefits.

description: Riding in a van as sleet pelted the windows, Alexander M. Haig Jr. said with a laugh that he had decided, at long last, ''to have a ball, have some fun, talk in an uninhibited way.''

description: Whist was popular in Western Europe in the 18th century, and it takes only a small effort of anachronistic imagination to assume that the game was bridge.

description: ''THE people who call me aren't those that want just a flat wrap,'' said Joanna-Faith Whitney, whose company, Wrappe, specializes in gift wrapping. ''They want an artistic statement: the thought on top of the package, as well as inside.''

description: Ask Kathryne Andrews how many shopping days are left until Christmas, and she may well ask, ''What year?''

description: The Pentagon conducted an experiment this week demonstrating for the first time that lasers and other high-powered electrical devices can be operated in space without heavy insulation to prevent short circuits, officials said Tuesday.

title: Flyers Gaining on Islanders
description: There is a curious relationship between the Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers - each seems to covet what belongs to the other.

title: Sports People; Tar Heels Pick Brown
description: After having led Tulane from a 1-10 record in 1985 to 6-5 this season, Mack Brown was not entirely surprised when he was selected yesterday by North Carolina to be its new football coach. Brown has one game left at Tulane, Saturday night against Washington in the Independence Bowl, before starting his new duties the next day. At the age of 36, Brown has a career record of 17-27 as a head coach, including a 6-5 season at Appalachian State in 1983. After breaking the news to his Tulane players, Brown said: ''Most of them came by and hugged my neck and said, 'Congratulations, coach.' The big emotion is - a program that's come this far together in three years - to leave it.''

title: Edberg Doubtful For Davis Cup
description: Stefan Edberg, who sprained his right foot on a slippery indoor clay court Monday, returned to practice today, but his status for the Davis Cup final against India remained in doubt. The competition begins Friday.

title: WANTED: SOVIET MISSILE PHOTO
description: The new missile treaty may have been signed, but one important piece of business is still outstanding: The Soviet Union has yet to provide the United States with a good photograph of its SS-20 missile.

title: Economists' World View
description: The dollar should fall some more, the United States should cut its budget deficit to zero by 1992, and West Germany and Japan should let their deficits grow, an international spectrum of economists said today.

title: Textile Import Rise Cited
description: The United States textile industry, a leading supporter of tough trade legislation, said today that 1987 would mark the seventh consecutive year of record textile and apparel imports. The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, a trade organization, said in its year-end report that foreign shipments would raise the textile and apparel trade deficit by 20 percent, to $25.4 billion, by the end of December.

title: STUDY SEES STRAIN ON HOMELESS AID
description: The number of people seeking shelter and food assistance in major cities has grown steadily in the last year, straining resources so severely that many city shelters are now turning away an average 25 percent of those seeking help.

description: Credit is almost everything in agriculture, and no institution has lent more to farmers than the Farm Credit System.

description: The Senate approved and sent legislation to President Reagan today that temporarily prohibits the Government from denying visas to foreigners because of their political beliefs.

description: Efforts by the Koch and Cuomo administrations to provide affordable housing were sharply criticized yesterday by two state legislators, including the chairman of the Assembly Housing Committee.

He won there in 1984 and went on to numerous bigger-state primary triumphs. That made him, far and away, the best known of the Democrats who started the Presidential race this year. The well-publicized scandal that drove him to ''suspend'' his campaign seven months ago only made his name and face the more recognizable.

title: Advertising; Departure at Doremus
description: G. Barry McMennamin is retiring after 42 years at Doremus & Company, where he has been vice chairman since 1984, and served as president from 1973 to 1984. Mr. McMennamin, 65 years old, has another job lined up. He will be publisher of Worldpaper, a Boston-based monthly publication with a circulation of 650,000 in 22 countries. Crocker Snow Jr. is president and editor in chief. Martin Stone is chairman.

title: Guarding a Sick Prisoner: $250,000 Overtime a Year
description: The costs of guarding a small but growing number of sick jail inmates at New York City hospitals are soaring as the inmates are being assigned constant, individual guards on overtime rates amounting to $250,000 a year per prisoner, city officials acknowledge.

title: Where is the Wetlands Board?
description: New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation has designated as ''wetlands'' up to 2,000 acres of Staten Island, thereby severely limiting the way owners may use such acreage. Dismayed at the extent of opposition to the department's designation methods, the Legislature has established a Freshwater Wetlands Appeals Board. It offers any landowner whose property was not designated as wetland on the department's original map a chance to challenge subsequent inclusion.

description: Ariel Sharon, the Cabinet Minister who was the architect of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, has taken a small apartment in the heart of the cramped Moslem Quarter in Jerusalem's Old City.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: There's no place like home for the holidays, For no matter how far away you roam, If you want to be happy in a million ways, For the holidays you can't beat home sweet home.

title: Deaver Found Guilty of Lying 3 Times Under Oath
description: A Federal jury today found Michael K. Deaver, a longtime friend of President and Mrs. Reagan and a former senior member of their staff, guilty on three charges of lying under oath about using his influence with the White House as a highly paid lobbyist.

title: The Deaver Defense: A Lawyer's Risky Tactic
description: The decision by Michael K. Deaver's defense lawyer, Herbert J. Miller, not to call any witnesses in his client's behalf was a risky one, and it apparently backfired, defense lawyers said yesterday.

title: Dennis A. Volman, Reporter, 37
description: Dennis A. Volman, a reporter for The Christian Science Monitor, died of cancer Monday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 37 years old and lived in Washington.

title: KEY RATES
Vote Yes on Shelters
description: New York City's Board of Estimate will vote today on four homeless shelter proposals already approved by the Planning Commission. Neighborhood opponents of the shelters argue that they fall short of perfection. Such opposition makes the best the enemy of the better. The proposals deserve support.

title: Drawings (Pg. D4); A NEW URGENCY FOR REFORMS IN POLICING SECURITIES TRADES
description: The Federal regulators who supervise the nation's securities markets may be breathing a sigh of relief after avoiding a disastrous trading shutdown in October. But they should not take too much comfort.

description: Charles George Muller, a novelist and naval historian, died Monday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 90 years old.

description: Porsche A.G. announced yesterday that Peter W. Schutz, the American who has directed the company since 1981, would be replaced as of Jan. 1 by Heinz Branitzki, the finance director.

title: Peanut Quota Increases
description: The national poundage quota for the 1988 peanut crop will be 1,402,200 tons, an increase of 46,700 tons from this year's level, Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng announced Tuesday. By law, the annual quota is set at a level equal to the estimated quantity of peanuts that will be needed for edible uses, seed and related purposes in the coming year.

title: Congressmen Delete Martha Graham Grant
description: A joint Congressional panel voted today to delete a grant of more than $4 million for the Martha Graham Dance Company.

description: When New York's subways are good they are very, very good, but when they are bad they are horrid. And according to the latest survey of conditions underground released yesterday by the Straphangers Campaign, they are bad most of the time.

William Fifield Dead; Prize-Winning Author
description: William Fifield, a writer of both fiction and nonfiction, died Monday at his home in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. He was 71 years old. Mr. Fifield, who won an O. Henry short-story prize in 1942, was the author of ''In Search of Genius,'' a collection of interviews with people he considered geniuses, including Picasso, Cocteau, Miro, Dali and Robert Graves. He also wrote a biography of Modigliani and collaborated on ''Alexis Lichine's Encyclopedia of Wines and Spirits,'' which appeared in 1965.

title: Sports People; Francis Is Waived
description: Russ Francis, the 34-year-old tight end, was waived from the San Francisco 49ers' injured-reserve list yesterday. Francis, who had 41 receptions for 505 yards for the 49ers in 1986, had 22 receptions for 202 yards this season before being placed on injured reserve with a back problem Dec. 4.

title: Currents; Living Over the Store: New Home for a Florist
description: IN mid-October, Renny Reynolds, a party designer and florist, closed his two East Side shops and moved to an 1890's four-story town house on East 64th Street that had been the home and offices of the late Donald Bruce White, a caterer. By the end of November, Mr. Reynolds was settled in.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Nick Thometz, the speed skater who spent two days in a hospital last week to be treated for a rare blood disorder, is practicing again but his status for the final three days of the United States Olympic trials are uncertain. . . . Patrick Allen, cornerback for the Houston Oilers, said he has been fined $5,000 by the National Football League for hitting Dean Biasucci, the Indianapolis Colts' place-kicker, with a forearm to the neck in a game three weeks ago. After Indianapolis scored its final touchdown, making the score 50-27 with six seconds left, Allen charged and struck the Colts' kicker following the extra point. The Oilers accused the Colts of trying to run up the score. ''I will appeal it,'' Allen said of the fine. ''It was wrong but five grand is tough.''

title: J. P. Strom, Law-Enforcement Chief, 69
description: J. P. Strom, who headed the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division for more than 30 years, died of a heart attack Monday at Providence Hospital here. He was 69 years old.

description: Voters here have defeated a proposal to have the city buy a vacant college campus to prevent it from being converted into a minimum-security Federal prison.

title: Brazil Moves to Ban Whaling
description: The Senate today enacted a law to ban whale hunting in Brazil's 200-mile territorial waters. The measure now needs only President Jose Sarney's signature to become law. Violators face fines, the confiscation of their vessels and prison terms of two to five years.

title: N.B.A. Notebook; Success of Pistons Is a Team Effort
description: Last Oct. 27 at Madison Square Garden, minutes before his Pistons were to play the Phoenix Suns in the first game of an exhibition doubleheader, Chuck Daly, the Detroit coach, was distressed. Several prognosticators had already chosen the Pistons to dethrone the Boston Celtics and win the Eastern Conference championship, but Daly wasn't sure.

title: Needed for Schools: Muscle
description: Mayor Koch offers to take responsibility for the New York City school system with a restructured Board of Education. Governor Cuomo recently convened a summit meeting, bringing together the Mayor, leading educators, legislators, borough presidents and business representatives to seek consensus on school reform.

title: Jobs Growth Centers on Manhattan
description: Three years of robust job growth in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx ended abruptly last year, leaving the economic health of New York City tied almost entirely to business conditions in Manhattan, according to a Federal Government report released yesterday.

title: Sports People; Helmet for Marsh, Too
description: Brad Marsh, a defenseman for the Philadelphia Flyers who is one of the few National Hockey League players not required to wear a helmet since the headgear became compulsory for new players in 1979, will have no choice the next time he takes the ice for a game. ''This is not a temporary thing,'' Marsh said of the helmet he wore during practice Tuesday. Marsh, 29 years old, received a concussion and scalp wounds from a collision last week against the Boston Bruins, and he has been advised to wear the helmet when he resumes play, which might be tonight against the Islanders in Philadelphia.

title: A Rosary and a Ballot, Then Prayers at a Stronghold of the Opposition
description: When the voting ended, Lee Keum Shil drew near the sealed ballot box and took out her rosary. Silently, the 32-year-old housewife prayed as election monitors circled the cold, stark warehouse that served as a polling station on Wednesday night.

title: Stage: 'From the Moon'
description: JACK CHANDLER'S solid set for ''Words From the Moon,'' which opened last night at the South Street Theater, takes us past a scruffy backyard into a kitchen that shows signs not only of having been lived in but of having been knocked around in. The inhabitants of this upscale God's Little Acre in Haw River, N.C., are as askew as the porch and roof on which they like to sit. Philip is concentrating on saving the air and the water, leaving to his wife, Connie, the job of earning their bread by working at a 7-Eleven and selling congo bars. She has retaliated with coolness in bed.

title: Hart Never Quelled Talk of Philandering
description: From the day he announced his candidacy last April 13 in the foothills of the Colorado Rockies, Gary Hart's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination was shadowed by rumors of philandering.

title: A House Becomes a Workable Home For a Disabled Officer and His Family
description: IT feels at first like so many homes: the whir of the vacuum cleaner, the potted poinsettias, the magnet on the refrigerator that spells out, ''Bless this home and all who live here.'' But this home, like its new occupants, is both ordinary and extraordinary.

title: Trading Fair With Brazil
description: Impatient with Brazil's fierce protectionism on computers and software, President Reagan last month ordered retaliation. His response is not without risks, given Brazil's fragile politics and $100 billion foreign debt. But thus far the response seems to have paid off: Brazil's more pragmatic leaders are forced to consider that the country is unlikely to realize its incredible economic potential unless it plays by the rules of fair trade.

title: Extra Effort in '86 Could Hurt Giants
description: A year ago, the Giants routed the Green Bay Packers, 55-24, and the Packers seemed to accept that. Late in the game, the Giants also embarrassed the Packers, and they did not accept that.

title: Feed Ethiopia, and Stop Its Wars
description: Once again at Christmastime, the well fed guiltily confront pervasive images of starving Ethiopians. But the world knows a good deal more about Ethiopia than it did when famine struck three years ago. Drought is only one culprit; unending war is the other.

title: Chrysler Incentive
description: The Chrysler Corporation added several car and truck models to the buyer-incentive programs that it began in mid-November. New 1987 Dodge Dakota pickups, except for the S-series, and Ramcharger pickups carry $770 rebates as well as 7.7 percent annual financing for four-year loans. Either the rebate or the low-rate financing may be applied to the purchase of 1988 models of the Chrysler Fifth Avenue and E-Body New Yorker Turbo cars, the Dodge Daytona car and Dakota Ramcharger pickup, except for the S-series.

title: Poll Shows Hart and Jackson Leading
description: Gary Hart has joined the Rev. Jesse Jackson at the front of the Democratic Presidential field in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. But Tuesday's survey also found that Mr. Hart has lost more than a third of his support since he withdrew from the contest last May and is rated unfavorably by a substantial minority of Democrats.

title: Safety Fears Raised By Seepage at a Site For Nuclear Waste
description: The nation's first permanent underground nuclear waste repository has developed water leaks that some scientists contend will make it useless. The facility is designed to demonstrate how to store millions of cubic feet of radioactive material that will be dangerous for thousands of years.

title: In Mexico, Spratling Means Silver
description: FROM a cobblestone street high above this town in the mountains of south-central Mexico, Antonio Castillo, a master craftsman in a silverworking center, surveyed with satisfaction the bustling shops below. Convoys of buses were disgorging tourists in search of the high-quality metalware that is synonymous with Taxco.

title: Rangers Trounce Devils With 5 Goals in 2d Period

description: Is America ready to elect a confessed adulterer as President? No. Although the twists and turns of politics have become more difficult to predict, it is clear this year that the press has helped the New Right win at least one victory, in the sense that social issues are now paramount in the selection of our leaders. There will be no Supreme Court Justices who have smoked marijuana and no Presidents who have had affairs. Not in 1988, anyway.

title: Nicaraguan Defector's Tale: How to Stop a U.S. Invasion
description: From a military standpoint, one of the more bizarre revelations by a Nicaraguan defector in Washington last week was his description of the Sandinista plan to cope with a United States invasion of Nicaragua. The defector, Maj. Roger Miranda Bengoechea, told American journalists that if the United States invaded Nicaragua, the Sandinista Government would try to ''regionalize the conflict.''

title: Operetta: 'Babes in Toyland'
description: THE Light Opera of Manhattan is a little bit like a peanut butter and jelly sandwich: nothing unusual or refined, but nothing pretentious either, and you know what you're getting. And sometimes a peanut butter and jelly sandwich is just what you want.

title: Suit Seeks to Halt Research As AIDS and Cancer Threat
description: A critic of Federal biotechnology programs filed a suit Tuesday to halt laboratory research that he argued could lead to the spread of AIDS and cancer.

description: A group of senior Democrats has been meeting periodically this fall to discuss the party's Presidential field. Many have expressed dismay at the available talent and have been hoping to attract a more visible candidate into the race.

title: B.P. Cancels Britoil Offer
description: The British Petroleum Company said today that it had canceled its bid for 15 percent of Britoil P.L.C. after the offer expired in the morning. B.P. had previously said that once its offer of 300 pence, or about $5.40, a share expired, it would either make a higher bid for Britoil or buy more shares on the open market. B.P. already owns 14.9 percent of Britoil and had said it would raise its stake to 29.9 percent.

title: Delaware Fugitive Captured
description: A fugitive twice convicted of murder was captured today, one day after he escaped from the Delaware Correctional Center in a prison truck, the authorities said. The 42-year-old fugitive, John Edward Garrett Jr., was arrested without incident while walking along U.S. 40 near Elkton, Md., officials said.Mr. Garrett was first jailed for the 1966 beating death of his mother in West Chester, Pa. He was paroled in 1971. A year later, he was arrested in Wilmington and convicted in 1973 in the death of a prostitute.

title: 2 Divided Camps of Bishops Form Over Catholic AIDS Policy Paper
description: In statements issued by Roman Catholic chanceries from Boston to Los Angeles in recent days, bishops have been lining up on either side of the controversy over a policy paper on AIDS released last week by the administrative board of the United States Catholic Conference.

title: Soviet Links Iran Embargo to U.N. Force

title: Concert: Emerson Quartet
description: IN Charles Ives's first string quartet, vernacular American elements (hymn tunes, mostly) are genially integrated with the Germanic procedures that the young composer was learning at Yale, rather than set in rugged opposition to them. It's an assured and likable piece, a little collegiate in its freshness but already subtle in the blending of popular and composed elements.

title: Septima Clark, 89, Active in Civil Rights In South Since 1918
description: Septima Poinsette Clark, a teacher who had been active in civil rights activities since World War I, died Tuesday at a nursing home on John's Island. She was 89 years old. Born in Charleston, the daughter of a former slave, Mrs. Clark was widely recognized for her work in civil rights. In 1964 she accompanied the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to Norway when he was presented the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is offering $168 million in tax-exempt bonds with yields as high as 8.53 percent for bonds due in 2017 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: U.S. Team to Leave Thursday To Inspect Old Soviet Radars
description: A team of eight American officials will leave on Thursday to inspect several old radars that the Reagan Administration has charged are a technical violation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, the State Department announced today.

title: Boesky Plea on Sentencing
description: Ivan F. Boesky's lawyer has asked the Federal judge who will sentence Mr. Boeksy tomorrow for a short prison sentence and at least 3,000 hours of required community service at a charity that distributes free food in Newark.

title: Currents; Miniature Houses For Birds and Beasts
description: A CHARMING exhibition of 50 new and antique miniature dwellings - ''Inch-to-the-Foot: Small House Perspectives'' - is now at the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. One structure is a ''possum hut - a southern New Jersey slang term for a simple rustic cabin,'' said its designer, Helga Tacreiter of Shiloh, N.J.

title: Stage: 'Trinity,' Three One-Acts

But once you have achieved it, he adds, ''the nice thing about failure is that people leave you to hell alone.'' Not in a play by Mr. White, they won't. All one of his characters has to do to set himself up for trouble is get a little overconfident.

title: Theatrical Community Unites to Fight AIDS
description: The New York theatrical community, including actors, unions, dramatists, theater owners, producers and press agents, announced the formation yesterday of an organization to coordinate information and help victims of AIDS.

title: Advertising; Scali, McCabe Deal
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, a subsidiary of the Ogilvy Group, is joining the agencies eagerly acquiring sales promotion shops. It plans to buy Morton Goldberg Associates, a New York operation with more than $5 million in billings. Goldberg will continue to operate under its own name, management and roof.

description: THE weakness of the United States dollar against major world currencies has played havoc lately with the stock market. But this same dollar instability has helped to turn mutual funds that invest mainly in bonds of foreign governments into star performers this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Manila yesterday about a Southeast Asian summit conference misstated the relative size of the Indonesian military. It is the largest among the members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations; Vietnam's military is the largest in Southeast Asia.

title: Bitter U.N. Election Campaign Opens at W.H.O.

title: TV Reviews; Update on 'Three Kings'
description: I CAN see it now. Sitting around the story-conference table one day were the executive producers Aaron Spelling, Douglas S. Cramer and Esther Shapiro, taking a moment from their struggles to get a bit more mileage out of ''Dynasty.'' This year, like every other year, would have a Christmas season. What about trying to put together a ''classic,'' the kind of television show that is hauled out every season and is as good as money in the bank? And lo, a television movie was born, a contemporary version of the story of the three wise men who followed their star to a manger in Jerusalem. ''The Three Kings'' can be seen on ABC at 9 this evening.

description: A building under construction in downtown Marrakesh collapsed today, killing 20 people and injuring eight others, the Moroccan news agency reported. The agency said 17 people were believed trapped in the rubble. Rescue workers dug through the rubble tonight, attempting to reach an estimated 17 people buried under the debris. Investigators were at the site to determine what caused the collapse of the five-story structure, which was to have included 16 apartments and eight stores.

Dr. Otto Gago, who performed this bypass operation and a previous bypass on Schembechler, said Schembechler could probably resume coaching in two to three months.

title: Q&A
description: Q.In winter, condensation forms and a mildew smell develops in our attic. We also get a lot of moisture in the bathroom, and algae on the walls. Do we need vents in the attic? A fan in the bathroom? A.It sounds as though you need both. The vents should be at opposite ends of the attic, to insure cross ventilation. If possible, there should also be vents in the eaves, to allow air to flow in at the bottom of the attic and travel up above the insulation. The vents must be large enough to provide at least one square foot of free opening for every 300 square feet of attic floor. Q.I am redoing a house that has a concrete-slab floor covered with carpet. I have taken up the carpet and plan to put a new one down, but in sweeping the old surface I find that dust keeps coming up. I am afraid the dust will come up through the new carpet. Is there anything I can do to stop this ''shedding''? A.You can apply a clear concrete sealer, using either a mop or a roller. Safe and easy to apply, sealers are sold in most paint stores, as well as in many masonry supply houses. Q.We have a tiled shower stall on our first floor. The tiles, as well as the grout, seem to be in good shape. However, the exposed wood beams in the basement directly under the shower are wet. A plumber said that the lead pan under the tiles in the shower has developed a leak, and that the only way to repair it is to rip out the entire shower. Is there any other way to fix this, like applying a clear sealer or installing a plastic pan on top of the tile? A.I'm afraid not. The tile floor of the shower must be torn up to get at the pan so it can be replaced. But you do not have to rip out the whole shower; only the floor. Q.We have a brick patio that has some dark areas, and others with algae. We want to clean this, but do not want to use anything that will harm the plants around the patio. What do you recommend? A.The most effective cleaner for this is trisodium phosphate (TSP), which is sold under various brand names (Soilax and Savogran TSP are two). If TSP is forbidden in your area, then use a strong powdered detergent. Scrub a section at a time, then rinse it off before it can dry. If you are careful, little of the cleaner will get on the plants, except for what is washed off. If you use plenty of water, this should cause no harm. For the algae, buy an algaecide at a swimming pool supply outlet and follow the directions on the package. Q.I think the linoleum flooring in one of my rooms has a terrazzo brick floor beneath it, which I want to expose. How can I remove the present floor covering? A.I don't know what you mean by ''terrazzo brick.'' Terrazzo is a seamless concrete floor with colorful chips of stone or marble embedded in it. It is polished by machine to a smooth high gloss. Brick is not smooth or glossy, and it has many mortar joints.

description: WHILE the sight of rampant insanity is horrifyingly sad, witnessing delusional torment can also provoke a ghastly kind of laughter.
