title: Dining Out Guide: For Wine Lovers
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. OYSTER BAR AND RESTAURANT, Grand Central Terminal, lower level, 42d Street and Vanderbilt Avenue (490-6650) - **(Sept. 13, 1985) The grandeur of the sprawling main dining room with its tile walls and vaulted ceiling is reminiscent of the heyday of rail travel. The restaurant's wine list is renowned for its selection of California whites, more than 100, at reasonable prices. (Fewer than half a dozen token reds are available.) Oyster fans should begin with a sampling from the dozen exquisitely fresh varieties posted, or you might start with the milky and chunky New England clam chowder. The pan-roasted shellfish are terrific, whether oysters, sea scallops, shrimp, lobster, clams, mussels or the works; bouillabaisse, a house specialty, is a standout. The long list of mostly broiled fish fillets changes daily, according to availability, and they are consistently pleasing. Entrees $12.85 to $25.95. Fridays, 11:30 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. (last seating); closed Saturdays and Sundays. RIVER CAFE, 1 Water Street, Brooklyn (718-522-5200) - ***(July 25, 1986) With its stunning views of Manhattan and the East River, this restaurant offers a romantic atmosphere for even the most jaded, and it has some of the most provocative food in the city. The River Cafe also has one of the better wine lists in town, particularly strong in American selections. Starter options are smoked salmon, grilled vegetable lasagna with basil oil, and chilled duck foie gras with dressed lentils and endive puree. Entrees include soy-and-honey marinated squab with potato pancakes, sauteed veal chop with Chinese mustard, and grilled yellowfin tuna with mushroom salad. Dinner prix fixe $48. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 7 P.M. to midnight; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 3 P.M. and 7 P.M. to midnight. SOFI, 102 Fifth Avenue, near 15th Street (463-8888) - **(May 22, 1987) This graceful restaurant south of the Flatiron district occupies a soaring loft space that has been warmed with paintings, rugs and soft lighting. The menu is cross-cultural, as many as 20 wines are offered by the glass, and the list of remarkably inexpensive bottles is imaginatively assembled to match the food. Appetizers include a cassoulet terrine; buffalo mozzarella with roasted marinated tomatoes, and endive, beet and mache salad with walnut oil vinaigrette. For a main dish, options are sauteed red snapper fillet with artichokes and roasted tomato puree; roasted breast of Muscovy duck with tapenade and endive confit, and lobster served out of the shell with a lobster sauce. Dinner entrees $16 to $28. Fridays, noon to 2:30 P.M. and 6 P.M. to 11 P.M.; Saturdays, 6 to 11 P.M.; closed Sundays. ''21'' CLUB, 21 West 52d Street (582-7200) - **(June 19, 1987) The patrician town house is more beguiling than ever, and the food is vastly improved since the refurbishing. The renowned wine list has ample selections in the $20-to-$30 range. The upstairs dining room is warm and welcoming, and appetizer choices include sauteed foie gras with deep-fried cellophane noodles in veal stock sauce, gratin of salt cod under Parmesan crust, and butterflied pan-fried shrimp in herb butter. Recommended main dish options are Kentucky bourbon steak with four kinds of peppers; grilled turbot with red pepper and saffron sauces; Black Angus steak in hot mustard crust. Dinner entrees $24 to $39. Dining room: Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 2 P.M. and 5:30 to 9:30 P.M. Barroom: Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight. Closed Sundays. UNION SQUARE CAFE, 21 East 16th Street (243-4020) - **(Jan. 24, 1986) A low-key restaurant with comfortable dining rooms, Union Square features many good wine selections in the lower price range, and it is one of the few restaurants in town to offer a number of good dessert wines by the glass. The menu straddles the border between France and Italy; starter options include seared sea scallops with fried angel hair pasta in creme fraiche and garlic sauce; duck breast with sliced winter pears. For a main dish you might choose bouillabaisse with saffron-aioli croutons; osso bucco with orange, honey cognac and orzo, or the seared rib eye with rosemary, spinach and fagioli. Entrees $15.50 to $21. Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 3 P.M. and 6 P.M. to midnight; closed Sundays. WINDOWS ON THE WORLD, 1 World Trade Center, 107th floor (938-1111) - *(July 4, 1986) Perched a quarter mile up atop the World Trade Center is the highest and grandest dining room of them all - glass enclosed with a wraparound view of the city and harbor. The wine list at Windows is justly famous, not only for its wide selection of French and American labels but also for its reasonable prices. You might begin with salmon and snapper, lightly grilled with orange and chive sauce; pate of wild boar with morels, and oysters and clams on the half shell with two sauces and freshly grated horseradish. Main dishes are baby pheasant marinated in wild thyme with autumn succotash; medallions of veal tenderloin with morel sauce; corn pancakes; sauteed large shrimp with fennel and leek custard, and rack of young lamb. Dinner prix fixe $29.95 to $33.95. Fridays and Saturdays, 5 to 10 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 7:30 P.M. What the stars mean, page C32.

title: Art: Sculptures by Nancy Graves at the Brooklyn Museum
description: AT the entrance to ''Nancy Graves: A Sculpture Retrospective'' is the 1969 ''Mongolian Bactrian (To Harvey Brennan),'' a main character in the shaggy camel story that helped establish Ms. Graves's reputation. A camel is an eccentric animal, and this is an eccentric work. It looks like an actual camel, but it was assembled, constructed and pieced together. A real camel's weight is so unevenly distributed that the body seems to be moving even when it is standing still. One of the characteristics of Ms. Graves's sculpture is quirky, shifting movement.

title: Japan Outlook For Economy
description: Government officials today painted a rosy economic picture for the Japanese economy next year, forecasting rapid growth and a falling trade surplus. The officials, who declined to be identified, said domestic demand, not exports, would be the driving economic force in 1988.

title: CONGRATULATIONS ARE GIVEN BY U.S. TO KOREA WINNER
description: The United States today officially congratulated Roh Tae Woo, the declared victor in the South Korean presidential elections, despite opposition complaints of widespread electoral fraud.

title: At the Movies
description: Jed Harris: the Movie Frederic Raphael, who won an Academy Award for the screenplay for ''Darling'' and dissected marriage to a fare-thee-well in ''Two for the Road,'' is turning his attention to the legendary Broadway producer Jed Harris.

title: G.M. Issuing a Recall of 203,000 Vehicles
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would recall 203,000 automobiles and light trucks to correct possible safety defects. The company said it knew of no accidents related to the defects.

title: State Urged to Be New York Schools' Builder
description: A special state panel proposed yesterday that construction of new schools in New York City be taken away from the Board of Education and placed in the hands of a new agency that could do it faster.

title: Article 358287 -- No Title
description: A judge today reversed his decision to deny bail for Raymond Buckey, who faces trial on 79 counts of molesting children at the McMartin nursery school in Manhattan Beach.

title: House Ethics Committee's Counsel Recommends the Ouster of Biaggi
description: The counsel to the House Ethics Committee recommended today that Represenative Mario Biaggi be expelled from Congress, while Mr. Biaggi's lawyers recommended a reprimand, according to the committee's chairman.

title: Christmas Music
description: Grande Bande, an original-instrument ensemble, is to present a program of 17th-century Christmas music tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $14 and $17.50. Information: (212) 874-6770.

title: Conferees Press for Spending Pact, But Snags May Lie Along the Way
description: A House-Senate conference committee, making decisions affecting Japanese trade, aid to Pakistan and military planning, today moved toward approval of a $600 billion catch-all appropriation bill needed to put this year's budget agreement into effect.

title: Inquiry in Death In City Custody Faces Problems
description: Prosecutors investigating the death in city custody of a 28-year-old Bronx woman are faced with conflicting reports from witnesses about her struggles with the police and with problems in determining the origin of a fatal blood clot in her leg.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., elected as a director Anne Wexler, chairman of Wexler, Reynolds, Harrison & Schule Inc. of Washington, consultants in government relations and public affairs.

title: Can't Wait for That Looser, Longer Look
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Plays Grinch for Media Crowd
description: Governor Cuomo read ''A Visit From St. Nicholas'' (''Twas the Night Before Christmas'') to 125 media-mobbed children yesterday, but when the press turned its attention to the Governor, there arose such a clatter that he gave, as a sort of encore, a fair impersonation of the Grinch.

title: DISARRAY OF OPEC IS CALLED BENEFIT TO U.S. CONSUMERS
description: American consumers will save billions of dollars next year and inflation will slow because of OPEC's inability to curb its members' crude oil production, oil industry analysts say.

title: Democrats Seem Wary of Hart's Insurgent Appeal
description: George Cunningham, a lawyer who is a South Dakota state chairman for Senator Paul Simon's Presidential campaign, got a pressing call today from the local campaign manager. It was about Gary Hart's lunchtime stop at Minerva's Restaurant here.

title: Democratic Chief Says Hart Put Own Goal Over Party's
description: The national Democratic chairman said today that Gary Hart had placed personal goals above the good of his party by re-entering the Presidential race this week.

title: Art: Egyptian Antiquities
description: THE title of the exhibition ''Antiquities From the Collection of Christos G. Bastis'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is displayed in letters at least a foot tall painted high on the wall in the first of the show's two galleries. These letters threaten to dwarf the objects on view, most of which range from small to tiny, and create the momentary impression that the show's contents are being hyped. Fortunately this impression is quickly dissipated by the objects themselves, drawn from a collection that has been assembled over 40 years by a man who came to the United States from his native Greece in 1922 at the age of 18.

title: Like Son, Like Father
description: Keith Asmussen, the block of the young chip, won his first race ever in New York yesterday, something his son, Cash, used to do regularly. Cash Asmussen was New York's leading rider in 1979, then began riding in Europe in 1980 and has since become the only non-French jockey to win the French riding title, doing so in 1985 and 1986.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of Alan Mitosky yesterday listed his survivors incompletely.

title: Budget Disputes Said to Delay U.N. Windup
description: A dispute over plans to build a $70 million conference center in Ethiopia is delaying the windup of the 42d United Nations General Assembly, delegates say.

title:
Market Place;
Container Field's Thriving Sector
description: LEAD: FLEXIBLE packaging for the food business has emerged as one of the fastest-growing sectors of the container industry, with some niches growing at more than 15 percent a year, compared with the 2 to 3 percent growth in conventional packaging.

title: Oslo Reviews Oil Restraints
description: With its economy threatened by tumbling prices for its North Sea oil, Norway could drop efforts to help OPEC stabilize the market if the organization is unable to maintain production discipline among its members.

title: Niekro Declines Offer
description: Phil Niekro, winner of 318 major-league games, has turned down offers to work in the Atlanta Braves minor-league system and will apparently enter private business. Niekro spent 25 years in the Braves' organization and ended his pitching career with a farewell appearance in the last home game of the 1987 season. He was offered the manager's job at the Brave's new Class A affiliate in Burlington, Iowa, or as pitching coach at Class AA Greenville, S.C., or as a roving pitching instructor throughout the organization.

title: Apple Optimistic
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it expected record revenues and earnings for its first fiscal quarter, which ends Jan. 1. Analysts have estimated the earnings at between 65 and 85 cents a share, with revenues between $925 million and $980 million. In the comparable period last year, Apple earned 45.5 cents a share, after an adjustment for a 2-for-1 split, on revenues of $662.3 million. ''Sales in both our product families are exceeding our expectations due to strong demand in all of our markets,'' said John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive.

title: Film: 'September,' From Allen
description: ''SEPTEMBER'' is Woody Allen's riskiest film yet. It's a small, tightly disciplined drama about love, friendship and family, set entirely within a Vermont summer house at the end of the season. People come and go to destinations elsewhere, but the movie remains inside the cottage, like a possibly hypochondriacal, invalid ghost.

title: Karpov's Rook Smashes Blunder by Kasparov
description: Whether it was seductive wild hope or just a miscalculation, Gary Kasparov blundered yesterday with an incorrect combination and was smartly smashed by Anatoly Karpov in the adjournment session of their 23d world chess championship game in Seville, Spain.

title: Lost Collection
description: A lifelong collection of basketball memorabilia was lost Wednesday when the four-bedroom house in Columbia, S.C., built 23 years ago for Frank McGuire, a Hall of Fame basketball coach, burned to the ground. McGuire and his wife, Jane, barely escaped serious injury from a blaze that fire officials said probably had been caused by a gas leak ignited by a spark after Mrs. McGuire plugged in the lights to a Christmas tree.

title: Dokes Knocks Out Porter in 5
description: Michael Dokes, the former World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, knocked out K. P. Porter last night 25 seconds into the fifth round of a bout scheduled for 10 rounds at the Felt Forum.

title: Film: Cronyn in 'Batteries'
description: ''NO, they're not toys. You can't buy these things at Macy's!'' cries one of the characters in ''Batteries Not Included,'' describing the dinner-plate-size flying saucers that are the film's real stars. But even if the merchandise isn't readily at hand, toys are very much on the minds of all concerned, since everything in the film has been designed in toymaker's terms. That includes the human characters, who are adults only in the way an 8-year-old might imagine them. Children may enjoy this, but their adult escorts will have a harder time.

title: String Quartet
description: The Mendelssohn String Quartet, with Lucy Shelton, a soprano, is to perform works by Janacek, Ginastera and Ravel tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Merkin Concert Hall, at 129 West 67th Street. Tickets are $10. Information: 362-8719.

title: Korean Opposition, Declaring Extensive Fraud, Pledges to Keep Fighting
description: Stunned by their decisive defeat in the presidential election, rival opposition leaders declared Thursday that the results were void because of what they called widespread fraud, and pledged to step up their anti-Government resistance.

title: Dizzy Gillespie
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie is leading a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 9 and 11:30 P.M. through Sunday, plus a 1:30 A.M. show tonight and tomorrow; there is a $15 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, or a $7.50 charge at the bar.

title: Mox Arthur Weber, Coach, 85
description: Mox Arthur Weber, retired chairman of the department of physical education at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., died Dec. 5 at the North Hill retirement home in Needham, Mass. He was 85 years old and lived in Needham.

title: Blunder Puts Chess Crown Into Jeopardy
description: After a flurry of quick and dramatic moves that left chess analysts confused, Gary Kasparov shook hands with his challenger today in a gesture of resignation that left his hold on the world chess championship hanging by a thread.

title: View on College Playoff
description: Dick Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday he expected a postseason playoff system to determine the national champion in Division I-A football to be rejected by a 2-1 ratio when members vote on the proposal next month.

title: Some Deft Help From Great Minds
description: Under interrogation in Senate hearings this week on his nomination to the Supreme Court, Judge Anthony M. Kennedy demonstrated a knack for coming up with apt quotations to underscore his philosophical points.

title: Brooklyn Judge Criticized in New Case
description: The judge accused by the Brooklyn District Attorney of humiliating a complainant in a sexual-misconduct trial has been accused by jurors in another case of demeaning witnesses, of falling asleep on the bench and of intimidating the defense and prosecuting attorneys.

title: Critics' Circle Awards
description: ''Broadcast News,'' James L. Brooks's romantic comedy about three ambitious young professionals working in television news, was voted the best film of 1987 by the New York Film Critics' Circle yesterday.

title: Restaurants Planned for Pier Overlooking Harbor
description: Pier A on the Battery, a century-old landmark that commands an uninterrupted, almost seaborne, vista of New York Harbor, would be turned into a high-priced restaurant - with a visitors' center and fast-food dining, too -under a new plan by the Koch administration.

title: Businessman Convicted in Pakistan Nuclear Plot
description: A Pakistani-born Canadian businessman was convicted today of conspiring to ship material to Pakistan that could be used to produce nuclear weapons.

title: Soviet U.N. Envoy Arrested For Espionage, Then Freed
description: A Soviet diplomat accredited to the United Nations was arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on suspicion of espionage, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said tonight.

title: Murdoch Rival Shows Interest in Bid for Post
description: Robert Maxwell, head of a multibillion dollar British communications empire and a chief rival to Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday in London that he was interested in ''seriously looking'' into acquiring Mr. Murdoch's New York Post.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 4 Haitians Press Namphy to Quit
description: In an attempt to pressure Lieut. Gen. Henry Namphy to step down, four leading presidential candidates have announced agreement on a coalition government that would replace him if he yields.

title: Road Fatalities Soared as Limit For Speed Rose
description: Traffic fatalities on rural interstate highways soared by more than 50 percent in states that increased their speed limit to 65 miles per hour last spring, according to Transportation Department figures.

title: Conferees, Upset by Trade Gap, Move to Limit Japanese Business
description: Reflecting yearlong trade disputes and tensions over the trade deficit with Japan, House and Senate conferees agreed today to ban Japanese companies from participation in public works construction of airports, veterans' hospitals and other projects in the United States.

title: Air Force Proposes Abandoning Anti-Satellite Weapon to Reduce Budget
description: To help cut the Pentagon budget, the Air Force has proposed ending work on a weapon system to destroy Soviet satellites in space, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Crude Oil Falls for 4th Day, With Key Price at $15.84
description: Crude oil prices fell for the fourth straight day in hectic, heavy trading yesterday, as market participants continued to react negatively to OPEC's apparent inability to curtail production.

title: AT THE BAR
description: In his heyday on Wall Street, Ivan Boesky was much admired for his uncanny sense of timing. That talent, as it turns out, was largely illusory. But in one sense, at least, the fallen arbitrageur's timing was indeed impeccable: if he had to commit crimes, he committed them at precisely the right moment.

title: L.I. Hospital in Inquiry Is Criticized for Controls
description: The New York State Department of Health cited Good Samaritan Hospital with deficiencies in eight major areas today, saying that the hospital's quality-assurance system was so badly flawed that hospital officials are not able to quickly detect if an employee deliberately harmed patients.

title: Chief of Latin Lender May Quit in Protest
description: The president of the Inter-American Development Bank, Antonio Ortiz Mena, said yesterday that he would quit rather than accept a Reagan Administration appointee as his No. 2, according to officials of the bank, a major lender to Latin America.

title: Panel Says Memo Calls Bush 'Solid' for Iran Arms Sale
description: The Congressional Iran-contra committees made public a newly discovered White House memo today that describes Vice President Bush as being ''solid'' in his support of the arms shipments to Iran as of February 1986.

title: Wary Waterbury Waits for 'Hanoi Jane' Fonda
description: It was on Veterans Day that Gaetano (Guy) Russo, a former assistant adjutant in the Connecticut National Guard, first learned that Jane Fonda was coming to town to make a movie. Outraged, he wrote a letter to the local newspaper. A few days later, he had 250 bumper stickers printed. They read, ''I'm Not Fond'a Hanoi Jane.''

title: Film: Bill Cosby's 'Leonard Part 6'
description: ''LEONARD PART 6'' has a James Bond, weapon-equipped car and soapsuds billowing down a stairwell in a scene Lucille Ball could romp through. Tom Courtenay is a gentleman's gentleman, in a role that owes a lot to Sir John Gielgud in ''Arthur,'' and Gloria Foster is a villain who owes something to Tina Turner in ''Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome.'' If this comic stew were all of ''Leonard Part 6,'' it would be a harmless, derivative holiday movie that children could giggle at and that would give anyone over the age of 10 a severe case of deja vu. Because this is a backdrop for Bill Cosby, fans may expect some comic extravagance from the television icon. But ''Leonard'' proves that even Bill Cosby makes mistakes.

title: Celluloid Stars
description: IT'S the season for warm sentiments and heavy artillery, the time when Hollywood traditionally rolls out its biggest guns. And it's especially true, in a moviegoing year that got off to an exceptionally poor start, that the best has been saved for last. But Christmas moviegoing can be as overwhelming as Christmas anything else, so choose carefully.

title: Investor Buys 7.3% of Showboat
description: Paul W. Lowden, the investor who controls the Sahara Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, Nev., has purchased 7.3 percent of Showboat Inc. and has said he might seek control of the casino company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Lowden said he planned to discuss the acquisition of Showboat's Las Vegas Casino Hotel and other properties with the company. Showboat also owns a casino in Atlantic City.

title: HUSAK STEPS DOWN AS PRAGUE LEADER
description: Gustav Husak, who dismantled a program of liberalization in Czechoslovakia two decades ago under the watchful eye of Soviet invasion forces, resigned today as head of the Czechoslovak Communist Party, the official press agency said.

title: Boesky Sentencing Today To Be Closely Watched
description: The sentencing of Ivan F. Boesky, scheduled for this morning, may be one of the most important events in white-collar law enforcement in years, according to several lawyers, law enforcement officials and regulators.

title: Jackson, Appealing to the Young, Presses Drive to Register New Voters
description: At a campaign rally Wednesday night in this heavily Hispanic town on the Gulf Coast, the Rev. Jesse Jackson personally persuaded 25 to 30 people to register to vote for the first time.

title: Topics of The Times; Roughing the Strikers
description: When National Football League players finally capitulated after a 24-day strike this fall, team owners couldn't resist rubbing salt into their wounds. Now, if a preliminary ruling from the National Labor Relations Board holds up, the owners will have to pay for their nastiness.

title: About Real Estate; A Rental Complex for Roosevelt Island
description: Within the next two years 882 free- market rental apartments will be created on an 8.5-acre waterfront tract on the northern portion of Roosevelt Island.

title: Deaths Increase Among Patients With Medicare
description: Deaths of elderly Medicare patients in municipal hospitals in New York City exceeded statistical predictions in 1986, according to a new Federal survey. At the same time, however, death rates for such patients in private nonprofit hospitals did not exceed the Federal predictions.

title: Freed Two Times by Mistake, A Murder Suspect Surrenders
description: A 23-year-old New York man wanted for a double murder in Pennsylvania surrendered in Brooklyn yesterday, ending a week of freedom in which he was mistakenly freed twice by what Brooklyn prosecutors called a mixup in court papers.

title: U.S. REORGANIZING THE GULF COMMAND
description: ABOARD U.S.S. MIDWAY, in the Arabian Sea, Dec. 17 - The Pentagon is planning to reorganize the command running its Persian Gulf escort operations for the second time since convoys of oil tankers under naval protection began in July, according to Navy officials in the region and in Washington.

title: What Else Can New York City Do for the Homeless Insane?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Sponsor For Millrose
description: For 80 years - the last 74 in Madison Square Garden - the Millrose Games have provided sparkle, grace and world records in track.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Helicopter Co., a unit of Boeing Co., has received a $198.9 million contract from the Army for production of 48 CH-47D helicopters.

title: Renaissance Works
description: Pomerium Musices and Calliope, a Renaissance chorus and wind band, is to perform works by Dufay, Josquin, Praetorius and others on Sunday at 6:30 and 8:30 P.M. in the Medieval Sculpture Court of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $23. Information: 570-3949.

title: Antitrust Trial for N.B.A.
description: Rejecting opposing motions from the National Basketball Association and the players' union, a Federal judge yesterday ordered both sides to prepare for a trial on the union's lawsuit charging that the league is in violation of antitrust laws.

title: INSIDE
description: Friedman Charges Dropped

title: Report on Mortality: Guarded Praise
description: The Government's report today on hospital mortality rates was praised by many, but flaws in the study show that measuring quality of care is a science still in its infancy.

title: Will Sparks, 63, Dies; Johnson Speech Writer
description: Will R. Sparks, a speech writer for President Lyndon B. Johnson and a retired director of public affairs for Citicorp, died of a brain tumor Wednesday at Long Island College Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Monday about a Nicaraguan Army officer who defected in October said the proposed peace accord for Central America calls for limiting national armies in the region.

title: FIRST BOSTON FORGOES A PARTY TO GIVE HELP TO THE NEEDIEST
description: There will be no Christmas party for employees of the First Boston Corporation's Manhattan headquarters this year.

title: Cantata Premiere
description: A world premiere of a cantata by Gunther Schuller is to be presented tonight at 8 at St. Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church, 65 East 89th Street. The work, ''Thou Art the Son of God,'' is to be performed by the Horace Mann Glee Club and the Amor Artis Orchestra, conducted by Johannes Somary. Also on the program are Mozart's Coronation Mass and Britten's ''Ceremony of Carols.'' Admission is by contribution. Information: (212) 884-5547.

title: British Jobless Rate Falls
description: The unemployment rate in Britain fell to 9.5 percent in November, the 17th consecutive monthly decline, the Government said today. The Employment Secretary, Norman Fowler, said 1987 had seen ''the largest sustained fall in unemployment on record.'' On a seasonally adjusted basis, the number of jobless in November was 2.69 million, down 63,500 from October, when the unemployment rate was 9.8 percent. The unemployment rate is at its lowest since March 1982.

title: 'Re-educated' 12 Years, An Ex-General Reflects
description: In April 1975, when the Republic of South Vietnam was on the edge of collapse, Nguyen Huu Co, a retired general and former Defense Minister, took stock of his options.

title: Theater Grants
description: More than 20 theatrical organizations, most of which are in the New York area, are the recipients this year of grants and scholarships from the American Theater Wing. The grants, which total more than $30,000, were awarded at a luncheon yesterday. Among the recipients are the AMAS Repertory Company, the Equity Library Theater, Negro Ensemble Company, Theaterwork-U.S.A., the Drama League of New York and the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center.

title: Estimate Board Defeats Koch Plan On East Harlem Homeless Shelter
description: A Koch administration plan to turn an East Harlem school building into a shelter for homeless families was soundly defeated last night by the Board of Estimate.

title: Dole Backs Treaty, but Expects Changes
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, stood beside President Reagan today to announce his support for the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles, but said the pact would probably be amended in the Senate.

title: Koreans Fight Police in an Opposition Stronghold
description: Street battles broke out here today as students and workers vented their anger at the electoral defeat of this city's favorite son, Kim Dae Jung.

title: New York Adds Hospital Beds To Treat AIDS
description: Citing the rising number of AIDS patients crowding New York City hospitals, state health officials yesterday increased the overall capacity of hospital beds by as much as 500 beds. The move reverses 10 years of reductions stemming from efforts to control costs.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Randy Weston

title: Our Towns; A Day's Work: Spending $50,000 In Jersey Malls
description: As the 35-foot superstretch limo wheeled along Route 46, Melissa Motichka kept trying to find herself on the limo's TV. But there's always so much blab on the noon news. South Korea was picking a president. And Donna Rice's old boyfriend had changed his mind again and was running for President, too. ''Who cares?!'' said Melissa's mother, Mary. Finally a Channel 2 newscaster said, ''A New Jersey woman gets the chance of a lifetime'' -that was Melissa - and everyone in the superstretch perked up. Real news, at last! There was footage of Melissa, taken hours before, waving as she got into the limo for the $50,000 shopping spree she'd won from WQHT radio, Hot 103.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1987
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about investment rates included an incorrect figure for Donoghue's Money Fund seven-day compounded average yield for the week. The yield should have been 6.75 percent.

title: Economic Scene; World Outlook: Warning Issued
description: ALTHOUGH the securities markets have steadied in recent weeks, there are plenty of signs that the danger to the international economy is anything but over. The dollar is continuing to fall. The third world debt problem appears to be worsening. Oil prices, in the wake of a flimsy price and production agreement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, plunged below $16 a barrel - good news to consumers and financial markets, but alarming to producers from Indonesia to Texas.

title: Jordan Has 52, Season High
description: Michael Jordan had a season-high 52 points and began a 12-0 spurt during a 2-minute-53-second span in the final quarter to give the Chicago Bulls a 111-100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: Order to Shut School That Tested Poorly Is Upheld on Appeal
description: A divided appeals court panel in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones had acted within his power in ordering a Bronx junior high school closed because of poor test scores and attendance.

title: British Food Retailer Bids for Larger Rival
description: The Barker & Dobson Group P.L.C., a small British food retailer, today offered $:2.04 billion, or about $3.7 billion, for the Dee Corporation P.L.C., a supermarket group whose sales are 37 times larger than its own.

title: Righetti Says No to Japanese
description: Dave Righetti, who seems to be the most aggressively pursued free agent in the last three years, last night rejected an offer to pitch in Japan. But that decision did little to clarify his status. With the Yankees, Los Angeles and California among the teams seeking his services, Righetti must take the next step by tomorrow midnight and decide if he will accept the Yankees' offer of salary arbitration. Indications were growing stronger that he would.

title: Group of Seven Meeting on Dollar Delayed
description: A seven-nation meeting to devise a way to stabilize the dollar, which some countries sought immediately after the mid-October fall of world stock markets, is still likely but probably not until February, officials of participating foreign countries said.

title: Musica Sacra
description: The Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra, directed by Richard Westenburg, is to perform Handel's ''Messiah'' tonight at 7:30 in Avery Fisher Hall. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: 874-6770.

title: Pritzker Group Has Ramada Stake
description: An investment group led by the Pritzker family of Chicago said it had purchased a 6 percent stake in Ramada Inc., a hotel, casino and restaurant company based in Phoenix. The Pritzker family controls the Hyatt Corporation and Braniff Airways Inc.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's 412 money market mutual funds decreased $174.2 million, to $262.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 111 institutional funds were up $75.5 million, to $73.27 billion. Assets of the 206 general purpose funds were down $87.6 million, to $79.81 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds decreased $162.1 million, to $109.24 billion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1987
description: International A3-15

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON NUCLEAR DUMP
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a compromise that would designate Yucca Mountain in Nevada as the only site for disposal of the nation's most dangerous nuclear waste.

title: Accounts
description: * Price Stern Sloan to Rubin Postaer & Associates, Los Angeles, for its Questron toy.

title: ISRAELIS MAINTAIN GAZA CRACKDOWN
description: Israeli troops kept a tight lid on the occupied Gaza Strip today, but scattered demonstrations broke out in Palestinian refugee districts and towns in the West Bank and the Arab sector of East Jerusalem.

title: U.S. Preparing Shells To Spread a Fatal Gas
description: The United States has ended an 18-year moratorium on producing chemical weapons and is filling canisters for an artillery shell that would spread toxic nerve gas, the Pentagon said today.

title: 732 Were Kept From Leaving Soviet in 11 Months of 1987
description: During the first 11 months of 1987 7,007 citizens emigrated from the Soviet Union and 732 people were barred from leaving, most of them for state security reasons, Interior Minister Aleksandr V. Vlasov said today.

title: Troubadours Carry Forth A Tradition
description: THE troubadour, a wandering poet-musician, has long been a figure swathed in mystery and romance, and not only in Europe. The tradition of the itinerant bard is well established in Africa and the Arab world as well. Indeed, there is evidence that the celebrated troubadours of 12th-century Provence were substantially influenced by Moorish bards. Certainly they played stringed instruments with Arab and African origins.

title: McPherson Honored
description: When the Maxwell Football Club in Philadelphia selected Don McPherson of Syracuse for its 1987 award yesterday, it marked the 27th time in 51 years and the fourth in the last 10 that the Heisman Trophy and the Maxwell Award honoring the outstanding college football player of the year went to different players.

title: New Agency For Schrafft's
description: The name Schrafft's, which has a bright and shining image to a certain age group of New Yorkers, is barely known to the up-and-coming generation.

title: Diner's Journal
description: HAUTE Lapland cuisine? Fasten your snowshoes and clomp over to Aquavit at 13 West 54th Street for what is being billed as New York City's first major Scandinavian restaurant to open in several decades. Based on a visit last week, it promises to be one of the most original new spots of the season.

title: Dance: Murray Louis And Alwin Nikolais
description: ALWIN NIKOLAIS and Murray Louis have combined forces for their current season but the second program, like the first, was dominated by one of the two choreographers rather than balanced as expected.

title: Everyone Has Something to Say About Wright
description: His admirers and his detractors tend to portray him in similar terms: the combatant, the partisan, the risk-taker.

title: Air Force Weighs Letting Pilots Fly Longer
description: The Air Force has agreed to consider creating a career alternative for its pilots that emphasizes continuing to fly rather than taking on broader duties.

title: A Chance in Nicaragua
description: There does seem to be a serious chance to end the war in Nicaragua and cut off all Soviet military support for the Sandinistas. That was the message the Russians tried to deliver during the Gorbachev visit.

title: Film: 'Ironweed,' From Hector Babenco
description: EARLY in his novel ''Ironweed,'' William Kennedy describes a visit made to a cemetery by the aging derelict Francis Phelan, whose mother and father and infant son are buried there. It is Halloween, and they are watching him, interested and bemused, from beyond the grave.

title: Financial Services Also Play Global Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Heyman May Buy More GAF Shares
description: Samuel J. Heyman, the chairman of the GAF Corporation, said he might increase his stake in GAF to 15 percent from 10.2 percent.

title: N.F.L. Matchups; Trade for Bennett Pays Off for Bills
description: The trade of the decade is only six games old for the Buffalo Bills, but they have won four of those games since acquiring Cornelius Bennett and that matches their number of victories for 1984 and 1985 combined and equals 1986's total.

title: PROSECUTOR LINKS FRAUD TO LAROUCHE
description: A Federal prosecutor argued today that Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. saw himself as the only man smart enough to save the Western world and that his supporters committed fraud after buckling under intense pressure to finance his 1984 Presidential bid.

title: Trial Leaves Old Questions For Palermo
description: ''The Mafia organization continues to function punctually,'' Mimmo Signorino, a deputy prosecutor, said the morning after a jury returned 338 guilty verdicts in the most successful law enforcement effort ever undertaken against the Sicilian underworld.

title: A Zionist Place in Jewish-Christian Dialogue
description: To the Editor:

title: Revised G.N.P. Growth Put at 4.3%
description: The nation's economy was expanding at a robust annual rate of 4.3 percent immediately before the October stock market collapse, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Four on Sax
description: The World Saxophone Quartet -Julius Hemphill, David Murray, Oliver Lake and Hamiet Bluiett - are to perform tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: 3 Directors In Festival At Modern
description: At first glance, Ettore Scola, Bertrand Tavernier and Krzysztof Zanussi seem an odd trio of film makers for the joint retrospective that begins today at the Museum of Modern Art, but Stephen Harvey, an assistant curator of film, explained the logic of the combination this way:

title: How to Prevent Endless War in Central America
description: LEAD: Like the ghosts of Christmas escorting Ebenezer Scrooge through Dickens's ''A Christmas Carol,'' Maj. Roger Miranda Bengoechea, a Nicaraguan defector, has provided a glimpse of what the future holds in store if we continue on our present course in Central America.

title: U.S. Orders Crews to Be Screened Before They Go Aboard Airliners
description: Airport and airline employees, including flight crews, will have to go through security screening before boarding planes, the Government ordered yesterday.

title: A Gremlin Greets I.B.M.
description: Gremlins have invaded I.B.M.'s computers. Worse yet, they reproduce.

title: Dioxin in Breast Milk Is Evaluated in Private Study
description: A study of breast milk from 50 mothers around the nation has found relatively high average levels of the toxic substance of dioxin, the study's author reported today.

title: NEW OFFER IS RECEIVED BY ROBINS
description: The A. H. Robins Company said yesterday that it had received a takeover offer from Sanofi that included assurances the large French pharmaceutical company would provide the $2.48 billion that Robins needs to compensate women injured by its Dalkon Shield birth control device.

title: A New Publication On Memorable Events
description: Memories magazine will be the first new product entry of Diamandis Communications. It is the brainchild of Peter G. Diamandis and is subtitled The Magazine of Then and Now.

title: Washington Talk: The White House; Finessing Facts About the Summit
description: Ever since Mikhail S. Gorbachev left town a week ago, some White House officials have been practicing the Washington art of ''spin control,'' the technique of delivering information to the press and the public with just the right twist to suit the purposes of the purveyor.

title: PTL DONORS FAVOR ORGANIZATION PLAN
description: Major contributors to the PTL television ministry have voted overwhelmingly to approve a reorganization plan for the troubled organization, officials announced today.

title: Colonel in Dispute Retiring
description: An Air Force colonel criticized as putting pressure on wives of senior officers at Grissom Air Force Base to quit work so they would be available for social activities will retire next month. The colonel, Gary R. Ebert, 44 years old, wing commander of the 305th Air Refueling Wing, based at Grissom, was on leave and unavailable for comment, a base spokeswoman said.

title: Israel Troops Kill 3 Guerrillas Who Attacked Lebanon Post
description: Israeli soldiers killed six Lebanese guerrillas in southern Lebanon today in a further escalation of violence in the area.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Beer at the Bar
description: In Washington, senders of holiday greeting cards often vy to combine the wittiest analysis of a current political situation, often cartoon-illustrated, with best wishes for the season. A contemporary example, circulated by Nordlinger Associates, a public relations concern, may raise an eyebrow or two in the capital's large legal fraternity.

title: A Lane on the Manhattan Bridge Is Closed
description: One lane of the lower roadway of the 78-year-old Manhattan Bridge was closed to traffic yesterday afternoon after cracks were found in the floor beams by city and state inspectors, officials said.

title: Revenue Bonds Set For Medical Center
description: The New York State Medical Facilities Finance Agency is tentatively offering $131.5 million of revenue bonds for the Catholic Medical Center, with a maximum yield of 8.315 percent for an issue due in 2022, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Dukakis Begins a Quest For Presidential Stature
description: As he rode across Iowa one recent wintry afternoon, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts mused on the sources of President Kennedy's inspirational leadership. Kennedy was not ''the greatest natural orator,'' Mr. Dukakis said, nor was his Presidential stature apparent to everyone in the early days of his campaign.

title: REAGANS TO AVOID LINKS WITH DEAVER
description: Nancy Reagan said today that she and President Reagan had been advised by counsel to suspend their personal relationship with Michael K. Deaver as long as appeals of his conviction were pending.

title: Music: New World Group
description: FROM the very first notes of its concert Wednesday evening in Alice Tully Hall - a sweet, perfectly balanced, utterly graceful statement of the opening of Beethoven's F major Quartet (Op. 18, No. 1) - the New World String Quartet declared itself an ensemble of almost startling refinement.

title: KEY RATES
Ex-Rep. Albert Morano, 79, Dies
description: Albert P. Morano, a Republican who represented the Fourth Congressional District of Connecticut from 1951 to 1959, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Wednesday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday, with an article about a speech by President Reagan on seeking conventional arms reductions in Europe, misidentified the head of the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

title: I-95 Journal; Road Completed but Debate Goes On
description: It's not exactly the Great Wall of China, although at 1,869 miles it is 20 percent longer. It's not even the longest superhighway in the interstate system.

title: Court Bars More Charges In Friedman Graft Case
description: New York's highest court yesterday barred the state from prosecuting Stanley M. Friedman, the former Bronx Democratic leader, and a colleague on corruption charges, asserting that to do so after their Federal convictions would violate double-jeopardy laws.

title: 50.07 Drop Puts Dow At 1,924.40
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday, amid what traders and analysts described as fears over the dollar and the arrival of another futures-related ''triple witching hour.''

title: A Touch of Tradition
description: LARRY BIRD recently came up with an interesting explanation for the Boston Celtics' slump. The Celtics' bench was too passive, he said. Maybe it was time to bring back M. L. Carr and let him wave his towel again.

title: Music: Boston Symphony
description: SEIJI OZAWA'S program for the Boston Symphony concerts Wednesday night and last night at Carnegie Hall amounted to a reminder not only of Igor Stravinsky's great gifts, but of Serge Koussevitzky. The Boston Symphony is hardly remiss about honoring Koussevitzky's memory, but in this era of erratic, halfhearted support for new music by so many of our leading orchestras (that was true in Koussevitzky's day, as well, to be sure), it's nice to be able to recall a truly enlightened champion of new music that has lasted.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Mrs. Zorinsky to Run
description: Cece Zorinsky is throwing her hat into the ring. Mrs. Zorinsky, whose husband, Edward, a Democrat from Nebraska, served in the Senate for 10 years until his death last March, has decided to run for the House of Representatives in Nebraska's second Congressional district. The incumbent, Representative Hal Daub, a Republican, is running for the Senate seat once held by Mr. Zorinsky.

title: Cabot Offers 2 Issues of Notes
description: The Cabot Corporation is offering two note issues totaling $250 million through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: On Stage
description: 'The Gospel' on Broadway After three and a half years of speculation as to whether it would or it wouldn't ever get to Broadway, the answer is in. It will, of course, or we wouldn't be talking about it, and the talk is particularly appropriate at this time of year because the production in question is ''The Gospel at Colonus.''

title: Art People
description: Debating 'Tilted Arc'

title: Mets Seek to Cut Pay of Gooden, Darling
description: The Mets tied up a loose end yesterday when they signed Lee Mazzilli to a two-year contract, but negotiations with their two frontline pitchers -Dwight Gooden and Ron Darling -may not be so orderly.

title: DEVILS ON A SLIDE; PENGUINS 7, DEVILS 4
description: The Devils scored more than three goals for the first time in seven games tonight, but it wasn't enough to prevent their fourth consecutive loss, their longest such streak this season.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article on the Health page yesterday about physician referral services appeared in some editions with a section omitted. Any reader wishing a copy of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Ford Ends Stock Buyback
description: The Ford Motor Company flexed its financial muscle today by completing an old stock buyback program and announcing a new stamping plant.

title: Treasury Bonds Retreat Slightly
description: The rally in the bond market lost some momentum yesterday, as a rebound in oil prices from their intra-day low led to a slight decline in Treasury bond prices.

title: Specials for Christmas
description: WITH Christmas just a week away, television is grinding away furiously to take advantage of the season while it lasts. The results are decidedly mixed, as can be seen on three specials this weekend - two public-broadcasting music specials this evening, the other a made-for-television movie Sunday on CBS.

title: On Wall Street, Blues for a Blue-Chip Firm
description: What is one of the nation's most prestigious law firms to do when a state appellate court chides it twice in six months for violations of the law, inexcusable breaches of ethics, specious legal arguments and hubris to boot?

title: WEBSTER DISMISSES OR DISCIPLINES
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, has dismissed two field operatives and disciplined three senior officials for improper actions during the Iran-contra affair, Administration officials said today.

title: Accord Reported in Suit Involving Texas Shooting
description: A $5 million settlement has been reached between T. Cullen Davis, the bankrupt oil heir, and his former wife, Priscilla Davis, in a suit stemming from a 1976 shooting at the Davis mansion, lawyers report. A jury failed to reach a verdict in the case earlier this year.

title: Schumer Ties Homelessness To Cuts in U.S. Housing Aid
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer of New York charged today that homelessness had ''skyrocketed'' in American cities largely because of cuts in Federal housing aid.

title: Bridge: Winter Regional to Include Unusual Open Pairs Event
description: The Winter Regional Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association begin today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, at 36th Street and 11th Avenue in Manhattan, with this schedule: Today - Men's pairs, women's pairs and senior pairs, 2 P.M. and 8 P.M.; knockout teams, 49er pairs and newcomer pairs, 8 P.M. Tomorrow - 49er pairs and newcomer pairs, 1 P.M.; open pairs, 1 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.; 49er pairs and newcomer pairs, 7:30 P.M. Sunday - 49er Swiss teams, noon; flighted Swiss teams, noon and 7 P.M.; 49er pairs and newcomer pairs, 7 P.M.

title: Insiders See Texaco Near A Settlement
description: A $3 billion settlement of the bitter four-year-old battle between Texaco Inc. and the Pennzoil Company appeared imminent last night, several people involved in negotiations said. The settlement would be the key part of a reorganization plan that would bring Texaco out of bankruptcy.

title: Background Radiation Is Tied to Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Marine Bank Chief Named
description: In a move that was expected by analysts, the Marine Midland Bank said that Geoffrey A. Thompson, its president, would take on the additional role of chief executive. Mr. Thompson, 47 years old, replaces John R. Petty, 57, who will continue as chairman of the bank and the chairman and chief executive of its holding company.

title: New President Chosen For Chevron U.S.A.
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that Willis J. Price would become president of Chevron U.S.A. Inc., its domestic operating subsidiary, and a member of the parent company's executive committee, effective immediately.

title: Two Kims Elect a Roh
description: South Korea's opposition fought a long, brave fight for direct elections in order to have the chance to vote an unpopular Government out of power. Instead, because of its deep division, the opposition appears to have handed victory to Roh Tae Woo, the ruling party candidate whose official anointment last spring touched off national unrest.

title: Can't Wait for That Looser, Longer Look; Presidential Style
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater: 'A Most Secret War'
description: WHILE Hugh Whitemore's ''Breaking the Code'' continues on Broadway, another play about Alan Turing, ''A Most Secret War'' by Kevin Patterson, opened this week at the Harold Clurman Theater. Both plays focus on the same aspect of Turing's life - his homosexuality -and neither amply investigates the mathematician's breaking of the German secret code during World War II.

title: 3 'PRICELESS' PIECES FROM OMAN STOLEN FROM CASES AT U.N.
description: A silver urn and two gold perfume bottles given to the United Nations by the sultanate of Oman as gifts were stolen Tuesday from display cases only yards from the Security Council chamber, United Nations officials said today.

title: Auctions
description: Successful Season

title: Article 286087 -- No Title
description: An Indian judge ordered the Union Carbide Corporation today to pay about $270 million as interim compensation to victims of the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster, which killed more than 2,000 people and injured at least 200,000.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Percussive Sounds

title: eagan's Legacy: A New Liberalism Among the States
description: LEAD: State governments are on a roll. In an effort to promote their own economic development, they are reforming education and health systems, trying to convert welfare to workfare and building new roads and bridges and other public works.

title: Restaurants
description: THE third gastronomic cornerstone has been wedged into place at the Equitable Center on Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, this one an all-American grill backed by that all-American girl of the big screen, Mariel Hemingway. Called Sam's (Ms. Hemingway's moniker among friends), it is the sport-shirt alternative to its very proper neighbors, Le Bernardin and Palio.

title: 10% RISE IS FOUND IN PRESCHOOLERS
description: The Census Bureau reported today that the preschool population increased more than 10 percent in the 1980's, with the fastest growth in Sun Belt states and Alaska.

title: Congress Kills Grant For Martha Graham
description: A special Federal grant of $4 million that was to have gone toward establishing a permanent record of the choreography of Martha Graham was killed today in Congress.

title: After Charges, A Lawmaker Gains Support
description: It was bad enough that this city's Senator Q was indicted. After all, he is thought of here more as a neighbor than as a politician, much less a corrupt one.

title: A Child's-Eye View of Grown-Up Shows
description: ''A guy has fallen in love with another woman. And the other woman has fallen in love with him. And it got all mixed up. He got on a ship, and the first woman he loved was going to get married to some Duke and he didn't want her to. And then gangsters gave him a ticket and he became the most wanted man in the United States. And they were going to hang him so they put him in the brig. And it all worked out fine and everybody was happy.'' Daniel Petroff, 12 years old, summarizing the plot of ''Anything Goes.''

title: Gamble Awaits Draft
description: In the early years of the National Football League draft, the scouting was rudimentary and the selections often haphazard. For his last choice in 1936, George Halas of the Chicago Bears regarded a list of unfamiliar players and said, ''Daniel Fortmann, guard, Colgate. That's a nice-sounding name.'' So Halas drafted Fortmann, who became a Hall of Fame performer.

title: Paxton at Bottom Line
description: Tom Paxton, a songwriter, is to perform tonight and Sunday at the Bottom Line, 14 West Fourth Street (228-6300). Tonight, the bill also includes Schooner Fare and John McCutcheon; on Sunday, Mr. Paxton shares a double bill with the Carolling Carollers led by Suzzy Roche. Shows begin at 7:30 and 10:30 P.M. Tickets are $11.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Specter Speaks
description: Last October, when Senator Arlen Specter sought recognition on the Senate floor to announce that he would vote against Judge Robert H. Bork for the Supreme Court, the Pennsylvania Republican was like a man without a legislative body. The Republican leadership would not make time for him to speak, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, a Bork supporter who controlled the floor that afternoon for the Democrats, would not yield to him either. Only after wandering the chamber forlornly for more than an hour did Mr. Specter find an opening to make his speech, which helped turn the tide against Judge Bork.

title: American Madrigals
description: The West Side Madrigalists are to perform early American madrigals on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Fraunces Tavern Museum, at 54 Pearl Street. Suggested contributions to the museum are $2.50, $1 for students and the elderly. Information: 425-1778.

title: Libel Award for Upstate Coach Is Reversed
description: New York's highest court today reversed a libel award against a newspaper that said a high school football coach had cursed and belittled his players.

title: Defense Dept. Aide Calls Defector's Nicaragua Data 'Speculative'
description: A senior official in the Defense Department acknowledged today that evidence provided by a Sandinista defector of a Nicaraguan plan to invade other nations was ''speculative.''

title: Hart Misses the Point
description: There is a common thread connecting many strong people who decide to seek psychiatric counsel. It is the realization that they are acting repeatedly in a way harmful to them, without knowing quite why. So they spend time, often painful time, with somebody who can make them see themselves more clearly, discover what it is that makes them act out the same mistake - and by knowing, change.

title: Article 354987 -- No Title
description: Congressional negotiators have cut the proposed budget for the space station to $425 million in the current fiscal year, $342 million less than the space agency had asked.

title: BARKLEY BEATS KNICKS
description: The play began last night where the endline and baseline meet near the Knick bench. After giving Sidney Green, who was guarding him, a head fake, Charles Barkley made his move to the basket. Patrick Ewing, coming over to cut off the Philadelphia 76ers' power forward, missed the block. Barkley drove round him, dribbled the ball once, took a step and half and then jammed the ball through the basket - in the face of the Knick center.

title: Advertising; Psychology Magazine's New Look
description: PSYCHOLOGY TODAY, owned for the last two years by the American Psychological Association, is taking a new tack at the direction of its recently arrived publisher, Sherwood (Woody) Katsoff, formerly of Science Digest and Penthouse/Omni.

title: College Basketball; SYRACUSE RESERVE LEADS ROUT
description: Keith Hughes, a sophomore reserve forward, scored a career-high 19 points tonight as Syracuse took control early in a 111-68 victory over St. Bonaventure.

title: Counterbid Seen In Martell Case
description: The London liquor and hotel group, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., said it might bid for Martell S.A., the cognac concern that has agreed to be acquired by the Seagram Company of Canada. Seagram said Wednesday that it would buy the 40 percent of Martell's stock owned by the company's founding family for 2,500 francs, or about $450, a share. The deal, which values Martell at about 3.5 billion francs, or about $635 million, would give Seagram majority control because it already owns 11.5 percent of the French company.

title: Tax and Budget Revolt: A Backlash in California
description: Eight years after California led a widespread revolt against taxes and government spending, Californians are growing unhappy with some of the consequences, and they soon will have the opportunity to relax those restrictions. Today a million signatures were filed to place an amendment on next June's ballot that would ease the spending limit.

title: Iran Attacks Maldivian Vessel
description: ABOARD U.S.S. LA SALLE, in the Persian Gulf, Dec. 17 - Iranian gunboats attacked and set afire a cargo ship flying the Maldivian flag in the Persian Gulf today. An American warship nearby sent observation craft to the scene but did not otherwise become involved in the episode.

title: Ex-Howard Beach Alternate Juror Discusses Case
description: An alternate juror dismissed by the judge in the Howard Beach trial predicted yesterday that the jury would decide the case on the evidence presented and would disregard the broader racial and social questions that have been discussed again and again in the courtroom.

title: Conferees Agree to Tax Rise Of $23 Billion Over 2 Years
description: House and Senate negotiators approved late tonight a package of individual and corporate tax law changes intended to raise $9 billion in new taxes in 1988 and $14 billion more in 1989.

title: Compromise Clears the Way For Reagan Abortion Curbs
description: Congressional negotiators have decided to allow the Reagan Administration to proceed with tough new abortion restrictions on family planning groups, handing a victory to the White House and its anti-abortion allies.

title: Qaddafi Foiled as an Ice Hockey Patron
description: Unable to find any domestic sponsors for his bankrupt ice hockey club, Heinz Weifenbach went for broke. He flew to Libya.

title: Mr. Deaver's Arm, Mr. Reagan's Thumb
description: What President Reagan once said in defense of his former deputy chief of staff wholly missed the point. Michael Deaver, he said, ''never put the arm on me, or sought anything or any influence from me since he has been out of government.'' What Mr. Deaver did, with unseemly haste after leaving the White House in 1985, was to put the arm on the rest of the Reagan Administration.

title: 4 Felled in Coast Apartment
description: An 8-year-old girl was found dead Wednesday and her parents and young brother unconscious in the family's apartment, according to the authorities, who said they believed carbon monoxide from a heater was responsible. The girl, Roseanne Keefe, was pronounced dead at the scene while her parents, David and Rosario Keefe, were reported in fair condition today in the hospital. Their 5-year-old son, David, was in serious condition.

title: Documentary Screening
description: Beginning tomorrow and continuing for the next three weekends, the 1986 documentary ''Robert Wilson and the Civil Wars'' will be shown at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street. The film, by Howard Brookner, documents the artistic and financial problems faced by Mr. Wilson as he prepared his theater piece ''The Civil Wars'' for the 1984 Olympic Games. As it turned out, the piece was never performed at the Olympics. Screenings are at 2 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays; free tickets are available one hour before each day's show. Information: 598-7171.

title: McLaughlin Expects Scrutiny in Labor Post
description: Ann Dore McLaughlin, sworn in today as Secretary of Labor, joins a select company with a high attrition rate. In seven years in office, President Reagan has appointed 41 other Cabinet members; the three women in that group have all resigned.

title: DEVILS ON A SLIDE; FLYERS 4, ISLANDERS 3
description: There is something logical about the way the Flyers, who shocked themselves and the rest of the league by making a pathetic start this season, have muscled their way back.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FROM COPYRIGHT TO COPPERFIELD. The Identity of Dickens. By Alexander Welsh. 200 pages. Illustrated. Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Rock Radio Station Fades Out on L.I.
description: Four apparently overwhelmed teen-agers, the self-described Friends of the Friendless, slipped out of their high school today to deliver a confused farewell to the staff of WLIR, an alternative radio station here that at midnight tonight officially lost its FM frequency.

title: AIDS, the Cardinal and the Public
description: Cardinal O'Connor says he won't allow AIDS education programs in the schools of the New York Archdiocese to include instruction about condoms. A church's teaching is its own business, but doctrine that affects public policy invites public comment. As public policy, the Cardinal's stand is dismaying. Educating children about AIDS is a hard issue. The Reagan Administration is divided. Secretary of Education William Bennett stresses abstinence and monogamy; Surgeon General Everett Koop urges that children also be taught about the protective value of condoms. Yet even Mr. Bennett, in his handbook for schools, realistically acknowledges that condoms are a second line of defense against disease, should abstinence fail.

title: Greenspan Plays Down Record Trade Deficit
description: In his first comprehensive review of economic issues since taking office in August, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the record trade deficit reported last week was an aberration.

title: Minnie Evans, 95, Folk Painter Noted For Visionary Work
description: Minnie Evans, a folk artist whose vividly colored works were often inspired by dreams and religious visions, died Wednesday at the Grotgen Nursing Home in Wilmington, N.C. She was 95 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about Steven McDonald, a disabled police officer, misstated his educational background in some editions. He attended several colleges in the New York area but did not graduate; he did not attend Notre Dame.

title: Player Ineligible
description: Woody Myers, the starting senior center for South Carolina, will not play against Louisiana State in the Gator Bowl on Dec. 31 because he tested positive for steroid use, according to an announcement yesterday by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which administered the tests. ''I took the steroid this past March and April,'' said Myers. ''I had just had shoulder surgery, and I took the steroid hoping that it would allow my shoulder to heal quicker and allow me to get back into playing shape a lot quicker.''

title: Conferees Complete Bill For $23 Billion Tax Rise
description: Congressional tax aides worked out the final details today of a $23 billion tax-increase package approved late Thursday night by House and Senate negotiators.

title: U.S. Is Expelling Soviet Diplomat at U.N. as a Spy
description: The United States is expelling a Soviet diplomat assigned to the United Nations, charging that he is a spy, the State Department said today.

title: Two in Yonkers, Citing Turmoil, Quit City Posts
description: Two of Yonkers's top officials, its City Manager and its Corporation Counsel, announced their resignations today in the face of a changing political lineup and mounting difficulties over a court desegregation order.

title: House Votes to Reprimand Lawmaker for Misconduct
description: The House of Representatives, imposing sanctions on a member for misconduct for the first time in three years, today reprimanded Austin J. Murphy, a Pennsylvania Democrat.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 18,

title: Editors' Note
description: A headline on Thursday about Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey said, ''Lautenberg: Well Liked but Vulnerable.'' The subheading said the Senator ''has not been identified with any major public issues.''

title: David Rhinelander King, Rector, 58

title: A Crazy Way to Govern America
description: Congress is about to send the President one gigantic, take-it-or-leave-it appropriations bill for fiscal 1988. It's bad enough that the bill isn't even arriving until the fiscal year is almost three months gone. Worse, it's loaded with trivia, fakery and irrelevant controversy, and forces on President Reagan a $600 billion choice: He must accept every detail of this bill, or, if he wants to block a single one, must veto the whole thing. It's a crazy way to govern the country. Normally there are 13 different annual appropriations bills, approved separately, which the President can pass on one by one before the fiscal year starts each Oct. 1. Because Congress has developed bad habits, this omnibus measure lumps them all together.

title: PATH Safety, Not Neighborhood Blight

Four hundred managed to climb a narrow 60-foot spiral stairway to safety. Firefighters had to lug hoses along the smoky track from a station entrance a quarter mile away. There were injuries but no fatalities.

title: Agent's Suit Rejected
description: A Federal judge in Atlanta threw out a $500,000 lawsuit by Norby Walters against Brent Fullwood, the former Auburn running back, ruling invalid a contract Fullwood signed with the agent before finishing his college career. ''We decline to serve as paymaster of the wages of crime, or referee between thieves,'' United States District Judge Charles Brieant wrote in his ruling, which was reported in the combined edition of The Atlanta Journal and The Atlanta Constitution today. Walters sued to recover $8,042 he gave Fullwood in 1986 before he began his senior season. He also sought $500,000 because Fullwood dismissed him and hired another agent. The payment violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, but Walters contended it was not illegal and maintained the contract should be enforced. Brieant's ruling said, ''Both sides of the transaction knew exactly what they were doing, and they knew it was fraudulent and wrong.''

title: RESULTS
description: Boxing Foreman Stops Sekorski: George Foreman stopped Rocky Sekorski in the third round last night in Las Vegas, Nev., for his fifth straight knockout since starting a comeback last March at the age of 39. Foreman, who held the heavyweight championship from January 1973 to October 1974, methodically pounded Sekorski with jabs and savage right hands before Referee Richard Steele stopped the bout at 2:48. Foreman (50-2 with 47 knockouts) showed only a little flab over his trunks at 244 pound as he patiently stalked the overmatched Sekorski (20-8). Foreman, who is coming back after a 10-year layoff, said he would like six more bouts before seeking a fight with Mike Tyson late next year. ''I want to fight for the championship of the world,'' Foreman said. (AP) College Basketball Kentucky 85, Miami of Ohio 71: Winston Bennett, a senior forward, scored 17 of his career-high 28 points in the second half last night to lead top-ranked Kentucky into today's championship game of the Kentucky Invitational Tournament, at Lexington. Kentucky (5-0) will meet North Carolina-Charlotte, a 78-63 winner over Middle Tennessee. Miami trailed by only 65-62 after Jim Paul sank a jumper from the lane with 8:58 left. But Kentucky's Rex Chapman connected on a 10-footer that began a 12-0 run. (AP) Villanova 83, La Salle 80: Tom Greis scored 17 of his 21 points in the second half, and hit two free throws with 21 seconds to go for Villanova to win the battle of city rivals in the first round of the Jostens Philadelphia Classic. The Wildcats will meet Wake Forest, an 82-72 victor over Canisius, for the title. Villanova held a 76-70 lead, but La Salle closed to 81-80 with 1:10 to go. Greis then converted his foul shots and La Salle (5-2) misfired on its final two attempts.(AP) Texas 99, Long Beach St. 85: Clarissa Davis scored 26 points and pulled down 13 rebounds to lead the top-ranked Texas Lady Longhorns (7-0) past Long Beach State (3-3). Texas surpassed 90 points for the sixth time this season. Doretha Conwell played for the first time in almost a year after a knee injury and scored 10 points for Texas. Penny Toler led Long Beach with 30 points.(AP) School Basketball Tolentine Wins in Hawaii: Malik Sealy, the 6-foot-7-inch forward headed for St. John's next year, scored 23 points and grabbed 10 rebounds to lead undefeated St. Nicholas of Tolentine to an 89-59 victory over the host school in the McDonald's-Iolani Prep Classic in Honolulu Thursday night. Sealy, who also had four blocks, two steals and three assists, played three quarters. There were four other players from the Bronx school in double figures: Brian Reese and Kenneth Beverly with 12 each and Jerome Holmes and Bo Paulle with 11 each. Tolentine (6-0) moved into the quarterfinal round today against St. John's of Washington, a 63-59 winner over Radford of Honolulu. Last night, St. Anthony's of Jersey City coasted past Leilehua of Honolulu, 105-43. Bob Hurley, a junior guard, paced St. Anthony with 21 points, 10 assists and 4 steals. Golf Baird and Johnson Lead: Butch Baird, a Senior PGA Tour player, and Chris Johnson, a Ladies Professional Golf Association player, combined for a seven-under-par 64 and a one-shot lead yesterday after the opening round of the Mazda Champions team tournament at the Tryall Golf and Beach Club in Montego Bay, Jamaica. Two teams - Arnold Palmer and Colleen Walker, and Miller Barber and Nancy Lopez - were tied at 65. In the 54-hole tournament, each player plays his or her own ball with the best score counting toward the team total. (AP) Speed Skating Blair Wins Third in a Row: Bonnie Blair skated her slowest 500-meter time in three Olympic trials, but still won her third straight race in the event last night at the United States speed-skating trials in Milwaukee. She finished in 41.96 seconds on the fourth day of competition at the Wisconsin Olympic Ice Rink. A skater's three best times out of four are used to determine the Olympic team; the top five skaters are chosen.
