description: The marriage of Allison Hall Whipple, a daughter of Mrs. George Carroll Whipple of Carmel, N.Y, and the late Mr. Whipple, to Peter Clark Rockefeller, a son of Rodman C. Rockefeller of New York and the late Barbara Olsen Rockefeller, took place yesterday at All Saints' Chapel of the Trinity-Pawling School in Pawling, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones, the associate minister of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Human Resource Hiring

title: Gateway to Saharan Adventure
description: LEAD: AT the end of the third day's travel by camel in the Sahara's dry heat, I felt not like the cartoon image of the parched and haggard desert traveler, but refreshed and relaxed by the solitude. My guides were two of the Tuaregs, the traditionally nomadic people of the region; we were following for a few days in the footsteps of the ancient caravans that had passed over this route for centuries.

title: TEXACO IN ACCORD ON REORGANIZATION
description: Texaco Inc. will file a plan of reorganization tomorrow with a Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, permitting the company to emerge from bankruptcy in the spring after a substantial restructuring, executives from Texaco and the Pennzoil Company said yesterday.

title: LITTLE BY LITTLE, A HOLIDAY SHOW IS PUT TOGETHER IN GREENWICH
description: LEAD: AFTER participating in a dollhouse show in Greenwich, Conn., 10 years ago, eight women formed the Greenwich Miniaturists. Now, grown in number to 20, they meet once a month at each others' homes to make tiny things. And every three years -that's how long it takes to get ready - they put on a show.

title: JESSE JACKSON AIMS FOR THE MAINSTREAM
description: There are any number of questions to be asked about a Jackson candidacy: the advisability of someone so closely related to a ministry assuming the Presidency, is he or isn't he a racist, and, having had Jimmy Carter, do we really want another ''outsider'' administration? But Joyce Purnick and Michael Oreskes deliver the usual private appraisals of character - anecdotes from teachers, the circumstances of his birth, etc. Any commentary that might aid the public debate over what policy Mr. Jackson would pursue in office is carefully avoided. CHUCK ZITO New York, N.Y.

title: NEW HAITIAN LAW WILL LET OFFICIALS VIEW ALL BALLOTS
description: The military-dominated Government today published a new election law that bars independent observers but not soldiers from polling stations, and lets the authorities examine every voter's ballot.

title: In Nicaragua, Economy Is Hobbling Sandinistas
description: By traditional measures, 1987 is the year the Nicaraguan economy essentially collapsed. And if fundamental changes do not occur, 1988 will see the national currency become worthless, according to diplomats, local economists and trade union leaders.

title: On Cigarette Ads
description: 'Pravda does not carry cigarette advertising, or indeed any advertising. Government control of information is typical of totalitarian regimes and dictatorships. Those who favor such a ban hope to control the behavior of Americans by limiting their access to information. Ad bans represent censorship and idea control.'

title: A Novelist Faces His Themes On New Ground
description: SIX THEMES IN SEARCH OF AN author:

title: Boston Harbor Fines Sought
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has asked the Federal district judge supervising the cleanup of Boston Harbor to fine a state agency $175,000 a day if it allows sludge to flow into the harbor after 1991.

title: LONG LIVE BABE'S MOMENTS
description: MORE than half a century after his last home run and nearly four decades after his death, Babe Ruth is still making headlines, still creating debate. Just as his 714 homers and his 94-46 record with a 2.28 earned run average as a left-handed pitcher certify him as the best player in baseball history, his enduring esteem as a newsmaker is another reason why he remains the most celebrated baseball player in history.

title:
GARDENING;
Getting the Most Out of Holiday Plants
description: LEAD: MORE plants, greens and flowers decorate homes and offices during the holidays than at any other time of the year.

title: Anne Danzig Is Bride of Reed Schneider, a Lawyer
description: Anne Phoebe Danzig, a registered representative with Equitable Financial Services in New York, was married last evening to Reed Graham Schneider, a lawyer in the office of the Corporation Counsel of New York City. Rabbi Sally Priesand performed the ceremony at the Monmouth Reform Temple in Tinton Falls, N.J.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS: Wall Street; Boesky Receives 3-Year Sentence
description: Long before it took place, the sentencing of Ivan F. Boesky became a test of whether, or how much, crime pays. On Friday, a Federal district judge, saying that ''some kind of message must be sent to the business community,'' sentenced the man at the center of Wall Street's insider-trading scandal to three years in prison.

title: LEAVING HIS IMPRINT ON BROADWAY
description: I do not question Lloyd Richards's esteemed place in the American theater (''Leaving His Imprint on Broadway,'' by Samuel G. Freedman, Nov. 22). But he has left his imprint on Broadway at the expense of students of the Yale School of Drama. As a student there, I knew Lloyd Richards to be a dean who was often absent from the school, a stranger to most students. Mr. Richards is a leader in the theatrical community who holds at least three full-time positions simultaneously; it is inevitable that his time and energy as dean are limited.

title: Historic Budapest Evokes Wartime on the Screen
description: IT WILL COME AS A SURPRISE to the people of Budapest, but film makers from America consider the Hungarian capital a city whose people and buildings still convey an image of World War II and is thus an ideal setting for wartime movies.

title: Dr. Bessie A. Watkins Is Wed to R. J. Duncan
description: Dr. Bessie Ann Watkins, a clinical psychologist, and Raymond Jerome Duncan, a pilot for the Bristol-Myers Company, were married yesterday at the Canaan Baptist Church in New York by the Rev. Wyatt T. Walker.

title: OLD BRIDGE TO GET 4TH SUPERFUND SITE
description: FEDERAL environmental officials have pledged to add the Global Landfill in Old Bridge, Middlesex County, to the nation's toxic cleanup agenda.

title: Old Habits of Distrust Lurk on Road to Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Kennedy's Constitution
description: As the repeated Senate hearings on Supreme Court nominees have demonstrated, the Constitution lives. Last week it was studied, argued over and even shaped by the Senate Judiciary Committee's dialogue with Judge Anthony Kennedy. If confirmed, he will have much to say about what the Constitution means. Even in his testimony last week, he contributed generously, often brilliantly, to the continuing dialogue.

title: CANADIENS' STREAK ENDED BY SABRES
description: Doug and Adam Creighton staked Buffalo to an early-two goal lead tonight and Jacques Clouriter made it stand up as the Sabres ended Montreal's nine-game unbeaten streak tonight with a 2-1 victory.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: SANTA'S ORIGINS That jolly old man who dominates the scene these days didn't start out wearing a red suit, smoking a clay pipe and using reindeer for transportation. This current image evolved between 1800 and 1870, and its evolution is the subject of ''Santa Claus -A Knickerbocker Creation,'' a new exhibition at Museum-in-the-Park at Eisenhower Park. With original prints, objects, miniature figures of Santa and even a life-size Mr. Claus in his sleigh, the display traces how such New York writers and illustrators as Thomas Nast, Washington Irving and Clement Moore transformed the historic legends of St. Nicholas into a New York version of Santa Claus. With barley-candy-making at 2 P.M. weekends thrown in as an extra atttraction, the exhibition at the museum in East Meadow can be seen from 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. daily through Jan. 3; and, thereafter, Wednesdays through Sundays through Jan. 3l. Admission is 25 cents. 'IN CELEBRATION'

title: ANSWERING THE MAIL
description: Q. Our 10-year-old house has a redwood exterior. This has grayed and blackened on all sides, so we plan to have all the siding steam-cleaned. Should we put preservative on the wood after it is cleaned, and if so, what should we use and how should it be put on, with brush or spray?

title: A SPIRITED CHRISTMAS PRESENT
description: In -towns called Smith-, Searing- and Mutton-, This is no time for gloom to butt in. In -villes called Brook- and nearby Hicks-, Santa unloads bags of tricks. Woodcleft Canal! Creek Gowanus! Another Island Yule's upon us. In Baldwin, Merrick, Rockville Centre, Hanukkah, then Christmas, enter Home and hearth, mailbox and flue: Near fireplaces' embers blue, Sis and junior bend each slim knee. Who's that sneaking down the chimney? Let spirits leap, good will spread random Through Great Neck, North Hills, Sands Point, Plandome. From Oceanside to far-out Montauk, Let's hear no Scrooges; only fond talk. Fill wassail bowl and plug in Yule log From Auburndale to Aquebogue! Stores and street lamps now are winking, Festooned with red and green lights blinking. Lists filled, the Christmas shoppers smile On Roosevelt Field, on Miracle Mile. (As for you worn-out clerks, this cheer: It happens only once a year.) New Hyde Park, Carle Place, New Cassel; Every village has a passel Of ho-ho-ho-ers who, to tickle us, Romp door to door dressed as St. Nicholas. At doorways, candies wait to greet The small fry out for trick-or-treat. 'MER-rick, BELL-more, SEA-ford, WAN-tagh!'' On, Comet, Cupid; on, L.I.R.R.! Home, for merry punchbowl-mixin'; ''MAA-sa-PE-qua!'' Go, Dancer, Vixen! Macy's, Bergdorf's: Take Manhattan! Long Island's what we hang our hat in. Who needs a city to be cramped in As carols ring, Long Beach to 'Hampton? Mix church bells' chiming with hosannas (And barside tinkling of piannas!) New York City? Beg our pardon, We'll wassail in the one called Garden-. But before we savor Yule feasts with dressings, Let's also stop and count our blessings. En route to Island celebration, This once be touched, when, in Penn Station, The huddled homeless meet your stares. It's Christmas; can you say, ''Who cares?''

title: Wendy Thompson Wheatley Planning To Marry Duncan W. Riefler in April
description: Announcement of the engagement of Wendy Thompson Wheatley to Duncan Winfield Riefler has been made by the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. George M. Wheatley Jr. of Old Brookville and Bridgehampton, L.I. Mr. Riefler is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Riefler of Glen Cove, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GAY RIGHTS BILL FALTERS
description: A bill to prevent discrimination against homosexuals in jobs, housing, credit and public places, first introduced in 1973, has finally won approval from both houses of the State Legislature.

title: Daring Comeback Saves Crown for Kasparov in a Close Match
description: After losing the 23d game of the world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, on Thursday, and falling behind in the series, Gary Kasparov made an amazing, determined comeback to win the final game yesterday, level the score and keep his title.

title: Albany to Aid Disposal Plans For Trash, but Not Pay Costs
description: The Cuomo administration is prepared to take a leadership role in garbage disposal in New York, including the lending of technical and management help, but it will not help pay local trash disposal costs, the state's Conservation Commissioner, Thomas C. Jorling, said today.

title: SHE'S SETTING SAIL TOWARD THE OLYMPICS
description: LEAD: ON a gloomy Friday, Sue Blackman looks bright and blond and tanned - as if she just stepped off the beach. With her yearly shuttling among Greece, California, Brazil, Florida, Italy and Texas, her life story reads like a travelogue on sunny places. But these are not merely endless-summer wanderings; they are the stops she has made in her quest to reach the 1988 Olympic

title: LONG LEAP: FROM THE HEALTH CLUB TO THE PARACHUTE
description: Among affluent and well-educated Bostonians, the Christmas gift of favor this year is also a potentially dangerous one: gift-certificates for skydiving lessons.

title: THE DOORS OF CHRISTMAS
description: THOSE with Christmas in their hearts like to put it on their doors. Whether inspired by custom or competition, the decorations on the doors have become part of the spirit of the season.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Tax Law Now Affects Passport

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Pleasures of Desolation The retreat to the primitive is a natural modern fantasy. Deborah Tall realized it, going to live on a thinly-populated lump of rock off the west coast of Ireland. In ''The Island of the White Cow: Memories of an Irish Ireland'' (Atheneum), she describes one of her good days there.

title: Fosse's Present Is Show-Stopper
description: GO out and have dinner on me,'' the choreographer and director Bob Fosse ordered in his will.

title: Social Events; Into the New Year
description: Loft Party Dec. 20 - Help Autistic People Please Inc. seeks to place autistic people in small group homes or in their own apartments and help them find jobs. Since its founding seven years ago, Happi has been raising money to send to a group in Rockville, Md., that has a program to draw autistic people into everyday life. Determined to establish such an organization in New York, Happi is holding a fund-raising party in the spacious loft of Marvin Schwam at 7 East 17th Street. Mr. Schwam is a designer and decorator who is also the president of the charitable group. There will be music, snacks and an open bar from 3 to 7 P.M. Tickets, $50, at the door. Information: 212-765-4008. Art, Song Downtown Dec. 20 - Founded in 1973 to defend equal rights for homosexuals, the Lambda Defense and Education Fund has also become an educational arm for gay groups and most recently an advocate in the many legal issues arising from AIDS. A benefit for the group will be held at the Schreiber/Cutler Contemporary Art gallery at 171 Spring Street off West Broadway. From 4 to 7 P.M. there will be an eclectic range of music from the Cream Tones, the Stonewall Chorale and the cabaret singer Kelly Vinci. Refreshments will be served amid an exhibition of Adrian Kellard's carved and painted wood reliefs of night scenes based on religious themes. Tickets, $25 at the door. Information: 212-925-1441. Debutante Ball Dec. 29 - The 33d International Debutante Ball to benefit the Leukemia Society of America and the Soldiers,' Sailors' and Airmen's Club will be held at the Waldorf-Astora. Starting with 7:30 P.M. cocktails and a receiving line of 68 young women from 13 countries, the white-tie dinner-dance and ceremonial presentation will continue its tradition of also having in the receiving line direct descendants of American Presidents, in the persons this year of Abigail Adams, a descendant of John Adams (and a namesake of his wife), and Catherine Lewis Robb, a granddaughter of President and Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson. Miss Robb is a daughter of former Gov. and Mrs. Charles S. Robb of Virginia. Tickets, $235, from 212-861-5911. Victorian New Year's Dec. 31 - Carnegie Hall will ring in the New Year with ''An Evening of Victorian Music and Song'' - Gilbert and Sullivan, Tchaikovsky, Offenbach and many others. Two British vocalists, Benjamin Luxon and Robert Tear, and the violinist Gil Shaham, the cellist Matt Haimovitz, the double bassist Gary Kerr and the trumpeter Stephen Burns will be among those appearing in the 8 P.M. performance. The audience is encouraged to wear Victorian dress so as to feel at home on the stage after the performance for a turn-of-the-century English buffet of curried lamb crescents, spinach turnovers, cheese madeleines, truffles and tuiles. Tickets, $200, from 212-903-9650, or for the performance alone, $100, $75, $50, $30, $25 and $20, from 212-247-7800. Evening of Dance Jan. 4 - The Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company will present an evening of dance at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue near 19th Street, to benefit the Gay Men's Health Crisis. The 7:30 P.M. performance will include Alwin Nikolais's ''Tensile Involvement'' and ''Crucible,'' Murray Louis's ''Four Brubeck Pieces'' and the premiere of his ''Bach II.'' Both companies will dance in the American premiere of Mr. Nikolais's ''Arc en Ciel.'' Following the performance, a Caribbean dinner will be served at Lola Restaurant, 30 West 22d Street. Tickets, $100, or $30 for performance alone, from 212-627-8417.

title: Tainted Fish Found in Dead Whales on Cape Cod
description: Contaminated mackerel were found in the stomachs of nine whales that died recently along Cape Cod beaches, a finding that may help explain other mysterious marine fatalities, researchers said today.

title: Talking: Loans; Buying Business Space
description: FOR a small-business man, owning rather than renting commercial space has always been a tantalizing option. Buying a property allows the owner to build up equity while building the business. Owning can also help distribute overhead more evenly, so business costs can be estimated over the long term.

title: Foreman Is Tested
description: THE comeback trail got a bit steep for George Foreman Friday night when the 39-year-old former heavyweight champion took on Rocky Sekorski in Las Vegas, Nev., and ran into something he had not encountered in four previous comeback fights, a real battle. Unlike the four opponents who had succumbed without a scrap, Sekorski actually tried to make a fight of it. At 209 pounds, however, he was no match for the 244-pound Foreman, who unleashed a barrage of 30 head shots that led the referee to stop the fight in the third round.

title: People on the Fringes Struggle for Dignity
description: Uncertainty and the feelings of helplessness it invariably provokes seem to rule the lives of disadvantaged New Yorkers more and more these days. The shameful plight of hungry and homeless people worsens, while shudders of doubt shake confidence from Wall Street to the nation's capital.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
A PSYCHIC'S FORECAST: THE FUTURE LIES AHEAD
description: LEAD: YEARS ago I wondered what the new year would bring. Would I go steady? Pass the French final? Get my braces off in time for the prom?

title: Europe Considers How to Take Up Arms
description: THIS is a watershed moment of promise and peril in a Europe that for four decades has been the most heavily armed corner of this planet and, paradoxically, the most peaceful, too.

title: Meese Amends Financial File To Show Bigger Stock Trades
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d has filed amended forms on his financial holdings showing that his investment manager bought stock for him that was worth far more than the $55,000 he had invested.

title: About Men; Old at Seventeen
description: THERE ARE SIGNS that say you're getting older. Getting a driver's license, needing a shave every morning, going to college and reading the front page of a paper before the sports section -these all say a person is getting older. Any man who says getting older comes later, that it's a matter of balding and middle-aged spread, just can't remember, I say.

title: Vanuatu
description: To the Editor: We have recently opened a North American National Tourism Office of Vanuatu and welcome any inquiries. Your readers may write or call for more information: 14252 Culver Drive, Suite A316, Irvine, Calif. 92714; telephone 714-733-1744. SUE HERRICK Irvine, Calif.

And Bear in Mind (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) RODIN: A Biography, by Frederic V. Grunfeld. (Holt, $35.) Easily the fullest and best life of the turn-of-the-century colossus, the father of modern sculpture who let loose a formal revolution. THE ART OF ROCK: Posters From Presley to Punk, by Paul D. Grushkin. Photographs by Jon Sievert. (Abbeville, $85.) A huge, fascinating, accessible examination of rock art from the 1950's to the 80's, especially strong on the psychedelic era in San Francisco. SUCH WAS THE SEASON, by Clarence Major. (Mercury House, $16.95.) An old-fashioned, straight-ahead novel of family and society, narrated by a black Atlanta matriarch and full of action: politics, homecomings, scandals, sudden death and other surprises, all packed into a single busy week. AGNES SMEDLEY: The Life and Times of an American Radical, by Janice R. MacKinnon and Stephen R. MacKinnon. (University of California, $25.) Smedley (1892-1950), buried in a hero's grave in China, appears to advantage in this judicious biography as a brave journalist, a generous woman and a political skeptic. STORIES FROM THE WARM ZONE AND SYDNEY STORIES, by Jessica Anderson. (Viking, $15.95.) This two-part collection by an Australian writer gives us, in uncluttered prose, tough, self-aware characters and dry, subtle dissections of family dynamics. STALIN IN THE BRONX: And Other Stories, by Suzanne Ruta. (Grove, $16.95.) Eleven stories, set in several countries, imbued with a sense of the fatal connectedness of private and political life. THE THIRTIETH YEAR, by Ingeborg Bachmann. (Holmes & Meier, $19.95.) Nothing that terrifies or makes life impossible is omitted from these relentless stories, now reissued, by an Austrian writer of genius who died, possibly by suicide, in 1973.

title: Broadcast TV
description: Calling all VCR's - to tape ''A Christmas Carol'' (1951) for family enjoyment on Christmas Day. This year the definitive British filming of Dickens is slotted late on Thursday - 12:30 A.M. on Channel 5 - with most children already tucked in bed awaiting Santa. So a taped run-off should make perfect family fare for Christmas Day. This durable movie superbly evokes the spirit of the glorious old Dickens fable, with its roast-beef English ambiance and a plum-pudding cast headed by Alistair Sim as Scrooge, Mervyn Johns, Hermione Baddley and Kathleen Harrison. A very good Hollywood version (1938) of ''A Christmas Carol'' is also ripe for taping on Wednesday at 2 A.M., same channel.

title: Where Blurred Focus Makes Sharp Statements
description: TEN YEARS AGO, PHOTOGRAPHS made to be seen as art were for the most part sharp, clear and descriptive. While not everyone subscribed to the Modernist notion that it is the nature of the medium to describe the world in exacting detail, most photographers would have agreed that photography's advantage over painting rested with its verisimilitude. Landscapes, portraits, still lifes, fictional tableaux - all were taken, more often than not, with large-format cameras capable of reproducing every nuance of texture and shape in the subject.

A third world people may slowly be absorbing a fourth world people, but meanwhile the Yi culture continues to be intriguing and the Yi marvelously hospitable.

title: Passing the Baton
description: Zubin Mehta will be leaving the New York Philharmonic at the end of the 1990-91 season. That is, unless he stays. In an interview last week, Mr. Mehta seemed anything but decisive about the prospects of retiring from the orchestra he has led for nearly 10 years. First, he announced that 1990-91 would be his last season. ''I've made it quite clear to the Philharmonic that I'll be leaving,'' he said. Later, apparently after a call from Philharmonic officials, he seemed less certain about the future. ''I never told the Philharmonic 100 percent I'm leaving,'' he said. ''The way it stands now, I'm leaving. But my contract has four years to go. If they come to me in two years' time with an offer, I will think about it then. That's not a hint, it's a fact.'' Or, as Yogi Berra once said about a baseball game, ''It ain't over till it's over.''

title:
JAMES BALDWIN: HIS VOICE REMEMBERED;
Jimmy in the House
description: LEAD: James Baldwin was the grandson of a slave. I was the grandson of a slave owner. We were virtually the same age and both bemused by our close link to slavery, since most Americans of our vintage - if connected at all to the Old South - have had to trace that connection back several generations. But Jimmy had vivid images of slave times, passed down from his grandfather to his father, a Harlem preacher of fanatical bent who left a terrifying imprint on his son's life.

description: A PROCESSION of priests, ministers and leading laymen made a ceremonial blocklong walk from the parish house of Holy Innocents Church in Pleasantville into the new church for a dedication Mass last Sunday.

title: BUSINESS FORUM: Congress, Taxes and the Arts; Let Artists Have a Fair Share of Their Profits
description: LAST year, two owners of an Australian mail-order firm known as Subdivision Art bought a 1959 Picasso linocut print entitled ''Trois Femmes.'' The purpose was to cut it into 500 pieces, each one inch square, and sell them for $135 apiece - complete with a certificate of authenticity and a 30-day money-back guarantee. They placed newspaper ads which read: ''Yes, your own beautiful framed Picasso piece, in the most original and exciting offer in the history of Australian art. And you can own a piece of the work yourself.'' One of these entrepreneurs, David Robertson, was quoted as saying, ''If this thing takes off, we may buy other masters as well and give them the chop.''

title: ESTIMATE TO CLOSE MILLSTONE UP 50%
description: THE estimate of how much it will cost to shut down the three nuclear power plants on Millstone Point in Waterford climbed almost 50 percent in a recent State Department of Public Utilities Control decision.

description: Were it not for a hint of the leprechaun in his smile, E L. Doctorow's could be the face of an elder in a Bible story. Talking in his overgrown backyard in Sag Harbor, he considers things slowly, with an eye for the wry twist.

title: POMANDERS: SIMPLE TO MAKE, DELIGHTFUL TO GIVE
description: THIS season has its own seductive scents. In our house, the perfume of pomanders replaces the lighter, sweeter fragrance of flowers. A combination of fruit and spice, pomanders have always seemed the perfect treasure or the perfect gift. They are as traditional as the tree, but far more lasting.

description: TAKING up a controversy that became a major issue in the Suffolk County Executive race, the State Commission on Integrity in Government has subpoenaed letters, literature and other material disseminated at taxpayer expense by Acting County Executive Michael A. LoGrande.

title: Paul Du Brul, Writer and Leader In Fight to Ban Lead Paints, Dies
description: Paul Du Brul, a writer and political consultant who was a leader in the fight to outlaw the use of lead-based paint in New York City, died of cardiac arrest - a complication of cystic fibrosis -Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lighting Lonely Lives
description: A man, lonely in old age, his eyesight dimmed, still holds on to the dignity of his spare room. But he needs help at the grocery store, as well as a break in the loneliness.

title: Frontiers for Art In San Antonio
description: LEAD: IT was always easy to be charmed to death by San Antonio, with its small riverside galleries chock-full of paintings of bluebonnet-covered hillsides and scenes of abandoned barns and rusting barbed-wire fences. But visitors were not likely to remember San Antonio as a center for experimental art - or any other type of art that passes for avant-garde, modern, post-modern or contemporary.

title: Counseling Enables Mother to Solve the Problems of Balancing Her Family
description: Overwhelmed by problems with her family, the woman had almost given up hope. Her husband drank, and her children were not doing well in school.

description: From the moment of his angry withdrawal from the 1988 Presidential campaign last May, in a speech so defiant that he never flatly said he was leaving the race, Gary Hart has been working on the resurrection of his political life.

title: Woven Baskets From Ireland
description: FOR centuries the common denominator of every household in Ireland - from a stone cottage perched on a Kerry cliff to a big house reigning over a Longford village - has been the daily use of baskets, especially to hold two staples of Irish life, potatoes and peat clods, or turf, for fuel. Today, in an age dominated by plastics, professional basket makers supply a growing home and international market for willow and rush baskets made in the traditional way.

title: Haughey: An Irish Survivor With a Gift for Timing
description: IF he were in American politics, Charles J. Haughey, Prime Minister of the Irish republic, could have been the stuff and star of a musical by now - winking, shambling, tapping across his own life, death and resurrection in politics. The music might thump as jingoistic as George M. Cohan's, but the lyrics should be as masochistic as Stephen Sondheim's. ''Deep down I'm a shallow person,'' Mr. Haughey once declared laughingly in dismissing an interviewer's attempt to elicit introspection.

title: Rock: Depeche Mode, Pain and Synthesizers
description: ON its albums, Depeche Mode has been one of Britain's most consistent synthesizer bands. Above a mechanical beat and keyboards that pulse and peck and clank, David Gahan or Martin Gore, the band's songwriter, sings about love linked with pain and uncertainty, or about love as a provisional bulwark against despair. The music has rigorously economical counterpoint and a variety of synthesizer tones that make it stark yet catchy, and the band often uses Arab-inflected lines alongside pop melodies. Its better songs are ominous yet willfully hopeful, with dark undercurrents of dominance and submission.

title: PLAYERS MAY ASK ARBITRATOR FOR SECOND-CHANCE FREE AGENCY
description: THE long-awaited remedy phase of Conspiracy Case I begins tomorrow.

title: Tell Riders Where to Get Off

Rush-hour standees have a tough time seeing them; the nearsighted can't make out what they say. When it is raining or dark, travelers depend on the kindness of strangers to find out where they are. Every so often, it would help to hear the driver's point of view.

The effort has borne fruit at the college level, where bridge-playing was strongly entrenched three decades ago, but sadly diminished in the 1960's. The preliminary stage of the North American Collegiate Bridge Championship attracted 29 teams last month, nine more than when it was inaugurated a year earlier.

title: 'The Haw Lantern'
description: Seamus Heaney's new collection, ''The Haw Lantern,'' following three such powerful books as ''North,'' ''Field Work'' and ''Station Island,'' looks slender, probably because it is deliberately impersonal. Yet the most successful poems - the spirited and intense ''Hailstones,'' ''Grotus and Coventina,'' ''Holding Course'' and ''Clearances'' - are in Mr. Heaney's accustomed style. They are intimate, tender, erotic: ''We are voluptuaries of the morning after.'' As always, Mr. Heaney is concerned with images and myths of origin. In ''Parable Island'' he envisions islands in the manner of the ''old revisionists'' who ''derive / the word island from roots in eye and land.''

But I wasn't enjoying any of it, for my eyes were fixed on the silver tips of my skis, which were in midair, suspended over the side of a mountain. My feet, encased in sturdy plastic boots, were planted at the edge, my knees were up against a thin metal wand in front of me, and I was leaning on my ski poles for support.

title: JAMES BALDWIN: HIS VOICE REMEMBERED
description: JAMES BALDWIN died Dec. 1 in southern France. On Dec. 8, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York City, his family and friends gathered at his funeral to grieve, to remember and to celebrate. Baldwin's insistent, passionate voice - as an essayist, novelist and playwright - helped to inform and transform the debate on civil rights for Afro-Americans; his deeply generous spirit nourished a generation of writers, black and white, who benefited from his personal warmth and were inspired by the incisive, articulate anger that distinguished his writings.

NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Rockport, Mass.: Building on A 'Rock Pile'
description: LEAD: THIS 7.2-square-mile town on the tip of Massachusetts's Cape Ann is experiencing steady residential construction in spite of its limited supply of buildable land and its rocky terrain, which its Appeals Board vice chairman, John Krenn describes as a ''lightly upholstered rock pile.''

title: In a Cautious Taste of Freedom, Korea Elects Government Candidate
description: ALTHOUGH on the surface it might not seem like it, South Koreans voted for change in last week's presidential election. True, it was the Government candidate, Roh Tae Woo, who won. But nearly two-thirds of the 23 million voters supported rival opposition contenders, stark testimony to the unpopularity of the present Government.

title: The Oldest Stories Made New
description: THE LITERARY GUIDE TO THE BIBLE Edited by Robert Alter and Frank Kermode. 678 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/ Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title: Message From Queen Assails Ulster Violence for First Time
description: Queen Elizabeth broke from tradition and included an attack on violence in Northern Ireland as part of her annual Christmas message, several newspapers reported today.

title: ADVOCACY GROUP PROTECTS STUDENT RIGHTS
description: IT had been a typical day at the Westchester Student Advocacy Coalition in White Plains.

title: Mark Stone Engaged To Margery Hellmold
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph O. Hellmold of Leonia, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Margery Hellmold, to Mark J. Stone, a son of Marion L. Stone of Stamford, Conn., and Elhanan C. Stone of Mount Washington, Mass. A February wedding is planned.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
DANCE
description: LEAD: The Nutcracker Conceived by Kent Stowell and Maurice Sendak. Directed by Carroll Ballard. Choreographed by Kent Stowell. Production and costumes by Maurice Sendak. Dolby Stereo. Color. Paramount Home Video. 82 minutes. $19.95.

title: TIPS ON CARE OF YULE TREE
description: THE Connecticut Tree Growers' Association offers the following suggestions for maintaining and disposing of a Christmas tree.

title: APPALACHIAN CLUB SEEKS SUPPORTERS
description: WHEN the Appalachian Mountain Club, a low-key, nonprofit organization that for more than 100 years has brought millions of Americans in closer contact with the natural world, started a multimillion-dollar fund-raising campaign nearly two years ago, it was counting on its reputation and the loyalty of its supporters to bring that effort to fruition.

title: RECITAL: Ciesinski And Rose
description: AS part of its ''Wordsworth and the Romantic Imagination'' exhibition, the New York Public Library is offering a series of concerts and lectures in its handsome, recently restored Celeste Bartos Forum (the entrance is on 42d Street just west of Fifth Avenue). Thursday evening at 6 there was a full-scale musical program offering the pianist Jerome Rose, both on his own and as accompanist, and the mezzo-soprano Katherine Ciesinski.

title: FOR THE LAST-MINUTE SHOPPERS
description: HERE'S some advice for last-minute shoppers: If you're planning to buy a camera for your favorite photo buff, don't.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;
A Revolutionary on Broadway
description: LEAD: It's the first law of Broadway that theater artists never pay for anything they can get the producer to shell out money for. In a stroke of good fortune, Boris Aronson made the exception to this rule and had all of his theater sets photographed even if he had to pay for the work. As a result, in THE THEATRE ART OF BORIS ARONSON (Knopf, $75) we now have photographs of his sets and designs, and they are remarkable.

title: Brewing Trouble
description: Back in his days at St. John's University, when Chris Mullin wasn't putting the ball through the hoop, he was putting away a few beers - quite a few beers, in fact, according to acquaintances. Reports that the popular Brooklyn-born basketball player had a drinking problem followed him into the pros and blew out into the open last weekend, when his team, the Golden State Warriors, announced that Mullin had agreed to get treatment for a drinking problem. Just a day earlier, Mullin was suspended for missing practice twice in one month. The whole mess, which shocked many Mullin fans, came amid the 6-foot-7 guard's best year as a pro. His scoring average this year - 17.6 points per game - was 25 percent higher than in his rookie season three years ago.

title: LEGISLATORS' IDEAS FILLING THE HOPPER
description: LEAD: THERE ought to be a law, people say. There ought to be a law that requires a 10-minute coffee break for everyone in Connecticut who works for more than four hours. Or a law that gives you more time in the voting booth. Or one that makes the state publish the names of everyone who owes it back taxes.

title: Will Mrs. Thatcher Squeeze the Beeb? Will British TV Be Americanized? Stay Tuned . . .
description: IF YOU WERE HANDING OUT nicknames to match public reputations in British television, Jeremy Isaacs would be ''Mr. Innovation'' and Michael Grade would be ''Mr. Ratings.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: THE Los Angeles Raiders' Bo Jackson, who has an ankle injury, will miss today's game against the Cleveland Browns. . . . He did well in four of his courses, but Jay Edwards, Indiana's acclaimed freshman guard, apparently didn't pay too much attention in an art class. As a result of a low grade in the course, he has been declared academically ineligible by Coach Bobby Knight and may miss the rest of the season. . . . Bo Schembechler, the Michigan football coach who underwent heart bypass surgery at an Ann Arbor hospital on Tuesday, has been moved from intensive care to an intermediate care unit and his condition has been upgraded from fair to good.

title: 39 Aspirants File for New Hampshire Primary
description: The familiar political figures who have traveled and debated around the country in recent months are not the only people running in New Hampshire's Presidential primary.

title: Dance: 'Man Who Turned Into a Dog'
description: THEATER and dance can easily show life's absurdities. Yet if productions are self-consciously grotesque, they may seem contrived rather than revelatory. Contrivance was often evident in ''The Man Who Turned Into a Dog'' and ''Uno, Dos,'' the theater pieces that Artists and Resources Inc. presented Thursday night at the Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street. The performance runs through today.

title: SURREAL CLARA JOINS 'NUTCRACKER'
description: LEAD: BECAUSE he considers ''a ballet like a work of art -never truly finished,'' Michael Vernon, the artistic director of the Eglevsky Ballet, has been tinkering with ''The Nutcracker'' for a decade now.

title: After the Briefest Respite, Africa Faces Starvation Again
description: HARDLY had the tragic images of famine in Africa that gripped the world barely three years ago finally begun to flicker than new events seemed to propel their return. A crippling drought, with blood-draining civil strife its dark ally, threatens once again to produce fresh scenes of horror.

title: Ms. Whelan, Writer, Marries
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Tensie Whelan, a daughter of Carol Storke Whelan and Sidney S. Whelan, both of New York, was married yesterday to Johan Ashuvud, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Olof Ashuvud of Markaryd, Sweden. Msgr. Harry J. Byrne performed the ceremony.

title: Theater
description: For more than a decade Penn & Teller, ''two eccentric guys who have learned to do a few cool things,'' as they like to say, have been refining their own curious exhibition of comedy, magic and menace. Now their show is back in New York - on Broadway no less, in the Ritz Theater at 219 West 48th Street.

title: Herbert H. Goldberger Businessman, 69
description: Herbert H. Goldberger, founder and chairman of Hills Department Stores in Canton, Mass., died Dec. 16 in Boca Raton, Fla., where he lived. He was 69 years old.

title: Power Shortages Loom In New England States
description: The New England governors, who were warned Tuesday of possible electrical shortages in their region this winter, sharply criticized the forecasts made by utilities.

title: BILL PROVIDES FUNDS FOR WATER STUDIES
description: A $549 MILLION ground-water protection bill recently passed by the House would pay for two research projects designed to prevent the contamination of water supplies in New Jersey coastal areas with vulnerably sandy soil.

title: 'Coats for Kids' to Keep 14,000 Warm
description: Fourteen thousand needy children in New York City have warm coats to wear for the winter, thanks to a undertaking involving the Salvation Army and businesses.

title: NORTHEAST JOURNAL
description: Moral Trailblazing In Rockland, Mass.

title:
INVESTING;
Better Times for U.S. Home?
description: LEAD: THE U.S. Home Corporation, a major builder of single-family homes, suffered such adversity in oil-related markets that its stock sank this year below the $5 low posted in the bear market of 1981-82. Last week, the shares closed on the New York Stock Exchange at $2.50; in the past 52 weeks, they have been as high as $8.25 and as low as $1.625.

title: Steven C. Gee Married To Teresa W. Y. Tong
description: The marriage of Teresa W. Y. Tong, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tong Yun Kai of Hong Kong, and Steven C. Gee, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Gee-Mah of Maspeth, Queens, took place yesterday at the Riverside Church in New York. The Rev. Fanny Erickson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: WOULD PONY EXPRESS DO A BETTER JOB?
description: My hat's off to Diane Ketcham, in whose Long Island Journal of Nov. 29 it was suggested that additional mail deliveries during the holiday season might constitute an improvement.

title: SCHOOL RADIO TOWER AT ISSUE
description: PLANS to build a 150-foot microwave tower for the Syosset High School radio station, WKWZ, have been challenged by local residents who want a delay on the construction until more information on the tower is obtained.

title: Leniency for Ailing Speeder
description: Leona B. Hann, who drove her car the wrong way at 90 to 100 miles an hour on Interstate 70 in March and crashed it into an unmarked police car has been found not criminally responsible because she was acutely depressed. Judge Francis M. Arnold of Howard County District Court placed Ms. Hann, 41 years old, of Warfordsburg, Pa., on probation Wednesday and ordered that she be given medical treatment.

title: Nigerian Nightmare
description: Marie McBroom of Jersey City worked for years as a travel agent to interest other blacks in visiting Nigeria. Her reward was to be held without charges in a fetid Lagos jail for 10 months in a dispute over alleged illegal exporting. When she was threatened with execution in 1985, the resulting international uproar forced her release.

title: PRESSURE TO HOUSE MENTALLY ILL
description: WITH a history of opposition to neighborhood group homes, Westchester communities now face mounting pressure to house the recovering mentally ill, according to state and county mental health leaders.

title: Rockwell Cover Joins Fight on AIDS
description: Norman Rockwell has been recruited posthumously in the fight against AIDS, with the illustrator's folksy depiction of a father teaching his embarrassed son ''The Facts of Life.''

title: IN CHRISTMASES PAST, TIMES WERE TOUGH BUT SPECIAL
description: THE spirit of Christmas in the early 1920's just seemed to settle quietly over Hastings-on-Hudson. It did not rush in and sweep aside Thanksgiving, nor was it forced upon us commercially. It seemed to come along, gradually and with dignity. The Christmas spirit grew within us and around us, as the days of early December moved closer to the big holiday.

title: Italy's Original Garlic Bread
description: WHEREVER olive oil is produced in Italy, it's traditional to celebrate the olive harvest and the pungent new oil with a feast of bruschetta. This is the original garlic bread, made with thick slices toasted over a fire, rubbed with fresh garlic and saturated with intense green olive oil. This simple yet superb dish is known by various names all over Italy - bruschetta, fett'unta, soma d'aj - depending on the region.

title: Gretchen Kelley And T. P. Witschi Engaged to Wed
description: Gretchen Sue Kelley and Thomas Phillip Witschi, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin B. Witschi of Bern and Norwich, Vt., plan to marry in May, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Kelley of Saddle River, N.J., and York Harbor, Me., have announced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title: On Track in Morocco
description: THERE'S a delicious scariness about skirting the fringes of a great desert. The feeling has something in common with riding a roller coaster or making faces at a caged tiger: one can savor the proximity of danger without actually having to confront it. When an unwary visitor or downed aviator is truly snared in the death grip of a major desert, of course, survival is no joke. The Atacama of Chile and Peru, the Gobi of Inner Mongolia and Antarctica's Polar Plateau, for instance, are among Mother's Earth's celebrated killers. Even in an age of spotter satellites and rescue helicopters, the wise traveler treats any desert with the utmost respect.

title: FIRST AID FOR SEA STINGS
description: ONE really disagreeable way to ruin a vacation in the sun is to plunge into the surf and get stung, stuck or bitten by a sea creature. In one case we know of, a vacationer had such an acute allergic reaction to sea urchin spines that he became ill and his traveling companions could not enjoy themselves for worry.

Some businesses have closed their economics departments, partly for such failures.

title:
DINING OUT;
PIANO-BAR SPOT IN WHITE PLAINS
description: LEAD: PATRONS who remember the tacky interior of this longtime restaurant and bar are in for a pleasant surprise. Reopened after a three-month renovation, the place has been partly gutted, replastered, repainted and receilinged with skylights. An exposed brick wall, dark grass-green carpeting and trellises against shades of rose and butterscotch suggest the garden, no doubt the ''secret'' tucked beyond the bar.

title: Building In Warmth: Icehouse
description: A load of hay on the second floor once kept the interior of a Stamford icehouse cold. Now, with its conversion to residential use, the 100-year-old, two-story structure on Fieldstone Road will have a heating system that is more high-tech.

title: LEAVING HIS IMPRINT ON BROADWAY
description: As an acting student at Hunter College, I once had the opportunity to work on a production of Lorraine Hansberry's play ''The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window,'' which Lloyd Richards was directing.

title: Darcy Hammerman Plans To Marry Allen B. Dalton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hammerman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Darcy Jill Hammerman, to Allen Bruce Dalton, the son of Theodore Dalton and Kate Mandel, both of Liberty, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: JESSE JACKSON AIMS FOR THE MAINSTREAM
description: Jesse Jackson may ''aim for the mainstream,'' but he remains a divisive force in American life, in spite of all his new appeals and continued efforts to paint himself as a ''rainbow'' man. His being a preacher makes me as uncomfortable with his candidacy as I am with Pat Robertson's. Their respective backgrounds and activities as adults were both partisan and religiously oriented, and I question whether such personalities would serve the country's best interests. HYMAN H. HAVES Pacific Palisades, Calif.

NUMISMATICS;
Seasonal Specialty From the Isle of Man
description: LEAD: THE Isle of Man, a small, self-governing British dependency in the Irish Sea, has issued the eighth in an annual series of 50-pence coins honoring Christmas. description: FAME MAY INEVITABLY breed controversy, but the arguments swirling around Andrew Lloyd Webber - who has composed more hit musicals than anyone else in this decade, and whose ''Phantom of the Opera,'' due next month on Broadway, looks to be his best and biggest hit of all - are especially virulent.

title: GARAGE DEBATED IN HUNTINGTON
description: LEAD: A CITIZENS' advisory committee on parking is expected to recommend soon the construction of a parking garage in Huntington village. But some Huntington residents see no need for such a structure and argue that it would destroy the ambiance of the downtown area.

description: Springtime, the Greek Cypriot physician said, is the hardest, when memories tumble against a present that denies them.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: IN LA-LA LAND WE TRUST, by Robert Campbell. (Mysterious Press, $3.95.) La-La Land is Los Angeles, where the discovery of a headless corpse helps a private investigator named Whistler uncover a pornography ring run by a seemingly respectable businessman with a voyeuristic taste for murder. ''Whistler is in many ways a very modern reincarnation of Hammett's Continental Op,'' Newgate Callendar said in The Book Review last year. He called Robert Campbell ''one of the most stylish crime writers in the business.'' BROTHERS IN ARMS: A Journey From War to Peace, by William Broyles Jr. (Avon, $4.50.) Long after the Vietnam War had ended, the journalist William Broyles Jr., a former Marine lieutenant, felt nostalgia for what he considered his ''initiation into the power of life and death.'' Returning to the battlefield in 1984, he found that some of his former adversaries were just as wistful as he was and eager to reminisce. The conversations ''have a credibility born of mutual respect,'' Bill Kurtis said here last year. The author's ''journey was quite personal, but it speaks for thousands of men who are still troubled by the unsettled issues'' of the war. ENCHANTMENT, by Daphne Merkin. (Fawcett, $3.95.) Having grown up in the emotional icebox of an Upper East Side household, Hannah Lehmann feels chilled and smothered by her past. ''In the wrong hands, the inside story of the Lehmann family, dirty linen and all, could easily have made uncomfortable reading,'' The Times's John Gross said in 1986. ''Thanks to Daphne Merkin's subtlety and sureness of touch, it is a story that draws the reader on unresisting.'' FIDEL: A Critical Portrait, by Tad Szulc. (Avon, $5.95.) A skilled manipulator of the masses and the news media, Fidel Castro has managed to play off the United States and the Soviet Union against each other for three decades. Last year, Walter Goodman said in The Times that as a ''conscientious and fair-minded'' biographer, Tad Szulc ''provides as full an account of the rise . . . of [ the Cuban leader ] as any general reader could ask and more than some may require.'' MALCOLM, by James Purdy. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $7.95.) When James Purdy's novel about the slow corruption of a 15-year-old boy was published in 1959, our reviewer, William Peden, praised the author's ''talent for depicting the sickly, the abnormal, the blasted aspects of contemporary American life.'' The same publisher has reprinted Mr. Purdy's subsequent novel, THE NEPHEW ($7.95), in which the aunt of a soldier missing during the Korean War writes a memorial to him, learning in the process disturbing facts about the town where she lives. In 1960, R. W. B. Lewis said in these pages that the book was ''a small work of authentic fictional art.'' It reads ''as though some of the stories in 'Winesburg, Ohio' had been rewritten by Eugene Ionesco.'' CRISIS IN BETHLEHEM: Big Steel's Struggle to Survive, by John Strohmeyer. (Penguin, $7.95.) As the editor of The Globe-Times of Bethlehem, Pa., John Strohmeyer watched the fall of the once-powerful Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which he sees as emblematic of the problems faced by the industry as a whole. Last year, our reviewer, Steven Greenhouse, admired the book for conveying both the company's ''extravagant and insular corporate culture'' and ''the extraordinary physical dangers of steelmaking.'' THE GATES OF HELL, by Harrison E. Salisbury. (Da Capo, $12.95.) Harrison E. Salisbury, a former Times editor and foreign correspondent, based this novel on the life of Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn. When it was first published in 1975, one reviewer said the book's ''evocation of Russian history enthralls the reader. . . . Salisbury has written a moving and informative novel.'' TAKING THE WORLD IN FOR REPAIRS, by Richard Selzer. (Penguin, $7.95.) The surgeon-writer Richard Selzer is known for his essays about what physicians call ''invasive procedures.'' In his latest collection, which also includes some short stories, he moves beyond the operating table. ''As he palpates the world, listening for the tiny arrhythmias of despair, he jots down his observations with a surgeon's cunning and a stylist's zest,'' Diane Ackerman said here in 1986. PECKHAM'S MARBLES, by Peter De Vries. (McGraw-Hill, $4.95.) Earl Peckham, whose gloomy novel ''The Sorry Scheme of Things Entire'' has sold three copies, falls in love with the best-selling author Poppy McCloud, whose work he considers trash. ''The comedy . . . is less strenuous than in some of Mr. De Vries's other books,'' John Gross said in The Times last year. ''But the author still remains in a class by himself among contemporary comic writers.'' CRACKPOT: The Obsessions of John Waters, by John Waters. (Vintage, $5.95.) As director of the films ''Pink Flamingos'' and ''Polyester,'' John Waters prides himself on being a purveyor of bad taste. In this collection of essays, he occasionally lets down his facade, as when he describes his stint teaching at a prison institution for murderers, sex offenders and other hard-core criminals. ''Mr. Waters is far more interesting when he ditches the crackpot pose and writes from the heart,'' our reviewer, Anthony Schmitz, said last year. SEMITES AND ANTI-SEMITES: An Inquiry Into Conflict and Prejudice, by Bernard Lewis. (Norton, $7.95.) Historically, the Islamic world has not been infected with the anti-Semitic religious fervor of the Christian West, the historian Bernard Lewis writes. But he fears that the situation is changing. He wrote ''this provocative book to sound the alarm against what he sees as the deepest and most dire consequence of the Arab-Israeli conflict,'' Arthur Hertzberg said here last year.

title: Pro & Con: Free Needles for Addicts, to Help Curb AIDS?
description: THE provocative idea of giving drug addicts clean needles to help slow the spread of AIDS was first broached two years ago, and New York officials have been fighting over it ever since. This month the issue arose at the national level, as the President's advisory commission on AIDS said it would consider such a proposal.

title: Streetscapes: Holbein Studio; Art Came Alive Over a Stable
description: THE outcome of a tenant-landlord battle may decide the fate of an unusual Romanesque-style structure on West 55th Street that was built in 1888 with a ground-floor stable and studios for artists above.

title: For a Lonely Woman, Some Good Cheer
description: Rows of tin cans and glass jars once lined the window sills of her cramped apartment in a city housing project on the Lower East Side, a poor woman's burglar alarm. Bands of youths looted her building frequently, and she had been mugged three times, attacks that left a deep fear that one day she would be irreparably harmed. Her fears were echoes of the past. Among the precious items stolen from her apartment were her only wristwatch and her birth certificate, so she does not know exactly how old she is, though she thinks she is close to 90. She also cannot remember when she took the long, rough boat ride to the United States from Poland, but she remembers why: the Cossacks made regular raids on her community, threatening the Jewish people, stealing their meager belongings and violating the sanctity of their religious practices. Her parents sent her here for her safety, and she never saw them again.

title: Kathleen Byrne, A Teacher, Weds
description: Kathleen Mary Byrne, a teacher, and Petrus Cornelis Hendrik Martens, an astrophysicist, were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. Neil Connolly.

Mr. Michel, who is 46 years old, has been counsel and administrative assistant to Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, since 1981. He previously served in various capacities with the Justice Department.

Method Acting

title: On the Trail of Ski Homes in the Rockies
description: PRICES for Rocky Mountain ski area vacation homes have been going downhill as fast as the skiers in recent years. But an influx of bargain hunters, including buyers from the East Coast's strong economic centers, has apparently stopped the decline and even sent some prices back up again.

title: Khmer Leader Sets Terms for New Talks
description: The leader of the largest civilian Cambodian rebel organization says he will join Prince Norodom Sihanouk in reconciliation talks with the Phnom Penh Government, but only if Hanoi will first give a public assurance that it will withdraw its troops from Cambodia when the negotiation process begins.

title: New Studies Zeroing In On Poorest of the Poor
description: While the number of Americans living below the poverty line has risen steadily in recent years, new research is finding a much faster rate of growth among the most severely disadvantaged.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE NEWSPAPER OF CLAREMONT STREET. By Elizabeth Jolley. (Viking, $14.95.) In this small, richly peculiar novel, Elizabeth Jolley writes about money the way others write about love - lyrically, longingly, sensually. Money is the obsession of Margarite Morris, known as ''the Newspaper of Claremont Street'' or ''Weekly'' because of the petty gossip she picks up and passes along on her rounds cleaning houses in a small Australian town. Everyone on Claremont Street knows the gaunt old woman, the object of innocent fun and occasionally vicious jokes. If she can just save enough for a piece of land in the country she can free herself from all the people who cling to her and whom, for the most part, she despises. And so money becomes Weekly's passion; to her, it has ''the fragrance of roses and honeysuckle and fresh country air.'' Like many characters in Ms. Jolley's books, eight of which have been published here since 1984, Weekly is a bit barmy. In this expanded version of a short story from an earlier collection, Ms. Jolley fleshes out Weekly's character, giving her a Dickensian childhood, a stinker of a brother (shady Victor, whom she betrays to his criminal enemies), and a daily struggle to fend off her sense of shame and guilt.

title: Jersey Wedding For Beth Cooke And G. P. Carey

Carey Jr. of Sands Point, L.I., and North Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Jack Thorn performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. David Mahon, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From The Negev; 'The Palestinians Have Earned a Share of Sovereignty'
description: A FEW weeks after the Israeli Government discovered a pretext for expelling Palestinian-American Muburak Awak, the nonviolent disciple of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., another darkly imaginative Palestinian wafted in over the Lebanese border in a hang glider. Before he could be dispatched, six Israeli soldiers were dead. Soon after that, violence began to erupt daily on the West Bank and in the Gaza Strip, where my son Ted has spent the last week leading a platoon on patrol around the alleys of Gaza.

title: A TREE FOR REMEMBRANCE
description: EITHER way you look at it, a Christmas tree is an expense. If a cut tree is chosen and trimmed with colorful trinkets and lights, its days of glory are brief. All too soon, the tree is tossed on a trash heap to be carted away or cut up to protect a perennial border from spring frosts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: INDOCHINE. By Christie Dickason. (Villard, $18.95.) A vivid sense of place and a thorough knowledge of Vietnamese culture distinguish this colorful if flawed first novel by an American-born director and choreographer who lived in Indochina in the 1950's. Christie Dickason's heroine, Nina Luoc, is the daughter of a Frenchwoman and a wealthy Vietnamese who sees her privileged life shattered in 1954 when her mother is killed and her father disappears in the wake of an explosion at their home. Stranded in the Saigon streets, Nina is rescued by a messenger from her father and initiated into the family opium trade. She rises to precarious fortune in the years of America's increasing involvement in Vietnam, jousting with rival drug lords and juggling two lovers, one an American journalist and the other a guerrilla who will stop at nothing to rid his country of the hated White Devils. ''Indochine'' is most notable for its characters' pragmatic, essentially amoral point of view, in which the Americans are simply the latest in a long line of foreign colonizers whose ignorant authority must be evaded or twisted to individual advantage. The author smoothly intersperses her narrative with necessary historical information, and she has a considerable gift for evoking the chaotic atmosphere of a war-torn nation. However, the plot, which is never more than serviceable, degenerates toward the end into an improbable series of confusing maneuvers that allow Nina to jet off into the sunset with no visible remorse and lots of cash. So many loose ends are left dangling in blatant anticipation of a sequel that this otherwise satisfying novel might just as well have closed with the words ''To Be Continued.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CITY OF REFUGE: The Collected Stories of Rudolph Fisher. Edited by John McCluskey Jr. (University of Missouri, $25.) Although his work is little read today, Dr. Rudolph Fisher once held a prominent place among that pantheon of writers and artists whose reputations blazed during the Harlem Renaissance. And justifiably so, since his writing effortlessly captures the spirit and vitality of the Harlem he experienced in the 1920's and early 30's. Taken individually, the short stories collected in ''The City of Refuge'' show Fisher's remarkable command of both standard English and various dialects. One feels, smells and tastes his Harlem; its people come alive and one cares about them. Unfortunately, when read over a short time span, these parts seem to diminish the volume as a whole. They tend to follow the same depressing theme: Harlem crushing the spirit of the naive newcomer. In fact, there is only one somewhat positive piece, ''Ezekiel,'' in the 15 that make up this book. Most of Fisher's tales are about Southern immigrants coming to black America's Promised Land, Harlem, and how these honest, hard-working, God-fearing country people are swept away by the cynicism of the mean uptown streets. Fisher, a physician who died in 1934 at the age of 37, certainly deserves to be read, and this collection is as good a place to start as any. But I suggest you start slowly and take the good doctor in small doses.

title: Posting; Freddie Mac: Ceiling Lifted
description: In response to rising home prices, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will increase the maximum price of mortgages it buys by 10.2 percent beginning Jan. 1. The corporation, better known as Freddie Mac, buys first mortgages from banks and then resells them to private investors. The bank continues to service the loan for a small percentage of the interest payment. Freddie Mac also earns a fee for guaranteeing the interest and principal for the investor. The purpose of the system, established by the Federal Government in 1970, is to encourage housing construction by making more mortgage money available through the country's home lenders. In 1986, Freddie Mac purchased over 1.75 million mortgages, providing the financing for almost a quarter of the $454 billion in mortgages extended that year.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: REQUIEM ON CERRO MARAVILLA: The Police Murders in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Government Coverup. By Manuel Suarez. (Waterfront Press, 52 Maple Avenue, Maplewood, N.J. 07040. Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $9.95.) If you cross the F.B.I. campaign against the Black Panthers with Watergate, you would get some idea of the story told in this engrossing, if extremely complicated, work of investigative journalism. And in the post-Iran-contra era some of the darkest inferences of ''Requiem on Cerro Maravilla'' seem plausible, if scarcely proved. The narrative begins on July 25, 1978, when two radical proponents of Puerto Rican independence were killed by police in an apparent shoot-out at the base of a television tower that the two had apparently intended to sabotage. Within days the official police version of events began to unravel. After more than five years and innumerable hearings and court challenges, Puerto Ricans learned that the ''terrorists'' had been lured to the site by a police infiltrator, ambushed, and then executed at close range while kneeling and begging for mercy. The killing had then been covered up by the police and investigators. Manuel Suarez, who spent years running down every angle of the case for The San Juan Star, persuasively places the killing and the cover-up in the context of the bitter feud between statehood and independence forces in Puerto Rico. He also does a highly credible job of implicating then Governor Carlos Romero Barcelo in a truly Nixonian scheme to stonewall investigators, discredit opponents and manipulate the media. One of the most pressing questions raised by the case is whether or not the Carter Administration colluded in the cover-up, possibly in exchange for Governor Romero's endorsement in the 1980 Democratic primary. Mr. Suarez closes by calling for a grand jury investigation into possible obstruction of justice. But there is, he concedes, ''no hard evidence . . . that a deal had been struck.''

title: A Theatrical Vision Endures
description: ''OUR TOWN'' MAY BE the most misunderstood and misinterpreted of American plays. It is not, as is often assumed, a hymn to small-town life at the turn of the century. Nor is it the American equivalent of Dylan Thomas's ''Under Milk Wood,'' a poetic memory piece suffused with character and atmosphere. The primary subject of ''Our Town'' is not love and marriage but life and death. In the play, Thornton Wilder deliberately sought a kind of evocative stoicism. Though certainly less mordant, there is a kind of Beckett-like aspect in the author's intention. In ''Our Town,'' as in ''Waiting for Godot,'' one is born astride the grave.

description: The Koch administration has begun a $5.4 million after-school recreation program intended to reduce racial tensions in New York City by taking youngsters off the streets and into community centers, parks and schools.

title: Kent K. Curtis, Scientist, 60
description: Kent K. Curtis, chief scientist of the National Science Foundation, died Thursday of cancer at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington, D.C. He was 60 years old and lived in Washington.

title: On Cincinnati
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles W. Ferguson, Ex-Magazine Editor
description: Charles W. Ferguson, a former senior editor of Reader's Digest, died Dec. 11 at Briar Crest Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: BOOKS as Christmas gifts aren't at all unusual. Even books as Christmas gifts to theater owners and producers aren't at all unusual, although there are those who think that these people read only excerpts. But according to James M. Nederlander, chairman of the theater chain, there are books and books.

title: Light a Match and Start a Revolution
description: LEAD: LOVERS OF THE AFRICAN NIGHT By William Duggan. 230 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

description: IF you have finished your Christmas shopping, there is still time to reward yourself with some Christmas listening.

description: IT didn't help Frank Guarascio's pizza business when the Third Avenue el was torn down in the Bronx in the mid-70's.

title: Distributor Issues a Recall For Defective Ski Bindings
description: Look USA, a distributor of French-made alpine ski bindings, is recalling 13 models to fix a defect that could cause the binding to release unexpectedly, the company said Friday.

title: INDUSTRIES LOWER TOXIC WASTE 15%
description: SPURRED by rising disposal and liability costs, Connecticut companies have reduced the hazardous waste they generate by about 15 percent in the last four years, according to an advisory panel appointed by Governor O'Neill.

title: RULING IS UPHELD IN DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: Employers should not be held responsible for their workers' drunken driving if the employer had nothing to do with the drinking, even if the employer provided the alcohol, the state's highest court ruled this week.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title: A FEAR OF LAWYERS
description: In his article ''A Fear of Lawyers'' (About Men, Nov. 15), Morley L. Torgov has near-missed the point. Because of the arcane and convoluted laws passed by legislators, most of whom are lawyers, his client and his client's opponent are at the mercy of their lawyers who do not always want their clients to ''compromise'' and ''settle.''

title: COUNTY WEIGHS WATER FILTRATION
description: THE water Westchester residents drink is by and large superior in quality and has been for years, according to experts. Nevertheless, Federal and state agencies are now calling for filtration systems on surface-water supplies - the kind that 90 percent of the county's population gets its water from. While filtering the drinking-water increases safety, it also considerably raises expenses.

title: A 'CERAMICS EACHER'S ART' AT THE STATE MUSEUM
description: ''ANYTHING can start with a practical idea, but when you deal with an object you forget the practical part. Then the esthetic idea comes into place.''
