description: LEAD: LANGUAGE is the road map of a culture.

title: Countdown to Christmas at K Mart
description: PAUL PORADA looked purposeful. With intense absorption, he strode through the shopperless K Mart, eyes dancing across the shelves, as he began another too-many-hour day during the Christmas shopping explosion.

title: WEAPONS BUILDERS AND THEIR CONTRACTS
description: I was an interested reader of the Nov. 22 article ''Weapons Builders Face New Tests as U.S. Retrenches,'' as I am currently an employee of one of the companies (Grumman) and am a former employee of another (Sperry, now Unisys).

title: SPIRIT OF GIVING
description: For some employees of Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, the season of giving will mean a computer instead of Christmas cards. What has touched their hearts is the plight of Ann Carina McBean, a 15-year-old Mount Vernon girl who has had sickle cell anemia since she was an infant.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MYTH OF THE MODERN: A Study in British Literature and Criticism After 1850. By Perry Meisel. (Yale University, $24.) Much of the literature now honored as modernist purports to confront the alienating complexity and spiritual depletion of modern life. Perry Meisel's new book persuasively calls this popular assumption into question.

title: Peru Urged to Curb Abuses in Fighting Rebels
description: Americas Watch, a human rights organization based in the United States, urged the Peruvian Government today to take stronger measures to prevent and punish abuses carried out by security forces in combating a Maoist guerrilla group.

title: INSURING PEACE ON SPACESHIP EARTH
description: A recent series of town meetings on national security, sponsored by the Long Island Alliance to Prevent Nuclear War, brought out a diversity of opinion. Here are excerpts from some of the statements.

title: GETTING THERE IS HALF THE FUN
description: WRITING ABOUT A fascinating wine region that few others are likely to see is like writing about rare wines that no one else can drink: it's just not fair.

title: ERICK HAWKINS: CREATOR OF ELEGANT MYTHS
description: IN ''GOD THE REVELLER,'' ERICK Hawkins has composed a noble work. It has long been evident that Mr. Hawkins's choreography differs markedly from the dance pieces of others, and the originality of his signature style is embodied with typical elegance in this latest premiere.

title: Job Outlook for '88 College Graduates Is Good, Survey Finds
description: Businesses will significantly increase their hiring of college graduates in 1988 and will increase starting salaries, according to a survey by Northwestern University.

title: Enemies Next Door
description: BELFAST DIARY War as a Way of Life By John Conroy. 218 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $18.95.

title: THEATER BANQUET WHETS APPETITE AS IT ENTERTAINS
description: HOW is a theater banquet different from a standard dinner theater? It offers five acts and four courses, in alternation, with each act requiring an attention span of 15 minutes, the most.

title: SHOCK THERAPY
description: I had a course of ECT at a prestigious New York hospital in 1984. Today, I struggle with a permanent loss of mental function. I don't need to wonder whether ECT causes brain damage; I have the result of my own brain scan to prove that it does. I doubt that the aging process could be blamed for this damage, because I am 27 years old.

title: Gadgets
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed ''Gifts of Gear and Gadgets'' (Travel, Nov. 22). As frequent travelers we have availed ourselves of most of them. However, one item that might seem superfluous, in the United States and some parts of Europe, is not mentioned. It is a traveling smoke detector. It may be purchased with traveling case for between $10 and $15. Ours, made by General Electric, has been a comforting companion in many parts of the world. MURIEL MCK. D'AGOSTINO Clinton, N.Y.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: LAUGHING AT LARSON

title: The Maine Town That Wants to Die
description: Frustrated by rising property taxes, townspeople here have launched a campaign that could lead to dissolution of the small town, which would give up its name and revert to state jurisdiction.

title: The Tempo Is Changing For Music Magazines
description: THE contentious world of general-interest classical-music publications is in turmoil. As they change ownership and cope with financial troubles, these magazines are facing up to irrevocable shifts in the audience for classical music itself.

title: China Display Of the Shoddy Breaks Down
description: Consumers in China, a land where refrigerator doors fall off, the frames of bicycles crack as they are wheeled from the store and the hands of doughnut-sized watches ignore conventional notions of time, are up in arms. Or so the country's newspapers say.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: ROSE THEATRE. By Gilbert Sorrentino. (Dalkey Archive Press/Small Press Distribution Inc., 1814 San Pablo Avenue, Berkeley, Calif. 94702, $20.) ''The secrets of art are long, long secrets,'' says, declaims, posits the narrator(s) of this novel, this exercise, this hilarious, infuriating book, this alternately whirling and static sendup of novels and novel writing and the people who read them and write them and talk about them, even if they haven't read or written them, and whose vocabularies and sensibilities are shaped by their most worn conventions.

title: Mothers, Fathers and Daughters
description: To the Editor:

title: Mixed-Use Headquarters: Growth for an Iron Works
description: A & T Iron Works, a company that specializes in crafting ornamental cast-iron fences, railings and furniture, plans to construct a new headquarters building from concrete, glass and aluminum tubing. If approved by local officials early next month, the $4 million, combination factory and office building would be erected on a half-acre site on South Columbus Avenue in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The company's current headquarters is in nearby New Rochelle. The move is impelled by A & T's expansion plans, which will mean doubling its work force from 25 to 50 employees.

title: GENEROSITY FOILS STAMFORD GRINCHES
description: DESPAIR, frustration and rage surged through Judith Moriarty when she found that her car had been broken into on Dec. 4 and that about $400 worth of Christmas gifts for Stamford's homeless and poor had been stolen.

title: For Art in Hungary, Wall St. Friends
description: Wall Street, not normally a subject of interest for the people of a Communist country without a stock market, has been worrying a surprising number of Hungarians since stocks plunged in October.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN FLOWERS
description: SUSAN OVERTON, manager of Ana's flower shop in Riverside, Calif., calls the year-end holidays the ''big profit time of year.'' Chuck Alexander, owner of eight Alexander's Flowers shops around Cleveland, relies on the period after Thanksgiving for 35 percent of sales. A member of the Florists' Transworld Delivery Association, Mr. Alexander does a high-volume business with the prepackaged F.T.D. bouquets - holiday basket and fireside basket arrangements, for example. He generally sells more than 1,400 such offerings each December.

title: TOM SELLECK STALKS HIS FUTURE
description: DESPITE A COLD THAT would put him to bed the next day, Tom Selleck was cheerfully standing amid fussing makeup men and gaffers, joking and mouthing his lines on a lush lawn below Diamond Head with the Hawaiian surf for background music. He was shooting yet another episode of ''Magnum, P.I.,'' this one a typically improbable tale about a brother and sister who are plotting the murder of their wealthy father.

title:
ART;
THE 'UNSEEN HAND' OF TYLER GRAPHICS
description: LEAD: KEN TYLER is a genuine impresario; he leads artists to a full-bodied expression of their talents and imagery in the historically demure medium of printmaking. As the director of Tyler Graphics, located from 1974 through 1986 in Bedford Village and more recently in Mount Kisco, Mr. Tyler prides himself as a ''backgrounder,'' always at the artist's elbow suggesting techniques or making wishes come true.

title: Gordon Hough Jr. And Holly E. Orr Are Wed in Darien
description: Holly Elizabeth Orr, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Orr Jr. of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church to Gordon Lord Hough Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hough of Darien. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence MacColl Horton, pastor emeritus of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Envoy of U.S. In Bonn Faces Wet Potatoes
description: A wet American Ambassador and a wet West German Foreign Minister are jointly equal in weight to 16 and a half sacks of wet potatoes.

title: Question Of the Week; Can Bo Jackson Succeed in 2 Sports?
description: The real question isn't can he do both, but can he play baseball. We all know he can play football. Consider 22 home runs and 56 r.b.i.'s before being benched for his high number of strikeouts (158). All sluggers strike out a lot, to name a couple on the all-time list, Mickey Mantle and Reggie Jackson. It will take a little time, but all Bo needs is a little fine-tuning. IRA BRAD LIEBMAN Lake Grove, L.I.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: SHE WANTED SOMETHING ELSE. By Megan Staffel. (North Point, $17.95.) Megan Staffel seems unable to resist the temptation to sentimentalize the artistic vocation in this, her first novel. In fact, her protagonist, Rose Ann Beech, is so self-consciously the artist that she has no sense of humor about herself, her work or the art scene (which is never actually depicted).

title: WASHINGTON GAINS INDEPENDENCE, 24-12
description: Chris Chandler threw for 234 yards and two touchdowns tonight, leading Washington to a 24-12 victory over Tulane in the Independence Bowl.

title: CAREY SET TO JOIN AN OLD LAW FIRM

description: CRATCHITT was walking down Fifth Avenue, looking harried, dodging holiday shoppers.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SAW MILL BRIDGES: PUBLIC WAS HEARD
description: WHEN state and Federal transportation officials last year withdrew a $12 million plan to build three bridges over the Saw Mill River Parkway, opponents of the project in Westchester County were jubilant.

title: Vanuatu
description: To the Editor: ''Two Worlds in the South Seas,'' describing Port Vila and Tanna in Vanuatu (Travel, Nov. 1), was like revisiting that locale, which Nicholas D. Kristof quite properly described as the only one he is ''so eager to return to.'' My wife and I still savor the four-day stopover we made some five years ago.

title: 'BIG APPLE' SHOP FINDS A NEW BRANCH
description: LEAD: WHEN word got out in October that the Metropolitan Museum of Art was planning to start a shop in Stamford, more than 150 people called the Stamford Town Center to ask when it would open, according to Patricia M. Milano, the museum's satellite shop manager.

title: DISSIDENTS STEP UP PROTESTS IN SEOUL
description: South Korean dissidents today stepped up their effort to overturn the results of the presidential election this week, but there were doubts about how much public support they could muster.

title: SHOCK THERAPY
description: Susan Squire deserves congratulations for her clear article on electroconvulsive therapy (''Shock Therapy's Return to Respectability,'' Nov. 22). ECT is the treatment of choice for certain severe forms of depression. Like other treatments, it has potential side effects, and patients should explore with their physicians the risks and benefits of treatment alternatives. ECT is not given without signed, informed consent.

title: Political Notes; D'Amato Seems to Waver on Backing of Dole
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato appears to be having second thoughts about his support of Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, for the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Marilee Payton Talman and Robert F. Elliott Wed
description: Marilee Payton Talman, a daughter of Mary Hicks Payton of Richmond and Leland Rodman Payton of La Jolla, Calif., was married yesterday to Robert Francis Elliott, the son of Mrs. John Raymond Elliott of Woodhaven, Queens, and the late Mr. Elliott. The Rev. Thomas Rightmyer performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan.

title: Redmen Triumph Easily
description: Niagara University's basketball team has been a problem for St. John's in recent years. The Purple Eagles were the only team, besides Georgetown, to beat the Redmen during the 1984-85 season - a year St. John's went to the Final Four and finished with a 31-4 record. Last season, St. John's barely notched an 8-point victory against Niagara, with a late run.

description: THE storm of conservative fury at Ronald Reagan may have subsided a bit, but, as one of the President's own men in the White House conceded late last week, ''There are some who are still in a real sour mood.''

description: LEAD: RESIDENTS of the Rocky Point area of Brookhaven Town are angry about a developer's proposal to build 57 homes on a golf course.

description: EVERY workday for the last two weeks, Debra Ingram of Highland Park has left her sleeping year-old daughter with a babysitter for six hours so she can take a state-financed computer training course.

title: TOYS: THE MESSAGE DEPENDS ON THE STYLE
description: TWICE last Christmas Eve my conscience was prodded by people who make it their business to do such things. Both times I agreed with the message, but was silent in my assent. Their method was just not for me.

NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WILKES-BARRE, PA.;
A 225-Foot Tall 'Angel' of Arts
description: LEAD: PLANS are moving forward here for a 20-story apartment and office building to provide a dependable source of income for a downtown performing arts center. The 225-foot-high building would be the tallest in the city.

title: Linda Davis Wed to A. A. Houghton 3d
description: Linda Livingston Davis, a daughter of Goodhue Livingston Jr. of Wainscott, L.I., and the late Lorna M. Livingston of Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York yesterday to Arthur Amory Houghton 3d, the son of Mr. Houghton Jr. of Queenstown, Md., and the late Ellen Crenshaw Houghton. The Rev. Alanson B. Houghton 2d, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Jazz
description: The Henry Threadgill Sextett is a minature orchestra, with strings (bass and cello), brass (trumpet and trombone), percussion (two drummers) and reed instruments (Mr. Threadgill, primarily on alto saxophone). For much of the 1980's, the Sextett has delivered some of Mr. Threadgill's wittiest, most boisterous music. The Sextett draws on jazz as old as New Orleans dirges and as new as free jazz; it also can sound like a circus band, a calypso group or a chamber ensemble, often in the course of a single Threadgill composition.

title: Lebanese Christians Strike, Protesting Arrests by Syria
description: Christians went on strike in East Beirut today to protest the arrest of Christians in northern Lebanon by Syrian troops searching for the killer of a comrade.

title: Karen Kuritzkes Wed To James Lee Greene
description: Temple Emanuel in Great Neck, L.I., was the setting last evening for the marriage of Karen Rebecca Kuritzkes, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Fedor A. Kuritzkes of Jamaica Estates, Queens, to James Lee Greene, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Greene of New York. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony.

description: THE TOMMYKNOCKERS By Stephen King. 558 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: FINE GALLIC TOUCHES IN GREAT NECK
description: MOST of the great restaurants are chef-owned. Long Island's are no exception. Often, it's husband in the kitchen, wife in the dining room and satisfied diners at the tables. Le Marquis in Great Neck takes the formula one step further: not only is the wife in the dining room, so are the brother-in-law, sister-in-law and mother-in-law. This is a French family combination that clicks.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
ENVIRONMENTAL CLEANUPS: PUTTING STRESS ON WHO SHOULD BEAR THE REPONSIBILITY
description: LEAD: AMID growing criticism from commercial and real-estate interests over the administration of the Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act (ECRA), the state's Department of Environmental Protection has agreed to adopt wholesale revisions in the regulatory framework of the controversial law.

title: Minimal Miking Spreads
description: IN AN INDUSTRY FOND OF promotional fanfare, it is surprising that an important new trend in recording remains largely unheralded. This unusual reticence may reflect the fact that the new recording method is still something of a minority cult practiced mainly by smaller companies. But what they have accomplished seems to please many critical listeners.

title: New York Honors U.S. Judge Who Has 37 Years of Service
description: Judge Edward Weinfeld of the Federal District Court in Manhattan has been selected to receive the La Guardia Medal, New York City's highest award.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bullets 109, Bulls 96: Bernard King scored 28 points and Moses Malone added 20 for Washington last night. King scored 8 points as the Bullets built an 89-78 lead 1 minute 45 seconds into the final quarter. He then added two baskets in an 8-2 Washington run that gave the Bullets a 99-84 lead with 6:31 to play. Michael Jordan scored 30 points to lead Chicago, which lost its fourth straight road game.(AP) 76ers 95, Mavericks 90: Cliff Robinson, who had left the game in the first half with a groin injury, scored 20 of his 22 points in the second half, including 10 straight in the third quarter, for Philadelphia. The 76ers have won six of their last seven games. Blackman led Dallas with 25 points and Sam Perkins added 17. The 76ers also signed Bob Thornton to a one-year contract, the team announced yesterday. The 6-foot-10-inch, 225-pound center averaged 2.4 points in seven games for the Knicks this season before he was waived on Dec. 16. (AP) Hawks 130, Jazz 124: Dominique Wilkins scored 46 points, including a tie-breaking rebound dunk in overtime, and John Battle forced the extra period with a 3-point basket at the buzzer as Atlanta posted its fifth consecutive victory. The Jazz appeared headed for their second road victory in 11 outings after Rickey Green hit one of two free throws with eight seconds left for a 118-115 lead. Wilkins missed on a 3-pointer, but the Jazz knocked the ball out of bounds with one second remaining. Spud Webb then passed to Battle in the left corner for the basket that forced the overtime. Darrell Griffith led the Jazz with 32 points. He scored 17 of his points in the third quarter, including 15 in a row.(AP) BOXING Whitaker, Ramirez Win: Pernell Whitaker of the United States and Jose-Luis Ramirez of Mexico scored easy victories in Paris last night, setting up a World Boxing Council lightweight championship bout next March 12. Whitaker, who won an Olympic gold medal in the 132-pound division in 1984, stopped Davey Montana of the United States with 46 seconds left in the fourth round. Whitaker is now 15-0 as a pro after winning 193 fights as an amateur. Ramirez, the W.B.C. lightweight champion, knocked out John Rafuse of the United States at 2:24 of the fourth round and raised his career record to 101-5.(AP) HORSE RACING Cougarized Triumphs: Cougarized took the lead after entering the stretch and scored a two-length victory in the $128,600 Nashua Stakes for 2-year-olds at Aqueduct. Blew by Em finished well along the rail to be runner-up. Conquisto's Delite, a son of Conquistador Cielo who had won both of his previous starts, raced dully throughout and finished ninth in the field of 12. Cougarized, a son of Cougar II and the Sir Ivor mare Jolie Jolie, was ridden by Jose Santos and covered the mile and a sixteenth in 1:46 over the inner dirt track. He scored his third victory in nine career starts and his first in stakes company. Cougarized earned $77,160 for his owner, Lloyd R. French Jr. His trainer, D. Wayne Lukas, leads the nation in stakes victories. Cougarized returned $8.80 for $2 to win as the second betting choice. HOCKEY Canadians Win on Soviet Ice: Ken Berry scored the game's last two goals as Canada beat the Soviet Union, 3-2 last night in the third round of the Izvestia tournament in Moscow, marking the first time in 15 years that a Canadian team has won a game in the Soviet Union. In other third-round matches, Finland beat West Germany, 8-2, and Sweden edged Czechoslovakia, 3-2.(AP) SKIING West German Takes Slalom: Christa Kinshofer of West Germany scored her first World Cup victory in eight years yesterday by capturing the women's slalom at Piancavallo, Italy. Kinshofer, who rejoined the German squad this year after four seasons with the Dutch team, skied through thick fog down the Sauc course in a winning aggregate of 1 minute 32.07 seconds. Patricia Chauvet of France was runner-up, 21-hundredths of a second behind. Beth Madsen, the only American finisher, was 21st.(AP) Svan First in Cross-Country: Gunde Svan of Sweden pushed through driving rain and soft snow to win a 15-kilometer men's race at Davos, Switzerland, and take the lead in the season's World Cup standing after three events. Svan posted a winning time of 43 minutes 4.7 seconds, almost 13 seconds ahead of Pal Mikkelsplass of Norway. Jan Ottoson of Sweden finished third, 25 seconds behind Svan. (AP) Austrian First; Tomba Streak Ends: Helmut Mayer of Austria captured his first World Cup victory ever in the giant slalom, and Alberto Tomba's winning streak ended when the Italian fell in a meet at Kranjskacora, Yugoslavia. Tomba had scored four consecutive giant slalom and slalom victories. He fell in the first run right after achieving the best intermediate time. Mayer clocked the best time in both runs for an aggregate of 2 minutes 27.08 seconds. Tomba managed to hold his lead in the World Cup standing with 100 points, 21 ahead of Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland, who placed second in 2:27.72. No Americans qualified among the 30 skiers for the second heat. (AP) GOLF Palmer-Walker Take Lead: Arnold Palmer and Colleen Walker combined for a nine-under-par 62 yesterday to take a one-shot lead after the second round of the Mazda Champions team tournament in Montego Bay, Jamaica. Nancy Lopez and Miller Barber were in second place at 128, one stroke ahead of the first-round leaders, Chris Johnson and Butch Baird, heading into the final round today. Despite strong winds, 10 of the 12 teams shot 65 or under. (AP)

title: To the Top of Africa
description: IT began as a pilgrimage, a sentimental voyage to Africa's northernmost cape to complement earlier voyages that had led to another cape, far to the south, at a continent's tip. But it ended more as uncharted meandering along Tunisia's less beaten tracks, beach and forest and antiquity, a journey freckled with surprise and discovery: how, for instance, to prepare and cook a brik; or how they hunt wild boar in the winter with dogs, beaters and shotguns in the uplands back from the coast. Then there were the carpets, made of wool, bought over mint tea in an old and magical house in the Tunis bazaar; and the painting of pheasants, done on mirror glass; and, at the end, after a chance turning through plantations of blue gum and pine, the unfurling of surf-scrubbed beaches at Cap Serrat, where there was no one and nothing save wind and white sand and the angry legions of the waves.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE NEW BREED. By W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $16.95.) This seventh volume of W. E. B. Griffin's ''Brotherhood of War'' series brings back many of the same characters whose military careers have been delineated in the first six. The series is in the platoon-movie genre - one of everything. There is, for example, the Jewish soldier who is both a decorated hero and an intelligence officer so good at his job that he hobnobs with President Johnson in the Oval Office. Also included is the spoiled rich kid who turns into a first-class officer. Earlier volumes were about fighting in World War II, postwar Greece, Korea and Vietnam. In all these conflicts, the adversaries were not only the historic ones but also the American brass who refused to consider the modern improvements being touted by the novel's intrepid band of military brothers, such as new tactics for armor and the helicopter. In ''The New Breed,'' the scene is the Congo in 1964, and again the enemy is a dual one: both the Congolese rebels, who are described in unrelievedly brutal terms, and the ''hand wringers'' in the State Department and C.I.A. who prevent fighting Americans from mowing down blacks to rescue American and Belgian hostages. What saves the book - and the series - from mediocrity is a generous ration of detailed and fascinating descriptions of weapons, tactics, Green Beret training, Army life and battle. The Brotherhood members themselves, although painted in primary colors, are still interesting characters and are usually possessed of intelligence and humor. Their womenfolk are also well drawn, but so brave and cheerful that they make one's teeth ache. In sum, ''The New Breed'' is absorbing, salted-peanuts reading. Mr. Griffin is an Army veteran himself, and his proficiency on the word processor convinces one that old soldiers never die, they just write away.

Answer: Amtrak intends to put the new, prototype Viewliner cars - two sleeping cars and a dining car - on the Auto Train this winter. The original proposal was for Jan. 1 but the start was postponed and this month an official said they were unlikely to come into service before late February. Their performance and reception on the Auto Train will be studied for some months before the three cars are transferred for continuing experimental use on other routes. The prototypes were designed by Amtrak and assembled at its plant in Beech Grove, Ind., with the long-term goal of substituting new equipment for Amtrak's aging and rehabilitated Heritage fleet.

Mr. Boesky could have been sentenced to up to five years and ordered to pay a $250,000 fine. But Judge Morris E. title: Stage: 'Acts of Faith'
description: GIVEN a set-up situation that has only one way to go and the playwright's determination to get there, ''Acts of Faith'' maintains a surprisingly high level of tension for much of the way, before collapsing into a lesson in Human Relations. Marilyn Felt's play, which opened yesterday at the Mosaic Theater, takes place in the small upper cabin of a hijacked jet, where Barbara, a light-traveling California psychologist in her 30's, who has been separated from the other passengers because she is the only Jew on board, is being guarded by young Ahmed, a devout Moslem who kisses his gun a lot.

title: Paraguay's Most Famous Prisoner Is 'Free'
description: Three days after completing a 25-year jail sentence, Paraguay's longest-serving political prisoner was freed from his cell in Asuncion today and ordered confined to a provincial town for 30 days.

title: Thousands March Against Homelessness
description: Carrying candles and protest signs, several thousand people marched through midtown Manhattan yesterday, criticizing city, state and Federal policies that they said had contributed to homelessness in New York City.

title: Jets' Fans Chant: 'Joe Must Go'
description: THE chant has begun. The chant that was inevitable now that a three-game losing streak has assured the Jets of not qualifying for the Super Bowl XXII playoffs.

title: New Policy Adopted On the Use of Babies As Donors of Organs
description: The medical center that pioneered infant heart transplants has announced a policy to make sure anencephalic babies, those born with most of the brain missing, are brain-dead before they are used as organ donors.

title: Haiti's Gloom Kills the Spirit Of a Holiday
description: Sitting on a stool pitched against his shanty on a hill overlooking this threadbare capital, Jean Delarouche sniffed and spat as he watched a group of children kicking a soccer ball along the half-paved street.

title: A Wry Survivor, Elaine Stritch Returns to Film
description: Long before the movie was even released, people were talking about Elaine Stritch's performance in Woody Allen's new film, ''September.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * C. R. Bard Inc., Murray Hill, N.J., a maker of surgical products, elected George A. Davis executive vice president and Terence C. Brady Jr. senior vice president.

title: Eagles Win, 38-27, And Eliminate Jets
description: The Jets' season lasted just long enough to tantalize and confound everyone again - players, their coach and their fans.

title: Helpful Attention and Unflattering Jokes Mark the Press's Reaction to Hart
description: Gary Hart's return to Presidential politics set off an explosion of media attention, with everyone from George Will, the columnist, to Johnny Carson, the comedian, commenting on the move.

title: Business and the Law; Compromise Near In Delaware
description: AFTER more than six months of speculation and debate, a committee of Delaware's bar association is on the verge of approving new rules governing corporate takeovers, lawyers say.

title: Despite New Laws, Students Find Ways to Drink
description: Laws making 21 the legal drinking age, intended to combat drunken driving among young people, are having little effect on limiting drinking among college students, according to recent studies and interviews with university officials and students.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Echoes of a Chess Match
description: Gary Kasparov is departing this city in southern Spain in the same manner as he arrived in October, triumphant and controversial, his world chess title firmly in hand.

title: Miss Hartocollis, A Reporter, Weds
description: Anemona Maria Hartocollis, a reporter for Newsday, and Joshua Steven Barbanel, a reporter for The New York Times, were married at a Manhattan loft yesterday by Rabbi Rolando Matalon.

title: Islanders Won't Panic
description: Kelly Hrudey, the repeated victim of a Philadelphia Flyer tactic he termed ''crease-bashing,'' scowled when asked about the difficulties of withstanding the proximity favored by Flyer forwards.

title: Advertising; Foote, Cone to Handle Holland America Line
description: Foote, Cone & Belding in San Francisco has taken over the Holland America Line account from Elgin Syferd, a Seattle agency. Billings have been reported to be more than $10 million.

title: No Sugar Bowl II
description: Syracuse University will be sending two football teams to the Sugar Bowl.

title: Judge Quits Intel-NEC Case
description: The judge presiding over the long-running legal battle between the Intel Corporation and the NEC Corporation of Japan has disqualified himself from the case and vacated an earlier ruling that was considered favorable to the American semiconductor industry.

title: Let American Indians Make Their Own Mistakes; Sovereign Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: Border Battle Reported Along Iran-Iraq Front
description: Iraq and Iran reported a border attack by Iranian soldiers, but the relatively small number of combatants said to have been involved indicated that this was not the major offensive that Iran has been reported planning for months.

title: Celtics Crush 76ers
description: Mark Acres, a rookie, and Larry Bird and Kevin McHale sparked a 73-point first half, and the Boston Celtics breezed to a 124-87 victory over Philadelphia tonight, foiling the 76ers' bid to take over first place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Flaw Sought in Shuttle Test
description: Engineers for the space agency and Morton Thiokol Inc. worked today to unravel a frustrating series of breakdowns that forced postponement of the second full-scale test-firing Saturday of the redesigned booster rocket for the space shuttle.

title: Supernova Offers Clue on Antimatter
description: The exploding star that flashed to life over the Southern Hemisphere early this year has inspired a clever approach to one of the most baffling questions of modern astronomy: how much of the universe is made of the type of matter found on earth, and how much consists of a rare, mysterious substance that scientists call antimatter.

title: Dravo Selling Key Businesses
description: Facing losses of more than $75 million this year and operating under new management, the Dravo Corporation said Friday that it was selling its engineering, construction and energy businesses to concentrate on limestone mining and other quarrying.

title: INSIDE
description: Ferry Sinks Near Manila

title: Yankees Almost Come Up Empty
description: Once upon a time, away back in the mid-1970's, if George Steinbrenner decided he wanted a player, he more often than not got him, whether striking with lightning-like quickness in the trading mart or with checkbook-like movement in the free-agent market. In the past two weeks, though, the Yankees tried unsuccessfully to get Dave Parker, Alfredo Griffin, Julio Franco, Floyd Bannister, Zane Smith, Mike Davis, Ron Hassey and Frank Tanana.

title: Daddy, Let's Get a Dog (Contd.)
description: LEAD: There's one thing I don't like about Christmas. Each year at this time, I'm made to feel bad when my children renew their request for a dog. I like animals. I really do. It's just that, together, we don't seem to have much luck.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about new cookbooks misstated a title. The book is ''Reading Between the Recipes,'' by Leslie Land (Yankee Books, $15.95).

title: How the Services Obey Orders
description: Caspar Weinberger spent more and supervised less than any other Secretary of Defense. His successor, Frank Carlucci, is reaping the fruit of this indiscipline.

title: South Korean Election Brightens Hopes
description: The election last week in South Korea appears to have had a favorable result for the International Olympic Committee and the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul.

title: Jay Cohen, Lawyer, Weds Miss Christman, a Student
description: Jennifer Christman, a daughter of Naomi Sacks Christman of Brooklyn Heights and Robert A. Christman of New York, was married yesterday to Jay Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Cohen of Brooklyn. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated at the Americas Society in New York.

title: Chinese Students Across U.S. Protest an Arrest in Shanghai
description: Chinese students at many colleges and universities across the United States have signed a petition to their Government on behalf of an American-educated molecular biologist who was arrested nearly a year ago in Shanghai during a crackdown on political dissent.

title: Advertising; Star of Ad Research To Become a Consultant
description: Rena Bartos, one of the stars of advertising research, is moving from the J. Walter Thompson phase of her life, where she has spent 21 years, to the consultant phase. Mail can reach her at 3 East 54th Street in New York.

title: On Course to the Whitbread
description: Skip Novak remembers the incident clearly. It was a day in August two years ago when the keel fell off the 77-foot maxi-yacht he was sailing near the southwestern coast of England. Water came rushing through the hatches as the boat turned belly up.

title: Let American Indians Make Their Own Mistakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Prison Riots Traced To Secrecy Obsession
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. EXPORT BANK SEEKS $3 BILLION
description: A Government agency that helps finance American exports is incurring such losses that its capital will be wiped out within nine months, and it will ask Congress for a $3 billion bailout next month, its chief executive says.

title: Angola War: South Africa Presses Role
description: Standing among stacks of wooden ammunition crates Sgt. Antonio Francisco da Silva offered tips for shooting down South African warplanes.

title: A Remarkable Athlete
description: By major college standards, Tony Dawson of Florida State is neither a particularly quick basketball player nor an impressive jumper. But by any measure, Dawson is truly a remarkable athlete.

title: The Face of Rage in Gaza: Frustrated Youth
description: The ''shebab,'' hot-eyed, desperate, angry young men, were gathered outside the tiny cinderblock dwelling - it would be hard to call it a house - mourning Abdul Salam Fteihah, who had been shot dead by the Israeli Army.

title: It's Payton's Day, But Not the Bears'
description: Walter Payton bid a bittersweet goodbye today to the Soldier Field crowds that watched his career unfold for the Chicago Bears, turning in a 79-yard, two-touchdown effort that was his best so far in a sometimes-trying final season.

title: Opera: Mascagni's 'Amico Fritz' at Kennedy Center
description: ''L'Amico Fritz'' is the second of Mascagni's 17 operas, and, as far as I know them, also the second best. In some ways its craftsmanship and tangy harmonies may even make it preferable to ''Cavalleria Rusticana,'' which made the young composer's fame in 1890. ''Fritz'' is a treasurable piece, completely different from its predecessor: the trailblazer of verismo took Bellini's pastoral ''Sonnambula'' as his model here, and made something touching and memorable. The Washington Opera revived it Saturday night as its first venture in the Kennedy Center's 1,000-seat Eisenhower Theater. Opportunities to hear the work are rare and the performance was mostly pleasing, so a visit is recommended to anyone who will be in the capital between now and Jan. 17.

title: Venezuela's View on Oil
description: Venezuelan President Jaime Lusinchi has said he does not expect world oil prices to collapse, describing their current slide as a passing phenomenon in an unstable, manipulated market.

title: Outdoors: Gifts Are Mine And More Will Come
description: Gifts I would unwrap each Christmas are bound in twine I cannot always cut in time to join the caroling; twine tough as mindless dread - or wisteria that chokes the tree it climbs - it must be slashed away each season.

title: Report Criticizes Nuclear Panel For Deficiencies on Safety Issues
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission came under renewed Congressional attack today in a sharply critical year-end report by the House subcommittee assigned to oversee its operations.

title: Advertising; People
description: * James Aaby, William Chororos, Philip Guthrie, Richard Mahan and Howard Stein have been named executive vice presidents on the creative side of Backer Spielvogel Bates, where James Keller and J. Edmund Keating have been made senior vice presidents.

title: A $3 Billion Question for Pennzoil
description: With the long-sought settlement pact with Texaco Inc. set to be filed Monday, J. Hugh Liedtke stands at the twilight of a remarkable career of oil patch dealings with a challenge few industrialists could face in their wildest dreams: What to do with $3 billion.

title: Banesto Names Lawyer As Chairman and Chief
description: Mario Conde, a 39-year-old lawyer, became Spain's youngest bank chairman and chief executive last week. Banco Espanol de Credito, which is known as Banesto and is Spain's second-largest bank, named him chairman at the height of its battle with Banco de Bilbao, Spain's third-largest bank, which had launched a hostile takeover bid for Banesto on Nov. 30.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target dates for major economic indicators scheduled for release this week. Monday None Tuesday Durable Goods Nov. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday None

title: Texaco's Plan On Lawsuits
description: Facing a host of shareholder lawsuits stemming from its dispute with Pennzoil, Texaco executives have sought to protect themselves in two provisions of a reorganization plan that will be filed today in a Federal bankruptcy court.

title: State's Role Key Issue For Brazil
description: With inflation again roaring out of control here, Luiz Carlos Bresser Pereira's job early last week was to play St. George to that perennial dragon. He picked ''fiscal shock'' as his weapon and prepared to do battle.

title: Water Dispute Stalls L.I. Hotel's Plan
description: As far as Daniel Davis is concerned, the faucets and sprinklers at the Marriott Hotel here have been flowing a little too freely.

title: Sleepy Hollow Journal; To Trainer, Llamas Are Not Just Fad
description: In the last six years, 30 llamas have graduated from Helen Bodington's obedience school at the top of a hill in this tiny community near San Francisco.

title: For Zimbabwe Whites, Armed Watch
description: As Jean Kirby made gravy for a lamb roast dinner, her hand grazed the Uzi submachinegun resting amid a clutter of herbs and vegetables on the kitchen counter.

title: John Fleming, A Book Dealer, Dies at Age 77
description: John F. Fleming, a rare-book dealer and collector who for 30 years dominated the antiquarian manuscript market, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: Titian Lent in U.S.-Soviet Deal
description: Among the lesser-known byproducts of the recent meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev is an agreement involving objects of a conspicuously peaceable sort. While the summit meeting was being arranged, United States and Soviet officials hastily drew up a plan to exchange paintings. As a result, ''St. Sebastian,'' an extraordinary picture by Titian, recently arrived here at the National Gallery, on loan from the Hermitage in Leningrad through Feb. 15. In return, the National Gallery will send El Greco's ''Laocoon'' in 1989 as part of a celebration honoring the Soviet museum's 225th anniversary.

title: Two Alabama Officers Slain By Man Who Then Kills Self
description: A man killed two police officers before apparently taking his own life Saturday, police officials said.

title: Dr. Lienhard Bergel, Opponent of Nazism
description: Dr. Lienhard Bergel, a retired professor of comparative literature at the graduate school of City University of New York, died Dec. 14 at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after being struck by an automobile in Port Washington, L.I., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Ford Payment In South Africa
description: The Ford Motor Company's former subsidiary in South Africa confirmed that it had received about 200 million rand, or about $103 million, from the American auto maker as part of its disinvestment arrangement. Leslie Boyd, chairman of the

title: Advertising; International Marketing Monthly Due
description: DAVID E. MOORE, a grandson of the publisher Joseph Pulitzer, is bankrolling the startup of a publication aimed at encouraging businesses in the Northeast to market internationally.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 21, 1987: MONDAY Bunker Hill Inc Secs NBD Bancorp Horizon Bancorp TUESDAY Signet Banking Corp WEDNESDAY Boston Edison

title: DOCTORS STRETCH RULES ON AIDS DRUG
description: Defying official recommendations, a growing number of doctors who treat carriers of the AIDS virus are prescribing a powerful, potentially toxic drug even before the patients develop serious signs of disease.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 28 about the retirement of Thomas L. Sheer, assistant director in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office, misidentified the private company he will join in January. It is Tillinghast, a Towers Perrin Company.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You do the best you can do under the circumstances.'' - House Speaker Jim Wright, on an agreement to provide $8.1 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels. [ A1:6. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Dec. 10 about companies that assist employees caring for elderly relatives misidentified a sponsor of an information and referral service for working people. It is J. P. Morgan & Company, not Morgan Stanley.

title: A Brooklyn Guide To Childrens' Activities
description: For Brooklyn youngsters (and parents) who have time on their hands, a free guide to activities in the borough for children is now available.

title: Cinemette Theaters Sold
description: The Cinemette Corporation has sold its 160 movie theaters for an undisclosed price to Cinema World Inc., a Cinemette vice president, George Stern, said. Cinema World is owned by Matthew Bronfman of New York, son of the head of the Seagram Company; Robert Malina of Malina, Bodner & Associates, the New York investment bankers, and Jeffrey Lewine, Cinema World's chairman and chief executive. Cinemette is privately owned by Mr. Stern; Ernest Stern, his cousin, and Richard Stern, Ernest's son. It operated theaters in Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia.

title: Advertising; HBM/Creamer Lands Another McDonald's Job
description: HBM/Creamer in Boston, owned by Britain's WCRS Group, has just gotten another McDonald's operators association account from Arnold & Company, also of Beantown, which has a number of them.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Staring at the Soviet Past
description: The deepest change in the Soviet Union is not in politics. As Americans who see the current Soviet film ''Repentance'' are finding out, it's in the arts.

title: A Proper Form Helps Provide Pace, Comfort and Efficiency
description: AT last month's New York City Marathon, all eyes were fixed on 27-year-old Pat Petersen of Ronkonkoma, L.I., who boldly took the lead and held it for 14 miles before finishing fourth in 2 hours 12 minutes 3 seconds. But it was not just Peterson's aggressive racing that commanded attention. It was his running form as well. He looked awful.

title: Market Place; Lukewarm Views Of Oil Stocks
description: SINKING oil prices customarily translate into a curb on inflation, and last week this interpretation sent stock and bond prices bounding ahead. Wall Street took its cue from recent meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries after it became apparent that the group was unable to stem overproduction and price discounting.

title: Theater: Don DeLillo's 'Day Room'
description: DON DELILLO is one of the most esteemed novelists in the country, so when ''The Day Room,'' his first play, unfolds at the Manhattan Theater Club, one keeps hoping against hope it is not what it seems to be: ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' as it might be rewritten by a pretentious undergraduate who has just completed the midterm, if not all the required reading, for a survey course in the works of Pirandello, Beckett and Stoppard.

title:
SCHOOL TRACK;
Loughlin Games Find a New Home
description: LEAD: Nnenna Lynch and Sharon Moore posted impressive victories in girls' events while Joe Tuttle and Sam Rice were outstanding among the boys' winners yesterday in the 34th annual Bishop Loughlin indoor track and field games, at Manhattan College's Draddy Gym in the Bronx.

title: Hearst Books Hires Kaminsky
description: Howard Kaminsky, ousted as executive vice president from Random House two months ago in a power struggle that stunned the book publishing industry, is to become president of the Hearst Corporation's trade book group - a unit that includes William Morrow, predominantly a publisher of hardcover books, and Avon Books, a mass market paperback publisher.

title: Hart Leaps Ahead in Iowa Poll
description: A poll published today shows Gary Hart has jumped to the head of the Democratic Presidential field in Iowa and knocked away half the support for previous poll leader, Senator Paul Simon of Illinois.

title: Timely Gusts Keep Patriots' Hopes Aloft
description: The New England Patriots used a wind-blown touchdown, a wind-induced interception and an aggressive defense that limited Buffalo to only 148 net yards today to beat the Bills, 13-7.

title: Dance: Ailey Troupe, In Works on Tradition
description: WHAT is ''the black tradition''? A program devoted to it, presented by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Wednesday at City Center, suggested that the tradition or heritage is one of strong women and playfully spirited men, of profound suffering and equally profound hope - and of the capacity to celebrate each in vital, entertaining theater and dance.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The Export-Import Bank will seek a $3 billion bailout next month. It is incurring such losses that its capital will be wiped out within nine months, its president has warned. For the latest fiscal year, its loss was a record $387 million. [ Page A1. ] Congress approved an emergency spending bill to keep the Government in business through midnight on Monday. [ A17. ] More information about the market for Treasury securities should be available, according to a G.A.O. report. [ D1. ] Whatever holiday shoppers are cutting back on, it is not toys. Despite gloomy earlier predictions, the Toys ''R'' Us chain is pleased with its retail sales this Christmas season. [ D3. ] COMPANIES Figuring out what to do with $3 billion is Pennzoil's challenge and that of its chairman, J. Hugh Liedtke. [ D1. ] When it emerges from bankruptcy proceedings next year, Texaco will have to address fundamental business issues shunted aside during its four-year legal battle. [ D1. ] Five top E. F. Hutton officers will collectively receive millions of dollars in compensation after the firm merges with Shearson Lehman, according to documents filed with the S.E.C. [ D1. ] Jay A. Pritzker's chances of taking over Pan Am are dim because of disunity among its five unions on concessions and disagreement by the board and management on the viability of the bid. [ D3. ] Singer said it would accept a bid from Paul A. Bilzerian if he could prove he had the financing for the $1.05 billion deal. [ D2. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Brazil's inefficient public sector had stymied Finance Minister Bresser Pereira, who resigned last week. [ D8. ] Sanofi sees A. H. Robins as ''a good fit.'' The French pharmaceutial company is flexing its young muscles in its bid for control of the maker of Robitussin and Chap Stick. [ D8. ] Mutual funds have arrived in India and are being strongly backed by the Government as safe investments. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS New rules on corporate takeovers may soon be approved by Delaware's state bar association. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Some analysts revised their views on oil stocks downward following OPEC's recent meeting in Vienna. Market Place. [ D6. ] The bond market has shifted its attention from the dangers of high inflation to the prospects of low inflation. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Advertising; New Name in Chicago
description: The Chicago office of Grey Advertising, which has been acquired by GGK Holding, a European company, will be retitled HFC & Lois/GGK, getting its name from its three top people; its sister company, Lois Pitts Gershon Ponn/GGK, and its new parent company.

title: Karin Schattman Weds Richard E. Tanenbaum
description: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Karin Jette Schattman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Rains Schattman Jr. of Hewlett Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Ethan Tanenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Tanenbaum of Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman and Cantor David Benedict.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Red and Leggy Visitors
description: In the spirit of the season, the National Zoological Park received 10 Japanese spider crabs, notable for their bright red and white shells, as a gift from All Nippon Airways over the weekend.

title: Sotheby's Good Quarter
description: Sotheby's auction house, which in November set the world record price of $53.9 million for a painting, with the sale of Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises,'' announced Friday its best-ever fourth-quarter results. It reported worldwide auction sales of $:340 million, or about $622 million, for the latest three months, up 2.7 percent over the corresponding period last year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SKIING Tomba Leads Sweep: Alberto Tomba of Italy, who threw away his birthday cake after his four-race World Cup winning streak was broken, began a new streak yesterday, leading a 1-2 Italian sweep in a men's slalom in Kranjska Gora, Yugoslavia, and improving his lead in the World Cup ski standing. The victory, Tomba's fifth this season, gave him 125 points, 34 ahead of Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland. Zurbriggen, the defending World Cup champion, placed fourth here. Richard Pramotton finished second and Guenther Mader of Austria was third. Tomba, starting in the second group, was timed in 1 minute 46.35 seconds. Pramotton was clocked in 1:46.95 and Mader in 1:47.27. Tomba fell in the first heat of a giant slalom Saturday - his 21st birthday - ending his streak of four consecutive victories. The spill prevented Tomba from equaling the record of six straight victories set by Sweden's Ingemar Stenmark during the 1977-78 season.(AP) Frenchwoman Is First: Catherine Quittet of France, returning from a serious knee injury, upset the Swiss favorites yesterday in Piancavallo, Italy, to win her first World Cup giant slalom. The 23-year-old skier Quittet, whose previous and only World Cup victory was a Super-G in Prfonten, West Germany last Jan. 17, was the fastest in the first heat. She had the second-best time in the second run for a winning aggregate of 2 minutes 27.32 seconds. (AP) SKI JUMPING Nykanen Soars Farthest: Matti Nykanen of Finland, the only man to jump more than 100 meters in the competition, won the 90-meter jump in a World Cup meet in Sapporo, Japan. Nykanen, a gold medalist at the 1984 Sarajevo Winter Olympics, leaped 112.5 and 103.5 meters and scored 202.4 points, nearly 40 points more than the runner-up, Jiri Parma of Czechoslovakia. (AP) HOCKEY Canada 2, West Germany 1: Ken Yaremchuk's goal at 13:05 of the third period gave Canada a victory over West Germany in the fourth round of the Izvestia tournament in Moscow. The Canadians, who defeated the Soviet Union, 3-2, on Saturday, have a 3-1 won-lost record for 6 points. The Germans are 0-4 and are in last place in the standing. In other matches, the Soviet Union defeated Czechoslovakia, 5-3, and Sweden and Finland played to a 2-2 tie. Canada leads by 1 point with Sweden and the Soviet team tied for second place with 5 points; each has a 2-1-1 record. The Czechs (2-2) and Finland (1-1-2) are tied for fourth with 4 points. (AP) TENNIS Swedes Dominate Davis Cup: Anders Jarryd and Mats Wilander completed a 5-0 Swedish sweep over India in the Davis Cup final by winning singles matches in straight sets yesterday in Goteborg, Sweden. Jarryd, who replaced Stefan Edberg in the final, defeated Ramesh Krishnan, 6-4, 6-3. Wilander beat Vijay Amritraj, 6-2, 6-0, on the indoor clay courts. The Swedish team won the Davis Cup for the fourth time since 1975.(AP) HORSE RACING Record for Tejano: Tejano scored a 2 1/4-length victory over Purdue King in the $1 million Hollywood Futurity at Hollywood Park yesterday to become the richest 2-year-old thoroughbred in history. Regal Classic took third. Tejano's stablemate, Success Express, winner of the Breeders' Cup Juvenile a month ago, finished sixth in the field of eight. Laffit Pincay kept Tejano, third choice in the wagering, close behind pace-setting Purdue King, and the colt surged ahead with a quarter-mile to go. Finishing the mile over a fast track in 1:34 3/ 5, Tejano returned $8.80 for $2 to win. His victory was worth $495,000 and increased his 1987 earnings to $1,177,189.(AP) GOLF Barber, Lopez Set Record: Miller Barber and Nancy Lopez combined for their second straight eight-under-par 63 yesterday for a 54-hole record total of 191 to win the Mazda Champions tournament in Montego Bay, Jamaica. The winners divided $500,000. Arnold Palmer and Colleen Walker, who led Barber and Lopez by one stroke after the second round, finished second with a 67 for 194. Next were Orville Moody and Jan Stephenson and Bruce Crampton and Betsy King, each at 196. Barber had three birdies and Lopez two on the first five holes. At the par-4 ninth hole, Palmer and Walker each shot a double bogey. Second place was worth $100,000. (AP)

title: CONTRAS ATTACK IN EAST NICARAGUA
description: A spokesman for the Nicaraguan rebels said today that the contras opened their biggest offensive in the seven-year-old war against the Sandinista Government today, on the eve of truce talks here.

title: 'Claymation Christmas,' On CBS
description: TONIGHT'S half-hour special ''A Claymation Christmas Celebration,'' on CBS at 8:30, offers telling testimony to the power of a television commerical.

title: Stopgap Appropriation Bill Approved
description: Meeting in a rare Sunday session, Congress late today approved an emergency spending bill designed to keep the Federal Government in business through midnight on Monday.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Ho, Ho, Hometowns
description: Also in the spirit of the season, the United States Geological Survey over at the Department of the Interior has ginned up a computer search of its Geographic Names Information System to document the jolly prevalence of holiday-related names all over this great land.

title: Swamped In New Jersey
description: THE news spread quickly on that cool autumn evening in October 1976. The New York Nets, as they were known then, were on the West Coast, beginning their first season in the National Basketball Association. It was supposed to be a time for celebration for the team from a maligned league that played with a ball that critics said belonged on a beach, not a basketball court. But for the Nets, membership in the established N.B.A. had taken a heavy toll.

title: Palestinian Deaths Strain Israel's Ties With Egypt
description: Israel's relations with Egypt, the only Arab country with which it has signed a peace treaty, have become increasingly strained as a result of the violence that has left at least 16 Palestinians dead in the last 12 days.

title: Article 036887 -- No Title
description: California has raised the minimum wage in the state to $4.25 an hour, an action that might spur other efforts around the nation to increase the basic pay level.

title: Rabbi Leo Jung, Spiritual Leader Of New York Jewish Center, Dies
description: Rabbi Leo Jung, a prominent Orthodox Jewish leader, and for 65 years the spiritual leader of the Jewish Center of New York, died at St. Clare's Hospital and Health Center Saturday, where he had been hospitalized after suffering a heart attack two weeks ago. Dr. Jung was 95 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dance: Stephanie Skura and Company
description: ONE of the wits of contemporary dance, Stephanie Skura is a choreographic prankster. Nevertheless, she can be serious when she's being funny, as Stephanie Skura and Company demonstrated Friday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Soviet Announces Mission to Replace Space Station Crew
description: A Soyuz TM-4 spacecraft and a booster rocket will be launched Monday to carry a new crew to the Soviet space station Mir, Tass, the official Government press agency, said today.

title: Transit Police Remove Officer For Quota Plan
description: A district commander of the New York City transit police has been relieved of his command for ignoring a departmental policy forbidding the use of arrest quotas.

title: One Craft Combines Two Popular Sports
description: It is unlikely that Johann Klepper, a German who invented the folding sea kayak in 1907, could have imagined its future. What would he think if he could see it with a sailing rig on a trans-Atlantic crossing nearly 50 years later? Or as a sabotage craft during World War II? Or in the 1980's as standard equipment for a weekend excursion on the water?

title: Dr. Coffin Says Goodbye to Riverside
description: As a cold rain beat against stained-glass windows, more than 2,000 people sat quietly in the neo-Gothic grandeur of the Riverside Church yesterday to hear the Rev. Dr. William Sloane Coffin say goodbye.

title: Texaco's Next Task Is to Rebuild
description: It has survived one of the fiercest, most unpredictable and costly legal battles in history. But Texaco Inc.'s problems are by no means over.

title: Advertising; Clorox to Wunderman
description: The Clorox Company, whose line of packaged goods runs from bleach to cat litter, has retained the San Francisco office of Wunderman Worldwide to ascertain how effective direct marketing would be for its brands. Wunderman is the direct-marketing subsidiary of Young & Rubicam.

title: Head of BP America To Take London Post
description: Robert B. Horton, the Briton who abruptly assumed command of Standard Oil for the British Petroleum Company in 1986, is returning to a B.P. position in London in April.

title: America's Team
description: It's hardly surprising that the faltering Dallas Cowboys have been displaced as ''America's Team,'' but it may come as something of a shock to learn which team has claimed the No. 1 spot in the hearts and minds -or at least the pocketbooks - of the American public.

title: Market Slide Cuts Gifts To a Charity
description: Two months after black Monday and in the midst of its holiday fund-raising drive, the Salvation Army says collections in the New York area are running far behind last year's.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; AIDS and Civil Rights
description: When the United States Commission on Civil Rights recently approved a proposal to study legal issues surrounding the AIDS epidemic, including the rights of people infected with the deadly virus, it said that victims suffer a ''tremendous stigma'' because ''those acts generally responsible for transmitting the virus are often illegal and have traditionally been morally proscribed.''

title: CONTRA AID ACCORD SET BY CONGRESS AND WHITE HOUSE
description: The White House and Congressional leaders reached agreement tonight on a compromise that would give $8.1 million in aid to the Nicaraguan rebels and sets up a possible showdown vote on American policy toward the contras in early February.

title: Concert: Grande Bande
description: WHEN the Grande Bande was founded 10 years ago, the period-instrument movement was hardly new, but neither was it squarely within the mainstream of concert life. As a reminder of how all that has changed, the ensemble's performance Saturday evening in Alice Tully Hall drew a full house to hear 17th-century Christmas music. Frederick Renz, Grande Bande's director, conducted the 12-member string orchestra and three guest singers while playing the claviorgan in a program that included works by Lully, Buxtehude, Purcell, Charpentier, Samuel Scheidt and others.

title: Last Treasury Sale for '87 Scheduled
description: The last Treasury note auctions of 1987 are scheduled this week, with a $9.25 billion two-year issue tomorrow and a $7 billion four-year issue on Wednesday.

title: Advertising; Ford of Argentina Will Stay With J.W.T.
description: The Ford Motor Company's divisions in three South American countries that retained offices of J. Walter Thompson have completed their review of their advertising and here is the final score: Thompson 1 - Visitors 2.

title: Rushing From a Low Point in Life to Top of N.F.L.
description: LEAD: THE fingernail on Charles White's right index finger is rubble, and the wound says something about White's repeated collisions with the helmets of would-be tacklers. The faint scar on White's left wrist speaks, too, of another confrontation, but this one with police handcuffs, from White's summer arrest.

title: Hope Dims for Pan Am-Braniff Tie
description: In the latest struggle to enable Pan American World Airways Inc. to survive another winter when traffic is low and cash is short, some managers and union leaders have put their hopes in being taken over by Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of Braniff Inc. and wealthy Chicago industrialist.

title: Arizona Improves To 9-0
description: Sean Elliott scored 18 points and seven other Wildcats scored in double digits as Arizona beat Washington in their Pacific-10 Conference opener tonight, 110-71. The Wildcats rolled up the biggest score ever against the Huskies.

title: Dealer' Inflation Worries Recede
description: Attention in the bond market shifted last week from the dangers of inflation stemming from a weak dollar to the prospects of low inflation stemming from lower oil prices.

title: Big Payments For 5 Officials At Hutton
description: The E. F. Hutton Group's efforts in the last two years to turn around the fortunes of the battered investment house by hiring away talent from other companies have turned out to be an expensive gamble that failed.

title: Koreans' 'Taste of Freedom' Brings a New Self-Assurance
description: On a weekend that many feared would be filled with tear gas and thousands in the streets, a group of women sat in a beauty salon, resigned to a new President most had voted against but determined that his new Government would be accountable to them.

title: Weighing Value of the Stress Test
description: THE exercise stress test, long a medical standard for detecting heart disease, is frequently ordered for those in their mid-30's or older who follow sound advice and see a doctor before they begin to work out.

title: Gift Money Is Used to Aid The Neediest
description: Daniel Rich is worried about the homeless and especially the children of the homeless in Manhattan and tried to help out by volunteering his services over the school holidays. The neighborhood charitable organizations, however, said they thought there was not very much the 13-year-old boy could do.

title: Rice Sets Two Records
description: Jerry Rice set two National Football League receiving records today and scored three touchdowns to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 35-7 victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Uncle Sugar's Sugar Deal
description: America will import no more sugar in 1988 than it did in 1875. The way things are going, it may soon import none at all. That's splendid for a few thousand protected farmers - but a raw deal for everyone else. Hopes of relief have faded what with Congress adjourning, but the Administration and consumers need to keep up the pressure for a reduced support price.

title: Metro Matters; Howard Beach: The 'Other' Jury In the Long Trial
description: It seemed like intermission in a play that already had lasted too long, and while few people milling about the lobby felt certain of the final outcome, many were willing to predict on what basis the critics would render their reviews.

title: Parts in 29 Cruise Missiles Did Not Have Proper Tests
description: A study conducted for the House Armed Services Committee said today that at least 29 Air Force cruise missiles had guidance systems with an improperly tested component.

title: Law on Aliens Fails to Halt Salvadorans
description: A new immigration law has failed to stem the flow of illegal aliens from El Salvador to the United States, according to a confidential cable from the American Embassy there.

title: India Reactor Deal Seen
description: India plans to buy at least three reactors fueled by enriched uranium from the Soviet Union, and they would be open to international inspection, The Sunday Mail said. The newspaper, which gave no sources for the report, said the decision indicated a departure for India's nuclear power program, which has relied on reactors that use natural uranium or heavy water. India would have to allow foreign inspection of Soviet-built plants because Moscow has signed an international agreement that seeks to insure that enriched uranium, an ingredient of atomic bombs, is not misused, the newspaper said. Indian officials could not be reached for comment.

title: Today, the Adirondacks; Tomorrow, a Subdivision
description: LEAD: The century-long fight to save the Adirondack Park has entered a final and critical stage.

title: Paris Journal; A French Thinker Who Declines a Guru Mantle
description: Andre Malraux is dead. Jean-Paul Sartre is dead. Raymond Aron is dead. The age of France's intellectual giants is past, and it is now customary to bemoan the decline of culture and even thought in France, to rail at the tawdry ascendancy of television and the transformation of writers into entertainers.

title: Two Teen-Age Girls Die in a Crowd Surge At Nashville Concert
description: About 1,000 youths surging out of a rap concert panicked in a narrow, winding hallway, trampling to death two teen-age girls and injuring at least 29 people, the police said today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1987
description: International A3-16

title: Culture Moves Into Fast Lane
description: Two immigrants to the United States, one English and the other French, have capitalized on America's love of fast cars and motorsports.

title: Toys 'R' Us Prospers As Holiday Sales Rise
description: Ida and Joseph Gabay may forgo a vacation and otherwise scrimp because of the money they lost when the stock market plunged. But the Gabays have no intention of playing Scrooge when it comes to their grandchildren.

title: Death and Tourism: Enshrining Cherokee Tears
description: No Cherokee Indians live here now, nor did they ever, but their history marks this town forever.

title: Peggy D. Kutzen Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Peggy Duke Kutzen, the daughter of Jerome L. Kutzen of Purchase, N.Y., and the late Carol T. Kutzen, to Gerold Mosher Wunderlich, a son of Eleanor B. Wunderlich of Ossining, N.Y., and Rudolph Wunderlich of Chicago, took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in White Plains. The Rev. Richard A. Burnett performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Cantor Raymond Smolover.

title: Young French Bidder for Robins
description: In bidding to take control of the A. H. Robins Company, Sanofi, France's second-largest pharmaceutical firm, is flexing its young muscles.

title: Bridge: Last Knockout Title Played At Javits Convention Center
description: The last knockout team championship to be played at the Jacob Javits Convention Center was won Saturday night by Greg Woods, Jeff Bayone, Ron Felton, Jon Greenspan, Steve Nellissen, all of Manhattan, and Lapt Chan, Woodside, Queens.

title: Washington Talk: Senate; A Tale of Two Legislators and How They; Pryor Thinks It's a 'Great Place' But Not for Making Toothpicks
description: Senator David Pryor, a Democrat from Arkansas, acknowledges that the Senate can be sluggish, unpredictable, inefficient and at times unproductive. But he is decidedly fond of the institution.

title: Slumping Devils Beaten by Jets, 4-1
description: Laurie Boschman and Ray Neufeld scored second-period power-play goals tonight as the Winnipeg Jets snapped a five-game streak without a victory by beating the Devils, 4-1.

title: Secrecy On Bonds Criticized
description: The veil of secrecy surrounding trading in the Treasury and agency securities market ought to be lifted, at least partly, according to a report to be published today by the General Accounting Office.

title: Singer Invites Bilzerian Bid
description: The Singer Company said late last night that it had notified Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, that he could complete his pending tender offer for the company if he could arrange the necessary financing and promptly complete the deal.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has the same ball park ever been the site of a perfect game and of a batter hitting for the cycle during the same season?

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Oatmeal Maker Hires Santa For a Battle With 2 Goliaths
description: This is a Christmas story.

title: College Economizing
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Panel Said to Seek Tax Shifts in Report
description: A New Jersey commission on taxes and spending will recommend changes in the state income and sales taxes when it delivers its report to the Legislature early next year, the commission's chairman said.

title: A Debacle Like the League of Nations?
description: In 1945, I wrote a book, ''The Killing of the Peace.'' It was an account of how opponents of the League of Nations, especially Senator Henry Cabot Lodge and former President Theodore Roosevelt, got the Senate to reject the Versailles treaty, which ended World War I. Both politically opposed and personally detested President Woodrow Wilson. Both feared that the League might interfere with American domestic affairs and that, as a League member, we might have to submit to decisions made by smaller nations.

description: His name had come to cover the statistics sheet, filling most of the blanks in almost all of the categories. Having thus authored what amounted to a miserably lost weekend for the Rangers, it was slightly sad that Mario Lemieux could not put his signature on its conclusion.

title: WPLJ Is Now WWPR, To Reflect Its Slogan
description: The New York top-40 radio station WPLJ, 95.5 FM, has changed its call letters to WWPR, echoing the radio station's logo ''Power 95.''

title: GERMANS' DEFENSE PLEDGED BY PARIS
description: The combined pressures of a superpower arms accord and maneuvering for a presidential campaign here have quickened the evolution of French strategic doctrine toward an automatic commitment to defend West Germany at its eastern frontiers in case of a Warsaw Pact attack.

title: Dance: Rachel Harms's 'Blue Foxes'
description: RACHEL HARMS has created some interesting dances that are memorable in part for their dramatic resonance. But ''Blue Foxes,'' a new work presented by the Rachel Harms Dance Company on Saturday at St. Mark's Church was surprisingly unevocative, despite the fact that the suite of dances was said to be an exploration of the charged atmosphere of nighttime and the behavior of people at night. Aside from the high energy of the dancing and some sensuous asides, this was uncharacteristically dull stuff.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Honoring 'Fred the Red'
description: At a gathering at the Yugoslav Embassy the other night, Ambassador Zivorad Kovacevic conferred one of his country's highest honors, the Decoration of the Yugoslav Flag with Golden Wreath, on a 72-year-old American political scientist, Fred Warner Neal.

description: For many suspicious South Koreans, the Battle of Kuro will long linger as the prime example that the presidential election last week was stolen by the Government.

title: Mutual Funds Offered To India Investors
description: Decades after they began in the United States, mutual funds have arrived in India -lacking the versatility, specialization and experience of the American funds but strongly backed by the national Government here as a safe investment.

title: Ranking Santas: Grading Their Beards and the Twinkle
description: Their eyes, do they twinkle? Their dimples, how merry? Are their cheeks like roses? Is each nose like a cherry?

title: Papp Cancels Three Plays
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival, faced with the largest cash shortfall in its history, heavy overhead expenses and diminished income from its investments and Broadway transfers, has canceled three productions and put a fourth on hold.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $4,802,000, or 65 cents a share, and $23,926,000, or $3.05 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and includes a loss from discontinued operations of $9,302,000. The company said that most of its gain in operating profit was provided by its technology segment operations.

title: DOW ADVANCES BY 15.08, TO 1,990.38
description: The stock market advanced again yesterday, and traders said that big institutional investors, initially fearful of the implications of the October crash, were continuing to inch back into stocks.

title: Careers; Tuck School Tie to Japan University
description: SNOW is one thing that Dartmouth's graduate business school - called the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration -and the International University of Japan have in common.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Includes a one-time credit of 21 cents a share from the settlement of customs litigation. c-Includes a one-time credit of 10 cents a share from recalculating the effect of the 1986 Tax Reform Act on a purchased tax liability.

title: Deficit So Far Tops '87 Pace
description: The Federal Government ran up a $25.77 billion budget deficit in November, and the shortfall in the first two months of the fiscal year has risen by 8 percent above last year's level, the Treasury Department reported today.
