description: Companies

title: No Candy for Durbin
description: When the delivery man with the cartful of Nabisco candy bars, crackers and other munchables wheeled down the fourth-floor corridor of the Cannon House Office Building last week passing out Christmas boxes to Congressional staffs, he did not stop at Room 417.

title: Cardinal Ratzinger Cures Jews of an Illusion
description: LEAD: Several weeks ago, yet another crisis broke out in the stormy recent history of Roman Catholic-Jewish relations. Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, the chief theologian of the Vatican, asserted in an interview that a Jew encounters the full truth of his Judaism only by becoming a Catholic.

title: Nicaraguan Conflict Appears to Be in a Stalemate
description: Despite reports of a rebel offensive that began in northeastern Nicaragua on Sunday, the war appears to be stalemated.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. North Stars 0, Maple Leafs 0: In Toronto last night, the Maple Leafs and Minnesota played to the scoreless tie in a penalty-filled game. It was Minnesota's first scoreless game since March 13, 1971, against Philadelphia. It was Toronto's first since Oct. 27, 1972, against Vancouver. It was the first shutout ever for Kari Takko of Minnesota. For Toronto's Allan Bester, it was the second shutout this season. Referee Bob Myers assessed 38 minor penalties, five majors and three 10-minute misconducts for a total of 131 minutes in penalties.(AP) Swimming Meagher Upset: Hong Qian of China upset Mary T. Meagher, the world-record holder, in the 100-meter butterfly yesterday at the United States Swimming Open in Orlando, Fla. Hong finished in 60.05 seconds. It was only the third time since 1978 that Meagher had not won a major 100 butterfly race. She finished third, with Julie Gorman, another American, taking second. Janet Evans set a meet record of 4:03.75 in the 400-meter individual medley, She missed Tracy Caulkins's American record by 51-hundredths of a second. Mary Wayte showed a return to her 1984 form, when she won an Olympic gold medal, by establishing a meet record of 1:59.24 in the 200-meter freestyle. David Berkoff of Harvard won the men's 100-meter backstroke in 56.79. Berkoff, the first swimmer permitted by the school to be red-shirted, swam the first 25 meters of the race underwater, a practice that has become his trademark but is rapidly spreading. Anders Holmertz of Sweden, the European champion in the 200-meter freestyle, won his specialty in a meet record 1:49.09.(AP) Horse Racing Raise a Beat Wins Easily: Raise a Beat took full advantage of the fast track to score an easy front-running eight-length victory yesterday in the $32,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 3-years-old and up at Aqueduct. Carrying 115 pounds with Carlos Correa riding, the favorite of the turnout of 7,736 went six furlongs in 1:09 2/5. I'm Quite High finished ahead of Drone Qui to be runner-up in the field of seven. The victory was the seventh in 10 career starts for Raise a Beat who earned $19,200 for James Riccio and paid $4.40 for $2 to win. Aqueduct will be closed today through Friday with racing resuming on Saturday.

description: James A. Harmon, an investment banker who has served on the board of Ames Department Stores Inc. since 1967, was named chairman yesterday, succeeding Herbert Gilman, one of three brothers who founded the chain.

description: At the Division III level, the so-called small college plateau in sports, the problems confronting a hockey team in the metropolitan area are monumental.

description: The New York City Planning Commission refused yesterday to grant retroactive approval for additions to a mid-Manhattan skyscraper that have resulted in a building 11 feet taller than originally permitted by the planning body and the Board of Estimate.

description: Carl E. McGowan, a senior judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Washington. He was 76 years old.

title: Black Satin and Braces: An 80's Teen-Age Ball
description: The young men arrived in tuxedos, some with the red bow ties and cummerbunds characteristic of teen fashion, only to be frisked at the door by bouncers looking for smuggled liquor. The young women, a few still sporting braces, came in ripples of black taffeta, velvet and satin, their rhinestone clutches also searched for intoxicants.

title: Seoul Opposition Candidate Apologizes
description: Kim Dae Jung, one of the losers in the presidential election last week, has apologized for the opposition's failure to field a single candidate and said the split was one reason for the Government's victory.

title: MIDEAST VIOLENCE ALARMS U.S. JEWS
description: The head of a leading American Jewish group said yesterday that the violence between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian demonstrators should ''shock Israel's Government'' into aggressively negotiating an end to the Israeli occupation of some Arab lands.

description: b-Net income The latest third quarter results reflect a pre-tax reserve of $500,000 related to the closing of three stores during its fourth quarter.

title: Pan Am Pilots Rebuff Offer
description: The pilots' union of Pan American World Airways Inc. has concluded that Jay A. Pritzker's takeover proposal for the airline is not viable, thus ending an effort by a union coalition to find a buyer for the airline, union leaders said yesterday.

description: In a rebuff to the Thatcher Government, a British judge ruled today that the duty of the press to inform the public had ''overwhelming weight'' against potential Government embarrassment from scandal.

description: Going to Japan used to be how a few aging American major leaguers could prolong their careers. Now, the Tokyo Giants have opened the eyes of younger players by making a Godzilla-sized offer to Dave Righetti, the splendid New York Yankee relief pitcher.

title: British Gas to Lift Bow Valley Stake
description: The British Gas Corporation has offered $837 million (Canadian), or $644 million in American currency, to increase its stake in Bow Valley Industries Ltd., the Canadian oil and gas producer. The deal restricts British Gas's stake in Bow Valley's voting stock to 33 percent to satisfy Canadian regulatory authorities, the company said.

description: The Phototron Corporation, a wholesale photographic finishing company based in San Bernardino, Calif., has filed suit in Federal court seeking $300 million from the Eastman Kodak Company and two other photo companies claiming they violated Federal and state antitrust laws.

description: As laboratory analysis plays an increasingly important role in law enforcement, there is growing concern about the professionalism and impartiality of the laboratory scientists whose testimony in court can often mean conviction or acquittal.

title: Fashion Director: Always an Elusive Job Description
description: ''It's our responsibility to be the eyes and ears of the store,'' said Ellin Saltzman of Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 6.3% on Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that the Big Board's ''short interest'' position - the number of shares sold short and not yet covered - in the month ended Dec. 15 rose by 29.1 million shares, or 6.3 percent, to 494.6 million shares.

title: Ailey Dancer Living His Dream
description: Leonard Meek is one of the first dancers the audience sees when the curtain rises on ''The Magic of Katherine Dunham,'' the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's new salute to the noted choreographer. Tall, slender and elegant, Mr. Meek moves at the ballet barre as one who wears an inherited mantle but wears it with unassuming grace. In a sense that is what the Dunham program, which will be performed on Friday evening and on Saturday afternoon and evening, is all about, for it suggests the black American dancer is heir not only to the traditions of Afro-Caribbean folk dance but also to the arts of ballet and modern dance.

title: Seismic Discovery
description: Geophysicists at the California Institute of Technology believe they have solved a longstanding scientific mystery: What happens to material from earth's moving crustal plates after it sinks out of sight at the so-called subduction zones? These zones are cracks at the margins of the crustal plates, notably the ''ring of fire'' around the Pacific basin where volcanoes and earthquakes are prevalent.

title: Crable Suggests Jet Trouble-Shooter
description: It's not a new idea for the Jets. But today marked the first time a player publicly suggested that the team needs front-office help to combat its cold-weather blahs.

title: British Airways Buys 50.02% of Caledonian
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it had acquired a controlling stake in the money-losing British Caledonian Airways, ending a six-month battle with Scandinavian Airlines System.

title: Q&A
description: Q.Cold air supposedly constricts the capillaries in the skin. Why, then, do your nose and cheeks turn red on a nippy day? A.Oxygen gives blood its bright red color, said Dr. Barbara Gilchrest, chairman of dermatology at the Boston University School of Medicine. Oxygenated blood flows in arteries from the heart to the capillaries, where it gives up oxygen to cells. From the capillaries it flows in veins back to the heart.

title: Music: Chamber Group
description: APPREHENSION of Ferruccio Busoni's music may eventually recapitulate the postwar ''discovery'' of Mahler. Both composers belong to that exciting period around the turn of the 20th century when everything in music was coming to a boil; both won great fame as performers but found only a limited audience for their strange, ambiguous amalgam of old and new in their compositions. Busoni's music lacks the frenetic excess that gives such an edge to Mahler and so may never gain the same prominence in the orchestral canon, but as one encounters piece after fascinating piece by the quizzical German-Italian composer, one gradually realizes that his oeuvre is both broad and rich.

description: Jacob R. Heller, an attorney who represented the Metropolitan Garage Owners Association for 40 years, died last Thursday at Wellington Regional Medical Center in Florida after a brief illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Rockville Centre, L.I., and in Royal Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Playoff Picture Is Still Crowded
description: They went through a strike and have managed to play 14 games. And now, with the National Football League's regular-season finale looming, 15 clubs are still in contention for a playoff spot.

title: Olympic Veterans On Skating Team
description: The 20-member United States Olympic speed skating team does not lack experience, talent or controversy.

title: CLEAN HARBORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Banks Add Charges, Cut Jobs
description: Seeking to bolster its profits, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company has begun charging a fee for withdrawals made through its cash machines and, according to banking industry officials, has planned to dismiss 2,500 employees by the end of March.

title: Housing for Homeless Families Opens in Brooklyn
description: The first housing in New York City specifically built for homeless families opened in Brooklyn yesterday as mothers and children, clutching their belongings in plastic trash bags and cardboard boxes, began to move in.

title: HOLLY SUGAR SEEKS A HIGHER PRICE
description: Two weeks after agreeing to a reduced $85-a-share buyout from Plum Associates, the Holly Sugar Corporation said it had begun talks that could produce a higher price. The sugar beet processor did not detail what the discussions involved. Plum is a New York investment group led by Peter R. Harvey, the Illinois financier.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Fire Tender and the Hungry
description: Kalif Beacon is an itinerant musician and founder of the Temple of the Rainbow Food Kitchen. He calls himself the Fire Tender. The pots on his makeshift wood stove have simmered steadily since he began feeding homeless and hungry New Yorkers in September. His sooty hands are as black as his beard; his eyes are a piercing blue; on his shaggy head sits a stovepipe hat.

title: Senate Passes $15 Billion Housing Bill
description: The Senate approved a $15 billion housing assistance bill tonight, dramatically reversing a course it took just a month ago and paving the way for final approval in the House and signature by President Reagan.

title: SCAN-GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Balboni Unsigned
description: Steve Balboni, whose base salary was cut $425,000 last year after the Kansas City Royals allowed him to become a free agent, became a free agent again yesterday when the club failed to offer him a contract for the 1988 season. Twenty-one other players became free agents in the same manner.

title: Next Stop: the South Pole
description: ACCORDING to the National Science Foundation, which logs the going and coming of travelers to the ultra-Deep South, about 7,200 paying tourists are visiting Antarctica this year, a mob that outnumbers the White Continent's normal complement of polar professionals by more than 2 to 1.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for 14wks to Oct 31
VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss The figures include operating results of the Vision Systems division, acquired on Dec. 24, 1986.

title: The Pace of Evolution: A Fossil Creature Moves to Center of Debate
description: WHEN Peter Sheldon chipped his first fossil trilobite from some rocks in Wales a decade ago, two American scientists were transforming standard evolutionary theory with a radical idea. Well-established species, they argued, tend to change little or not at all as the eons pass; most real evolution takes place in rapid bursts at the rare moments when new species are born.

title: Our Towns; Elderly Hands Help Brighten Holiday Season
description: ''Miss Pearl, where did you put the wiggly worm?'' Jean Batcheller was sure Pearl Curran would know. At 65, Miss Pearl Curran -the youngest worker at the Master Crafters shop here - knows every item's life story, not to mention where it's hidden.

title: Crude Falls and Heating Oil And Unleaded Gasoline Rise
description: Prices of crude oil futures weakened in late trading yesterday, while heating oil and unleaded gasoline prices advanced in a moderately active session on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Navy Expands the Roles of Women
description: The Navy today opened more assignments to women, many of them closer to combat than permitted before, while the Marine Corps and the Air Force studied actions intended to improve the lot of women in their services.

title: After 2 Months, Larry Davis's Trial Starts in Bronx
description: After more than two months of defense motions, protracted jury selection and a debate over where the defendant should be held, the trial of Larry Davis began yesterday in the Bronx.

title: Wherehouse To Be Acquired
description: Wherehouse Entertainment Inc., apparently thwarting a hostile tender offer from Shamrock Holdings Inc., said today that it would be acquired for $14 a share, or about $118 million, by an affiliate of Adler & Shaykin Inc., a New York leveraged buyout firm.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mario Lemieux of the Pittsburgh Penguins, who had five goals and seven assists in four games, was named player of the week in the National Hockey League. . . . Larry Nance, the Phoenix Suns forward who averaged 32.7 points, 11.7 rebounds and three blocked shots last week, was named National Basketball Association player of the week. . . . Jimmy Piersall, 58, now a minor league instructor and consultant in the Cubs' organization, is recovering from quadruple-bypass heart surgery he underwent Friday in Chicago. . . . Keith Clearwater and Laura Davies have been named rookies of the year by Golf Digest magazine. . . . The N.C.A.A. yesterday turned down Texas A&M's request that Melvin Collins and Tony Bartley, two reserves, have their eligibility restored in time for the Cotton Bowl game against Notre Dame. The two were declared ineligible because of dealings with an Atlanta sports agent, Jim Abernethy.

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: College Basketball; Pitt Rallies To Beat Akron
description: Sean Miller scored 15 points and Bobby Martin snapped a late tie with two foul shots as No. 3-ranked Pittsburgh (5-0) rallied from an 11-point deficit to win, 67-63.

title: ARCO Lifts Stake In Britoil to 14.7%
description: ARCO, competing against the British Petroleum Company for control of Britoil P.L.C., said it had lifted its stake in Britoil to 14.7 percent, from 7.7 percent. An ARCO spokesman, Al Greenstein, said the share purchases were made public in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: China Taking Stringent Steps To Prevent the Entry of AIDS
description: Trying to isolate itself from the worldwide spread of AIDS, China has adopted rigorous measures, including blood tests for foreigners and Chinese who return from abroad and renewed efforts by the police to prevent casual sexual contacts between foreigners and Chinese.

title: Gentle Justice Powell
description: The December issue of the Harvard Law Review carries a tribute by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor to a colleague, Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr., who retired from the Supreme Court last summer. Here are excerpts:

title: Blissfield Journal; Finding a Future in the Distant Past
description: Just north of the railroad tracks that cross this snow-packed town of 2,700 residents stands a stout wooden home framed in thick timbers with a roof that flows in waves to the ground, an ample porch, and large windows that give it an ancient, proud countenance.

title: Who Will Fight for Haitian Democracy?
description: After unleashing a massacre to block an independently monitored election just as it began, Gen. Henri Namphy of Haiti now announces election procedures that do every bit as much violence to the idea of democratic choice. It's small wonder, with voting set for Jan. 17, that political turmoil persists in the streets of Port-au-Prince.

title: 3 in Howard Beach Attack Are Guilty of Manslaughter
description: Three white teen-agers were convicted last night of manslaughter and assault charges stemming from an attack that led to the death of one black man and the severe beating of another in Howard Beach, Queens, a year ago.

title: 2 From Soviet Bloc in Games
description: Hungary and East Germany became the first Soviet-bloc nations to announce that they will participate in the 1988 Summer Olympics in South Korea.

title: Track and the Future
description: Fatima Whitbread, the world champion in the women's javelin throw, called for the establishment of a disciplinary committee to fine or suspend British athletes and officials who bring track and field into disrepute. Speaking in London yesterday, Whitbread, Britain's only world track and field champion in 1987, said she wanted to see an organization established with a top attorney as chairman that would help stamp out adverse publicity she believes is damaging to the sport. ''I fear for the future of the sport,'' Whitbread said, ''if all the backbiting and petty arguments, as well as these irresponsible, unfounded allegations about drugs from people who are just being mischievous or interested in their own self advancement, continue.'' Whitbread's comments followed a number of serious allegations made last week by The Times of London concerning drug abuse in British track and field. As a result, track officials said they would set up an inquiry team next year to investigate the claims.

title: WATERS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Stag's Call Is Enough To Put Doe Into Heat
description: AN experiment on red deer in New Zealand has shown that just the recorded roars of a rutting male deer are enough to bring a female into heat.

title: Trial Reactions: From Approval To a Letdown
description: Reaction to the Howard Beach verdicts ranged from dismay to cautious approval last night among political and civil-rights figures, religious leaders and others.

title: Both Sides Report Heavy Fighting In Rebel Offensive in Nicaragua
description: Both the Government and the contras reported heavy fighting today in a major guerrilla attack in northeastern Nicaragua, but otherwise the two sides offered conflicting accounts.

title: Pitchers Talking
description: Jack Morris is getting closer to an agreement on a new contract with the Detroit Tigers and Charlie Leibrandt may soon break off negotiations with the Kansas City Royals, the agent for the pitchers said yesterday.

title: Signatures Held Sufficient to Force Arizona Vote
description: More than enough petition signatures have been validated to force Gov. Evan Mecham to face an election to recall him from office, county recorders said today.

description: b-Included a gain of $153,000, or 2 cents a share, from the sale of an interest in another company.

description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Texaco, Pennzoil: Their Prospects
description: TEXACO INC. and the Pennzoil Company have ridden Wall Street's roller coaster in recent years and now, with the proposed settlement of their mammoth legal dispute, some analysts see both stocks poised for possible further gains.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Heavy Fighting in Gulf War
description: Iran and Iraq both reported heavy fighting today on the south-central front in the Persian Gulf war, but they differed sharply on the outcome.

title: John Francis O'Leary, Chairman Of a Utility and Ex-U.S. Official
description: John Francis O'Leary, chairman of the General Public Utilities Corporation and deputy secretary of energy in the Carter Administration, died Saturday at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia after a brief illness. He was 61 years old and lived in Mendham, N.J.

title: Group of 7 Expected to Back Halt in the Dollar's Decline
description: The United States and other leading industrial countries appear to have agreed on a declaration endorsing a halt in the decline of the dollar but making no lasting commitments to stabilize it, foreign economic officials said today.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Arkady I. Raikin, 76, a Comedian Who Lampooned Soviet Life, Dies
description: Arkady I. Raikin, who became the Soviet Union's most beloved comedian by deftly poking fun at the idiosyncracies of the Soviet system under a succession of rulers from Stalin to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, died over the weekend, the official press agency Tass reported today. He was 76 years old. Mr. Raikin's humor, which mixed wicked satire with sentimental schmaltz and in his younger days physical slapstick, made him a favorite of several generations, and led many Russians to wonder how he got away with it.

title: Many Foundations and Trusts Try to Aid the Neediest Cases
description: This year, ''more than ever,'' help is greatly needed for the city's poor, wrote Sadie Klau of Manhattan. The David and Sadie Klau Foundation, which has contributed regularly to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund since 1943, sent a gift of $5,000.

title: LEADER DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes merger costs of $376,240. c-Includes more than $2,600,000 in after-tax gains from sales of real estate investments.

title: Two Back Kennedy for Court
description: Senators Howard M. Metzenbaum and Dennis DeConcini, citing the nominee's open-minded approach to the law, announced today that they would vote to confirm Judge Anthony M. Kennedy as a Supreme Court justice.

title: Leo Burnett Loses Mars Candy Business
description: The Leo Burnett Company is losing all its Mars candy business because the pet foods it handles for the H. J. Heinz Company is upsetting Mars Inc. corporate management.

title: JOB OUTLOOK RATED CLOUDY IN NEW YORK
description: The stock market collapse has added ''substantial uncertainty'' to the future of New York City's economy, but it will not hurt as seriously as some economists have been predicting, according to a report issued by the State Comptroller.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Agree That Deficit Is Dragon
description: As he campaigns across the country, Senator Bob Dole maintains that ''the Federal budget deficit is the single greatest threat to a prosperous and dynamic America.''

title: The Poignant Thoughts Of Down's Children Are Given Voice
description: GIVEN voice by computer technology, adolescents with Down's syndrome are overcoming difficulties in hearing and speech to express unexpectedly vivid and intense thoughts and feelings.

title: MICROPRO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Latest and year-ago first quarter net equal less than 1 cent a share.

title: Piano: Aleksandra Romantic
description: ALEKSANDRA ROMANIC, a Yugoslavian pianist who has played prominently on the Soviet and Eastern European circuit, opened her austere debut program at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening with the massive Bach-Busoni Chaconne. She played with a sense of the work's grandeur that did not quite amount to an embodiment of it, but gave evidence of some imagination in matters of textural shading.

title: Yonkers Anguish: Black and White in 2 Worlds
description: Bernadette McLaughlin lives on the east side of this city, Margaret Puryear on the west. The two women share a deep nostalgia about a lost past and fears about the future. But they inhabit separate worlds, divided by far more than the Saw Mill River Parkway, the concrete barrier that runs between them.

title: MANAGEMENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
2 Candidates Lead Field For Fed Post
description: The former chief economist at Citibank, Leif H. Olsen, has emerged as the first choice of the White House to fill the vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration officials said today.

title: Thompson Splits With Godfather's Pizza
description: Godfather's Pizza, which like Burger King is a subsidiary of the Pillsbury Company, was reportedly ready to announce the future of its relationship with J. Walter Thompson of Chicago last Tuesday. It didn't. But yesterday the Thompson agency announced that it was splitting with the client over the matter of compensation. The billings are reportedly $8 million.

title: Korean Beetles Battle Plant Pest
description: Two predatory beetles from South Korea have been enlisted as warriors to fight tiny sucking insects that threaten American shrubbery, the Agriculture Department said last week.

title: SOVIET GIVES EXIT TO PROMINENT JEW
description: Aleksandr Lerner, who has been denied permission to leave the Soviet Union for nearly 17 years, said today that he had been told he could emigrate to Israel.

title: Arabs in Isreal Demonstrate for 'Our Brothers'
description: Israeli Arab youths crouched behind trash dumpsters and threw rocks at police officers here today in the shadow of the church where, according to Christian tradition, an angel told Mary she would give birth to a son.

title: Sandinistas and Contras Resume Peace Talks
description: While rebel forces mounted a military offensive against the Nicaraguan Government, representatives of the two sides met here Monday night with an intermediary for a second round of talks aimed at ending the conflict.

title: Curing Math Anxiety
description: ONLY 362 Americans received doctorates in mathematics in the last academic year, out of 32,000 doctorates awarded, according to a report by the American Mathematical Society and the Mathematical Association of America. This is the lowest number in 15 years, at a time when mathematics is a key to scientific, technological and industrial success.

title: SOVIET GIVES U.S. PHOTO OF MISSILE
description: The Soviet Union has provided the United States with an original photograph of its SS-20 missile, Reagan Administration officials said today.

Fletcher D. Richards Sr. Advertising Executive
description: Fletcher Doughitt Richards Sr., a retired advertising executive, died Friday at the Albany Medical Center Hospital after a brief illness. He was 95 years old and lived in Clifton Park, N.Y., where he had moved from Greenwich, Conn.

title: SOMERSET SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The bank converted to stock ownership in July 1986.

title: Judge Weighs Mass v. Class In Settling Battle of 2 Scents
description: A Federal judge in New York gave 55 retailers an early Christmas present yesterday, listing them as the classiest stores in the country.

title: Pentagon Says It Met '87 Goal In Recruiting for All Services
description: The all-volunteer armed services met or exceeded their recruiting goals for the eighth consecutive year last year without lowering their standards for high school graduates, the Defense Department announced today.

title: Celtics Overtake 76ers
description: Larry Bird scored 9 of his 31 points in the final 5 minutes as the Celtics defeated the 76ers, 118-115, tonight, Boston's first victory in Philadelphia in two years.

title: Pace Terminates Merger With MLX
description: The MLX Corporation, a distributor of cooling equipment based in Troy, Mich., said the agreement it had reached in September to acquire Pace Industries, the New York-based parent company of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, which makes heating and cooling equipment, had been terminated by Pace. MLX had earlier announced that its lender had not been able to provide it with the subordinated debt that it needed to finance the $825 million deal.

title: Winner in Seoul Promises to Quit If a Plebiscite Does Not Back Him
description: President-elect Roh Tae Woo said today that he would give up the presidency if he lost a public vote of confidence that he has pledged to seek after the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul.

title: Lilly Finishes Sale Of Its Arden Unit
description: Eli Lilly & Company completed the previously announced $700 million sale of its Elizabeth Arden Inc. cosmetics subsidiary to Faberge Inc. and announced that its board had approved a plan to repurchase up to $1 billion worth of common stock.

title: Virginia Defeats B.Y.U.
description: Scott Secules ran for one touchdown and passed for another as Virginia, in a rare postseason appearance, defeated Brigham Young, 22-16, tonight in the All-American Bowl.

title: Patience vs. Panic
description: Our knee-jerk reaction to pictures of soldiers manhandling demonstrators is to regard the soldiers as brutal and the rioters as heroic. That's not always true.

title: 7 Allies Back Stability For Dollar
description: The United States and its principal economic allies said today that they had agreed to ''cooperate closely'' on averting further ''excessive'' changes in the dollar's value.

title: O.E.C.D. Prods U.S. And Bonn
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development urged the United States and West Germany today to take stronger steps to reduce their trade imbalances to help restore market confidence and reinforce world economic expansion.

title: Congress Passes Housing Bill
description: Congress, struggling to adjourn for the year, early today approved and sent to President Reagan the first major housing bill in seven years.

description: An infant with a fatal birth defect, whose parents wanted to donate her organs for use in transplants, was delivered stillborn today at the Loma Linda University Medical Center.

title: Goodrich Abandons The Tire Business
description: After decades as a major player in the tire business, the B. F. Goodrich Company said yesterday that it was getting out.

title: Sports People; Robbery of a Saint
description: When two gunmen in Metairie, La., realized they were robbing Jim Mora, the popular coach of the New Orleans Saints, they grabbed their loot and ran. At least that's the way John Fortunato, a spokesman for the sheriff's office, saw it.

description: The mile or two that separate the glittering hotels of Manila from the garbage-strewn North Harbor docks of the Sulpicio Shipping Lines measure the distance between two Filipino nations.

description: It used to be that if what students had to say about their professors was unprintable, it remained that way. No longer.

description: It's all over but a little counting. Come Friday, people here will observe Noel's 100th Christmas, and a few days later, with a New Year's Eve celebration at the Community Center, they will close Noel's centennial, the 100th year of being the Christmas City of Missouri.

description: Raoul D. Edwards, the editor of United States Banker magazine since 1983, died of a heart attack Thursday after a staff meeting at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

description: Halfway around the world from their American campuses, professors from several United States universities are trying to re-create the essence of American college life, from Coke machines to computers.

description: Bill Foster, the basketball coach at the University of Miami, said he was only showing his enthusiasm, trying to stir his team. But instead, his wild waving during the Hurricanes' 110-107 victory Monday night over Alabama State put his arm in a sling.

title: Daisuke Yamauchi, News Executive, 62
description: Daisuke Yamauchi, president of the newspaper Mainichi Shimbun, died of liver failure today. He was 62 years old.

title: Stage: 'Davy Jones's Locker'
description: IN his lifetime, Bil Baird practiced creative puppetry in his Barrow Street marionette theater and also through his work on Broadway, in films and on television. Affirming his father's legacy, the puppeteer's son, Peter B. Baird, has returned to New York with a revival of one of the family's favorites, ''Davy Jones's Locker.'' The puppet show for children is presented at the Orpheum Theater in a special holiday matinee season through Jan. 3. This musical adventure takes place on the high seas and fathoms deep. Although the show was written by Waldo Salt, a Hollywood screenwriter, and Arthur Birnkrant, the story is mundane -and the yo-ho-ho score by Mary Rodgers is negligible.

description: Interest rates fell yesterday for the first time in more than a month at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 7.4395 percent, down from 7.9691 percent the previous week.

The Eatonton Police Chief, Kent Lawrence, identified the victims as Floyd Paynter, 30 years old, his wife, Pamela Sue, 24, and their children, Shawn, 5, Brandon, 3, and Kristen, 1. The Chief said a short in a wire caused the fire. The family had gone to bed with the lights on, he said.

description: An Indian helicopter gunship sank a fiberglass boat running guns into Sri Lanka's eastern province, killing five men on board, an Indian External Af-fairs Ministry spokesman said today.

title: Technology Adds New Meaning to Personalized Gifts
description: As a Christmas gift, Maria DeJuan's boyfriend asked for the new Belinda Carlisle record, ''Heaven on Earth.'' He's in for a surprise. He is getting a cassette of the top 10 single. But it is not Ms. Carlisle's version. The soft pop accompaniment may sound the same, but the singer is Ms. DeJuan. The picture on the slick package? Not Ms. Carlise's, but Ms. DeJuan's. At the Center Stage Productions franchise in Macy's at Herald Square, stardom is for sale at $12.95.

description: A committee studying problems in Georgia's virtually all-white Forsyth County divided sharply along racial lines today on the issues that led to two violent confrontations last January.

title: Backers Vow to Press Broadcast Rule in 1988
description: Proponents of legislation to require television and radio stations to broadcast varying views on controversial matters pledged today to push for the measure next year, after Congress deleted it from the spending bill early this morning.

title: Being Different
description: To The Living Section:

title: Strange Behavior on Campaign Trail Has Roots in Spending Limit Rules
description: Nebraska's primary does not come until May 10, but campaign money is already being spent here, to help Presidential candidates in neighboring Iowa where caucuses will be held Feb. 8.

title: Japan-Citibank Tie
description: The New York-based Citibank and Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank said they would link their automatic teller machine systems beginning in January, allowing customers to use the automatic tellers of both banks. Citibank is the largest commercial bank in the United States, while Dai-Ichi Kangyo is the largest in the world in terms of assets. Bank officials said it would be the first time for a Japanese bank to link its branch network with that of a foreign bank. As of Jan. 14, customers will be able to withdraw money and check their account balances on automatic teller machines belonging to either bank.

title: London Journal; Now Who Will Put a Penny in the Old Man's Hat?
description: Muttering about misery and a woman, Johnny Connors was drunk anew before noon, oblivious to Christmas caroling after reeling from the darkness of his makeshift cardboard sleeping shelter. He ascended as a burned-out Orpheus from the Hooverville that is jerrybuilt nightly down below the glittering South Bank arts center.

title: Trash of Past Is the Stuff of Archeology
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Beach: Judged and Prejudged
description: Finally, the Howard Beach case showed New York criminal justice at its best. But only hours before the tensely awaited verdict, an ill-timed demonstration recklessly inflamed the atmosphere. What did that accomplish, other than to frustrate hundreds of thousands of commuters and create a climate of danger for the whole city?

title: Head of Neiman-Marcus Shifts to Bonwit Teller
description: David Dworkin is moving from one big-name retail chain to another -from the presidency of Neiman-Marcus in Dallas to a similar post with Bonwit Teller in New York.

title: Pacific Telesis
description: The California Public Utilities Commission ordered the Pacific Telesis Group, the holding company for Pacific Bell and Nevada Bell, to decrease its rates by $194.5 million. Most of the money, $108 million, represents rate reductions retroactive to March 1986. The remaining $86.5 million was ordered for the upcoming year. No refunds will be issued as a result of the order. An administrative law judge had recommended the rate cuts to comply with state laws governing its maximum profit rate.

title: Boycott of Table Grapes by Union Is Backed
description: Environmental, consumer and public health groups joined the United Farm Workers today in urging support for the union's boycott of table grapes sprayed with pesticides.

title: Nicaragua-Contra Talks Suspended Indefinitely
description: Peace talks between the Nicaraguan Government and the rebels were suspended indefinitely today.

title: John Shiel, Engineer, 87
description: John Shiel, an electrical engineer and historian, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Glen Head, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: Chirac Linked to Iran Arms Sales
description: France's arms dealings with Iran, which began in 1983 under President Francois Mitterrand, continued as late as this summer under his political rival, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, French newspapers reported today.

title: The Added Sparkle Of Champagne In Large Bottles
description: THE world's largest Champagne bottle, called a sovereign, will be used Jan. 15 in Miami by Rosalynn Carter, the former First Lady, to christen the Sovereign of the Seas. The vessel will carry 2,690 passengers, more than any other passenger ship ever built.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We began the dawn on a good note, a note of compromise.

title: Washington Talk: Congress; A Holder of the Purse Is Moved to Verse
description: It was 1:35 A.M. today when, moved by the Christmas spirit and the Ghost of Budgets Past, Representative Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts, the ranking Republican member of the Appropriations Committee, took to the House floor in the midst of consideration of a Government spending bill for the 1988 fiscal year and declaimed:

title: I.R.S. Won't Penalize Those Underwithheld on 1987 Pay
description: The Internal Revenue Service announced today that it would not penalize Americans who had too little withheld from their paychecks this year.

title: Japan Auto Parts Plant Set for U.S.
description: The Nippondenso Company, a Japanese manufacturer of automotive components, will build a $200 million plant that will make starters and alternators in this East Tennessee city. Production is scheduled to begin in July 1990, said Michio Ohiwa of Southfield, Mich., president of Nippondenso America Inc. The company has purchased 100 acres and will begin construction of the 600,000-square-foot plant next spring.

title: Artworks By Soyer Are Stolen
description: Between 400 and 500 etchings and lithographs have been stolen from the Upper West Side studio of the late Raphael Soyer, according to the police and art experts.

title: Casper Yost Offutt, Former Diplomat, 93
description: Casper Yost Offutt, a former diplomat who served in Chile and Panama, died Sunday. He was 93 years old. From 1917 to 1919, Mr. Offutt was second secretary of the United States Embassy in Chile and first secretary and charge d'affaires in Panama.

title: Comes the Postman
description: Well, friends, neighbors, kin and just plain folks, it looks like it's that time of year again: short days, endless nights, and the slap, slap, slap of plastic on countertops. Time to send out our annual report on what a great year it's been at our house.

title: Gibbons Cancels Argonaut Buyout
description: Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Inc. said it had called off its $620 million buyout of Argonaut Group Inc. because the Los Angeles-based life insurer had refused to agree to two changes proposed by Gibbons, Green.

title: Righetti Gets 3-Year Pact; Trout Traded
description: The Yankees were prepared to announce a three-year, $4.3 million agreement with Dave Righetti yesterday, but they postponed the news until today because they came up with another announcement. This one was a five-player trade that sent Steve Trout and Henry Cotto to Seattle for Lee Guetterman, a left-handed pitcher, and two minor-league pitchers.

title: 'A Million Meals,' Hunger
description: ''METROLINE'' is of more than passing interest tonight. Channel 13's weekly series on public affairs looks at private organizations in New York that feed the hungry. In 1982, says Mike Shuster, the series host, only 30 organizations did this; now there are almost 500. The program, ''A Million Meals,'' at 8:30, is a model work.

title: Film: 'Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne'
description: ''THE Lonely Passion of Judith Hearne'' is a solemn film about a spinster whose only excess is the wearing of mildly flamboyant bonnets, a woman who declares ''It's only me!'' when she enters a room and who asks for ''just a soupcon of milk'' with her tea.

title: Hundreds Rally for 69 Held in Rush-Hour Protest
description: Hundreds of civil-rights demonstrators, most of them black, transformed the vast, columned lobby of the Brooklyn Criminal Courthouse into a tumultuous speakers' forum yesterday, shouting support for 69 people arrested in a coordinated series of rush-hour protests against racism Monday night.

title: Fractious Israeli Leaders Are Circling the Wagons
description: Two weeks of violent Palestinian protests have shaken many Israelis but have had little effect on the domestic political lineup.

title: Film: 'Good Morning, Vietnam'
description: THE time of ''Good Morning, Vietnam'' is 1965. Adrian Cronauer (Robin Williams), an Armed Forces Radio disk jockey previously stationed in Crete, lands in Saigon to breathe a little life into the local programming. Until Cronauer's arrival, the AFR Saigon station has depended largely on the music of Mantovani and Percy Faith and helpful hints on how to withdraw books from the Army's lending libraries, interrupted from time to time by sanitized newscasts.

title: Familiar Style As Rangers Fall
description: The patterns are becoming so patented as to lack even the semblance of drama. For the second straight game and the third time in their last eight, the Rangers gained an early lead and then forsook it, folding before the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-4, at Madison Square Garden last night. For the third consecutive game, they outshot their opponent in prodigious fashion (34-23 this time), but lost. And for the 15th time this season, they entered the third period trailing and concluded it in that position.

title: Market Place; Trump Hedging On Resorts Offer
description: DONALD J. TRUMP, chairman and controlling stockholder of Resorts International Inc., hinted yesterday that he might revoke his tender offer of $15 a share for all of the company's class A common stock. The offer, made just two days ago, marked the latest chapter in the turbulent saga of the company that first brought legalized gambling to Atlantic City.

title: Washington Talk: The Bureaucracy; Many Are Called and Many Answer, at Sacrifice
description: A recent financial disclosure form submitted by Frank C. Carlucci, President Reagan's new Secretary of Defense, raises a question about some of Washington's top bureaucrats that, on the surface, seems baffling.

title: Ruling-Party Chief Is Slain With 3 Others in Sri Lanka
description: The chairman of the ruling United National Party and three others were slain today, the police and hospital sources said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 15, headed ''Political Memo,'' about the Democratic contest for President, misstated the number of delegate votes at the National Convention next year.

title: Fast-Growing Toy Maker's Hard Fall
description: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the toy maker that only last year set a record as one of the fastest-growing companies in history, has filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws.

title: In Collider Project, Lundine is Lightning Rod
description: As Stan Lundine flew north into the Adirondacks recently, he knew he was returning to friendly territory, a place where he could feel safe without bodyguards.

title: School Basketball; Some Go Far, Win or Lose
description: If they make all their connecting flights, St. Nicholas of Tolentine of the Bronx and St. Anthony's of Jersey City should be back from their game in the final of the McDonald's-Iolani Prep Classic in Hawaii in time for the players to spend Christmas Eve and Christmas Day with their families. Then they will go right back on the road for the opener of the Seagull Interscholastic tournament in Absecon, N.J., on Saturday.

title: Donors to Neediest Seek To Aid Specific Groups
description: When she was a child, Joyce Golden of Manhattan gave part of her allowance to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. She has been making contributions ever since, for about 40 years.

title: Success Stalls Inquiry on Mississippi Counties
description: Federal prosecutors say there will be no more arrests of county supervisors on corruption charges in Mississippi until after Christmas, because the 50 charged so far have left them snowed under with work.

title: Wells Fargo Will Manage U.S. Employee Investments
description: The Federal Retirement Thrift Investment Board, an agency that began managing a savings plan for Federal employees in April, announced yesterday that Wells Fargo Bank N.A. had been selected to manage investments in the stock and bond markets.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Yule at the Zoo
description: Animal rights advocates have been active in the Washington area over the last several years. Some of them even went so far as to steal 11 cats last August from a Department of Agriculture research center where they were being used to study cellular parasites.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: MY most enduring and exalted memory of Christmas is an odd one, tied to neither home nor family. It is the memory of singing in the elementary school Christmas concert each year. We were rehearsed mercilessly from Halloween on, our consonants honed to a cutting edge, our tight little mouths coaxed into generous ovals.

title: New Methods Of Handling Toxic Waste
description: FOR decades environmental engineers cleaned up toxic waste in one way: by enclosing and burying it, either in landfills or at the site.

title: Hynes Summoned to Albany for Praise by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo summoned Charles J. Hynes to the State Capitol today to praise his successful prosecution of the Howard Beach case, saying that Mr. Hynes's work proved there was no need to create a new special prosecutor's post for handling race-related cases.

title: A Director Is Named At Houghton Mifflin
description: Joseph A. Kanon, formerly president and publisher of E. P. Dutton Inc., will become director of the Houghton Mifflin Company's trade and reference division on Jan. 1. He succeeds Austin G. Olney, who will remain a member of the board through next April.

title: Oil Prices Rebound Sharply After Report of OPEC Cuts
description: Reports of OPEC production cutbacks and of military actions in the Persian Gulf, as well as technical factors, contributed to a sharp jump in oil prices yesterday, analysts said.

title: Robert W. Blankshine, A Dancer and Teacher
description: Robert W. Blankshine, an American dancer and teacher and a former featured member of the Joffrey Ballet, died of a heart attack Sunday at a friend's home in New York City, according to his mother, Serene Blankshine. He was 42 years old.

title: Manhattan Upset By Coach's Protest
description: Jack Powers, the director of athletics at Manhattan College, said yesterday that the school's basketball coach used poor judgment Monday night when he took his team off the court to protest the officiating.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: TW Services Inc., the successor to the Transworld Corporation, said it had arranged a $1.05 billion line of credit with a group of 12 banks led by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and J. P. Morgan & Company.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Presslers in White
description: The freak snowfall that blanketed the capital in early November gave Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, an idea.

title: Advertising; New Woman Gets a New Campaign
description: NEW WOMAN magazine, doing well in circulation and advertising, will begin its first TV advertising campaign tomorrow, and it should benefit both those profit centers. The agency is Wyse Advertising, whose president, Lois Wyse, is a bit of a new woman herself.

title: U.N. Council 'Deplores' Israeli Actions in Unrest
description: With the United States abstaining, the Security Council adopted a resolution today strongly deploring Israel's handling of the disturbances in the occupied territories.

title: L.I.R.R. Told to Ban Smoking or Lose U.S. Funds
description: Smoking on the Long Island Rail Road may soon be a thing of the past.

title: German TV Host Quits Over His Nazi Past
description: The 74-year-old host of West Germany's longest-running television talk show resigned today, a week after a magazine reopened his past as a Nazi journalist.

title: Opera: Dutoit Leads Met 'Hoffmann'
description: CHARLES DUTOIT, whose impressive stewardship of the Montreal Symphony has brought him favorable attention and high record sales over the past decade, introduced himself to Metropolitan Opera audiences Monday at the season's first performance of ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' with an evening of honest, keenly propulsive operatic conducting. He did not call attention to himself with gimmicky ideas or interpose himself as a Svengali interpreting the singers' lines for them; he showed a zest for Offenbach's inventions, a ready willingness to take them on their own terms, and the command to secure alert, committed playing throughout.

title: Preventing New Year's Eve No-Shows
description: RESTAURATEURS say that it might cost you almost as much not to dine out New Year's Eve as it will to honor your reservations.

title: A Lumber Baron And His Gift of Toys
description: SILAS L. GRIFFITH, a 19th-century lumber baron, gave much to the town of Danby, including the municipal water system, the public library, the orphans' fund and money for the beautification of the Congregational church. But of all the gifts Mr. Griffith gave, none is so cherished as his Christmas tree.

title: Boxing Notebook; W.B.C. Is in Chavez's Corner
description: With his spectacular knockout of Edwin Rosario for the World Boxing Association lightweight title last month, Julio Cesar Chavez has emerged as a future star attraction. But just how Chavez will cash in on his new prominence remains to be seen.

title: 'Miss Daisy' Gives Uhry Success at Long Last
description: From the time he was a little boy growing up in Atlanta, Alfred Uhry wanted to move to New York and become a leading light of the musical theater. He saw himself as Cary Grant in a penthouse overlooking Central Park, surrounded by beautiful women and witty friends, effortlessly spinning out songs like a latter-day Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bets on the Democrats
description: Let's say you are a typical Washington political junkie but you have a hankering to do something really exciting like, say, become an international arbitrageur.

title: Sports People; Waiting for Thomas
description: Penn State officials said they would wait until the last minute to decide whether Blair Thomas, the junior tailback who was the team's leading rusher and scorer this season, will be fit to play in the Citrus Bowl New Year's Day.

title: Tax Break: No Penalty
description: Citing the complicated W-4 forms, the I.R.S. said it would not penalize Americans who had too little withheld from their 1987 paychecks. Page D2. U.S. and Bonn Urged to Act

title: Software Curb Eased In Brazil
description: President Jose Sarney of Brazil today signed into law a computer software bill, but he eliminated provisions that would have set tariffs of up to 200 percent on imported software and imposed criminal penalties for using illegal software.

title: Three Are Charged With Plotting To Influence Meese for Wedtech; Figures in the Indictment
description: E. Robert Wallach

title: 4 Convicted At Mob Trial In Brooklyn
description: Two reputed leaders in the Gambino organized-crime family, including the man described as the group's new underboss, were convicted last night of taking part in a racketeering conspiracy and of other Federal charges.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Hold the Salad Recent prices for commonplace lettuce varieties like iceberg and romaine seem more suited for imported endive. Bad weather in southern California and Arizona beginning in October has caused the prices for common lettuces to rise to $2 a head or more in many stores.

title: Delaware Merger Rules
description: A special committee of the Delaware Bar Association last night approved, as expected, new rules giving companies incorporated there more protection against takeovers. The rules could have a major impact since many leading companies are incorporated in Delaware.

title: About New York; Place of Civility, Or a Tourist Visa For Rhett Butler
description: The day they issued the tourist visa to the world of the other half was the day there was a madman on the subway platform, three helpless beggars on the train and an evangelical screamer at the end of the line - in short, a day like any other down here on the ground.

title: Howard Beach Verdict: Mixed Message
description: In one wrenching year, the Howard Beach case dramatized the vulnerability of black New Yorkers, divided the city and, finally, achieved a result that already seems to have restored a measure of faith in the criminal-justice system for many black people.

title: TV Reviews; 'A Child's Christmas In Wales'
description: ''A CHILD'S CHRISTMAS IN WALES,'' the prose poem by Dylan Thomas (1914-1953), is back in still another filmed incarnation, this one produced in association with the Chicago public-television station WTTW and being broadcast tonight on Channels 21, 31 and 49 at 8 o'clock and on Channel 13 at 9.

title: U.S. Plans to Make Master List of Abusers of Aid Programs
description: The Reagan Administration plans to compile a Governmentwide list of ''irresponsible'' people whose ''seriously improper conduct'' would make them ineligible to receive Federal grants, scholarships, loans, subsidies and other financial aid.

title: Islanders Beaten by Jets, 5-2
description: Andrew McBain and Gilles Hamel each scored twice, and Dave Ellett had three assists as the Winnipeg Jets beat the Islanders, 5-2, tonight.

title: College Basketball; Seton Hall Gains Best Start Since '55
description: James Major scored 20 points and hit two 3-point field goals late in the first half tonight to start a 14-point Seton Hall spurt as the Pirates defeated Holy Cross, 98-76.

title: Jurors Discounted the Key Witness
description: A juror in the Howard Beach trial said yesterday that the jurors, in emotional proceedings, discounted the testimony of the prosecution's key witness but found the testimony of other prosecution witnesses compelling enough to convict three of the defendants of manslaughter.

title: Seeking a Versatile 'Easy' Camera
description: THE popularity of the ''point and shoot'' 35-millimeter camera has significantly affected the photography business in recent years. The automatic cameras - like the Canon Sure Shot, Minolta Freedom and Nikon One-Touch - make it easy for a beginner to take good photographs, buoying interest in conventional still photography and revitalizing the industry.

title: WINE TALK
description: DON'T be ashamed; we all do it. Put off holiday shopping as long as possible, that is.

title: Aquino Needs Help To Curb the Army
description: LEAD: The Aug. 28 coup attempt against the Government of Corazon C. Aquino - its leader, Col. Gregorio Honasan, was captured only last week - shattered the United States Government's complacency toward the Philippines. But Washington has yet to come to terms with the threat to democracy there.

title: Nigeria Frees U.S. Executive
description: An American oil executive left Nigeria tonight, nearly four months after he was detained by the security police, apparently in connection with a $150 million oil dispute.

title: Arnold Bernhard Is Dead at 86; Led Value Line Investor Service
description: Arnold Bernhard, the founder and chief executive officer of Value Line Inc., the world's largest investment advisory service, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Bridge: Not as Well Known as Jay, Simon Becker Was a Titlist
description: One of America's most respected veteran players, 87-year-old Simon Becker, died Dec. 12 after an auto accident in Philadelphia, where he lived.

title: The Pop Life
description: Saxophone Improviser

title: Some Only Dream Of Holiday at Home
description: LEAD: CHRISTMAS is a day to spend with food and familiars, pine boughs and wrapping paper, unless you have a job that automatically puts you out of the running for Mr. or Ms. Sociability of the holiday season.

title: Candidates in Haiti Asking Foreign Help To End Present Rule
description: The four leading presidential candidates called on foreign governments today to rule out intervention in Haiti but asked them to help force the military-dominated Government to resign.

title: The Crucial Legal Charges
description: In voting to acquit two teen-age defendants of second-degree murder, yet convict them and one other youth of second-degree manslaughter, the jury in the Howard Beach case was forced to decide a crucial yet elusive point of law - the distinction between a ''depraved indifference to human life'' and mere recklessness.

title: The Dance: Nikolais And Louis
description: ONE could understand the advantages of sharing a season when the Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company once again appeared together on Monday night as part of the companies' engagement at the Joyce Theater. The well-balanced program contained two pieces by Alwin Nikolais and two by Murray Louis. All were well-made works. None outstayed their welcome. And they gave dancegoers much to cheer about.

title: Florida Suit Names Andrew Cuomo
description: A civil suit filed today contends that Andrew Cuomo, the son of Governor Cuomo of New York, and a group of business associates violated Federal regulations in an attempt to take over two southern Florida savings institutions and drain their assests.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL The O.E.C.D. urged the U.S. and West Germany to take stronger steps to reduce their trade imbalances in order to restore market confidence and reinforce world economic expansion. The organization reserved its strongest criticism for Bonn in a report that predicted sluggish growth for the U.S. and other industrial nations in the next two years. However, the organization did not predict a recession. [ Page D1. ] Excessive changes in the dollar's value should be avoided, the U.S. and its major trading partners agreed. They said they would ''cooperate closely'' to that end. [ D1. ] Companies doing business in South Africa lost their tax credits in a little-noticed amendment to the revenue bill passed by Congress. [ B9. ] A spending bill passed by Congress includes sanctions that are expected to deprive Japanese companies of several hundred million dollars a year of business in the U.S. [ D13. ] Brazil may have fended off U.S. sanctions with reductions in curbs that it had placed on U.S. computers and software. [ D5. ] COMPANIES I.B.M. will join a leading supercomputer scientist in a venture to develop a new generation of supercomputers. Its partner is Steve S. Chen, former chief engineer at Cray. [ D1. ] Worlds of Wonder has filed for bankruptcy protection only a year after the toy maker was one of the fastest-growing companies in history. A dismal Christmas season didn't help matters. [ D1. ] A Federal judge gave 55 retailers an early Christmas present - a ruling that they are the classiest stores in America. That opinion came in the case of two competing fragrances, Passion and Elizabeth Taylor's Passion. [ D1. ] Three securities firms were designated as primary dealers by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. They are Nikko, CRT Government Securities and Lloyds Government Securities. [ D1. ] Goodrich, which had no blimp, now has no tires: It has agreed to sell its 50 percent interest in Uniroyal Goodrich. [ D5. ] Jay A. Pritzker dropped his bid for Pan Am after the pilots union refused to go along with the $800 million in concessions he needed from a coalition of five unions. [ D5. ] THE ECONOMY The President signed a catch-all spending bill and another measure to limit the deficit, and Congress adjourned. [ A1 ] . The I.R.S. will not penalize taxpayers who had too little withheld from their paychecks this year. [ D2. ] Orders for durable goods edged up slightly in November to a seasonally adjusted rate of $111.09 billion last month. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stock prices lost ground, and traders blamed profit taking and nervousness about Middle Eastern developments. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.93 points, to 1978.45. [ D6. ] Oil prices rose sharply amid reports of OPEC production cutbacks and of military actions in the Persian Gulf. [ D12. ] The surge in oil prices eroded bond prices, causing intermediate and longer-term interest rates to rise. [ D13. ] The dollar was narrowly mixed in light pre-holiday trading. Gold rose $4.85, to $484.60 an ounce, in New York. [ D12. ] A Chicago Merc panel found no evidence that the futures markets accelerated the stock market's plunge on Oct. 19. [ D6. ] TECHNOLOGY The latest single-lens reflex cameras take advantage of new and compact battery designs, microprocessors and electronic motors and provide surprising versatility. [ D4. ] New methods to destroy or detoxify waste greatly increase the options available. Advances. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Japan is starting to redirect its economy toward faster domestic growth and slower external growth. Prime Minister Takeshita and his Cabinet accepted a plan calling for that transformation. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Donald J. Trump may revoke his Resorts International tender offer of $15 a share for all of the company's class A common stock, made just two days ago. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: A Texas-Size Stain on Justice
description: Settlement of the Pennzoil-Texaco case reduces history's largest civil judgment from $10 billion to a mere $3 billion and enriches a lot of lawyers, but still leaves a huge blemish on the Texas judiciary. Last month the Texas Supreme Court, without even hearing oral argument, found nothing wrong with a trial judge's accepting a $10,000 campaign contribution from Pennzoil's lawyer and enlisting that lawyer to raise $50,000 more.

title: Third Deadline Is Set for Plan At Coliseum Site
description: Negotiations over the new Columbus Circle project failed to meet a deadline of Monday at midnight, went past a second deadline of early last night and are now facing yet a third deadline of tomorrow at 2 P.M.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Anti-Apartheid Sermon
description: The Rev. Allan Boesak of South Africa, a leading opponent of apartheid, has established a tradition of preaching a sermon at Christmas time at Bethel Baptist Church in central Washington. The pastor of the church is Walter E. Fauntroy, the nonvoting Congressman from the District of Columbia.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE always been interested by the natural liaisons of foods whose flavors complete each other like well-made harmonies. Some of the most obvious that come to mind are port and Roquefort cheese; a genuine Sauternes and fresh foie gras, and roast lamb with flageolets.

title: Economic Scene; Japan Will Seek Balanced Growth
description: JAPAN is starting to rejuggle its economy in an effort to attain faster domestic growth and slower external growth. Prime Minister Noburo Takeshita and his Cabinet accepted a plan yesterday, prepared by the Economic Planning Agency, for transforming the country from a supercompetitive export machine to a more balanced and affluent society ready to play a larger role in stabilizing the world economy.

title: Shots Heard on Jet Crash Tape
description: Four apparent gunshots were heard in the cockpit of Pacific Southwest Airlines Flight 1771 before it crashed on Dec. 7, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: EDUCATION: Lessons
description: The blood is boiling. The heart has begun to thump. A radical idea is at hand, and the call to scholarship has been sounded.

title: Advertising; New Blair President
description: It takes a special sort of guy with a special sort of dedication - or greed - to desert Tampa, Fla., for Rochester as the winter begins to bare its icy talons. Just that sort of man is Edmond C. Froehlich, 41 years old, who has left behind Young & Rubicam/ Zemp, where he was president and chief executive, to join Blair Advertising, one of the Omnicom Group, as president and chief operating officer. The chairman and chief executive is John F. Kraushaar.

title: I.B.M. in Joint Venture On Supercomputers
description: Highlighting its intention to stake a claim at the leading edge of computer technology, the International Business Machines Corporation today announced plans for an ambitious joint development project with a tiny, three-month-old company led by one of the world's leading supercomputer scientists.

title: Gretchen Uppercu Hill, Flower Judge, 76
description: Gretchen Uppercu Hill died of a stroke Monday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Going to Israel?
description: With the unrest in Israel over Palestinian protests and a general strike joined by hundreds of thousands, the State Department sought Monday to offer assistance to Americans planning to go there over the holidays.

title: Kodak-Matsushita Battery Venture
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and the Matsushita Group of Japan have agreed to create a jointly managed battery factory in the United States. Kodak already sells alkaline batteries made by Matsushita. The new plant, which is scheduled to be built in 1988, would make batteries for both Kodak and the Matshushita Electric Corporation of America, a Kodak spokesman, Henry Kaska, said. The site has not been selected.

title: Bilzerian Remains Silent on Financing
description: The Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian gave no word about whether his partnership had obtained the financing it needed for his extended $1.06 billion bid to take over the Singer Company. On Monday, Mr. Bilzerian said he had asked Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. and the National Westminster Bank USA for financing commitments by today. And he extended his $50-a-share tender offer by one day.

title: Restore the Marines' Good Name
description: The Navy brass owe the Marines and the country an explanation. After almost three months of grilling and polygraphing the one suspect it knew to be guilty, the Naval Investigative Service apparently is satisfied that Marine security guards at the U.S. Embassy in Moscow didn't give away the store to Soviet spies. In fact, they didn't even come close.

title: Corrections
description: An article from Sharpsburg, Md., on Nov 10, about preserving the Civil War battlefield at Antietam, misattributed the statement that ''consciousness of the past is necessary to maintain our cohesive cultural identity.'' It is from an article by Prof, Ruben Rainey of the University of Virginia. He was quoted at a Civil War round table by Robert Meinhard, professor emeritus at Winona College in Minnesota.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE NATIONAL GEOGRAPHIC SOCIETY. 100 Years of Adventure and Discovery. By C. D. B. Bryan. Illustrated. 484 pages. Abrams. $45.

title: Board of Ed Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1987
description: International A3-9

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Seven days after undergoing quadruple heart bypass surgery, Coach Bo Schembechler of Michigan was released from St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. . . . A former Harlem Globetrotter, Curly Neal, has been hired as director of special projects for the Orlando Magic, which is scheduled to join the National Basketball Association in 1989...Curtis Strange has been named Player of the Year by the Golf Writers Association of America. Strange, who set a PGA Tour earnings record of $925,941 this season, also won the award in 1985. The writers also named Betsy King the L.P.G.A. Player of the Year and Chi Chi Rodriguez as the Seniors winner. . . . Miami's Bennie Blades, Oklahoma's Rickey Dixon and Florida State's Deion Sanders are the finalists for the Jim Thorpe Award, which recognizes the best college defensive back as voted upon by a committee of sportscasters, and former coaches and players. The winner will be announced Jan. 19.

title: Keeping Eggshells Out
description: To The Living Section:
