title: To Many Blacks, Bias Remains the Big Issue
description: Black officials, civil-rights leaders, clergy and citizens expressed qualified approval of the verdicts in the Howard Beach case yesterday, but renewed their criticism of what they see as a deep undercurrent of racism in the city that sprang to the surface again in that violent incident one year ago.

title: ARCO Buys More of Britoil
description: ARCO, moving quickly to increase its stake in Britoil P.L.C., which is also the target of a takeover bid by the British Petroleum Company, said today that it had raised its stake in Britoil to 19.25 percent. On Friday, it held 14.7 percent.

title: Musical 'Chess' to Open Earlier Than Expected
description: The musical ''Chess'' will open on Broadway in late April or May -earlier than previously anticipated and without an out-of-town tryout, according to Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, which is a co-producer of the show .

title: Bucks Outrun Knicks
description: John Lucas scored a season-high 25 points, and Randy Breuer added 24 tonight, leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 122-105 victory over the Knicks.

title: Dow Closes Down 11.93, to 1,978.45
description: Stock prices gave ground yesterday as profit taking and nervousness about developments in the Middle East were blamed for the trades.

title: George R. Morrison, Economist, 57
description: George R. Morrison, a professor of economics at the Rutgers University School of Management, died of a heart attack Dec. 15 at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 57 years old.

title: Jerome Seckler, Publishing Executive, 72
description: Jerome Seckler, a retired publishing company executive, died of cardiac arrest Sunday after undergoing bypass surgery at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: CONGRESS FINISHES
description: President Reagan today signed a catch-all spending measure and a bill to hold down the Federal deficit, allowing a battle-weary Congress to call it quits at last for 1987.

title: Durables Orders Up Slightly
description: Orders to United States manufacturers for durable goods edged up slightly in November, the Government said today.

title: Official of Democratic Party In Kansas Is Shot to Death
description: Charles W. Thompson, chairman of the Wyandotte County Democratic Party Central Committee and a two-time delegate to the party's national convention, was shot and killed today outside a restaurant, the police said.

title: Operetta: 'Dynamite Tonight'
description: TOWARD the end of ''Dynamite Tonight,'' a cabaret-style operetta set in a war-ravaged bunker, a woman bearing word of a cease-fire is shot, to which one soldier sings, ''If peace was declared, killing a girl was not the thing to do.''

title: Westchester Faces 15% Rise In Taxes as Budget Is Passed
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators today approved an $846.9 million budget for next year, after trimming $3.4 million from the spending plan that County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke had presented.

title: Fugitive Jersey Politician Seized Off India's Coast
description: A former state senator who disappeared two years ago after a staged scuba-diving death off Grand Bahama Island has been seized on the island of Male in the Indian Ocean, Federal authorities said today.

title: Judge Cleared of Witness Abuse; Investigation of Holtzman Is Urged
description: A Brooklyn judge was cleared yesterday of an allegation that he humiliated a complainant by ordering her to re-enact a rape. At the same time, the state's Chief Administrative Judge recommended that the Brooklyn District Attorney be investigated for making the allegation.

title: No Current Plans to Prosecute Meese on Wedtech
description: A special prosecutor announced today that he had no current plans to prosecute Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d as a result of an investigation of the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor.

title: Sports People; Nets Sign O'Koren
description: Mike O'Koren, after being released by Washington and spurned by Boston, signed a contract with the Nets yesterday and will rejoin New Jersey for the rest of this season. The 29-year-old O'Koren, who played six seasons in New Jersey, was traded by the Nets to the Washington Bullets in 1986. He appeared in only 15 games for the Bullets before he was waived last February.

title: Stephen Crane's Shifting Image
description: A markedly altered image of Stephen Crane that changes the familiar view of him as a dashing war correspondent is to appear next year in a new edition of his correspondence. The work adds 170 newly discovered letters by Crane and 20 by his wife, Cora, to the standard edition of his letters that came out three decades ago.

title: Wide Range of Bills Would Affect Foreign Policy
description: The measures enacted by Congress in the year-end rush to adjourn contain a wide range of provisions affecting American policy in South Africa, Central America and the Middle East, as well as the operations of the State Department.

title: Hockey Rivals May Be Catching Up to Soviet
description: Muscovites who came to the Luzhniki Arena in recent days expecting to savor the power and perfection of the Soviet hockey team returned home wondering if they had instead witnessed the demise of a dynasty.

title: S.E.C. Gives Key Post To New York Lawyer
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday named Lawrence Iason, a New York lawyer, as administrator for its key New York regional office, ending a temporary situation in which two S.E.C. officials from Washington ran the office.

title: Single Gene May Determine Sex of an Embryo
description: An international team of scientists has discovered what appears to be a single gene that determines whether a human embryo will grow into a male or a female.

title: Advertising; HBM/Creamer Wins Kinney Shoes Account
description: A lot of agencies would like to be in the shoes of HBM/Creamer of Boston, because those shoes are Kinney's and Kinney will be spending at least $12 million to advertise them.

title: Gutfreund's Pay Is Cut
description: In a sign of the decline in the securities industry this year, John H. Gutfreund, the chairman and chief executive of Salomon Inc., will take a $2 million pay cut for 1987, he has told executives at the Wall Street firm.

title: CRITICISM OF ISRAEL SHARPENED BY U.S. ON ARAB PROTESTS
description: After days of quiet and unsuccessful diplomatic appeals to Israeli leaders, the Reagan Administration today issued an unusual public criticism of the ''harsh security measures and excessive use of live ammunition'' by Israeli troops who have been confronting Palestinian demonstrators.

title: KEY RATES
A Personalized Card Ideal for Procrastinators
description: Even procrastinators can now send ''photocards'' -photographs with holiday messages printed on them -which undoubtedly explains why so many people seem to be doing it this year.

title: Sports of The Times; Hitting the Comeback Trail
description: ''He had a broad face and a little round belly, that shook when he laughed like a bowl full of jelly.'' DID you see him last Friday night, completing his appointed rounds? He was right there, big as life, on ESPN. It looked as if he would have a difficult time wriggling his 244-pound frame down a chimney. As it was, George Foreman, the onetime heavyweight champion of the world, pretty much filled the television screen. He did not even bother to sit between rounds, perhaps wondering whether the stool would support him.

title: Transit for the Disabled Shouldn't Be Expensive
description: To the Editor:

title: Warm Doings at the South Pole
description: AT Palmer Station, the American base on the Antarctic Peninsula, Christmas came a few days early last year. As Nancy Pellerin, a research technologist in microbiology, recalled, she and 34 other scientists performing research at the station were awaiting a supply ship, due around Christmas Day.

title: Pates and Terrines For Winter Eves
description: IT is true, as has often been observed, that a terrine is nothing more than a meat loaf with a French accent. But it is equally true that one of the most welcome presentations on the holiday table could be a well-made terrine maison, a savory mixture of rough-textured chopped pork, pork fat and liver that has been flavored with warm aromatics like cinnamon and allspice.

title: Soviet-U.S. Finale a Tie
description: Mikhail Vasiljev scored on a breakaway with less than three minutes left in the third period tonight to give the Soviet Union Select team a 3-3 tie against the United States Olympic team in the finale of their eight-game exhibition series.

title: Bonds Decline as Oil Prices Surge
description: An unexpected surge in oil prices eroded bond prices yesterday, causing intermediate and longer-term interest rates to rise. The rebound in oil prices also stirred some fears of an increase in inflation next year.

title: Angola Turning to the West to Equip Its Military
description: Four Soviet-made WAZ jeeps pulled out of Lubango's airport, ferrying visiting United Nations military observers to a hotel.

title: Why No Testing of Additives?
description: LEAD: In the next several years, American companies will be readying for the market a number of synthetic food additives, primarily substitutes for sugars and fats. Before they can be sold, however, the Federal Government must certify that they are safe. That shouldn't take long, though: The Government has hardly any rules for such additives.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: EATING WELL
description: TO a New Yorker, Bostonian or Philadelphian, seltzer is salt-free carbonated water: club soda without the salt. To a Californian, seltzer is salt-free carbonated water or flavored salt-free carbonated water or sweetened and flavored salt-free carbonated water.

title: Jackson Makes Plea On the Middle East At Holiday Season
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday in a holiday message that it was inappropriate to extend Christmas and Hanukkah greetings while the Middle East was ravaged by violence and the Israelis were occupying Arab territory.

title: Clearing the Air for Nonsmokers
description: A smoker feels harassed when asked to put out a cigarette. But nonsmokers feel harassed, and subjected to health risk, by having to breathe in the smoker's smoke. How, then, to keep both happy? By making it very clear where smoking will and will not be allowed.

title: Panel Says Futures Markets Did Not Cause Stock Plunge
description: An independent panel appointed by the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it had found no evidence that the futures markets accelerated the stock market's huge plunge on Oct. 19.

title: Buyout Is Studied Of Pueblo Chain
description: A Pueblo International Inc. shareholder group, including the company's chairman and chief executive officer, Harold Toppel, said it was exploring a leveraged buyout of the supermarket company. The group, which said it controls nearly 1.2 million Pueblo shares, or 33.8 percent of the total common stock, made the disclosure in a filing with Federal securities regulators.

title: Judge Blocks Ethics Inquiry of a Georgia Official
description: A judge today ordered the Georgia Bar to halt disciplinary proceedings against the State Attorney General on charges that he violated an ethics code by suing a state agency over a closed meeting.

title: Weight Control; From Obesity Experts, A Green Light For Merry-Makers
description: It may be too much to ask that obesity experts tell people to go ahead and gorge themselves over the holidays. But they are coming close.

title: 200 Mourners Recall Woman Who Died After Her Arrest
description: More than 200 people crowded into a tiny Bronx funeral home where a 28-year-old black woman was mourned yesterday by public officials and ministers as a symbol of what they termed the continuing struggle to stamp out racism in New York City.

title: Dollar Firm; 7-Nation Plan Is Doubted
description: The dollar firmed slightly yesterday in very light trading, as dealers shrugged off the latest affirmation by the United States and its trading partners that they would seek to check a further decline in its value.

title: Drugs Mar Christmas on a Harlem Street
description: On winter nights 119th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues looks much like a turn-of-the-century photograph, with its low buildings and brownstone facades. Bathed in the amber of the street lamps, the street is sepia-toned, serene. The doorway of one of the grander homes is draped with wreaths and the tiny white lights that mark the holiday season.

title: Market Place; New Enthusiasm For Wal-Mart
description: IF you liked the stock of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in the low 40's, you ought to love it in the mid-20's.

title: Concert: Chicago Baroque Ensemble
description: BACH'S ''Christmas Oratorio,'' all six cantatas of it, was performed with lightness, precision and some virtuosity Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall by the 26-voice choir and 39-member orchestra (modern instruments) of Thomas Wikman's Music of the Baroque ensemble from Chicago.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Reggie Sutton, a cornerback, rejoined the New Orleans Saints yesterday after a month during which he underwent treatment for substance abuse. ''I'm just trying to get my life together,'' Sutton said. . . . Dennis Harrah, the Los Angeles Rams guard, has announced his retirement after 13 seasons. His announcement came after the league announced that he had been selected to the Pro Bowl for the sixth time.

title: The Clearer Message
description: Some may think the meaning of the Howard Beach trial is that racial violence no longer will be tolerated. Others may think the manslaughter convictions of three young white men demonstrate the power of black political pressures. But the clearer ''message'' comes not from the verdict - reached only after 12 days of jury deliberation - but in the reaction of all too many blacks and whites.

title: Silver Treasures From Latin Lands
description: FROM the 17th to the 19th centuries, the Latin American regions that are now Argentina, Bolivia and Peru produced a treasury of silver objects. A selection is currently on view at a show called ''Southern Splendor'' at the Americas Society, Park Avenue at 68th Street.

title: Homeless Children: Looking for Compassion as Well as Shelter
description: The West Women's Hotel, a run-down building on Skid Row here, is an outpost in the difficult battle being waged around the country to save the spirits of homeless children. It is a place where it can take a month of cuddling and comfort in a locked playroom to coax a 3-year-old girl to smile at her own reflection in a mirror.

title: 'Woza Albert!' Revival Planned at City College
description: The play ''Woza Albert!'' by Percy Mtwa, Mbongeni Ngema and Barney Simon will begin a 12-performance run on Jan. 13 at Davis Hall, City College of the City University of New York, Convent Avenue and West 133d Street. Mr. Mtwa and Mr. Ngema, both South Africans, also appeared in the play when it was first presented in New York in 1984; Mr. Simon, artistic director of the Market Theater in Johannesburg, directed the production.

title: Misha Dichter in Recitals
description: The pianist Misha Dichter will give the first of three New York recitals this season on Jan. 22 at 8 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Dichter, whose New York debut was 20 years ago in January, will play works by Beethoven, Schumann, Chopin and Liszt. He is also to play all-Schubert programs Jan. 26 and Feb. 2 at the 92d Street Y. Tickets to the Carnegie Hall concert are $11, $13 and $16. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Jane E. Brody
description: When a semitropical animal chooses to live in a cold climate, keeping warm is a primary concern. We are such animals, but when it comes to protecting our relatively hairless bodies against the onslaught of frigid winter air and winds, we often don't do as well as less intelligent animals.

title: Yields Flat For Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts were flat for the pre-holiday week ended yesterday.

title: Bilzerian Obtains Financing For Bid to Acquire Singer
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor, announced yesterday that he had raised most of the money for his $1 billion cash offer to buy the Singer Company.

title: '88 Growth Forecast Cut to 2.4%
description: The Reagan Administration today substantially lowered its forecast for economic growth next year but predicted that 1988 would become the sixth consecutive year without a recession.

title: To Mars, Via Moscow
description: America's space agency keeps looking at the heavens through bizarre bifocals. At a time when the paramount need is to reduce the Federal deficit, NASA's top goal is to build a $32 billion space station that has no clear purpose. Congress knows that, yet is willing only to cut in half NASA's request for $770 million in start-up funds.

title: Support for Dollar Helps Bonds
description: Bond prices rebounded yesterday after finance ministers of seven major industrialized Western countries stated that they opposed further declines in the dollar's value.

title: Eddie Murphy's 'Raw' Is No. 1 at Box Office
description: ''Raw,'' Eddie Murphy's verbally explicit comedy concert film, took in $9 million in its first week to top the box office receipts.

title: Jazz: McGriff-Crawford
description: THERE'S a satisfying aura of dependability about the double bill at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, through Sunday. The Jimmy McGriff-Hank Crawford quartet and the Houston Person-Etta Jones quintet deliver ballads, steaming uptempo tunes and maybe even a bop or Latin number, but they never stray far from the blues. Within such well-worn riffs and harmonies, the challenge is to walk the line between the comfortable and the predictable: to avoid corniness and infuse solos with down-home emotion.

title: U.S. Seeks to Keep P.L.O. Office Open
description: The Reagan Administration is struggling to find a way to avoid closing the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations, even though a new law requires that it be shut, Administration officials said today.

title: Pell the Pioneer
description: Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has agreed to be the pioneer in trying out a state-of-the-art hearing room that was recently completed in the Hart Senate Office Building.

title: 3-1 (Maybe 2-1), This'll Awaken Voters
description: Let's face it. Except for the odd dramatic event, like Gary Hart's departure and return, the country has been sleeping through the Presidential primary season. Voter participation rates are hitting all-time lows. Just a few weeks ago, thousands of viewers complained when NBC pre-empted ''Alf,'' the sitcom, to show Tom Brokaw's interview with Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Radical reform - something dramatic - is needed to sustain the image of a great democracy in which constitutional freedoms are vigorously exercised.

title: Retailers See Lower Gains From Holiday Sales
description: Pre-Christmas sales are not working, retailers say.

title: Egypt, Challenging the Iranians, Is Expanding Military Role in Gulf
description: Egypt is laying the groundwork for a significant expansion of its military presence in the Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, taking a more conspicuous role in a widening Arab military confrontation with Iran.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Surrender in Chicago
description: Chicago has surrendered its public housing projects to heavily armed street gangs. Their bloody encounters terrorize the dilapidated high-rise communities that are home to thousands of poor families. Children are particularly at risk. Some, even while in grade school, are dragooned by the gangs for training in drug dealing. Those who escape that fate are still exposed daily to stray bullets and to the violent deaths of siblings and schoolmates. Their experience at times sounds like that of the children in Belfast or Beirut.

title: South Africa Gold Plant
description: South Africa, the world's biggest gold producer, will spend 77.9 million rand, or about $40 million, to build a gold refinery capable of processing about 800 metric tons of bullion a year. The new plant will be built on the high-security site of the existing refinery at Germiston, near Johannesburg.

title: Deborah Kaback, Lawyer, And Alvin Korn Are Wed
description: The marriage of Deborah Kaback, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kaback of New York, to Alvin H. Korn, the son of Ann Korn of New York and the late David Korn, took place yesterday at the bride's home in New York. Rabbi Gordon Tucker officiated.

title: Turks Answer the Met In Suit Over Artifacts
description: The Turkish Government has filed legal papers responding to a motion by the Metropolitan Museum of Art to dismiss a suit in which Turkey has demanded the return of artifacts it contends were illegally exported in the 1960's, Harry I. Rand, an attorney representing Turkey, said yesterday.

title: Mob Figure Is Offered A Deal for His Release
description: In a highly unusual move, a Federal judge yesterday offered to release Joseph Armone, the reputed underboss of the Gambino crime family, on $1 million bond pending his sentencing if he publicly renounced any connection he might have had with the organization and resigned any position he might hold.

title: For Child With AIDS, Hospital Is Home
description: He was born on Christmas Day 1984 in a New York City hospital, and although no one knew it at the time, he was infected with the AIDS virus.

title: INSIDE
description: Computer Security Change President Reagan is expected to sign a bill shifting from military to civilian hands the control over standards for safeguarding information stored in the nation's computers. Page A10. Slower U.S. Growth Seen The Reagan Administration predicted lower economic growth in 1988, but expects a steady employment rate and lower inflation. Page D1. Cutbacks by Postal Service Many post offices around the nation will shut at least the next two Saturdays because of budget cuts, but Saturday delivery will go on. Page B6.

title: AIDS Test Facility For No. 7 Insurer
description: The Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company said it had agreed to provide part of the financing in a $10 million laboratory and plans to enter the growing market for AIDS testing by insurers.

title: South African Blacks Moving to White Areas
description: The view from Rose Malakeng's balcony, across Wanderers Street to the railroad station, is not the stuff of which postcards are made. But it is special to Mrs. Malakeng, who has the kind of home that many blacks in South Africa have hankered after for a lifetime.

title: Going for the Gold in Decor and Design
description: WHILE gold has always been a mark of opulence in traditional interiors -18th-century palaces and late 19th-century parlors were not shy about flaunting gilded accoutrements - gold has been out of fashion in contemporary interiors for decades.

title: U.S. Finds Progress in Cutting Alcohol's Toll, Except Among Adolescents
description: A national campaign to reduce the death and suffering from alcohol abuse seems to be working for adults, with consumption dropping, drinking-related traffic fatalities decreasing and more people becoming aware that alcohol and pregnancy don't mix.

title: Shuttle Booster Rocket Passes 2d Test
description: Engineers at a snowy, remote Utah site today successfully conducted the second full-scale test firing of the redesigned rocket booster for the space shuttle.

title: Israel's Time Bomb
description: LEAD: There simply is no genteel democratic way to keep a restive population of more than one million people in check. This is the lesson Israel is learning, to its sorrow, in Gaza, Judea and Samaria. Only force will restrain a people living under military occupation, no matter how benign. That is the only way to keep a refractory population under permanent rule -with force, spies and the political power that comes from the barrel of a gun.

title: 'Squeaky' Fromme Sought After an Apparent Escape
description: Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme, who is serving a life sentence for the attempted assassination of President Ford in 1975, was reported missing last night from the Alderson Federal Prison for Women in West Virginia, the authorities said early today.

title: European Steel Quotas
description: The steel ministers of the European Community have extended its quota system on steel production for six months to allow the industry more time to cut surplus production. Without the decision, the community quota system, which has shielded the steel industry from competition since 1980, would have expired on Dec. 31.

title: Jazz: Bloom and Robinson
description: ALTHOUGH the soprano saxophonist Jane Ira Bloom has been leading a jazz group for a decade and the clarinetist Perry Robinson has had his own groups for 20 years, they are both strangers to New York's major jazz clubs. So their current appearance with their quartets at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street through Sunday, is a breakthrough for each of them.

title: ISRAEL BEARS DOWN TO STOP PROTESTS IN OCCUPIED AREAS >
description: As the Israeli Army arrested hundreds of Palestinians, the Government pressed tough measures today to smother disorders in the occupied territories.

title: Barkley Lifts 76ers in Stretch
description: Charles Barkley sat on the training table, bags of ice on each knee, as he answered reporters' questions. Despite a slow start, he took care to have the last word.

title: Protege's Goal: That His Design Mentor Get Her Due
description: AS the last and one of the best known of Elsie de Wolfe's proteges, Tony Duquette is often asked to describe his mentor. What would Mrs. de Wolfe think of such and such? Which of her talents were the greatest? What was it like when she walked into a room? What was her darkest secret?

title: Campaign Finance; Top Insurance Officials Underwrite Dole Effort
description: This year some top insurance executives, who usually help protect policyholders against risk, are helping to underwrite Senator Bob Dole's effort to win the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: Undercover Operations Are Threat to Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Toon Is Lone Jet Named
description: Al Toon was the only Jet voted to the American Conference Pro Bowl team by the conference's players and coaches. The graceful wide receiver was also named the Jets' most valuable player this season by his teammates. Of the two honors, both announced today, the second had the most significance for Toon.

title: Hob Broun, a Novelist, Dies as Respirator Fails
description: Hob Broun, a writer, died of asphyxiation Dec. 16 when his respirator broke down in his home in Portland, Ore. He was 37 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The Administration sharply lowered its growth forecast for next year but predicted that 1988 would become the sixth consecutive year without a recession. It estimated that the G.N.P. would rise by 2.4 percent after adjusting for inflation - more than a full percentage point lower than the 3.5 percent projection for next year that it made in August. The unemployment rate will hold steady, according to the forecast by Beryl W. Sprinkel, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. [ Page D1. ] Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 11.7 percent in mid-December from the year-ago period. But analysts said that the sales were strong and that the year-to-year comparison was misleading, because last year's sales were inflated by the effects of the impending change in the tax law. [ D3. ] Pre-Christmas sales are not working, retailers say. Even where sales have increased volume, they have not helped the bottom line, and diminished fourth-quarter profits are foreseen. [ D2. ] Fewer people are watching network television, according to the recently introduced ''people meter'' ratings device. [ A1. ] COMPANIES A General Dynamics/McDonnell Douglas team won a Navy contract to build an advanced attack aircraft in a program that could eventually be worth $45 billion. The Advanced Tactical Aircraft has been described as a carrier-based bomber with ''stealth'' technology intende to evade detection by radar. [ D1. ] American Home Products joined the bidding for A. H. Robins, offering stock valued at $550 million and a commitment to provide $2.48 billion in cash over seven years to compensate women who claim they suffered injuries from Robins's Dalkon Shield intrauterine birth control device. [ D1. ] Paul A. Bilzerian seemed near completion of his deal for Singer, saying he had raised most of the money for his $1 billion cash offer. He also said he was seeking a $150 million investment in the venture from T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman. [ D1. ] A takeover panel said B.P.'s bid for Britoil could proceed, but the Government said it would prevent any bidder from gaining control of the country's largest independent oil company. [ D3. ] Phillips Petroleum's shares rose sharply amid rumors of a hostile takeover bid. [ D5. ] Wurlitzer will sell its keyboard business to Baldwin Piano, combining two of the best-known names in musical instruments. [ D3. ] MARKETS The dollar firmed slightly in very light trading, as dealers shrugged off the latest affirmation by the U.S. and its trading partners that they would seek to check a further decline in its value. In New York, gold dropped $1.25 an ounce, to $483.35. [ D1. ] The Dow Jones industrial average rose above the 2,000 level for the first time since Nov. 2, and many traders said computerized buying by large institutions helped push it along. At the close, the Dow was up 27.19 points, or 1.37 percent, to 2,005.64. [ D4. ] Bond prices rebounded after the Group of Seven said it opposed further declines in the dollar's value. The closely watched 8 7/8 percent Treasury issue due in 2017 was offered at 99 5/8, up 1 3/8 points, to yield about 8.91 percent. [ D10. ] Oil prices were mixed as traders took profits in the wake of Tuesday's rally. [ D11. ] Yields were flat on C.D.'s, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts for the week ended yesterday. [ D14. ] INTERNATIONAL Many Western nations - but not the U.S. - will contribute about $8 billion to a new fund to aid the poorest and most indebted developing countries, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa. The fund will lend money at half a percent annual interest to help finance economic reform programs of the I.M.F. and the World Bank. [ A3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Before Frank Lorenzo bid for Eastern Airlines, he gave some thought to selling some of its assets if he couldn't control labor costs, an aide recalls. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] If you liked the stock of Wal-Mart in the low 40's, you ought to love it in the mid-20's, according to analysts. Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Paris Is Cool To Pere Noel: Is He Passe?
description: Ferdinand Bachmann, a 30-year veteran of the Salvation Army, had an insider's explanation for why the Christmas shoppers sliding by him in front of Galeries Lafayette were plunking fewer francs into his metal drum this year. It was too warm. ''The colder it is,'' he said, an idle bell dangling in his left hand, ''the more they give.'' Three decades of bell-ringing told him that in this exceptionally mild holiday season potential donors had trouble empathizing with the destitute and the homeless.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Congress; Gifts Given, Received and Sometimes Shared
description: Despite their preoccupation with last-minute work on catch-all spending legislation and a bill to reduce the Federal deficit, members of Congress still found time to spread holiday cheer among themselves.

title: Holly Sugar Gets New Bid
description: Facing a Thursday deadline to accept a $95 million takeover bid from a New York investor group, the Holly Sugar Corporation said today that it had received a rival offer from the Imperial Sugar Company.

title: College Basketball; Rutgers Falls, 72-46
description: Max Blank, a junior center, scored a career-high 27 points as George Washington defeated Rutgers, 72-46, tonight in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.

title: Rust's Parents Visit Prison
description: The parents of the West German pilot Mathias Rust, who was sentenced to four years in a Soviet labor camp after a flight from Finland to Red Square last May, visited him in Lefortovo prison today. Heinz and Monika Rust told journalists their son was in good spirits and expected to be transferred to a labor camp early next year. Mr. Rust, 19, was convicted in September of hooliganism and violation of flight and border laws.

title: Aurlie Pomerantz Is Wed To Mark Chass, a Student
description: Aurlie Pomerantz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haim Pomerantz of Givatayim, Israel, was married last evening to Mark Chass, a first-year student at the Columbia University Law School. Rabbi Yechezkel Zweig performed the ceremony at Loews Glenpointe Hotel in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Aliens Are Paying a Price for Honesty
description: If Mohsen Moharerzadeh, a 26-year-old Iranian photographer, had secretly waded across the Rio Grande into the United States, he would probably be free, working here and pursuing an application for political asylum.

title: At 4 Major Catholic Colleges, AIDS Statement Is Welcome
description: Despite the split among Roman Catholic bishops in the United States over their recent statement on AIDS education and the use of condoms, officials at four major Catholic colleges say they welcome the statement as an endorsement of their AIDS policies.

title: Advertising; Celebrations Mask Fear At Agencies
description: ON the surface, at least, Christmas is coming to Madison Avenue much as it usually does. There are parties. There are bonuses. But the frivolity is tempered by fear. Jobs thought secure have evaporated as the result of megamergers or the new economics of the business.

title: Faster Move by Penney
description: The J. C. Penney Company expects to complete its move from New York by July 1, several months ahead of schedule. The retailing company's chairman, William Howell, said on Tuesday that he expected about 60 percent of Penney's 2,200 top managers and a smaller percentage of the 1,600 New York-based non-managers to move in the headquarters shift to the Dallas suburb of Plano.

title: Europe Inflation Slows
description: Consumer prices in the European Community edged up two-tenths of a percent in November, a much smaller increase than October's five-tenths of a percent, the community's statistics office, Eurostat, said today. It said the community's inflation rate for the year should come to a modest 3.4 percent, up from last year's 2.9 percent.

title: Andrew Cuomo Files Libel Suit in Florida
description: Andrew Cuomo filed a $10 million libel suit today against the chairwoman of a savings group who sued him and other shareholders in a claim that they tried to conduct an illegal takeover.

title: Tanjore Ranganathan, Drummer, 62
description: Tanjore Ranganathan, a professional performer of South Indian music for half a century and a longtime artist-in-residence at Wesleyan University, died Monday after a long illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Rights Group Faults Taiwan
description: Taiwan is making some progress but has quite a way to go to live up to its stated commitment to human rights and greater democracy, according to the rights group Asia Watch.

title: Navy Fears Faulty Jet Work
description: Navy engineers are checking 300 jet engines throughout the world after discovering that an error-prone mechanic was incorrectly assembling gearboxes, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, has received an order from Canadian Airlines International, which was formed last March with the merger of Pacific Western and Canadian Pacific airlines, for two 767-300 extended-range jets, plus options on eight more, worth a total of $660 million if all the options are exercised.

title: Howard Beach Lawyer to Request Court Hearing on Juror's Conduct
description: The lawyer for a convicted teen-ager in the Howard Beach case said yesterday that he would ask the judge for a hearing to determine if, before the verdict, the jury foreman had authorized a television news producer to try to sell her story to newspapers.

title: A Judge in Manhattan Is Charged With Misusing Powers for Friend
description: A judge in Manhattan has been charged by state disciplinary officials with misusing his judicial powers in a series of cases involving a friend, according to state officials and court records.

title: Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL

title: Doctor Settles AIDS Lawsuit Against Roommate in Texas
description: A pediatrician whose practice collapsed after he filed a lawsuit that revealed he had tested positive for the AIDS virus has agreed to settle the suit against his former roommate.

title: U.S. Urges Inspections Of Engine Bolts on Jets
description: Federal safety investigators are urging closer inspection of the engine mounting bolts on hundreds of Boeing 737 airplanes to detect possible cracking.

title: Nancy E. Wright Wed To George H. Garfield
description: The marriage of Nancy Elizabeth Wright, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Madison B. Wright of Dickinson, Tex., to George Hodges Garfield, the president of Inverness Counsel, investment counselors in New York, took place yesterday in Houston. The Rev. John N. McAllister officiated at St. Martin's Episcopal Church.

title: Soviet Reports on Afghan Battle
description: Soviet and Government troops have killed or wounded more than 1,500 Afghan guerrillas in the first two days of a drive to lift the siege of Khost, a major garrison city southeast of Kabul, the Kremlin said today.

title: 6 Killed as a Commuter Plane Crashes in Alaska
description: A commuter plane carrying eight people lost power in one of its two engines after takeoff today and crashed into a house, killing five passengers and the pilot, officials said.

title: TV Reviews; Profundity and Puffery
description: FREQUENTLY in the land of television, the line between an entertainment and a commercial can get curiously thin. Next week, for instance, on Wednesday, CBS will be offering an hourlong ''documentary'' entitled ''China Odyssey: Empire of the Sun,'' which is less about China than about Steven Spielberg's new movie. Presumably an hour of prime time is more valuable than a plug on ''Entertainment Tonight.'' The program-length commercial has evolved into a valuable tool for selling everything from movies to children's toys.

title: Postal Service Cutting Back To Meet Goal of Deficit Law
description: Many post offices will be closed for at least the next two Saturdays and half of the new construction projects will be canceled as part of a package of budget-slashing measures, the Postal Service announced today.

title: Bridge: 'Mrs. Namyats' Used Tactic Named After Her Husband
description: Disguising a word by spelling it backwards is an old conception. In ''Erewhon,'' more than a century ago, Samuel Butler did not quite succeed in palindroming ''nowhere.''

title: U.S. Thinks Libya May Plan to Make Chemical Weapons
description: Libya is building a plant that Reagan Administration officials strongly suspect will be used to make chemical weapons.

title: New Life for Old Linens
description: ''PEOPLE live in cramped quarters in New York, and linen is a little bit of luxury that is nice and affordable,'' said Jana Starr of Jana Starr-Jean Hoffman Antiques, a store that carries antique linens. She said her customers usually buy ''a few showcase pieces,'' like a top sheet with an elaborate border and a few pillow shams, ''so the bed has one gorgeous outfit.''

title: HERS
description: WHEN we say we can't make love without love, I think, it's intimacy that we mean we can't make love, can't make out, can't live very well without. Intimacy, I think, is what those who live alone in their beds, and those who live with someone without the habitual touch of flesh or mind want to weep for the lack of.

title: 3d Year Was Key for Righetti
description: The implications of Dave Righetti's three-year, $4.3 million deal with the Yankees are potentially so far reaching that General Manager Lou Piniella didn't think he could make the official announcement yesterday without making sure he added a quick disclaimer.

title: Canadian Group's Multifoods Filing
description: Bregman Partners, an investment group consisting of the Bregman and Belzberg families of Canada, disclosed that it held discussions this month with the International Multifoods Corporation's financial advisers about the ''possibility of entering into negotiations'' about buying certain assets of the Minneapolis-based food-processing concern.

title: B.P.'s Bid For Britoil Advances
description: Britain's independent Takeover Panel ruled today that the British Petroleum Company's multibillion-dollar bid for Britoil P.L.C. could go ahead, despite the Government's intention to use its ''golden share'' to prevent any bidder from gaining control of Britain's largest independent oil company.

title: Righetti, and Other Gifts
description: THAT was a nice gesture on the part of Dave Righetti, giving himself to George Steinbrenner for the holidays. In an era when athletes are depicted as mercenaries, the Yankees reliever put friendship and loyalty ahead of money, and decided to remain in New York. In a big business like baseball, some may say that Righetti was foolish to let sentiment override the profit motive. But at this time of year, it is the thought that counts.

title: Former Trade Official Named Mazda President
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation has named Norimasa Furuta, a former Director General of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, as the company's new president.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a rollcall listing yesterday on the Senate's vote on a $600 billion spending bill misidentified Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee. He is a Democrat.

title: FLYERS UNBEATEN OVER 13 STRAIGHT
description: Dave Poulin scored two goals tonight as the Flyers extended their unbeaten streak to 13 games by defeating the Minnesota North Stars, 5-3. Philadelphia also moved past the Islanders into first place in the Patrick Division.

title: Chief Sees Transition For Software Maker
description: In reassuming the positions of president and chief executive, Fred M. Gibbons, the co-founder of the Software Publishing Corporation, said he hoped to lead the company through two transitions.

title: Pullback at Block Trading Desks
description: By putting up millions of dollars of their own capital, Wall Street's largest brokerage firms have long made the difference between an orderly market for giant institutional stock trades and one that bounces around wildly.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about the adjournment of Congress misstated the amount of aid voted for rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government. It is $8.1 million, not $8.1 billion.

title: F.D.I.C. Loss Estimate Lifted
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company yesterday raised its estimates of the amount that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will lose as a result of bad loans transferred to it under the rescue plan that was adopted in 1984.

title: O.K., an Educator. Where's the Clout?
description: Should New York City's next schools chancellor be more an educator or an administrator? A search committee finally presents New York's Board of Education with an answer: three candidates, all accomplished educators now serving in other cities. It's a defensible choice but more needs to be said. In New York, effectiveness depends heavily on the ability to understand a gritty political system and make it respond.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Journalism and Scholarship; I. F. Stone at 80: The Scooping Goes On
description: His eyesight and hearing are failing. He can no longer study or write for 12 hours at a stretch without a break. But I. F. Stone, who turns 80 years old on Thursday, is gloriously happy, surrounded by the books he loves.

title: Paul E. Levine, Lawyer, 38
description: Paul E. Levine, a partner in a Manhattan law firm, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 38 years old.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some years ago during a water shortage I reduced water used by my flush toilets by twisting the bowl refill tube to one side so that instead of directing water through the overflow tube and into the bowl it sent the water into the tank. I have operated two toilets this way for years with no noticeable decrease in flushing efficiency. What does the refill tube do, and is it really necessary? A. The refill tube does what its name says: it refills the bowl with enough water to provide a seal to keep sewer gases from coming into the home, and to hold enough water so the toilet will flush clean and not stain the next time it is used.

title: Soviet Astronauts in Capsule Dock With Mir Space Station
description: Three Soviet astronauts today docked their Soyuz capsule with the Mir space station, whose crew holds the world record for endurance in space.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Off 8.2% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that over-the-counter ''short interest'' - the number of shares sold short, and not yet covered - fell 17 million shares, or 8.2 percent, to 190.6 million shares in the month ended Dec. 15. That was down from a revised 207.6 million shares in the period ending Nov. 13.

title: NEW YORK COUNCIL ENACTS TOUGH LAW AGAINST SMOKING
description: After years of effort, the New York City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved the city's first comprehensive anti-smoking bill. It would restrict smoking in places of business and most enclosed public places, including stores, restaurants, schools, indoor sports arenas and taxicabs.

title: Recital: The Luzerne Trio
description: THE Luzerne Trio, which made its New York debut on Tuesday evening in Merkin Concert Hall, consists of Bert Phillips, a cellist in the Philadelphia Orchestra, Toby Blumenthal, a pianist, and Anna Pelekh, a Soviet-born violinist who studied with David Oistrakh. The ensemble's recital consisted of three works for different instrumental combinations: Barber's Sonata for Cello and Piano, Franck's A major Sonata for Violin and Piano and, after intermission, the Trio in D minor by Arensky.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday, about the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, misstated the arrangement under which banks make payments in the New York Cash Exchange system, a network of automatic tellers. When the cash machine used does not belong to the customer's own bank, the customer's bank pays the owning bank a fee of 20 cents for a balance inquiry or 38 cents for a cash withdrawal; another fee of 13 to 19 cents is paid to the exchange.

title: Francis Rejoins Patriots
description: Russ Francis, a former first-round draft choice of New England, has agreed to rejoin the Patriots for the remainder of the season and may sign a contract for next year, team officials said. Francis, who was waived by the San Francisco 49ers last week, made the decision to rejoin the Patriots Tuesday after being told by Coach Bill Walsh of San Francisco that the 49ers had no intention of re-signing him. Francis had originally rejected an offer to sign with the Patriots, saying he hoped to stay with San Francisco or be contacted by a playoff-bound team.

title: Think of New York Deal to Keep NBC as Corporate Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Carter-Wallace to Offer College Health Message
description: Carter-Wallace, whose product line includes Trojan condoms, will be sponsoring two- to three-minute public service video messages reaching college campuses, intended to inform students on the diseases that threaten them, from AIDS to anorexia, according to the announcement.

title: A Holiday Hurrah in the Summer Home
description: THERE will always be those for whom the Christmas and New Year season is synonymous with city lights. For them, there is joy in hustle, bustle and bundles. For them, a tinseled tree in an apartment-house lobby, alongside a taped-up poster of Kermit the frog in a Santa outfit, is holiday enough.

title: Productivity Is Crucial For Closing Trade Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Wiggins Banned Again
description: Mitchell Wiggins, who was banned from the N.B.A. for cocaine use, has been dismissed from the Continental Basketball Association for failing a drug test. Wiggins, who played for the Houston Rockets until he and Lewis Lloyd were banned on Jan. 13, 1987, was playing for the Quad City Thunder. ''This is an extremely unfortunate situation,'' Mike Storen, the C.B.A. commissioner, said in a statement. ''We expect Mitchell to admit himself in a rehabilitation program. Although his C.B.A. careeer is over, we would look forward to him gaining a complete recovery.'' Wiggins was admitted to the C.B.A. last February under a joint C.B.A.-N.B.A. rehabilitation program. He played for the Mississippi Jets last season. Under contracts for all C.B.A. players, failure to pass a drug test results in permanent dismissal. Wiggins's contract, adapted especially for the joint program, calls for random drug testing and an after-care program.

title: CURRENTS
description: From Food to Fashion: Mr. Chow's New Project

title: Soviet Scientist Requesting Australian Asylum in India
description: A Soviet scientist missing from a tour group in New Delhi since Friday is in the Australian High Commission, or embassy, here and is seeking political asylum, an Australian spokesman said today.

title: Counting the Pages
description: Now that President Reagan has signed the two huge bills that Congress passed in the final hours of the 1987 session, Government officials are holding their breath, hoping there will not be a repetition of last year's debacle.

title: Pakistan's Position
description: To the Editor:

title: Brownsville Journal; In Texas, It's the Season For the Humble Tamale
description: Bing Crosby never warbled a holiday season tune in their honor. You wouldn't want one in your Christmas stocking. It's a little hard to picture Santa eating one.

title: Olympians Investigated
description: Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany, who was a silver medalist at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics in the decathalon, is under investigation for suspected purchases of cocaine, a prosecutor in Essen, West Germany, said yesterday. The prosecutor, Hermann Kerl, said an investigation was opened against Hingsen and Rolf Milser, an Olympic weight lifting champion. Kerl said Hingsen and Milser were suspected of buying cocaine on several occasions from two suspected drug smugglers arrested in Essen in July. ''They are being investigated as part of a larger probe in connection with the two arrests,'' Kerl said. ''There have been statements that have to be checked.'' Bild, a West German newspaper, reported that Hingsen and Milser were named as cocaine buyers by several people who were interrogated by the police after the arrest of the two suspected smugglers, an Italian and a West German. Bild said Hingsen and Milser were expected to be questioned by police within the next few days. They are suspected of belonging to a group that supposedly bought cocaine on several occasions in the last two years in an Essen discotheque, the newspaper said. Hingsen has refused to comment on the reports.

title: I.R.S. Ruling Seen On Carter Payout
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said that the Internal Revenue Service intends to rule that most of the $320 million in cash distributed to its shareholders in a restructuring this year will be taxed as a dividend. The percentage of the cash payout that will be considered taxable depends on the year-end earnings and retained profits of the Los Angeles-based retailer, a spokesman said. The company had predicted the I.R.S. position and estimated that 60 percent or more of the cash distribution would count as income for shareholders.

title: New Donors Seek to Help The Neediest
description: Until recently, Dr. Edward Scott Valentine of Manhattan had assumed that taxes took care of the poor people. ''The increasing numbers of homeless and destitute that I see every day on the streets indicate how thoughtless I have been,'' Dr. Valentine wrote.

title: Calendar of Events: Holiday Bird Count
description: Christmas Bird Count

title: Talking Deals; The Maneuvering At Eastern Air
description: A FEW days before Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, made his bid for Eastern Airlines, he called in Philip J. Bakes, then the president of Texas Air's Continental Airlines unit, to thrash out why the company should make an offer for the then financially ailing airline.

title: Bol Speaks on Report
description: Manute Bol, the Washington Bullet center, said that Kevin Mackey, the Cleveland State basketball coach, never did him any favors. The National Collegiate Athletic Association last week charged the Cleveland State basketball program with recruiting violations, primarily concerning Bol, and placed the program on three years' probation. Both the university and Bol contend that Mackey had met Bol, but that the 7-foot-6-inch native of Sudan had not qualified to become a Cleveland State student. Bol told reporters in Richfield, Ohio before the Cleveland Cavaliers-Washington Bullets game Tuesday night that his decision to remain in Cleveland in 1983 and take an English course at Case Western Reserve University had nothing to do with Mackey. Bol said he spent the year living, at his own expense, with a former teammate on the Sudanese national team who was a basketball team manager at Cleveland State. ''I read in the newspapers that the N.C.A.A. says Coach Mackey gave me money and a car,'' Bol said. ''If that's true, where's the car? Where's my money? Why would I leave Cleveland State if they gave me money and a car?''

title: Blake Stern, Singer and Teacher, 70
description: Blake Stern, an oratorio singer and a professor emeritus of music at Yale University, died Tuesday in Logan, Iowa. He was 70 years old.

title: Reagan Signs Measure Easing Entry to U.S.
description: President Reagan has signed legislation that will prevent immigration officials from barring foreigners because of their political beliefs for at least the next 14 months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will fight with all our power against any element that tries by violence to upset our full control over Judea, Samaria and the Gaza Strip.'' - Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel. [ A1:3. ]

title: Tribune's New Defense
description: Directors of the Tribune Company, trying to make the diversified publishing and broadcasting conglomerate a less attractive takeover target, have approved a more bitter ''poison pill'' contingency plan.

title: Advertising; Unusual Commercial For Barney's New York
description: A TV commercial will start running in the New York market tomorrow that will confuse many a viewer at first. It looks more like the last few minutes of ''Sunday Morning'' on CBS than a commercial. It's almost all mood, with the camera starting out with a winter country scene that goes to black and is followed by a different winter scene, and so on. All this is accompanied by new-age music.

title: Advertising; Lakeside Picks Gross For Nicorette Gum
description: Lakeside Pharmaceuticals is switching advertising responsibility for its Nicorette gum to Gross Townsend Frank Hoffman, from Medicus Consumer. The chewing gum, sold by prescription only, contains nicotine that is said to help people break the smoking habit.

title: Carson Is Selected For Ninth Pro Bowl
description: Harry Carson made National Football League history today when he was voted a Pro Bowl linebacker for the ninth time. Lawrence Taylor made history of sorts when he failed to be named a Pro Bowl starter, although he did make the team.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL/A2-9

title: Of Coats and Caps: Children's Classics
description: WHAT does the well-dressed Munchkin wear at this magical time of year? To find out we stalked Fifth Avenue, that thoroughfare of good taste, for several days.

title: Costs of Doing Business
description: To The Home Section:

title: Robert Paige Is Dead; Appeared in 65 Films
description: Robert Paige, an Emmy Award-winning actor who starred in such movies as ''Bye Bye Birdie'' with Janet Leigh and ''Can't Help Singing'' with Deanna Durbin, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack. The Orange County Coroner's office listed his age as 76, but biographies put his age at 77.

title: Tale of a Soured Friendship Unfolds in Queens Killings
description: On St. Patrick's Day 1982, two men moving a dining room set into a sixth-floor apartment in Elmurst, Queens, decided to take a break. They sat down on a landing to drink a few beers.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Dec. 16 reported that Boston Properties, developer of the skyscraper proposed for the site of the New York Coliseum, had replaced Moshe Safdie, the building's architect, with David Childs of the firm of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, and asked him to design a smaller building.

title: Ex-Panama Colonel Gets 5 Years
description: A former army colonel whose allegations of high-level corruption touched off a summer of unrest has been sentenced to five years in prison for crimes against state security, a court official said today.

title: Green of U.C.L.A. To Miss Bowl
description: Gaston Green, the U.C.L.A. tailback, will be unable to play in the Aloha Bowl against Florida Friday because of a pulled thigh muscle.

title: Advertising; Dailies' Ads Rise
description: According to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, advertising spending in the nation's dailies in October rose 5.5 percent over the same month in 1986, to $2.66 billion. The biggest category gainer was classified, which was up 14.7 percent, to $969 million, while retail rose 1.7 percent, to $1.37 billion. National dropped 2.6 percent, to $319 million.

title: Aiding Afghanistan's Transition From War
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Suspends 4 In Dispute Over Icing Of Jet, Union Says
description: Four Eastern Airlines flight attendants who refused to work on an aircraft leaving Denver unless the plane was de-iced have been suspended without pay for 30 days, union representatives said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE THIRTEENTH MAN. A Reagan Cabinet Memoir. By Terrel H. Bell. 195 pages. Free Press/Macmillan. $19.95.

title: Metro Matters; For Cuomo's Son, A Bold Venture To Aid the Poor
description: The first 25 homeless families moved this week into an imaginative prefabricated housing project in Brooklyn called Help I. If it succeeds and can be replicated elsewhere in the region, then helped, too, will be Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's 30-year-old son, who conceived the project nearly two years ago and had the gumption to get it built.

title: FORMER SCHOOL STAR REBOUNDS ON LIFE
description: Kenny Hutchinson sat in the living room of his apartment here one day recently recalling his last trip home to New York. He remembered walking through his old neighborhood in the Bronx and meeting friends who looked at him as if they had seen a ghost. ''They were like, 'Hey, Kenny! You all right, man? I heard you'd cracked up,' '' he said.

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Fell 11.7% in Mid-December
description: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks fell 11.7 percent in the second 10 days of December from the comparable period a year ago, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

title: Lincoln Center Drops Play
description: Lincoln Center Theater has halted rehearsals of ''Ron Giovanni,'' a satirical musical that was to begin performances Jan. 22 at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. The show will be replaced by a comedy, ''Boy's Life,'' the artistic director of the company, Gregory Mosher, said yesterday.

title: Harlem Boys Choir's Struggle
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem has sung to critical acclaim all over the United States, in Japan and in major cathedrals and churches of Europe, including St. Paul's in London and St. Germain des Pres in Paris. Yet, says the director, the group has an image problem.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: School Basketball St. Anthony's Holds On in Honolulu: Bob Hurley Jr. scored 29 points, including four free throws in the final 11 seconds as St. Anthony's of Jersey City held on to defeat St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 62-58, in the championship game of the McDonald's-Iolani Prep Classic Tuesday night in Honolulu. Tolentine, which trailed by 31-28 at the half, overcame an 8-point fourth-quarter deficit when Jerome Holmes connected on a 12-foot jump shot with just under two and a half minutes to play in the game to make the score 55-54. St. Anthony's however, broke a 56-56 tie with 45 seconds to go on a basket by Jerry Walker, a forward. Hurley, who connected on seven of his first eight shots, including three 3-point shots, was named the most valuable player in the tournament. For Tolentine, Malik Sealy scored 20 points and grabbed 9 rebounds and Adrian Autry added 12 points. In the consolation game, Flint Hill Academy of Reston, Va., defeated Dunbar of Baltimore, 63-60.

title: General Haig's Joke
description: That uproar between Alexander M. Haig Jr. and the United States Marines over a joke that the Republican Presidential contender made at the expense of The Few and The Proud is not over yet, despite his insistence that the joke be treated as a joke.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Briefing
description: Counting the Pages Now that President Reagan has signed the two huge bills that Congress passed in the final hours of the 1987 session, Government officials are holding their breath, hoping there will not be a repetition of last year's debacle.

title: State Dept. Urges Israel to Ease Riot Control
description: The State Department urged Israeli leaders again today to adopt nonlethal techniques to control rioting in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Critic's Notebook; Reflections on a Punk-Rocker's Death
description: THE news came in a plain white envelope marked ''personal and confidential.''

title: KEY RATES
Navy Awards Contract for Bomber
description: The Navy announced today that a team of the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation had been selected to build an advanced attack aircraft in a program that could be worth $45 billion.

title: The Elsie de Wolfe Design Revolution
description: SINCE her death in France in 1950 at the age of 85, Elsie de Wolfe has been variously remembered as the first interior decorator, the first ''lady'' to appear on a Broadway stage, the first hostess to invite artists and writers to society parties and the first woman to sue the United States Government over taxes. As a nurse in France in World War I, she earned the Legion of Honor and the Croix de Guerre. As a New York socialite she marched for women's rights.

title: Restaurant to Remain Under U.S. Supervision
description: A former Federal prosecutor will continue to supervise the operation of Umberto's Clam House under a court order issued yesterday in Manhattan.

title: Knicks Slow Jordan, Bulls
description: Patrick Ewing's driving basket past Dave Corzine with 15 seconds remaining last night provided the Knicks with a 90-89 victory over the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden. Ewing was fouled on the play by Corzine, but he missed the free throw.

title: Music: Moyse Leads Bach
description: AS they say, better late than never. At the august age of 78, Blanche Moyse finally made her Carnegie Hall debut Monday evening, leading the Orchestra of St. Luke's and the Blanche Moyse Chorale in an absolutely glorious rendition of Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.'' Even after three hours on stage the conductor seemed vigorous enough to start over again. Many audience members would probably not have minded a bit.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PORTABLE power tools have become as much a part of homeowners' tool kits as hammers. Most modern power tools are surprisingly light and easy to handle, thanks to new technologies and to tool manufacturers' strong interest in satisfying the needs of amateurs. If you don't own any power tools, or are confused by the variations available, here are some basic choices to consider. Drills

title: 15-Year-Old Hijacks KLM Plane; Incident Ends With Boy's Capture
description: An unarmed teen-ager who said he had a bomb hijacked a KLM airliner with 97 people aboard today, forced it to land in Rome and demanded $1 million, airline officials said. The police overpowered him four hours later, and all hostages were released unharmed.

title: Dow Rises to 2,005.64; Program Trades Cited
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose above the 2,000 level yesterday for the first time since Nov. 2, and many traders said computerized buying by large institutions had helped push it along.

title: Tripucka Picks Up Tempo For Jazz
description: Kelly Tripucka came off the bench, scoring 13 of his 15 points in the final 5 minutes 33 seconds, to lead the Utah Jazz to a 91-83 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: That Street Trees May Survive the Season
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Rebuts U.S. Charges That It Used Excessive Force
description: Israeli officials today rejected the Reagan Administration's assertion that Israeli troops had used excessive force in quelling Palestinian riots.

title: Where Lighting Up Will Be O.K., and Where It Won't Be
description: Places of Employment

title: Computer Security Shift Is Approved by Senate
description: As one of its final acts before adjourning, the Senate has passed and sent to President Reagan a bill to restore civilian control over the standards for safeguarding information stored in the nation's computers.

title: Von Bulow Says He Will Drop Claim to Money
description: Claus von Bulow, the Danish-born aristocrat who was convicted and then, in a retrial, acquitted of twice trying to murder his wife with insulin injections, confirmed yesterday that he has agreed to renounce all claims to his wife's fortune, to divorce her and to leave the country.

title: Juror's Attempt to Sell Story Raises Ethics Issue
description: An effort to sell a juror's account of the Howard Beach trial to three newspapers has focused attention on an ethical and legal quandary that many journalists and lawyers describe as extremely troubling.

title: Advertising; Revlon Splits With Grey
description: The 27-year relationship between Revlon Inc. and Grey Advertising is over. They have split without explanation. The brands that were at

title: Gary Pallack, Clothing Manufacturer, 41
description: Gary Pallack, a clothing manufacturer, died of a heart attack Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Prosperous Turn For Bookbinders
description: LEAD: THEY are not book collectors, and they don't consider themselves extravagant, but recently Gilbert and Mary Schwartz found themselves in a bindery on Lexington Avenue, choosing the leather (teal-blue Moroccan goatskin), the tooling designs (floral sprigs and a dove) and the endpapers (hand marbled) for an album that would hold their wedding pictures and wind up costing them more than $750.

title: Beard Plans Talks With Union Pacific
description: The Beard Company announced it intends to resume merger talks with the Union Pacific Corporation as soon as Union Pacific's tender offer for Uspci Inc. is consummated. Beard's president, Herb Mee Jr., said, however, that ''there can be no assurance that any transaction will be authorized or consummated.''

title: Pan Am Seeks Concessions
description: The board of the Pan Am Corporation has asked two of its five unions, those representing the pilots and the flight engineers, to give them about the same level of concessions that they had been willing to give to Jay A. Pritzker, the financier who controls Braniff Airways Inc., in his unsuccessful bid to purchase the airline.

title: I.B.M. Signals Big Shift In Designing Computers
description: A radical new computer design that only a few years ago was routinely dismissed as unworkable suddenly appears ready for broad acceptance after an about-face by I.B.M. that gratified the Federal Government and stunned the computer industry.

title: New TV Ratings Device Registers Fewer Viewers of Network Shows
description: After three months as the new standard in measuring who watches what on television, the ''people-meter'' ratings device seems to be a network nightmare coming true.

title: Takeover Rumors Send Phillips Stock Up 17%
description: Shares of the Phillips Petroleum Company, which eluded separate takeover attempts three years ago by T. Boone Pickens and by Carl C. Icahn rose sharply today on rumors that a new hostile bid may be pending.

title: New Robins Bid by American Home
description: The American Home Products Corporation yesterday joined a fast-developing bidding war for the troubled A. H. Robins Company, offering stock valued at $550 million and a commitment to provide $2.48 billion in cash over seven years to compensate women who say they suffered injuries from Robins's Dalkon Shield birth control device.

title: TV Reviews; 'CBS This Morning,' With Sullivan and Smith
description: WATCH it once or twice, or maybe only in pieces. It's Kathleen Sullivan and old Harry whosis. Stay with it a while, though, and Harry takes on substance. In fact, he wears quite well. There are worse ways to start the day than by watching ''CBS This Morning,'' with Ms. Sullivan and Harry Smith as co-anchors.

title: Skiing Areas Will Observe 50th Anniversaries
description: SKIING as a means of transportation began with the Vikings, who got around on snow on slippery boards. As recreation in the winter, skiing's origins go back to the 19th century and, as a competitive sport, ski racing started to evolve in the 1920's.

title: Recruits to Be Tested for Drug Use Before Entering the Armed Forces
description: Beginning next June, the armed forces will be required under a new law to test all recruits for drug abuse before they enter the service.

title: Prague Journal; To a Border Patrol (and Diligent Dogs), a Tribute
description: At Checkpoint Charlie, the border crossing in West Berlin, a small museum honors the courage and ingenuity of the many refugees from Communism who have tunneled, flown, swum or sneaked to freedom from behind what the West used to call the Iron Curtain.

title: Iranian Attack Damages Tanker
description: An Iranian vessel attacked a loaded Norwegian tanker in the southern Persian Gulf shortly before midnight tonight, starting a fire aboard, maritime executives reported.

title: Filipino Rebels Plan to Halt Raids on Christmas Holidays
description: Communist rebels said today that they would refrain from military attacks on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day.

title: AIDS Suit Filed In Effort to End Ban on Pupil, 5
description: The parents of a 5-year-old girl who is an AIDS victim have gone to court in an effort to force the Fairfax County school system, one of the nation's largest and best rated, to reverse a decision that forbids the child to attend classes.

title: China Expels Member of 'Reactionary' Group
description: A Taiwan citizen who is an American resident has been ordered to leave China for belonging to a ''reactionary organization,'' Chinese newspapers reported today. The man, Qian Ga, was said to belong to the Chinese Alliance for Democracy, a New York-based Chinese dissident group with underground cells in China.

title: Power Play Clicks for Devils
description: The special teams, which had been the main reason for the recent slide by the Devils, proved very effective tonight against the Penguins.

title: Secrecy and Folly
description: Secrecy in government has a thousand fathers: a thousand excuses. But Frank Carlucci, the new Secretary of Defense, came up with a particular gem last week. He testified that the President should not have to inform the Congressional intelligence committees promptly about covert operations because foreign countries whose help we need do not like the idea.

title: 2,636 Entrants For Westminster
description: Entries for the 112th annual Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden Feb. 8-9 have closed with 2,636 dogs, representing 140 breeds or varieties. ''It's the earliest close in the long history of Westminster,'' said Chet Collier, the show chairman.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE holiday guests inwardly cringe as the 6-year-old scratches his way through a tune on his new violin. They keep a watchful eye on the living-room furniture as his younger sister demonstrates her skill at indoor cartwheels. They smile at the pure tones of the 10-year-old singing a Christmas carol and are impressed as the 13-year-old demonstrates the computer program she just wrote.

title: New Ceramics Evoke Ancient Ritual Vessels
description: ROBERT TURNER and Karen Karnes worked together at Black Mountain College in North Carolina, where he established the ceramics department in 1951 and she became the department's co-director in 1952. The two artists are now reunited in an exhibition at the Garth Clark Gallery in Manhattan.

title: Farm Credit Issues Total $2.38 Billion
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering three- and six-month bonds totaling $2.38 billion through various securities dealers.

title: Islanders Fall From First
description: Rick Vaive continued his sizzling scoring pace with two goals tonight, leading the Chicago Blackhawks to a 7-5 victory over the New York Islanders. The defeat and the Flyers' victory over the North Stars knocked the Islanders out of first place in the Patrick Division.

title: U.S. Providing Information On Performance by Airlines
description: The Department of Transportation has put into use a computerized system that will permit airline passengers to select a flight on the basis of on-time performance.

title: Correction
description: An article in some editions yesterday about indictments involving the Wedtech Corporation misstated the activity of W. Franklyn Chinn, one of those indicted. Mr. Chinn managed investments for Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, but there is no evidence the investments included Wedtech.

title: Gunmen in Sri Lanka Kill Leader Of Governing Party and 3 Aides
description: The chairman of the governing United National Party and three of his aides were killed by gunmen today, the authorities said. Ethnic Sinhalese extremists were blamed for the attack.

title: I.M.F. PLANS $8 BILLION IN AFRICA HELP
description: A broad group of nations is ready to contribute about $8 billion to a new fund to aid the poorest and most indebted developing countries, mainly in sub-Saharan Africa, according to involved officials.

title: Trotsky a Tough Nut for Actor
description: In an age of greater openness in Soviet society, how does an actor bring a former unperson to life?

title: U.S. Plans 2 Buildings At Foley Sq.
description: The Federal Government plans to build two office buildings in the Foley Square area of Manhattan to ease congestion in the United States Court House and other Government buildings nearby.

title: Dance: At City Ballet, 2 Sugar Plum Fairies
description: THE role of the Sugar Plum Fairy in ''The Nutcracker'' is a peculiar one. The part, a focal point of the ballet, is usually danced by a ballerina of artistic stature, but she appears for a very short time on the stage and then only at the end in the ballet's culminating pas de deux. Almost everything in the fairy-tale ballet - Christmas parties, warring mice and toy soldiers and dancing sweets and snowflakes - upstages those final moments of pure classicism. And yet it is a testing part, for the performer must not only dance well but also epitomize radiance, grandeur and sweetness. Margaret Tracey and Lauren Hauser acquitted themselves well in performances of George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' presented by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater on Sunday afternoon and Tuesday night.

description: In this village of well-tended homes, architectural changes are as closely scrutinized as the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: Grumman Upbeat Despite Lost Bid
description: The Grumman Corporation, which was the member of a team that lost a competition to build an advanced attack aircraft for the Navy, said that it was in no danger of going out of business. The Defense News, an industry publication, had reported that several New York legislators had urged Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci to steer the contract to Grumman, contending that the company could close if it was not included in the program. The Navy awarded the contract, worth $45 million, to the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: George Kelly, Authority on Hegel
description: George Armstrong Kelly, a professor and authority on the works of Hegel, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pueblo Chain Gets Buyout Offer
description: Pueblo International Inc., an operator of supermarkets in Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands and Florida, has received a leveraged buyout offer of $24.50 a share in cash for its outstanding shares. The offer by First Boston Inc. and Harold Toppel, Pueblo's chairman, includes the assumption of Pueblo debt and values the company at $185 million.

title: Henry Cotton, Former Golfer, 80
description: Henry Cotton, the most distinguished British golfer of his generation, died Tuesday. He was 80 years old. Cotton, who turned professional in 1924, won the British Open in 1934, ending a long run of American victories and again in 1937 and 1948. He played many times in the United States and was captain of the Ryder Cup team in 1939, 1947 and 1953. He wrote 10 books about the sport.

title: Sports People; Coffey's Injury Status
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins said yesterday that the injury suffered Wednesday night by Paul Coffey, a defenseman, was a minor cartilage tear in his right knee that does not warrant surgery. A team spokesman said he did not know if Coffey would play tomorrow when the Penguins meet the Detroit Red Wings in Pittsburgh. Coffey originally bruised the knee Dec. 11 against the Islanders and missed three games. The latest injury occurred when Coffey collided with a referee during the first period of a 6-2 loss to the Devils.

title: When 'Japan's Art Opened to Western Winds
description: ''PARIS IN JAPAN: The Japanese Encounter With European Painting'' may be the sleeper of the season. It arrived at the Japan Society Gallery without fanfare and without great paintings. What it brings is a fresh perspective on both Paris and Japan in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. And in a catalogue indispensable to the exhibition, there is an eye-opening essay by J. Thomas Rimer that places the art - and the present moment - in context.
