description: This Christmas seems notable for the carol that hasn't been sung - that hymn to materialism, ''The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' Like the dog that didn't bark, could the carol not sung reveal something profound?

title: Two Who Make a Difference in New York City's Schools; 'A Good Teacher' Extends 'Herself Beyond the Requirements'
description: The quality of the New York City school system has been attacked by business leaders, politicians and educators recently. As they express their concerns, the Board of Education is preparing to pick a new chancellor. Among the challenges he will face are a high dropout rate, overcrowding and deteriorating buildings.

title: 49er Formula: Talent and Walsh's Way

title: Pakistan Jail Riot Put Down
description: The police quelled a mutiny by about 2,000 prisoners today at Karachi's central jail, the authorities said. The police said more than 1,000 police officers and paramilitary forces used gunfire and tear gas to put down the 10-hour mutiny. They said about 90 prisoners and staff members were hurt. The Karachi police chief, Iftikhar Rasheed, said the insurrection came after three political groups asserted that the death of a prisoner Monday resulted from torture.

title: Pop/Jazz; Yomo Toro Blends Latin And Cuban
description: WHEN Latin music aficionados are discussing players like Yomo Toro, the Puerto Rican virtuoso of the 10-stringed mini-guitar called the cuatro, they often resort to a term that sounds out-of-place amid the streams of voluble, rapid-fire Spanish: hillbilly. The ''jibaro'' music that is Mr. Toro's specialty actually is folk music from the Puerto Rican hill country - buoyant, driving string-band music that can be compared to American hillbilly and bluegrass styles without stretching the point. Mr. Toro even wears the straw hat and baggy trousers of a country bumpkin, and entertains his audiences by impersonating a rustic buffoon. One can easily imagine him starring on television in some improbable Puerto Rican ''Hee Haw!''

title: Film: 'Pinocchio And Emperor of Night'
description: DISNEY animation reached its pinnacle with ''Pinocchio,'' and that film's finest moment is the scene in Geppetto's workshop when every single toy springs gloriously to life. In the new film ''Pinocchio and the Emperor of the Night,'' by comparison, the toys in the workshop don't bother to move, and only one token tweety-bird flutters in the foreground. This is Saturday morning animation at best, and if presented as such it wouldn't seem worse than ordinary. But as a spinoff of the real ''Pinocchio,'' to which it has virtually no connection (though the author Carlo Collodi gets an ''inspired by'' credit), it amounts to a form of bait and switch.

title: Sports People; Bulls Waive Gilmore
description: Artis Gilmore was placed on waivers yesterday by the Chicago Bulls, a team official said. ''Artis is debating retirement and has asked us to waive him, thus keeping his options open for a possible return to the National Basketball Association at a later date if he should decide not to retire,'' said Jerry Krause, the team's vice president for operations. If he retires without waivers, Gilmore would be ineligible to return to the league for one year. ''Artis has had a great career, a 17-year run as one of the game's finest and classiest players,'' Krause said. ''His wishes are paramount to us. This is the way he has chosen to leave the Bulls.'' Gilmore, a 38-year-old center, played 24 games this season, averaging 4 points, 2 rebounds and 16 minutes a game. He lost his starting job to Dave Corzine this week. Gilmore broke into pro ball with Kentucky of the American Basketball Association in 1971 and spent five years with the Colonels, six years with the Bulls and five years in San Antonio, before returning to Chicago.

title: Sports People; Miami Suspends Two
description: Two starters on the University of Miami football team, the linebacker George Mira Jr. and the offensive tackle John O'Neill, were suspended yesterday by Coach Jimmy Johnson and won't play against Oklahoma in the Orange Bowl Jan. 1. ''Both George and John violated team policy,'' Johnson said in a statement released last night. ''The nature of the violations is confidential, and consistent with our past procedures, we will not reveal them.'' The university said Mira and O'Neill would not comment. Mira, a fifth-year senior, is the school's career leader in tackles and leads the team with 147 this season. O'Neill, a junior, has started the last two seasons. Bernard Clark, a sophomore, will replace Mira and Darren Bruce, a junior, will replace O'Neill, the university said.

title: Sports People; Dorsett's Swan Song?
description: Tony Dorsett believes the game Sunday against St. Louis will be his last in a Dallas Cowboys uniform. ''The only way I can see being here,'' said Dorsett, ''is if no other team in the league was interested in me.'' In an interview Wednesday with The Forth Worth Star Telegram, Dorsett said once again that he was upset with the way the transition to Herschel Walker was handled. The Cowboys have wrestled for the better part of two seasons for a way to make a Walker-Dorsett backfield work. Both Dorsett and Walker complained this season that the system wasn't working. Both players suggested that the Dallas coach, Tom Landry, should choose one of them to be the main back even if it put the other on the sidelines. After a 27-17 loss to Detroit on Nov. 8, Landry chose Walker and said he would start at halfback against New England the next week. ''Hopefully, the Cowboys will be kind enough to give me a new address and let me play football,'' Dorsett said.

title: Sports People; Slaney Sidelined
description: Mary Decker Slaney, the nation's top female middle-distance runner but also the most injury-prone, will miss the 1988 indoor track season because of an injured right calf, her coach said yesterday. The coach, Luiz de Oliveira, said Slaney, who has not competed since last Feb. 28, when she set a course record of 32 minutes 3 seconds, in winning the Continental Homes 10-kilometer (6.2 miles) race at Phoenix, would ''take off the next 15 days and see how she reacts to the injury.'' He said, however, that the injury did not appear serious. But with the Olympics coming up next September, de Oliveira said it was not worth the risk of greater injury to compete indoors. Slaney, the American outdoor record holder at all distances between 800 meters and 10,000 meters, had planned to compete in three indoor meets - the Pacific Northwest Bell Indoor Games at Portland, Ore., Jan. 23; the Panasonic Millrose Games at New York Feb. 5, and the Vitalis-United States Olympic Invitational at East Rutherford, N.J., Feb. 13. ''Winning an Olympic gold medal is now the major goal in my career,'' Slaney was quoted as saying by Advantage International, her management firm. ''I don't want to risk any more injuries by racing indoors.'' The troublesome calf is the same one that Slaney injured during the 1985 United States Olympic Invitational - the last time she competed indoors. She missed the entire 1987 outdoor season because of surgery on her right Achilles' tendon.

title: Preserving Balance on Landmarks
description: New York's rich architectural heritage, like that of other older cities, justifies efforts to protect truly distinguished buildings from onrushing change. In New York, that is the job of an 11-member Landmarks Preservation Commission. But the commission has been eroding credibility and undermining its proper function by designating questionable buildings, embroiling itself in neighborhood battles against reasonable development and usurping the role of zoning agencies, For example, Marjory Pearson, the commission's own research director, was willing to put in writing her opinion that three small and decayed buildings were not distinguished enough for landmark designation. Yet, the commission designated the buildings, at Central Park West and 95th Street, landmarks anyway. These empty buildings were undistinguished on the day they were built and remain so. Declaring them landmarks sticks their owners with properties of small value and without any leeway to increase their worth.

title: Noisy Advantage
description: The crowd noise at the Metrodome during the World Series apparently helped the Minnesota Twins, according to a study published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association. In the report ''Decibeldome,'' Dr. Steven Vincent, a Minneapolis family physician, tells how he wore a noise-measuring dosimeter to Game 2, when Minnesota beat St. Louis, 8-4. He compared his top reading of 125 decibels from a seat in the center-field upper deck to the sound of a jackhammer pounding concrete from a distance of 5 feet. Based on industrial research done elsewhere, the report said that the crowd noise was so loud that ''the lopsided score may be related to a fine motor and communication deficit that could have been caused by noise.'' A St. Louis fielder's dexterity may have been thrown off just enough so he couldn't catch a ball cleanly or throw it to first base in time, explained Thomas Hawkinson, an industrial hygienist at Medtronics Inc. and a co-author of the report.

description: SABBATICALS ARE AN IN-grained part of academic life, but they are less common for conductors. Yet a yearlong sabbatical is just what Zubin Mehta took in 1987, a state of grace from which he returns this week to take up his fulltime duties as music director of the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Mehta's first regular concert with the orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall since late last year will take place on Tuesday, with Kathleen Battle as guest soloist, and for the rest of the season he will be much in evidence.

title: Tighter Tax Disclosure for Realty Deals
description: IF you are among the four million Americans who sold a house or apartment this year, the Internal Revenue Service is looking for you. And yes, it is a matter of taxes, the additional collection of hundreds of millions of dollars nationwide.

title: Nina Allison Gelberg To Wed Robert Sobel
description: An April wedding is planned by Nina Allison Gelberg and Robert Leland Sobel, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gelberg of Teaneck, N.J., have announced. Mr. Sobel is the son of Mrs. Bernard S. Berkowitz of West Orange, N.J., and the late Martin Sobel.

title: ON THE EDGE OF GREATNESS
description: WE HAVE AN image of downhill racers. Downhill racers are wild men. They make airborne assaults on moun-tains, schussing head down, soaring off a bump intentionally placed to spring them 40 yards into the air, just to test, kind of, their sang-froid - and if everything's O.K., no blown-out knees, they glide home at 80 miles an hour. To maximize speed, downhill racers learn to ski on the edge of losing control. Off the slopes, their personalities tend toward brinksmanship as well. These are athletes like loud-mouthed Billy Johnson, winner of the 1984 Olympic gold medal at Sarajevo, or the brooding loner Robert Redford, with a chip on his shoulder the size of all Colorado, in the 1969 film ''Downhill Racer.''

title: Methadone Would Slow The Spread of AIDS
description: Recently I saw two young people, husband and wife, in consultation. They were both intravenous drug users, addicted to an illegal synthetic opiate. I tried to detoxify them as outpatients without success. I then tried to arrange for them to get help through a methadone program elsewhere because no such program is locally available.

title: No Saints Wanted
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Textiles Reveal Subtle Beauty
description: FOR many years, the arts of Japan have exerted a strong influence on Western taste. Ever since the mid-19th century, the Oriental esthetic of simple, elegant design has found increasing favor in the United States, where Japanese prints, pottery and textiles have become ever more popular.

title: STATEHOOD CELEBRATIONS FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: EIGHT states will be honored in 1988 by the United States Postal Service. The 200th anniversaries of Georgia, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maryland, South Carolina, New Hampshire, Virginia and New York will be celebrated as part of the continuing recognition of the ratification of the United States Constitution by the 13 original colonies.

title: New Kind of Criminal Is Stealing the Trash
description: Rhode Island's new mandatory recycling program has created a new crime: theft of garbage.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Hartsdale, N.Y.$322,500 28 Townsend Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 32-year-old split level; eat-in kitchen, family room, 2-car garage, fenced yard; taxes $5,911. Larchmont, N.Y. $269,500 12 Shadow Lane 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 61-year-old English stucco; den, screened porch, beach privileges, walk to station; taxes $3,833. Bayport, L.I. $138,000 88 Bayview Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 22-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, basement; taxes $3,300.

title: RANGERS BEAT DEVILS AGAIN
description: Ten days ago, across the Hudson River, the visiting Devils took a severe 9-3 beating at the hands of the Rangers. After the game, the Rangers were angry and accused the Devils of intending to injure Ranger players when New Jersey's strongmen were killing a penalty in the waning moments.

title: Just Freed, Dotson Is Arrested
description: Gary Dotson was arrested at a tavern in nearby Calumet City today, just two days after the convicted rapist was given a ''last-chance'' parole by Gov. James R. Thompson. ''He ordered some food in the restaurant section of the lounge, and there was some sort of altercation after it came to the table,'' Police Officer Clyde Butcher of the Calumet City police said. ''He apparently refused to pay and lunged forward at the female cook, who sustained a cut on her left hand.''

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE PARENT BUSINESS
description: LEAD: PROVIDING parents with information about giving birth and raising their children has become a booming business in the last few years, producing an explosion of books, newsletters, broadcasts and cassette tapes. And there is a good reason for the boom, said Elisabeth Bing, the childbirth educator who helped to popularize the Lamaze method in this country as co-founder of the American Society for Psychoprophylaxis in

title: MUSIC
description: Celebrating Bird: The Triumph of Charlie Parker Sony Video Software Company. 58 minutes. $29.95. So many audio recordings of Charlie (Bird) Parker exist, legal and surreptitious, that it's astonishing that he survives on movie film in only two clips, one of them without a sound track. Despite such a handicap, this documentary of a meteoric jazz figure could hardly be bettered. The critic Gary Giddins has finessed around holes in the visual evidence by combining a voice-over narration, dozens of stills and recordings, clips of Bird's associates, and some illuminating interviews.

title: Equity Loans: Lures and Pitfalls
description: LEAD: CONSUMER groups and legislators are warning that although home equity loans may provide an attractive tax deduction for some, they could lead some homeowners to financial disaster.

title: CRIME
description: Joseph Hansen's Dave Brandstetter novels, starting with ''Fadeout'' in 1970, have been probing studies of the homosexual culture. Brandstetter is an independently wealthy claims investigator for an insurance company and a homosexual. A man of deep feeling, he can give the impression of being cold because he is 100 percent rational. And in the ninth of the series, EARLY GRAVES (Mysterious Press, $15.95), his sensitivity and objectivity are put to full test.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PARENT BUSINESS;
TURNING THE PARTY OVER TO THE PROS
description: LEAD: WHETHER it's held at home or on an aircraft carrier, a child's birthday party is no longer a matter for parents to handle alone. Cultural institutions, party planners and publishers of birthday-party guidebooks say they are doing a strong business, telling parents how birthday children and their friends can have the most fun.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a good-quality wallcovering of plastic that was carefully hung and neatly joined at the edges. We now find that the edges are curling up in some places and none of the adhesives I have tried seem to hold these edges down. Do you have a suggestion?

title: From Forest to Manila, Stranger in a Strange Land
description: Dula, the first member of the primitive Tasaday tribe known to have visited a big city, has spent much of her time here sitting on her bed waiting to go home again, her belongings packed and ready.

title: FUND USE DEBATED IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The indictment of a former state college president last week and the recent departure of four other top education officials amid charges of poor financial management have cast a shadow on the reputation of the $1.1 billion-a-year Massachusetts higher education system.

title: USING GENETIC ENGINEERING TO MAKE TOMATOES TASE LIKE TOMATOES AGAIN
description: THE tomato is a symbol of the triumphs and disappointments of American agriculture. Over the last 50 years, breeders have crossed one variety with another to produce hybrids with large yields, long shelf lives and the ruggedness to survive a long trek to market. At the same time, the store-bought tomato has become pale, hard, thick-skinned and increasingly tasteless.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When we're cutting programs for the the poor in this country, should we be feeding excess wild horses?'' - Robert Burford, director of the Bureau of Land Management. [ 1:1. ]

title: IN SWIFT PURSUIT OF THE SETTING SUN
description: OUR Boeing 767 took off from Kennedy International Airport at sunset, and the sky was a glorious sight. From my window seat I watched eagerly as we soared through a thin cloud cover over Jamaica Bay. The plane turned smoothly toward the Jersey coast, and I saw the long shoreline that encompasses Atlantic City and Cape May.

title: 13 CANDIDATES REACH 1988, WITH PLENTY TO FRET OVER
description: In 1987, amid all the talk of things like adultery and politicians' stealing speeches, it has been easy to lose sight of what the American people will be deciding in the election of 1988.

title: Charlotte Feng to Marry W. E. Ford 3d
description: The engagement of Charlotte Amalie Feng to William E. Ford 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ford Jr. of Summit, N.J., has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Louis T. Feng of Creve Coeur, Mo. A June 25 wedding is planned.

title: Steps for Making Sure Good Time Is Had by All
description: LEAD: FOR Andrew Rubenoff, much of his professional life is a party. Mr. Rubenoff, who lives in New Haven, is a graphic designer, a theater set designer, a professional pianist and an interior and exterior designer. He is also a professional party giver.

title: JORDAN HELD TO 17 AS BULLS LOSE
description: Vern Fleming scored 10 of his 22 points in the third period as the Indiana Pacers opened a 20-point lead and then handed the Chicago Bulls their sixth consecutive road loss, 106-92, today.

title: Engaged Drama Treated Real Concerns
description: TO HEAR PEOPLE IN THE INSU-lar theater business talk about it, the hot stories of 1987 were the ascendancy of the English musical, the landmarking of irreplaceable Broadway theaters, the immigration travails of Mrs. Andrew Lloyd Webber, the return of the low-cost, high-yield entertainment (Jackie Mason, Penn and Teller), and the extravaganza-hungry public's almost mute compliance with the freshly minted $50 ticket. But there was another world spinning in 1987 - the real world - and what made the theater year memorable, if at times painful, was the surprising extent to which that world kept bursting through the playhouse's walls.

title: In Southeast Asia, Season of Upscale Giving
description: Year round, there are plenty of statistics produced to chart the steadily rising prosperity of Southeast Asia's ''little dragon'' economies. But when Christmas comes, the affluence is measured in happy human faces.

title: Caracas
description: To the Editor: A friend and I visited Caracas in July. We agreed with Anthony Austin's observation (Travel, Oct. 25) that instead of providing architecture, Venezuelean money could have eased the plight of the poor. As prominent as the modern skyscrapers are, the shanties spilling down three sides of the surrounding mountains paint a rusty stain that ends flush against the high-rise fences. The prosperity of the past is gone, and the city is gravely affected. Visiting the Beaux Artes Museum, we were stunned to find there were no pictures. MILDRED WARNER MUNROE Jackson Heights, Queens

title: A Chinese Film Studio Becomes a Haven for Innovators
description: ONE DAY IN OCTOBER 1983, Wu Tianming walked onto the stage of the Xian Film Studio auditorium and looked out over the 4,000 faces that he was to manage as the new studio chief. This is what he told them:

title: Gwendolyn Fager to Wed Paul R. Cheek Next April
description: Gwendolyn Anne Fager, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Fager of New Canaan, Conn., and Paul Raynor Cheek, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd McForrest Cheek of Madison, N.J., plan to marry in April, the future bride's parents have announced.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
For an American-Born Jew, a Paradox
description: LEAD: TO HUNDREDS of millions of Christians throughout the world, Christmas is a very special holiday.

title: Ellen T. O'Grady to Wed Peter Edward Fitzgerald
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Grady 3d of Garden City, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Ellen Theresa O'Grady to Peter Edward Fitzgerald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Fitzgerald of Stoughton, Mass. A spring wedding is planned.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;
Lakefront Projects on a Saltwater Island
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Long Island has more than 1,000 linear miles of shoreline, its sandy soil is not conducive to freshwater lakes, and the few that exist are for the most part in parks or nature preserves.

title: WHAT WERE THE YEAR'S BEST SPORTS STORIES?
description: As we celebrate the 40th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's entry into baseball, we should be grateful to Al Campanis for reminding us of the continued prejudice and discrimination that permeates major-league baseball. KEN FERBER New York

title: Racists and Anarchists
description: To the Editor:

title: ALIENATION OF AFFECTION: PUTTING IT INTO PERSPECTIVE
description: MY vacation was long overdue and I couldn't wait to get started. The only problem was leaving the dogs - Bubeli and Dunkeli, my middle-aged dachshunds. From the time they had tumbled out of their carrying case and bounced into my life at the age of five weeks, they had been an integral part of my existence.

title: First Test for Soviet Reforms: Has Gorbachev Already Lost Round I?
description: There's no doubting Mikhail Gorbachev's determination to breathe new life into the wheezing Soviet economy. But there are already reasons to think that his first round of reforms will fail.

title: For Chinese, A Mismatch Of Job Skills
description: Li Xiaoyan remembers the day he began working for his master's degree in business administration from an American university.

title: Trip Insurance
description: To the Editor: The Practical Traveler column on Oct. 25 discussed trip cancellation insurance. No mention was made of the cancellation policy of Saga International Holidays of Boston. Providing group packages for people 60 and older, Saga offers a complete refund for cancellations for medical reasons.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE DISCOVERY OF THE TITANIC. By Robert D. Ballard with Rick Archbold. Illustrations of Titanic by Ken Marschall. (Warner/Madison Press, $29.95.) The sinking of the Titanic has become an enduring symbol of Edwardian splendor and hubris, endlessly documented and debated, and seductively elusive. It is no wonder that discovery of the wreckage in 1985 - 73 years after the sinking - by a French-American oceanographic expedition should have stirred enormous popular interest while raising hopes among Titanic scholars and buffs that some of the missing pieces might finally fall into place.

title: FLYERS EXTEND STREAK TO 14
description: Ilkka Sinisalo scored with 2 minutes 25 seconds left in the game to give Philadelphia a 3-2 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight and extend the Flyers' unbeaten streak to 14 games.

title: TWO SHOWS FEATURE LANDSCAPE PHOTOGRAPHY BY KETCHUM
description: ROBERT GLENN KETCHUM emerged with a master's degree in fine arts from the California Institute of the Arts in 1974. Since then, apparently, he has been working nonstop - as a curator, consultant, lecturer and, most of all, as a landscape photographer. At the Hudson River Museum it is Mr. Ketchum the photographer and heartfelt environmentalist who is the center of attention.

title: Out of Register
description: Two million New Yorkers are eligible to vote but not registered. In October, Mayor Koch announced an ambitious campaign to sign them up with a late-November mailing of registration forms to every household in the city. Senators Moynihan and D'Amato agreed to contribute $300,000 worth of their Congressional franking privilege. City officials hoped that the effort would swell voter rolls by at least 500,000.

title: Whether, or When, to Buy OS/2
description: SOME people loathe OS/2, some say it is the greatest development in personal computing in many years, and most don't know it from chopped liver. But the new operating system for powerful personal computers is eventually going to affect everyone who uses a PC in business.

title: Johanna Neuman to Wed Ron Nessen
description: Johanna Neuman, the White House correspondent for USA Today, and Ron Nessen, the vice president for news of the Mutual Broadcasting System in Washington, plan to marry Feb. 14, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Neuman of Los Angeles, have announced.

title: Just the Right Note on New Year's Day
description: WHETHER they constitute a late supper on New Year's Eve or brunch on New Year's Day, certain dishes always hit the spot. Blinis, Russian buckwheat pancakes, served with red or black caviar, melted butter and sour cream, are one of my favorites, especially with a glass of champagne or iced vodka.

title: Mary O'Callaghan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James B. O'Callaghan of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Anne Elizabeth O'Callaghan to Thomas F. McElroy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James T. McElroy of Fairfield, Conn. Ms. O'Callaghan graduated from St. Joseph's College in New York and received a master's degree in history from St. John's University. Her fiance is an alumnus of George Washington University. They plan to marry in May.

title: WHAT WERE THE YEAR'S BEST SPORTS STORIES?
description: This year's top sports story is, and continues to be, the pollution of the athletic environment by moneyed interests. Big-time college campuses have been infected by agents offering illegal financial assistance, coaches motivated by personal avarice rather than the desire to educate, administrations dedicated to the pursuit of television revenues, and athletes hoping to use school as a way station to the pros.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: TWO BLIZZARDS

title: Shaw's 'Arms and the Man' Is Staged in Fairfield
description: STAGING ''Arms and the Man'' is a tricky thing. All excess and extravagance on the surface, it is filled with more operetta-like outbursts than the musical it inspired, ''The Chocolate Soldier'' with its signature song, ''My Hero.'' It is, after all, a play by George Bernard Shaw - and that isn't romantic.

title: THE OLDEST BOY OF BRITISH INTELLIGENCE
description: ''C'' The Secret Life of Sir Stewart Graham Menzies, Spymaster to Winston Churchill. By Anthony Cave Brown. Illustrated. 830 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $25.

title: Hidden Touches On U.S. Stamps
description: UNAUTHORIZED markings on United States stamps, made by the engravers of the dyes, prompted smiles in the world of philately but frowns in the Treasury Department's Bureau of Engraving and Printing earlier this year.

title: Fighting All-Male Clubs at Harvard
description: A female student at Harvard University has filed a legal complaint against one of the campus's nine all-male social clubs, renewing a debate here over whether the clubs, which admit no women and very few men, should retain their single-sex status.

title: INQUIRY PLANNED INTO PREMIUM RISE
description: The New York State Comptroller will investigate cost increases of 60 percen, suddenly ordered last month, in premiums for public employers who belong to the state-sponsored Empire Plan insurance program.

title: AT HOSPICE, PRESCHOOLERS REACH OUT TO THE DYING
description: Each school day, 24 children roam the Connecticut Hospice in small groups, visiting the kitchen, the offices, the pharmacy, asking doctors, nurses, maintenence people and patients the endless questions of the young.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BRAVE NEW WORDS
description: LEAD: I WILL quit smoking. I will lose weight. I will start a happy relationship, ask for a raise, maybe even change jobs. In every way possible, I will better my lot - after the first of the year.

title: SOME TIPS ON FIXING VENETIAN BLINDS
description: WHEN a Venetian blind requires repair or becomes so grimy that ordinary dusting or sponging won't suffice, disassembling the blind may be the only answer. Though the job takes patience, it is not difficult.

title: Bicentennial Film Is Too Late
description: A producer hired to film a documentary on the city's celebration of the Constitution's bicentennial has failed to complete the project and never contacted prominent people he had planned to interview, a newspaper here reported Tuesday.

title: Food Without Foam
description: The Styrofoam box with two compartments keeps the burger hot while the lettuce and tomato stay cool and crisp. But at what cost to the environment? The white plastic packages create hazardous waste. Tons of nonbiodegradable boxes and cups strain the nation's overflowing landfills. Burning can generate toxic emissions. Richard Kessel, executive director of New York State's Consumer Protection Commission, sensibly calls on McDonald's, the largest fast-food chain, to switch voluntarily to recyclable paper wrappers. Not all jurisdictions stop at voluntary measures. In October, Berkeley, Calif., prohibited the use of foam packaging by fast-food restaurants. Rhode Island, Seattle and New York's Suffolk County are considering similar steps.

title: Syracuse Arrives For Sugar Bowl
description: Syracuse (11-0) arrived here today to begin on-site preparations for Friday's Sugar Bowl game with Auburn (9-1-1), and Coach Dick MacPherson said that he expected his players to enjoy their stay.

title: On Language; Smiles Of a Summit Night
description: THE WORLD'S EARS were poised to pick up the awaited word. As Ronald Reagan and Mikhail Gorbachev stepped into the rain to say farewell after a newsless summit, the diplomatic words that would signal genuine progress in superpower relations would be fruitful and productive.

title: The Words of Karen Horney
description: To the Editor:

title: The Record of Pat Robertson On Religion and Government
description: Pat Robertson, the Republican Presidential candidate who resigned his ministry to allay concern that he would impose religion on government if elected, said emphatically when he was a minister that he believed only devout Christians and Jews were qualified to govern.

title: A Half-Century of Nostalgia for 4 Submerged Towns
description: Half a century after they sang ''Home, Sweet Home'' and watched the waters of Quabbin Reservoir swallow their houses, survivors still remember the four towns flooded to provide drinking water for Boston.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We have a good-quality wallcovering of plastic that was carefully hung and neatly joined at the edges. We now find that the edges are curling up in some places and none of the adhesives I have tried seem to hold these edges down. Do you have a suggestion?

title: ...AS STUDENTS WIDEN HORIZONS
description: THE poet exhorts the ninth graders to take life and make mythology out of it, not to worry about the facts for one half-hour in their day of revolving classes at Harborfields High School in Greenlawn.

title: Correction
description: A table last Sunday showing economic predictions for 1988 misstated the frequency of publication of a collection of forecasts edietd by Victor Zarnowitz. The journal, economic Forecast: A Worldwide Survey, is published monthly by Elsevier Science Publishers, Amsterdam.

title: Bodies of 133 Found From Ferry Disaster, The Filipinos Report
description: The coast guard said today that it had recovered the bodies of 133 of the more than 1,600 people believed killed in a collision between a passenger ship and an oil tanker Sunday night.

title: HOW LONG CAN ISRAEL DENY ITS CIVIL WAR?
description: AN American reporter in Jerusalem who used to work in Beirut was talking to his Israeli neighbor the other day about the latest Palestinian riots, in which Israeli troops shot and killed 22 Arab youths.

title: CABLE FLEXES ITS OPTIONS
description: THIS WAS THE YEAR WHEN THE LONG-heralded promise of more meaningful viewing options for the home audience began coming into clearer focus. Independent stations continued to get livelier. Home recorders and video cassettes became more entrenched as viewing alternatives. And, with Fox Broadcasting, there is even a fledgling effort to create a fourth network. But by far the most significant advances could be claimed by cable television. According to the Cable Advertising Bureau, basic cable systems passed the 50 percent mark in reaching the country's 88.4 million TV households. In cable households with pay-TV, 42 percent of viewing time was spent watching cable, while 49 percent went to ABC, CBS and NBC. A mere 10 years ago, the three networks could claim more than 90 percent of the nation's home audience.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A TEMPORARY RESIDENCE. By Helen Hudson. (Putnam, $18.95.) The title of Helen Hudson's novel refers to Mt. Hope, an internment camp in World War II where thousands of Japanese-Americans have been imprisoned. The camp's name is sadly ironic, since the humiliating conditions that exist there have caused the innocent evacuees to adopt a fatalistic motto, ''Shikata ga nai'' (''It can't be helped'').

title: SOME TIPS ON FIXING VENETIAN BLINDS
description: WHEN a Venetian blind requires repair or becomes so grimy that ordinary dusting or sponging won't suffice, disassembling the blind may be the only answer. Though the job takes patience, it is not difficult.

title: Iroquois Project Can Avoid Public Hearings
description: Under pressure from a powerful committee chairman and industry lobbyists, Congressional negotiators have reached a compromise that will allow builders to avoid lengthy public hearings as they seek approval of a $407 million gas pipeline through New York and Connecticut.

title: War Status in Angola Is Status Quo
description: The Angolan civil war, 12 years old and with no end in sight, continues to stunt this potentially rich land.

title: POPULAR BULB TO GROW
description: PLANT the live Christmas tree; protect the root area with mulch. Be sure covers are secure on coldframes and doors are tight on greenhouses. Move tender house plants away from cool windows.Check cactuses for mealybugs and control, if found. Amaryllis

title: A CHANGE OF SPACE
description: TYPECASTING CAN be as much of a problem for architects as for actors. Especially top architects, whose projects are so widely publicized that both the architectural community and the public have come to associate a particular style with a particular practitioner. Were design aficionados asked to describe the work of a partnership like Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, for instance, they would no doubt point out what has become the firm's signature over the last 20 years: dramatic, sculptural facades and interiors that often feature curving glass blocks, minimal contemporary furnishings, meticulouly crafted details and good modern art. The company's work would suggest that its clients are only those with a penchant for 20th-century taste.

title: Dana Kohnken To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Dana Elise Kohnken to Bradley Douglas Cole has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Kohnken of Westport, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of David M. Cole and Samina R. Cole, both of Annapolis, Md. A June wedding is planned.

title: Developer Buys Church Land: Gothic Details for an Office Building
description: When the Rev. Peter Larom, pastor of the Grace Episcopal Church in White Plains, heard that Harry A. Halpern planned an office project on the same block as his church building, he briefly considered fighting it. Instead, he decided upon an option being exercised by an increasing number of nonprofit institutions that are situated on valuable, downtown property: He agreed to sell church land to the developer. Now, Mr. Larom and Halpern Enterprises are jointly petitioning the city for the necessary zoning changes.

The tab was $517.42 - and I felt that we got our money's worth.

title: ON THE WAY TO MANILA, 1,500 ARE KILLED AT SEA
description: ON the moonless night of Dec. 20, most of the passengers on the overcrowded Dona Paz were asleep, either in steel bunks or on outside decks, as the ferry made for Manila. Many of them were going to the Philippine capital for the Christmas holidays. Then the 2,215-ton ferry collided with the 629-ton tanker Victor, with a crew of 13. Fire broke out; some passengers jumped in the sea, escaped; within minutes both ships sank, killing at least 1,500 people. By week's end, only 26 survivors had been found after searches in the area of the collision, between the islands of Luzon, where Manila is, and Mindoro, to the south.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: AND CONDORS DANCED By Zilpha Keatley Snyder. 211 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 9 to 13) RAMBUNCTIOUS and fun-loving, 11-year-old Mehitabel Carlton Hartwick - Carly - reminds us of Louisa May Alcott's kinetic Jo March in ''Little Women.'' Carly seeks adventures, such as those she reads about in ''King Arthur and His Round Table'' and ''Sherlock Holmes,'' but she must contend with a family to whom she is alternately invisible or irritating. Her invalid mother is preoccupied with painful memories of her 2-year-old-son who died of influenza, and her two older sisters are busy with cleaning, cooking, sewing, washing, ironing and mending. Her father is distant and stern. When he does notice Carly, he chastises her for reading books that are ''too stimulating,'' or for riding her horse astride instead of the more ladylike sidesaddle.

The store's decor is traditional, understated and a bit intimidating, with somber wood cases, carved balcony rail and wall-to-wall carpets in Bond Street blue, as it has come to be known. The merchandise also evokes tradition and the past. At $9 there are palm-size leather-bound diaries that are virtually unchanged since the store's founder, Frank Smythson, introduced them a century ago. At the other end of the price scale, at about $550, is an old-fashioned black attache case that even the store's general manager acknowledges is not a big seller.

title: NONFICTION
description: ALEXIS LICHINE'S NEW ENCYCLOPEDIA OF WINES & SPIRITS. Fifth Edition, Revised. By Alexis Lichine with William Fifield. (Knopf, $45.) New Year's Eve celebrants who seek Alexis Lichine's advice on serving Champagne will also learn that Art Buchwald likes bubbly ''because it always tastes as though my foot's asleep.'' Such tidbits explain why Mr. Lichine's encyclopedia, 20 years after it first appeared, remains popular. Now, newly expanded in its fifth revision, it gains complexity as it ages, like vintage Bordeaux. Wine lovers who savor the stylish reds the author makes at Chateau Prieure-Lichine in the Medoc village of Margaux can serendipitously ''sip'' hundreds of entries with pleasure. Though biased toward France, and devoting less attention to spirits than wine, this volume towers higher than ever over countless manuals that challenge but never threaten its supremacy as a virtual library in itself. For the amateur and professional, the 10 essays that form the book's backbone merit periodic rereading. They illuminate such basic topics as how wine is made, the history of wine, wine and food, the vine and spirit-making. Mystifyingly, the alphabetized definitions omit blush wines and West Germany's important trocken (dry) and halbtrocken (half dry) wines, and list minor chateaus separately while relegating E. & J. Gallo, the world's largest winery, to a subchapter. Impressively, seven pages are devoted to the viticultural and enological revolutions in New York State, which is shifting from sweet labrusca to dry vinifera wines. But why did Washington and Oregon together rate not quite four pages? Still, the index is subtle and the con-version tables are golden.

title: Don't Water Down The Antifraud Law

But something was conspicuously absent from the criminal sentence: a significant fine commensurate with the crime.

Not that it's surprising, or even bad: the CD has become the format of choice among classical-music record buyers, and naturally one wants as many valuable recordings as possible from the analogue era to remain readily available.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Track and Field Two Golds for Foderingham: Winsome Foderingham captured two gold medals yesterday in women's events at the Reebok Christmas Classic track and field meet in the West Point field house in West Point, N.Y. The meet was conducted by the Metropolitan Athletics Congress. Foderingham, a Jamaican representing the Bronx International Express Track Club, won the 55-meter dash in 7.14 seconds and the 55-meter hurdles in 8.12 seconds. Lynn Weik of Sayville, L.I., a 20-year-old junior at the State University at Stony Brook, posted an American indoor record for the women's one-mile walk when she won in 6 minutes 47.95 seconds. In men's events, Mike Pascuzzo of the New York Athletic Club and John Finney of the University of Maryland scored impressive victories. Pascuzzo cleared the high-jump bar at 7 feet 2 inches; Finney was first in the pole vault at 16 feet 6 inches. Sharon Moore of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn was the winner of the high school 400-meter run in 58.11 seconds. Derrick Atkins of Malverne, L.I., won the boys' 400 meters in 50.45. Hockey U.S. Junior Team Loses: Poland edged the United States, 4-3, yesterday in Moscow as play began in the world junior hockey championships for players under 20 years of age, the Tass press agency reported. Poland took a 1-0 lead in the first period. Both teams scored three times in the second period but the third period was scoreless. In other matches, Canada defeated Sweden, 4-2, Finland beat West Germany, 6-0, and the Soviet Union downed Czechoslovakia, 6-4. Rob Dimaio, Rob Brown, Dan Currie and Theoren Fleury scored for Canada, which received outstanding goaltending from Jimmy Waite. Sweden outshot the Canadians by 53-33. (AP) Tennis Dogger, Labat Win Youth Titles: Sixth-seeded Paul Dogger of the Netherlands defeated eighth-seeded Brice Karsh of Cortez, Fla., 6-1, 6-0, yesterday to win the boys' 16 title in the 1987 Orange Bowl international tennis championship in Miami Beach. In the girls' 16 title match, Florence Labat of Argentina defeated Macarena Miranda of Chile, 6-1, 1-6, 6-1.(A) Steeplechase French Horse Scores an Upset: Nupsala upset the favorites with a late burst of speed to give France its first-ever victory in the King George VI steeplechase race yesterday at Kempton, England. Ridden by Andre Pommier, the 25-1 shot charged back into contention before pulling clear in the homestretch. The 8-year-old Nupsala clinched the victory when Forgive 'n Forget, who was challenging for the lead, fell at the last fence. The favored Desert Orchid, who had led for much for the race, finished second ahead of Golden Friend.(AP) Soccer Liverpool Stays Unbeaten: Liverpool maintained its unbeaten league record yesterday, blanking Oxford, 3-0, as the English League soccer season reached the halfway stage. John Aldridge, John Barnes and Steve McMahon scored for Liverpool, which extended its unbeaten streak to 20 games. Liverpool stretched its lead at the top of the First Division to 10 points. Nottingham Forest scored its first victory at Arsenal in 19 years, winning by 2-0. The victory enabled Forest to tie Arsenal for second place. Terry Wilson and Stuart Pearce were the goal scorers. (AP)

title: FICTION
description: THE FLOOD. By John Broderick. (Marion Boyars/ Kampmann, $22.95.) Forget about plot. John Broderick's latest novel, ''The Flood,'' which is set during the 1930's in Bridgeford, Ireland (population 8,767), boasts such a colorful jumble of characters and voices one barely notices that its story is thin and inconsequential. In this community where drinking in a pub is ''as respectable as going to church,'' the townspeople crowd into the Cafe Royal. There they dawdle, talk and plot to bamboozle an Englishman named Hector Slyne, who wants to buy several parcels of land along the Shannon River, which flows through Bridgeford and, unbeknown to Slyne, floods its banks every winter. Benny O'Farrell, dubbed Fenny O'Barrell because of his majestic girth, presides over the bar and the town, stabilizing their flightier characters. And so, when ''Hosannah'' Braiden, Sarah Jane McLurry and Mrs. ''Pig'' Prendergast raise a ruckus over Slyne's attempt to withdraw from the land deal, it's Fenny who dispenses the drink and quiet wisdom that ease their fears. Keenly interested in all his characters' intricate interconnections and negotiations, Mr. Broderick depicts their strict and quirky provincial protocol in a masterly fashion, exposing the bulk of the interactions among these shopkeepers and servants as pure theater. ''The Flood'' presents nothing to contradict the stereotypical image of the Irish as a charming, hard-drinking, devious, witty and blarneying lot, whose attachment to their social rituals and to the auld sod creates wonderfully human and humorous moments. This is a first-rate comic novel, and its lush characterization and language richly recommend it.

title: WILLIAM SIMON'S FACIFIC OVERTURES
description: THE BUILDING ON SANTA MONICA BOULEVARD in Beverly Hills, just over the Los Angeles city line, bears no resemblance to the West Coast headquarters of a world-class tycoon with bold new plans of conquest in the Pacific. A scant three stories tall, muted post-modern in design, set in a row of nondescript shops facing the Hilton and the back of Robertson's department store, the World Trade Bank resembles the showroom of a moderately prosperous Chevrolet dealer. On a recent autumn day, the second-floor offices of William E. Simon - the headquarters of his ''Pacific Initiative'' - were still without decor or intercoms, and chairs were in short supply.

title: To Improve Medicaid's Bad Deal
description: A new study finds that New York State's Medicaid program is one of the best in the country, but it costs New York City plenty. The city's share of the health insurance for the poor now comes to $1.4 billion annually, a figure that has been increasing 11 percent per year, well above the national average. Yet too many city Medicaid patients still receive haphazard care. Mayor Koch's proposal to reshape the program makes eminent sense.

Indeed, he did eliminate billions in spending for education, housing, public works, job training and a variety of programs for the needy. State and local governments were to take over these tasks, and Federal employment was to hold steady as state and municipal hiring grew.

Of course, at this time of year hundreds of charlatans hang out their shingles, dust off their crystal balls and spew out a lot of hot air about what's coming up. We professionals are deeply upset that sophisticated forecasting has become so contaminated. That's why we greatly appreciate the chance now to show our stuff and thereby distance ourselves from the flimflammers.

title: Leslie Carothers Is a Ballerina Ablaze With Passion
description: THIS HAS BEEN CALLED an age of dancers. Virtuoso whiz kids dart, spin and soar through choreography whose challenges would once have been considered almost impossible. Then there are the performers who fill the stage with their very presence. Every so often, however, a dancer is endowed with both superb technical facilities and a commanding stage personality. Such a performer is Leslie Carothers, the ballerina who will dance the Snow Queen on Wednesday when the Joffrey Ballet opens at City Center in its new production of ''The Nutcracker.'' The holiday classic will be performed through next Sunday.

title: NEW PLANT MAP IS PROPOSED
description: HARDY is a word often used in defining how well a plant grows, but it is a relative term. A plant that is considered hardy in a certain area should survive cold weather and not be subject to frost damage. But the word is not completely accurate, because it does not take into account many factors that affect growth: drought/rainfall, exposure/radiation, soils, summer heat and other environmental constraints.

title: PENZOIL PONDERS $3 BILLION QUESTION
description: What to do with $3 billion was the question Penzoil was pondering as a settlement plan was filed in its historic feud with Texaco. Texaco's plan to emerge from bankruptcy calls for a $3 billion payment to settle Pennzoil's claim that Texaco' acquisition of Getty Oil wrongfully interfered with a Pennzoil takeover of the company. The plan will also require Texaco to pay creditors $2.5 billion. For Texaco, the plan relieves one set of pressures but sets up others. For one thing, the financial burdens will probably require Texaco to sell some assets. The largest shareholder, Carl C. Icahn, has opposed the antitakeover provisions in Texaco's plan and this week he said he might file his own reorganization proposal. Mr. Icahn also disclosed that he had been contacted by parties interested in buying parts or all of Texaco. But for J, Hugh Liedtke, the chairman and Chief executive of Pennzoil, the settlemenat caps a 25-year career with the company. Mr. Liedtke wasn't talking about what the company would do with the payment, saying ''you want to get your hands on it first.'' * * *

Byrnes, vice president of Shaeffer-Eton Inc., said Thursday that the pen and stationery manufacturer planned to lease back a portion of the building for its headquarters staff.

description: Three Palestinian guerrillas infiltrated a short distance into Israel from Jordan Friday night and were captured alive by Israeli troops after a shootout, the Israeli Army spokesman announced today.

This was not immediate cause for alarm. To the contrary, what was happening was that a crucial problem that had plagued me since college was being resolved before my ears.

title: Headliners; Out of Russia
description: Like many other Jewish scientists in the Soviet Union, Aleksandr Lerner was long denied permission to emigrate because, officials said, he knew too much. Mr. Lerner, a leader in the campaign for Jewish emigration, is a specialist in cybernetics, and Soviet authorities for 17 years denied him an exit visa on the ground that his research had given him access to state secrets. But last week, continuing a trend toward increased Jewish emigration, the scientist, along with his son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter, was granted permission to emigrate to Israel. ''There are so many getting out that I could have expected this,'' he said. ''But it's one thing to expect it and still be waiting. It's another to get the call.''

title: Campaign for Egg Eating Stirs Storm in India
description: When hundreds of runners turned up for a marathon race in the western city of Pune last month, they were handed free boiled eggs by members of a movement seeking to promote the egg-eating habit in india.

title: Jazz Milestones and Rock Pioneers
description: HERE, IN ALPHABETICAL order by artist, are 10 very personal favorites from among the year's albums. Ranking the list internally in order to arrive at an ''album of the year'' would be as futile as the old apples-and-oranges comparison. The albums: Ornette Coleman, ''In All Languages'' (Caravan of Dreams) Andrew Hill, ''Shades'' (Soul Note) Live Skull, ''Dusted'' (Homestead) Roscoe Mitchell, ''The Flow of Things'' (Black Saint) Sonic Youth, ''Sister'' (SST) Russ Tolman, ''Totem Poles and Glory Holes'' (Down There/Restless) Townes Van Zandt, ''At My Window'' (Sugar Hill) Tom Verlaine, ''Flash Light'' (I.R.S.) Bunny Wailer, ''Rootsman Skanking'' (Shanachie) La Monte Young, ''The Well Tuned Piano'' (Gramavision) The La Monte Young and Ornette Coleman albums are watershed events, not just in the careers of two vitally important artists but in the development of late 20th-century music. Rock's pleasures are more immediate and visceral. Sonic Youth's ''Sister'' was the year's freshest, most intensely visionary rock-and-roll record. The Roscoe Mitchell and Andrew Hill albums were unexpected returns to peak form by two of the most determinedly individual voices in jazz. Townes Van Zandt and Russ Tolman spoke directly and eloquently from the heart.

title: Lewis C. Coffin, Library of Congress Official, 78
description: Lewis C. Coffin, a former law librarian of the Library of Congress, died of cancer Monday at his home in Washington. He was 78 years old.

MUSIC

Before the brief performance that provides this video with its reason to be, we are given a pointless patchwork of visions that includes hillsides in blustery weather and gulls lifting into flight (to the sound of revving airplane engines); tai chi being performed at a poolside and footage of the attack on Pearl

title: WHEN JUDGES MUST KNOW MORE THAN LAW
description: AFTER a four-year jury trial, probably the longest in United States history, a court in Belleville, Ill., decided in October that 65 citizens of a small Missouri town had not been harmed when a chemical used as a wood preservative was spilled in a 1979 railroad accident. Nevertheless, the jurors awarded the plaintiffs $16 million in punitive damages against the manufacturer, the Monsanto Company, for not ridding its product of dioxin, a potentially dangerous contaminant, and failing to warn the public about it. By the time this seemingly contradictory verdict was rendered, $22 million in legal costs had been consumed. Why did it take so long and cost so much to reach the decision? Are the courts competent to handle complex scientific matters?

title: AN ANIMATED '88 AWAITS ON THE DRAWING BOARD
description: TELEVISION'S CRAVING FOR animation continues to be as ravenous as the appetites of those sinister cats on the film maker Ralph Bakshi's ''Mighty Mouse: The New Adventures,'' Saturday mornings on CBS. While just about all program schedules have currently been offering a cornucopia of animated holiday fare, animators are already busy at their drawing boards crafting colorful fantasies for 1988 and '89.

description: Dennis Conner's reclamation of the America's Cup, after losing it to the Aussies in 1983, has to be the sports story of the year. Why else would so many Americans stay up until 4 A.M. just to ''watch grass grow?'' STEWART J. WILEY Westport, Conn.

Unglamorous, unsmiling, contorted with emotion, imploring attention for the songs rather than himself, he acts not like an overgrown bad boy or a high-living hedonist but an everyman about to explode with hopes and fears. It is the face of popular music feeling its power and its global reach, and taking them very seriously. This year rock got earnest - in earnest.

In 1987, quite a number of harmless quiche-and-salad places opened, following Manhattan deserters to county condominium developments. title: THAW AND FREEZE AND THAW AGAIN: THE CULTURAL WEATHER IN CHINA
description: ''THE wind has turned,'' said Feng Yidai, a tight-lipped cautious man who edits Dushu (Reading), Beijing's avant-garde scholarly journal. We were standing in a corner of the faded reception hall of the International Club earlier this month, quietly talking about the bitter chill that had swept China's cultural life. It came at the onset of the year in the guise of a campaign by Chinese Communist Party conservatives against bourgeois liberalization, code for Western influence. Prominent intellectuals were disciplined. Hu Yaobang, the patron of the cultural ''openness'' policy that had given writers and artists more license than at any other time since the establishment of the People's Republic in 1949, was ousted as the general secretary of the party. For writers and artists it was another of the recurring winters of silenced voices, unpublished manuscripts and exhibitions of vacuous art. Now Mr. Feng was telling me there was a thaw that raised hope once again for greater freedom of expression. ''We have been free of interference since the congress,'' he said. The 13th party congress ended in early November.

title: INCREASINGLY, THOSE WHO HAVE JOBS ARE POOR, TOO
description: IN 1981, President Reagan persuaded Congress to adopt many of his proposals tightening eligibility and limiting benefits in the main welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Emphasizing the importance of the work ethic, Administration officials said A.F.D.C. should be restricted to those who could not work because they were old or disabled or had to care for young children.

title: Headliners; In Custody
description: Until he disappeared while scuba diving in the Bahamas two years ago, David J. Friedland was just a New Jersey politician with a swindling conviction on his record. Subsequently the former State Senator was known as a nimble international fugitive, and was spotted in Paris and Hong Kong among other places, traveling first class and moving a little faster than the law. Mr. Friedland's run ended last week when he was arrested on the Indian Ocean island of Male in the Republic of the Maldives. The Hudson County Democrat, who faces eight years in prison for taking kickbacks from a union pension fund, escaped from the authorities' grasp while cooperating under the Federal witness protection program.

title: From Euphoria to Glory to Grand Scope
description: WAS IT ALWAYS SO EASY TO find great performers as it is today? They are all over the landscape, helpfully labeled for us by arts packagers. Here they come, armies of great singers, great violinists, great pianists, great conductors, great computer programmers. Others fall into old but strangely new categories marked designer or stage director, whose most celebrated celebrities now invite us to enjoy the odd sensation of experiencing music as primarily a visual art to which aimless sounds are added, generally quite unobtrusively, though occasionally with the wit and subtlety of a laugh track. Opera in particular has lately been examined and found to be sadly out of kilter: not enough simplicity and repetition in the rhythms, not enough microphones and amplifiers, not enough sado-masochist sex and Yuppie-oriented conservative political chic.

title: Skiing the Uncrowded Colorado
description: BEAVER CREEK is a refuge for hawks, elk, whistle pigs (groundhogs), eagles, deer, beaver and skiers fleeing the winter carnival of Vail. Vail, just up the road, is a dazzling place to ski. The Colorado snow is abundant, the temperature rarely cold enough to be uncomfortable, the air dry, the lifts fast; the runs, lined with spruce and aspen, are varied and seemingly endless. Its only drawback is its popularity - even with the high-speed chairs installed in 1985 and 1,880 acres of snowfields, skiers can find themselves spending more time than they'd like in lift lines and looking for elbow room on the slopes.

title: Campaign Calendar '88
description: Jan. 4 Treasury hands out first batch of Federal matching funds to candidates who qualify. Kemp, Babbitt, Gephardt are especially eager; they have already borrowed against the Federal money. Jan. 15 The Democrats take part in a two-hour debate, broadcast via public television from Des Moines. May be the first time the newly reconstituted field of seven will appear together. Jan. 29-30 The Republicans are scheduled for the first delegate selection, in Michigan state convention. The stakes: Bush stands to be embarrassed if Robertson does well. Feb. 8, Feb. 16 Iowa caucuses, N.H. primary. Winners get exposure and momentum. Dole must take Iowa. Dukakis, Hart each must win N.H. Only one can. Mar. 8 16 primaries make this a 'super Tuesday' of mostly southern and border states. Gore, a Southerner, counting on victories to establish himself as the center's candidate; with the black vote, Jackson expects to get more delegates than any of the others. Mar. 9 Field could narrow. Candidates with less than 10 percent in any two consecutive primaries will lose Federal matching funds in 30 days. Haig, du Pont, among others, may be at risk. Mar. 29 After three more primaries and a handful of caucuses, both parties will have picked over half their delegates, making, in theory at least, commanding leads possible. Illinois voting is a key test of industrial state sentiment. If Simon is still a player, he must take his home base. Apr. 2-19 Big-state voting continues. N.Y. primary especially could be key in a contested Democratic race. Cuomo looms over it all. Apr. 20 Democrats in Congress pick 253 of their number to be among 643 unpledged 'super-delegates.' Total convention votes: 4,160. Republicans send their governors, Congressmen and party officials to conventions through the regular electoral machinery. Apr. 26-May 3 Blockbuster primaries continue in Ind., Pa. and Ohio. More delegates than ever are picked by primaries this year. Democrats have them in 33 states, Republicans in 37. May 10-24 A small collection of Western contests will not yield a lot in delegates -only 107 in each party -but could yield a lot in headlines, and so help raise money for the last round, if either race is close. Sometime in June, probably Inter- and intra-party sniping may be replaced by displays of statesmanship as Reagan journeys to Moscow summit with Gorbachev. June 7 Four primaries end the season. Maneuvering for the Vice Presidential nomination will come out into the open. If no Democrat has nearly half the delegates after Calif. and N.J., brokering for the top spot on the ticket will start in earnest. July 18-21 Democratic National Convention, Atlanta. Even if a nominee is assured going in, Democrats will quarrel about their platform and vision of the future. They always do. Aug. 15-18 Republican National Convention, New Orleans. Celebration of the nominee will compete with paeans to Reagan's successes. Sept.-Oct. Labor Day is the traditional opening day for the general election campaign. Four debates, Sept. 14 and 25, Oct. 11 and 27, are now scheduled. Oct.-Nov. Last economic statistics before the voters go to the polls could be valuable political capital for someone. Trade, growth and inflation reports come two to three weeks, and unemployment four days, before Election Day. Nov. 8 Election Day. In 1984, 53.3 percent of those eligible to vote did so.

title: Spreading the Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: THE TOXIC CLOUD. By Michael H. Brown. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) Michael Brown is our Paul Revere of toxic pollution. As a reporter who broke the story of the burial of poisonous chemicals beneath a residential community at the Love Canal, and in his subsequent book, ''Laying Waste,'' Mr. Brown was among the first to cry the alarm about toxic waste dumps. Now, in ''The Toxic Cloud,'' he is spreading the word about the ubiquitous, dangerous but virtually unaddressed problem of the pollution of our air by toxic gases. This book is essentially a Baedeker of foul air over the United States. It takes us from the dioxins spewed by chemical plants and heavy metals, to air reeking with volatile organic chemicals from refineries in the South; from the brown smog of southern California to the ''cancer alley'' stretching from Baltimore to New York City and, finally, to the acidified lakes and dying sugar maples of New England. Along the way, Mr. Brown gives us angry stories of ordinary people who suffered, grew sick and sometimes died because their air was poisoned. Aside from some simplified toxicology, he provides no detailed scientific explanations of the problem. He puts the blame on the usual suspects: ''arrogant'' industry and an uncaring, immobile government bureaucracy. He has not thought through a solution. But the book's cumulative evidence about tainted air and endangered communities is so compelling it may prod the public to demand that serious attention be paid to this national scandal.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ELYSIAN FIELDS IN ISLIP CENTRAL PARK has its Strawberry Fields, and now the hamlet of Islip has its Elysian Fields.

title: Chemical Cleanup
description: IT'S A CHILLING SUMMARY. After 40 years of manufacturing waterproofing materials for the textiles industry, the Arkansas Chemical Company went bankrupt in 1983 and abandoned its facilities in Newark, N.J. Under the provisions of the so-called Superfund Act of 1980, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency was ultimately called in to begin a cleanup. By then, last January, vagrants and stray animals were living in and among the nine empty buildings. There were 1,800 55-gallon drums of unidentified chemical substances and more than 20,000 smaller containers on the site, many spilled. Three thousand gallons of sulfuric acid were discovered in an outdoor tank sitting perilously close to a drainage system. There had been three fires.

title: IDENTIFYING ARGENTINA'S DISAPPEARED

One is a medical student; two have undergraduate degrees in anthropology and another is working toward one. Although they speak with measured dispassion, their subject is death, violent death - the kind only state terrorism can produce.

title: Moose's Love Takes a Place In Literature

title: FICTION
description: NIGHT WITHOUT DAY. By Raphaele Billetdoux. Translated by Derek Mahon. (Viking, $14.95.) In this chronicle of a torturous three-day affair, the lovers' first meeting summons up ''the memory of a bruised pear . . . demanding anew to be eaten or thrown away.'' The burden of their first embrace ''was heavy, but they took the weight of it in their legs, they clung to each other, they concentrated harder, their clenched fingers hurting.'' Two questions persist: Does love have to be this excruciating? And could Billetdoux possibly be the author's real name? The answer to both is yes. ''Night Without Day'' was a French best seller. To wit, the lovers are as beautiful and fashion-conscious as they are anguished - a hip Tristram and Isolde. Blanche is 25, and the pulsing center of life itself, ''a girl to take pride in cold water, the redness of red fruit, the desire in a man's eye.'' She is also a chanteuse cum kinky violinist. Lucas is a man who, ''swathed in white jeans . . . suggested the walking wounded.'' He divides his time between brooding over the vision of his parents drowning when he was 8 and trying to get his dissertation together at 38. Ms. Billetdoux's prose style, at least as translated here, is an unfortunate marriage of the tone of Blanche's violin playing and that of Lucas's dissertation - clotted and hyperbolic, lurching from apocalypse to ennui and back again. And even with a 36-hour marathon of lovemaking, the novel is hardly erotic, probably because of lines like ''To see and hear each stroke modify further the tenor of her grimaces and the resonance of her voice . . . made it so urgently necessary to resist a general upheaval that he was nearly unseated when she suddenly cried, 'You know everything! You know everything!' ''

One or two absurd errors were made - notably the welcome accorded at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, and elsewhere, to the so-called Helga paintings by Andrew Wyeth - but fundamentally, and contrary to what is often supposed, museums the world over made sense.

title: When the Tide Turned on Rampant Growth
description: THE EXTRAORDINARY EVENT in architecture in 1987 was surely the building that collapsed before it was ever built: the tower designed by Moshe Safdie for the site of the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle. What was extraordinary was not the actual design for this building, which was a wretched piece of architecture, but the circumstances surrounding its demise. For in the early months of 1987, it seemed a foregone conclusion that this immense, double-towered structure would rise over Columbus Circle: the complex deal by which the city sold the land under the Coliseum to the development firm of Boston Properties for $455 million had been approved by the Board of Estimate with only token opposition. But as the year went on, there was a growing sense around New York that this project was too big by half as well as a wholly innappropriate piece of architecture, and the cries against it began to mount. They grew louder and louder, and reached a climax earlier this month with the surprise victory of the Municipal Art Society in its lawsuit against the City of New York to block the project.

description: Botswana, a peaceful, relatively prosperous democracy surrounded by southern African countries in turmoil, has enjoyed a swift development since independence from Britain in 1966. Now, however, it faces a series of new challenges complicated by its rapid growth.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE LEOPARD, by Giuseppe di Lampedusa. Translated by Archibald Colquhoun. (Pantheon, $7.95.) Set in the late 19th century, when the kingdom of Sicily was losing its independence to Italy, Giuseppe di Lampedusa's novel describes how an enlightened monarch adjusts to a situation he is powerless to change. '' 'The Leopard' is written by a highly civilized man whose intelligence illuminates the pages,'' our reviewer, Marc Slonim, said in 1960. IN SEARCH OF L. L. BEAN, by M. R. Montgomery. Drawings by Mary F. Rhinelander. (Mentor/New American Library, $4.50.) This history of the renowned mail-order sporting goods king, Leon Leonwood Bean, begins, appropriately enough, with an epigraph from Thoreau about the practical and spiritual value of a good pair of boots. In 1984, The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said the book is ''an edifying tale of America's development as a consuming society.'' Among its observations: the company's most successful advertisements have run not in such publications as Outdoor Life or Field & Stream but in The New York Review of Books. STRAIGHT CUT, by Madison Smartt Bell. (Penguin, $3.95.) In writing this ''odd, old-fashionedly hard-boiled novel'' about a degenerate sometime film editor caught up in an international drug deal, Madison Smartt Bell has ''piled up a debt to Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett that will take him a long time to repay,'' Elliott Sirkin said here last year. But the author's depiction of ''the ordinary horrors of life for a wandering philosopher-esthete'' make the novel worth reading. THE STRAW GIANT. America's Armed Forces: Triumphs and Failures, by Arthur T. Hadley. (Avon, $10.95.) Since World War II, Arthur T. Hadley has observed the military - both as an Army captain and with the detached eye of a journalist. ''Few writers have as profound a knowledge of the armed services, their virtues and faults,'' Drew Middleton said in The Book Review in 1986. ''At a critical moment in the history of the American military he has written a clear, incisive account of its strengths and many weaknesses.'' THE BRANDONS, by Angela Thirkell. (Carroll & Graf, $4.95.) Angela Thirkell, the author of ''Pomfret Towers,'' has gained a following among those who are amused by her satires of English country-house life. When this story of the conflicts between a widow and her husband's aunt was published in 1939, Louise Maunsell Field said here that it gets off to a rather slow start but is ''a refreshing, entertaining and very restful novel stemming directly from the Jane Austen-Anthony Trollope branch of English fiction.'' WHEN THE WAR WAS OVER: The Voices of Cambodia's Revolution and Its People, by Elizabeth Becker. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) It has been estimated that a million people, or about 15 percent of the population, died in Cambodia's ''killing fields'' during the Khmer Rouge terror of the late 1970's. Elizabeth Becker, a former Washington Post correspondent, tells the story by ''blending narrative with analysis . . . solid research and a broad historical perspective'' to produce a book that is as thoughtful as it is deeply felt,'' John Gross said in The Times last year. THE MALDIVE MYSTERY, by Thor Heyerdahl. (Ballantine, $4.95.) On a 1982 trip to the Maldive Islands in the Indian Ocean, the explorer Thor Heyerdahl found that the early settlers of this Moslem nation worshiped not Allah but the sun. His story of the archeological expedition ''is a fascinating combination of historical reconstruction and intelligent speculation,'' our reviewer, Jon Foreman, said last year. THE PEACOCK FEATHER MURDERS, by Carter Dickson. (International Polygonics, $4.95.) Despite the title's suggestion, no one is actually tickled to death in this mystery, Isaac Anderson said in The Book Review in 1937, but the story (in which police are invited to a murder and the killer seems to vanish before their eyes) is ''an absolute topnotcher.'' The same publisher has also reprinted NINE - AND DEATH MAKES TEN ($4.95) by Carter Dickson (a pseudonym used by John Dickson Carr, who died in 1977), which takes place in the confined, floating universe of a seagoing munitions carrier. Although there are only nine people aboard, the identity of the murderer is a mystery to the end, Kay Irvin said here in 1940. FROM HEAVEN LAKE: Travels Through Sinkiang and Tibet, by Vikram Seth. (Vintage, $5.95.) Before he became known for ''The Golden Gate,'' his novel-in-verse about lapsed yuppies in San Francisco, Vikram Seth hitchhiked across China and recorded his impressions. ''This is the perfect travel book,'' one reviewer said in 1983. Mr. Seth ''is a wonderful companion.'' IRON & SILK, by Mark Salzman. (Vintage, $5.95.) Another young author, Mark Salzman, learned about China by spending two years teaching English to doctors in the province of Hunan; at the same time, he studied calligraphy and martial arts. Mr. Salzman's anecdotes ''kept a smile on my face from cover to cover,'' Richard Selzer said earlier this year. ''If there were a prize for most winning writer, [ he ] would cop it.'' THE WOMEN'S DECAMERON, by Julia Voznesenskaya. Translated by W. B. Linton. (Owl/Holt, $9.95.) Ten women confined in a maternity ward in Leningrad have little in common except their violent, sordid pasts. The stories they tell one another of rape and revenge result in a ''profoundly interesting'' novel, Fay Weldon said here last year. ''Julia Voznesenskaya's vision shines through the opaqueness of cruelty, indecency, pornography, and . . . into the sheer delight and wonder of just being alive, and female, and fighting back.''

title:
FASHION;
IN VIVIER'S SHOES
description: LEAD: LABELING ROGER VIVIER A SHOEMAKER WOULD BE LIKE dismissing Dior as a dressmaker. For half a century, this French designer has been creating footwear virtually unrivaled in imaginative artistry. He has, for example, fashioned boots for John Lennon, complete with rhinestone-studded heels. And it was Vivier that then-Princess Elizabeth turned to for her gold-kid coronation sandals.

In the eyes of the law, they and some others who came to the United States with the Mariel boatlift never actually entered the country. They stand at the water's edge, knocking for admission.

title: FICTION
description: MOUNT'S MISTAKE. By Lew McCreary. (Atlantic Monthly, Paper, $7.95.) Jay Fielding Mount, the hapless protagonist of Lew McCreary's exuberant first novel, is an ''accidental'' man, carried along on the swift currents of change that are pulsing through America in the last years of the 19th century. Part of that current is quite literally electric as the country becomes fascinated both by the power of electricity and by the character of the man most closely associated with it, Thomas Edison. Jay, struck and almost killed by lightning in his youth, becomes involved in increasingly ironic incidents with Edison. In the last of these, he inspires a plan to electrocute an elephant while Edison's fledgling film company covers the event. Jay's peregrinations begin when he becomes a pariah in his hometown of Bolusburgh, Ohio, after the death of a child left in his charge. At first, he falls in with a wonderfully sardonic group of itinerant entertainers. Later he experiences the humiliations of jail and, after his release, takes a job stoking a boiler in one of Edison's plants. Eventually he becomes a roustabout in a seedy but resourceful circus. The characters who collide with Jay in his erratic travels are all vividly illuminated in prose that catches the haunting specifics of a moment. But finally Jay is too fragile a figure to sustain much speculation on the modern age, and ''Mount's Mistake'' comes to seem more a collection of wonderful images than a tightly woven tale. Nevertheless, it announces the arrival of an extraordinary writer who requires only a more pointed story to showcase his considerable talents. By RICHARD E. NICHOLLS

title: 4 Die in Philippines as Truce For the Holidays Is Violated

title: OF DRINKING WATER AND GREEN POCKETS

Right on target, Louise! The Civic Action Council of Nassau County has attempted for some years to persuade our county and town governments to acknowledge that there is a problem relative to preservation of Long Island's fresh drinking water. The municipalities now, at long last, acknowledge that the problems of quality and quantity of drinking water do exist, especially after they were startled by the ''cap'' placed on water usage by the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

description: THERE is a folk tale about a beautiful little fir tree that is chosen to be the Christmas tree in the manor house.

description: IN Mexico, its message is admired by millionaires and street peddlers. In Argentina, it is No. 2 on the best-seller list, sandwiched between the latest books from Jackie Collins and Sidney Sheldon. And in Peru, its gospel of ''a new culture'' based on rewarding individual effort was used to fire up thousands of people who rallied against the recent bank nationalization.

The show, a three-hour CBS special, had lost money in New York and even though the city rivals Los Angeles as a music capital, the expense and logistics of bringing back an event that costs a million dollars an hour to produce, seemed prohibitive.

WOODRUFF, the scientist who became an outcast after challenging Edward Teller, has returned to an important position at the nation's largest laboratory for the design of nuclear weapons. Even at holiday time with the overkill of glitter and glow from nearby Fortunoff and Roosevelt Field, this restaurant stands out.
