Miss Weiner, a graduate of Hamilton College, is an assistant vice president in the treasury sales group at the National Westminster Bank USA in New York. description: Kim M. Burke, an associate in the New York law firm of Semel, Boeckmann, Diamond, Schepp & Yuhas, and Glenn S. Goldberg, the press secretary to District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, plan to be married in May. Mr. and Mrs. John P. Burke of Oceanside, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Beverly Goldberg of Little Neck, Queens, and Louis Goldberg of West Hempstead, L.I. Miss Burke graduated cum laude from the State University at Albany and received a J.D. degree from the Hofstra University School of Law. Her fiance is a magna cum laude graduate of the State University College at Brockport, N.Y.

title: County Colleges Await Aid Revisions
description: OVER the last 20 years, a million New Jerseyans have attended the state's 19 two-year county community colleges, and for many it has been the start of a career that leads to further study at a four-year college.

title: CONGRESS BATS UNDER .500
description: The 100th Congress, the Democrats in charge after they recaptured the Senate in the 1986 elections, began 1987 with heady expectations for redirecting the Reagan Administration's domestic agenda and reshaping the President's foreign policy. It adjourned last week, three months later than planned, not so much defeated as deflated.

title: Verbatim: Feelings of Remorse
description: 'I think my responsibility is overwhelming, and I sincerely apologize.' Kim Dae Jung one of the losers in Dec. 16 presidential election in South Korea, expressing regret last week for the divided opposition's inability to agree on a single candidate.

title: Dance
description: The Joffrey Ballet brings its new production of ''The Nutcracker'' to New York this week, for a week only, opening on Wednesday at City Center (131 West 55th Street). A long-cherished project of Robert Joffrey's, the ballet is based on the traditional story with a few differences: For example, the setting of the ballet is Victorian American, andhuman characters from the first act reappear in the second in other guises. Mr. Joffrey's choreography for the ballet, his first since 1980, will be augmented by Gerald Arpino's snowflakes scene and Richard Englund's party scene.

title: LEGISLATORS ADOPT A BUDGET FOR 1988
description: THE County Board of Legislators approved an $846.9 million budget for 1988 last week, trimming $3.4 million from the proposed spending plan presented in mid-November by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke. The final version will require a 15 percent increase in the county tax levy, or the amount raised from real estate taxes.

title: 'Sophisticated Ladies' Settles In at Crossroads
description: WITH its unbeatable track record of such musical revues as ''Ain't Misbehavin','' ''Eubie,'' ''Bubbling Brown Sugar'' and ''One Mo' Time,'' all in effervescent stagings, one has come to look upon the Crossroads Theatre Company as the state's premiere showplace for musical tributes to black composers and the eras they represent.

title: ADVISORY GROUP TO DETERMINE FUTURE OF LANDMARKS BOARD
description: Will the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission run out of landmarks to designate? Or will it be swamped first by its regulatory duties? Should residents of historic districts have more of a say in administering their areas?

title: Miss Cohen Engaged To Michael Bresnick
description: Andrea Victoria Cohen and Michael Noah Bresnick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Bresnick of Riverdale, the Bronx, plan to marry in March, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Cohen of Princeton, N.J., and New York, have announced.

title: U.S. Weighs Fate of Unwanted Wild Horses
description: On the rolling plains of northeast Nebraska, the Federal Government manages the nation's largest wild horse ranch with 3,000 mares, colts and stallions confined in pens across 74 acres.

title:
ANTIQUES;
Newark: Accent Is on Miniatures
description: LEAD: THE candlelights are bright, a delicate table is set for tea and visitors are welcome to tour Philadelphia's grand and elegant Morris House, replicated in a remarkable 12-room doll house on display through Jan. 10 at the Newark Museum.

title: Photography
description: Humor and art are not always allies, especially when it comes to photographs of dogs. But William Wegman's new color pictures at Pace/ MacGill Gallery (11 East 57th Street, through Jan. 16) manage to make us laugh and think at the same time. In ''Hatched,'' for example, we see the artist's new pet Weimaraner, Fay Ray, wrapped in red-faced aluminum foil, looking somewhat like a Christmas gift and somewhat like a half-opened bonbon. In other large-format Polaroids we see Fay Ray wearing sneakers, roller skates, false eyelashes and a wig.

title: GOING SOUTH, BUT NOT FOR A STATUS TAN
description: We will board a jammed plane bound for the South this winter. All 10 of us will go, and in time we hope there will be additions.

title: AFTER HOWARD BEACH: A NEW MILITANCY?
description: THE conviction last week of three white teen-agers for manslaughter, nearly a year to the day after they chased a black man to his death in Howard Beach, Queens, seemed to relieve, for a moment, an extended period of racial tension in New York City. There were cries of ''murderers'' from some people in the courtroom, but the verdicts were widely regarded as fair. Certainly that was the view of Cedric Sandiford, who was one of the victims, and a wide range of politicians and civic leaders, white and black.

title: Q And A
description: City Property Auctions

title: GRAND ENTRANCES FOR A GRAND ROOM
description: IF someone was going to spend $20 million to redo the Rainbow Room, New York's tastiest Art Deco confection, it seemed a safe bet that the city's well-dressed women would go to some lenghts to make a grand entrance in that sparkling setting. And so they did.

title: Stalemate in Bangladesh Drains the Economy
description: Six weeks after the political opposition opened a campaign of protests to force the resignation of President H. M. Ershad, there is no sign that the Government and its opposition will come to a settlement soon.

title: THE SECRET INGREDIENT IN HOME MOVIES
description: THE party to celebrate Shirlee and Sy Sloyer's 40th wedding anniversary in Lawrence recently showed me by good example what I had been doing wrong in my home movies all these years.

title: WEDTECH'S LEGACY: TIGHTER RULES ON MINORITY CONTRACTS
description: AS two associates of Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d and another man were indicted last week on charges involving fraud and influence peddling, Congress moved to legislate a cure for the kinds of improper activities that led to what has become known as the Wedtech affair.

title: ARMY INCREASING USE OF FAKE TANKS
description: The Army, returning to an age-old strategy used extensively by the Soviet military, is increasing its use of decoys and fake targets in hopes of outsmarting an enemy's modern weapons.

title: Finding the Right Financial Planner
description: WHEN the holiday spending spree is over, many people resolve to put their personal finances in order. But it is easy to be overwhelmed by the prospect, and avoid the task. Some people turn to friends and relatives for advice; others to books, magazines and newspapers. Yet another source of help is professional financial advisers, including brokers and financial planners.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK;
Adams, Mass.: A Hopeful Sign In a Mill Town
description: LEAD: AFTER the textile manufacturing operation at the Berkshire Mill closed in the 1950's, the building became a symbol of hard times for this community in northwest Massachusetts.

title: PARIS-DAKAR A GRUELING RALLY
description: Malcolm Smith, who is 46 years old, will be celebrating the New Year with a little trip to France and North Africa.

title: WARNINGS SOUGHT ON LIQUOR BOTTLES
description: Massachusetts lawmakers are considering a bill that would require health warnings on every bottle of beer, wine and liquor sold.

title: FRESHMAN IS RATED WITH CHERYL MILLER
description: Terri Mann, Western Kentucky's freshman center on the women's basketball team, invites comparisons to Cheryl Miller. She is also from Southern California, and she produced the same type of eye-opening statistics in high school as did Miller, the former Southern Cal all-American who led the women's Olympic team to a gold medal in 1984.

title: ROMANCE, THE SAVING REMNANT
description: THE NATURE OF LOVE Volume Three: The Modern World. By Irving Singer. 473 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $24.95.

title: MIAMI'S MIRA TO PRACTICE SEPARATELY
description: George Mira Jr., a linebacker suspended after failing to pass a drug test administered by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, will not practice with Miami for its Orange Bowl game against Oklahoma next Friday night, despite a court ruling that permits him to do so, Coach Jimmy Johnson said today.

title: Israel's Tough Choice
description: LEAD: The violent disturbances among Palestinians in the territories occupied by Israel and among Israeli Arabs are not surprising. What is astonishing is the blindness of American policy and the inability of Israeli politicians to draw sensible conclusions from stark realities that are only likely to get worse.

title: GLASS ARTIST, 87, USES SELF-DESIGNED KILN
description: LEAD: THE five glass enamel panels on display in the Craft Gallery of the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers are the work of Maurice Heaton, an 87-year-old artist who lives in Valley Cottage in Rockland County.

title: BEST AND THE BRIGHTEST OF THE SOUNDS OF THE COUNTY
description: AS we get ready for another round of Auld Lang Syne, the time seems right to think back upon some of the more important musical happenings of 1987. Perhaps we could paraphrase the category system used by so many award-winning ceremonies and cite the:

title: Dervishes
description: To the Editor: I am writing about an oversight in the article entitled ''A Flourishing of Whirling Dervishes'' (Travel, Dec. 6). My translation of a quatrain by Rumi appeared without crediting the book in which it was originally published and without mentioning my name. The translation first appeared in the book entitled ''Mevlana Celaleddin Rumi and the Whirling Dervishes'' by Talat Sait Halman and Metin And (published in Istanbul in 1983 by Dost). TALAT SAIT HALMAN New York, N.Y.

title: Moscow Assails U.S. Output Of Binary Chemical Weapons
description: Moscow angrily denounced Washington today for starting production of binary chemical weapons and hinted it might follow suit.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: Gericault: Men and Wild Horses Written and produced by Leslie Megahey. Home Vision. 60 minutes. $39.95. Gericault had the closest thing in the early 19th century to a cult of personality. A dark and mysterious man who had a child with his uncle's wife and who once painted a series of bodiless heads (supplied by the industrious Parisian guillotine), he was ''avant garde'' in the salons where that word hadn't yet been coined.

title: Pop for Grown-Ups Gathers Momentum
description: EVEN IN THE BEST OF artistic climates, the majority of pop music has always been conceived as disposable light commercial entertainment. And in 1987 that climate tended to be more frivolous than usual. From the formulaic metal bombast of Whitesnake to the teen-age triflings of Tiffany, the year offered more than its share of pure fluff. But ever since ''We Are the World,'' the all-star U.S.A. for Africa charity single and album two and a half years ago that launched a rash of charitable pop causes, there has been a movement within pop's higher artistic echelons to make music that addresses humane concerns.

title: Miami Room Offers a View Of Crime Past
description: The property room of the Miami Police Department has become a kind of museum reflecting the problems of South Florida: overcrowded, understaffed, besieged by drugs, guns and cash, and strangled in red tape.

title: Prisons Make People Secure In Iona, Mich.
description: On one side of Wall Street are rambling old homes and shade trees. On the other side is The Wall.

title: Correspondent's Choice; FOLLOWING THE SUN
description: The time for getting away from it all -the damp and chill of the northern winter - has arrived. In the following articles, 11 foreign correspondents of The New York Times describe their favorite out-of-the-way refuges of sun, sand and sea. The choices range from the sites of ancient ruins along the Nile to New Caledonia, a Gallicized group of islands in the South Pacific. BALI

title: Bull Market for Movies and Screens
description: THE MOST IMPORTANT MOVIE news this year wasn't movies but business. More movies than ever went into release this year than at any time in recent memory. Distributors of video cassettes became an important source of production money. Box offices boomed, but often with movies that were interchangeable (''Robocop,'' ''Stakeout,'' ''Lethal Weapon,'' ''Extreme Prejudice''). Theater chains were acquiring other theater chains so fast, so heedlessly, that it seemed possible one of them might accidentally acquire itself.

title: STUDENTS HOLD FUND-RAISERS TO GIVE TO THE NEEDIEST CASES
description: In three days of fund-raising activities, which included a bake sale, a dance and contributions of lunch money and allowances, students at the O. Henry School in Manhattan collected $661.14 for The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: NEW STATE LAW ON LICENSING FISHERMEN STIRS DEBATE
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND, which contains most of the state's fishing industry, is expected to be most directly affected by a new state law requiring that all fishermen be licensed beginning Jan. 1.

title: Miss McLaughlin Engaged to Wed Paul J. Kennedy
description: The engagement of Anne Colleen McLaughlin to Paul Joseph Kennedy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. McLaughlin of Rosemont, Pa., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kennedy of Haverford, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Body and Mind;
CHILDBEARING AND AGE
description: LEAD: I REALIZED NOT LONG ago that a dozen or so of the women I know, most of them in their late 30's - old friends, peers, colleagues - were spending more time than they'd like in infertility clinics. I found that this fact somehow added to my aches and pains, that it imposed on me a kind of gnawing unease, adding to my heightened sense of age, as I pass 40.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS ADVANCE ON 2 FRONTS
description: THE Nicaraguan rebels last week launched what appeared to be the largest and most successful military operation of their war against the Sandinista Government.

title: When the World's Growth Slows
description: WORLD economic growth has been shrinking and shrinking, but so gradually - and so inexorably - that economists have grown accustomed to the numbers. Yet a stark tale emerges when those numbers are added together year after year and their impact is examined.

title:
HOME VIDEO;
ART
description: LEAD: The Hague School: Touched by Nature Home Vision. 45 minutes. $39.95. The painters of the Hague School, a Dutch offshoot of the late-19th-century Barbizon School in France, are among the poets of art, as distinct from the novelists. They are not much discussed, but their intimate, realistic landscapes, bathed in the soft gray light of

title: JERSEY CONDOMINIUMS FULFILL DREAMS OF SECURITY
description: The carpenter building a wall of what is to be a new apartment was helping to fulfill a dream for Julia and Sonia Abrew.

title: THE DOLLAR'S DROP
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Testing of Students Raises Growing Debate
description: Increased Federal testing of what American schoolchildren have learned is the subject of a debate in Congress and among educators and the outcome will affect American education for decades.

title: Art of Cooking Is Now Getting Taste of Science
description: LEAD: SCIENTISTS at Rutgers University have some ambitious plans to make cooking more of a science than an art, but right now just finding space to work takes up some of their time.

title: A New Breed Challenges the Illusion of Realism
description: IS IT TOO MUCH OF A GOOD THING, OR a sign of a new mood? In either case, the acknowledged modern masters of photography failed to command the lion's share of attention in terms of 1987's major exhibitions. Some have been overexposed to the point that their images have begun to pale. This might explain the generally lukewarm response to the Edward Weston centennial exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and to the International Center of Photography's show, ''Andre Kertesz: Diary of Light.'' Taking their place in the spotlight is a generation of living photographer-artists whose careers have yet to be neatly sorted out.

title: Hancock, Me.: 2 Bald Eagles Scuttle Homes
description: EMERY PURSLOW has a recurring thought: if only he'd known about those eagle's nests.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SPANGLE. By Gary Jennings. (Atheneum, $21.95.) This third novel by the amazing Gary Jennings, who has already chronicled the Spanish conquest of Mexico (''Aztec'') and the exploits of Marco Polo (''The Journeyer''), is another whopper. Its subject is circus life around 1870, namely, that of Florian's Flourishing Florilegium of Wonders, a sorry mud show when we first meet it in Virginia.

title: Going Out in Action
description: WHEN Gary Fencik announced earlier that this would be his final season of professional football, it appeared that the Chicago Bears' 33-year-old safety, a Yale graduate, would be closing an outstanding 12-year career in an unfamilair manner: riding the bench. But Coach Mike Ditka changed the situation when he announced that, in an effort to shake up the 10-4 Bears, who have lost their last two games, there would be seven new starters for the team's regular-season finale today against the Los Angeles Raiders. One would be Fencik, replacing Todd Bell. ''It's an opportunity to go out precisely in the style you wish to,'' said Fencik. ''It's like riding a bike. I just hope my body is with my mind.''

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE PARENT BUSINESS;
ADVICE UNDER A CORPORATE BANNER
description: LEAD: IN their pursuit of that assiduous consumer, the parent, manufacturers of diapers, baby food and other child-related products are seeking to determine the kinds of information that parents want to hear and then tailoring their public-relations programs to match.

title: Diversity Was Partnered by New Talent
description: IT WAS A GRAB BAG OF A YEAR IN dance. Anything goes and anything went. In general, there was no single trend comparable to the kind that had dominated recent seasons; instead, one phenomenon balanced out another.

title: Hazard Seen for New York From Outdated Incinerators
description: Outmoded incinerators in 2,500 New York City apartment buildings pose a serious health risk - particularly in Manhattan where they are surrounded by new, taller buildings - and should be shut down, according to a petition to be sent today to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency by a group of scientists, legislators and environmental organizations.

title: 2 Blacks Chased and Beaten By Whites on Brooklyn Street
description: Two black men were set upon and beaten by a group of whites in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn Friday night, in what authorities said was a racial attack, and the police have arrested a white teen-ager in connection with the incident.

title: Heeding Plato, Greek-Americans Aid In Effort to Raise Money for Dukakis
description: In a plea mailed to Greek-Americans for contributions to his Presidential campaign, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts asked that they ''consider the words of Plato'' to Greeks reluctant to participate in the political process:

title: In the Catskills: Lakeside Surprise
description: The developers of Lake Joseph Estates had an ideal opportunity to build a vacation home community, but it did not work out that way. All of 250-acre lake was theirs, as well as over 1,000 acres of forest surrounding it. The only previous activity this Catskill Mountain retreat five miles south of Monticello, N.Y., on Route 42 saw was a Catholic youth camp, closed years ago. Still, of the 28 homes completed on the site - some before O & H Construction and Rausman Associates, took over the project in September - all have been sold as first homes, according to Ben Yamen, an O & H executive. ''It was a pleasant surprise,'' he said.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: WHAT WERE THE YEAR'S BEST SPORTS STORIES?
description: Who can ever forget Terry Pendleton's ninth-inning home run that saved the St. Louis Cardinals from defeat at the hands of the New York Mets and propelled them to the N.L. pennant? The Mets could never recover from it. I still do not know if I recovered from it, either. HOWARD SHAPIRO Brooklyn

title: Marie Silverman Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Syd Silverman of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Saxon Silverman, to Peter Robert Marich, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vladislav Marich of Oak Park, Ill. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transmission error, an article about child abuse in the New Jersey Weekly last week gave the wrong first name of the chairman of the sociology department at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. He is Dr. Allan V. Horwitz.

title: MAO'S WIDOW FREE, MAGAZINE REPORTS
description: Jiang Qing, the widow of Mao Zedong, has been released from prison and is living in poor health outside Beijing, according to a Hong Kong magazine.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
A FASCINATING NEW MEDAL FOR COLLECTORS
description: LEAD: SHERLOCK Holmes, one of the world's most famous fictional characters, is the subject of an imaginative new medal marking the centennial of his literary birth. The medal was designed by the noted medallic artist, Marika Somogyi, and is being offered in gold and silver.

title: Shoot-out at the Sandbox: the Boyhood Urge to Bear Arms
description: MY first clue to my son Christopher's penchant for weaponry came the afternoon I picked him up at prercohl. . I Intneded w w faced with a whirlpool of 4-year olds who had gathered around my son. Christopher had just improvised a gun out of two tongue depressors.

title: Prospects
description: A Corker for Champagne

title: SOCIETY'S WOES, SCHOOL'S TOPICS
description: THE headline said, ''AIDS Training in Kindergarten.'' Was I reading correctly? Surely they meant ''aides.''

title: In 1987, the Pleasures Were Many
description: WITH the new year just before us, it seems appropriate to reminisce about the pleasures of dining out in Connecticut in 1987. There were many, and, in fact, more Excellent-rated restaurants than we remembered: four.

title: The Ball's in Bradley's Court
description: IF Bill Bradley were to declare his candidacy for the Presidency, he would sweep through the 1988 Democratic primaries and convention, win a landslide victory in November and on Jan. 20, 1989, become the next man to live in the White House.

title: On the Road: Odyssey of a Christmas Present
description: Reese Badman's Christmas present from his grandfather had to find its own way to Pennsylvania from California.

title: North Africa Keeps an Eye on Islam's Storms
description: When officials here and in other North African countries confront problems that seem to be getting worse, they keep an eye on the volatile issue of Islamic fundamentalism.

title: Miss Wilkins Plans to Wed
description: The engagement of Anna Sharon Wilkins to Thomas Handasyd Perkins Henderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Welles Henderson of Philadelphia and Manchester, Mass., has been announced by Nancy Schrader Wilkins of Truckee, Calif., and Dr. Edmund Earl Wilkins Jr. of Dalhousie, New Brunswick, parents of the bride-to-be. An April wedding is planned. Miss Wilkins, who graduated from Mills College, is a senior technical manager for the Oracle Corporation in Belmont, Calif., a software computer concern. Her mother teaches at the Truckee Elementary School. Her father practices family medicine in Dalhousie.

title: Les Paul: No Stopping the Guitarist
description: LEAD: ''PLAY 'How High the Moon,' '' one member of the audience called out.

title: The Year DAT Was Put on Hold
description: THE PASSING YEAR, AS concerns audio, was marked by a non-event. DAT didn't happen. As most audio fans know, DAT stands for Digital Audio Tape. It is a system of recording and playback that brings digital techniques to tape cassettes and makes them sound just as good as CD's. Listeners accustomed to the latter's sonic excellence had long been hoping for cassettes to catch up and were eagerly expecting DAT's American debut. After all, DAT already had a head start in Japan and was more recently launched in Europe, so it seemed reasonable to expect that its benefits would be extended to this country.

title: HIGHWAYS CAN BE HAZARDOUS TO DEER
description: MOTOR vehicles kill more deer in New York state each year than do hunters in Vermont, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Connecticut and Rhode Island combined, the comparative totals being 30,000 and 28,500.

title: Pamela Eve Slavin To Marry in May
description: Justice and Mrs. Joseph B. Slavin of Brooklyn and Long Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Eve Slavin, to Seth Nathan Barnett, the son of Selma Barnett of Delray, Fla., and the late Raymond Barnett. A May wedding is planned.

title: Market Reverses and Tax Reform Can't Deter American Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Mandate Is to Protect Consumers
description: WHO says that American fiction is dead? Representative James J. Florio's recent Opinion Page discourse on the Consumer Product Safety Commission indicates otherwise, and, while I hate to throw cold water on such a good story, a few misconceptions should be cleared up.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 13 about Morelia, Mexico, described Guadalajara-to-Morelia air service incorrectly. There are no regular flights from Guadalajara, but there are flights from Mexico City to Morelia.

title: For the Pursuit of a More Balanced Life
description: WHILE riding down in an elevator, an old friend of the family and I were commenting on the break-up of a young marriage: a cousin and his wife who had never presented any outward signs of serious distress prior to announcing their intention to dissolve their once cherished union.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: FIGHTING FOR TONY. By Mary Callahan. (Fireside/ Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) This brief, engrossing book is Mary Callahan's coming-of-age story. Raised in a Chicago suburb, she trains as a pulmonary nurse and moves to New Mexico, where she hopes to meet the man of her dreams and stock a house with children.

title: NEW WINDOWS ARE OPEN
description: DID IT GO TOO FAST? DID PICTURES JOIN, voices mingle and stories swoosh round in a blender? Why, of course; they had to. There was no other way. Ollie North gave way to Presidential candidates, who disappeared in the Persian Gulf, which evaporated when the stock market tumbled. Red neckties - Washington correspondents now favor solid scarlet - remained the only constant. The year may have begun with mournful cries about declining budgets and the withering of network news, but, in retrospect, it's hard to think of much that television missed.

title: 2 D.E.P. Aides Reply To Article on Radon
description: We are compelled to rebut the Oct. 18 Opinion Page article by Leonard A. Cole entitled, ''Bad Advice About Problems of Radon.'' (Mr. Cole is a political scientist at Rutgers-Newark, where he teaches in the program on science, technology and society.) Mr. Cole's timing was indeed unfortunate, as it occurred coincident to the latest Eagleton Institute poll, which once again shows that the residents of New Jersey are largely unconcerned about the risk posed by radon gas.

title: CRACKS ARE VISIBLE IN ALBANY'S 'EGG'
description: A power struggle at the Empire State Institute for the Performing Arts in Albany has pitted Patricia Snyder, the executive director of the organization, against Barnabas McHenry, chairman of the New York State corporation that finances the repertory season of drama at the institute. Recent developments have also brought Actors' Equity, citizens' groups and labor unions into the picture.

title: Lisa Lockwood Plans To Wed John Winston
description: Lisa Joy Lockwood and John B. Winston, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Winston of Havertown, Pa., plan to marry in March, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Lockwood of North Woodmere, L.I., have announced.

title: 3 Car Bombs Kill One and Wound 40 in Pakistan
description: Three car bombs exploded in two downtown shopping areas today, killing one person and wounding 40 people, the authorities said.

title: New Laws for the New Year
description: LEAD: FIFTEEN new state laws go into effect Jan.1, and they will, among other things, impose tighter controls over absentee ballots, allow mail-in voter registration and increase day-care subsidies.

title: GIANTS, JETS END DISMAL SEASON
description: Make this one for the Staggering Rights. Or the Good Riddance Game. Or the Wait-Till-Next-Year Affair.

title: Correspondent's Choice; FOLLOWING THE SUN
description: The time for getting away from it all -the damp and chill of the northern winter - has arrived. In the following articles, 11 foreign correspondents of The New York Times describe their favorite out-of-the-way refuges of sun, sand and sea. The choices range from the sites of ancient ruins along the Nile to New Caledonia, a Gallicized group of islands in the South Pacific. INDIA

title: Rebecca Marshall Boyd, Art Director, Is Engaged
description: Rebecca Marshall Boyd, an art director at Jobson Publishing in New York, and Robert Van Antwerp Benner Jr., an associate at the First Boston Corporation in New York, plan to be married Feb. 13.

title: Ex-California Governor to Seek Office Again
description: Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has been enjoying life outside politics for the last five years, but he says he plans to run for office again after the 1988 elections.

title: A HOLIDAY PUZZLE
description: TOP-RANKED chess players have often played bridge as a recreation, perhaps with more enthusiasm than skill. When in 1941 Samuel Reshevsky beat back a challenge for the United States Chess Championship by the late Al Horowitz, long the chess columnist for this newspaper, the standard of play was not as high as might have been expected. This was ascribed in some quarters to both contestants having played bridge all night, between chess games.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE HOUSE NEXT DOOR TO AFRICA. By Denis Hirson. (Carcanet, $14.95.) The publisher calls it an autobiographical novel, but this 99-page book about a South African boyhood is closer in form and feeling to a cycle of lyric poems or a film by Jean-Luc Godard. Denis Hirson, an auteur of an author, has created a stylized structure of short paragraphs that function like camera shots, reproducing the perspective of the child narrator, who is as likely to focus on small gestures and objects as he is to pan the scene of the main action.

title: Medal Loses Luster
description: IN a gesture of frustration as well as pride, Giovanni Evangelisti of Italy said yesterday that, because of doubts cast upon his performance, he was renouncing the bronze medal he won in the long jump at the world track and field championships in Rome last summer.

title: KEAN'S STAR RISING IN G.O.P.
description: SOME of Governor Kean's aides gave their boss a sweatshirt for Christmas with his picture on a map of the United States captioned ''Tom Kean's '86-'87 North American Tour.'' Like a memento of a rock star's itinerary, the back of the shirt lists the 36 cities the New Jersey Republican has visited since his landslide re-election victory in 1985.

title: Manson Rumor Is Checked In Fromme's Prison Escape
description: Prison officials were trying to find out today why Lynette (Squeaky) Fromme fled the Federal Correctional Institution for Women on Wednesday after she had rejected parole hearings and quietly served 12 years of her life sentence for trying to kill President Ford.

title: GRACE CHURCH SEEKS A NEW VISTA
description: THE Grace Episcopal Church has flourished - at least, most of the time - on a site at Church and Main Streets in White Plains, where it was built during the Civil War, when White Plains had only 1,500 residents.

title: Citing Crime, Koch Seeks a Shift in Hauling
description: Mayor Koch is seeking ways to break what he says is organized crime's 30-year hold on much of New York City's commercial hauling industry.

title: OF RELIGION AND FREEDOM
description: In answer to Joan Silverman's recent Opinion Page article, ''States' Role in Religious Pluralism,'' I ask, ''Are Jews really made so uncomfortable by Christmas?''

title: Lynn M. Villency Engaged to Marry Stephen A. Cohen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Villency of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Marie Villency, to Stephen Abraham Cohen, the son of Muriel Novack of Stamford, Conn., and the late Robert Cohen. A February wedding is planned.

title: 1987: A YEAR OF 'CITY' PROBLEMS ON L.I.
description: MODERN-DAY Long Island - the Long Island of burgeoning housing developments, of a rapidly expanding economy, of growing urban ills - did not enter its middle age peacefully.

title: TAX SHELTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE INTERDISCIPLINARY ART OF MAKING A PIPE ORGAN
description: To Gerd Klais, an organ builder, his ancient craft is a multidiscipline test of mastery.

title: Pravda Warns of Offenses by New Political Clubs
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda warned today that some of the unofficial political clubs spreading through the country were violating the law by promoting anti-Soviet views.

title: Newark Bishop Encounters Stormy Days
description: Over the centuries, Christian clerics have offered their blessings to everything from the hounds before the hunt to battleships going off to war. Why then should they withhold their blessing from a homosexual couple who have decided to lead a loving, monogamous relationship?

title: Panel Finds New York Schools Poorly Maintained
description: Almost one-quarter of the public schools in New York City have inadequate lighting and more than a quarter need major roof repairs, according to a report released yesterday by the Board of Education's Task Force on Capital Financing and Construction.

title: SAUDI KING ACCUSES IRAN OF HAMPERING FIGHT WITH ISRAEL
description: Saudi Arabia accused Iran today of seeking to impose alien ideologies on fellow Moslem nations in the Arab world to the detriment of the Arab campaign against Israel.

title: Italy's Heroin Addicts Face New Challenge: AIDS
description: For 15 years the Rev. Gino Rigoldi has been trying to convince young heroin addicts that they can change their lives, a task now made considerably more difficult by the AIDS epidemic.

title: Jets Will Stick With Walton
description: The Jets' future cleared a little and clouded a little today as they ended the season with a loss to the Giants, their fourth straight.

title: Diana Melamid Marries Stephen B. Henderson
description: Diana Melamid and Stephen Bruce Henderson were married yesterday at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y., by Arthur E. Sullivan, the village justice of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Gephardt Made Trade A Test for Candidates
description: Early this year, as record trade deficits fueled the drive for trade protectionism in Congress, the name of Representative Richard A. Gephardt became almost synonymous with the issue. His proposal that would require retaliation against Japan and other countries that have trade surpluses with the United States became known as the Gephardt Amendment. The most controversial part of the trade bill pending in the House, the amendment put the Missouri Democrat at the center of an intense rivalry among lawmakers, businesses and labor leaders, not to mention the Presidential aspirants.

title: Palestinian Cause Turns to Fury As It Passes From Fathers to Sons
description: Behind the Palestinian riots of the last few weeks is a story about fathers and sons -Palestinian fathers and the sons over whom they may have lost control.

title: American Sailor Dies in Barcelona After U.S.O. Blast That Hurt 10
description: An American sailor died today from wounds received Saturday in a bomb attack on a U.S.O. club, the fourth against American targets in Barcelona this year. Rival Catalan separatist groups took responsibility for the bombing, in which nine other sailors were wounded.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY Holiday sales disappointed retailers across the nation. Although results averaged about 3 percent more than last year, most merchants suffered declines in real terms. A telephone survey indicated that sales varied among types of stores, with those catering to the affluent showing the biggest rises. Retailers serving middle-income consumers showed slight gains or declines. [ Page A1. ] The F.D.I.C. could record its first annual loss in 54 years, its chairman, L. William Seidman, said. The cost of handling almost 200 bank failures in 1987 could mean a loss of $200 million to $300 million for the deposit insurance agency. [ D1. ] The dollar fell to new lows in Tokyo, reaching 123.30 yen. [ D2. ] MARKETS The S.E.C. is reviewing an American Stock Exchange proposal that would make it easier for U.S. investors to trade foreign securities not registered in the U.S. [ Page D1. ] COMPANIES Prime Computer is offering to buy Computervision. The $13.50-a-share cash offer, worth $400 million, is being made to shareholders in advertisements today. [ D1. ] Banks and property-and-casualty insurers are angry about an accounting change. Under the rule, companies that show liabilities on their balance sheets for so-called deferred taxes will have to adjust those liabilities when tax rates change. [ D4. ] INTERNATIONAL A pall hangs over Latin America's relationship with creditors as economic crises occur simultaneously in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina. Government officials are finding they must pay a higher political price for acceding to the banks' demands. [ D8. ] Guinea's socialist system is being dismantled by technocrats, and a free-enterprise economy is springing up. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Sweeping changes in pension rules will significantly affect the payments companies must make and the guidelines under which employers must operate. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Sales of mutual funds are expected to suffer next year. The October stock collapse and the Presidential election are likely to make investors cautious. Market Place. [ D4. ] Credit market participants are still guessing about the likely effects on consumer spending, the economy and interest rates. But they expect answers about consumer behavior will be clearer early next year. Credit Markets. [ D5. ]

title: The Only Game in Town
description: The team bus is a crowded van. The pre-game meal takes place at McDonald's. The coach does not receive a paycheck. And the cheerleaders, locker room and big crowds do not exist. Welcome to the world of junior varsity college basketball.

title: Flashy Life as Fugitive Led Agents to Ex-Senator
description: After almost two years as one of the Federal authorities' most wanted fugitives, former New Jersey State Senator David J. Friedland was snared last week by his own success as an operator of a chain of scuba diving shops on an island in the Indian Ocean, a Federal marshal said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When they arrested all these people last week, they said they were just arresting the 'organizers.' One thousand organizers? In 10 years they will just have to put a wall up around the whole West Bank and Gaza Strip to arrest all of the organizers.'' - Ibrahim Karaeen, a Palestinian in East Jerusalem. [ A14:6. ]

title: A Speech For Mr. X
description: My fellow Americans: As the new year is about to begin, I'm announcing my candidacy for President of the United States because I don't think any of the 13 people already running have offered you the kind of hope and vision you're looking for. (Alternate opening: After long months of campaigning for President, I'm starting over with the new year, because I've learned the hard way that neither I nor the other 12 candidates have offered you the kind of hope and vision you're looking for.) The first and most important part of my new platform is that I aim to put Americans to work at useful jobs. Official unemployment stands at just below 6 percent of the work force today, but that doesn't include those who've never had jobs and those who've lost jobs and have been discouraged from looking for another. It doesn't tell you how many millions of Americans who lost high-paying industrial jobs owing to plant failures and cutbacks have found new jobs only in the service sector - paying half or less of what they used to make. Or how many wives have had to take jobs to supplement their husband's income.

title: Where Does Mario Cuomo Lead?
description: As the Democratic candidates plod on to their first event before real voters in Iowa, the public is finally turning its attention from personalities to policies. Even taking the leading non-candidate at his word that he's not running, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York will open himself to such attention in a few days when he delivers his 1988 State of the State address.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; 1987 and Women
description: In a yearend review, the National Organization for Women went beyond well-publicized episodes to recall events that may have escaped public notice. The review, which was compiled by the group's Legal Defense and Education Fund, considered some of the events as progress, others as reverses.

title: TV Boom in Europe Is Aiding Hollywood
description: It offends the guardians of French culture, is considered inferior to the best offerings of the British Broadcasting Corporation and sometimes translates awkwardly into German. But American television programming is being snapped up at a rapidly increasing rate in Europe as a host of new television networks and stations take to the air from Spain to Finland.

title: Summer Tale Gets An Easy Victory
description: Summer Tale prompted pace-setting Mugatea to the stretch, then took the lead and raced to an easy 7 1/2-length victory yesterday in the $70,900 Alex M. Robb Stakes for New Yorkbred 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Nordiques 5, Whalers 3: Michel Goulet scored three goals and had an assist yesterday as Quebec (16-16-2) completed a weekend sweep of Hartford (13-16-6). It was Goulet's second hat trick of the season. Peter Stastny, who had scored once and assisted on two goals in Quebec's 4-2 victory in Hartford on Saturday night, repeated that performance yesterday in Quebec.

title: At Marist, Making Smits the Center of Attention Is Top Goal
description: Six years ago, a lanky, 6-foot-10-inch Dutch youth named Rik Smits laid his enormous fingers on a basketball for the first time.

title: Ouster by Allegis Board Ended Dream for Ferris
description: For Richard J. Ferris, the former chairman and chief executive of the Allegis Corporation, 1987 will not be a year of fond memories.

title: 25 Reported Killed in Sri Lanka Clash
description: Twenty-five people or more were believed to have been killed today after ethnic Tamil rebels shot and killed a policeman and then battled policemen and Indian soldiers in a gunfight at a crowded market, witnesses said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1987
description: International A2-14

title: Giants End Season By Beating Jets, 20-7
description: The awful season ended today on the upside for the Giants and with another disappointment for the Jets. The Giants played well on offense and especially well on defense, and won the battle between the metropolitan area's two professional football teams, 20-7.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: At Sea With the Navy
description: Chief Petty Officer Kenneth A. Young sat at a table in the ward room of the United States Navy's helicopter landing ship Okinawa, the common area where the ship's senior enlisted men gather to smoke, drink coffee, snack, watch movies, trade stories and write letters.

title: Social Security Tax Rates Rise at Least 5% Friday
description: The Social Security payroll tax rate is going up on New Year's Day for the 13th time in the last 25 years, part of the price for the 1983 bailout of the retirement program.

title: Metro Datelines; Suspect Assaults Officers With Bottle
description: EAST NEW YORK

title: Who's Really to Blame for Dull Textbooks?; Publishers at Fault
description: To the Editor:

title: Compaq's Quiet Canion Profitably Defied I.B.M.
description: Not long ago, Joseph R. Canion recalls, every time the International Business Machines Corporation brought out a new personal computer, reporters, colleagues, even friends ''all wanted to know when we were going to board up the windows at Compaq and go away.''

title: Hess Continuity on the Spot
description: FOR several minutes after the Giants' 20-7 victory, Joe Walton stood in a corner of the Jets' locker room, providing predictable answers to predictable questions. But when the Jets' coach spoke of how ''there will be a 1988,'' somebody asked him if Jim Kensil, the Jets' president, had assured him that he would return next season. ''Mr. Hess has,'' Walton said. For better or for worse, Leon Hess, the oil baron who owns the Jets, has decided that the roster, not the coach, is the reason for another December demise. That philosophy might put Mike Hickey, the personnel director who supervises the Jet drafts, in jeopardy. But in the decade since Hess took personal command of the franchise, he has been committed to continuity of command.

title: Spend Now, Pay Later Is Poor Plan for a City
description: To the Editor:

title: Singapore Curbs Asia News Weekly
description: The Government of Singapore this weekend restricted the circulation of one of Asia's most influential publications, the weekly Far Eastern Economic Review.

title: Over-the-Counter Market Is Improving Its Own Operations
description: To the Editor:

title: Poland's Font of Catholic Scholarship
description: Lenin probably never wanted them to found a Catholic university.

title: Chemical Cars Derail And Water Is Checked
description: A chemical-laden freight train derailed Saturday near this east Texas city and burned through the night, causing Federal and state environmental officials to monitor water in the area today for possible contamination.

title: Metro Matters; A Snail's Pace: Public Projects And Bureaucracy
description: For months, the Y-shaped concrete pillars flanking the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in lower Manhattan resembled a latter-day Stonehenge, akin to the original monoliths in their apparent futility but distinguished by their spray-painted graffiti.

title: Car Racing Crash Kills One and Injures Four on Staten Island Street
description: One man was killed and four people were injured on Staten Island early yesterday morning when a car racing down Hylan Boulevard spun out of control and burst into flames, the police said.

title: Medicine Man Bill Reimbursed
description: An agency that helps crime victims paid $4,140 for a healing ceremony performed by a Navajo medicine man after physicians said they could not remove a bullet from the chest of a wounded Indian.

title: Portuguese Guides Strike
description: More than 2,000 tour guides and interpreters staged a 24-hour strike in Portugal today, complaining that tour operators were illegally employing foreign guides who were not qualified. About 200 strikers blocked a road leading to Faro Airport on the Algarve coast for 30 minutes.

title: In a Museum, a Trace of Tenochtitlan
description: A glittering new museum overlooking ruins of the Aztecs' Great Temple displays treasures found in the 14th-century ceremonial center that now is the heart of downtown.

title: Guinea Booms as Markets Replace Marxism
description: For years, Ibrahima Camara dreamed of opening a carpentry workshop to make wooden chairs to sell to his neighbors. Such a project, however, was prohibited by what was known as the Peoples Revolutionary Republic of Guinea, which restricted chair production to a state-owned furniture factory.

title: Who's Really to Blame for Dull Textbooks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco Plan For Assets
description: Texaco Inc. has no plans to sell its Canadian unit, Texaco Canada Inc., or its interest in the Caltex Petroleum Corporation, James W. Kinnear, its president and chief executive, said on a television program today. In an interview on ''Business

title: U.S. 'Father Image' Is Blamed For Low Filipino Self-Esteem
description: One of the main tasks of the Philippines, according to the new Foreign Secretary, Raul Manglapus, is to deal with ''the American father image.''

title: Washington Talk: The Hotel Trade; He Who Started the Luxury Market
description: Luxury hotels, with their hot-towel racks, monogrammed robes and perfumed soaps, have proliferated in the capital over the last 10 years, to the point that the market is engaged in a trade war of sorts.

title: Amex Seeks New Network
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is reviewing a proposal from the American Stock Exchange that would make it easier for sophisticated investors in the United States to trade securities issued by foreign corporations that do not register with the commission.

title: HANOI ARMY TOLD OF CAMBODIA PERIL
description: A Vietnamese military officer writing in an army journal has acknowledged that Hanoi's soldiers are waging ''fierce and complicated'' psychological battles in Cambodia.

title: Orangemen Set Sights on More Than Big East Title
description: IT may be just an illusion, but Rony Seikaly says that Coach Jim Boeheim is more relaxed as Syracuse enters the 1987-88 Big East Conference season.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Don Mattingly set a major-league record with six grand slams this past season. How many did the Yankees hit altogether, and what team holds the mark for bases-filled home runs in a season?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Dec. 27, 1987: WEDNESDAY Wash DC Gas Lt THURSDAY Cascade Nat Gas

title: Light Schedule Of Bond Sales
description: In a holiday-shortened week, when activity is normally reduced by the absence of many traders and investors, little new financing is expected in the credit markets.

title: TV Review; 'Roman Holiday' Remake and Georg Solti Tribute
description: TELEVISION has a talent for opening itself up to ridicule, and nowhere is this more apparent than in tampering with movie classics.

title: Walking: 'Ever So Refreshing,' and Good Exercise
description: IT was nearly 4 P.M. on a damp, overcast winter day when Keith Redrup stopped his group of walkers on a tree-lined country lane here and announced dramatically that they had reached a ''point of no return.'' They could either walk straight to their cars, about two miles away, and bring their Sunday afternoon jaunt to a close after a respectable six-mile distance, or they could add an extra two miles and stop at a nearby farm where the farmer's wife was waiting to serve tea with scones, cream and jam.

title: Police Seek Witnesses to Murder Of Hasidic Jew in Borough Park
description: The murder of a Hasidic Jew in a ferocious knife attack in Brooklyn remained a mystery yesterday as detectives sought witnesses and a motive while neighborhood residents held a demonstration and voiced fears that the killing was anti-Semitic.

title: Critic of Academe Fears Catch-22 in His Success
description: Russell Jacoby, author of ''The Last Intellectuals,'' ought to be a happy man, yet disappointed seems to describe him better than joyous.

title: Banks and Insurers Irate Over Accounting Rule
description: Banks and property-and-casualty insurers, their earnings already weak, are furious over a new accounting rule that is likely to depress their earnings further.

title: Larson of Bruins Is Finding Solace
description: When the emergency medical personnel finally arrived and assured him his son and daughter were alive and well, Reed Larson refused to believe them.

title: New York's Schools: Profiles of Chancellor Finalists
description: Four-and-a-half months after Nathan Quinones announced that he was stepping down as New York City's Schools Chancellor, the search for a successor to run the nation's largest public school system is nearing an end.

title: Tutu Urges Blacks to End Political Killings
description: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu called on blacks today to halt factional bloodshed in Natal province, where at least 14 people have been killed since Christmas Eve.

title: The Stage: 'Us,' by Karen Malpede
description: MAYBE you won't need a program to tell one character from another in ''Us,'' but it can't hurt. Although there are only two actors in Karen Malpede's play at the Theater for the New City, they take six parts, and the action occurs in three countries over an unchronological period of about 40 years. Since neither the playwright nor the director, Judith Malina, goes out of her way to assist the viewer, you may find yourself glancing down at your program between scenes while the performers are changing costumes and wigs.

title: Fans Made Their Voice Heard
description: MORE than ever before, in 1987 the audience shared the sports stage with the athletes. And in the Year of the Fan, the athletes appreciated it.

title: June S. Cummins Weds Jonathan David Lewis
description: At the Beth Jacob Congregation in San Diego, June Stacey Cummins, a doctoral candidate in English at Columbia University, was married yesterday to Jonathan David Lewis, a doctoral candidate in physics at Cornell University. Rabbi Eliezer Langer performed the ceremony.

title: Texas Player Ineligible
description: Tony Griffin, a starting cornerback for Texas, failed a drug test and has been declared ineligible for the Bluebonnet Bowl game Thursday night, Coach David McWilliams of Texas said today.

title: Ford, Under Petersen, Became a Giant Killer
description: Donald E. Petersen, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, has every reason to face the coming year with confidence. When financial results for 1987 are reported, Ford is almost certain to be more profitable than the mighty General Motors Corporation - for the second year in a row.

title: City Ballet: 'Nutcracker'
description: JEFFREY EDWARDS took over the role of the Sugar Plum Fairy's Cavalier yesterday afternoon when the New York City Ballet danced ''The Nutcracker'' at the New York State Theater. It was a performance that made one realize that although the Cavalier is a small part, it is a very important one.

title: Anthony West, Critic and Author; Wrote Essays for The New Yorker
description: Anthony West, the critic and novelist, died yesterday at his home in Stonington, Conn., after suffering a stroke. He was 73 years old and also kept a home on Fisher's Island, N.Y.

title: The Detroit Advantage in Trucks
description: Parking lots at schools are crowded with mothers in mini-vans picking up their children. Young executives park their BMW's and Volvos on weekends to drive their Jeeps to the country club or their vacation homes. The payload in a pickup these days is as likely to be a surfboard as a sheet of plywood.

title: Bridge: Swedish 'Barometer' System Proves to Be Popular Import
description: Some interesting ideas in bridge organization have come from Sweden, and slowly made an impact on this side of the Atlantic.

title: Coconut Grove Journal; Doing the Strut for Fun and Protest
description: In Pasadena, Calif., it's the DooDa Parade. In the District of Columbia, it's the Gross National Parade, in Tampa the Momma Guava Stumble, and in Orlando, the Queen Kumquat Sashay.

title: Critic's Notebook; Repertory of Legends Immortalizes Jascha Heifetz
description: Jascha Heifetz, who died on Dec. 12 at the age of 86, was unforgettable in every way. It was not only that he was the greatest virtuoso after Paganini, and that he set all standards for 20th-century violin playing.

title: NEW TREATY STIRS A BROADER DEBATE
description: In an effort to hasten the approval of the new treaty on intermediate range missiles, the Reagan Administration has begun quiet negotiations with Senate Democratic leaders on the politically sensitive issue of how all treaties are made and interpreted.

title: Correction
description: A report on Tuesday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page misidentified the assistant editor of Roll Call, a Capitol Hill newspaper.

title: The Paradox of Pete du Pont: Political Iconoclast With Establishment Roots
description: Something startling would happen in the first months of the Administration of President Pete du Pont, the candidate predicts.

title: Dole and Bush Leading In an Iowa G.O.P. Poll
description: A poll indicated today that the Iowa race between Senator Bob Dole and Vice President Bush remains close six weeks before the state's precinct caucuses, a key test of the Republican Presidential campaign.

title: Ranch Shooting
description: To the Editor:

title: Penn and Teller on Broadway
description: Penn and Teller, the comic co-conspirators, are performing these days on a Broadway stage once trod by Alfred Lunt, Claudette Colbert, Leslie Howard and Dame Sybil Thorndike.

title: Wells Fargo Robbery Case Takes a Long Route to Trial
description: The beginning was simple enough: on Sept. 12, 1983, a Wells Fargo guard robbed a depot in West Hartford. Getting to the end, however, has turned into what some lawyers are calling one of the lengthiest and most complex criminal cases in Federal court history.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE TENANTS OF TIME. By Thomas Flanagan. 824 pages. William Abrahams/Dutton. $21.95.

title: Market Place; Investors Wary On Mutual Funds
description: NOBODY knows what 1988 will bring for the stock and bond markets, but James S. Riepe, director of the mutual fund division of T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, seems sure of one thing. ''It's going to be harder to sell mutual funds than it has been in recent years,'' he said.

title: New Faces Appear In Playoff Picture New Faces Appear In Playoff Picture
description: On this last weekend of the National Football League regular season, the scramble for playoff berths had the rabid fan no less than the casual observer puzzled by the possibilities.

title: TV Review; 'The Other Olympic Game,' From ABC News
description: A POLITICAL question already hangs over the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in South Korea: will Soviet athletes compete? As ''The Other Olympic Game,'' a sophisticated ABC News documentary, notes toward its close, the Soviet Union won't say. The documentary, on Channel 7 at 8 o'clock tonight, indicates, however, that Soviet foreign policy will determine the answer.

title: Colts Grab Title and First Playoff Berth in 10 Years
description: Eric Dickerson ran for 196 yards and two touchdowns today as the Indianapolis Colts won the American Confernce Eastern Division title and gained their first playoff berth in a decade with a 24-6 victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Harvard Is Beaten By Illinois-Chicago
description: The University of Illinois at Chicago, its sports teams known as the Flames, has 25,000 students and has had for the last six seasons a Division I hockey team. The coach, Val Belmonte, came from Harvard where he was Bill Cleary's assistant for three seasons.

title: Dolphin Toll at 28 in Florida
description: The number of bottlenose dolphins found dead on Florida beaches since Thanksgiving has risen to 28, and officials fear that a mysterious disease is moving south along the East Coast.

title: Diane Strachan Becomes a Bride
description: At St. John's United Church of Christ in Meadville, Pa., Diane Shafer Strachan was married yesterday to Dr. Larry Allan Graham. The Rev. Donald Engler performed the ceremony.

title: Madeline Warren Weds
description: The marriage of Madeline Warren, an independent film producer, to Bruce Feirstein, an author and a screenwriter, took place yesterday at the bridegroom's home in East Hampton, L.I. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Jean Warren of Southold, L.I., and the late Dr. Monte M. Warren. Mr. Feirstein is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Feirstein of Maplewood, N.J. Previous marriages for both the bride and the bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: Blazing Away
description: The scene is the Oregon State Penitentiary. Several hundred inmates crowd into a steamy gymnasium with a 12-foot ceiling, hoping to see some of their more athletic peers win a basketball game.

title: Bragging Rights Not Worth Exercising
description: Giants fans were just getting used to thinking of their team as Super Bowl champion, and the Jets teased their fans with playoff appearances in the last two seasons. But at Giants Stadium today, the party was over.

title: Alexander G. Barmine, 88, Dies; Early High-Level Soviet Defector
description: Alexander G. Barmine, a brigadier general in the Soviet Army who defected in 1937 and became an influential journalist and a United States Government official, died Friday at a nursing home in Rockville, Md. He died of complications resulting from a stroke.

title: West Bank Schools Reopen; Military Trials Begin
description: Palestinian schools in the West Bank, closed by the army as a security measure a week ago, reopened today as combat-equipped soldiers patrolled the main streets and entrances to refugee centers.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Bush Declines
description: Vice President Bush is taking a respite from his political toils with a short vacation in Kennebunkport, Me. On his return trip to Washington next weekend, the Republican Presidential contender will fly over Boston but, being a Yale man, does not plan to drop in at Harvard for a televised interview to which he had been invited.

title: Former Senator Improving
description: Former Senator Ralph Yarborough, 84 years old, continues to improve after heart surgery Tuesday and probably will be released from Seton Medical Center within a week, a hospital spokeswoman said today. ''The Senator is making steady progress,'' said M. A. Bengston, the hospital's information director. ''He is walking with assistance down the hall.'' Mr. Yarborough, a Democrat and a leader of the party's liberal wing in Texas, served as a Senator from 1957 to 1971.

title: Business and the Law; Changes by U.S. For Pension Plans
description: AFTER months of growing debate over pension laws and how to reduce the mountainous deficit of the Federal agency that insures pension payments, sweeping changes were enacted last week that will significantly affect the payments companies must make and the guidelines under which employers must operate.

title: New Yorkers & Co.; Reviews of 740 Restaurants With Not a Critic in Sight
description: If you haven't yet picked a place for dinner on New Year's Eve, you might consult the Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey. The pocket-size guide lists 740 dining establishments, from Abyssinia to Zucchini, the overwhelming majority of them in Manhattan. Each is rated on food, decor, service and cost. But don't expect Zagat to lead you to a quiet, undiscovered spot to call your own.

title: Elizabeth Martin Sanford Senator's Mother, 99
description: Elizabeth Martin Sanford, mother of Senator Terry Sanford of North Carolina, died Saturday after a heart attack she suffered in a holiday visit to her son's home. She was 99.

title: CHRISTMAS SALES ARE DISAPPOINTING ACROSS THE NATION
description: The results of this year's Christmas shopping season, reflecting in part the effect of the stock market doldrums and hinting at next year's economy, were disappointing across the nation.

title: Landmark Potential Confuses Plans for a Building
description: Four cast-iron buildings below Canal Street have been added to New York City's list of potential landmarks, and one of them has thrown into confusion a developer's plan for a new apartment building in TriBeCa.

title: Dollar Falls Again in Tokyo, And Stocks Tumble as Well
description: The dollar fell to new lows against the yen this morning, dropping as low as 123.30 yen amid pessimism over the prospects for changes in American fiscal policy.

title: Good Image
description: In this season of the strike and the replacement games, with coaches who complain about a certain torpor, and uncertainty taking the field each Sunday, things are still going great in the National Football League.

title: Mother of Youth in Suicide Pact Files Suit
description: The mother of one of four teen-agers who committed suicide together in Bergenfield in March has filed suit against a hospital and several employees, charging that they failed to diagnose the youth as suicidal a week before he died.

title: Advertising; 1987: What Kind of a Year Was It?
description: IT appears as if the demystification of advertising agencies has been completed.

title: Welfare Allowance Going Up But Homeless Worries Persist
description: New York State will increase the housing allowances of welfare families by an average of 13 percent on Jan. 1. But public officials, community leaders, housing specialists, welfare recipients and landlords assert that the allowances, less than most rents in New York City, will be inadequate to stop an increase in homeless families.

title: Man Freed in Rape Case Is Seized And May Have to Finish Sentence
description: A man who was freed from prison after the woman who had accused him of rape recanted was denied bond today on new charges of battery and disorderly conduct. He may have to finish his original 25-to-50-year sentence.

title: Metro Datelines; 5 Injured in a Fight At Basketball Game
description: ABSECON, N.J.

title: Washington Talk: Census Bureau; How Problematic the 1990 Enumeration? Let Us Count the Ways
description: If you are one of those people who think the 1988 Presidential campaign started too soon, you almost certainly aren't ready to contemplate the 1990 census.

title: Concert: P. D. Q. Bach Plays Carnegie Hall
description: LIKE new shoes to a wad of gum, Peter Schickele just can't seem to avoid stepping into yet another piece chewed up and spit out by P. D. Q. Bach, the 21st of the great master's 20 children and the only dead composer from whom works can still be commissioned. Mr. Schickele imposed the latest discoveries on his audience Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall and will subject other listeners to the same music tonight and Wednesday evening at Carnegie.

title: Hold the Price Line And Aid the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Leading Indicators Nov. Home Sales Nov. Prices of New Homes Nov. Thursday Factory Orders Nov. Farm Prices Nov. Friday None

title: Mary Klinger Married To Dr. Joseph Salerno
description: The marriage of Mary Elizabeth Klinger and Dr. Joseph Anthony Salerno took place yesterday at the Rockland Lake Manor in Congers, N.Y. The Rev. Giles Spoonhour, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: News Lurks on the Crime Blotter in Moscow
description: Every Wednesday at one of Moscow's most fearsome addresses, 38 Petrovka St., the local police meet the Soviet press to report the latest incidents of exploding television sets, snatchings of fur hats, vodka moonshining and other constabulary notes from all over Moscow.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Apple Computer Inc., San Francisco, nominated the former astronaut Sally Ride as a director on its six-member board to replace Henry Singleton, chairman of Teledyne Inc. who is not standing for re-election.

title: Iranian Visits Qaddafi
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the leader of Libya, met today with the Iranian Foreign Minister in Tripoli, Libya's official news agency reported. Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, who arrived in the Libyan capital Saturday, was accompanied by an Iranian delegation, according to the report, which was monitored in Rome. Earlier today, Mr. Velayati met with his Libyan counterpart, Jadallah Azzouz al-Talhi, the agency said, and the two men reportedly discussed current Palestinian unrest in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. They were quoted as saying ''armed struggle is the only way to confront the Zionist enemy.''

title: Inouye Wins Aid for French Jews
description: As Congress rushed to adjourn last week, Senator Daniel K. Inouye persuaded colleagues to appropriate $8 million to build Jewish schools in France in a project supported by a campaign contributor but opposed by the State Department.

title: Port Louis Journal; Land of Apartheid Befriends an Indian Ocean Isle
description: This Indian Ocean island-state, a vigorous multiparty democracy with a racially and culturally diverse population, is in the midst of an economic boom that is based in good measure on trade, tourism and investment ties with South Africa.

title: Deepening Gloom Over Latin Debt
description: Economic crises in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina, occurring simultaneously for the first time since Latin America's debt troubles began five years ago, are casting a pall over the region's relations with its foreign creditors.

title: Israelis Defend Protest Tactics
description: Israeli officials said today that Israeli soldiers had resorted to using live ammunition against Palestinian demonstrators when their own lives were endangered.

title: Metro Datelines; Surgery Ruled Out For Injured Worker
description: MANHATTAN
