title: Dr. Cathy A. Colt Wed To Dr. R. J. Pomerantz
description: Dr. Cathy Ann Colt, a resident in ophthalmology at the Wills Eye Hospital in Philadelphia, and Dr. Roger James Pomerantz, the chief medical resident at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at the Harvard Memorial Chapel at Harvard University. Rabbi Albert Ginsberg officiated.

title: Wall Street Sang Praises Of Merck Chief Vagelos
description: In the last few years under Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck & Company's army of 3,400 research scientists have had the golden touch in developing new drugs. Led by Vasotec, a blood pressure drug, which some analysts say will nudge $1 billion in sales in 1988, 13 of Merck's new products have each registered sales of $100 million or more.

title: Nine Mirage Jets for India
description: India has received nine more Mirage 2000 jet fighters from France, the United News of India said today. The Indian Air Force, which relies heavily on Soviet combat aircraft, now has 49 Mirages, the news agency said.

title: Bond Activity Suggests Rate Cuts
description: Ten weeks after the steep decline in stock prices on Oct. 19, credit market participants are still guessing about the likely effects on consumer spending, the economy and interest rates.

title: As Tradition, Families Help The Neediest
description: Not long ago, Julie Houston of Brooklyn found $49 on the street and asked her children what treat they would like with the found money.

title: Hard Times Persist in the Virginia Coal Country
description: Despite more than two decades of intensive Federal and state assistance, the depressed coal counties of southwestern Virginia are making little progress in catching up economically with the rest of the state, a major study has found.

title: Knicks' New Plan: No Clear Verdict
description: Looking for some kind of advantage for his struggling Knicks, Coach Rick Pitino mapped a new game plan Saturday night against the Atlanta Hawks, who trail the Detroit Pistons by one-half game in the Central Division.

title: Soviet-Egyptian Trade
description: The Soviet Union and Egypt plan to double their trade over the next three years, Soviet Deputy Trade Minister Vladimir Burmistov said in Cairo today. ''I will sign a new trade protocol raising the volume of trade from $900 million, to $1.8 billion, during this visit,'' he told reporters after arriving for talks on a new 1988-1990 agreement. Egypt exports textiles, leather and liquor to Moscow and imports Soviet industrial and farm machinery. Although the United States has been Egypt's main superpower ally since the 1970's, Moscow's ties with Cairo warmed after the Soviet Union rescheduled $3 billion of military debt last April.

title: Poddubny Goals Pace Victory
description: Two weeks ago, Walt Poddubny stood on the boardwalk in Rye, N.Y., and stared into the cold afternoon breeze, smiling broadly as his wife and three dogs worked their way toward him along the beach. It was a raw day, he hadn't been home in a week, and he wanted nothing more than an afternoon of solitude.

title: When the Clock Flashes 12-12-12
description: Until Ed Greif, Herman T. Baron and Max Lowenthal went public with their strategies for turning electronic clocks backward and forward, it may have been the rare American who gave much thought to how hard it has become to change time in this age of technological convenience. To read the Greif/Baron/Lowenthal correspondence in The Times's Letters column, however, is to think of little else.

title: Outdoors: Learning the Ways of a New Weapon
description: OLD dogs can be taught new tricks; it just takes time.

title: Joffrey Prepares 'Nutcracker'
description: Does America need a new ''Nutcracker''? The Joffrey Ballet thinks it does, and on the strength of its conviction it has mounted a new production of the balletic fairy tale that receives its New York premiere on Wednesday at the City Center, 131 West 55th Street.

title: New Zealand Fire Kills 3
description: Fire destroyed a hotel today and killed three children in the town of Taneatua, 150 miles south of Auckland, the police said.

title: Vermont Won't Be a Japanese Colony
description: To the Editor:

title: Near-Perfect Conditions Can Be Found Indoors
description: THE United States Davis Cup team has played five of its last six home matches indoors, even in the middle of summer when the rest of the tennis-playing world is competing outside. Why? Because indoor tennis removes the natural elements as factors in determining the outcome of a match, and there have been instances in which the United States Tennis Association felt that Mother Nature contributed as much to an American defeat as the opposition. By contrast, American teams have won four of their last five home matches indoors.

title: Why Verification Can Be Solidly Trusted
description: LEAD: President Reagan's signing of the treaty to eliminate short- and intermediate-range nuclear missiles makes him the seventh consecutive chief executive to acknowledge, however belatedly, that such agreements are adequately verifiable.

title: Moscow Seems Ready to Smile on Bonn Anew
description: The reports that the conservative leader of Bavaria will visit Moscow next week and the Soviet Foreign Minister will come to Bonn next month appear to signal a revived Soviet diplomatic initiative toward West Germany.

title: Enact a Gasoline Tax, to Begin With
description: For many years, the Federal Government has emulated New York City's pre-1975 spending and borrowing practices. Since 1980, the Government has outdone New York's most financially irresponsible conduct. It has borrowed recklessly, first from ourselves, then from the rest of the world, to finance a huge defense program, significant tax cuts and continuously growing social programs such as Social Security. New York City, in 1975, was lucky: We could not borrow any more because our markets were closed and so we had to adjust to reality.

title: Washington Helps Nets Take It Easy
description: Several weeks ago, Harry Weltman, the Nets' general manager, found little to no interest on the National Basketball Association market for Dwayne (Pearl) Washington. If Weltman were to try to move Washington based on his showing in the last four games, he would likely find a decided change in demand.

title: Prime Bids For Rival In Computers
description: Prime Computer Inc., going around the Computervision Corporation's management, is offering shareholders about $400 million for the maker of automated design and manufacturing systems.

title: CARRY-ON LUGGAGE FACES NEW CURBS
description: Travelers who hauled large, heavy bags aboard planes when they left for their holiday trips may find a surprise on return flights as tighter restrictions on carry-on luggage take effect on New Year's Day.

title: Rewi Alley, Expatriate in China
description: Rewi Alley, a New Zealander who came to China in 1927 and stayed 60 years to help the Communist cause, died Sunday in Beijing, the official New China News Agency reported. He was 90 years old.

title: Search Ends for Plane In Hawaii After 4 Days
description: The search for a twin-engine commuter plane missing since Wednesday night with eight people aboard was called off today, and a newspaper reported that the pilot had been having trouble with his door before the plane vanished.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Wayne B. Fulcher has rejoined McCann-Erickson/San Francisco as senior vice president and management supervisor.

title: F.D.I.C. Could See First Yearly Loss
description: The Government agency that insures almost $2 trillion in deposits at the nation's commercial banks could record the first annual loss in its 54-year history, its chairman says.

title: Foes of Contra Aid Are Grasping at Straws
description: The dramatic disclosures by the Sandinista Defense Minister, Humberto Ortega Saavedra, and by Maj. Roger Miranda Bengoechea, the Sandinista defector, have opponents of aid to the contras grasping at straws.

title: U.S. Study of Cost Overruns Singles Out Ship Companies
description: Intense competition among ship and submarine builders is prompting many contractors to submit unrealistically low bids for Navy contracts, leading to huge cost overruns that the Navy must help absorb, a General Accounting Office report concludes.

title: Books: Ike in the War
description: IKE THE SOLDIER. As They Knew Him.

title: AFGHAN REFUGEES RALLY IN PAKISTAN
description: Thousands of Afghan refugees gathered at rallies in Pakistan today to mark the eighth anniversary of the Soviet military invervention in Afghanistan.

title: INMATE APOLOGIZES FOR FLEEING PRISON
description: A former state trooper who was serving two consecutive life terms for murder until his escape two weeks ago has sent a letter of apology to the head of the state's prison system but says he has no plans to return.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Aerial Ventures
description: While senior Defense Department officials complain about budget austerity, the Pentagon plans to dispatch three aerial demonstration teams to perform in 160 events next year.

title: New York Legislature Criticized on Environment
description: Although the passage of New York State's $1.45 billion Environmental Quality Bond Act showed strong public support for environmental protection, the State Legislature failed to enact any significant environmental legislation in its last session, a report published recently by the Environmental Planning Lobby asserts.

title: N.J. Transit to Ask Big Rise in Aid to Offset Losses
description: N. J. Transit will seek a significant increase in state aid to maintain bus and train fares at current levels for the fiscal year beginning next July 1, according to the head of the the state transit agency.

title: INSIDE
description: The Year of the Fan Audiences at the World Series, the Super Bowl and many other events this year shared the spotlight with the players. And the athletes, for the most part, appreciated it. A review of 1987. SportsMonday, page C1. Boom Time for an Island Mauritius, an Indian Ocean island state of 1.1 million people, is in the midst of an economic boom based largely on trade, tourism and investment ties with South Africa. Page A4. Arms Compromise Sought The Administration, seeking quick approval of its missile treaty, is talking with Senate Democrats on how treaties are interpreted. Page A5.

title: Trial of AIDS Drug in U.S. Lags As Too Few Participants Enroll
description: More than a year after it was conceived, the largest and most important clinical trial of an AIDS drug in the United States is lagging, with only half the needed patients enrolled.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Chile's Unburied Past
description: Fourteen years of relentless dictatorship have done little to concentrate Chilean democrats' minds on the future. A recent visit showed the opposition to be as divided today as it was in September 1973. That's when a military coup, supported by centrist and right-wing civilian parties, ended the elected Socialist presidency of Salvador Allende and with it, Chile's democratic political life. As Jacobo Timerman notes in an eloquent new book, Chile's political class remains obsessed with the traumas of its past.

title: A Reel That Computerizes Casting
description: Sport fishing has come a long way since the days of bamboo poles and twine. Now comes a touch of technological wizardry that may leave even the most tournament-crazed angler wanting.

title: Home Resales Off in Month
description: Sales of existing homes fell 4.5 percent in November, the biggest drop in five months, as the collapse in stock prices in October apparently dampened home-buying enthusiasm, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Afghan Government and Foes Each Claiming War Successes
description: The Soviet-backed Afghan Government says its troops killed 1,603 guerrillas in a battle to reopen the road leading to the besieged city of Khost, the Kabul radio said today.

title: Trustcorp to Acquire Summcorp of Indiana
description: Trustcorp Inc., a financial services company based in Toledo, Ohio, said today that it had agreed to acquire Summcorp Inc., a bank holding company in Fort Wayne, Ind., in a stock swap valued at nearly $200 million.

title: It's Time to Retire, Doctor Tells Klecko; Walton Silent On Jet Changes
description: As the Jets dumped their clothes into bags and headed home today amid speculation over their future, the team orthopedist told Joe Klecko to retire.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Good News for Ginsburg
description: All the news is not bad these days for Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. True, he failed to win elevation to the United States Supreme Court as President Reagan had proposed. True, he is under investigation by the Justice Department for possible conflicts of interest while working on cable television cases and serving as an assistant attorney general.

title: Pitt Is Poised to Leap to the Top
description: For the University of Pittsburgh's basketball team, 1988 may well prove to be a year of vindication. Unfortunately for the Panthers, however, it will probably take nothing short of a national championship to undo the bad publicity and the unrealistic expectations of the last few years.

title: Computer Memories Deal
description: Computer Memories Inc. said today that it planned to merge with DIC Animation City Inc., the producer of such television cartoon shows as ''Alf'' and ''Real Ghostbusters,'' in a $75 million stock deal.

title: JG INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Sales in the year-ago periods included $8.5 million from five stores that have been sold or closed for the quarter and sales for the 9 months included $23.5 million from discontinued stores.

title: Offices of Transit Police Are Targets of Burglary
description: The headquarters of the New York City Transit Police Department, some of whose members are under investigation amid allegations they made false arrests, were broken into over the weekend, with file cabinets open and papers strewn about, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Hart Wins Federal Campaign Financing
description: Gary Hart's revived Presidential campaign was declared eligible today to receive Federal matching funds, with the first $100,000 installment expected early next week.

title: A New Spirit at U.S. Auto Plants
description: Workers at a factory of the General Motors Corporation factory here are building cars in ways that would have astonished Henry Ford, the man who introduced the assembly line to the automobile industry. Instead of thousands of workers performing the same task over and over again as the cars move by them, teams of 5 to 11 people build entire sections of the new Buick Reatta sports car.

title: Market Place; Cloud Over Avon: Dividend Worries
description: MENTION Avon Products Inc. and Wall Street professionals immediately think of the $2 annual dividend rate on the common stock that has been paid regularly since 1983. Most analysts believe Avon's dividend is secure for now, but its safety is like a shadow that keeps lingering over the stock.

title: PLUNGE IN DOLLAR BRINGS CALL BY U.S. FOR STABILIZATION
description: Continuing its year-end decline, the dollar plunged to new lows today, prompting a statement from the White House that the Reagan Administration remained opposed to any further fall in the currency's value.

title: A Cost-Cutting Designer Who's Riding a Wave
description: In Paris, it's Christian Lacroix, in New York, Arnold Scaasi and in Dallas, Victor Costa. Victor Costa?

description: A NEW technique for surgery in prostate cancer is moving into widespread use as doctors find it can avoid the procedure's most feared side effect: impotence.

Kenya-Uganda Accord To Cut Border Forces
description: Kenya and Uganda agreed today to reduce security forces at their border, a move expected to ease tensions that led to shooting between the East African neighbors two weeks ago.

title: Philosophical Rift: A Tale of Two Approaches
description: Charles Sherover, who teaches philosophy at Hunter College, speaks in a sort of paradox about certain other philosophers. All too often, he says, those who were accepted into the ranks of the philosophers in America were not what he calls ''philosophically inclined.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1987
description: International A2-9

title: Bridge: A Mike Lawrence Workbook Shows How to Cover Cracks
description: Almost all books about bidding theory offer the reader typical sequences, carefully avoiding the difficult borderline situations and the problems that plague any method.

title: New Theory on Oceans of Venus

title: Q&A
description: Q. Many people get a pain below the ribcage when they run. What causes this pain? A. Several things can cause such a ''stitch'' or cramp, said Dr. Averil Ma, a gastroenterology fellow at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. For example, he said, if someone ate a heavy meal and then ''started doing something else that demands blood flow, there would be relative ischemia,'' or a reduction of blood supply to the intestines; this would produce a cramp. Muscular problems could also cause such pain, he said. Q. Why do some mammals mate for life? A. Few mammals do so, according to Marie Lawrence, senior scientific assistant in the mammalogy department of the American Museum of Natural History. ''The ones that come to mind immediately are wolves,'' she said. ''Beavers are also thought to mate for life.''

description: Nearly 200 years ago the Founding Fathers drafted a Bill of Rights whose first 16 words insured freedom of worship and separation of church and state to the citizens of the new nation. Now, a Senator, a retired Chief Justice and a British scholar have concluded that that freedom of religion has come on difficult times.

The company also said that revenue and net income results for the third quarter and 9 months of 1986 represent results of New England Sales Inc., the company's wholly owned subsidiary, which was acquired in January 1987.

title: Washington Talk: Briefing; Quoting the A.N.C.
description: Sechaba, the official publication of the African National Congress, is banned in South Africa. As such, it may not be distributed or quoted by any South African publication. But South African cabinet ministers often quote banned publications or leaders of the guerrilla organization when they believe it helps them to press their case against the rebels. And an editorial from the October issue of Sechaba showed up in, of all places, a monthly bulletin published by the South African Embassy in Washington. The embassy said that the editorial showed that the A.N.C. was not interested in negotiations with the Pretoria Government.

title: 2 Tax Lawyers Are Indicted
description: Two tax attorneys were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan yesterday, charged with scheming to generate more than $890 million in fictitious investment losses so that taxpayers could deduct more than $200 million on their tax returns.

title: First Chicago And Wood Call Off Deal
description: The First Chicago Corporation and Wood Gundy Inc. said today that they had ended their agreement to form a partnership amid questions about the health of the Canadian investment firm after the October stock market plunge.

title: Mexican Rancher Breeds Miniature Cows
description: STANDING in the corral of his sprawling ranch here, Angel Castrillon affectionately patted the pride and joy among one of his herds of Zebu cattle - a robust-looking cow with good musculature and a placid personality.

title: Long Stay in Space Proves 'Very Difficult' For Soviet Commander
description: EARLIER this month, on one of the Mir space station's 112 weekly orbits, its commander, Col. Yuri V. Romanenko, let irritation get the better of him. Asked yet again about his well-being, the man who has been in space three months longer than anyone else snapped: ''Leave me alone. I have a lot of work to do.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about an increase in the number of ''bias incidents'' reported to the New York City Police Department included some erroneous statistics, provided by the police, for some months of 1987. In the first three months of the year, 161 racial or ethnic incidents were reported, more than three times the number reported in the same period last year.

title: Bond Prices Decrease Modestly
description: Note and bond prices declined modestly in light trading yesterday, with little participation by institutional investors or speculators outside the major securities firms.

title: Gulf Insurers Ask Rate Curb
description: Persian Gulf insurance companies are trying to halt a steep rise in war risk premiums before the increase drives ships away from the area, a representative said today.

title: Families Celebrate Joyous Occasions by Giving to the Neediest
description: To celebrate the birth of Rachel, her first grandchild, Lillian Miller of Manhattan sent a gift of $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The orders fashioned by the district court to remedy the housing and school segregtion in Yonkers were well within the proper bounds of discretion.'' - Judge Amalya L. Kearse of the United States Court of Appeals. [ B2:5 ]

title: Sports of The Times; The Best Were Invisible
description: IN the current issue of The Sporting News, that estimable and indispensable periodical, there is a headline that reads, ''Man of the Year? See Page 4.''

title: AIDS: Everyone's Business
description: For a few weeks earlier this winter I had a chance people in the news business rarely get - to read the newspapers and watch news broadcasts without any sense of urgency, responsibility or competitiveness.

title: More Buyouts Seen in 1988
description: The recent volatility in the stock market will set the stage for more acquisitions and leveraged buyouts in 1988, the Acquisition Funding Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company's G.E. Credit Corporation, predicted today.

title: Copter Pilot Signals Train to Save Driver
description: A police pilot saved the life of a driver who had passed out on railroad tracks today by dipping his helicopter within a few feet of the ground and using his searchlight to warn an oncoming freight train, the police said.

title: H. H. Robertson
description: The H. H. Robertson Company, based in Pittsburgh, said that it had agreed to sell its Freeman chemical units. The transactions are part of Robertson's plan, announced earlier this year, to concentrate on its building-products units. Robertson said that it would sell Freeman Chemicals Ltd., based in Ellesmere Port, England, to Naamloze Vennootschap D.S.M of the Netherlands, and that it would sell the Freeman Chemical Corporation, in Port Washington, Wis., to the Georgia Gulf Corporation of Atlanta. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Results Plus
description: N.F.L. Patriots 24, Dolphins 10: Steve Grogan threw for 238 yards and two touchdowns as the visiting New England Patriots, eliminated from the playoffs a day earlier, beat Miami in the final game of the 1987 regular season. Grogan, playing with a broken bone in his left hand, connected with Irving Fryar for a 3-yard score after a Miami fumble and hit Stephen Starring with a 34-yard pass to cap a 79-yard drive. Grogan completed 21 of 32 passes. Both New England and Miami finished with 8-7 records. (AP) N.H.L. Capitals 4, Maple Leafs 4: The veteran defenseman Rod Langway, playing in his second game after suffering a back injury, fired a wrist shot from the point in the third period last night to give Washington the tie in Toronto. Langway, who missed 14 games with a ruptured disk, got the puck at the blue line just as an interference penalty to Ed Olczyk ended and put a wrist shot past the screened goaltender, Allan Bester, at 5 minutes 31 seconds of the third period. Michal Pivonka, Scott Stevens and Mike Gartner also scored for the Capitals, who came back from second-period deficits of 3-1 and 4-2. Tom Fergus had two goals and Olczyk and Russ Courtnall each had one for Toronto. Gary Leeman had a chance to score in the overtime but was thwarted by Clint Malarchuk, the Washington goalie, who started in place of an injured Pete Peeters. (AP) Oilers 7, Canucks 3: The Oilers, playing before only their third sellout crowd this season, extended their unbeaten string against the Canucks to 24 games. Vancouver is 0-22-2 against Edmonton since a victory on March 10, 1985. Mark Messier and Craig Simpson each scored two goals to lead Edmonton. Messier finished off a pair of two-on-one breaks as the Oilers scored twice in the first period. Vancouver trailed by 4-3 after two periods, but Simpson scored in the first and eighth minutes of the final period to put the game away. (AP) N.B.A. Suns 117, 76ers 101: Larry Nance scored 39 points and Jay Humphries added 20 as Phoenix shut down Charles Barkley and beat visiting Philadelphia last night, snapping a three-game losing streak. Barkley, the league's second-leading scorer with a 29.3-point average, was held to 5 points in the first half and finished with 15 in 35 minutes. He was also limited to five rebounds, seven off his average, which is third-best in the league. Walter Davis scored 8 of his 15 during an 18-8 run as the Suns took a 47-38 lead 5:17 before halftime and then added a 12-2 run on the way to a 59-49 lead at the half. Nance had 13 third-quarter points and the Suns led, 88-76, entering the final period. The 76ers lost for the fourth time in their last five games. Philadelphia was led by Cliff Robinson with 21 points and Ron Hinson with 16. (AP) Horse Racing Cougar Sue Is First: Cougar Sue saved ground throughout and prevailed in a hard drive to score a three-quarter-length victory yesterday in the $42,000 allowance feature for fillies and mares 3 years old and up at Aqueduct. The 3-year-old daughter of Cojak-Ms. Director went six furlongs carrying Eddie Maple on the fast track in 1:11 1/5. She carried 113 pounds and edged the favorite, Dream Launch. Cougar Sue earned $25,200 for Sharon L. Hild and paid $14.60 for $2 to win as the fourth choice in a field of six.

title: Hebe Dorsey Dies in France at 62; Fashion Writer at Herald Tribune
description: Hebe Dorsey, the fashion editor of The International Herald Tribune and a major figure in the fashion world, died of cancer yesterday morning at the American Hospital in Neuilly-sur-Seine, near Paris. She was 62 years old and had been working for the paper for about 40 years.

title: Japan Video Output Off
description: Japanese output of video cassette recorders and color televisions fell 6.8 percent and 2.1 percent, respectively, in November from a year earlier because of slow exports, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said today. November's production of 2.3 million video recorders marked the 12th straight monthly decline from the previous year and was down 6.6 percent from October, a spokesman said. The 1.3 million television sets produced last month were 1.7 percent fewer than a month earlier.

description: A TEST developed recently to detect bacteria that cause gum disease is opening the way to improved dental treatment, experts say.

description: Four days before the Orange Bowl game against Oklahoma, an attorney for George Mira Jr., the linebacker from the University of Miami, said that the school has appealed a suspension by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that resulted from a drug test.

description: Emergency crews worked for more than three hours yesterday to free a diver who was trapped under 45 feet of water off Staten Island.

description: REM sleep, a paradoxical and mysterious state characterized by rapid eye movements, is leading scientists to new insights about the chemistry of the brain.

title: Charles P. Thompson, Architect, 67
description: Charles Prentice Thompson, a Manhattan architect, died of pneumonia Dec. 16 at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: South Korea's gross national product grew by 12.2 percent in real terms this year, according to preliminary figures released today by the Bank of Korea.

description: THERE is a monumental joke at the end of Robert Patrick's ''Explanation of a Xmas Wedding'' that isn't bad. But it is more than a little presumptuous of the playwright to assume that an audience will be happy to wait two hours to get to it.

description: Israeli leaders are openly upset at the news coverage they received abroad, particularly in the United States, during more than two weeks of Palestinian disturbances in which at least 21 protesters were shot to death by the army.

title: L.I. Hospital Director Resigns Amid Dispute
description: The executive director of the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow resigned yesterday, two weeks after a Federal agency found that the hospital's mortality rate for Medicare patients was the highest in the state.

title: Stage: 'A Child's Christmas in Wales'
description: FOR 20 years, the National Theater of the Deaf has made sign language speak to hearing audiences as well as to theatergoers who are hearing impaired. As demonstrated in a special seasonal engagement at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center, the troupe has a style and a message that transcend a very evident social need.

description: As it happens, 1988 will arrive a little late this year - one second late, to be exact - and thereupon hangs a tale.

description: IF you want to file away education's key topics for 1987, consider the headings of ''poverty'' and ''reform.'' Regrettably, poverty was real, while reforms still remained largely in blueprints. Yet, the two are closely connected: reforms in education were supposed to reduce the damage poverty does to children.

description: In a surprise move, the Cincinnati Bengals ended two days of management discussions yesterday by announcing that Sam Wyche would be back as head coach next season despite the team's 4-11 record in 1987.

title: Jersey Tourney Is Jeopardized By Drug Dispute
description: The future of one of the nation's most prestigious high school basketball tournaments - the Seagull Classic in Absecon, N.J. - has been jeopardized by a brawl among spectators that the police said was related to a drug ''turf war'' and had nothing to do with the event.

title: Economic Scene; Worrying About Reagan's Legacy
description: THE Reagan years, which embodied a dramatic effort to restructure and revitalize the economy, are winding up with the dollar falling, the external deficit widening, the stock market still in a state of shock after its steepest fall in history and wide expectations of sluggish growth or recession in the Administration's final year.

title: New York Among 8 States On List for Atom Smasher
description: Eight states, including New York, have been chosen as finalists in an intense national competition to build and operate a giant $4.4 billion atom smasher, a selection committee announced today.

description: At least 30 people were injured today in clashes with the police during an eight-hour nationwide strike called by the opposition to demand the removal of President H. M. Ershad, witnesses said.

description: Opponents of the death penalty, who are usually on the losing end of judicial and legislative battles, are looking back at what they regard as a generally successful year on Capitol Hill. title: Pennzoil May Seek An Oil Deal
description: The Pennzoil Company appears to be leaning toward a major acquisition in the oil industry as the best way to use the $3 billion settlement it will receive next year from Texaco Inc., according to a letter that Pennzoil's chairman and chief executive sent to shareholders last week.

title: Dow Falls 16.08 Points on Slow Day
description: Stock prices fell again yesterday in lackluster year-end trading, and some Wall Street experts attributed the decline to the dollar's weakness and tax-related selling.

title: Koreans to Lift Auto Exports
description: South Korea's three main auto companies said today that they plan to increase exports by 23.4 percent next year. The companies' 1988 export targets total 679,000 vehicles, mostly small cars, up from 550,000 vehicles in 1987.

title: Patrick Bissell, Dancer, Is Dead; A Principal With Ballet Theater
description: Patrick Bissell, a leading principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, was found dead yesterday morning in his apartment in Hoboken, N.J. He was 30 years old.

title: Boesky In New Venture: An Auction at His Office
description: Ivan F. Boesky was not there, but many of the 100 or so people could still feel his presence in the Manhattan office where he once conducted billion-dollar deals.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Increase
description: Prices of Treasury issues advanced yesterday, largely because of an unexpected rise in institutional buying that persisted well into the trading session. Dealers said these buyers were encouraged that the central banks in the major industrial nations had intervened to support the dollar.

title: The Paris Opera Is Abuzz, Literally
description: While singers strive in the rehearsal rooms of the Paris Opera for the fabled honeyed tones, there's a lot of humming-along on the roof, where Jean Pocton's 10,000 worker bees create gallons of honey every year.

title: Bus Routes Cut 10% as Service Is Re-examined
description: A Transit Authority program to revise service on all 200 of New York City's local bus routes, some of which have not been studied for decades, is resulting in schedule reductions averaging about 10 percent.

title: Advances; New Efforts To Foil Food Tampering
description: WHEN seven people in the Chicago area died in 1982 because they swallowed Tylenol capsules that had been laced with cyanide, the United States entered a new era of product tampering.

title: Brooklyn Man Surrenders In Transit Police Burglary
description: A 24-year-old self-described crack user walked into the 84th Precinct station house in downtown Brooklyn yesterday morning, said that his conscience was bothering him and confessed to burglarizing the headquarters of the Transit Authority police early Christmas day, the police said.

title: The Wrong Response to Holtzman
description: Not content to clear Judge Irving W. Levine of the New York State Supreme Court of charges that he participated in the humiliation of an alleged rape victim, the Chief Administrative Judge, Albert M. Rosenblatt, has filed countercharges against the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman. Her alleged offense: making false accusations against a judge.

title: Sir Melford Stevenson, A Judge and Barrister
description: Sir Melford Stevenson, an outspoken judge who as a lawyer defended the last woman to be hanged in Britain, died of a heart attack Saturday. He was 85 years old.

title: Sihanouk Says Talks Must Be in North Korea
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leading Cambodian rebel figure, said today that he would hold peace talks only in North Korea. The statement appeared to rule out a meeting scheduled next month in France.

title: The Pointing of Fingers And the Bay of Pigs
description: More than a quarter-century after Cuban exiles tried to invade their native island by landing at the Bay of Pigs, Americans are still fighting over responsibility for the fiasco.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: THE new year has come early to Seattle this year, with restaurants opening like so many corks popping from champagne bottles; this is after a summer notable more for the absence of some restaurants than for any great culinary excitement.

description: A survey of 114 members of Congress has found that about a fifth of them acknowledge that political contributions have affected their votes on legislation.

description: With campus protests having dropped to a murmur, fewer colleges are unloading their stocks in companies with South African operations.

description: The major American broadcast networks, which plan a New Year's Day schedule of parades and football games, may not broadcast the video greetings exchanged between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, but a satellite news service will transmit the speeches to more than 900 local television stations across the country.

title: Tax Policies That Aren't Doing the Job Against Budget Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Surgery for Golic
description: If the Cleveland Browns make it to the Super Bowl, they will have to do it without Bob Golic, their All-Pro nose tackle. Golic underwent surgery yesterday on his broken right arm and probably will not recuperate for about six weeks, the team's physician said. The Super Bowl game will be played Jan. 31.

title: Georgia Rallies to Top Arkansas, 20-17
description: John Kasay, a freshman who had missed two field-goal attempts, connected from 39 yards as time expired tonight to give Georgia a 20-17 come-from-behind victory over Arkansas in the Liberty Bowl.

description: Sixteen years of Republican control of Suffolk County ends Friday as a Democrat, Patrick G. Halpin, moves into the County Executive's office.

description: AT the local fish market I have been impressed lately by the supply of ready-to-cook skate, a fish that just a few years ago was rarely found outside seafood restaurants.

title: LIFE IN THE 30'S
description: WHEN I was growing up the Italian word melanzana had two meanings.

title: Aaron Rubin, Ex-TV Executive, 72
description: Aaron Rubin, a former executive vice president and chief financial officer of NBC, died of a heart attack Dec. 23 at his home in Lake Worth, Fla. He was 72 years old, and also had a home in Brookville, L.I.

title: MacPhersn Finds Sugar Bowl Sweet
description: A bowl game is college football's equivalent of a corporate convention, mixing business and pleasure. That mix, however, is not necessarily the same for all teams. While Auburn, under Pat Dye, has become accustomed to receiving postseason invitations, Syracuse is treating the Sugar Bowl as an adventure. And perhaps no one is more caught up in the whirl of events than Dick MacPherson, the silver-haired coach of the Orangemen.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Doctors say that Laffit Pincay, who broke vertebrae in a spill at Santa Anita Sunday, will be sidelined at least a month. Pincay was unseated just as he and a 2-year-old filly, May First, left the gate in the third race. . . . Mike Jones, Auburn's leading scorer and rebounder this season with averages of 21.9 and 10.0, has been declared academically inelgible and will concentrate on a pro career in Europe, according to Coach Sonny Smith. ''The news didn't catch any of us by surprise,'' Smith said of his 6-foot-7-inch forward. ''Mike's been one of those guys who's struggled every quarter and it always came down to the wire.'' . . . Willie Jeffries, one of the people interviewed for the head football coaching job at Ohio State, has signed a new long-term contract with Howard University, where his teams have compiled a 23-19 record in four years. This season's team finished with a 9-1 mark. . . . Charles Andrews, a wide receiver and tailback on the Northeast Louisiana team that won the Division I-AA championship, suffered a cerebal hemorrhage and was in critical condition at St. Francis Medical Center in Monroe, La. . . . The Minnesota Vikings announced that Tommy Kramer and not Wade Wilson would start at quarterback Sunday in New Orleans when the Vikings play the Saints in a National Football Conference wildcard playoff game. Coach Jerry Burns said he made the decision after watching Kramer practice.

title: Treasures In the Ashes
description: HE'S 73 years old, but his hair is still more the reddish shade of a basketball than gray. And as the new year approaches, Frank McGuire is planning his new home. After it's built among the pine trees of Columbia, S.C., this New York Irishman everybody still calls Coach will sit with his wife, Jane, and his son, Frankie, and watch television or entertain friends. But the new house won't ever be the same as the big white ranch home that exploded into flames two weeks ago, leaving his treasures in ashes.

title: Iran Plane Crash Kills 6
description: Six people were killed and several injured today when a plane on a training flight crashed into a residential area of Teheran, the official Iranian press agency reported. The agency said it was not known whether the pilot was among those killed and gave no further details.

title: Market Place; Focus on Profits In '88 Stock Hunt
description: WITH 1987 about to exit as a disquieting investment year, market professionals are mulling over their candidates for favored stocks in 1988. One general theme running through these choices is the prospect for increased earnings during the next two years.

title: NEW WAY OFFERED TO RELIEVE CRISIS IN 3D WORLD DEBT
description: Prospects for relief in the third-world debt crisis brightened yesterday with an innovative proposal in which banks would forgive billions of dollars of Mexican debt in return for bonds of lesser value issued by Mexico. The bonds would be backed by United States Treasury bonds bought by Mexico.

description: Pope John Paul II has appointed an Arab priest who was born in Nazareth to be Patriarch of Jerusalem for Latin Rite Catholics.

description: The Nets lost the man called Pearl early in the game tonight, then their game lost its luster and they suffered another one-sided defeat.

title: DATA PUT FLORIDA 4TH IN POPULATION
description: Florida has supplanted Pennsylvania as the fourth most populous state, behind California, New York and Texas, the Census Bureau said today.

title: Dorrance Sexton, Executive, 76
description: Dorrance Sexton, former chairman and chief executive officer of the international insurance firm Johnson & Higgins, died Saturday in the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Ballet: Kirov 'Corsaire' in Paris
description: ''Le Corsaire'' is a three-act ballet whose title is more famous than its choreography. For the thousands who were dazzled by Rudolf Nureyev and Dame Margot Fonteyn in the 1960's and 1970's, ''Le Corsaire'' meant only the pas de deux that became their celebrated signature piece.

title: Corrections
