Beginning Jan. 1, 1988, buerre blanc shall never again pass your lips; you will throw yourself on your sword before tasting a morsel of foie gras, and if you are ever tempted to drink more than a single glass of wine at dinner, you have given your nearest and dearest permission to wrest it from your grasp.

title: Harold Haydn Clum, Professor, 93
description: Dr. Harold Haydn Clum, who retired as professor of biology at Hunter College in 1962 after 35 years on the faculty, died Dec. 14 at Northern Westchester Hospital Center. He was 93 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: About New York; Intense Nights In a Cold Shanty On Sixth Street
description: Delia Torres and her husband, Michael Cruzado, and their friend Randy Semiday were sitting quietly in the plywood and tin tumbledown shack that Ms. Torres and Mr. Cruzado share on 6th Street near the corner of Avenue C on the Lower East Side. Outside, snow was on the wind. Inside, a cat from a grab bag of forebears prowled the corners of the heatless hut.

title: New Orleans Journal; After Two Decades, Losing Season Ends
description: There is no longer any doubt: The party wasn't waning, it was just waiting for a winner.

title: Shearson Is Revising Hutton Offer
description: Seeking to remove the legal and other obstacles to its acquisition of the E.F. Hutton Group, Shearson Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it was raising the cash portion of its bid, lowering the debt portion and sweetening the terms on the debt.

title: CATHOLIC LEADER REBUTS O'CONNOR ON CONDOM ISSUE
description: The president of the United States Catholic Conference insisted yesterday that the nation's Roman Catholic bishops stood by a policy paper that gave qualified support for teaching about condoms in AIDS education programs.

title: Emery Air Freight Chairman Retires
description: The son of the founder of the Emery Air Freight Corporation announced his retirement as chairman and chief executive yesterday, and he was replaced by a board member who had never worked for the company. No reasons were given for the unexpected moves.

title: Advertising; New Marketing Firm
description: Next week Stephen A. Douglas, who has been a researcher for both U.S. News & World Report and Newsweek, will open the Douglas Group, a marketing consulting firm at 88 Bleecker Street, near Broadway. It will offer magazine research and marketing services.

title: REAGAN AIDE SAYS MOSCOW OPPOSES 'STAR WARS' TESTS
description: President Reagan's national security adviser made it clear in a letter distributed today that the Soviet Union had reserved the right to abandon a proposed arms-reduction accord if the United States tested ''Star Wars'' components in space.

title: Real Estate; New Projects Take Shape In Norwalk
description: LIKE many other aging cities of the Northeast in the last few decades, Norwalk has seen its downtown wither, primarily as a result of competition from shopping malls and suburban office parks.

title: The Energized Cereal Industry
description: AFTER a period of stagnation that began in the 1970's and lasted into this decade, the ready-to-eat breakfast cereal industry is enjoying a renaissance aided by consumer interest in nutrition and changing technology.

title: Noye M. Johnson Dies; Acid Rain Researcher
description: Noye Monroe Johnson, a Dartmouth College geology professor who did early research on acid rain, died of cancer at his home here Sunday, school officials said Monday. He was 57 years old.

title: A New Year's Day of Television, Football and Food
description: LEAD: YES, yes. We know. The Russian chap with the broad smile and ready handshake was here recently and it was very exciting. But he and his wife have gone back to the Soviet Union and now there are pressing domestic concerns to mull. New Year's Day is around the corner, and if we don't do something fast, it's going to be tear-open-the-corn-chip-bag-and-mix-the-s our-cream-with-onion-powder time.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cincinnati Bell Information Systems, a unit of Cincinnati Bell Inc., named Richard A. Licursi president.

title: Advertising; P.& G. Picks Grey
description: As was expected, Procter & Gamble is switching its Pantene line of hair-care products from FCB/Leber Katz Partners to Grey Advertising, a P.& G. agency. Billings are more than $10 million. The move was expected because FCB/L.K.P. is also the agency for a bunch of Colgate-Palmolive products. One doesn't have Colgate and Procter under the same roof; the same goes for Lever Brothers. P.&G. added the Pantene line to its product list when it acquired Richardson-Vicks, a longtime client of Leber Katz.

title: In Egypt, a Lonely Palestinian Parcel
description: The trouble did not spill over here, but the anger did, and so did the futility.

title: College Basketball; Pitt Rolls to Title Against Alabama
description: Demetreus Gore scored 24 points tonight to lead Pitt to an 87-51 victory over Alabama and the championship of the Citrus Bowl Classic.

title: Fighting Crime and Inflation: New York Gets F.B.I. Chief
description: For his 50th birthday, James M. Fox got something he had always wanted - the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Making 'Wall Street' Look Like Wall Street
description: Kenneth Lipper has always been a dues-paying member of many of Wall Street's most venerable institutions. But lately he has been paying dues to an organization of a different sort: the Screen Actors Guild. Oliver Stone, the award-winning director of ''Platoon,'' hired the 46-year-old investment banker and former Deputy Mayor of New York for finance and economic development as the technical adviser on his latest film, ''Wall Street,'' and Mr. Lipper even landed a bit part.

title: Black Priest Is Criticized By Koch as Anti-Semitic
description: Mayor Koch yesterday sharply criticized remarks by a Roman Catholic priest at a rally Monday in Brooklyn as anti-Semitic and contended that the priest, along with several political allies, was ''exacerbating racial tensions.''

title: 4 Black Men Are Held in Racial Attack on Cabby
description: Four black men were arrested yesterday in what the police said was a racially motivated attack on a white taxicab driver in Washington Heights last Wednesday.

title: Race and the Chancellor Race
description: Should race be a factor in the selection of New York City's next schools chancellor? Of course it should - but it can be only one factor in determining who could function most effectively to rescue the floundering school system.

title: WINE TALK
description: WITS used to refer to a well-known American literary magazine as The New York Review of Each Other's Books because of the tight coterie of writers, editors and publishers who put it out. The London wine trade is like that.

title: Violence Protested in Peru
description: Church bells rang and white doves were released as Peruvians observed a minute's silence today to protest growing political violence that has taken nearly 10,000 lives since 1980.

title: Arab Nations on Gulf Urge Sanctions Against Iran
description: Arab nations of the Persian Gulf, speaking of a ''dangerous escalation'' in hostilities, urged the imposition of sanctions against Iran today to support a United Nations demand for a truce in the war with Iraq.

title: Israeli Vows to Stress Riot Training
description: Israel's army commander said today that his troops would be given more riot training and riot control equipment to deal with Palestinian protests.

title: Hart Meets Deadline for Primary in Illinois
description: Supporters of Gary Hart filed petitions Monday to put his name on the ballot for the Illinois primary, saying they had gathered twice as many signatures as were required.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Time for Hoppin' John

title: Monroe M. Stearns, 74, A Teacher and Writer
description: Monroe M. Stearns, a teacher, writer and editor, died Dec. 17, apparently of a respiratory ailment, at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Robertson Asks Delay on U.S. Funds
description: The Republican Presidential campaign of Pat Robertson asked the Federal Election Commission today for a 30-day delay in dispensing $4.5 million in public matching funds to the campaign.

title: 9 Bodies Found in Arkansas, Lifting Slaying Toll to 16
description: The police discovered nine bodies in a shallow grave and in abandoned cars today outside the rural home of a man who was arrested after a shooting spree here Monday. The bodies brought to 16 the number of slayings linked to the man.

title: Hopes Fall for Oil-Rig Suppliers
description: After three years of staggering losses, executives in the oilfield service industry thought that the worst was finally over last summer. Oil prices went as high as $22 a barrel and exploration for new oil in the United States began to accelerate, increasing the demand for the drilling rigs, casing, pipe and other equipment and services needed to find and produce new reserves.

title: Smorrebrod: Danish Way With Bread
description: SMORREBROD is almost easier to make than to pronounce. This decorative, infinitely varied Danish open-faced sandwich is certainly simple and delicious to eat.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Elizabeth Nickles is joining Warwick Advertising as executive vice president and co-creative director.

title: Gabelli Not Asking For Allegheny Role
description: The New York investor Mario J. Gabelli said that he had ''no plans'' to participate in the management of beleaguered Allegheny International Inc. Mr. Gabelli's statement, contained in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, appears to clear the way for Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a New York brokerage, to obtain representation on the board of the Pittsburgh-based manufacturer of industrial and consumer products.

title: Boxing Notebook; Spinks's Promoter Backed Into a Corner
description: Not long ago, Mickey Duff, the British fight manager and promoter, was recalling the guidance a veteran boxing man gave him when he was just starting out.

title: National Testing: Many Questions
description: If Congress follows through on legislation to set up more systematic national testing of schoolchildren, the country's political and educational leaders will soon find themselves making some important decisions about how to judge the success or failure of American schools.

title: Advertising; Tucker Wayne to Join With Luckie & Forney
description: Tucker Wayne & Company, part of the Atlanta advertising scene for 65 years, and Luckie & Forney Inc., a 34-year-old agency in Birmingham, Ala., have agreed to merge to form Tucker Wayne/Luckie & Company. It will have $125 million in billings, with about two-thirds coming from the Atlanta unit.

title: On the Differences of Species
description: How to tell Democrats from Republicans? Some clues are offered in a new work, ''The Dorsey Dictionary of American Government and Politics,'' by Jay M. Shafritz, a professor in the Graduate School of Public and International Affairs at the University of Pittsburgh.

title: Police Kill Queens Man They Term Disturbed
description: A 39-year-old man said by the police to be emotionally disturbed was shot to death by officers last night on a Queens street when he lunged at them with a knife, the police reported.

title: When Focaccia's Good It's Very Good; When It's Bad It's Oily
description: ''DO you have focaccia?''

title: Kaisertech Chemicals Sale Set
description: Kaisertech Ltd. said today that it had agreed to sell its specialty chemicals business, known as the Harshaw/Filtrol Partnership, to the Engelhard Corporation for $264 million in cash.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Film: 'The Rose King,' By Werner Schroeter
description: WERNER SCHROETER'S ''Rose King,'' opening today at the Film Forum 1, is one of those supposedly avant-garde films that aren't easy to write about without cracking up, but I'll try.

title: Big Reserves For Taiwan
description: The foreign-exchange reserves of Taiwan may grow to as much as $90 billion (United States funds) next year, according to economists.

title: Tremors in Rumania
description: LEAD: Uprisings in Eastern Europe are too rare to be interpreted with confidence, but recent riots in Rumania's second largest city, Brasov, may signal the unraveling of President Nicolae Ceausescu's 23-year reign. In particular, a sharp response by a senior Communist Party leader indicates that important elements in the party elite may share the rioters' discontent.

title: Bridge: Kathie Wei, Venice Winner, Is Goren Personality of Year
description: One of the world championship winners in Jamaica in October had accepted another honor a few days earlier.

title: KEY RATES
Advertising; New Hanson Tabloid On Magazine Industry
description: Hanson Publishing Group of Stamford, Conn., whose titles include Folio: The Magazine for Magazine Management, is coming out with still another publication for the trade. The monthly tabloid, called Publishing News, will cover news in the magazine publishing industry, while Folio comes out with how-to feature articles in the same field. The former will be delivered in the middle of the month and Folio at the start of the month.

title: Bland S. Montenecourt, Professor, 45
description: Bland Symington Montenecourt, a professor of microbiology and a researcher in biotechnology, died of cancer Dec. 19 at St. Luke's Hospital in Bethlehem, Pa. She was 45 years old and lived in Bloomsbury, N.J.

title: Koch Faults McDonald's Packaging
description: Mayor Koch, citing concern over the environment, announced a drive yesterday against one of the most familiar of packaging materials, polystyrene foam.

title: It Seems Like Old Times For the Streaking Flyers
description: In the suburban igloo of sheet metal and cement that serves as the practice facility for the Philadelphia Flyers, several dozen people had gathered outside the team's locker room one morning this week. They dug their hands deep into their pockets, stomped their feet in the furtherance of renewed circulation and tried to look around their own breath, which plumed visibly into the frigid air. The players, they excitedly assured each other, would walk through the doors at the Voorhees, N.J., rink any minute.

title: Firestone Division To Lay Off 1,300
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's Canadian unit will shut its Hamilton, Ontario, plant next month and lay off 1,300 workers because of a shrinking market for its model of tires. Firestone said that unsuccessful talks to sell the unprofitable bias-ply tire facility to the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company of Ohio had scuttled its last chance for survival.

title: Doyenne of Booksellers Is 100
description: On the eve of the New Year, Frances Steloff - one of the most revered booksellers in the United States - turns 100.

title: Anna Sokolow Troupe To Dance at 92d St. Y
description: ''Kurt Weill,'' a new work by the dancer and choreographer Anna Sokolow that is set to music by Kurt Weill, is to have its world premiere on Monday at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: Letter: On Consumer Costs; Sugar's Price Is Lower Than You Think
description: To the Editor:

title: Fugitive Politician Ordered to Serve Prison Term
description: Former State Senator David J. Friedland was ordered today to begin serving a seven-year Federal prison sentence for a 1980 extortion conviction that had prompted him to become first a Federal informer and, later, a high-living, globe-trotting fugitive for 27 months.

title: Sports People; Skier Suspended
description: Kerry Lynch, an American skier living in Denver, has been stripped of his world championship silver medal in the Nordic combined event and has been suspended briefly after admitting he received an improper blood transfusion before competing last February, the United States Ski Association said yesterday.

title: Shuttle Rocket Test Discloses Flaw That Will Delay Scheduled Flight
description: The first space shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster is being delayed because of the failure of a redesigned rocket nozzle component in a recent test firing, the space agency announced yesterday.

title: Advertising; Amid Gains, Wyse Seeks New Blood
description: WYSE ADVERTISING - with Marc A. Wyse as chairman and chief executive and Lois Wyse as president - is doing very nicely, despite the divorce and subsequent remarriages of the principals.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Is Nicaraguan Peasant Militia a Military Threat?; Stop Contra Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Destroys Part of MX Missile Plant and Kills 4
description: A fire today destroyed part of the Morton Thiokol plant in Utah where the first stage of the MX missile is built, killing four workers and threatening to slow production of the Air Force's most powerful nuclear weapon.

title: 'Three Men and a Baby' Is No. 1 at Box Office
description: ''Three Men and a Baby,'' starring Tom Selleck, Steve Guttenberg and Ted Danson, earned $10.3 million over the three-day holiday weekend to win the No. 1 spot for the week at the box office.

title: E.P.A. Sees No Need for New Rules on Oil Wastes
description: The Environmental Protection Agency told Congress today that new Federal regulations governing toxic waste from drilling operations for oil and gas were not needed.

title: Dance: Louis's 'Junk'
description: THERE was wonderful junk on stage Monday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Farm Fresh Holds Acquisition Talks
description: GF Investments Two Inc., a shareholder group including Alex Grass, chairman of the Rite Aid Corporation, said that it had been approached by the senior management of Farm Fresh Inc. about ''a possible negotiated acquisition of the company by GF which could include the participation of the company's management.''

title: For Maker of Cartoons, A Chance to Go Public
description: Sitting at his mother's kitchen table near Los Angeles in 1982, Andy Heyward and a French businessman, Jean Chalopin, developed the idea for a television cartoon series on a crime-solving handyman. After drawing a few sketches, Inspector Gadget was born. The men have since built a powerhouse in television animation.

title: Trump Increases Alexander's Stake
description: Donald J. Trump, the developer, has raised his stake in the Alexander's Inc. retail chain to 21.4 percent. A source close to Mr. Trump said that he was lifting his stake only to bring it to the level held by Interstate Properties Inc., a New Jersey developer.

title: Edward Kleban, 48, 'Chorus Line' Lyricist
description: Edward Kleban, the Tony Award-winning lyricist of ''A Chorus Line,'' died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: The Ideal Curriculum for Madison High
description: t a news conference in Washington yesterday, Secretary of Education William J. Bennett released his dream curriculum for imaginary James Madison High School. He has long spoken out for a curriculum with a stronger academic core, though he has no authority to order one. Elective courses would include band, driver education and shop. SUBJECT: English 1st YEAR: Introduction to literature 2d YEAR: American literature 3d YEAR: British literature 4th YEAR: Introduction to world literature SUBJECT: Social studies 1st YEAR: Western civilization 2d YEAR: American history 3d YEAR: Principles of American democracy; American democracy and the world (one semester each) 4th YEAR: Electives SUBJECT: Mathematics 1st YEAR, 2d YEAR, 3d YEAR: Three years required from among the following courses: Algebra I, plane and solid geometry, Algebra II and trigonometry, statistics and probability (one semester), pre-calculus (one semester) and calculus 4th YEAR: Electives SUBJECT: Science 1st YEAR, 2d YEAR, 3d YEAR: Three years required from among the following courses: Astronomy/geology, biology, chemistry, and physics or principles of technology 4th YEAR: Electives SUBJECT: Foreign language 1st YEAR, 2d YEAR: Two years required in a single language from among offerings determined by local jurisdictions 3d YEAR, 4th YEAR: Electives SUBJECT: Physical education/health 1st YEAR: Physical education/health 2d YEAR: Physical education/health 3d YEAR, 4th YEAR: Electives SUBJECT: Fine arts 1st YEAR: Art history, music history (one semester each) 2d YEAR, 3d YEAR, 4th YEAR: Electives

title: For the New Nannies, Life Begins at 55
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Knicks Finally Get Cheers
description: The announcement that Sidney Green was starting at power forward for the Knicks last night brought boos from the crowd at Madison Square Garden. And after Jerome Kersey scored the Portland Trail Blazers' first 6 points of the game and Kenny Walker replaced Johnny Newman at small forward there were more boos, this time for Walker.

title: 4-Month Sabbatical Refreshes Columbia President
description: Sabbaticals for college presidents are still a relatively new idea. Michael I. Sovern, who has been president of Columbia University for seven years, was on sabbatical for the fall semester. He and his wife, Joan, a sculptor, have spent most of that time in New York City.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1987
description: International A2-6

title: Is Nicaraguan Peasant Militia a Military Threat?
description: To the Editor:

title: Women's Basketball; Top-Ranked Texas Halts Rutgers, 86-75
description: Yulonda Wimbish scored 18 points, and Beverly Williams had 17 to lead top-ranked Texas to an 86-75 victory over Rutgers tonight in the second round of the Orange Bowl Classic.

title: American Economy Is Reported Shifting To Exports to Grow
description: The American economy, long dominated by its free-spending consumers, is rapidly being transformed into one whose growth depends heavily on producing goods for foreign markets.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Minneapolis
description: LEAD: THE Dallas partnership of the chef Stephan Pyles and the front-of-house mastermind John Dayton has brought the Twin Cities not one but two restaurants. Strategically placed in the Conservatory, the sleek new downtown shopping complex in Minneapolis, Tejas, a casual dining spot, and Goodfellow's, its elegant counterpart, are going strong after only eight weeks.

title: 2 Stockholders In Fraud Case
description: Two West German shareholders, charged with fraud, are accused of forcing payments from companies during takeover battles, officials said today.

title: Giants Need Little Tinkering
description: Now that the season's games have been won and lost (mostly lost), Coach Bill Parcells is about to sit down and figure out how to make the Giants winners again. Although the Giants, one season after winning the Super Bowl, fell to 6-9, they do not seem to need an overhaul. Instead, parts need fixing. Help is needed primarily on the offensive line and then on the defensive line and in the secondary.

title: Apex Oil Files For Protection
description: The Apex Oil Company, threatened with foreclosure on a $533 million loan and a liquidation of its assets, has filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: INSIDE
description: 8 Vie for Atom Smasher Eight states, including New York, are finalists in the national competition for the $4.4 billion atom smasher, a selection panel says. Page B7. Slaying on Park Avenue A retired advertising executive was bludgeoned to death in his Park Ave-nue apartment, and his son-in-law was arrested in the slaying. Page B1.

title: Argentines Fight for Orphans of a Dirty War
description: According to Argentine court records, friends of Maj. Norberto Bianco and his wife, Susana, vividly recall the couple's delight when, unable to have children of their own, they adopted a baby girl and then a baby boy in the mid-1970's.

title: A Thai Monk Unlocks a Melody in the Earth
description: In dusty corners of rural Thailand, where people live suspended between the high technology of a newly industrializing nation and the herbs-and-spirits environment of another age, the stranger is apt to come upon unexpected people drawing inspiration from both worlds.

title: Is Nicaraguan Peasant Militia a Mmilitary Threat?; No Soviet Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: Retired Ad Executive Found Slain on Park Ave.
description: A 77-year-old retired advertising executive was found bludgeoned to death yesterday in the apartment on Park Avenue in Manhattan where he lived alone.

title: Dukakis-Backed Health Bill Is Dead for Current Session
description: Legislative leaders said today that there would not be time this session to consider a bill, backed by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, that would make Massachusetts the first state in the nation to guarantee health care insurance for all residents.

title: Soil Removal at Trump Site Draws Concern Over Relics and Wastes
description: A kind of unofficial groundbreaking for Donald J. Trump's Television City development - the removal of 60,000 cubic yards of soil and rubble from the Upper West Side riverfront site - has been greeted by city officials and neighborhood opponents with concern.

title: Seminars on News of 1968
description: Some of the people who made news in 1968 and some of the journalists who were covering them will take part in four days of seminars beginning Jan. 12 at the Mark Goodson Auditorium, 2 Columbus Circle.

title: Gain for Oklahoma's Running Game
description: This is a time for reputations to be made, for the climax of a college football season to produce a news-agency poll champion. New Year's Day, on the college football calendar, is an end, not a beginning. This is no time to start over.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Of course, I'm happy to be back on earth again, to be among friends and comrades, to see all of you.'' - Col. Yuri V. Romanenko, Soviet astronaut, on returning from record-setting 326 days in orbit. [ B7:2. ]

title: AIDS: The End of the Beginning
description: The AIDS epidemic in America is nearing the end of its first phase. The virus is firmly established among homosexual and bisexual men and intravenous drug abusers, and among their regular sexual partners. If, next, it should leak substantially from these groups into the population at large, the epidemic could become self-sustaining. Yet so far, amazingly, despite Washington's extraordinary neglect of the obvious measures of containment, the leakage has been a trickle, not a torrent.

title: Sports People; Harper Reactivated
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers reactivated their outstanding guard, Ron Harper, yesterday and waived Kannard Johnson, a rookie forward. Harper, the Cavaliers' leading scorer with an average of 22.9 points a game last season as a rookie, broke a bone in his left foot and severely sprained his ankle in Cleveland's second game this season. He will be in uniform for the game tonight against Atlanta.

title: Chicago
description: HUNDREDS of volunteers, restaurateurs, chefs and other food professionals have joined in publishing ''Specialties of the House: Great Recipes From Great Chicago Restaurants,'' a collection of 160 recipes from 91 top eating establishments in the metropolitan region. The proceeds will benefit Chicago House, a social-service agency that supplies residences and support for people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: Rum: A Versatile Beverage With a Long, Colorful History
description: LEAD: FOR some people, the word rum conjures visions of pina coladas on Caribbean beaches or buttery concoctions sipped by the fireside at ski lodges. Readers more steeped in history perhaps think of pirates' treasure and of the daily ration of rum given to British sailors during the 18th century.

title: Soaring Copper Market Closely Watched by U.S.
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has intensified its surveillance of the copper market while an impending shortage has sent prices soaring, according to agency officials.

title: Advertising; Record Ad Revenues
description: November advertising revenues for the members of the Publishers Information Bureau were the highest for any month in the history of the organization, $619.3 million, a 12.5 percent gain from November 1986. Ad pages for the month were 16,826, a 7.8 percent increase.

title: Office Pool, 1988
description: What poor prognostication in this space last year; I even predicted the stock market would go down, and of course it has risen a bit since last year-end. This year I resolve to bet my hopes, instead of merely my expectations. 1. Begging the President's pardon, clemency next year will be offered (a) to Messrs. Poindexter, North, Secord and Hakim before any potential indictments; (b) to all the same if convicted, but after November's elections, in the form of sentence commutation rather than pardons; (c) to the Iran-contra quartet plus Michael Deaver at Nancy's insistence; (d) to nobody. 2. The publishing world's political grabber will be (a) ''The Power Game,'' by Hedrick Smith (Random House); (b) ''Buying into America,'' by Susan and Martin Tolchin (Times Books); (c) ''The Politics of Public Management,'' by Philip Heymann (Yale University Press); (d) ''Speaking Out,'' by Larry Speakes (Scribner's); (e) the memoirs of Bud McFarlane (Doubleday). 3. The first head of state to be ousted next year will be (a) Roh Tae Woo of South Korea; (b) Corazon Aquino of the Philippines; (c) Andrei Gromyko of the Soviet Union; (d) Kurt Waldheim of Austria; (e) Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. 4. The economy will (a) muddle along for six months and then drop like a rock; (b) surprise the doomsayers with a rise of the dollar and a surge of the stock market; (c) mystify economists with a drop in the deficit, a drop in interest rates and a drop in the market; (d) be led out of a spring downturn by loose money and a boom in housing starts. 5. Congress will (a) support the contras, complaining all the way; (b) fail to override the President's veto of trade protection; (c) ratify the medium missile treaty with non-killer reservations; (d) all of these. 6. The new detente will be (a) celebrated at a Moscow summit meeting with a strategic arms accord and agreement on Star Wars testing, concurrent with an end to the Soviet war on Afghanistan; (b) advanced on Soviet terms with a long-range missile cut and no linkage to conventional arms reduction, adventurist behavior or human rights; (c) derailed by harsh Soviet military response to a reach for freedom in Eastern Europe; (d) put on hold as Mikhail Gorbachev awaits a new President willing to concede S.D.I. testing. 7. The deal of the year will be (a) the secret compact the Russians made with the Ayatollah to protect Iran in the U.N. in return for no Shiite trouble in the Soviet Union; (b) the informal alliance of Robert Dole, Howard Baker and Warren Rudman that will make life difficult for George Bush; (c) the bargain to be sought by a Wedtech special prosecutor to induce Ed Meese's indicted associates to testify against the Attorney General; (d) the deal to be cut by Jesse Jackson at the Democratic Convention. 8. The surprise of the primary campaign will be (a) Al Haig's success in savaging George Bush on his arms-for-hostages participation; (b) the staying power of Bruce Babbitt and Pat Robertson; (c) Jack Kemp's better-than-expected showing on his issue of subsidized grain sales to the Russians; (d) the last-few-primaries entry of Mario Cuomo to stop Gary Hart. 9. In the brokered Democratic convention, (a) Robert Strauss, matchmaker, will put together Sam Nunn and Paul Simon; (b) Bert Lance, in the Jackson Southern camp, will broker Gary Hart and Bob Strauss; (c) Lane Kirkland, curiously silent amidst the early anti-Hart cacophony, will nevertheless amalgamate Mario Cuomo and Al Gore; (d) there will be no brokerage possible - the winner will be decided in the primaries. 10. At the non-brokered Republican convention, (a) George Bush will choose Jack Kemp as his running mate; (b) Bob Dole will pick Pete du Pont for his V.P.; (c) Jack Kemp will head the ''JK2'' ticket with Jeane Kirkpatrick; (d) Messrs. Bush and Dole will reach a delegate standoff and the brokering Baker boys, Howard and Jim, will make a deal with the combined Kemp-Robertson forces. 11. The big issue of the 1988 general election will be: (a) Who lost NATO? (b) Don't let them take away our prosperity; (c) Throw out the recessionary rascals; (d) Detente is a chimera; (e) What is character and who's got it? (f) Stop the rising tide of sleaze. 12. The next President of the U.S. will be (a) Gary Hart; (b) Jack Kemp; (c) George Bush; (d) Mario Cuomo; (e) someone else.

title: Books of The Times
description: LITERAL MADNESS: Kathy Goes to Haiti, My Death My Life by Pier Paolo Pasolini and Florida. By Kathy Acker. 410 pages. Grove Press. $19.95.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said its de Havilland Aircraft Company would not be profitable again for at least two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a bill in Congress allowing states to raise the speed limit on some highways misstated the origin of the 55-mile limit.

title: Cold Sends Homeless To Shelters
description: Homeless people packed New York City's shelters and transportation centers last night as temperatures plummeted into the teens and gusty winds created wind chills of below zero.

title: Seabrook Utility Asked to Pay Debt
description: A bank representing bondholders became the second financial institution to call in a debt of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the lead owner of the stalled Seabrook nuclear plant. The IBJ Schroder Bank and Trust Company of New York called in three of the utility's debenture issues totaling $275 million and filed suit in Hillsboro County Superior Court late Monday seeking control of the utility's New Hampshire property to compensate for missed interest payments.

title: Kean Forestalls Increase in Tolls On the Parkway
description: Governor Kean today vetoed the proposed budget of the New Jersey Highway Authority, an action that stops, at least for the time being, plans to raise tolls on the Garden State Parkway.

title: New Brazil Inflation Record
description: Brazil's inflation rate soared to a record 365.96 percent in 1987, according to figures released today, easily beating the previous high of 233 percent of 1985. The rate was more than six times last year's 58.60 percent.

title: Nation's Homeless Veterans Battle a New Foe: Defeatism
description: Hundreds of homeless people live in the park behind the sprawling shelter here, where blue tents line the fence and fires flicker all night in steel drums. Tent 31, where Jay Martin lives, is decorated with a small American flag, an ironic reminder of Mr. Martin's war service and his failure to find a way into the mainstream of American life in the 11 years since his return.

title: Hispanic Power in Florida Is Felt Beyond Miami
description: Dr. Silvia Flores lives near the Atlantic ocean in an upper-middle-class section in the northeastern part of this city, the largest city in Broward County. The Mexico-born pediatrician is president of the socially prominent Broward International Women's Club, which she joined in 1977 when her family came to Florida. Her husband, Dr. Jorge Arturo Flores, is a cardiologist.

title: James W. Dye Jr., Executive, 63
description: James W. Dye Jr., executive vice president of the Long Island Lighting Company, died of intestinal cancer Thursday at his home in Oyster Bay, L.I. He was 63 years old.

title: Restaurant Owners Adjusting To the New Immigration Law
description: THE restaurant industry has traditionally been a haven for immigrants, some of them illegal aliens. But restaurants, like other American industries, now must comply with a tough new immigration law. So far, restaurant owners say, the new law has meant, mainly, an increase in paper work and a shortage of workers to fill low-level jobs.

title: Sentences Are Reduced In Polish Priest's Death
description: Four former officials of the Interior Ministry, who were convicted of murdering a priest who supported the Solidarity labor movement, have been given shorter prison sentences, Government officials said today.

title: Islanders Rally for Tie
description: Denis Potvin said he did not know what Pat LaFontaine intended to do with the pass he had forwarded, and LaFontaine confirmed that the strategy behind the game-tying goal was simply one of desperation.

title: G.O.P. Lawyer Battles Request for Party Data
description: The counsel to the Republican State Committee yesterday challenged a subpoena by the New York State Commission on Integrity in Government, contending that the commission is a partisan group that has overstepped its authority in investigating political campaigns rather than governmental corruption.

title: Pop Life
description: Bon Jovi and Bonbons

title: Shut and Open
description: The spending compromise reached by Congress before it recessed for the year requires the State Department to shut down its Office of Public Diplomacy for Latin America and the Caribbean, a center for activity in support of the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Christmas Week in Warsaw: Bright Lights, Black Creche
description: In the crypt of the Capuchin Church along Miodowa Street, children and grown-ups six and seven deep lined a rail to watch a mechanical pageant of Polish history and fun unfold beneath figures of Mary, Joseph and the infant Jesus.

title: XEROX WINS ORDER ON FUNDS FOR HART
description: The Xerox Corporation won a court order today that would seize Federal funds earmarked for Gary Hart's renewed bid for the Presidency. The money would be used to satisfy a debt left over from the Democrat's 1984 campaign.

title: Soviet Astronaut Back With Record
description: Col. Yuri V. Romanenko, the Soviet astronaut, returned home today from the space station Mir, ending a record-breaking 326-day stay in orbit. The marathon mission is expected to provide important new information about the limits of human endurance in space.

title: Richard Koopman, 73; Led Department Stores
description: Richard Koopman, former president of the G. Fox & Company department stores, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Hartford. He was 73 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: Lessons
description: From the top of the campus, Dallas Hall, a red brick and Georgian building with great stone columns, looks down a long boulevard of greensward and live oaks. It is an honest and imposing piece of architecture, the original building here at Southern Methodist University.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1987
description: INTERNATIONAL Prospects for relief in the third-world debt crisis are brighter. Under an innovative proposal, banks would forgive billions of dollars of Mexican debt in return for bonds of lesser value issued by Mexico. The new bonds would be backed by United States Treasury bonds bought by Mexico. If banks around the world accept the proposal, Mexico's foreign bank debt, which now stands at more than $70 billion, could be reduced by as much as $10 billion. [ Page A1. ] THE ECONOMY The American economy is undergoing a change with far-reaching implications. It is becoming more dependent on exports and less on domestic consumption. This shift, in the long run, may resolve the trade deficit problem. In the short run, it appears to be the key to avoiding a recession. [ A1. ] The first space shuttle flight since the Challenger disaster is being delayed because Morton Thiokol engineers discovered that a redesigned rocket nozzle component had failed in recent tests. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Pennzoil appears to be leaning toward a major acquisition in the oil industry as the best way to use the $3 billion settlement it will receive from Texaco. The company also estimates the net value of the settlement before taxes to be more than $2.6 billion because of legal fees and other expenses. [ D1. ] Shearson Lehman Brothers raised the cash portion of its bid for E. F. Hutton, lowering the debt portion and sweetening the terms on the debt, in an effort to remove legal and other obstacles to its acquisition. Shearson's purchase price remains unchanged, however, at $29.25 a share, or a total of $961 million. [ D1. ] The son of Emery Air Freight's founder has retired as chairman and chief executive. He was replaced by a board member who had never worked for the company. No reasons were given for the unexpected moves. [ D1. ] Kaisertech agreed to sell its specialty chemicals business, known as the Harshaw/Filtrol Partnership, to the Engelhard Corporation for $264 million in cash. [ D5. ] The Apex Oil Company has filed for protection from creditors after being threatened with foreclosure on a $533 million loan. [ D5. ] MARKETS Stock prices fell again in lackluster year-end trading. Some Wall Street analysts attributed the decline to the dollar's weakness and tax-related selling. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 16.08 points, to 1,926.89. [ D1. ] Prices of Treasury issues advanced in the credit markets as support for the dollar by central banks encouraged an unexpected number of institutional investors. [ D12. ] The dollar closed lower again in thin trading despite a brief lift provided by central banks' intervention. In New York gold dropped $1.30, to $486.45 an ounce. [ D14. ] Prices of precious metals futures fell in light trading, helped little by the dollar's weakness. [ D14. ] Surveillance of the copper market has been intensified by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission while an impending shortage has sent prices soaring, [ D1. ] An auction of Ivan F. Boesky's office furniture raised only $25,000 for the former arbitrager's firm. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY The breakfast cereal industry is enjoying a renaissance aided by consumer interest in nutrition and the changing technology for processing grain. [ D4. ] Experts want the food industry to introduce new packaging to protect against deliberately tainted food. Advances. [ D4. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Some economists seem worried by a Reagan legacy - internal and external debt - and they fault the Administration for the shifting and unsustainable means by which it has sought to achieve its ends. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Analysts seeking stock candidates for 1988 emphasize the earnings outlook. But they do not always agree. One firm's investment strategist finds Polaroid attractive, for instance, while another firm carries this stock on its ''sell'' list. Market Place. [ D6. ]

title: Jazz: Bill Barron LeaDS Quartet at the Blue Note
description: BILL BARRON belongs to a Philadelphia tenor saxophone tradition that has included Jimmy Heath, John Coltrane and, more recently, Odean Pope. If there's any single characteristic that would justify describing a Philadelphia ''school,'' it's the combination of a formidable technical fluency with the tendency for each player to work out his own system of interval permutations - the improviser as comprehensive music theorist.

title: Results Plus; N.B.A.
description: Rockets 101, Pistons 91: Joe Barry Carroll scored 25 points as the visiting Rockets outscored the Pistons, 15-7, in the final 5 minutes 41 seconds last night to break the Pistons' 10-game winning streak. The loss prevented the Pistons from setting a franchise record for consecutive victories. They had tied the mark set Feb. 12-28, 1986. This latest winning streak was the longest in the league this season. Carroll and Akeem Olajuwon each had 10 points in the third quarter when Houston outscored Detroit, 30-10, to erase a 57-46 halftime lead. Carroll, who was traded earlier in the season with Sleepy Floyd to Houston from Golden State for Ralph Sampson and Steve Harris, tied his season high in scoring. (AP) N.H.L. Nordiques 5, Sabres 1: Peter Stastny scored his 300th career goal and Ron Tugnutt, the Quebec goaltender, won his league debut to lead the Nordiques at home. The victory was the third straight for the Nordiques, who moved into third place in the Adams Division, a point ahead of Buffalo. Tugnutt, who was credited with an assist on Stastny's goal, was promoted a week ago from the Fredericton Express of the American Hockey League, where he had a 13-2-2 record and a 2.79 goals-against average. Besides making some key saves earlier in the game with the Nordiques shorthanded, Tugnutt also stopped Christian Ruuttu on a breakaway in the third period. He made 29 saves over all. Anton Stastny, Jeff Jackson, Alan Haworth and Mike Eagles also scored for Quebec. (AP) Bruins 4, Penguins 4: Chris Dahlquist scored with 3:27 left in the third period last night and Gilles Meloche made 40 saves for the Penguins. Dahlquist fired a 50-foot shot from the left point past Rejean Lemelin, the Boston goaltender, for his second goal of the season. Cam Neely scored his 18th goal at 8:56 of the third period to give the visiting Bruins a 4-3 lead. Boston tied the game, 3-3, in the third period when Rick Middleton scored on a breakaway. (AP) Horse Racing Anniron Wins Ticonderoga: Anniron scored her 13th triumph in 17 career starts when she posted a 3 1/2-length victory yesterday in the Ticonderoga Handicap for New York-bred fillies and mares at Aqueduct. Chase the Dream, who led to the stretch, held to be easily second best in the field of six. Anniron, who carried highweight of 121 pounds under Robbie Davis, went a mile and an eighth on the fast track in 1:52 4/5 to earn $40,560, the winner's share of the gross purse of $67,600 for her owner, William A. Martusewicz. She returned $2.60 for $2 to win. Tennis Paradis Upsets Sukova: Pascal Paradis of France scored a 6-4, 6-3 upset over second-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia yesterday in the second round of the $150,000 Ariadne Classic in Brisbane, Australia. Paradis, ranked 105th in the world, trailed by 0-4 in the first set before beating Sukova in straight sets to advance to a third-round meeting with Masako Yanagi of Japan. Pam Shriver of the United States, seeded first, started slowly in her second-round match against Julie Richardson of New Zealand before winning, 4-6, 6-1, 6-0. Another American, 12th-seeded Betsy Nagelsen, was the only other seeded player to lose, falling to Claudia Porwick of West Germany, 7-6, 7-6. Wendy Turnbull of Australia, seeded sixth, struggled before beating Tina Mochizuki of the United States, 1-6, 6-1, 6-2. (AP) Pozzi Defeats Anger: Gianluca Pozzi of Italy scored a 6-4, 6-3 first-round victory over Matt Anger, seeded eighth, yesterday in the $93,400 South Australian Open in Adelaide. Anger became the fifth seeded player to lose in the first round of the 32-player Grand Prix event. Other winners yesterday included Johan Anderson, a 16-year-old Swedish-born Australian, Barry Moir of South Africa and Joey Rive of the United States. Anderson surprised Alexander Mronz of West Germany, 6-2, 2-6, 6-2, and Moir beat Tom Nijssen of the Netherlands, 6-4, 6-3. Rive defeated Eddie Edwards of South Africa, who won this event two years ago, 6-1, 7-6. (AP) Track and Field Meet Records Set: Two Brooklyn runners, Kevin Russell of Tilden High School and Ian Jones of Nazareth, posted meet records yesterday at the sixth annual Brown University interscholastic meet in the field house on the university's campus in Providence, R.I. Russell finished first in the 500-meter dash in 1 minute 6.88 seconds, and Jones won the 800-meter run in 1:55.0. Two other New York City athletes set meet records in the girls' events. Monifa Taylor of Truman in the Bronx won the 55-meter hurdles in 8.23 seconds and Tilden's sprint medley foursome finished first in 4:13.3. Courtney Finn of Notre Dame, Staten Island, tied the 800-meter mark with a winning time of 2:18.8.

title: Morris and Tigers Reportedly Agree
description: Jack Morris, who created the biggest stir among free agents a year ago, quietly ended his second stab at free agency yesterday by signing a two-year contract with the Detroit Tigers worth about $4 million. The pitcher will earn salaries of $1,988,000 in 1988 and $1,989,000 in 1989.

title: Haiti Deserves a Free Election
description: The junta that destroyed an independent election at gunpoint a month ago hopes to legitimize dictatorship in an electoral travesty scheduled for Jan. 17. Gen. Henri Namphy now demands that voters hand their ballots directly to his soldiers. Candidates representing some 90 percent of the electorate have properly declined to participate under these circumstances, refusing to lend legitimacy to a cynical exercise.

title: Donald Nathan, 62, Movie Trade Executive
description: Donald H. Nathan, a motion picture trade association executive, died yesterday at his home in Wantagh, L.I. He was 62 years old.

title: Chief for a Day
description: Defenders of Wildlife, a Washington-based conservation and animal welfare group, is something of a lion's den for its chief executives, having gone through three presidents in the last five years.

title: TV Review; 'Scared Sexless' On NBC
description: ''SCARED SEXLESS'' is glossy, attractive and inane, even if it does warn at the beginning, ''Parental discretion advised.'' Discretion about what, for goodness' sake? The NBC News report, on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tonight, acts as if it just discovered s-e-x.

title: Strasbourg Journal; Too German for France, Too French for Germany
description: The city's monument to the dead is a marble statue of a grieving mother holding two fallen sons, one killed fighting for the Germans and the other for the French. To say the lovely capital of Alsace has an identity crisis is putting it mildly.

title: New York Had Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about effects of the stock market crash on private schools in New York City gave an outdated address for McBurney. A picture in some editions showed the school's previous location, and the caption also gave the old address. The school moved to 20 West End Avenue last year.

title: A Chef Returns With the Tastes of India
description: THE Princeton Charcuterie Cafe, a five-month-old restaurant, is in that most American of locations, a shopping mall in Princeton, N.J. And Bob Spiegel, the 26-year-old chef, invents American dishes like black and orange striped ravioli filled with pumpkin for Halloween. But an alert diner can also detect a bit of India in his creations, perhaps a hint of coriander and lemon verbena in a chutney, a gastronomic souvenir of a trip he made to India.

title: Many in Haiti, Vowing Vote Boycott, Fear a New Dictatorship Is in Power
description: In a few weeks, Haitians are to have another chance to choose a president, but many Haitians say they are not going to vote. It is clear, they say, that a little less than two years after President Jean-Claude Duvalier fled into exile, a new dictatorship is taking shape.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chocolate Assignment For Grace Executives
description: LEAD: ''It looks like an enormous Hershey bar,'' John Timson, the new president of the Ambrosia Chocolate Company, said of a 10-pound ingot that is undoubtedly the food of the gods. ''It's 3 inches in depth, 12 inches long, 8 inches wide, and would be hard on your teeth, but is very, very edible.''

title: Pop: The Cucumbers, Group From Hoboken
description: MOST pop songs end where romance begins, at the moment when partners pair off. The Cucumbers, a Hoboken band that recently released its second album, pick up the story some time later; with a few diversions, they write about friction and affection within longtime couples. In ''My Boyfriend,'' Deena Shoshkes points out, he ''sings me to sleep/Sometimes it's beautiful/ Sometimes it's too loud.'' The songs are winsome on top, sinewy down below, neatly mirroring the gist of the lyrics. At the Lone Star Cafe on Monday, the Cucumbers showed that after four years of playing clubs, they've got the punch and assurance to capture the tensions behind seeming domestic bliss.

title: Cleveland
description: AT one time, Cleveland had the world's second-largest Hungarian population, right after Budapest. It was a result of the allure of the bituminous coal and the steel industries. And, there being culinary strength in numbers, dozens of Hungarian-style butchers, bakers and family-owned restaurant and strudel shops lined Buckeye Road.

description: A report financed by the New York Stock Exchange concludes that trading in stock-index futures has contributed to excessive speculation in the market and should be curbed.

title: Trading Bright Lights For Rural Life
description: LEAD: FOR most of the years that Martin and Sandy Parker divided their time between a home in Queens and a house in the country, they dreaded the winding down of the weekend.

title: Punishment Sought by V.A. In Death After Test Mix-Up
description: Veterans Administration officials recommended disciplinary action today against 11 hospital workers in the death of a man given the wrong test.

description: The New Year's honor list, which confers on a handful of people the traditional appellations of entry into the English aristocracy, includes a rather striking new life peer: Rabbi Immanuel Jakobovits.

title: Electric Service Extended by L.I.R.R.
description: After decades of dealing with diesel, thousands of Suffolk County commuters are switching to electric this week. Electric trains, that is. As part of the first major extension of its electrified rail system since 1970, the Long Island Rail Road on Monday began replacing diesel-powered trains with faster, quieter electric trains on 18 miles of its Main Line.

description: Alfred W. Roberts, a lawyer who specialized in real-property law, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Mountain Lakes, N.J. He was 76 years old.

title: Texaco Filing Due
description: Texaco Inc. plans to file a disclosure statement today that is expected to detail how the company will finance its reorganization and how it will affect its shareholders. The statement, to be filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court in White Plains, must be approved by Judge Howard Schwartzberg. The document will accompany the ballots sent to shareholders, who must approve Texaco's reorganization plan.

title: MAKERS TO HALT SALES OF VEHICLE
description: The Justice Department announced today that the manufacturers of three-wheel all-terrain vehicles, which have been linked to about 900 deaths in the past five years, had agreed to stop selling them.

description: Jango Edwards is a Detroit native whose lunacy has brought to the sophisticated Paris stage a show that is speedy, fun and irresistibly American.

description: A 32-year-old officer with the rank of general in the tiny army of nominally independent Transkei, the largest of South Africa's black homelands, staged his second coup today in less than four months and installed himself in power.

description: b-Net income The latest year loss includes a pre- tax charge of $1,343,000 from a bankruptcy proceeding of a customer.

description: G.L. (Peter) Alcock Jr., an avid hunter and sportsman, bought a Winchester rifle in 1982. Yesterday, he and the six other investors of the New Haven Arms Company announced that they had completed negotiations for the purchase of the U.S. Repeating Arms Company, the manufacturer of Winchester hunting firearms.

description: Doug Williams was named yesterday as the starting quarterback when the Washington Redskins play their first game Jan. 9 or 10 in the National Football League playoffs.

description: Two Chinese diplomats left the United States last week after they were detained on suspicion of espionage, Reagan Administration officials said today.

description: Rabbi Hershel Matt, a professor at the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College in Philadelphia and at the Academy of Jewish Learning in New York City, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Highland Park, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: Preserving the Past, Studying the Future
description: OF all the months in the year, especially in the colder parts of the country, January has the least horticultural interest. Except for a few heaths, which I admire greatly for their habit of blooming now to lend touches of pink and white to the winter landscape, everything in the garden has gone to sleep.

title: Al Ghourayib Journal; And if the Nile Dries Up, Who Will Feed Egypt?
description: The Nile slides by here like a blessing renewed with each day and night and season's turning. So why, the farmer said, should anyone gainsay such benediction?

description: A three-year struggle to save the Western Union Corporation has come to a successful end.

title: Death at Creedmor: Story of a Failure
description: LEAD: On Dec. 6, Kevin Pace, who was 25 years old, died in Creedmoor Psychiatric Center, an institution in Queens for the mentally ill. New Yorkers must pay heed to this death not only because it involves anguish but also because it reflects two urgent problems confronting the city: the lack of needed services for the homeless and gross malfunctioning of the criminal justice system.

description: LEAD: ARNOLD COPPER walks - often coatless -through miles of auction houses every week.

The company said the latest year loss reflects a $5 million charge related to the financial insolvency of one of its products liability insurance carriers.

title: XEROX FAILS IN BID TO GET HART FUNDS
description: Spurred by the news that Gary Hart had been awarded 1988 Federal matching funds for his reborn Presidential campaign, the Xerox Corporation, one of his numerous unpaid creditors, tried but apparently failed to attach some of the new money to pay bills from 1984.

title: Article 743687 -- No Title
description: Every time the dollar loses another few percent in exchange value against the Japanese yen and German mark it raises the dollar price of a sushi lunch in Tokyo or a hotel room in Frankfurt. But for most Americans, life hasn't changed much since the long slide of the greenback began in 1985. Is there then good reason for the fuss about the dollar?

title: Morgan Bank Outlines Its Mexican Debt Plan
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company yesterday began sending to other banks that have loans to Mexico details of a proposal under which the banks would forgive part of their Mexican debt in return for 20-year Mexican bonds backed by United States Government securities.

title: Coleman Heads Effort To Rescue Pan Am
description: With the collapse of an almost yearlong effort by the Pan Am unions to find a buyer for Pan American World Airways, the initiative to find a way to keep the airline operating has fallen largely on the shoulders of William T. Coleman Jr., a member of the Pan Am Corporation's board and noted Washington lawyer.

description: The Kenyan Government said today that it had jailed the Ugandan priestess who sent her rebel troops into suicide battles against the Ugandan Government.

title: Merck and Stuart Get F.D.A. Backing
description: The Food and Drug Administration has allowed two drug companies to market a new medicine for treating high blood pressure that may be taken only once a day. Merck Sharp & Dohme, a subsidiary of Merck & Company, developed the drug, to be sold under the brand name Prinivil.

title: Why Germany's Growth Is Slow
description: At 2 P.M. on most Saturdays, when Hermann Franzen is required by law to close his porcelain shop on Dusseldorf's fashionable Konigsallee, he ''almost has to push people out of the store,'' he said.

title: Simplistically Blaming Israel
description: LEAD: The trouble with much of the thinking about the Israel-Arab conflict today is that it not only relies on television as a source of information but resembles television coverage itself. Simplistic and superficial, it views the present situation out of the context of history and offers quick fixes without regard to consequences.

title: Three Who Quit at Smith Say College Neglected Minorities
description: Two black administrators and a black professor at Smith College have submitted their resignations, each saying that the private school for women in Northampton, Mass., does not pay enough attention to the concerns of minority people.

title: Kabul Says a Convoy Breaks Siege of a City
description: The Soviet-backed Afghan Government asserted today that a convoy of 155 Government trucks ferrying food and other supplies had reached the besieged city of Khost safely.

To that end, a combination desk calendar and handbook for the next session of Congress, just published by the LTV Corporation, a major military contractor, is likely to come in somewhat handy.

title: Betty Ford Improving
description: Betty Ford, the former first lady, was reported in good condition today at Eisenhower Medical Center here, where she was taken when she began feeling weak after dinner Tuesday, officials said. Mrs. Ford, who underwent heart surgery last month, was ''feeling quite good'' today and was able to sit up, said her secretary, Penny Circle. She did not give details of the 69-year-old Mrs. Ford's condition. She was expected to remain in the hospital a day or two more for observation.

The newspaper carriers received little or no remuneration for their rounds.

title: Hialeah Park Not Ready to Be Scratched
description: There have been recent afternoons at Hialeah Park when it seemed that the flamingos in the infield outnumbered the railbirds in the grandstand. Flamingos and railbirds are both endangered species in Florida these days, as is Hialeah Park itself. All of them, though, look like good bets to escape extinction.

Mr. Grisanti was a founding partner of the consulting firm of Grisanti, Galef & Goldress. Most recently he was chairman of Deutschman & Company.

title: Friends Remember Toscanini
description: So you have a television program about Arturo Toscanini coming up on Channel 13 on Jan. 8 at 9 P.M., and you want to publicize it. So you throw a cocktail party. Which is what Peter Rosen, the show's producer, did Tuesday night at the East Side home of Eric Selch, publisher of Ovation magazine, inviting some musicians who had worked with the Old Man. They were glad to accept. Through the snow and slush came the sopranos Licia Albanese, Jarmila Novotna and Rose Bampton, all stars of the Metropolitan Opera for several decades starting in the 1930's. Vivian Della Chiesa, who worked with Toscanini on some broadcasts, happily reminisced. Robert Merrill, the silken-voiced baritone was there. Gabor Carelli, who was a comprimario at the Met and must have had about 80 roles at least, beamed at the company. He had been in the ''Falstaff'' recording. Walfredo Toscanini, the conductor's grandson, circulated. Several musicians of the NBC Symphony had their say. It was enough to make any opera buff gulp once or twice and look starry-eyed.

title: Results Plus; Racing
description: Buoy Wins Joseph O'Farrell Stakes: Buoy, who was disqualified from a stakes victory in Kentucky last time out, held off Hooting Star by a head yesterday to win the $50,000 Joseph O'Farrell Stakes for 2-year-olds at Hialeah. The winner finished a head in front of Notebook in the Kentucky Jockey Club Stakes at Churchill Downs Nov. 28, but was placed second for interference. Notebook won his next start, the Bongard Stakes at Aqueduct last Saturday, by 18 lengths. Yesterday, Buoy, under Keith Allen, took the lead in midstretch and held off Hooting Star, the 9-5 favorite, who was off poorly. Distinctintentions finished third. Buoy, a son of Blue Ensign and Mop Mop, paid $6 for $2 to win and ran the six furlongs in 1:10 1/5. Buoy is owned by Lois Bollero and trained by her husband, Joe Bollero. Tennis Kohde-Kilsch Advances: Third-seeded Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany advanced to the round of 16 in the $150,000 Ariadne Classic tournament in Brisbane, Australia, with a 6-3, 6-1, triumph yesterday over Anna Maria Fernandez of the United States. Kohde-Kilsch, who had a first-round bye in the Virginia Slims grass-court event, had too much power for her opponent. (AP) Chesnokov Defeats Dyke: Fourth-seeded Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union rallied to beat Brod Dyke of Australia, 6-7, 6-2, 6-4, in the second round of the New Zealand Open. Chesnokov will meet fifth-seeded Tim Wilkison of the United States in the quarterfinals tomorrow. Wilkison defeated Stephen Shaw of Britain, 7-5, 6-3. (AP)

Serious questions have been raised about Septa's management and the safety of its operations, and its future appears badly clouded.

title: Music: Schneider and New York String Orchestra
description: EVEN more than most concerts, the New York String Orchestra's performance at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening posed the eternal half-full, half-empty question. On the one hand, the 60-member ensemble of talented young people drawn from high schools and conservatories around the country performed at an impressive level considering the less than two weeks the group had in which to rehearse. It is Alexander Schneider's considerable accomplishment as the principal organizer and conductor of this annual event to get his players into such good shape while also exploiting their naturally high pitch of excitement.

title: Recycling Christmas Trees
description: YOU can toss your Christmas tree unceremoniously onto the curb once the holidays are over. Or you can cut off the boughs and recycle them, adding instant greenery to the ground around street trees, forlorn window boxes and bare spots in your yard or on a terrace.

title: Tracing Buildings Of the Past
description: LEAD: NEW YORKERS often radiate a smug satisfaction in living in an old building. It's not because older is necessarily better. Maid's rooms and thick walls have to be balanced against radiators that cannot be adjusted and clanging pipes.

title: ROCKET FLAW STIRS QUESTIONS ON PUSH TO LOFT SHUTTLE
description: When a group of engineers with respirators and searchlights crawled into the burned-out hulk of a booster rocket Monday morning, they discovered one of the space agency's worst fears: a new, mysterious flaw in the shuttle's design that would once again stop dead the nation's effort to get into space.

description: From the low foothills west of Denver, Interstate 70 climbs nearly 5,400 feet over the next 46 miles, a twisting, soaring route past sheer rock cliffs and deep mountain valleys, on its way across the Continental Divide.

title: Freedom Bowl; Arizona St. Downs Air Force by 33-28
description: Daniel Ford, Arizona State's junior quarterback, threw for 272 yards, including a 61-yard touchdown to Aaron Cox that capped a 24-point second quarter, as the Sun Devils beat Air Force, 33-28, tonight in the Freedom Bowl.

title: Bank Provision Set
description: The Bank of New England Corporation said it would make a special $90 million provision in the fourth quarter for its loans to troubled developing countries, including Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela. The company said the action should result in a fourth-quarter net income of about $13 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with about $68 million, or 98 cents a share, if the provision were not made.

title: Blacks in Brooklyn Plan Rally to Protest Beatings
description: In a high-spirited gathering in a Brooklyn church late yesterday evening that was a defiant political rally and a heart-warming commemoration, several ministers, leaders of social service organizations and prominent black lawyers called for a march Saturday morning in Brooklyn to protest the beating of two black men this week by a group of white youths.

Grand Met, which makes Smirnoff vodka and other spirits, said it would offer 2,675 francs, or about $495, a share for Martell. The offer values the company at about $685 million.

title: Ballet: Joffrey's 'Nutcracker'
description: ''THE NUTCRACKER'' once again cast its magic spell when the Joffrey Ballet offered the New York premiere of its version of the holiday classic last night at the City Center.

title: Margaret Scolari Barr, a Teacher And Art Historian, Is Dead at 86
description: Margaret Scolari Barr, an art historian and teacher who was the wife and assistant of Alfred H. Barr, the founding director of the Museum of Modern Art, died of cancer of the colon yesterday at New York Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Syracuse's New No. 44 Is Filling the Slot
description: There is usually an element of luck involved when a team wins all its games, many with some last-second heroics that even the most loyal fans thought improbable. When those at Syracuse reflect on the 1987 season, the first image that may come to mind is that of Michael Owens, the sophomore running back, sprinting untouched into the end zone, his 2-point conversion providing the margin of victory against West Virginia on Nov. 21.

title: Crackdown on Baiting Fowl
description: BECAUSE its law enforcement agents believe that waterfowl baiting is on the increase, the United States Fish and Wildlife Service is cracking down on this long-illegal practice.

title: British Aerospace Orders
description: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that it had received orders worth $80 million for two BAe 146 jetliners and six more of its BAe 125-800 business jets. The orders for the 100-seat BAe 146 were from Air U.K. and Druk Air, the national airline of Bhutan, and bring the total orders for the short-haul aircraft to 109. The BAe 125's were ordered by companies in the United States, West Germany and Botswana and bring total orders to 681, of which 108 are for the Series 800.

title: Senator Inouye's Christmas Tree Bauble
description: The United States will provide $8 million of its scarce refugee funds for the year to build parochial schools in France for North African Jews. Only they aren't refugees. Except to Congress and Senator Daniel Inouye, that is, who so labeled them in the pre-adjournment rush to finish the gigantic appropriations bill.

title: Sports People; McEnroe Withdraws
description: John McEnroe said yesterday that he would not play in the Australian Open, the first Grand Slam tennis event of the year. McEnroe said he would pass up the tournament, which begins Jan. 11, because he had aggravated a back injury.

title: The Year In Birdhouses
description: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SEVEN was the year of the birdhouse and the bird cage. No fly-by-night fads, they abounded at decorator show houses and antiques shows.

title: Freedom To Disagree
description: On the evening of Aug. 22, 1918, copies of two thin leaflets were thrown from the roof of a building on New York's Lower East Side. Unsigned, one printed in English and one in Yiddish, they attacked President Wilson for sending U.S. troops to intervene in revolutionary Russia.

title: Officer Suspended Over Dispute
description: A New York City police officer has been suspended without pay after an argument with other officers in front of her home in Brooklyn early Christmas morning, the police said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1987
description: THE ECONOMY The index of leading indicators fell 1.7 percent in November as stock prices, a component, dropped for the second straight month, the Commerce Department reported. The drop in the index has not been exceeded in more than six years, but most analysts remained confident that the economy would continue to expand, though probably at a slower pace than in the last several months. [ Page D1. ] Sales of new homes edged down 1.2 percent in November as a huge jump in demand in the Northeast was not enough to offset weakness in the rest of the country. The decline in sales was accompanied by a big jump in prices, with the median price of a new home soaring by 12.3 percent, to $119,000. [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL Latin America hailed the proposal to help Mexico reduce its debt. Other debt-burdened nations like Argentina and Brazil hope they can take advantage of a similar plan. [ D3. ] Morgan Guaranty Trust, the primary architect of the proposal, began sending details of the plan to other banks that have made loans to Mexico. Regional banks in the U.S. followed in the footsteps of the nation's biggest banks by praising the proposal. [ D3. ] COMPANIES Western Union will complete its long-sought restructuring. The company said its bondholders had agreed to a debt exchange, the last hurdle in its race to complete its restructuring plan by the end of the year. [ D1. ] Rupert Murdoch will be unable to continue his ownership of The New York Post and The Boston Herald while owning television stations in those cities because of a little-noticed addition to a catchall Federal spending measure. [ A1. ] A judge rejected an application by Gannett and Knight-Ridder to merge the business operations of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, which they own respectively. [ A13. ] Makers of three-wheeled all-terrain vehicles agreed to stop selling them, the Justice Department announced. The vehicles have been linked to 900 deaths in five years. [ A10. ] The Higbee Company is being acquired by the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation and Dillard Department Stores. [ D3. ] Dyncorp has accepted a new offer by its chairman to purchase the military contractor for cash and securities he valued at $23.25 a share, or $246 million. [ D3. ] MARKETS Trading in stock-index futures should be curbed, because it has contributed to excessive speculation in the market, a report financed by the New York Stock Exchange concludes. Among other changes, the report recommended an increase in the amount of cash required to be put up to trade the index futures. [ D1. ] The stock market bounced back with a broad advance on sharply higher volume. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.21 points, to 1,950.10, ending a three-session slide. One of the principal reasons for the rise, analysts said, was the abnormally large premium of stock-index futures over actual averages. [ D4. ] Short-term interest rates fell sharply, as fears of a temporary but sharp upward spike in borrowing costs over the New Year's weekend evaporated. [ D10. ] The dollar was mixed in quiet trading as gold prices fell. In New York, gold dropped $3.05, to $483.40 an ounce. [ D11. ] Livestock and meat futures prices advanced strongly on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. [ D11. ] Yields were mixed for C.D.'s, money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The bankruptcy case of A. H. Robins provides twists on the cliche that timing is everything. Bidding companies face deadlines for legal findings, while Robins is under pressure from shareholders to choose quickly. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] Analysts agree on solid growth for railroads in 1988. Tariff increases are likely, along with lower effective tax rates. Opinion about individual issues varies, however. Market Place. [ D4. ]

description: A fire Tuesday at a group home for mentally ill people that was scheduled to open soon was arson, the Nassau County Fire Marshal's office said today.

title: Metro Matters; Looking Back And Forward In a Leap Second
description: Some of the metro matters that were subjects of this column in 1987 continued to unfold after they were first reported. Today's leap second offers an opportunity to catch up on a few of them.

title: Great Expectations: The Measure of a New Year's Eve
description: TONIGHT is never what I thought it would be. Once you bring expectations to something, how can it live up to them? Those smiles that swim past you from the Waldorf-Astoria always seem camera-ready. And you know somebody's wallet is being picked at Times Square, maybe some kid from New Rochelle who's going to wind up calling her parents from a police station and be told, ''I told you so.''

description: Draped in silver satin and waving a makebelieve torch, 95-year-old Stefania Ludwika Babinski proudly portrayed the Statue of Liberty as she wheeled her chair around her nursing home one recent Halloween.

description: The bad news, folks, as 1987 shuffles off this mortal coil, is that on Jan. 1, 1988, your Social Security payroll taxes are going up again, by an estimated $14 million a year. The good news is that you're about to hear a soft-headed liberal pundit's confession of all-too-frequent error in the old year.

description: Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced today that he was dropping out of the Republican Presidential competition in Iowa, 40 days before the opening round of that state's caucuses.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Jack Morris's agent, Dick Moss, confirmed that the 31-year-old righthander will be pitching for the Detroit Tigers next season. . . . Chris Welp, the Philadelphia 76ers' first-round draft choice, will be out for the rest of the season after undergoing reconstructive surgery on his left knee. The team announced that it did not expect Welp, who averaged 4.8 points in 10 games, to be in uniform again until the middle of next year. . . . Glen Mason, formerly the coach of Kent State, has signed a five-year contract to become football coach at Kansas. Mason succeeds Bob Valesente, who was dismissed after a two-year record of 4-17-1. The 37-year-old Mason became the fourth head coach at Kansas since 1979. He was 12-10 in two seasons at Kent State. . . . The University of South Carolina extended the contract of Joe Morrison, the football coach, for an additional year, through 1992. Morrison's Gamecocks play Louisiana State today in the Gator Bowl.

The company said it was reviewing the petition, filed Tuesday in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of Missouri, and had no further comment. Tom Litz, a lawyer for Toys Plus, said the creditors were seeking approximately $3 million.

title: Police Say Man Wielded Knife And Was Shot
description: A Queens man who was shot and killed by two police officers Tuesday evening was four to five feet away from one and was lunging with a knife when they fired 11 shots at him, the police said The man, Alfred Sanders, 39 years old, of 122-08 Farmers Boulevard, was pronounced dead about an hour later at Mary Immaculate Hospital of multiple gunshot wounds to the stomach region. The shooting occurred at 7 P.M. in front of 218-12 134th Road in Laurelton, the authorities said.

title: Rover Builds More Cars
description: Britain's state-controlled Rover Group P.L.C. says it has built 14.5 percent more cars this year than last, mainly because of demand abroad. Production rose to more than 468,000, from 408,677 in 1986. Last month Rover (once called British Leyland) said it would show a pretax profit for 1987, its first since 1983.

description: ''Are 300 Arabs in Beersheba a provocation? I never said a word against it. All of these liberals, what do they want? Segregation. I am for integration.'' - Ariel Sharon, Israel's Minister of Industry and Trade. [ A1:4. ]

title: Woody Allen Flirts With Chekhov
description: Long before he reaches those sobering final words in the end credits - ''Filmed entirely at Kaufman Astoria Studios in New York'' - Woody Allen abandons any pretense that his new film, ''September,'' is anything other than a one-set play performed before the camera. The play is Chekhovian. We know this because the characters drink only vodka - until the final fade-out, at which point the more mournful women in the household switch to tea. Although the setting is nominally present-day Vermont and the intellectual characters yearn for Paris instead of Moscow, we might as well be in the provincial Russia of long ago. The dowdy antique furnishings of the family estate show few signs of the contemporary (no recent brand-name products, only black dial telephones), and that estate, along with any surrounding orchards, is up for sale to crass moneyed strangers. If there isn't a symbolic sea gull in ''September,'' we do hear about a neighboring town called East Hope. As the author of ''Without Feathers'' knows well, hope, like a sea gull, is the thing with feathers.

title: NEW YORK REOPENS HUNT BY SCHOOLS FOR A CHANCELLOR
description: The Borough Presidents of New York City and the teachers' union, overcoming the opposition of the president of the Board of Education, have forced the board to reconsider three candidates for the job of Schools Chancellor.
